86: PROEM.
87: 
88: 
89: More than three centuries and a half ago, in the mid spring-time of
90: 1492, we are sure that the angel of the dawn, as he travelled with
91: broad slow wing from the Levant to the Pillars of Hercules, and from
92: the summits of the Caucasus across all the snowy Alpine ridges to the
93: dark nakedness of the Western isles, saw nearly the same outline of
94: firm land and unstable sea—saw the same great mountain shadows on the
95: same valleys as he has seen to-day—saw olive mounts, and pine forests,
96: and the broad plains green with young corn or rain-freshened grass—saw
97: the domes and spires of cities rising by the river-sides or mingled
98: with the sedge-like masts on the many-curved sea-coast, in the same
99: spots where they rise to-day. And as the faint light of his course
100: pierced into the dwellings of men, it fell, as now, on the rosy warmth
101: of nestling children; on the haggard waking of sorrow and sickness; on
102: the hasty uprising of the hard-handed labourer; and on the late sleep
103: of the night-student, who had been questioning the stars or the sages,
104: or his own soul, for that hidden knowledge which would break through
105: the barrier of man’s brief life, and show its dark path, that seemed to
106: bend no whither, to be an arc in an immeasurable circle of light and
107: glory. The great river-courses which have shaped the lives of men have
108: hardly changed; and those other streams, the life-currents that ebb and
109: flow in human hearts, pulsate to the same great needs, the same great
110: loves and terrors. As our thought follows close in the slow wake of the
111: dawn, we are impressed with the broad sameness of the human lot, which
112: never alters in the main headings of its history—hunger and labour,
113: seed-time and harvest, love and death.
114: 
115: Even if, instead of following the dim daybreak, our imagination pauses
116: on a certain historical spot and awaits the fuller morning, we may see
117: a world-famous city, which has hardly changed its outline since the
118: days of Columbus, seeming to stand as an almost unviolated symbol,
119: amidst the flux of human things, to remind us that we still resemble
120: the men of the past more than we differ from them, as the great
121: mechanical principles on which those domes and towers were raised must
122: make a likeness in human building that will be broader and deeper than
123: all possible change. And doubtless, if the spirit of a Florentine
124: citizen, whose eyes were closed for the last time while Columbus was
125: still waiting and arguing for the three poor vessels with which he was
126: to set sail from the port of Palos, could return from the shades and
127: pause where our thought is pausing, he would believe that there must
128: still be fellowship and understanding for him among the inheritors of
129: his birthplace.
130: 
131: Let us suppose that such a Shade has been permitted to revisit the
132: glimpses of the golden morning, and is standing once more on the famous
133: hill of San Miniato, which overlooks Florence from the south.
134: 
135: The Spirit is clothed in his habit as he lived: the folds of his
136: well-lined black silk garment or _lucco_ hang in grave unbroken lines
137: from neck to ankle; his plain cloth cap, with its _becchetto_, or long
138: hanging strip of drapery, to serve as a scarf in case of need,
139: surmounts a penetrating face, not, perhaps, very handsome, but with a
140: firm, well-cut mouth, kept distinctly human by a close-shaven lip and
141: chin. It is a face charged with memories of a keen and various life
142: passed below there on the banks of the gleaming river; and as he looks
143: at the scene before him, the sense of familiarity is so much stronger
144: than the perception of change, that he thinks it might be possible to
145: descend once more amongst the streets, and take up that busy life where
146: he left it. For it is not only the mountains and the westward-bending
147: river that he recognises; not only the dark sides of Mount Morello
148: opposite to him, and the long valley of the Arno that seems to stretch
149: its grey low-tufted luxuriance to the far-off ridges of Carrara; and
150: the steep height of Fiesole, with its crown of monastic walls and
151: cypresses; and all the green and grey slopes sprinkled with villas
152: which he can name as he looks at them. He sees other familiar objects
153: much closer to his daily walks. For though he misses the seventy or
154: more towers that once surmounted the walls, and encircled the city as
155: with a regal diadem, his eyes will not dwell on that blank; they are
156: drawn irresistibly to the unique tower springing, like a tall
157: flower-stem drawn towards the sun, from the square turreted mass of the
158: Old Palace in the very heart of the city—the tower that looks none the
159: worse for the four centuries that have passed since he used to walk
160: under it. The great dome, too, greatest in the world, which, in his
161: early boyhood, had been only a daring thought in the mind of a small,
162: quick-eyed man—there it raises its large curves still, eclipsing the
163: hills. And the well-known bell-towers—Giotto’s, with its distant hint
164: of rich colour, and the graceful-spired Badia, and the rest—he looked
165: at them all from the shoulder of his nurse.
166: 
167: “Surely,” he thinks, “Florence can still ring her bells with the solemn
168: hammer-sound that used to beat on the hearts of her citizens and strike
169: out the fire there. And here, on the right, stands the long dark mass
170: of Santa Croce, where we buried our famous dead, laying the laurel on
171: their cold brows and fanning them with the breath of praise and of
172: banners. But Santa Croce had no spire then: we Florentines were too
173: full of great building projects to carry them all out in stone and
174: marble; we had our frescoes and our shrines to pay for, not to speak of
175: rapacious condottieri, bribed royalty, and purchased territories, and
176: our façades and spires must needs wait. But what architect can the
177: Frati Minori (the Franciscans) have employed to build that spire for
178: them? If it had been built in my day, Filippo Brunelleschi or
179: Michelozzo would have devised something of another fashion than
180: that—something worthy to crown the church of Arnolfo.”
181: 
182: At this the Spirit, with a sigh, lets his eyes travel on to the city
183: walls, and now he dwells on the change there with wonder at these
184: modern times. Why have five out of the eleven convenient gates been
185: closed? And why, above all, should the towers have been levelled that
186: were once a glory and defence? Is the world become so peaceful, then,
187: and do Florentines dwell in such harmony, that there are no longer
188: conspiracies to bring ambitious exiles home again with armed bands at
189: their back? These are difficult questions: it is easier and pleasanter
190: to recognise the old than to account for the new. And there flows Arno,
191: with its bridges just where they used to be—the Ponte Vecchio, least
192: like other bridges in the world, laden with the same quaint shops where
193: our Spirit remembers lingering a little on his way perhaps to look at
194: the progress of that great palace which Messer Luca Pitti had set
195: a-building with huge stones got from the Hill of Bogoli (now Boboli)
196: close behind, or perhaps to transact a little business with the
197: cloth-dressers in Oltrarno. The exorbitant line of the Pitti roof is
198: hidden from San Miniato; but the yearning of the old Florentine is not
199: to see Messer Luca’s too ambitious palace which he built unto himself;
200: it is to be down among those narrow streets and busy humming Piazze
201: where he inherited the eager life of his fathers. Is not the anxious
202: voting with black and white beans still going on down there? Who are
203: the Priori in these months, eating soberly-regulated official dinners
204: in the Palazzo Vecchio, with removes of tripe and boiled partridges,
205: seasoned by practical jokes against the ill-fated butt among those
206: potent signors? Are not the significant banners still hung from the
207: windows—still distributed with decent pomp under Orcagna’s Loggia every
208: two months?
209: 
210: Life had its zest for the old Florentine when he, too, trod the marble
211: steps and shared in those dignities. His politics had an area as wide
212: as his trade, which stretched from Syria to Britain, but they had also
213: the passionate intensity, and the detailed practical interest, which
214: could belong only to a narrow scene of corporate action; only to the
215: members of a community shut in close by the hills and by walls of six
216: miles’ circuit, where men knew each other as they passed in the street,
217: set their eyes every day on the memorials of their commonwealth, and
218: were conscious of having not simply the right to vote, but the chance
219: of being voted for. He loved his honours and his gains, the business of
220: his counting-house, of his guild, of the public council-chamber; he
221: loved his enmities too, and fingered the white bean which was to keep a
222: hated name out of the _borsa_ with more complacency than if it had been
223: a golden florin. He loved to strengthen his family by a good alliance,
224: and went home with a triumphant light in his eyes after concluding a
225: satisfactory marriage for his son or daughter under his favourite
226: loggia in the evening cool; he loved his game at chess under that same
227: loggia, and his biting jest, and even his coarse joke, as not beneath
228: the dignity of a man eligible for the highest magistracy. He had gained
229: an insight into all sorts of affairs at home and abroad: he had been of
230: the “Ten” who managed the war department, of the “Eight” who attended
231: to home discipline, of the Priori or Signori who were the heads of the
232: executive government; he had even risen to the supreme office of
233: Gonfaloniere; he had made one in embassies to the Pope and to the
234: Venetians; and he had been commissary to the hired army of the
235: Republic, directing the inglorious bloodless battles in which no man
236: died of brave breast wounds—_virtuosi colpi_—but only of casual falls
237: and tramplings. And in this way he had learned to distrust men without
238: bitterness; looking on life mainly as a game of skill, but not dead to
239: traditions of heroism and clean-handed honour. For the human soul is
240: hospitable, and will entertain conflicting sentiments and contradictory
241: opinions with much impartiality. It was his pride besides, that he was
242: duly tinctured with the learning of his age, and judged not altogether
243: with the vulgar, but in harmony with the ancients: he, too, in his
244: prime, had been eager for the most correct manuscripts, and had paid
245: many florins for antique vases and for disinterred busts of the ancient
246: immortals—some, perhaps, _truncis naribus_, wanting as to the nose, but
247: not the less authentic; and in his old age he had made haste to look at
248: the first sheets of that fine Homer which was among the early glories
249: of the Florentine press. But he had not, for all that, neglected to
250: hang up a waxen image or double of himself under the protection of the
251: Madonna Annunziata, or to do penance for his sins in large gifts to the
252: shrines of saints whose lives had not been modelled on the study of the
253: classics; he had not even neglected making liberal bequests towards
254: buildings for the Frati, against whom he had levelled many a jest.
255: 
256: For the Unseen Powers were mighty. Who knew—who was sure—that there was
257: _any_ name given to them behind which there was no angry force to be
258: appeased, no intercessory pity to be won? Were not gems medicinal,
259: though they only pressed the finger? Were not all things charged with
260: occult virtues? Lucretius might be right—he was an ancient, and a great
261: poet; Luigi Pulci, too, who was suspected of not believing anything
262: from the roof upward (_dal tetto in su_), had very much the air of
263: being right over the supper-table, when the wine and jests were
264: circulating fast, though he was only a poet in the vulgar tongue. There
265: were even learned personages who maintained that Aristotle, wisest of
266: men (unless, indeed, Plato were wiser?) was a thoroughly irreligious
267: philosopher; and a liberal scholar must entertain all speculations. But
268: the negatives might, after all, prove false; nay, seemed manifestly
269: false, as the circling hours swept past him, and turned round with
270: graver faces. For had not the world become Christian? Had he not been
271: baptised in San Giovanni, where the dome is awful with symbols of
272: coming judgment, and where the altar bears a crucified Image disturbing
273: to perfect complacency in one’s self and the world? Our resuscitated
274: Spirit was not a pagan philosopher, nor a philosophising pagan poet,
275: but a man of the fifteenth century, inheriting its strange web of
276: belief and unbelief; of Epicurean levity and fetichistic dread; of
277: pedantic impossible ethics uttered by rote, and crude passions acted
278: out with childish impulsiveness; of inclination towards a
279: self-indulgent paganism, and inevitable subjection to that human
280: conscience which, in the unrest of a new growth, was rilling the air
281: with strange prophecies and presentiments.
282: 
283: He had smiled, perhaps, and shaken his head dubiously, as he heard
284: simple folk talk of a Pope Angelico, who was to come by-and-by and
285: bring in a new order of things, to purify the Church from simony, and
286: the lives of the clergy from scandal—a state of affairs too different
287: from what existed under Innocent the Eighth for a shrewd merchant and
288: politician to regard the prospect as worthy of entering into his
289: calculations. But he felt the evils of the time, nevertheless; for he
290: was a man of public spirit, and public spirit can never be wholly
291: immoral, since its essence is care for a common good. That very
292: Quaresima or Lent of 1492 in which he died, still in his erect old age,
293: he had listened in San Lorenzo, not without a mixture of satisfaction,
294: to the preaching of a Dominican Friar, named Girolamo Savonarola, who
295: denounced with a rare boldness the worldliness and vicious habits of
296: the clergy, and insisted on the duty of Christian men not to live for
297: their own ease when wrong was triumphing in high places, and not to
298: spend their wealth in outward pomp even in the churches, when their
299: fellow-citizens were suffering from want and sickness. The Frate
300: carried his doctrine rather too far for elderly ears; yet it was a
301: memorable thing to see a preacher move his audience to such a pitch
302: that the women even took off their ornaments, and delivered them up to
303: be sold for the benefit of the needy.
304: 
305: “He was a noteworthy man, that Prior of San Marco,” thinks our Spirit;
306: “somewhat arrogant and extreme, perhaps, especially in his
307: denunciations of speedy vengeance. Ah, _Iddio non paga il Sabatol_
308: (‘God does not pay on a Saturday’)—the wages of men’s sins often linger
309: in their payment, and I myself saw much established wickedness of
310: long-standing prosperity. But a Frate Predicatore who wanted to move
311: the people—how could he be moderate? He might have been a little less
312: defiant and curt, though, to Lorenzo de’ Medici, whose family had been
313: the very makers of San Marco: was that quarrel ever made up? And our
314: Lorenzo himself, with the dim outward eyes and the subtle inward
315: vision, did he get over that illness at Careggi? It was but a sad,
316: uneasy-looking face that he would carry out of the world which had
317: given him so much, and there were strong suspicions that his handsome
318: son would play the part of Rehoboam. How has it all turned out? Which
319: party is likely to be banished and have its houses sacked just now? Is
320: there any successor of the incomparable Lorenzo, to whom the great Turk
321: is so gracious as to send over presents of rare animals, rare relics,
322: rare manuscripts, or fugitive enemies, suited to the tastes of a
323: Christian Magnifico who is at once lettered and devout—and also
324: slightly vindictive? And what famous scholar is dictating the Latin
325: letters of the Republic—what fiery philosopher is lecturing on Dante in
326: the Duomo, and going home to write bitter invectives against the father
327: and mother of the bad critic who may have found fault with his
328: classical spelling? Are our wiser heads leaning towards alliance with
329: the Pope and the Regno (The name given to Naples by way of distinction
330: among the Italian States), or are they rather inclining their ears to
331: the orators of France and of Milan?
332: 
333: “There is knowledge of these things to be had in the streets below, on
334: the beloved _marmi_ in front of the churches, and under the sheltering
335: Loggie, where surely our citizens have still their gossip and debates,
336: their bitter and merry jests as of old. For are not the well-remembered
337: buildings all there? The changes have not been so great in those
338: uncounted years. I will go down and hear—I will tread the familiar
339: pavement, and hear once again the speech of Florentines.”
340: 
341: Go not down, good Spirit! for the changes are great and the speech of
342: Florentines would sound as a riddle in your ears. Or, if you go, mingle
343: with no politicians on the _marmi_, or elsewhere; ask no questions
344: about trade in the Calimara; confuse yourself with no inquiries into
345: scholarship, official or monastic. Only look at the sunlight and
346: shadows on the grand walls that were built solidly, and have endured in
347: their grandeur; look at the faces of the little children, making
348: another sunlight amid the shadows of age; look, if you will, into the
349: churches, and hear the same chants, see the same images as of old—the
350: images of willing anguish for a great end, of beneficent love and
351: ascending glory; see upturned living faces, and lips moving to the old
352: prayers for help. These things have not changed. The sunlight and
353: shadows bring their old beauty and waken the old heart-strains at
354: morning, noon, and eventide; the little children are still the symbol
355: of the eternal marriage between love and duty; and men still yearn for
356: the reign of peace and righteousness—still own _that_ life to be the
357: highest which is a conscious voluntary sacrifice. For the Pope Angelico
358: is not come yet.
359: 
360: 
361: 
362: 
363: CHAPTER I.
364: The Shipwrecked Stranger.
365: 
366: 
367: The Loggia de’ Cerchi stood in the heart of old Florence, within a
368: labyrinth of narrow streets behind the Badia, now rarely threaded by
369: the stranger, unless in a dubious search for a certain severely simple
370: doorplace, bearing this inscription:
371: 
372: 
373: Qui Nacque Il Divino Poeta.
374: 
375: 
376: To the ear of Dante, the same streets rang with the shout and clash of
377: fierce battle between rival families; but in the fifteenth century,
378: they were only noisy with the unhistorical quarrels and broad jests of
379: woolcarders in the cloth-producing quarters of San Martino and Garbo.
380: 
381: Under this loggia, in the early morning of the 9th of April 1492, two
382: men had their eyes fixed on each other: one was stooping slightly, and
383: looking downward with the scrutiny of curiosity; the other, lying on
384: the pavement, was looking upward with the startled gaze of a
385: suddenly-awakened dreamer.
386: 
387: The standing figure was the first to speak. He was a grey-haired,
388: broad-shouldered man, of the type which, in Tuscan phrase, is moulded
389: with the fist and polished with the pickaxe; but the self-important
390: gravity which had written itself out in the deep lines about his brow
391: and mouth seemed intended to correct any contemptuous inferences from
392: the hasty workmanship which Nature had bestowed on his exterior. He had
393: deposited a large well-filled bag, made of skins, on the pavement, and
394: before him hung a pedlar’s basket, garnished partly with small
395: woman’s-ware, such as thread and pins, and partly with fragments of
396: glass, which had probably been taken in exchange for those commodities.
397: 
398: “Young man,” he said, pointing to a ring on the finger of the reclining
399: figure, “when your chin has got a stiffer crop on it, you’ll know
400: better than to take your nap in street-corners with a ring like that on
401: your forefinger. By the holy ’vangels! if it had been anybody but me
402: standing over you two minutes ago—but Bratti Ferravecchi is not the man
403: to steal. The cat couldn’t eat her mouse if she didn’t catch it alive,
404: and Bratti couldn’t relish gain if it had no taste of a bargain. Why,
405: young man, one San Giovanni, three years ago, the Saint sent a dead
406: body in my way—a blind beggar, with his cap well-lined with pieces—but,
407: if you’ll believe me, my stomach turned against the money I’d never
408: bargained for, till it came into my head that San Giovanni owed me the
409: pieces for what I spend yearly at the Festa; besides, I buried the body
410: and paid for a mass—and so I saw it was a fair bargain. But how comes a
411: young man like you, with the face of Messer San Michele, to be sleeping
412: on a stone bed with the wind for a curtain?”
413: 
414: The deep guttural sounds of the speaker were scarcely intelligible to
415: the newly-waked, bewildered listener, but he understood the action of
416: pointing to his ring: he looked down at it, and, with a half-automatic
417: obedience to the warning, took it off and thrust it within his doublet,
418: rising at the same time and stretching himself.
419: 
420: “Your tunic and hose match ill with that jewel, young man,” said
421: Bratti, deliberately. “Anybody might say the saints had sent _you_ a
422: dead body; but if you took the jewels, I hope you buried him—and you
423: can afford a mass or two for him into the bargain.”
424: 
425: Something like a painful thrill appeared to dart through the frame of
426: the listener, and arrest the careless stretching of his arms and chest.
427: For an instant he turned on Bratti with a sharp frown; but he
428: immediately recovered an air of indifference, took off the red
429: Levantine cap which hung like a great purse over his left ear, pushed
430: back his long dark-brown curls, and glancing at his dress, said,
431: smilingly—
432: 
433: “You speak truth, friend: my garments are as weather-stained as an old
434: sail, and they are not old either, only, like an old sail, they have
435: had a sprinkling of the sea as well as the rain. The fact is, I’m a
436: stranger in Florence, and when I came in footsore last night I
437: preferred flinging myself in a corner of this hospitable porch to
438: hunting any longer for a chance hostelry, which might turn out to be a
439: nest of blood-suckers of more sorts than one.”
440: 
441: “A stranger, in good sooth,” said Bratti, “for the words come all
442: melting out of your throat, so that a Christian and a Florentine can’t
443: tell a hook from a hanger. But you’re not from Genoa? More likely from
444: Venice, by the cut of your clothes?”
445: 
446: “At this present moment,” said the stranger, smiling, “it is of less
447: importance where I come from than where I can go to for a mouthful of
448: breakfast. This city of yours turns a grim look on me just here: can
449: you show me the way to a more lively quarter, where I can get a meal
450: and a lodging?”
451: 
452: “That I can,” said Bratti, “and it is your good fortune, young man,
453: that I have happened to be walking in from Rovezzano this morning, and
454: turned out of my way to Mercato Vecchio to say an Ave at the Badia.
455: That, I say, is your good fortune. But it remains to be seen what is my
456: profit in the matter. Nothing for nothing, young man. If I show you the
457: way to Mercato Vecchio, you’ll swear by your patron saint to let me
458: have the bidding for that stained suit of yours, when you set up a
459: better—as doubtless you will.”
460: 
461: “Agreed, by San Niccolò,” said the other, laughing. “But now let us set
462: off to this said Mercato, for I feel the want of a better lining to
463: this doublet of mine which you are coveting.”
464: 
465: “Coveting? Nay,” said Bratti, heaving his bag on his back and setting
466: out. But he broke off in his reply, and burst out in loud, harsh tones,
467: not unlike the creaking and grating of a cart-wheel: “_Chi
468: abbaratta_—_baratta_—_b’ratta_—_chi abbaratta cenci e vetri_—_b’ratta
469: ferri vecchi_?” (“Who wants to exchange rags, broken glass, or old
470: iron?”)
471: 
472: “It’s worth but little,” he said presently, relapsing into his
473: conversational tone. “Hose and altogether, your clothes are worth but
474: little. Still, if you’ve a mind to set yourself up with a lute worth
475: more than any new one, or with a sword that’s been worn by a Ridolfi,
476: or with a paternoster of the best mode, I could let you have a great
477: bargain, by making an allowance for the clothes; for, simple as I stand
478: here, I’ve got the best-furnished shop in the Ferravecchi, and it’s
479: close by the Mercato. The Virgin be praised! it’s not a pumpkin I carry
480: on my shoulders. But I don’t stay caged in my shop all day: I’ve got a
481: wife and a raven to stay at home and mind the stock. _Chi
482: abbaratta_—_baratta_—_b’ratta_? ... And now, young man, where do you
483: come from, and what’s your business in Florence?”
484: 
485: “I thought you liked nothing that came to you without a bargain,” said
486: the stranger. “You’ve offered me nothing yet in exchange for that
487: information.”
488: 
489: “Well, well; a Florentine doesn’t mind bidding a fair price for news:
490: it stays the stomach a little though he may win no hose by it. If I
491: take you to the prettiest damsel in the Mercato to get a cup of
492: milk—that will be a fair bargain.”
493: 
494: “Nay; I can find her myself, if she be really in the Mercato; for
495: pretty heads are apt to look forth of doors and windows. No, no.
496: Besides, a sharp trader, like you, ought to know that he who bids for
497: nuts and news, may chance to find them hollow.”
498: 
499: “Ah! young man,” said Bratti, with a sideway glance of some admiration,
500: “you were not born of a Sunday—the salt-shops were open when you came
501: into the world. You’re not a Hebrew, eh?—come from Spain or Naples, eh?
502: Let me tell you the Frati Minori are trying to make Florence as hot as
503: Spain for those dogs of hell that want to get all the profit of usury
504: to themselves and leave none for Christians; and when you walk the
505: Calimara with a piece of yellow cloth in your cap, it will spoil your
506: beauty more than a sword-cut across that smooth olive cheek of
507: yours.—_Abbaratta, baratta_—_chi abbaratta_?—I tell you, young man,
508: grey cloth is against yellow cloth; and there’s as much grey cloth in
509: Florence as would make a gown and cowl for the Duomo, and there’s not
510: so much yellow cloth as would make hose for Saint Christopher—blessed
511: be his name, and send me a sight of him this day!—_Abbaratta, baratta,
512: b’ratta_—_chi abbaratta_?”
513: 
514: “All that is very amusing information you are parting with for
515: nothing,” said the stranger, rather scornfully; “but it happens not to
516: concern me. I am no Hebrew.”
517: 
518: “See, now!” said Bratti, triumphantly; “I’ve made a good bargain with
519: mere words. I’ve made you tell me something, young man, though you’re
520: as hard to hold as a lamprey. San Giovanni be praised! a blind
521: Florentine is a match for two one-eyed men. But here we are in the
522: Mercato.”
523: 
524: They had now emerged from the narrow streets into a broad piazza, known
525: to the elder Florentine writers as the Mercato Vecchio, or the Old
526: Market. This piazza, though it had been the scene of a provision-market
527: from time immemorial, and may, perhaps, says fond imagination, be the
528: very spot to which the Fesulean ancestors of the Florentines descended
529: from their high fastness to traffic with the rustic population of the
530: valley, had not been shunned as a place of residence by Florentine
531: wealth. In the early decades of the fifteenth century, which was now
532: near its end, the Medici and other powerful families of the _popolani
533: grassi_, or commercial nobility, had their houses there, not perhaps
534: finding their ears much offended by the loud roar of mingled dialects,
535: or their eyes much shocked by the butchers’ stalls, which the old poet
536: Antonio Pucci accounts a chief glory, or _dignita_, of a market that,
537: in his esteem, eclipsed the markets of all the earth beside. But the
538: glory of mutton and veal (well attested to be the flesh of the right
539: animals; for were not the skins, with the heads attached, duly
540: displayed, according to the decree of the Signoria?) was just now
541: wanting to the Mercato, the time of Lent not being yet over. The proud
542: corporation, or “Art,” of butchers was in abeyance, and it was the
543: great harvest-time of the market-gardeners, the cheesemongers, the
544: vendors of macaroni, corn, eggs, milk, and dried fruits: a change which
545: was apt to make the women’s voices predominant in the chorus. But in
546: all seasons there was the experimental ringing of pots and pans, the
547: chinking of the money-changers, the tempting offers of cheapness at the
548: old-clothes stalls, the challenges of the dicers, the vaunting of new
549: linens and woollens, of excellent wooden-ware, kettles, and
550: frying-pans; there was the choking of the narrow inlets with mules and
551: carts, together with much uncomplimentary remonstrance in terms
552: remarkably identical with the insults in use by the gentler sex of the
553: present day, under the same imbrowning and heating circumstances.
554: Ladies and gentlemen, who came to market, looked on at a larger amount
555: of amateur fighting than could easily be seen in these later times, and
556: beheld more revolting rags, beggary, and rascaldom, than modern
557: householders could well picture to themselves. As the day wore on, the
558: hideous drama of the gaming-house might be seen here by any chance
559: open-air spectator—the quivering eagerness, the blank despair, the
560: sobs, the blasphemy, and the blows:—
561: 
562: 
563: “E vedesi chi perde con gran soffi,
564: E bestemmiar colla mano alia mascella,
565: E ricever e dar di molti ingoffi.”
566: 
567: 
568: But still there was the relief of prettier sights: there were
569: brood-rabbits, not less innocent and astonished than those of our own
570: period; there were doves and singing-birds to be bought as presents for
571: the children; there were even kittens for sale, and here and there a
572: handsome _gattuccio_, or “Tom,” with the highest character for mousing;
573: and, better than all, there were young, softly-rounded cheeks and
574: bright eyes, freshened by the start from the far-off castello (walled
575: village) at daybreak, not to speak of older faces with the unfading
576: charm of honest goodwill in them, such as are never quite wanting in
577: scenes of human industry. And high on a pillar in the centre of the
578: place—a venerable pillar, fetched from the church of San Giovanni—stood
579: Donatello’s stone statue of Plenty, with a fountain near it, where,
580: says old Pucci, the good wives of the market freshened their utensils,
581: and their throats also; not because they were unable to buy wine, but
582: because they wished to save the money for their husbands.
583: 
584: But on this particular morning a sudden change seemed to have come over
585: the face of the market. The _deschi_, or stalls, were indeed partly
586: dressed with their various commodities, and already there were
587: purchasers assembled, on the alert to secure the finest, freshest
588: vegetables and the most unexceptionable butter. But when Bratti and his
589: companion entered the piazza, it appeared that some common
590: preoccupation had for the moment distracted the attention both of
591: buyers and sellers from their proper business. Most of the traders had
592: turned their backs on their goods, and had joined the knots of talkers
593: who were concentrating themselves at different points in the piazza. A
594: vendor of old-clothes, in the act of hanging out a pair of long hose,
595: had distractedly hung them round his neck in his eagerness to join the
596: nearest group; an oratorical cheesemonger, with a piece of cheese in
597: one hand and a knife in the other, was incautiously making notes of his
598: emphatic pauses on that excellent specimen of _marzolino_; and elderly
599: market-women, with their egg-baskets in a dangerously oblique position,
600: contributed a wailing fugue of invocation.
601: 
602: In this general distraction, the Florentine boys, who were never
603: wanting in any street scene, and were of an especially mischievous
604: sort—as who should say, very sour crabs indeed—saw a great opportunity.
605: Some made a rush at the nuts and dried figs, others preferred the
606: farinaceous delicacies at the cooked provision stalls—delicacies to
607: which certain four-footed dogs also, who had learned to take kindly to
608: Lenten fare, applied a discriminating nostril, and then disappeared
609: with much rapidity under the nearest shelter; while the mules, not
610: without some kicking and plunging among impeding baskets, were
611: stretching their muzzles towards the aromatic green-meat.
612: 
613: “Diavolo!” said Bratti, as he and his companion came, quite unnoticed,
614: upon the noisy scene; “the Mercato is gone as mad as if the most Holy
615: Father had excommunicated us again. I must know what this is. But never
616: fear: it seems a thousand years to you till you see the pretty Tessa,
617: and get your cup of milk; but keep hold of me, and I’ll hold to my
618: bargain. Remember, I’m to have the first bid for your suit, specially
619: for the hose, which, with all their stains, are the best _panno di
620: garbo_—as good as ruined, though, with mud and weather stains.”
621: 
622: “Ola, Monna Trecca,” Bratti proceeded, turning towards an old woman on
623: the outside of the nearest group, who for the moment had suspended her
624: wail to listen, and shouting close in her ear: “Here are the mules
625: upsetting all your bunches of parsley: is the world coming to an end,
626: then?”
627: 
628: “Monna Trecca” (equivalent to “Dame Greengrocer”) turned round at this
629: unexpected trumpeting in her right ear, with a half-fierce,
630: half-bewildered look, first at the speaker, then at her disarranged
631: commodities, and then at the speaker again.
632: 
633: “A bad Easter and a bad year to you, and may you die by the sword!” she
634: burst out, rushing towards her stall, but directing this first volley
635: of her wrath against Bratti, who, without heeding the malediction,
636: quietly slipped into her place, within hearing of the narrative which
637: had been absorbing her attention; making a sign at the same time to the
638: younger stranger to keep near him.
639: 
640: “I tell you I saw it myself,” said a fat man, with a bunch of
641: newly-purchased leeks in his hand. “I was in Santa Maria Novella, and
642: saw it myself. The woman started up and threw out her arms, and cried
643: out and said she saw a big bull with fiery horns coming down on the
644: church to crush it. I saw it myself.”
645: 
646: “Saw what, Goro?” said a man of slim figure, whose eye twinkled rather
647: roguishly. He wore a close jerkin, a skull-cap lodged carelessly over
648: his left ear as if it had fallen there by chance, a delicate linen
649: apron tucked up on one side, and a razor stuck in his belt. “Saw the
650: bull, or only the woman?”
651: 
652: “Why, the woman, to be sure; but it’s all one, _mi pare_: it doesn’t
653: alter the meaning—_va_!” answered the fat man, with some contempt.
654: 
655: “Meaning? no, no; that’s clear enough,” said several voices at once,
656: and then followed a confusion of tongues, in which “Lights shooting
657: over San Lorenzo for three nights together”—“Thunder in the clear
658: starlight”—“Lantern of the Duomo struck with the sword of Saint
659: Michael”—“_Palle_” (Arms of the Medici)—“All smashed”—“Lions tearing
660: each other to pieces”—“Ah! and they might well”—“_Boto_[1] _caduto in
661: Santissima Nunziata_!”—“Died like the best of Christians”—“God will
662: have pardoned him”—were often-repeated phrases, which shot across each
663: other like storm-driven hailstones, each speaker feeling rather the
664: necessity of utterance than of finding a listener. Perhaps the only
665: silent members of the group were Bratti, who, as a new-comer, was busy
666: in mentally piecing together the flying fragments of information; the
667: man of the razor; and a thin-lipped, eager-looking personage in
668: spectacles, wearing a pen-and-ink case at his belt.
669: 
670:  [1] A votive image of Lorenzo, in wax, hung up in the Church of the
671:  Annunziata, supposed to have fallen at the time of his death. _Boto_
672:  is popular Tuscan for _Voto_.
673: 
674: 
675: “_Ebbene_, Nello,” said Bratti, skirting the group till he was within
676: hearing of the barber. “It appears the Magnifico is dead—rest his
677: soul!—and the price of wax will rise?”
678: 
679: “Even as you say,” answered Nello; and then added, with an air of extra
680: gravity, but with marvellous rapidity, “and his waxen image in the
681: Nunziata fell at the same moment, they say; or at some other time,
682: whenever it pleases the Frati Serviti, who know best. And several cows
683: and women have had still-born calves this Quaresima; and for the bad
684: eggs that have been broken since the Carnival, nobody has counted them.
685: Ah! a great man—a great politician—a greater poet than Dante. And yet
686: the cupola didn’t fall, only the lantern. _Che miracolo_!”
687: 
688: A sharp and lengthened “Pst!” was suddenly heard darting across the
689: pelting storm of gutturals. It came from the pale man in spectacles,
690: and had the effect he intended; for the noise ceased, and all eyes in
691: the group were fixed on him with a look of expectation.
692: 
693: “’Tis well said you Florentines are blind,” he began, in an incisive
694: high voice. “It appears to me, you need nothing but a diet of hay to
695: make cattle of you. What! do you think the death of Lorenzo is the
696: scourge God has prepared for Florence? Go! you are sparrows chattering
697: praise over the dead hawk. What! a man who was trying to slip a noose
698: over every neck in the Republic that he might tighten it at his
699: pleasure! You like that; you like to have the election of your
700: magistrates turned into closet-work, and no man to use the rights of a
701: citizen unless he is a Medicean. That is what is meant by qualification
702: now: _netto di specchio_[2] no longer means that a man pays his dues to
703: the Republic: it means that he’ll wink at robbery of the people’s
704: money—at robbery of their daughters’ dowries; that he’ll play the
705: chamberer and the philosopher by turns—listen to bawdy songs at the
706: Carnival and cry ‘Bellissimi!’—and listen to sacred lauds and cry again
707: ‘Bellissimi!’ But this is what you love: you grumble and raise a riot
708: over your _quattrini bianchi_” (white farthings); “but you take no
709: notice when the public treasury has got a hole in the bottom for the
710: gold to run into Lorenzo’s drains. You like to pay for footmen to walk
711: before and behind one of your citizens, that he may be affable and
712: condescending to you. ‘See, what a tall Pisan we keep,’ say you, ‘to
713: march before him with the drawn sword flashing in our eyes!—and yet
714: Lorenzo smiles at us. What goodness!’ And you think the death of a man,
715: who would soon have saddled and bridled you as the Sforza has saddled
716: and bridled Milan—you think his death is the scourge God is warning you
717: of by portents. I tell you there is another sort of scourge in the
718: air.”
719: 
720:  [2] The phrase used to express the absence of disqualification—i.e.,
721:  the not being entered as a debtor in the public book—_specchio_.
722: 
723: 
724: “Nay, nay, Ser Cioni, keep astride your politics, and never mount your
725: prophecy; politics is the better horse,” said Nello. “But if you talk
726: of portents, what portent can be greater than a pious notary? Balaam’s
727: ass was nothing to it.”
728: 
729: “Ay, but a notary out of work, with his inkbottle dry,” said another
730: bystander, very much out at elbows. “Better don a cowl at once, Ser
731: Cioni: everybody will believe in your fasting.”
732: 
733: The notary turned and left the group with a look of indignant contempt,
734: disclosing, as he did so, the sallow but mild face of a short man who
735: had been standing behind him, and whose bent shoulders told of some
736: sedentary occupation.
737: 
738: “By San Giovanni, though,” said the fat purchaser of leeks, with the
739: air of a person rather shaken in his theories, “I am not sure there
740: isn’t some truth in what Ser Cioni says. For I know I have good reason
741: to find fault with the _quattrini bianchi_ myself. Grumble, did he say?
742: Suffocation! I should think we do grumble; and, let anybody say the
743: word, I’ll turn out into the piazza with the readiest, sooner than have
744: our money altered in our hands as if the magistracy were so many
745: necromancers. And it’s true Lorenzo might have hindered such work if he
746: would—and for the bull with the flaming horns, why, as Ser Cioni says,
747: there may be many meanings to it, for the matter of that; it may have
748: more to do with the taxes than we think. For when God above sends a
749: sign, it’s not to be supposed he’d have only one meaning.”
750: 
751: “Spoken like an oracle, Goro!” said the barber. “Why, when we poor
752: mortals can pack two or three meanings into one sentence, it were mere
753: blasphemy not to believe that your miraculous bull means everything
754: that any man in Florence likes it to mean.”
755: 
756: “Thou art pleased to scoff, Nello,” said the sallow, round-shouldered
757: man, no longer eclipsed by the notary, “but it is not the less true
758: that every revelation, whether by visions, dreams, portents, or the
759: written word, has many meanings, which it is given to the illuminated
760: only to unfold.”
761: 
762: “Assuredly,” answered Nello. “Haven’t I been to hear the Frate in San
763: Lorenzo? But then, I’ve been to hear Fra Menico in the Duomo too; and
764: according to him, your Fra Girolamo, with his visions and
765: interpretations, is running after the wind of Mongibello, and those who
766: follow him are like to have the fate of certain swine that ran headlong
767: into the sea—or some hotter place. With San Domenico roaring _è vero_
768: in one ear, and San Francisco screaming _è falso_ in the other, what is
769: a poor barber to do—unless he were illuminated? But it’s plain our Goro
770: here is beginning to be illuminated for he already sees that the bull
771: with the flaming horns means first himself, and secondly all the other
772: aggrieved taxpayers of Florence, who are determined to gore the
773: magistracy on the first opportunity.”
774: 
775: “Goro is a fool!” said a bass voice, with a note that dropped like the
776: sound of a great bell in the midst of much tinkling. “Let him carry
777: home his leeks and shake his flanks over his wool-beating. He’ll mend
778: matters more that way than by showing his tun-shaped body in the
779: piazza, as if everybody might measure his grievances by the size of his
780: paunch. The burdens that harm him most are his heavy carcass and his
781: idleness.”
782: 
783: The speaker had joined the group only in time to hear the conclusion of
784: Nello’s speech, but he was one of those figures for whom all the world
785: instinctively makes way, as it would for a battering-ram. He was not
786: much above the middle height, but the impression of enormous force
787: which was conveyed by his capacious chest and brawny arms bared to the
788: shoulder, was deepened by the keen sense and quiet resolution expressed
789: in his glance and in every furrow of his cheek and brow. He had often
790: been an unconscious model to Domenico Ghirlandajo, when that great
791: painter was making the walls of the churches reflect the life of
792: Florence, and translating pale aerial traditions into the deep colour
793: and strong lines of the faces he knew. The naturally dark tint of his
794: skin was additionally bronzed by the same powdery deposit that gave a
795: polished black surface to his leathern apron: a deposit which habit had
796: probably made a necessary condition of perfect ease, for it was not
797: washed off with punctilious regularity.
798: 
799: Goro turned his fat cheek and glassy eye on the frank speaker with a
800: look of deprecation rather than of resentment.
801: 
802: “Why, Niccolò,” he said, in an injured tone, “I’ve heard you sing to
803: another tune than that, often enough, when you’ve been laying down the
804: law at San Gallo on a festa. I’ve heard you say yourself, that a man
805: wasn’t a mill-wheel, to be on the grind, grind, as long as he was
806: driven, and then stick in his place without stirring when the water was
807: low. And you’re as fond of your vote as any man in Florence—ay, and
808: I’ve heard you say, if Lorenzo—”
809: 
810: “Yes, yes,” said Niccolò. “Don’t you be bringing up my speeches again
811: after you’ve swallowed them, and handing them about as if they were
812: none the worse. I vote and I speak when there’s any use in it: if
813: there’s hot metal on the anvil, I lose no time before I strike; but I
814: don’t spend good hours in tinkling on cold iron, or in standing on the
815: pavement as thou dost, Goro, with snout upward, like a pig under an
816: oak-tree. And as for Lorenzo—dead and gone before his time—he was a man
817: who had an eye for curious iron-work; and if anybody says he wanted to
818: make himself a tyrant, I say, ‘_Sia_; I’ll not deny which way the wind
819: blows when every man can see the weathercock.’ But that only means that
820: Lorenzo was a crested hawk, and there are plenty of hawks without
821: crests whose claws and beaks are as good for tearing. Though if there
822: was any chance of a real reform, so that Marzocco (the stone Lion,
823: emblem of the Republic) might shake his mane and roar again, instead of
824: dipping his head to lick the feet of anybody that will mount and ride
825: him, I’d strike a good blow for it.”
826: 
827: “And that reform is not far off, Niccolò,” said the sallow, mild-faced
828: man, seizing his opportunity like a missionary among the too
829: light-minded heathens; “for a time of tribulation is coming, and the
830: scourge is at hand. And when the Church is purged of cardinals and
831: prelates who traffic in her inheritance that their hands may be full to
832: pay the price of blood and to satisfy their own lusts, the State will
833: be purged too—and Florence will be purged of men who love to see
834: avarice and lechery under the red hat and the mitre because it gives
835: them the screen of a more hellish vice than their own.”
836: 
837: “Ay, as Goro’s broad body would be a screen for my narrow person in
838: case of missiles,” said Nello; “but if that excellent screen happened
839: to fall, I were stifled under it, surely enough. That is no bad image
840: of thine, Nanni—or, rather, of the Frate’s; for I fancy there is no
841: room in the small cup of thy understanding for any other liquor than
842: what he pours into it.”
843: 
844: “And it were well for thee, Nello,” replied Nanni, “if thou couldst
845: empty thyself of thy scoffs and thy jests, and take in that liquor too.
846: The warning is ringing in the ears of all men: and it’s no new story;
847: for the Abbot Joachim prophesied of the coming time three hundred years
848: ago, and now Fra Girolamo has got the message afresh. He has seen it in
849: a vision, even as the prophets of old: he has seen the sword hanging
850: from the sky.”
851: 
852: “Ay, and thou wilt see it thyself, Nanni, if thou wilt stare upward
853: long enough,” said Niccolò; “for that pitiable tailor’s work of thine
854: makes thy noddle so overhang thy legs, that thy eyeballs can see nought
855: above the stitching-board but the roof of thy own skull.”
856: 
857: The honest tailor bore the jest without bitterness, bent on convincing
858: his hearers of his doctrine rather than of his dignity. But Niccolò
859: gave him no opportunity for replying; for he turned away to the pursuit
860: of his market business, probably considering further dialogue as a
861: tinkling on cold iron.
862: 
863: “_Ebbene_” said the man with the hose round his neck, who had lately
864: migrated from another knot of talkers, “they are safest who cross
865: themselves and jest at nobody. Do you know that the Magnifico sent for
866: the Frate at the last, and couldn’t die without his blessing?”
867: 
868: “Was it so—in truth?” said several voices. “Yes, yes—God will have
869: pardoned him.”
870: 
871: “He died like the best of Christians.”
872: 
873: “Never took his eyes from the holy crucifix.”
874: 
875: “And the Frate will have given him his blessing?”
876: 
877: “Well, I know no more,” said he of the hosen, “only Guccio there met a
878: footman going back to Careggi, and he told him the Frate had been sent
879: for yesternight, after the Magnifico had confessed and had the holy
880: sacraments.”
881: 
882: “It’s likely enough the Frate will tell the people something about it
883: in his sermon this morning; is it not true, Nanni?” said Goro. “What do
884: you think?”
885: 
886: But Nanni had already turned his back on Goro, and the group was
887: rapidly thinning; some being stirred by the impulse to go and hear “new
888: things” from the Frate (“new things” were the nectar of Florentines);
889: others by the sense that it was time to attend to their private
890: business. In this general movement, Bratti got close to the barber, and
891: said—
892: 
893: “Nello, you’ve a ready tongue of your own, and are used to worming
894: secrets out of people when you’ve once got them well lathered. I picked
895: up a stranger this morning as I was coming in from Rovezzano, and I can
896: spell him out no better than I can the letters on that scarf I bought
897: from the French cavalier. It isn’t my wits are at fault,—I want no man
898: to help me tell peas from paternosters,—but when you come to foreign
899: fashions, a fool may happen to know more than a wise man.”
900: 
901: “Ay, thou hast the wisdom of Midas, who could turn rags and rusty nails
902: into gold, even as thou dost,” said Nello, “and he had also something
903: of the ass about him. But where is thy bird of strange plumage?”
904: 
905: Bratti was looking round, with an air of disappointment.
906: 
907: “Diavolo!” he said, with some vexation. “The bird’s flown. It’s true he
908: was hungry, and I forgot him. But we shall find him in the Mercato,
909: within scent of bread and savours, I’ll answer for him.”
910: 
911: “Let us make the round of the Mercato, then,” said Nello.
912: 
913: “It isn’t his feathers that puzzle me,” continued Bratti, as they
914: pushed their way together. “There isn’t much in the way of cut and
915: cloth on this side the Holy Sepulchre that can puzzle a Florentine.”
916: 
917: “Or frighten him either,” said Nello, “after he has seen an Englander
918: or a German.”
919: 
920: “No, no,” said Bratti, cordially; “one may never lose sight of the
921: Cupola and yet know the world, I hope. Besides, this stranger’s clothes
922: are good Italian merchandise, and the hose he wears were dyed in
923: Ognissanti before ever they were dyed with salt water, as he says. But
924: the riddle about him is—”
925: 
926: Here Bratti’s explanation was interrupted by some jostling as they
927: reached one of the entrances of the piazza, and before he could resume
928: it they had caught sight of the enigmatical object they were in search
929: of.
930: 
931: 
932: 
933: 
934: CHAPTER II.
935: Breakfast for Love.
936: 
937: 
938: After Bratti had joined the knot of talkers, the young stranger,
939: hopeless of learning what was the cause of the general agitation, and
940: not much caring to know what was probably of little interest to any but
941: born Florentines, soon became tired of waiting for Bratti’s escort; and
942: chose to stroll round the piazza, looking out for some vendor of
943: eatables who might happen to have less than the average curiosity about
944: public news. But as if at the suggestion of a sudden thought, he thrust
945: his hand into a purse or wallet that hung at his waist, and explored it
946: again and again with a look of frustration.
947: 
948: “Not an obolus, by Jupiter!” he murmured, in a language which was not
949: Tuscan or even Italian. “I thought I had one poor piece left. I must
950: get my breakfast for love, then!”
951: 
952: He had not gone many steps farther before it seemed likely that he had
953: found a quarter of the market where that medium of exchange might not
954: be rejected.
955: 
956: In a corner, away from any group of talkers, two mules were standing,
957: well adorned with red tassels and collars. One of them carried wooden
958: milk-vessels, the other a pair of panniers filled with herbs and
959: salads. Resting her elbow on the neck of the mule that carried the
960: milk, there leaned a young girl, apparently not more than sixteen, with
961: a red hood surrounding her face, which was all the more baby-like in
962: its prettiness from the entire concealment of her hair. The poor child,
963: perhaps, was weary after her labour in the morning twilight in
964: preparation for her walk to market from some castello three or four
965: miles off, for she seemed to have gone to sleep in that half-standing,
966: half-leaning posture. Nevertheless, our stranger had no compunction in
967: awaking her; but the means he chose were so gentle, that it seemed to
968: the damsel in her dream as if a little sprig of thyme had touched her
969: lips while she was stooping to gather the herbs. The dream was broken,
970: however, for she opened her blue baby-eyes, and started up with
971: astonishment and confusion to see the young stranger standing close
972: before her. She heard him speaking to her in a voice which seemed so
973: strange and soft, that even if she had been more collected she would
974: have taken it for granted that he said something hopelessly
975: unintelligible to her, and her first movement was to turn her head a
976: little away, and lift up a corner of her green serge mantle as a
977: screen. He repeated his words—
978: 
979: “Forgive me, pretty one, for awaking you. I’m dying with hunger, and
980: the scent of milk makes breakfast seem more desirable than ever.”
981: 
982: He had chosen the words “_muoio di fame_” because he knew they would be
983: familiar to her ears; and he had uttered them playfully, with the
984: intonation of a mendicant. This time he was understood; the corner of
985: the mantle was dropped, and in a few moments a large cup of fragrant
986: milk was held out to him. He paid no further compliments before raising
987: it to his lips, and while he was drinking, the little maiden found
988: courage to look up at the long dark curls of this singular-voiced
989: stranger, who had asked for food in the tones of a beggar, but who,
990: though his clothes were much damaged, was unlike any beggar she had
991: ever seen.
992: 
993: While this process of survey was going on, there was another current of
994: feeling that carried her hand into a bag which hung by the side of the
995: mule, and when the stranger set down his cup, he saw a large piece of
996: bread held out towards him, and caught a glance of the blue eyes that
997: seemed intended as an encouragement to him to take this additional
998: gift.
999: 
1000: “But perhaps that is your own breakfast,” he said. “No, I have had
1001: enough without payment. A thousand thanks, my gentle one.”
1002: 
1003: There was no rejoinder in words; but the piece of bread was pushed a
1004: little nearer to him, as if in impatience at his refusal; and as the
1005: long dark eyes of the stranger rested on the baby-face, it seemed to be
1006: gathering more and more courage to look up and meet them.
1007: 
1008: “Ah, then, if I must take the bread,” he said, laying his hand on it,
1009: “I shall get bolder still, and beg for another kiss to make the bread
1010: sweeter.”
1011: 
1012: His speech was getting wonderfully intelligible in spite of the strange
1013: voice, which had at first almost seemed a thing to make her cross
1014: herself. She blushed deeply, and lifted up a corner of her mantle to
1015: her mouth again. But just as the too presumptuous stranger was leaning
1016: forward, and had his fingers on the arm that held up the screening
1017: mantle, he was startled by a harsh voice close upon his ear.
1018: 
1019: “Who are _you_—with a murrain to you? No honest buyer, I’ll warrant,
1020: but a hanger-on of the dicers—or something worse. Go! dance off, and
1021: find fitter company, or I’ll give you a tune to a little quicker time
1022: than you’ll like.”
1023: 
1024: The young stranger drew back and looked at the speaker with a glance
1025: provokingly free from alarm and deprecation, and his slight expression
1026: of saucy amusement broke into a broad beaming smile as he surveyed the
1027: figure of his threatenor. She was a stout but brawny woman, with a
1028: man’s jerkin slipped over her green serge gamurra or gown, and the
1029: peaked hood of some departed mantle fastened round her sunburnt face,
1030: which, under all its coarseness and premature wrinkles, showed a
1031: half-sad, half-ludicrous maternal resemblance to the tender baby-face
1032: of the little maiden—the sort of resemblance which often seems a more
1033: croaking, shudder-creating prophecy than that of the death’s-head.
1034: 
1035: There was something irresistibly propitiating in that bright young
1036: smile, but Monna Ghita was not a woman to betray any weakness, and she
1037: went on speaking, apparently with heightened exasperation.
1038: 
1039: “Yes, yes, you can grin as well as other monkeys in cap and jerkin.
1040: You’re a minstrel or a mountebank, I’ll be sworn; you look for all the
1041: world as silly as a tumbler when he’s been upside down and has got on
1042: his heels again. And what fool’s tricks hast thou been after, Tessa?”
1043: she added, turning to her daughter, whose frightened face was more
1044: inviting to abuse. “Giving away the milk and victuals, it seems; ay,
1045: ay, thou’dst carry water in thy ears for any idle vagabond that didn’t
1046: like to stoop for it, thou silly staring rabbit! Turn thy back, and
1047: lift the herbs out of the panniers, else I’ll make thee say a few Aves
1048: without counting.”
1049: 
1050: “Nay, Madonna,” said the stranger, with a pleading smile, “don’t be
1051: angry with your pretty Tessa for taking pity on a hungry traveller, who
1052: found himself unexpectedly without a quattrino. Your handsome face
1053: looks so well when it frowns, that I long to see it illuminated by a
1054: smile.”
1055: 
1056: “_Va via_! I know what paste you are made of. You may tickle me with
1057: that straw a good long while before I shall laugh, I can tell you. Get
1058: along, with a bad Easter! else I’ll make a beauty-spot or two on that
1059: face of yours that shall spoil your kissing on this side Advent.”
1060: 
1061: As Monna Ghita lifted her formidable talons by way of complying with
1062: the first and last requisite of eloquence, Bratti, who had come up a
1063: minute or two before, had been saying to his companion, “What think you
1064: of this pretty parrot, Nello? Doesn’t his tongue smack of Venice?”
1065: 
1066: “Nay, Bratti,” said the barber in an undertone, “thy wisdom has much of
1067: the ass in it, as I told thee just now; especially about the ears. This
1068: stranger is a Greek, else I’m not the barber who has had the sole and
1069: exclusive shaving of the excellent Demetrio, and drawn more than one
1070: sorry tooth from his learned jaw. And this youth might be taken to have
1071: come straight from Olympus—at least when he has had a touch of my
1072: razor.”
1073: 
1074: “_Orsù_! Monna Ghita!” continued Nello, not sorry to see some sport;
1075: “what has happened to cause such a thunderstorm? Has this young
1076: stranger been misbehaving himself?”
1077: 
1078: “By San Giovanni!” said the cautious Bratti, who had not shaken off his
1079: original suspicions concerning the shabbily-clad possessor of jewels,
1080: “he did right to run away from _me_, if he meant to get into mischief.
1081: I can swear that I found him under the Loggia de’ Cerchi, with a ring
1082: on his finger such as I’ve seen worn by Bernardo Rucellai himself. Not
1083: another rusty nail’s worth do I know about him.”
1084: 
1085: “The fact is,” said Nello, eyeing the stranger good-humouredly, “this
1086: _bello giovane_ has been a little too presumptuous in admiring the
1087: charms of Monna Ghita, and has attempted to kiss her while her
1088: daughter’s back is turned; for I observe that the pretty Tessa is too
1089: busy to look this way at present. Was it not so, Messer?” Nello
1090: concluded, in a tone of courtesy.
1091: 
1092: “You have divined the offence like a soothsayer,” said the stranger,
1093: laughingly. “Only that I had not the good fortune to find Monna Ghita
1094: here at first. I begged a cup of milk from her daughter, and had
1095: accepted this gift of bread, for which I was making a humble offering
1096: of gratitude, before I had the higher pleasure of being face to face
1097: with these riper charms which I was perhaps too bold in admiring.”
1098: 
1099: “_Va, va_! be off, every one of you, and stay in purgatory till I pay
1100: to get you out, will you?” said Monna Ghita, fiercely, elbowing Nello,
1101: and leading forward her mule so as to compel the stranger to jump
1102: aside. “Tessa, thou simpleton, bring forward thy mule a bit: the cart
1103: will be upon us.”
1104: 
1105: As Tessa turned to take the mule’s bridle, she cast one timid glance at
1106: the stranger, who was now moving with Nello out of the way of an
1107: approaching market-cart; and the glance was just long enough to seize
1108: the beckoning movement of his hand, which indicated that he had been
1109: watching for this opportunity of an adieu.
1110: 
1111: “_Ebbene_,” said Bratti, raising his voice to speak across the cart; “I
1112: leave you with Nello, young man, for there’s no pushing my bag and
1113: basket any farther, and I have business at home. But you’ll remember
1114: our bargain, because if you found Tessa without me, it was not my
1115: fault. Nello will show you my shop in the Ferravecchi, and I’ll not
1116: turn my back on you.”
1117: 
1118: “A thousand thanks, friend!” said the stranger, laughing, and then
1119: turned away with Nello up the narrow street which led most directly to
1120: the Piazza del Duomo.
1121: 
1122: 
1123: 
1124: 
1125: CHAPTER III.
1126: The Barber’s Shop.
1127: 
1128: 
1129: “To tell you the truth,” said the young stranger to Nello, as they got
1130: a little clearer of the entangled vehicles and mules, “I am not sorry
1131: to be handed over by that patron of mine to one who has a less
1132: barbarous accent, and a less enigmatical business. Is it a common thing
1133: among you Florentines for an itinerant trafficker in broken glass and
1134: rags to talk of a shop where he sells lutes and swords?”
1135: 
1136: “Common? No: our Bratti is not a common man. He has a theory, and lives
1137: up to it, which is more than I can say for any philosopher I have the
1138: honour of shaving,” answered Nello, whose loquacity, like an over-full
1139: bottle, could never pour forth a small dose. “Bratti means to extract
1140: the utmost possible amount of pleasure, that is to say, of hard
1141: bargaining, out of this life; winding it up with a bargain for the
1142: easiest possible passage through purgatory, by giving Holy Church his
1143: winnings when the game is over. He has had his will made to that effect
1144: on the cheapest terms a notary could be got for. But I have often said
1145: to him, ‘Bratti, thy bargain is a limping one, and thou art on the lame
1146: side of it. Does it not make thee a little sad to look at the pictures
1147: of the Paradiso? Thou wilt never be able there to chaffer for rags and
1148: rusty nails: the saints and angels want neither pins nor tinder; and
1149: except with San Bartolommeo, who carries his skin about in an
1150: inconvenient manner, I see no chance of thy making a bargain for
1151: second-hand clothing.’ But God pardon me,” added Nello, changing his
1152: tone, and crossing himself, “this light talk ill beseems a morning when
1153: Lorenzo lies dead, and the Muses are tearing their hair—always a
1154: painful thought to a barber; and you yourself, Messere, are probably
1155: under a cloud, for when a man of your speech and presence takes up with
1156: so sorry a night’s lodging, it argues some misfortune to have befallen
1157: him.”
1158: 
1159: “What Lorenzo is that whose death you speak of?” said the stranger,
1160: appearing to have dwelt with too anxious an interest on this point to
1161: have noticed the indirect inquiry that followed it.
1162: 
1163: “What Lorenzo? There is but one Lorenzo, I imagine, whose death could
1164: throw the Mercato into an uproar, set the lantern of the Duomo leaping
1165: in desperation, and cause the lions of the Republic to feel under an
1166: immediate necessity to devour one another. I mean Lorenzo de’ Medici,
1167: the Pericles of our Athens—if I may make such a comparison in the ear
1168: of a Greek.”
1169: 
1170: “Why not?” said the other, laughingly; “for I doubt whether Athens,
1171: even in the days of Pericles, could have produced so learned a barber.”
1172: 
1173: “Yes, yes; I thought I could not be mistaken,” said the rapid Nello,
1174: “else I have shaved the venerable Demetrio Calcondila to little
1175: purpose; but pardon me, I am lost in wonder: your Italian is better
1176: than his, though he has been in Italy forty years—better even than that
1177: of the accomplished Marullo, who may be said to have married the Italic
1178: Muse in more senses than one, since he has married our learned and
1179: lovely Alessandra Scala.”
1180: 
1181: “It will lighten your wonder to know that I come of a Greek stock
1182: planted in Italian soil much longer than the mulberry-trees which have
1183: taken so kindly to it. I was born at Bari, and my—I mean, I was brought
1184: up by an Italian—and, in fact, I am a Greek, very much as your peaches
1185: are Persian. The Greek dye was subdued in me, I suppose, till I had
1186: been dipped over again by long abode and much travel in the land of
1187: gods and heroes. And, to confess something of my private affairs to
1188: you, this same Greek dye, with a few ancient gems I have about me, is
1189: the only fortune shipwreck has left me. But—when the towers fall, you
1190: know it is an ill business for the small nest-builders—the death of
1191: your Pericles makes me wish I had rather turned my steps towards Rome,
1192: as I should have done but for a fallacious Minerva in the shape of an
1193: Augustinian monk. ‘At Rome,’ he said, ‘you will be lost in a crowd of
1194: hungry scholars; but at Florence, every corner is penetrated by the
1195: sunshine of Lorenzo’s patronage: Florence is the best market in Italy
1196: for such commodities as yours.’”
1197: 
1198: “_Gnaffè_, and so it will remain, I hope,” said Nello, “Lorenzo was not
1199: the only patron and judge of learning in our city—heaven forbid!
1200: Because he was a large melon, every other Florentine is not a pumpkin,
1201: I suppose. Have we not Bernardo Rucellai, and Alamanno Rinuccini, and
1202: plenty more? And if you want to be informed on such matters, I, Nello,
1203: am your man. It seems to me a thousand years till I can be of service
1204: to a _bel erudito_ like yourself. And, first of all, in the matter of
1205: your hair. That beard, my fine young man, must be parted with, were it
1206: as dear to you as the nymph of your dreams. Here at Florence, we love
1207: not to see a man with his nose projecting over a cascade of hair. But,
1208: remember, you will have passed the Rubicon, when once you have been
1209: shaven: if you repent, and let your beard grow after it has acquired
1210: stoutness by a struggle with the razor, your mouth will by-and-by show
1211: no longer what Messer Angelo calls the divine prerogative of lips, but
1212: will appear like a dark cavern fringed with horrent brambles.”
1213: 
1214: “That is a terrible prophecy,” said the Greek, “especially if your
1215: Florentine maidens are many of them as pretty as the little Tessa I
1216: stole a kiss from this morning.”
1217: 
1218: “Tessa? she is a rough-handed contadina: you will rise into the favour
1219: of dames who bring no scent of the mule-stables with them. But to that
1220: end, you must not have the air of a _sgherro_, or a man of evil repute:
1221: you must look like a courtier, and a scholar of the more polished sort,
1222: such as our Pietro Crinito—like one who sins among well-bred, well-fed
1223: people, and not one who sucks down vile _vino di sotto_ in a chance
1224: tavern.”
1225: 
1226: “With all my heart,” said the stranger. “If the Florentine Graces
1227: demand it, I am willing to give up this small matter of my beard, but—”
1228: 
1229: “Yes, yes,” interrupted Nello. “I know what you would say. It is the
1230: _bella zazzera_—the hyacinthine locks, you do not choose to part with;
1231: and there is no need. Just a little pruning—ecco!—and you will look not
1232: unlike the illustrious prince Pico di Mirandola in his prime. And here
1233: we are in good time in the Piazza San Giovanni, and at the door of my
1234: shop. But you are pausing, I see: naturally, you want to look at our
1235: wonder of the world, our Duomo, our Santa Maria del Fiore. Well, well,
1236: a mere glance; but I beseech you to leave a closer survey till you have
1237: been shaved: I am quivering with the inspiration of my art even to the
1238: very edge of my razor. Ah, then, come round this way.”
1239: 
1240: The mercurial barber seized the arm of the stranger, and led him to a
1241: point, on the south side of the piazza, from which he could see at once
1242: the huge dark shell of the cupola, the slender soaring grace of
1243: Giotto’s campanile, and the quaint octagon of San Giovanni in front of
1244: them, showing its unique gates of storied bronze, which still bore the
1245: somewhat dimmed glory of their original gilding. The inlaid marbles
1246: were then fresher in their pink, and white, and purple, than they are
1247: now, when the winters of four centuries have turned their white to the
1248: rich ochre of well-mellowed meerschaum; the façade of the cathedral did
1249: not stand ignominious in faded stucco, but had upon it the magnificent
1250: promise of the half-completed marble inlaying and statued niches, which
1251: Giotto had devised a hundred and fifty years before; and as the
1252: campanile in all its harmonious variety of colour and form led the eyes
1253: upward, high into the clear air of this April morning, it seemed a
1254: prophetic symbol, telling that human life must somehow and some time
1255: shape itself into accord with that pure aspiring beauty.
1256: 
1257: But this was not the impression it appeared to produce on the Greek.
1258: His eyes were irresistibly led upward, but as he stood with his arms
1259: folded and his curls falling backward, there was a slight touch of
1260: scorn on his lip, and when his eyes fell again they glanced round with
1261: a scanning coolness which was rather piquing to Nello’s Florentine
1262: spirit.
1263: 
1264: “Well, my fine young man,” he said, with some impatience, “you seem to
1265: make as little of our Cathedral as if you were the Angel Gabriel come
1266: straight from Paradise. I should like to know if you have ever seen
1267: finer work than our Giotto’s tower, or any cupola that would not look a
1268: mere mushroom by the side of Brunelleschi’s there, or any marbles finer
1269: or more cunningly wrought than these that our Signoria got from far-off
1270: quarries, at a price that would buy a dukedom. Come, now, have you ever
1271: seen anything to equal them?”
1272: 
1273: “If you asked me that question with a scimitar at my throat, after the
1274: Turkish fashion, or even your own razor,” said the young Greek, smiling
1275: gaily, and moving on towards the gates of the Baptistery, “I daresay
1276: you might get a confession of the true faith from me. But with my
1277: throat free from peril, I venture to tell you that your buildings smack
1278: too much of Christian barbarism for my taste. I have a shuddering sense
1279: of what there is inside—hideous smoked Madonnas; fleshless saints in
1280: mosaic, staring down idiotic astonishment and rebuke from the apse;
1281: skin-clad skeletons hanging on crosses, or stuck all over with arrows,
1282: or stretched on gridirons; women and monks with heads aside in
1283: perpetual lamentation. I have seen enough of those wry-necked
1284: favourites of heaven at Constantinople. But what is this bronze door
1285: rough with imagery? These women’s figures seem moulded in a different
1286: spirit from those starved and staring saints I spoke of: these heads in
1287: high relief speak of a human mind within them, instead of looking like
1288: an index to perpetual spasms and colic.”
1289: 
1290: “Yes, yes,” said Nello, with some triumph. “I think we shall show you
1291: by-and-by that our Florentine art is not in a state of barbarism. These
1292: gates, my fine young man, were moulded half a century ago, by our
1293: Lorenzo Ghiberti, when he counted hardly so many years as you do.”
1294: 
1295: “Ah, I remember,” said the stranger, turning away, like one whose
1296: appetite for contemplation was soon satisfied. “I have heard that your
1297: Tuscan sculptors and painters have been studying the antique a little.
1298: But with monks for models, and the legends of mad hermits and martyrs
1299: for subjects, the vision of Olympus itself would be of small use to
1300: them.”
1301: 
1302: “I understand,” said Nello, with a significant shrug, as they walked
1303: along. “You are of the same mind as Michele Marullo, ay, and as Angelo
1304: Poliziano himself, in spite of his canonicate, when he relaxes himself
1305: a little in my shop after his lectures, and talks of the gods awaking
1306: from their long sleep and making the woods and streams vital once more.
1307: But he rails against the Roman scholars who want to make us all talk
1308: Latin again: ‘My ears,’ he says, ‘are sufficiently flayed by the
1309: barbarisms of the learned, and if the vulgar are to talk Latin I would
1310: as soon have been in Florence the day they took to beating all the
1311: kettles in the city because the bells were not enough to stay the wrath
1312: of the saints.’ Ah, Messer Greco, if you want to know the flavour of
1313: our scholarship, you must frequent my shop: it is the focus of
1314: Florentine intellect, and in that sense the navel of the earth—as my
1315: great predecessor, Burchiello, said of _his_ shop, on the more
1316: frivolous pretension that his street of the Calimara was the centre of
1317: our city. And here we are at the sign of ‘Apollo and the Razor.’
1318: Apollo, you see, is bestowing the razor on the Triptolemus of our
1319: craft, the first reaper of beards, the sublime _Anonimo_, whose
1320: mysterious identity is indicated by a shadowy hand.”
1321: 
1322: “I see thou hast had custom already, Sandro,” continued Nello,
1323: addressing a solemn-looking dark-eyed youth, who made way for them on
1324: the threshold. “And now make all clear for this signor to sit down. And
1325: prepare the finest-scented lather, for he has a learned and a handsome
1326: chin.”
1327: 
1328: “You have a pleasant little adytum there, I see,” said the stranger,
1329: looking through a latticed screen which divided the shop from a room of
1330: about equal size, opening into a still smaller walled enclosure, where
1331: a few bays and laurels surrounded a stone Hermes. “I suppose your
1332: conclave of _eruditi_ meets there?”
1333: 
1334: “There, and not less in my shop,” said Nello, leading the way into the
1335: inner room, in which were some benches, a table, with one book in
1336: manuscript and one printed in capitals lying open upon it, a lute, a
1337: few oil-sketches, and a model or two of hands and ancient masks. “For
1338: my shop is a no less fitting haunt of the Muses, as you will
1339: acknowledge when you feel the sudden illumination of understanding and
1340: the serene vigour of inspiration that will come to you with a clear
1341: chin. Ah! you can make that lute discourse, I perceive. I, too, have
1342: some skill that way, though the serenata is useless when daylight
1343: discloses a visage like mine, looking no fresher than an apple that has
1344: stood the winter. But look at that sketch: it is a fancy of Piero di
1345: Cosimo’s, a strange freakish painter, who says he saw it by long
1346: looking at a mouldy wall.”
1347: 
1348: The sketch Nello pointed to represented three masks—one a drunken
1349: laughing Satyr, another a sorrowing Magdalen, and the third, which lay
1350: between them, the rigid, cold face of a Stoic: the masks rested
1351: obliquely on the lap of a little child, whose cherub features rose
1352: above them with something of the supernal promise in the gaze which
1353: painters had by that time learned to give to the Divine Infant.
1354: 
1355: “A symbolical picture, I see,” said the young Greek, touching the lute
1356: while he spoke, so as to bring out a slight musical murmur. “The child,
1357: perhaps, is the Golden Age, wanting neither worship nor philosophy. And
1358: the Golden Age can always come back as long as men are born in the form
1359: of babies, and don’t come into the world in cassock or furred mantle.
1360: Or, the child may mean the wise philosophy of Epicurus, removed alike
1361: from the gross, the sad, and the severe.”
1362: 
1363: “Ah! everybody has his own interpretation for that picture,” said
1364: Nello; “and if you ask Piero himself what he meant by it, he says his
1365: pictures are an appendix which Messer Domeneddio has been pleased to
1366: make to the universe, and if any man is in doubt what they mean, he had
1367: better inquire of Holy Church. He has been asked to paint a picture
1368: after the sketch, but he puts his fingers to his ears and shakes his
1369: head at that; the fancy is past, he says—a strange animal, our Piero.
1370: But now all is ready for your initiation into the mysteries of the
1371: razor.”
1372: 
1373: “Mysteries they may well be called,” continued the barber, with rising
