1374: spirits at the prospect of a long monologue, as he imprisoned the young
1375: Greek in the shroud-like shaving-cloth; “mysteries of Minerva and the
1376: Graces. I get the flower of men’s thoughts, because I seize them in the
1377: first moment after shaving. (Ah! you wince a little at the lather: it
1378: tickles the outlying limits of the nose, I admit.) And that is what
1379: makes the peculiar fitness of a barber’s shop to become a resort of wit
1380: and learning. For, look now at a druggist’s shop: there is a dull
1381: conclave at the sign of ‘The Moor,’ that pretends to rival mine; but
1382: what sort of inspiration, I beseech you, can be got from the scent of
1383: nauseous vegetable decoctions?—to say nothing of the fact that you no
1384: sooner pass the threshold than you see a doctor of physic, like a
1385: gigantic spider disguised in fur and scarlet, waiting for his prey; or
1386: even see him blocking up the doorway seated on a bony hack, inspecting
1387: saliva. (Your chin a little elevated, if it please you: contemplate
1388: that angel who is blowing the trumpet at you from the ceiling. I had it
1389: painted expressly for the regulation of my clients’ chins.) Besides,
1390: your druggist, who herborises and decocts, is a man of prejudices: he
1391: has poisoned people according to a system, and is obliged to stand up
1392: for his system to justify the consequences. Now a barber can be
1393: dispassionate; the only thing he necessarily stands by is the razor,
1394: always providing he is not an author. That was the flaw in my great
1395: predecessor Burchiello: he was a poet, and had consequently a prejudice
1396: about his own poetry. I have escaped that; I saw very early that
1397: authorship is a narrowing business, in conflict with the liberal art of
1398: the razor, which demands an impartial affection for all men’s chins.
1399: Ecco, Messer! the outline of your chin and lip is as clear as a
1400: maiden’s; and now fix your mind on a knotty question—ask yourself
1401: whether you are bound to spell Virgil with an _i_ or an _e_, and say if
1402: you do not feel an unwonted clearness on the point. Only, if you decide
1403: for the _i_, keep it to yourself till your fortune is made, for the _e_
1404: hath the stronger following in Florence. Ah! I think I see a gleam of
1405: still quicker wit in your eye. I have it on the authority of our young
1406: Niccolò Macchiavelli, himself keen enough to discern _il pelo nell’
1407: uovo_, as we say, and a great lover of delicate shaving, though his
1408: beard is hardly of two years’ date, that no sooner do the hairs begin
1409: to push themselves, than he perceives a certain grossness of
1410: apprehension creeping over him.”
1411: 
1412: “Suppose you let me look at myself,” said the stranger, laughing. “The
1413: happy effect on my intellect is perhaps obstructed by a little doubt as
1414: to the effect on my appearance.”
1415: 
1416: “Behold yourself in this mirror, then; it is a Venetian mirror from
1417: Murano, the true _nosce teipsum_, as I have named it, compared with
1418: which the finest mirror of steel or silver is mere darkness. See now,
1419: how by diligent shaving, the nether region of your face may preserve
1420: its human outline, instead of presenting no distinction from the
1421: physiognomy of a bearded owl or a Barbary ape. I have seen men whose
1422: beards have so invaded their cheeks, that one might have pitied them as
1423: the victims of a sad, brutalising chastisement befitting our Dante’s
1424: Inferno, if they had not seemed to strut with a strange triumph in
1425: their extravagant hairiness.”
1426: 
1427: “It seems to me,” said the Greek, still looking into the mirror, “that
1428: you have taken away some of my capital with your razor—I mean a year or
1429: two of age, which might have won me more ready credit for my learning.
1430: Under the inspection of a patron whose vision has grown somewhat dim, I
1431: shall have a perilous resemblance to a maiden of eighteen in the
1432: disguise of hose and jerkin.”
1433: 
1434: “Not at all,” said Nello, proceeding to clip the too extravagant curls;
1435: “your proportions are not those of a maiden. And for your age, I myself
1436: remember seeing Angelo Poliziano begin his lectures on the Latin
1437: language when he had a younger beard than yours; and between ourselves,
1438: his juvenile ugliness was not less signal than his precocious
1439: scholarship. Whereas you—no, no, your age is not against you; but
1440: between ourselves, let me hint to you that your being a Greek, though
1441: it be only an Apulian Greek, is not in your favour. Certain of our
1442: scholars hold that your Greek learning is but a wayside degenerate
1443: plant until it has been transplanted into Italian brains, and that now
1444: there is such a plentiful crop of the superior quality, your native
1445: teachers are mere propagators of degeneracy. Ecco! your curls are now
1446: of the right proportion to neck and shoulders; rise, Messer, and I will
1447: free you from the encumbrance of this cloth. _Gnaffè_! I almost advise
1448: you to retain the faded jerkin and hose a little longer; they give you
1449: the air of a fallen prince.”
1450: 
1451: “But the question is,” said the young Greek, leaning against the high
1452: back of a chair, and returning Nello’s contemplative admiration with a
1453: look of inquiring anxiety; “the question is, in what quarter I am to
1454: carry my princely air, so as to rise from the said fallen condition. If
1455: your Florentine patrons of learning share this scholarly hostility to
1456: the Greeks, I see not how your city can be a hospitable refuge for me,
1457: as you seemed to say just now.”
1458: 
1459: “_Pian piano_—not so fast,” said Nello, sticking his thumbs into his
1460: belt and nodding to Sandro to restore order. “I will not conceal from
1461: you that there is a prejudice against Greeks among us; and though, as a
1462: barber unsnared by authorship, I share no prejudices, I must admit that
1463: the Greeks are not always such pretty youngsters as yourself: their
1464: erudition is often of an uncombed, unmannerly aspect, and encrusted
1465: with a barbarous utterance of Italian, that makes their converse hardly
1466: more euphonious than that of a Tedesco in a state of vinous loquacity.
1467: And then, again, excuse me—we Florentines have liberal ideas about
1468: speech, and consider that an instrument which can flatter and promise
1469: so cleverly as the tongue, must have been partly made for those
1470: purposes; and that truth is a riddle for eyes and wit to discover,
1471: which it were a mere spoiling of sport for the tongue to betray. Still
1472: we have our limits beyond which we call dissimulation treachery. But it
1473: is said of the Greeks that their honesty begins at what is the hanging
1474: point with us, and that since the old Furies went to sleep, your
1475: Christian Greek is of so easy a conscience that he would make a
1476: stepping-stone of his father’s corpse.”
1477: 
1478: The flush on the stranger’s face indicated what seemed so natural a
1479: movement of resentment, that the good-natured Nello hastened to atone
1480: for his want of reticence.
1481: 
1482: “Be not offended, _bel giovane_; I am but repeating what I hear in my
1483: shop; as you may perceive, my eloquence is simply the cream which I
1484: skim off my clients’ talk. Heaven forbid I should fetter my
1485: impartiality by entertaining an opinion. And for that same scholarly
1486: objection to the Greeks,” added Nello, in a more mocking tone, and with
1487: a significant grimace, “the fact is, you are heretics, Messer; jealousy
1488: has nothing to do with it: if you would just change your opinion about
1489: leaven, and alter your Doxology a little, our Italian scholars would
1490: think it a thousand years till they could give up their chairs to you.
1491: Yes, yes; it is chiefly religious scruple, and partly also the
1492: authority of a great classic,—Juvenal, is it not? He, I gather, had his
1493: bile as much stirred by the swarm of Greeks as our Messer Angelo, who
1494: is fond of quoting some passage about their incorrigible
1495: impudence—_audacia perdita_.”
1496: 
1497: “Pooh! the passage is a compliment,” said the Greek, who had recovered
1498: himself, and seemed wise enough to take the matter gaily—
1499: 
1500: 
1501: “‘Ingenium velox, audacia perdita, sermo
1502: Promptus, et Isaeo torrentior.’
1503: 
1504: 
1505: “A rapid intellect and ready eloquence may carry off a little
1506: impudence.”
1507: 
1508: “Assuredly,” said Nello. “And since, as I see, you know Latin
1509: literature as well as Greek, you will not fall into the mistake of
1510: Giovanni Argiropulo, who ran full tilt against Cicero, and pronounced
1511: him all but a pumpkin-head. For, let me give you one bit of advice,
1512: young man—trust a barber who has shaved the best chins, and kept his
1513: eyes and ears open for twenty years—oil your tongue well when you talk
1514: of the ancient Latin writers, and give it an extra dip when you talk of
1515: the modern. A wise Greek may win favour among us; witness our excellent
1516: Demetrio, who is loved by many, and not hated immoderately even by the
1517: most renowned scholars.”
1518: 
1519: “I discern the wisdom of your advice so clearly,” said the Greek, with
1520: the bright smile which was continually lighting up the fine form and
1521: colour of his young face, “that I will ask you for a little more. Who
1522: now, for example, would be the most likely patron for me? Is there a
1523: son of Lorenzo who inherits his tastes? Or is there any other wealthy
1524: Florentine specially addicted to purchasing antique gems? I have a fine
1525: Cleopatra cut in sardonyx, and one or two other intaglios and cameos,
1526: both curious and beautiful, worthy of being added to the cabinet of a
1527: prince. Happily, I had taken the precaution of fastening them within
1528: the lining of my doublet before I set out on my voyage. Moreover, I
1529: should like to raise a small sum for my present need on this ring of
1530: mine,” (here he took out the ring and replaced it on his finger), “if
1531: you could recommend me to any honest trafficker.”
1532: 
1533: “Let us see, let us see,” said Nello, perusing the floor, and walking
1534: up and down the length of his shop. “This is no time to apply to Piero
1535: de’ Medici, though he has the will to make such purchases if he could
1536: always spare the money; but I think it is another sort of Cleopatra
1537: that he covets most... Yes, yes, I have it. What you want is a man of
1538: wealth, and influence, and scholarly tastes—not one of your learned
1539: porcupines, bristling all over with critical tests, but one whose Greek
1540: and Latin are of a comfortable laxity. And that man is Bartolommeo
1541: Scala, the secretary of our Republic. He came to Florence as a poor
1542: adventurer himself—a miller’s son—a ‘branny monster,’ as he has been
1543: nicknamed by our honey-lipped Poliziano, who agrees with him as well as
1544: my teeth agree with lemon-juice. And, by the by, that may be a reason
1545: why the secretary may be the more ready to do a good turn to a strange
1546: scholar. For, between you and me, _bel giovane_—trust a barber who has
1547: shaved the best scholars—friendliness is much such a steed as Ser
1548: Benghi’s: it will hardly show much alacrity unless it has got the
1549: thistle of hatred under its tail. However, the secretary is a man
1550: who’ll keep his word to you, even to the halving of a fennel-seed; and
1551: he is not unlikely to buy some of your gems.”
1552: 
1553: “But how am I to get at this great man?” said the Greek, rather
1554: impatiently.
1555: 
1556: “I was coming to that,” said Nello. “Just now everybody of any public
1557: importance will be full of Lorenzo’s death, and a stranger may find it
1558: difficult to get any notice. But in the meantime, I could take you to a
1559: man who, if he has a mind, can help you to a chance of a favourable
1560: interview with Scala sooner than anybody else in Florence—worth seeing
1561: for his own sake too, to say nothing of his collections, or of his
1562: daughter Romola, who is as fair as the Florentine lily before it got
1563: quarrelsome and turned red.”
1564: 
1565: “But if this father of the beautiful Romola makes collections, why
1566: should he not like to buy some of my gems himself?”
1567: 
1568: Nello shrugged his shoulders. “For two good reasons—want of sight to
1569: look at the gems, and want of money to pay for them. Our old Bardo de’
1570: Bardi is so blind that he can see no more of his daughter than, as he
1571: says, a glimmering of something bright when she comes very near him:
1572: doubtless her golden hair, which, as Messer Luigi Pulci says of his
1573: Meridiana’s, ‘_raggia come stella per sereno_.’ Ah! here come some
1574: clients of mine, and I shouldn’t wonder if one of them could serve your
1575: turn about that ring.”
1576: 
1577: 
1578: 
1579: 
1580: CHAPTER IV.
1581: First Impressions.
1582: 
1583: 
1584: “Good-day, Messer Domenico,” said Nello to the foremost of the two
1585: visitors who entered the shop, while he nodded silently to the other.
1586: “You come as opportunely as cheese on macaroni. Ah! you are in
1587: haste—wish to be shaved without delay—ecco! And this is a morning when
1588: every one has grave matter on his mind. Florence orphaned—the very
1589: pivot of Italy snatched away—heaven itself at a loss what to do next.
1590: _Oimè_! Well, well; the sun is nevertheless travelling on towards
1591: dinner-time again; and, as I was saying, you come like cheese ready
1592: grated. For this young stranger was wishing for an honourable trader
1593: who would advance him a sum on a certain ring of value, and if I had
1594: counted every goldsmith and money-lender in Florence on my fingers, I
1595: couldn’t have found a better name than Menico Cennini. Besides, he hath
1596: other ware in which you deal—Greek learning, and young eyes—a double
1597: implement which you printers are always in need of.”
1598: 
1599: The grave elderly man, son of that Bernardo Cennini, who, twenty years
1600: before, having heard of the new process of printing carried on by
1601: Germans, had cast his own types in Florence, remained necessarily in
1602: lathered silence and passivity while Nello showered this talk in his
1603: ears, but turned a slow sideway gaze on the stranger.
1604: 
1605: “This fine young man has unlimited Greek, Latin, or Italian at your
1606: service,” continued Nello, fond of interpreting by very ample
1607: paraphrase. “He is as great a wonder of juvenile learning as Francesco
1608: Filelfo or our own incomparable Poliziano. A second Guarino, too, for
1609: he has had the misfortune to be shipwrecked, and has doubtless lost a
1610: store of precious manuscripts that might have contributed some
1611: correctness even to your correct editions, Domenico. Fortunately, he
1612: has rescued a few gems of rare value. His name is—you said your name,
1613: Messer, was—?”
1614: 
1615: “Tito Melema,” said the stranger, slipping the ring from his finger,
1616: and presenting it to Cennini, whom Nello, not less rapid with his razor
1617: than with his tongue, had now released from the shaving-cloth.
1618: 
1619: Meanwhile the man who had entered the shop in company with the
1620: goldsmith—a tall figure, about fifty, with a short trimmed beard,
1621: wearing an old felt hat and a threadbare mantle—had kept his eye fixed
1622: on the Greek, and now said abruptly—
1623: 
1624: “Young man, I am painting a picture of Sinon deceiving old Priam, and I
1625: should be glad of your face for my Sinon, if you’d give me a sitting.”
1626: 
1627: Tito Melema started and looked round with a pale astonishment in his
1628: face as if at a sudden accusation; but Nello left him no time to feel
1629: at a loss for an answer: “Piero,” said the barber, “thou art the most
1630: extraordinary compound of humours and fancies ever packed into a human
1631: skin. What trick wilt thou play with the fine visage of this young
1632: scholar to make it suit thy traitor? Ask him rather to turn his eyes
1633: upward, and thou mayst make a Saint Sebastian of him that will draw
1634: troops of devout women; or, if thou art in a classical vein, put myrtle
1635: about his curls and make him a young Bacchus, or say rather a Phoebus
1636: Apollo, for his face is as warm and bright as a summer morning; it made
1637: me his friend in the space of a ‘credo.’”
1638: 
1639: “Ay, Nello,” said the painter, speaking with abrupt pauses; “and if thy
1640: tongue can leave off its everlasting chirping long enough for thy
1641: understanding to consider the matter, thou mayst see that thou hast
1642: just shown the reason why the face of Messere will suit my traitor. A
1643: perfect traitor should have a face which vice can write no marks
1644: on—lips that will lie with a dimpled smile—eyes of such agate-like
1645: brightness and depth that no infamy can dull them—cheeks that will rise
1646: from a murder and not look haggard. I say not this young man is a
1647: traitor: I mean, he has a face that would make him the more perfect
1648: traitor if he had the heart of one, which is saying neither more nor
1649: less than that he has a beautiful face, informed with rich young blood,
1650: that will be nourished enough by food, and keep its colour without much
1651: help of virtue. He may have the heart of a hero along with it; I aver
1652: nothing to the contrary. Ask Domenico there if the lapidaries can
1653: always tell a gem by the sight alone. And now I’m going to put the tow
1654: in my ears, for thy chatter and the bells together are more than I can
1655: endure: so say no more to me, but trim my beard.”
1656: 
1657: With these last words Piero (called “di Cosimo,” from his master,
1658: Cosimo Rosselli) drew out two bits of tow, stuffed them in his ears,
1659: and placed himself in the chair before Nello, who shrugged his
1660: shoulders and cast a grimacing look of intelligence at the Greek, as
1661: much as to say, “A whimsical fellow, you perceive! Everybody holds his
1662: speeches as mere jokes.”
1663: 
1664: Tito, who had stood transfixed, with his long dark eyes resting on the
1665: unknown man who had addressed him so equivocally, seemed recalled to
1666: his self-command by Piero’s change of position, and apparently
1667: satisfied with his explanation, was again giving his attention to
1668: Cennini, who presently said—
1669: 
1670: “This is a curious and valuable ring, young man. This intaglio of the
1671: fish with the crested serpent above it, in the black stratum of the
1672: onyx, or rather nicolo, is well shown by the surrounding blue of the
1673: upper stratum. The ring has, doubtless, a history?” added Cennini,
1674: looking up keenly at the young stranger.
1675: 
1676: “Yes, indeed,” said Tito, meeting the scrutiny very frankly. “The ring
1677: was found in Sicily, and I have understood from those who busy
1678: themselves with gems and sigils, that both the stone and intaglio are
1679: of virtue to make the wearer fortunate, especially at sea, and also to
1680: restore to him whatever he may have lost. But,” he continued, smiling,
1681: “though I have worn it constantly since I quitted Greece, it has not
1682: made me altogether fortunate at sea, you perceive, unless I am to count
1683: escape from drowning as a sufficient proof of its virtue. It remains to
1684: be seen whether my lost chests will come to light; but to lose no
1685: chance of such a result, Messer, I will pray you only to hold the ring
1686: for a short space as pledge for a small sum far beneath its value, and
1687: I will redeem it as soon as I can dispose of certain other gems which
1688: are secured within my doublet, or indeed as soon as I can earn
1689: something by any scholarly employment, if I may be so fortunate as to
1690: meet with such.”
1691: 
1692: “That may be seen, young man, if you will come with me,” said Cennini.
1693: “My brother Pietro, who is a better judge of scholarship than I, will
1694: perhaps be able to supply you with a task that may test your
1695: capabilities. Meanwhile, take back your ring until I can hand you the
1696: necessary florins, and, if it please you, come along with me.”
1697: 
1698: “Yes, yes,” said Nello, “go with Messer Domenico, you cannot go in
1699: better company; he was born under the constellation that gives a man
1700: skill, riches, and integrity, whatever that constellation may be, which
1701: is of the less consequence because babies can’t choose their own
1702: horoscopes, and, indeed, if they could, there might be an inconvenient
1703: rush of babies at particular epochs. Besides, our Phoenix, the
1704: incomparable Pico, has shown that your horoscopes are all a nonsensical
1705: dream—which is the less troublesome opinion. _Addio! bel giovane_!
1706: don’t forget to come back to me.”
1707: 
1708: “No fear of that,” said Tito, beckoning a farewell, as he turned round
1709: his bright face at the door. “You are to do me a great service:—that is
1710: the most positive security for your seeing me again.”
1711: 
1712: “Say what thou wilt, Piero,” said Nello, as the young stranger
1713: disappeared, “I shall never look at such an outside as that without
1714: taking it as a sign of a lovable nature. Why, thou wilt say next that
1715: Leonardo, whom thou art always raving about, ought to have made his
1716: Judas as beautiful as Saint John! But thou art as deaf as the top of
1717: Mount Morello with that accursed tow in thy ears. Well, well: I’ll get
1718: a little more of this young man’s history from him before I take him to
1719: Bardo Bardi.”
1720: 
1721: 
1722: 
1723: 
1724: CHAPTER V.
1725: The Blind Scholar and his Daughter.
1726: 
1727: 
1728: The Via de’ Bardi, a street noted in the history of Florence, lies in
1729: Oltrarno, or that portion of the city which clothes the southern bank
1730: of the river. It extends from the Ponte Vecchio to the Piazza de’ Mozzi
1731: at the head of the Ponte alle Grazie; its right-hand line of houses and
1732: walls being backed by the rather steep ascent which in the fifteenth
1733: century was known as the hill of Bogoli, the famous stone-quarry whence
1734: the city got its pavement—of dangerously unstable consistence when
1735: penetrated by rains; its left-hand buildings flanking the river and
1736: making on their northern side a length of quaint, irregularly-pierced
1737: façade, of which the waters give a softened loving reflection as the
1738: sun begins to decline towards the western heights. But quaint as these
1739: buildings are, some of them seem to the historical memory a too modern
1740: substitute for the famous houses of the Bardi family, destroyed by
1741: popular rage in the middle of the fourteenth century.
1742: 
1743: They were a proud and energetic stock, these Bardi; conspicuous among
1744: those who clutched the sword in the earliest world-famous quarrels of
1745: Florentines with Florentines, when the narrow streets were darkened
1746: with the high towers of the nobles, and when the old tutelar god Mars,
1747: as he saw the gutters reddened with neighbours’ blood, might well have
1748: smiled at the centuries of lip-service paid to his rival, the Baptist.
1749: But the Bardi hands were of the sort that not only clutch the
1750: sword-hilt with vigour, but love the more delicate pleasure of
1751: fingering minted metal: they were matched, too, with true Florentine
1752: eyes, capable of discerning that power was to be won by other means
1753: than by rending and riving, and by the middle of the fourteenth century
1754: we find them risen from their original condition of _popolani_ to be
1755: possessors, by purchase, of lands and strongholds, and the feudal
1756: dignity of Counts of Vernio, disturbing to the jealousy of their
1757: republican fellow-citizens. These lordly purchases are explained by our
1758: seeing the Bardi disastrously signalised only a few years later as
1759: standing in the very front of European commerce—the Christian
1760: Rothschilds of that time—undertaking to furnish specie for the wars of
1761: our Edward the Third, and having revenues “in kind” made over to them;
1762: especially in wool, most precious of freights for Florentine galleys.
1763: Their august debtor left them with an august deficit, and alarmed
1764: Sicilian creditors made a too sudden demand for the payment of
1765: deposits, causing a ruinous shock to the credit of the Bardi and of
1766: associated houses, which was felt as a commercial calamity along all
1767: the coasts of the Mediterranean. But, like more modern bankrupts, they
1768: did not, for all that, hide their heads in humiliation; on the
1769: contrary, they seemed to have held them higher than ever, and to have
1770: been among the most arrogant of those grandees, who under certain
1771: noteworthy circumstances, open to all who will read the honest pages of
1772: Giovanni Villani, drew upon themselves the exasperation of the armed
1773: people in 1343. The Bardi, who had made themselves fast in their street
1774: between the two bridges, kept these narrow inlets, like panthers at
1775: bay, against the oncoming gonfalons of the people, and were only made
1776: to give way by an assault from the hill behind them. Their houses by
1777: the river, to the number of twenty-two (_palagi e case grandi_), were
1778: sacked and burnt, and many among the chief of those who bore the Bardi
1779: name were driven from the city. But an old Florentine family was
1780: many-rooted, and we find the Bardi maintaining importance and rising
1781: again and again to the surface of Florentine affairs in a more or less
1782: creditable manner, implying an untold family history that would have
1783: included even more vicissitudes and contrasts of dignity and disgrace,
1784: of wealth and poverty, than are usually seen on the background of wide
1785: kinship.[1] But the Bardi never resumed their proprietorship in the old
1786: street on the banks of the river, which in 1492 had long been
1787: associated with other names of mark, and especially with the Neri, who
1788: possessed a considerable range of houses on the side towards the hill.
1789: 
1790:  [1] A sign that such contrasts were peculiarly frequent in Florence,
1791:  is the fact that Saint Antonine, Prior of San Marco, and afterwards
1792:  archbishop, in the first half of this fifteenth century, founded the
1793:  society of Buonuomini di San Martino (Good Men of Saint Martin) with
1794:  the main object of succouring the _poveri vergognosi_—in other words,
1795:  paupers of good family. In the records of the famous Panciatichi
1796:  family we find a certain Girolamo in this century who was reduced to
1797:  such a state of poverty that he was obliged to seek charity for the
1798:  mere means of sustaining life, though other members of his family were
1799:  enormously wealthy.
1800: 
1801: 
1802: In one of these Neri houses there lived, however, a descendant of the
1803: Bardi, and of that very branch which a century and a half before had
1804: become Counts of Vernio: a descendant who had inherited the old family
1805: pride and energy, the old love of pre-eminence, the old desire to leave
1806: a lasting track of his footsteps on the fast-whirling earth. But the
1807: family passions lived on in him under altered conditions: this
1808: descendant of the Bardi was not a man swift in street warfare, or one
1809: who loved to play the signor, fortifying strongholds and asserting the
1810: right to hang vassals, or a merchant and usurer of keen daring, who
1811: delighted in the generalship of wide commercial schemes: he was a man
1812: with a deep-veined hand cramped by much copying of manuscripts, who ate
1813: sparing dinners, and wore threadbare clothes, at first from choice and
1814: at last from necessity; who sat among his books and his marble
1815: fragments of the past, and saw them only by the light of those far-off
1816: younger days which still shone in his memory: he was a moneyless, blind
1817: old scholar—the Bardo de’ Bardi to whom Nello, the barber, had promised
1818: to introduce the young Greek, Tito Melema.
1819: 
1820: The house in which Bardo lived was situated on the side of the street
1821: nearest the hill, and was one of those large sombre masses of stone
1822: building pierced by comparatively small windows, and surmounted by what
1823: may be called a roofed terrace or loggia, of which there are many
1824: examples still to be seen in the venerable city. Grim doors, with
1825: conspicuous scrolled hinges, having high up on each side of them a
1826: small window defended by iron bars, opened on a groined entrance-court,
1827: empty of everything but a massive lamp-iron suspended from the centre
1828: of the groin. A smaller grim door on the left-hand admitted to the
1829: stone staircase, and the rooms on the ground-floor. These last were
1830: used as a warehouse by the proprietor; so was the first floor; and both
1831: were filled with precious stores, destined to be carried, some perhaps
1832: to the banks of the Scheldt, some to the shores of Africa, some to the
1833: isles of the Aegean, or to the banks of the Euxine. Maso, the old
1834: serving-man, when he returned from the Mercato with the stock of cheap
1835: vegetables, had to make his slow way up to the second storey before he
1836: reached the door of his master, Bardo, through which we are about to
1837: enter only a few mornings after Nello’s conversation with the Greek.
1838: 
1839: We follow Maso across the ante-chamber to the door on the left-hand,
1840: through which we pass as he opens it. He merely looks in and nods,
1841: while a clear young voice says, “Ah, you are come back, Maso. It is
1842: well. We have wanted nothing.”
1843: 
1844: The voice came from the farther end of a long, spacious room,
1845: surrounded with shelves, on which books and antiquities were arranged
1846: in scrupulous order. Here and there, on separate stands in front of the
1847: shelves, were placed a beautiful feminine torso; a headless statue,
1848: with an uplifted muscular arm wielding a bladeless sword; rounded,
1849: dimpled, infantine limbs severed from the trunk, inviting the lips to
1850: kiss the cold marble; some well-preserved Roman busts; and two or three
1851: vases from Magna Grecia. A large table in the centre was covered with
1852: antique bronze lamps and small vessels in dark pottery. The colour of
1853: these objects was chiefly pale or sombre: the vellum bindings, with
1854: their deep-ridged backs, gave little relief to the marble, livid with
1855: long burial; the once splendid patch of carpet at the farther end of
1856: the room had long been worn to dimness; the dark bronzes wanted
1857: sunlight upon them to bring out their tinge of green, and the sun was
1858: not yet high enough to send gleams of brightness through the narrow
1859: windows that looked on the Via de’ Bardi.
1860: 
1861: The only spot of bright colour in the room was made by the hair of a
1862: tall maiden of seventeen or eighteen, who was standing before a carved
1863: _leggio_, or reading-desk, such as is often seen in the choirs of
1864: Italian churches. The hair was of a reddish gold colour, enriched by an
1865: unbroken small ripple, such as may be seen in the sunset clouds on
1866: grandest autumnal evenings. It was confined by a black fillet above her
1867: small ears, from which it rippled forward again, and made a natural
1868: veil for her neck above her square-cut gown of black _rascia_, or
1869: serge. Her eyes were bent on a large volume placed before her: one long
1870: white hand rested on the reading-desk, and the other clasped the back
1871: of her father’s chair.
1872: 
1873: The blind father sat with head uplifted and turned a little aside
1874: towards his daughter, as if he were looking at her. His delicate
1875: paleness, set off by the black velvet cap which surmounted his drooping
1876: white hair, made all the more perceptible the likeness between his aged
1877: features and those of the young maiden, whose cheeks were also without
1878: any tinge of the rose. There was the same refinement of brow and
1879: nostril in both, counterbalanced by a full though firm mouth and
1880: powerful chin, which gave an expression of proud tenacity and latent
1881: impetuousness: an expression carried out in the backward poise of the
1882: girl’s head, and the grand line of her neck and shoulders. It was a
1883: type of face of which one could not venture to say whether it would
1884: inspire love or only that unwilling admiration which is mixed with
1885: dread: the question must be decided by the eyes, which often seem
1886: charged with a more direct message from the soul. But the eyes of the
1887: father had long been silent, and the eyes of the daughter were bent on
1888: the Latin pages of Politian’s ‘Miscellanea,’ from which she was reading
1889: aloud at the eightieth chapter, to the following effect:—
1890: 
1891: “There was a certain nymph of Thebes named Chariclo, especially dear to
1892: Pallas; and this nymph was the mother of Teiresias. But once when in
1893: the heat of summer, Pallas, in company with Chariclo, was bathing her
1894: disrobed limbs in the Heliconian Hippocrene, it happened that Teiresias
1895: coming as a hunter to quench his thirst at the same fountain,
1896: inadvertently beheld Minerva unveiled, and immediately became blind.
1897: For it is declared in the Saturnian laws, that he who beholds the gods
1898: against their will, shall atone for it by a heavy penalty... When
1899: Teiresias had fallen into this calamity, Pallas, moved by the tears of
1900: Chariclo, endowed him with prophecy and length of days, and even caused
1901: his prudence and wisdom to continue after he had entered among the
1902: shades, so that an oracle spake from his tomb: and she gave him a
1903: staff, wherewith, as by a guide, he might walk without stumbling... And
1904: hence, Nonnus, in the fifth book of the ‘Dionysiaca,’ introduces
1905: Actreon exclaiming that he calls Teiresias happy, since, without dying,
1906: and with the loss of his eyesight merely, he had beheld Minerva
1907: unveiled, and thus, though blind, could for evermore carry her image in
1908: his soul.”
1909: 
1910: At this point in the reading, the daughter’s hand slipped from the back
1911: of the chair and met her father’s, which he had that moment uplifted;
1912: but she had not looked round, and was going on, though with a voice a
1913: little altered by some suppressed feeling, to read the Greek quotation
1914: from Nonnus, when the old man said—
1915: 
1916: “Stay, Romola; reach me my own copy of Nonnus. It is a more correct
1917: copy than any in Poliziano’s hands, for I made emendations in it which
1918: have not yet been communicated to any man. I finished it in 1477, when
1919: my sight was fast failing me.”
1920: 
1921: Romola walked to the farther end of the room, with the queenly step
1922: which was the simple action of her tall, finely-wrought frame, without
1923: the slightest conscious adjustment of herself.
1924: 
1925: “Is it in the right place, Romola?” asked Bardo, who was perpetually
1926: seeking the assurance that the outward fact continued to correspond
1927: with the image which lived to the minutest detail in his mind.
1928: 
1929: “Yes, father; at the west end of the room, on the third shelf from the
1930: bottom, behind the bust of Hadrian, above Apollonius Rhodius and
1931: Callimachus, and below Lucan and Silius Italicus.”
1932: 
1933: As Romola said this, a fine ear would have detected in her clear voice
1934: and distinct utterance, a faint suggestion of weariness struggling with
1935: habitual patience. But as she approached her father and saw his arms
1936: stretched out a little with nervous excitement to seize the volume, her
1937: hazel eyes filled with pity; she hastened to lay the book on his lap,
1938: and kneeled down by him, looking up at him as if she believed that the
1939: love in her face must surely make its way through the dark obstruction
1940: that shut out everything else. At that moment the doubtful
1941: attractiveness of Romola’s face, in which pride and passion seemed to
1942: be quivering in the balance with native refinement and intelligence,
1943: was transfigured to the most lovable womanliness by mingled pity and
1944: affection: it was evident that the deepest fount of feeling within her
1945: had not yet wrought its way to the less changeful features, and only
1946: found its outlet through her eyes.
1947: 
1948: But the father, unconscious of that soft radiance, looked flushed and
1949: agitated as his hand explored the edges and back of the large book.
1950: 
1951: “The vellum is yellowed in these thirteen years, Romola.”
1952: 
1953: “Yes, father,” said Romola, gently; “but your letters at the back are
1954: dark and plain still—fine Roman letters; and the Greek character,” she
1955: continued, laying the book open on her father’s knee, “is more
1956: beautiful than that of any of your bought manuscripts.”
1957: 
1958: “Assuredly, child,” said Bardo, passing his finger across the page, as
1959: if he hoped to discriminate line and margin. “What hired amanuensis can
1960: be equal to the scribe who loves the words that grow under his hand,
1961: and to whom an error or indistinctness in the text is more painful than
1962: a sudden darkness or obstacle across his path? And even these
1963: mechanical printers who threaten to make learning a base and vulgar
1964: thing—even they must depend on the manuscript over which we scholars
1965: have bent with that insight into the poet’s meaning which is closely
1966: akin to the _mens divinior_ of the poet himself; unless they would
1967: flood the world with grammatical falsities and inexplicable anomalies
1968: that would turn the very fountain of Parnassus into a deluge of
1969: poisonous mud. But find the passage in the fifth book, to which
1970: Poliziano refers—I know it very well.”
1971: 
1972: Seating herself on a low stool, close to her father’s knee, Romola took
1973: the book on her lap and read the four verses containing the exclamation
1974: of Actreon.
1975: 
1976: “It is true, Romola,” said Bardo, when she had finished; “it is a true
1977: conception of the poet; for what is that grosser, narrower light by
1978: which men behold merely the petty scene around them, compared with that
1979: far-stretching, lasting light which spreads over centuries of thought,
1980: and over the life of nations, and makes clear to us the minds of the
1981: immortals who have reaped the great harvest and left us to glean in
1982: their furrows? For me, Romola, even when I could see, it was with the
1983: great dead that I lived; while the living often seemed to me mere
1984: spectres—shadows dispossessed of true feeling and intelligence; and
1985: unlike those Lamiae, to whom Poliziano, with that superficial ingenuity
1986: which I do not deny to him, compares our inquisitive Florentines,
1987: because they put on their eyes when they went abroad, and took them off
1988: when they got home again, I have returned from the converse of the
1989: streets as from a forgotten dream, and have sat down among my books,
1990: saying with Petrarca, the modern who is least unworthy to be named
1991: after the ancients, ‘Libri medullitus delectant, colloquuntur,
1992: consulunt, et viva quadam nobis atque arguta familiaritate junguntur.’”
1993: 
1994: “And in one thing you are happier than your favourite Petrarca,
1995: father,” said Romola, affectionately humouring the old man’s
1996: disposition to dilate in this way; “for he used to look at his copy of
1997: Homer and think sadly that the Greek was a dead letter to him: so far,
1998: he had the inward blindness that you feel is worse than your outward
1999: blindness.”
2000: 
2001: “True, child; for I carry within me the fruits of that fervid study
2002: which I gave to the Greek tongue under the teaching of the younger
2003: Crisolora, and Filelfo, and Argiropulo; though that great work in which
2004: I had desired to gather, as into a firm web, all the threads that my
2005: research had laboriously disentangled, and which would have been the
2006: vintage of my life, was cut off by the failure of my sight and my want
2007: of a fitting coadjutor. For the sustained zeal and unconquerable
2008: patience demanded from those who would tread the unbeaten paths of
2009: knowledge are still less reconcilable with the wandering, vagrant
2010: propensity of the feminine mind than with the feeble powers of the
2011: feminine body.”
2012: 
2013: “Father,” said Romola, with a sudden flush and in an injured tone, “I
2014: read anything you wish me to read; and I will look out any passages for
2015: you, and make whatever notes you want.”
2016: 
2017: Bardo shook his head, and smiled with a bitter sort of pity. “As well
2018: try to be a pentathlos and perform all the five feats of the palaestra
2019: with the limbs of a nymph. Have I forgotten thy fainting in the mere
2020: search for the references I needed to explain a single passage of
2021: Callimachus?”
2022: 
2023: “But, father, it was the weight of the books, and Maso can help me; it
2024: was not want of attention and patience.”
2025: 
2026: Bardo shook his head again. “It is not mere bodily organs that I want:
2027: it is the sharp edge of a young mind to pierce the way for my somewhat
2028: blunted faculties. For blindness acts like a dam, sending the streams
2029: of thought backward along the already-travelled channels and hindering
2030: the course onward. If my son had not forsaken me, deluded by debasing
2031: fanatical dreams, worthy only of an energumen whose dwelling is among
2032: tombs, I might have gone on and seen my path broadening to the end of
2033: my life; for he was a youth of great promise. But it has closed in
2034: now,” the old man continued, after a short pause; “it has closed in
2035: now;—all but the narrow track he has left me to tread—alone in my
2036: blindness.”
2037: 
2038: Romola started from her seat, and carried away the large volume to its
2039: place again, stung too acutely by her father’s last words to remain
2040: motionless as well as silent; and when she turned away from the shelf
2041: again, she remained standing at some distance from him, stretching her
2042: arms downwards and clasping her fingers tightly as she looked with a
2043: sad dreariness in her young face at the lifeless objects around her—the
2044: parchment backs, the unchanging mutilated marble, the bits of obsolete
2045: bronze and clay.
2046: 
2047: Bardo, though usually susceptible to Romola’s movements and eager to
2048: trace them, was now too entirely preoccupied by the pain of rankling
2049: memories to notice her departure from his side.
2050: 
2051: “Yes,” he went on, “with my son to aid me, I might have had my due
2052: share in the triumphs of this century: the names of the Bardi, father
2053: and son, might have been held reverently on the lips of scholars in the
2054: ages to come; not on account of frivolous verses or philosophical
2055: treatises, which are superfluous and presumptuous attempts to imitate
2056: the inimitable, such as allure vain men like Panhormita, and from which
2057: even the admirable Poggio did not keep himself sufficiently free; but
2058: because we should have given a lamp whereby men might have studied the
2059: supreme productions of the past. For why is a young man like Poliziano
2060: (who was not yet born when I was already held worthy to maintain a
2061: discussion with Thomas of Sarzana) to have a glorious memory as a
2062: commentator on the Pandects—why is Ficino, whose Latin is an offence to
2063: me, and who wanders purblind among the superstitious fancies that
2064: marked the decline at once of art, literature, and philosophy, to
2065: descend to posterity as the very high priest of Platonism, while I, who
2066: am more than their equal, have not effected anything but scattered
2067: work, which will be appropriated by other men? Why? but because my son,
2068: whom I had brought up to replenish my ripe learning with young
2069: enterprise, left me and all liberal pursuits that he might lash himself
2070: and howl at midnight with besotted friars—that he might go wandering on
2071: pilgrimages befitting men who know of no past older than the missal and
2072: the crucifix?—left me when the night was already beginning to fall on
2073: me.”
2074: 
2075: In these last words the old man’s voice, which had risen high in
2076: indignant protest, fell into a tone of reproach so tremulous and
2077: plaintive that Romola, turning her eyes again towards the blind aged
2078: face, felt her heart swell with forgiving pity. She seated herself by
2079: her father again, and placed her hand on his knee—too proud to obtrude
2080: consolation in words that might seem like a vindication of her own
2081: value, yet wishing to comfort him by some sign of her presence.
2082: 
2083: “Yes, Romola,” said Bardo, automatically letting his left-hand, with
2084: its massive prophylactic rings, fall a little too heavily on the
2085: delicate blue-veined back of the girl’s right, so that she bit her lip
2086: to prevent herself from starting. “If even Florence only is to remember
2087: me, it can but be on the same ground that it will remember Niccolò
2088: Niccoli—because I forsook the vulgar pursuit of wealth in commerce that
2089: I might devote myself to collecting the precious remains of ancient art
2090: and wisdom, and leave them, after the example of the munificent Romans,
2091: for an everlasting possession to my fellow-citizens. But why do I say
2092: Florence only? If Florence remembers me, will not the world remember
2093: me? ... Yet,” added Bardo, after a short pause, his voice falling again
2094: into a saddened key, “Lorenzo’s untimely death has raised a new
2095: difficulty. I had his promise—I should have had his bond—that my
2096: collection should always bear my name and should never be sold, though
2097: the harpies might clutch everything else; but there is enough for
2098: them—there is more than enough—and for thee, too, Romola, there will be
2099: enough. Besides, thou wilt marry; Bernardo reproaches me that I do not
2100: seek a fitting _parentado_ for thee, and we will delay no longer, we
2101: will think about it.”
2102: 
2103: “No, no, father; what could you do? besides, it is useless: wait till
2104: some one seeks me,” said Romola, hastily.
2105: 
2106: “Nay, my child, that is not the paternal duty. It was not so held by
2107: the ancients, and in this respect Florentines have not degenerated from
2108: their ancestral customs.”
2109: 
2110: “But I will study diligently,” said Romola, her eyes dilating with
2111: anxiety. “I will become as learned as Cassandra Fedele: I will try and
2112: be as useful to you as if I had been a boy, and then perhaps some great
2113: scholar will want to marry me, and will not mind about a dowry; and he
2114: will like to come and live with you, and he will be to you in place of
2115: my brother... and you will not be sorry that I was a daughter.”
2116: 
2117: There was a rising sob in Romola’s voice as she said the last words,
2118: which touched the fatherly fibre in Bardo. He stretched his hand upward
2119: a little in search of her golden hair, and as she placed her head under
2120: his hand, he gently stroked it, leaning towards her as if his eyes
2121: discerned some glimmer there.
2122: 
2123: “Nay, Romola mia, I said not so; if I have pronounced an anathema on a
2124: degenerate and ungrateful son, I said not that I could wish thee other
2125: than the sweet daughter thou hast been to me. For what son could have
2126: tended me so gently in the frequent sickness I have had of late? And
2127: even in learning thou art not, according to thy measure, contemptible.
2128: Something perhaps were to be wished in thy capacity of attention and
2129: memory, not incompatible even with the feminine mind. But as Calcondila
2130: bore testimony, when he aided me to teach thee, thou hast a ready
2131: apprehension, and even a wide-glancing intelligence. And thou hast a
2132: man’s nobility of soul: thou hast never fretted me with thy petty
2133: desires as thy mother did. It is true, I have been careful to keep thee
2134: aloof from the debasing influence of thy own sex, with their
2135: sparrow-like frivolity and their enslaving superstition, except,
2136: indeed, from that of our cousin Brigida, who may well serve as a
2137: scarecrow and a warning. And though—since I agree with the divine
2138: Petrarca, when he declares, quoting the ‘Aulularia’ of Plautus, who
2139: again was indebted for the truth to the supreme Greek intellect,
2140: ‘Optimam foeminam nullam esse, alia licet alia pejor sit’—I cannot
2141: boast that thou art entirely lifted out of that lower category to which
2142: Nature assigned thee, nor even that in erudition thou art on a par with
2143: the more learned women of this age; thou art, nevertheless—yes, Romola
2144: mia,” said the old man, his pedantry again melting into tenderness,
2145: “thou art my sweet daughter, and thy voice is as the lower notes of the
2146: flute, ‘dulcis, durabilis, clara, pura, secans aëra et auribus sedens,’
2147: according to the choice words of Quintilian; and Bernardo tells me thou
2148: art fair, and thy hair is like the brightness of the morning, and
2149: indeed it seems to me that I discern some radiance from thee. Ah! I
2150: know how all else looks in this room, but thy form I only guess at.
2151: Thou art no longer the little woman six years old, that faded for me
2152: into darkness; thou art tall, and thy arm is but little below mine. Let
2153: us walk together.”
2154: 
2155: The old man rose, and Romola, soothed by these beams of tenderness,
2156: looked happy again as she drew his arm within hers, and placed in his
2157: right-hand the stick which rested at the side of his chair. While Bardo
2158: had been sitting, he had seemed hardly more than sixty: his face,
2159: though pale, had that refined texture in which wrinkles and lines are
2160: never deep; but now that he began to walk he looked as old as he really
2161: was—rather more than seventy; for his tall spare frame had the
2162: student’s stoop of the shoulders, and he stepped with the undecided
2163: gait of the blind.
2164: 
2165: “No, Romola,” he said, pausing against the bust of Hadrian, and passing
2166: his stick from the right to the left that he might explore the familiar
2167: outline with a “seeing hand.” “There will be nothing else to preserve
2168: my memory and carry down my name as a member of the great republic of
2169: letters—nothing but my library and my collection of antiquities. And
2170: they are choice,” continued Bardo, pressing the bust and speaking in a
2171: tone of insistence. “The collections of Niccolò I know were larger; but
2172: take any collection which is the work of a single man—that of the great
2173: Boccaccio even—mine will surpass it. That of Poggio was contemptible
2174: compared with mine. It will be a great gift to unborn scholars. And
2175: there is nothing else. For even if I were to yield to the wish of Aldo
2176: Manuzio when he sets up his press at Venice, and give him the aid of my
2177: annotated manuscripts, I know well what would be the result: some other
2178: scholar’s name would stand on the title-page of the edition—some
2179: scholar who would have fed on my honey, and then declared in his
2180: preface that he had gathered it all himself fresh from Hymettus. Else,
2181: why have I refused the loan of many an annotated codex? why have I
2182: refused to make public any of my translations? why? but because
2183: scholarship is a system of licenced robbery, and your man in scarlet
2184: and furred robe who sits in judgment on thieves, is himself a thief of
2185: the thoughts and the fame that belong to his fellows. But against that
2186: robbery Bardo de’ Bardi shall struggle—though blind and forsaken, he
2187: shall struggle. I too have a right to be remembered—as great a right as
2188: Pontanus or Merula, whose names will be foremost on the lips of
2189: posterity, because they sought patronage and found it; because they had
2190: tongues that could flatter, and blood that was used to be nourished
2191: from the client’s basket. I have a right to be remembered.”
2192: 
2193: The old man’s voice had become at once loud and tremulous, and a pink
2194: flush overspread his proud, delicately-cut features, while the
2195: habitually raised attitude of his head gave the idea that behind the
2196: curtain of his blindness he saw some imaginary high tribunal to which
2197: he was appealing against the injustice of Fame.
2198: 
2199: Romola was moved with sympathetic indignation, for in her nature too
2200: there lay the same large claims, and the same spirit of struggle
2201: against their denial. She tried to calm her father by a still prouder
2202: word than his.
2203: 
2204: “Nevertheless, father, it is a great gift of the gods to be born with a
2205: hatred and contempt of all injustice and meanness. Yours is a higher
2206: lot, never to have lied and truckled, than to have shared honours won
2207: by dishonour. There is strength in scorn, as there was in the martial
2208: fury by which men became insensible to wounds.”
2209: 
2210: “It is well said, Romola. It is a Promethean word thou hast uttered,”
2211: answered Bardo, after a little interval in which he had begun to lean
2212: on his stick again, and to walk on. “And I indeed am not to be pierced
2213: by the shafts of Fortune. My armour is the _aes triplex_ of a clear
2214: conscience, and a mind nourished by the precepts of philosophy. ‘For
2215: men,’ says Epictetus, ‘are disturbed not by things themselves, but by
2216: their opinions or thoughts concerning those things.’ And again,
2217: ‘whosoever will be free, let him not desire or dread that which it is
2218: in the power of others either to deny or inflict: otherwise, he is a
2219: slave.’ And of all such gifts as are dependent on the caprice of
2220: fortune or of men, I have long ago learned to say, with Horace—who,
2221: however, is too wavering in his philosophy, vacillating between the
2222: precepts of Zeno and the less worthy maxims of Epicurus, and
2223: attempting, as we say, ‘duabus sellis sedere’—concerning such
2224: accidents, I say, with the pregnant brevity of the poet—
2225: 
2226:     ‘Sunt qui non habeant, est qui non curat habere.’
2227: 
2228: “He is referring to gems, and purple, and other insignia of wealth; but
2229: I may apply his words not less justly to the tributes men pay us with
2230: their lips and their pens, which are also matters of purchase, and
2231: often with base coin. Yes, ‘_inanis_’—hollow, empty—is the epithet
2232: justly bestowed on Fame.”
2233: 
2234: They made the tour of the room in silence after this; but Bardo’s
2235: lip-born maxims were as powerless over the passion which had been
2236: moving him, as if they had been written on parchment and hung round his
2237: neck in a sealed bag; and he presently broke forth again in a new tone
2238: of insistence.
2239: 
2240: “_Inanis_? yes, if it is a lying fame; but not if it is the just meed
2241: of labour and a great purpose. I claim my right: it is not fair that
2242: the work of my brain and my hands should not be a monument to me—it is
2243: not just that my labour should bear the name of another man. It is but
2244: little to ask,” the old man went on, bitterly, “that my name should be
2245: over the door—that men should own themselves debtors to the Bardi
2246: Library in Florence. They will speak coldly of me, perhaps: ‘a diligent
2247: collector and transcriber,’ they will say, ‘and also of some critical
2248: ingenuity, but one who could hardly be conspicuous in an age so
2249: fruitful in illustrious scholars. Yet he merits our pity, for in the
2250: latter years of his life he was blind, and his only son, to whose
2251: education he had devoted his best years—’ Nevertheless, my name will be
2252: remembered, and men will honour me: not with the breath of flattery,
2253: purchased by mean bribes, but because I have laboured, and because my
2254: labours will remain. Debts! I know there are debts; and there is thy
2255: dowry, Romola, to be paid. But there must be enough—or, at least, there
2256: can lack but a small sum, such as the Signoria might well provide. And
2257: if Lorenzo had not died, all would have been secured and settled. But
2258: now...”
2259: 
2260: At this moment Maso opened the door, and advancing to his master,
2261: announced that Nello, the barber, had desired him to say, that he was
2262: come with the Greek scholar whom he had asked leave to introduce.
2263: 
2264: “It is well,” said the old man. “Bring them in.”
2265: 
2266: Bardo, conscious that he looked more dependent when he was walking,
2267: liked always to be seated in the presence of strangers, and Romola,
2268: without needing to be told, conducted him to his chair. She was
2269: standing by him at her full height, in quiet majestic self-possession,
2270: when the visitors entered; and the most penetrating observer would
2271: hardly have divined that this proud pale face, at the slightest touch
2272: on the fibres of affection or pity, could become passionate with
2273: tenderness, or that this woman, who imposed a certain awe on those who
2274: approached her, was in a state of girlish simplicity and ignorance
2275: concerning the world outside her father’s books.
2276: 
2277: 
2278: 
2279: 
2280: CHAPTER VI.
2281: Dawning Hopes.
2282: 
2283: 
2284: When Maso opened the door again, and ushered in the two visitors,
2285: Nello, first making a deep reverence to Romola, gently pushed Tito
2286: before him, and advanced with him towards her father.
2287: 
2288: “Messer Bardo,” he said, in a more measured and respectful tone than
2289: was usual with him, “I have the honour of presenting to you the Greek
2290: scholar, who has been eager to have speech of you, not less from the
2291: report I have made to him of your learning and your priceless
2292: collections, than because of the furtherance your patronage may give
2293: him under the transient need to which he has been reduced by shipwreck.
2294: His name is Tito Melema, at your service.”
2295: 
2296: Romola’s astonishment could hardly have been greater if the stranger
2297: had worn a panther-skin and carried a thyrsus; for the cunning barber
2298: had said nothing of the Greek’s age or appearance; and among her
2299: father’s scholarly visitors, she had hardly ever seen any but
2300: middle-aged or grey-headed men. There was only one masculine face, at
2301: once youthful and beautiful, the image of which remained deeply
2302: impressed on her mind: it was that of her brother, who long years ago
2303: had taken her on his knee, kissed her, and never come back again: a
2304: fair face, with sunny hair, like her own. But the habitual attitude of
2305: her mind towards strangers—a proud self-dependence and determination to
2306: ask for nothing even by a smile—confirmed in her by her father’s
2307: complaints against the world’s injustice, was like a snowy embankment
2308: hemming in the rush of admiring surprise. Tito’s bright face showed its
2309: rich-tinted beauty without any rivalry of colour above his black _sajo_
2310: or tunic reaching to the knees. It seemed like a wreath of spring,
2311: dropped suddenly in Romola’s young but wintry life, which had inherited
2312: nothing but memories—memories of a dead mother, of a lost brother, of a
2313: blind father’s happier time—memories of far-off light, love, and
2314: beauty, that lay embedded in dark mines of books, and could hardly give
2315: out their brightness again until they were kindled for her by the torch
2316: of some known joy. Nevertheless, she returned Tito’s bow, made to her
2317: on entering, with the same pale proud face as ever; but, as he
2318: approached, the snow melted, and when he ventured to look towards her
2319: again, while Nello was speaking, a pink flush overspread her face, to
2320: vanish again almost immediately, as if her imperious will had recalled
2321: it. Tito’s glance, on the contrary, had that gentle, beseeching
2322: admiration in it which is the most propitiating of appeals to a proud,
2323: shy woman, and is perhaps the only atonement a man can make for being
2324: too handsome. The finished fascination of his air came chiefly from the
2325: absence of demand and assumption. It was that of a fleet, soft-coated,
2326: dark-eyed animal that delights you by not bounding away in indifference
2327: from you, and unexpectedly pillows its chin on your palm, and looks up
2328: at you desiring to be stroked—as if it loved you.
2329: 
2330: “Messere, I give you welcome,” said Bardo, with some condescension;
2331: “misfortune wedded to learning, and especially to Greek learning, is a
2332: letter of credit that should win the ear of every instructed
2333: Florentine; for, as you are doubtless aware, since the period when your
2334: countryman, Manuelo Crisolora, diffused the light of his teaching in
2335: the chief cities of Italy, now nearly a century ago, no man is held
2336: worthy of the name of scholar who has acquired merely the transplanted
2337: and derivative literature of the Latins; rather, such inert students
2338: are stigmatised as _opici_ or barbarians according to the phrase of the
2339: Romans themselves, who frankly replenished their urns at the
2340: fountain-head. I am, as you perceive, and as Nello has doubtless
2341: forewarned you, totally blind: a calamity to which we Florentines are
2342: held especially liable, whether owing to the cold winds which rush upon
2343: us in spring from the passes of the Apennines, or to that sudden
2344: transition from the cool gloom of our houses to the dazzling brightness
2345: of our summer sun, by which the _lippi_ are said to have been made so
2346: numerous among the ancient Romans; or, in fine, to some occult cause
2347: which eludes our superficial surmises. But I pray you be seated: Nello,
2348: my friend, be seated.”
2349: 
2350: Bardo paused until his fine ear had assured him that the visitors were
2351: seating themselves, and that Romola was taking her usual chair at his
2352: right-hand. Then he said—
2353: 
2354: “From what part of Greece do you come, Messere? I had thought that your
2355: unhappy country had been almost exhausted of those sons who could
2356: cherish in their minds any image of her original glory, though indeed
2357: the barbarous Sultans have of late shown themselves not indisposed to
2358: engraft on their wild stock the precious vine which their own fierce
2359: bands have hewn down and trampled under foot. From what part of Greece
2360: do you come?”
2361: 
2362: “I sailed last from Nauplia,” said Tito; “but I have resided both at
2363: Constantinople and Thessalonica, and have travelled in various parts
2364: little visited by Western Christians since the triumph of the Turkish
2365: arms. I should tell you, however, Messere, that I was not born in
2366: Greece, but at Bari. I spent the first sixteen years of my life in
2367: Southern Italy and Sicily.”
2368: 
2369: While Tito was speaking, some emotion passed, like a breath on the
2370: waters, across Bardo’s delicate features; he leaned forward, put out
2371: his right-hand towards Romola, and turned his head as if about to speak
2372: to her; but then, correcting himself, turned away again, and said, in a
2373: subdued voice—
2374: 
2375: “Excuse me; is it not true—you are young?”
2376: 
2377: “I am three-and-twenty,” said Tito.
2378: 
2379: “Ah,” said Bardo, still in a tone of subdued excitement, “and you had,
2380: doubtless, a father who cared for your early instruction—who, perhaps,
2381: was himself a scholar?”
2382: 
2383: There was a slight pause before Tito’s answer came to the ear of Bardo;
2384: but for Romola and Nello it began with a slight shock that seemed to
2385: pass through him, and cause a momentary quivering of the lip; doubtless
2386: at the revival of a supremely painful remembrance.
2387: 
2388: “Yes,” he replied, “at least a father by adoption. He was a Neapolitan,
2389: and of accomplished scholarship, both Latin and Greek. But,” added
2390: Tito, after another slight pause, “he is lost to me—was lost on a
2391: voyage he too rashly undertook to Delos.”
2392: 
2393: Bardo sank backward again, too delicate to ask another question that
2394: might probe a sorrow which he divined to be recent. Romola, who knew
2395: well what were the fibres that Tito’s voice had stirred in her father,
2396: felt that this new acquaintance had with wonderful suddenness got
2397: within the barrier that lay between them and the alien world. Nello,
2398: thinking that the evident check given to the conversation offered a
2399: graceful opportunity for relieving himself from silence, said—
2400: 
2401: “In truth, it is as clear as Venetian glass that this fine young man
2402: has had the best training; for the two Cennini have set him to work at
2403: their Greek sheets already, and it seems to me they are not men to
2404: begin cutting before they have felt the edge of their tools; they
2405: tested him well beforehand, we may be sure, and if there are two things
2406: not to be hidden—love and a cough—I say there is a third, and that is
2407: ignorance, when once a man is obliged to do something besides wagging
2408: his head. The _tonsor inequalis_ is inevitably betrayed when he takes
2409: the shears in his hand; is it not true, Messer Bardo? I speak after the
2410: fashion of a barber, but, as Luigi Pulci says—
2411: 
2412: 
2413: “‘Perdonimi s’io fallo: chi m’ascolta
2414: Intenda il mio volgar col suo latino.’”
2415: 
2416: 
2417: “Nay, my good Nello,” said Bardo, with an air of friendly severity,
2418: “you are not altogether illiterate, and might doubtless have made a
2419: more respectable progress in learning if you had abstained somewhat
2420: from the _cicalata_ and gossip of the street-corner, to which our
2421: Florentines are excessively addicted; but still more if you had not
2422: clogged your memory with those frivolous productions of which Luigi
2423: Pulci has furnished the most peccant exemplar—a compendium of
2424: extravagances and incongruities the farthest removed from the models of
2425: a pure age, and resembling rather the _grylli_ or conceits of a period
2426: when mystic meaning was held a warrant for monstrosity of form; with
2427: this difference, that while the monstrosity is retained, the mystic
2428: meaning is absent; in contemptible contrast with the great poem of
2429: Virgil, who, as I long held with Filelfo, before Landino had taken upon
2430: him to expound the same opinion, embodied the deepest lessons of
2431: philosophy in a graceful and well-knit fable. And I cannot but regard
2432: the multiplication of these babbling, lawless productions, albeit
2433: countenanced by the patronage, and in some degree the example of
2434: Lorenzo himself, otherwise a friend to true learning, as a sign that
2435: the glorious hopes of this century are to be quenched in gloom; nay,
2436: that they have been the delusive prologue to an age worse than that of
2437: iron—the age of tinsel and gossamer, in which no thought has substance
2438: enough to be moulded into consistent and lasting form.”
2439: 
2440: “Once more, pardon,” said Nello, opening his palms outwards, and
2441: shrugging his shoulders, “I find myself knowing so many things in good
2442: Tuscan before I have time to think of the Latin for them; and Messer
2443: Luigi’s rhymes are always slipping off the lips of my customers:—that
2444: is what corrupts me. And, indeed, talking of customers, I have left my
2445: shop and my reputation too long in the custody of my slow Sandro, who
2446: does not deserve even to be called a _tonsor inequalis_, but rather to
2447: be pronounced simply a bungler in the vulgar tongue. So with your
2448: permission, Messer Bardo, I will take my leave—well understood that I
2449: am at your service whenever Maso calls upon me. It seems a thousand
2450: years till I dress and perfume the damigella’s hair, which deserves to
2451: shine in the heavens as a constellation, though indeed it were a pity
2452: for it ever to go so far out of reach.”
2453: 
2454: Three voices made a fugue of friendly farewells to Nello, as he
2455: retreated with a bow to Romola and a beck to Tito. The acute barber saw
2456: that the pretty youngster, who had crept into his liking by some strong
2457: magic, was well launched in Bardo’s favourable regard; and satisfied
2458: that his introduction had not miscarried so far, he felt the propriety
2459: of retiring.
2460: 
2461: The little burst of wrath, called forth by Nello’s unlucky quotation,
2462: had diverted Bardo’s mind from the feelings which had just before been
2463: hemming in further speech, and he now addressed Tito again with his
2464: ordinary calmness.
2465: 
2466: “Ah! young man, you are happy in having been able to unite the
2467: advantages of travel with those of study, and you will be welcome among
2468: us as a bringer of fresh tidings from a land which has become sadly
2469: strange to us, except through the agents of a now restricted commerce
2470: and the reports of hasty pilgrims. For those days are in the far
2471: distance which I myself witnessed, when men like Aurispa and Guarino
2472: went out to Greece as to a storehouse, and came back laden with
2473: manuscripts which every scholar was eager to borrow—and, be it owned
2474: with shame, not always willing to restore; nay, even the days when
2475: erudite Greeks flocked to our shores for a refuge, seem far-off
2476: now—farther off than the on-coming of my blindness. But doubtless,
2477: young man, research after the treasures of antiquity was not alien to
2478: the purpose of your travels?”
2479: 
2480: “Assuredly not,” said Tito. “On the contrary, my companion—my
2481: father—was willing to risk his life in his zeal for the discovery of
2482: inscriptions and other traces of ancient civilisation.”
2483: 
2484: “And I trust there is a record of his researches and their results,”
2485: said Bardo, eagerly, “since they must be even more precious than those
2486: of Ciriaco, which I have diligently availed myself of, though they are
2487: not always illuminated by adequate learning.”
2488: 
2489: “There _was_ such a record,” said Tito, “but it was lost, like
2490: everything else, in the shipwreck I suffered below Ancona. The only
2491: record left is such as remains in our—in my memory.”
2492: 
2493: “You must lose no time in committing it to paper, young man,” said
2494: Bardo, with growing interest. “Doubtless you remember much, if you
2495: aided in transcription; for when I was your age, words wrought
2496: themselves into my mind as if they had been fixed by the tool of the
2497: graver; wherefore I constantly marvel at the capriciousness of my
2498: daughter’s memory, which grasps certain objects with tenacity, and lets
2499: fall all those minutiae whereon depends accuracy, the very soul of
2500: scholarship. But I apprehend no such danger with you, young man, if
2501: your will has seconded the advantages of your training.”
2502: 
2503: When Bardo made this reference to his daughter, Tito ventured to turn
2504: his eyes towards her, and at the accusation against her memory his face
2505: broke into its brightest smile, which was reflected as inevitably as
2506: sudden sunbeams in Romola’s. Conceive the soothing delight of that
2507: smile to her! Romola had never dreamed that there was a scholar in the
2508: world who would smile at a deficiency for which she was constantly made
2509: to feel herself a culprit. It was like the dawn of a new sense to
2510: her—the sense of comradeship. They did not look away from each other
2511: immediately, as if the smile had been a stolen one; they looked and
2512: smiled with frank enjoyment.
2513: 
2514: “She is not really so cold and proud,” thought Tito.
2515: 
2516: “Does _he_ forget too, I wonder?” thought Romola, “Yet I hope not, else
2517: he will vex my father.”
2518: 
2519: But Tito was obliged to turn away, and answer Bardo’s question.
2520: 
2521: “I have had much practice in transcription,” he said; “but in the case
2522: of inscriptions copied in memorable scenes, rendered doubly impressive
2523: by the sense of risk and adventure, it may have happened that my
2524: retention of written characters has been weakened. On the plain of the
2525: Eurotas, or among the gigantic stones of Mycenae and Tyrins—especially
2526: when the fear of the Turk hovers over one like a vulture—the mind
2527: wanders, even though the hand writes faithfully what the eye dictates.
2528: But something doubtless I have retained,” added Tito, with a modesty
2529: which was not false, though he was conscious that it was politic,
2530: “something that might be of service if illustrated and corrected by a
2531: wider learning than my own.”
2532: 
2533: “That is well spoken, young man,” said Bardo, delighted. “And I will
2534: not withhold from you such aid as I can give, if you like to
2535: communicate with me concerning your recollections. I foresee a work
2536: which will be a useful supplement to the ‘Isolario’ of Christoforo
2537: Buondelmonte, and which may take rank with the ‘Itineraria’ of Ciriaco
2538: and the admirable Ambrogio Traversari. But we must prepare ourselves
2539: for calumny, young man,” Bardo went on with energy, as if the work were
2540: already growing so fast that the time of trial was near; “if your book
2541: contains novelties you will be charged with forgery; if my elucidations
2542: should clash with any principles of interpretation adopted by another
2543: scholar, our personal characters will be attacked, we shall be
2544: impeached with foul actions; you must prepare yourself to be told that
2545: your mother was a fish-woman, and that your father was a renegade
2546: priest or a hanged malefactor. I myself, for having shown error in a
2547: single preposition, had an invective written against me wherein I was
2548: taxed with treachery, fraud, indecency, and even hideous crimes. Such,
2549: my young friend—such are the flowers with which the glorious path of
2550: scholarship is strewed! But tell me, then: I have learned much
2551: concerning Byzantium and Thessalonica long ago from Demetrio
2552: Calcondila, who has but lately departed from Florence; but you, it
2553: seems, have visited less familiar scenes?”
2554: 
2555: “Yes; we made what I may call a pilgrimage full of danger, for the sake
2556: of visiting places which have almost died out of the memory of the
2557: West, for they lie away from the track of pilgrims; and my father used
2558: to say that scholars themselves hardly imagine them to have any
2559: existence out of books. He was of opinion that a new and more glorious
2560: era would open for learning when men should begin to look for their
2561: commentaries on the ancient writers in the remains of cities and
2562: temples, nay, in the paths of the rivers, and on the face of the
2563: valleys and the mountains.”
2564: 
2565: “Ah!” said Bardo, fervidly, “your father, then, was not a common man.
2566: Was he fortunate, may I ask? Had he many friends?” These last words
2567: were uttered in a tone charged with meaning.
2568: 
2569: “No; he made enemies—chiefly, I believe, by a certain impetuous
2570: candour; and they hindered his advancement, so that he lived in
2571: obscurity. And he would never stoop to conciliate: he could never
2572: forget an injury.”
2573: 
2574: “Ah!” said Bardo again, with a long, deep intonation.
2575: 
2576: “Among our hazardous expeditions,” continued Tito, willing to prevent
2577: further questions on a point so personal, “I remember with particular
2578: vividness a hastily snatched visit to Athens. Our hurry, and the double
2579: danger of being seized as prisoners by the Turks, and of our galley
2580: raising anchor before we could return, made it seem like a fevered
2581: vision of the night—the wide plain, the girdling mountains, the ruined
2582: porticos and columns, either standing far aloof, as if receding from
2583: our hurried footsteps, or else jammed in confusedly among the dwellings
2584: of Christians degraded into servitude, or among the forts and turrets
2585: of their Moslem conquerors, who have their stronghold on the
2586: Acropolis.”
2587: 
2588: “You fill me with surprise,” said Bardo. “Athens, then, is not utterly
2589: destroyed and swept away, as I had imagined?”
2590: 
2591: “No wonder you should be under that mistake, for few even of the Greeks
2592: themselves, who live beyond the mountain boundary of Attica, know
2593: anything about the present condition of Athens, or _Setine_, as the
2594: sailors call it. I remember, as we were rounding the promontory of
2595: Sunium, the Greek pilot we had on board our Venetian galley pointed to
2596: the mighty columns that stand on the summit of the rock—the remains, as
2597: you know well, of the great temple erected to the goddess Athena, who
2598: looked down from that high shrine with triumph at her conquered rival
2599: Poseidon;—well, our Greek pilot, pointing to those columns, said, ‘That
2600: was the school of the great philosopher Aristotle.’ And at Athens
2601: itself, the monk who acted as our guide in the hasty view we snatched,
2602: insisted most on showing us the spot where Saint Philip baptised the
2603: Ethiopian eunuch, or some such legend.”
2604: 
2605: “Talk not of monks and their legends, young man!” said Bardo,
2606: interrupting Tito impetuously. “It is enough to overlay human hope and
2607: enterprise with an eternal frost to think that the ground which was
2608: trodden by philosophers and poets is crawled over by those
2609: insect-swarms of besotted fanatics or howling hypocrites.”
2610: 
2611: “_Perdio_, I have no affection for them,” said Tito, with a shrug;
2612: “servitude agrees well with a religion like theirs, which lies in the
2613: renunciation of all that makes life precious to other men. And they
2614: carry the yoke that befits them: their matin chant is drowned by the
2615: voice of the muezzin, who, from the gallery of the high tower on the
2616: Acropolis, calls every Mussulman to his prayers. That tower springs
2617: from the Parthenon itself; and every time we paused and directed our
2618: eyes towards it, our guide set up a wail, that a temple which had once
2619: been won from the diabolical uses of the pagans to become the temple of
2620: another virgin than Pallas—the Virgin Mother of God—was now again
2621: perverted to the accursed ends of the Moslem. It was the sight of those
2622: walls of the Acropolis, which disclosed themselves in the distance as
2623: we leaned over the side of our galley when it was forced by contrary
2624: winds to anchor in the Piraeus, that fired my father’s mind with the
2625: determination to see Athens at all risks, and in spite of the sailors’
2626: warnings that if we lingered till a change of wind, they would depart
2627: without us: but, after all, it was impossible for us to venture near
2628: the Acropolis, for the sight of men eager in examining ‘old stones’
