2629: raised the suspicion that we were Venetian spies, and we had to hurry
2630: back to the harbour.”
2631: 
2632: “We will talk more of these things,” said Bardo, eagerly. “You must
2633: recall everything, to the minutest trace left in your memory. You will
2634: win the gratitude of after-times by leaving a record of the aspect
2635: Greece bore while yet the barbarians had not swept away every trace of
2636: the structures that Pausanias and Pliny described: you will take those
2637: great writers as your models; and such contribution of criticism and
2638: suggestion as my riper mind can supply shall not be wanting to you.
2639: There will be much to tell; for you have travelled, you said, in the
2640: Peloponnesus?”
2641: 
2642: “Yes; and in Boeotia also: I have rested in the groves of Helicon, and
2643: tasted of the fountain Hippocrene. But on every memorable spot in
2644: Greece conquest after conquest has set its seal, till there is a
2645: confusion of ownership even in ruins, that only close study and
2646: comparison could unravel. High over every fastness, from the plains of
2647: Lacedaemon to the straits of Thermopylae, there towers some huge
2648: Frankish fortress, once inhabited by a French or Italian marquis, now
2649: either abandoned or held by Turkish bands.”
2650: 
2651: “Stay!” cried Bardo, whose mind was now too thoroughly preoccupied by
2652: the idea of the future book to attend to Tito’s further narration. “Do
2653: you think of writing in Latin or Greek? Doubtless Greek is the more
2654: ready clothing for your thoughts, and it is the nobler language. But,
2655: on the other hand, Latin is the tongue in which we shall measure
2656: ourselves with the larger and more famous number of modern rivals. And
2657: if you are less at ease in it, I will aid you—yes, I will spend on you
2658: that long-accumulated study which was to have been thrown into the
2659: channel of another work—a work in which I myself was to have had a
2660: helpmate.”
2661: 
2662: Bardo paused a moment, and then added—
2663: 
2664: “But who knows whether that work may not be executed yet? For you, too,
2665: young man, have been brought up by a father who poured into your mind
2666: all the long-gathered stream of his knowledge and experience. Our aid
2667: might be mutual.”
2668: 
2669: Romola, who had watched her father’s growing excitement, and divined
2670: well the invisible currents of feeling that determined every question
2671: and remark, felt herself in a glow of strange anxiety: she turned her
2672: eyes on Tito continually, to watch the impression her father’s words
2673: made on him, afraid lest he should be inclined to dispel these visions
2674: of co-operation which were lighting up her father’s face with a new
2675: hope. But no! He looked so bright and gentle: he must feel, as she did,
2676: that in this eagerness of blind age there was piteousness enough to
2677: call forth inexhaustible patience. How much more strongly he would feel
2678: this if he knew about her brother! A girl of eighteen imagines the
2679: feelings behind the face that has moved her with its sympathetic youth,
2680: as easily as primitive people imagined the humours of the gods in fair
2681: weather: what is she to believe in, if not in this vision woven from
2682: within?
2683: 
2684: And Tito was really very far from feeling impatient. He delighted in
2685: sitting there with the sense that Romola’s attention was fixed on him,
2686: and that he could occasionally look at her. He was pleased that Bardo
2687: should take an interest in him; and he did not dwell with enough
2688: seriousness on the prospect of the work in which he was to be aided, to
2689: feel moved by it to anything else than that easy, good-humoured
2690: acquiescence which was natural to him.
2691: 
2692: “I shall be proud and happy,” he said, in answer to Bardo’s last words,
2693: “if my services can be held a meet offering to the matured scholarship
2694: of Messere. But doubtless,”—here he looked towards Romola—“the lovely
2695: damigella, your daughter, makes all other aid superfluous; for I have
2696: learned from Nello that she has been nourished on the highest studies
2697: from her earliest years.”
2698: 
2699: “You are mistaken,” said Romola; “I am by no means sufficient to my
2700: father: I have not the gifts that are necessary for scholarship.”
2701: 
2702: Romola did not make this self-depreciatory statement in a tone of
2703: anxious humility, but with a proud gravity.
2704: 
2705: “Nay, my Romola,” said her father, not willing that the stranger should
2706: have too low a conception of his daughter’s powers; “thou art not
2707: destitute of gifts; rather, thou art endowed beyond the measure of
2708: women; but thou hast withal the woman’s delicate frame, which ever
2709: craves repose and variety, and so begets a wandering imagination. My
2710: daughter,”—turning to Tito—“has been very precious to me, filling up to
2711: the best of her power the place of a son. For I had once a son...”
2712: 
2713: Bardo checked himself: he did not wish to assume an attitude of
2714: complaint in the presence of a stranger, and he remembered that this
2715: young man, in whom he had unexpectedly become so much interested, was
2716: still a stranger, towards whom it became him rather to keep the
2717: position of a patron. His pride was roused to double activity by the
2718: fear that he had forgotten his dignity.
2719: 
2720: “But,” he resumed, in his original tone of condescension, “we are
2721: departing from what I believe is to you the most important business.
2722: Nello informed me that you had certain gems which you would fain
2723: dispose of, and that you desired a passport to some man of wealth and
2724: taste who would be likely to become a purchaser.”
2725: 
2726: “It is true; for, though I have obtained employment, as a corrector
2727: with the Cennini, my payment leaves little margin beyond the provision
2728: of necessaries, and would leave less but that my good friend Nello
2729: insists on my hiring a lodging from him, and saying nothing about the
2730: rent till better days.”
2731: 
2732: “Nello is a good-hearted prodigal,” said Bardo; “and though, with that
2733: ready ear and ready tongue of his, he is too much like the ill-famed
2734: Margites—knowing many things and knowing them all badly, as I hinted to
2735: him but now—he is nevertheless ‘abnormis sapiens,’ after the manner of
2736: our born Florentines. But have you the gems with you? I would willingly
2737: know what they are—yet it is useless: no, it might only deepen regret.
2738: I cannot add to my store.”
2739: 
2740: “I have one or two intaglios of much beauty,” said Tito, proceeding to
2741: draw from his wallet a small case.
2742: 
2743: But Romola no sooner saw the movement than she looked at him with
2744: significant gravity, and placed her finger on her lips—
2745: 
2746: 
2747: “Con viso che tacendo dicea, Taci.”
2748: 
2749: 
2750: If Bardo were made aware that the gems were within reach, she knew well
2751: he would want a minute description of them, and it would become pain to
2752: him that they should go away from him, even if he did not insist on
2753: some device for purchasing them in spite of poverty. But she had no
2754: sooner made this sign than she felt rather guilty and ashamed at having
2755: virtually confessed a weakness of her father’s to a stranger. It seemed
2756: that she was destined to a sudden confidence and familiarity with this
2757: young Greek, strangely at variance with her deep-seated pride and
2758: reserve; and this consciousness again brought the unwonted colour to
2759: her cheeks.
2760: 
2761: Tito understood her look and sign, and immediately withdrew his hand
2762: from the case, saying, in a careless tone, so as to make it appear that
2763: he was merely following up his last words, “But they are usually in the
2764: keeping of Messer Domenico Cennini, who has strong and safe places for
2765: these things. He estimates them as worth at least five hundred ducats.”
2766: 
2767: “Ah, then, they are fine intagli,” said Bardo. “Five hundred ducats!
2768: Ah, more than a man’s ransom!”
2769: 
2770: Tito gave a slight, almost imperceptible start, and opened his long
2771: dark eyes with questioning surprise at Bardo’s blind face, as if his
2772: words—a mere phrase of common parlance, at a time when men were often
2773: being ransomed from slavery or imprisonment—had had some special
2774: meaning for him. But the next moment he looked towards Romola, as if
2775: her eyes must be her father’s interpreters. She, intensely preoccupied
2776: with what related to her father, imagined that Tito was looking to her
2777: again for some guidance, and immediately spoke.
2778: 
2779: “Alessandra Scala delights in gems, you know, father; she calls them
2780: her winter flowers; and the Segretario would be almost sure to buy any
2781: gems that she wished for. Besides, he himself sets great store by rings
2782: and sigils, which he wears as a defence against pains in the joints.”
2783: 
2784: “It is true,” said Bardo. “Bartolommeo has overmuch confidence in the
2785: efficacy of gems—a confidence wider than what is sanctioned by Pliny,
2786: who clearly shows that he regards many beliefs of that sort as idle
2787: superstitions; though not to the utter denial of medicinal virtues in
2788: gems. Wherefore, I myself, as you observe, young man, wear certain
2789: rings, which the discreet Camillo Leonardi prescribed to me by letter
2790: when two years ago I had a certain infirmity of sudden numbness. But
2791: thou hast spoken well, Romola. I will dictate a letter to Bartolommeo,
2792: which Maso shall carry. But it were well that Messere should notify to
2793: thee what the gems are, together with the intagli they bear, as a
2794: warrant to Bartolommeo that they will be worthy of his attention.”
2795: 
2796: “Nay, father,” said Romola, whose dread lest a paroxysm of the
2797: collector’s mania should seize her father, gave her the courage to
2798: resist his proposal. “Your word will be sufficient that Messere is a
2799: scholar and has travelled much. The Segretario will need no further
2800: inducement to receive him.”
2801: 
2802: “True, child,” said Bardo, touched on a chord that was sure to respond.
2803: “I have no need to add proofs and arguments in confirmation of my word
2804: to Bartolommeo. And I doubt not that this young man’s presence is in
2805: accord with the tones of his voice, so that, the door being once
2806: opened, he will be his own best advocate.”
2807: 
2808: Bardo paused a few moments, but his silence was evidently charged with
2809: some idea that he was hesitating to express, for he once leaned forward
2810: a little as if he were going to speak, then turned his head aside
2811: towards Romola and sank backward again. At last, as if he had made up
2812: his mind, he said in a tone which might have become a prince giving the
2813: courteous signal of dismissal—
2814: 
2815: “I am somewhat fatigued this morning, and shall prefer seeing you again
2816: to-morrow, when I shall be able to give you the secretary’s answer,
2817: authorising you to present yourself to him at some given time. But
2818: before you go,”—here the old man, in spite of himself, fell into a more
2819: faltering tone—“you will perhaps permit me to touch your hand? It is
2820: long since I touched the hand of a young man.”
2821: 
2822: Bardo had stretched out his aged white hand, and Tito immediately
2823: placed his dark but delicate and supple fingers within it. Bardo’s
2824: cramped fingers closed over them, and he held them for a few minutes in
2825: silence. Then he said—
2826: 
2827: “Romola, has this young man the same complexion as thy brother—fair and
2828: pale?”
2829: 
2830: “No, father,” Romola answered, with determined composure, though her
2831: heart began to beat violently with mingled emotions. “The hair of
2832: Messere is dark—his complexion is dark.” Inwardly she said, “Will he
2833: mind it? will it be disagreeable? No, he looks so gentle and
2834: good-natured.” Then aloud again—
2835: 
2836: “Would Messere permit my father to touch his hair and face?”
2837: 
2838: Her eyes inevitably made a timid entreating appeal while she asked
2839: this, and Tito’s met them with soft brightness as he said, “Assuredly,”
2840: and, leaning forward, raised Bardo’s hand to his curls, with a
2841: readiness of assent, which was the greater relief to her, because it
2842: was unaccompanied by any sign of embarrassment.
2843: 
2844: Bardo passed his hand again and again over the long curls and grasped
2845: them a little, as if their spiral resistance made his inward vision
2846: clearer; then he passed his hand over the brow and cheek, tracing the
2847: profile with the edge of his palm and fourth finger, and letting the
2848: breadth of his hand repose on the rich oval of the cheek.
2849: 
2850: “Ah,” he said, as his hand glided from the face and rested on the young
2851: man’s shoulder. “He must be very unlike thy brother, Romola: and it is
2852: the better. You see no visions, I trust, my young friend?”
2853: 
2854: At this moment the door opened, and there entered, unannounced, a tall
2855: elderly man in a handsome black silk lucco, who, unwinding his
2856: becchetto from his neck and taking off his cap, disclosed a head as
2857: white as Bardo’s. He cast a keen glance of surprise at the group before
2858: him—the young stranger leaning in that filial attitude, while Bardo’s
2859: hand rested on his shoulder, and Romola sitting near with eyes dilated
2860: by anxiety and agitation. But there was an instantaneous change: Bardo
2861: let fall his hand, Tito raised himself from his stooping posture, and
2862: Romola rose to meet the visitor with an alacrity which implied all the
2863: greater intimacy, because it was unaccompanied by any smile.
2864: 
2865: “Well, god-daughter,” said the stately man, as he touched Romola’s
2866: shoulder; “Maso said you had a visitor, but I came in nevertheless.”
2867: 
2868: “It is thou, Bernardo,” said Bardo. “Thou art come at a fortunate
2869: moment. This, young man,” he continued, while Tito rose and bowed, “is
2870: one of the chief citizens of Florence, Messer Bernardo del Nero, my
2871: oldest, I had almost said my only friend—whose good opinion, if you can
2872: win it, may carry you far. He is but three-and-twenty, Bernardo, yet he
2873: can doubtless tell thee much which thou wilt care to hear; for though a
2874: scholar, he has already travelled far, and looked on other things
2875: besides the manuscripts for which thou hast too light an esteem.”
2876: 
2877: “Ah, a Greek, as I augur,” said Bernardo, returning Tito’s reverence
2878: but slightly, and surveying him with that sort of glance which seems
2879: almost to cut like fine steel. “Newly arrived in Florence, it appears.
2880: The name of Messere—or part of it, for it is doubtless a long one?”
2881: 
2882: “On the contrary,” said Tito, with perfect good-humour, “it is most
2883: modestly free from polysyllabic pomp. My name is Tito Melema.”
2884: 
2885: “Truly?” said Bernardo, rather scornfully, as he took a seat; “I had
2886: expected it to be at least as long as the names of a city, a river, a
2887: province, and an empire all put together. We Florentines mostly use
2888: names as we do prawns, and strip them of all flourishes before we trust
2889: them to our throats.”
2890: 
2891: “Well, Bardo,” he continued, as if the stranger were not worth further
2892: notice, and changing his tone of sarcastic suspicion for one of
2893: sadness, “we have buried him.”
2894: 
2895: “Ah!” replied Bardo, with corresponding sadness, “and a new epoch has
2896: come for Florence—a dark one, I fear. Lorenzo has left behind him an
2897: inheritance that is but like the alchemist’s laboratory when the wisdom
2898: of the alchemist is gone.”
2899: 
2900: “Not altogether so,” said Bernardo. “Piero de’ Medici has abundant
2901: intelligence; his faults are only the faults of hot blood. I love the
2902: lad—lad he will always be to me, as I have always been ‘little father’
2903: to him.”
2904: 
2905: “Yet all who want a new order of things are likely to conceive new
2906: hopes,” said Bardo. “We shall have the old strife of parties, I fear.”
2907: 
2908: “If we could have a new order of things that was something else than
2909: knocking down one coat of arms to put up another,” said Bernardo, “I
2910: should be ready to say, ‘I belong to no party: I am a Florentine.’ But
2911: as long as parties are in question, I am a Medicean, and will be a
2912: Medicean till I die. I am of the same mind as Farinata degli Uberti: if
2913: any man asks me what is meant by siding with a party, I say, as he did,
2914: ‘To wish ill or well, for the sake of past wrongs or kindnesses.’”
2915: 
2916: During this short dialogue, Tito had been standing, and now took his
2917: leave.
2918: 
2919: “But come again at the same hour to-morrow,” said Bardo, graciously,
2920: before Tito left the room, “that I may give you Bartolommeo’s answer.”
2921: 
2922: “From what quarter of the sky has this pretty Greek youngster alighted
2923: so close to thy chair, Bardo?” said Bernardo del Nero, as the door
2924: closed. He spoke with dry emphasis, evidently intended to convey
2925: something more to Bardo than was implied by the mere words.
2926: 
2927: “He is a scholar who has been shipwrecked and has saved a few gems, for
2928: which he wants to find a purchaser. I am going to send him to
2929: Bartolommeo Scala, for thou knowest it were more prudent in me to
2930: abstain from further purchases.”
2931: 
2932: Bernardo shrugged his shoulders and said, “Romola, wilt thou see if my
2933: servant is without? I ordered him to wait for me here.” Then, when
2934: Romola was at a sufficient distance, he leaned forward and said to
2935: Bardo in a low, emphatic tone—
2936: 
2937: “Remember, Bardo, thou hast a rare gem of thy own; take care no one
2938: gets it who is not likely to pay a worthy price. That pretty Greek has
2939: a lithe sleekness about him, that seems marvellously fitted for
2940: slipping easily into any nest he fixes his mind on.”
2941: 
2942: Bardo was startled: the association of Tito with the image of his lost
2943: son had excluded instead of suggesting the thought of Romola. But
2944: almost immediately there seemed to be a reaction which made him grasp
2945: the warning as if it had been a hope.
2946: 
2947: “But why not, Bernardo? If the young man approved himself worthy—he is
2948: a scholar—and—and there would be no difficulty about the dowry, which
2949: always makes thee gloomy.”
2950: 
2951: 
2952: 
2953: 
2954: CHAPTER VII.
2955: A Learned Squabble.
2956: 
2957: 
2958: Bartolommeo Scala, secretary of the Florentine Republic, on whom Tito
2959: Melema had been thus led to anchor his hopes, lived in a handsome
2960: palace close to the Porta Pinti, now known as the Casa Gherardesca. His
2961: arms—an azure ladder transverse on a golden field, with the motto
2962: _Gradatim_ placed over the entrance—told all comers that the miller’s
2963: son held his ascent to honours by his own efforts a fact to be
2964: proclaimed without wincing. The secretary was a vain and pompous man,
2965: but he was also an honest one: he was sincerely convinced of his own
2966: merit, and could see no reason for feigning. The topmost round of his
2967: azure ladder had been reached by this time: he had held his
2968: secretaryship these twenty years—had long since made his orations on
2969: the _ringhiera_, or platform of the Old Palace, as the custom was, in
2970: the presence of princely visitors, while Marzocco, the republican lion,
2971: wore his gold crown on the occasion, and all the people cried, “Viva
2972: Messer Bartolommeo!”—had been on an embassy to Rome, and had there been
2973: made titular Senator, Apostolical Secretary, Knight of the Golden Spur;
2974: and had, eight years ago, been Gonfaloniere—last goal of the Florentine
2975: citizen’s ambition. Meantime he had got richer and richer, and more and
2976: more gouty, after the manner of successful mortality; and the Knight of
2977: the Golden Spur had often to sit with helpless cushioned heel under the
2978: handsome loggia he had built for himself, overlooking the spacious
2979: gardens and lawn at the back of his palace.
2980: 
2981: He was in this position on the day when he had granted the desired
2982: interview to Tito Melema. The May afternoon sun was on the flowers and
2983: the grass beyond the pleasant shade of the loggia; the too stately silk
2984: lucco was cast aside, and the light loose mantle was thrown over his
2985: tunic; his beautiful daughter Alessandra and her husband, the Greek
2986: soldier-poet Marullo, were seated on one side of him: on the other, two
2987: friends not oppressively illustrious, and therefore the better
2988: listeners. Yet, to say nothing of the gout, Messer Bartolommeo’s
2989: felicity was far from perfect: it was embittered by the contents of
2990: certain papers that lay before him, consisting chiefly of a
2991: correspondence between himself and Politian. It was a human foible at
2992: that period (incredible as it may seem) to recite quarrels, and favour
2993: scholarly visitors with the communication of an entire and lengthy
2994: correspondence; and this was neither the first nor the second time that
2995: Scala had asked the candid opinion of his friends as to the balance of
2996: right and wrong in some half-score Latin letters between himself and
2997: Politian, all springing out of certain epigrams written in the most
2998: playful tone in the world. It was the story of a very typical and
2999: pretty quarrel, in which we are interested, because it supplied
3000: precisely that thistle of hatred necessary, according to Nello, as a
3001: stimulus to the sluggish paces of the cautious steed, Friendship.
3002: Politian, having been a rejected pretender to the love and the hand of
3003: Scala’s daughter, kept a very sharp and learned tooth in readiness
3004: against the too prosperous and presumptuous secretary, who had declined
3005: the greatest scholar of the age for a son-in-law. Scala was a
3006: meritorious public servant, and, moreover, a lucky man—naturally
3007: exasperating to an offended scholar; but then—O beautiful balance of
3008: things!—he had an itch for authorship, and was a bad writer—one of
3009: those excellent people who, sitting in gouty slippers, “penned poetical
3010: trifles” entirely for their own amusement, without any view to an
3011: audience, and, consequently, sent them to their friends in letters,
3012: which were the literary periodicals of the fifteenth century. Now Scala
3013: had abundance of friends who were ready to praise his writings: friends
3014: like Ficino and Landino—amiable browsers in the Medicean park along
3015: with himself—who found his Latin prose style elegant and masculine; and
3016: the terrible Joseph Scaliger, who was to pronounce him totally ignorant
3017: of Latinity, was at a comfortable distance in the next century. But
3018: when was the fatal coquetry inherent in superfluous authorship ever
3019: quite contented with the ready praise of friends? That critical
3020: supercilious Politian—a fellow-browser, who was far from amiable—must
3021: be made aware that the solid secretary showed, in his leisure hours, a
3022: pleasant fertility in verses, which indicated pretty clearly how much
3023: he might do in that way if he were not a man of affairs.
3024: 
3025: Ineffable moment! when the man you secretly hate sends you a Latin
3026: epigram with a false gender—hendecasyllables with a questionable
3027: elision, at least a toe too much—attempts at poetic figures which are
3028: manifest solecisms. That moment had come to Politian: the secretary had
3029: put forth his soft head from the official shell, and the terrible
3030: lurking crab was down upon him. Politian had used the freedom of a
3031: friend, and pleasantly, in the form of a Latin epigram, corrected the
3032: mistake of Scala in making the _culex_ (an insect too well-known on the
3033: banks of the Arno) of the inferior or feminine gender. Scala replied by
3034: a bad joke, in suitable Latin verses, referring to Politian’s
3035: unsuccessful suit. Better and better. Politian found the verses very
3036: pretty and highly facetious: the more was the pity that they were
3037: seriously incorrect, and inasmuch as Scala had alleged that he had
3038: written them in imitation of a Greek epigram, Politian, being on such
3039: friendly terms, would enclose a Greek epigram of his own, on the same
3040: interesting insect—not, we may presume, out of any wish to humble
3041: Scala, but rather to instruct him; said epigram containing a lively
3042: conceit about Venus, Cupid, and the _culex_, of a kind much tasted at
3043: that period, founded partly on the zoological fact that the gnat, like
3044: Venus, was born from the waters. Scala, in reply, begged to say that
3045: his verses were never intended for a scholar with such delicate
3046: olfactories as Politian, nearest of all living men to the perfection of
3047: the ancients, and of a taste so fastidious that sturgeon itself must
3048: seem insipid to him; defended his own verses, nevertheless, though
3049: indeed they were written hastily, without correction, and intended as
3050: an agreeable distraction during the summer heat to himself and such
3051: friends as were satisfied with mediocrity, he, Scala, not being like
3052: some other people, who courted publicity through the booksellers. For
3053: the rest, he had barely enough Greek to make out the sense of the
3054: epigram so graciously sent him, to say nothing of tasting its
3055: elegances; but—the epigram was Politian’s: what more need be said?
3056: Still, by way of postscript, he feared that his incomparable friend’s
3057: comparison of the gnat to Venus, on account of its origin from the
3058: waters, was in many ways ticklish. On the one hand, Venus might be
3059: offended; and on the other, unless the poet intended an allusion to the
3060: doctrine of Thales, that cold and damp origin seemed doubtful to Scala
3061: in the case of a creature so fond of warmth; a fish were perhaps the
3062: better comparison, or, when the power of flying was in question, an
3063: eagle, or indeed, when the darkness was taken into consideration, a bat
3064: or an owl were a less obscure and more apposite parallel, etcetera,
3065: etcetera. Here was a great opportunity for Politian. He was not aware,
3066: he wrote, that when he had Scala’s verses placed before him, there was
3067: any question of sturgeon, but rather of frogs and gudgeons: made short
3068: work with Scala’s defence of his own Latin, and mangled him terribly on
3069: the score of the stupid criticisms he had ventured on the Greek epigram
3070: kindly forwarded to him as a model. Wretched cavils, indeed! for as to
3071: the damp origin of the gnat, there was the authority of Virgil himself,
3072: who had called it the “_alumnus_ of the waters;” and as to what his
3073: dear dull friend had to say about the fish, the eagle, and the rest, it
3074: was “nihil ad rem;” for because the eagle could fly higher, it by no
3075: means followed that the gnat could not fly at all, etcetera, etcetera.
3076: He was ashamed, however, to dwell on such trivialities, and thus to
3077: swell a gnat into an elephant; but, for his own part, would only add
3078: that he had nothing deceitful or double about him, neither was he to be
3079: caught when present by the false blandishments of those who slandered
3080: him in his absence, agreeing rather with a Homeric sentiment on that
3081: head—which furnished a Greek quotation to serve as powder to his
3082: bullet.
3083: 
3084: The quarrel could not end there. The logic could hardly get worse, but
3085: the secretary got more pompously self-asserting, and the scholarly
3086: poet’s temper more and more venomous. Politian had been generously
3087: willing to hold up a mirror, by which the too-inflated secretary,
3088: beholding his own likeness, might be induced to cease setting up his
3089: ignorant defences of bad Latin against ancient authorities whom the
3090: consent of centuries had placed beyond question,—unless, indeed, he had
3091: designed to sink in literature in proportion as he rose in honours,
3092: that by a sort of compensation men of letters might feel themselves his
3093: equals. In return, Politian was begged to examine Scala’s writings:
3094: nowhere would he find a more devout admiration of antiquity. The
3095: secretary was ashamed of the age in which he lived, and blushed for it.
3096: _Some_, indeed, there were who wanted to have their own works praised
3097: and exalted to a level with the divine monuments of antiquity; but he,
3098: Scala, could not oblige them. And as to the honours which were
3099: offensive to the envious, they had been well earned: witness his whole
3100: life since he came in penury to Florence. The elegant scholar, in
3101: reply, was not surprised that Scala found the Age distasteful to him,
3102: since he himself was so distasteful to the Age; nay, it was with
3103: perfect accuracy that he, the elegant scholar, had called Scala a
3104: branny monster, inasmuch as he was formed from the off-scourings of
3105: monsters, born amidst the refuse of a mill, and eminently worthy the
3106: long-eared office of turning the paternal millstones (_in pistrini
3107: sordibus natus et quidem pistrino dignissimus_)!
3108: 
3109: It was not without reference to Tito’s appointed visit that the papers
3110: containing this correspondence were brought out to-day. Here was a new
3111: Greek scholar whose accomplishments were to be tested, and on nothing
3112: did Scala more desire a dispassionate opinion from persons of superior
3113: knowledge than on that Greek epigram of Politian’s. After sufficient
3114: introductory talk concerning Tito’s travels, after a survey and
3115: discussion of the gems, and an easy passage from the mention of the
3116: lamented Lorenzo’s eagerness in collecting such specimens of ancient
3117: art to the subject of classical tastes and studies in general and their
3118: present condition in Florence, it was inevitable to mention Politian, a
3119: man of eminent ability indeed, but a little too arrogant—assuming to be
3120: a Hercules, whose office it was to destroy all the literary
3121: monstrosities of the age, and writing letters to his elders without
3122: signing them, as if they were miraculous revelations that could only
3123: have one source. And after all, were not his own criticisms often
3124: questionable and his tastes perverse? He was fond of saying pungent
3125: things about the men who thought they wrote like Cicero because they
3126: ended every sentence with “esse videtur:” but while he was boasting of
3127: his freedom from servile imitation, did he not fall into the other
3128: extreme, running after strange words and affected phrases? Even in his
3129: much-belauded ‘Miscellanea’ was every point tenable? And Tito, who had
3130: just been looking into the ‘Miscellanea,’ found so much to say that was
3131: agreeable to the secretary—he would have done so from the mere
3132: disposition to please, without further motive—that he showed himself
3133: quite worthy to be made a judge in the notable correspondence
3134: concerning the _culex_. Here was the Greek epigram which Politian had
3135: doubtless thought the finest in the world, though he had pretended to
3136: believe that the “transmarini,” the Greeks themselves, would make light
3137: of it: had he not been unintentionally speaking the truth in his false
3138: modesty?
3139: 
3140: Tito was ready, and scarified the epigram to Scala’s content. O wise
3141: young judge! He could doubtless appreciate satire even in the vulgar
3142: tongue, and Scala—who, excellent man, not seeking publicity through the
3143: booksellers, was never unprovided with “hasty uncorrected trifles,” as
3144: a sort of sherbet for a visitor on a hot day, or, if the weather were
3145: cold, why then as a cordial—had a few little matters in the shape of
3146: Sonnets, turning on well-known foibles of Politian’s, which he would
3147: not like to go any farther, but which would, perhaps, amuse the
3148: company.
3149: 
3150: Enough: Tito took his leave under an urgent invitation to come again.
3151: His gems were interesting; especially the agate, with the _lusus
3152: naturae_ in it—a most wonderful semblance of Cupid riding on the lion;
3153: and the “Jew’s stone,” with the lion-headed serpent enchased in it;
3154: both of which the secretary agreed to buy—the latter as a reinforcement
3155: of his preventives against the gout, which gave him such severe twinges
3156: that it was plain enough how intolerable it would be if he were not
3157: well supplied with rings of rare virtue, and with an amulet worn close
3158: under the right breast. But Tito was assured that he himself was more
3159: interesting than his gems. He had won his way to the Scala Palace by
3160: the recommendation of Bardo de’ Bardi, who, to be sure, was Scala’s old
3161: acquaintance and a worthy scholar, in spite of his overvaluing himself
3162: a little (a frequent foible in the secretary’s friends); but he must
3163: come again on the ground of his own manifest accomplishments.
3164: 
3165: The interview could hardly have ended more auspiciously for Tito, and
3166: as he walked out at the Porta Pinti that he might laugh a little at his
3167: ease over the affair of the _culex_, he felt that fortune could hardly
3168: mean to turn her back on him again at present, since she had taken him
3169: by the hand in this decided way.
3170: 
3171: 
3172: 
3173: 
3174: CHAPTER VIII.
3175: A Face in the Crowd.
3176: 
3177: 
3178: It is easy to northern people to rise early on Midsummer morning, to
3179: see the dew on the grassy edge of the dusty pathway, to notice the
3180: fresh shoots among the darker green of the oak and fir in the coppice,
3181: and to look over the gate at the shorn meadow, without recollecting
3182: that it is the Nativity of Saint John the Baptist.
3183: 
3184: Not so to the Florentine—still less to the Florentine of the fifteenth
3185: century: to him on that particular morning the brightness of the
3186: eastern sun on the Arno had something special in it; the ringing of the
3187: bells was articulate, and declared it to be the great summer festival
3188: of Florence, the day of San Giovanni.
3189: 
3190: San Giovanni had been the patron saint of Florence for at least eight
3191: hundred years—ever since the time when the Lombard Queen Theodolinda
3192: had commanded her subjects to do him peculiar honour; nay, says old
3193: Villani, to the best of his knowledge, ever since the days of
3194: Constantino the Great and Pope Sylvester, when the Florentines deposed
3195: their idol Mars, whom they were nevertheless careful not to treat with
3196: contumely; for while they consecrated their beautiful and noble temple
3197: to the honour of God and of the “Beato Messere Santo Giovanni,” they
3198: placed old Mars respectfully on a high tower near the River Arno,
3199: finding in certain ancient memorials that he had been elected as their
3200: tutelar deity under such astral influences that if he were broken, or
3201: otherwise treated with indignity, the city would suffer great damage
3202: and mutation. But in the fifteenth century that discreet regard to the
3203: feelings of the Man-destroyer had long vanished: the god of the spear
3204: and shield had ceased to frown by the side of the Arno, and the
3205: defences of the Republic were held to lie in its craft and its coffers.
3206: For spear and shield could be hired by gold florins, and on the gold
3207: florins there had always been the image of San Giovanni.
3208: 
3209: Much good had come to Florence since the dim time of struggle between
3210: the old patron and the new: some quarrelling and bloodshed, doubtless,
3211: between Guelf and Ghibelline, between Black and White, between orthodox
3212: sons of the Church and heretic Paterini; some floods, famine, and
3213: pestilence; but still much wealth and glory. Florence had achieved
3214: conquests over walled cities once mightier than itself, and especially
3215: over hated Pisa, whose marble buildings were too high and beautiful,
3216: whose masts were too much honoured on Greek and Italian coasts. The
3217: name of Florence had been growing prouder and prouder in all the courts
3218: of Europe, nay, in Africa itself, on the strength of purest gold
3219: coinage, finest dyes and textures, pre-eminent scholarship and poetic
3220: genius, and wits of the most serviceable sort for statesmanship and
3221: banking: it was a name so omnipresent that a Pope with a turn for
3222: epigram had called Florentines “the fifth element.” And for this high
3223: destiny, though it might partly depend on the stars and Madonna dell’
3224: Impruneta, and certainly depended on other higher Powers less often
3225: named, the praise was greatly due to San Giovanni, whose image was on
3226: the fair gold florins.
3227: 
3228: Therefore it was fitting that the day of San Giovanni—that ancient
3229: Church festival already venerable in the days of Saint Augustine—should
3230: be a day of peculiar rejoicing to Florence, and should be ushered in by
3231: a vigil duly kept in strict old Florentine fashion, with much dancing,
3232: with much street jesting, and perhaps with not a little stone-throwing
3233: and window-breaking, but emphatically with certain street sights such
3234: as could only be provided by a city which held in its service a clever
3235: Cecca, engineer and architect, valuable alike in sieges and in shows.
3236: By the help of Cecca, the very saints, surrounded with their
3237: almond-shaped glory, and floating on clouds with their joyous
3238: companionship of winged cherubs, even as they may be seen to this day
3239: in the pictures of Perugino, seemed, on the eve of San Giovanni, to
3240: have brought their piece of the heavens down into the narrow streets,
3241: and to pass slowly through them; and, more wonderful still, saints of
3242: gigantic size, with attendant angels, might be seen, not seated, but
3243: moving in a slow mysterious manner along the streets, like a procession
3244: of colossal figures come down from the high domes and tribunes of the
3245: churches. The clouds were made of good woven stuff, the saints and
3246: cherubs were unglorified mortals supported by firm bars, and those
3247: mysterious giants were really men of very steady brain, balancing
3248: themselves on stilts, and enlarged, like Greek tragedians, by huge
3249: masks and stuffed shoulders; but he was a miserably unimaginative
3250: Florentine who thought only of that—nay, somewhat impious, for in the
3251: images of sacred things was there not some of the virtue of sacred
3252: things themselves? And if, after that, there came a company of merry
3253: black demons well armed with claws and thongs, and other implements of
3254: sport, ready to perform impromptu farces of bastinadoing and
3255: clothes-tearing, why, that was the demons’ way of keeping a vigil, and
3256: they, too, might have descended from the domes and the tribunes. The
3257: Tuscan mind slipped from the devout to the burlesque, as readily as
3258: water round an angle; and the saints had already had their turn, had
3259: gone their way, and made their due pause before the gates of San
3260: Giovanni, to do him honour on the eve of his _festa_. And on the
3261: morrow, the great day thus ushered in, it was fitting that the
3262: tributary symbols paid to Florence by all its dependent cities,
3263: districts, and villages, whether conquered, protected, or of immemorial
3264: possession, should be offered at the shrine of San Giovanni in the old
3265: octagonal church, once the cathedral and now the baptistery, where
3266: every Florentine had had the sign of the Cross made with the anointing
3267: chrism on his brow; that all the city, from the white-haired man to the
3268: stripling, and from the matron to the lisping child, should be clothed
3269: in its best to do honour to the great day, and see the great sight; and
3270: that again, when the sun was sloping and the streets were cool, there
3271: should be the glorious race or Corso, when the unsaddled horses,
3272: clothed in rich trappings, should run right across the city, from the
3273: Porta al Prato on the north-west, through the Mercato Vecchio, to the
3274: Porta Santa Croce on the south-east, where the richest of _Palii_, or
3275: velvet and brocade banners with silk linings and fringe of gold, such
3276: as became a city that half-clothed the well-dressed world, were mounted
3277: on a triumphal car awaiting the winner or winner’s owner.
3278: 
3279: And thereafter followed more dancing; nay, through the whole day, says
3280: an old chronicler at the beginning of that century, there were weddings
3281: and the grandest gatherings, with so much piping, music and song, with
3282: balls and feasts and gladness and ornament, that this earth might have
3283: been mistaken for Paradise!
3284: 
3285: In this year of 1492, it was, perhaps, a little less easy to make that
3286: mistake. Lorenzo the magnificent and subtle was dead, and an arrogant,
3287: incautious Piero was come in his room, an evil change for Florence,
3288: unless, indeed, the wise horse prefers the bad rider, as more easily
3289: thrown from the saddle, and already the regrets for Lorenzo were
3290: getting less predominant over the murmured desire for government on a
3291: broader basis, in which corruption might be arrested, and there might
3292: be that free play for everybody’s jealousy and ambition, which made the
3293: ideal liberty of the good old quarrelsome, struggling times, when
3294: Florence raised her great buildings, reared her own soldiers, drove out
3295: would-be tyrants at the sword’s point, and was proud to keep faith at
3296: her own loss. Lorenzo was dead, Pope Innocent was dying, and a
3297: troublesome Neapolitan succession, with an intriguing, ambitious Milan,
3298: might set Italy by the ears before long: the times were likely to be
3299: difficult. Still, there was all the more reason that the Republic
3300: should keep its religious festivals.
3301: 
3302: And Midsummer morning, in this year 1492, was not less bright than
3303: usual. It was betimes in the morning that the symbolic offerings to be
3304: carried in grand procession were all assembled at their starting-point
3305: in the Piazza della Signoria—that famous piazza, where stood then, and
3306: stand now, the massive turreted Palace of the People, called the
3307: Palazzo Vecchio, and the spacious Loggia, built by Orcagna—the scene of
3308: all grand State ceremonial. The sky made the fairest blue tent, and
3309: under it the bells swung so vigorously that every evil spirit with
3310: sense enough to be formidable, must long since have taken his flight;
3311: windows and terraced roofs were alive with human faces; sombre stone
3312: houses were bright with hanging draperies; the boldly soaring palace
3313: tower, the yet older square tower of the Bargello, and the spire of the
3314: neighbouring Badia, seemed to keep watch above; and below, on the broad
3315: polygonal flags of the piazza, was the glorious show of banners, and
3316: horses with rich trappings, and gigantic _ceri_, or tapers, that were
3317: fitly called towers—strangely aggrandised descendants of those torches
3318: by whose faint light the Church worshipped in the Catacombs. Betimes in
3319: the morning all processions had need to move under the Midsummer sky of
3320: Florence, where the shelter of the narrow streets must every now and
3321: then be exchanged for the glare of wide spaces; and the sun would be
3322: high up in the heavens before the long pomp had ended its pilgrimage in
3323: the Piazza di San Giovanni.
3324: 
3325: But here, where the procession was to pause, the magnificent city, with
3326: its ingenious Cecca, had provided another tent than the sky; for the
3327: whole of the Piazza del Duomo, from the octagonal baptistery in the
3328: centre to the façade of the cathedral and the walls of the houses on
3329: the other sides of the quadrangle, was covered, at the height of forty
3330: feet or more, with blue drapery, adorned with well-stitched yellow
3331: lilies and the familiar coats of arms, while sheaves of many-coloured
3332: banners drooped at fit angles under this superincumbent blue—a gorgeous
3333: rainbow-lit shelter to the waiting spectators who leaned from the
3334: windows, and made a narrow border on the pavement, and wished for the
3335: coming of the show.
3336: 
3337: One of these spectators was Tito Melema. Bright, in the midst of
3338: brightness, he sat at the window of the room above Nello’s shop, his
3339: right elbow resting on the red drapery hanging from the window-sill,
3340: and his head supported in a backward position by the right-hand, which
3341: pressed the curls against his ear. His face wore that bland liveliness,
3342: as far removed from excitability as from heaviness or gloom, which
3343: marks the companion popular alike amongst men and women—the companion
3344: who is never obtrusive or noisy from uneasy vanity or excessive animal
3345: spirits, and whose brow is never contracted by resentment or
3346: indignation. He showed no other change from the two months and more
3347: that had passed since his first appearance in the weather-stained tunic
3348: and hose, than that added radiance of good fortune, which is like the
3349: just perceptible perfecting of a flower after it has drunk a morning’s
3350: sunbeams. Close behind him, ensconced in the narrow angle between his
3351: chair and the window-frame, stood the slim figure of Nello in holiday
3352: suit, and at his left the younger Cennini—Pietro, the erudite corrector
3353: of proof-sheets, not Domenico the practical. Tito was looking
3354: alternately down on the scene below, and upward at the varied knot of
3355: gazers and talkers immediately around him, some of whom had come in
3356: after witnessing the commencement of the procession in the Piazza della
3357: Signoria. Piero di Cosimo was raising a laugh among them by his
3358: grimaces and anathemas at the noise of the bells, against which no kind
3359: of ear-stuffing was a sufficient barricade, since the more he stuffed
3360: his ears the more he felt the vibration of his skull; and declaring
3361: that he would bury himself in the most solitary spot of the Valdarno on
3362: a _festa_, if he were not condemned, as a painter, to lie in wait for
3363: the secrets of colour that were sometimes to be caught from the
3364: floating of banners and the chance grouping of the multitude.
3365: 
3366: Tito had just turned his laughing face away from the whimsical painter
3367: to look down at the small drama going on among the checkered border of
3368: spectators, when at the angle of the marble steps in front of the
3369: Duomo, nearly opposite Nello’s shop, he saw a man’s face upturned
3370: towards him, and fixing on him a gaze that seemed to have more meaning
3371: in it than the ordinary passing observation of a stranger. It was a
3372: face with tonsured head, that rose above the black mantle and white
3373: tunic of a Dominican friar—a very common sight in Florence; but the
3374: glance had something peculiar in it for Tito. There was a faint
3375: suggestion in it, certainly not of an unpleasant kind. Yet what
3376: pleasant association had he ever had with monks? None. The glance and
3377: the suggestion hardly took longer than a flash of lightning.
3378: 
3379: “Nello!” said Tito, hastily, but immediately added, in a tone of
3380: disappointment, “Ah, he has turned round. It was that tall, thin friar
3381: who is going up the steps. I wanted you to tell me if you knew aught of
3382: him?”
3383: 
3384: “One of the Frati Predicatori,” said Nello, carelessly; “you don’t
3385: expect me to know the private history of the crows.”
3386: 
3387: “I seem to remember something about his face,” said Tito. “It is an
3388: uncommon face.”
3389: 
3390: “What? you thought it might be our Fra Girolamo? Too tall; and he never
3391: shows himself in that chance way.”
3392: 
3393: “Besides, that loud-barking ‘hound of the Lord’[1] is not in Florence
3394: just now,” said Francesco Cei, the popular poet; “he has taken Piero
3395: de’ Medici’s hint, to carry his railing prophecies on a journey for a
3396: while.”
3397: 
3398:  [1] A play on the name of the Dominicans (_Domini Canes_) which was
3399:  accepted by themselves, and which is pictorially represented in a
3400:  fresco painted for them by Simone Memmi.
3401: 
3402: 
3403: “The Frate neither rails nor prophesies against any man,” said a
3404: middle-aged personage seated at the other corner of the window; “he
3405: only prophesies against vice. If you think that an attack on your
3406: poems, Francesco, it is not the Frate’s fault.”
3407: 
3408: “Ah, he’s gone into the Duomo now,” said Tito, who had watched the
3409: figure eagerly. “No, I was not under that mistake, Nello. Your Fra
3410: Girolamo has a high nose and a large under-lip. I saw him once—he is
3411: not handsome; but this man...”
3412: 
3413: “Truce to your descriptions!” said Cennini. “Hark! see! Here come the
3414: horsemen and the banners. That standard,” he continued, laying his hand
3415: familiarly on Tito’s shoulder,—“that carried on the horse with white
3416: trappings—that with the red eagle holding the green dragon between his
3417: talons, and the red lily over the eagle—is the Gonfalon of the Guelf
3418: party, and those cavaliers close round it are the chief officers of the
3419: Guelf party. That is one of our proudest banners, grumble as we may; it
3420: means the triumph of the Guelfs, which means the triumph of Florentine
3421: will, which means triumph of the popolani.”
3422: 
3423: “Nay, go on, Cennini,” said the middle-aged man, seated at the window,
3424: “which means triumph of the fat popolani over the lean, which again
3425: means triumph of the fattest popolano over those who are less fat.”
3426: 
3427: “Cronaca, you are becoming sententious,” said the printer; “Fra
3428: Girolamo’s preaching will spoil you, and make you take life by the
3429: wrong handle. Trust me, your cornices will lose half their beauty if
3430: you begin to mingle bitterness with them; that is the _maniera Tedesca_
3431: which you used to declaim against when you came from Rome. The next
3432: palace you build we shall see you trying to put the Frate’s doctrine
3433: into stone.”
3434: 
3435: “That is a goodly show of cavaliers,” said Tito, who had learned by
3436: this time the best way to please Florentines; “but are there not
3437: strangers among them? I see foreign costumes.”
3438: 
3439: “Assuredly,” said Cennini; “you see there the Orators from France,
3440: Milan, and Venice, and behind them are English and German nobles; for
3441: it is customary that all foreign visitors of distinction pay their
3442: tribute to San Giovanni in the train of that gonfalon. For my part, I
3443: think our Florentine cavaliers sit their horses as well as any of those
3444: cut-and-thrust northerners, whose wits lie in their heels and saddles;
3445: and for yon Venetian, I fancy he would feel himself more at ease on the
3446: back of a dolphin. We ought to know something of horsemanship, for we
3447: excel all Italy in the sports of the Giostra, and the money we spend on
3448: them. But you will see a finer show of our chief men by-and-by, Melema;
3449: my brother himself will be among the officers of the Zecca.”
3450: 
3451: “The banners are the better sight,” said Piero di Cosimo, forgetting
3452: the noise in his delight at the winding stream of colour as the
3453: tributary standards advanced round the piazza. “The Florentine men are
3454: so-so; they make but a sorry show at this distance with their patch of
3455: sallow flesh-tint above the black garments; but those banners with
3456: their velvet, and satin, and minever, and brocade, and their endless
3457: play of delicate light and shadow!—_Va_! your human talk and doings are
3458: a tame jest; the only passionate life is in form and colour.”
3459: 
3460: “Ay, Piero, if Satanasso could paint, thou wouldst sell thy soul to
3461: learn his secrets,” said Nello. “But there is little likelihood of it,
3462: seeing the blessed angels themselves are such poor hands at
3463: chiaroscuro, if one may judge from their _capo-d’opera_, the Madonna
3464: Nunziata.”
3465: 
3466: “There go the banners of Pisa and Arezzo,” said Cennini. “Ay, Messer
3467: Pisano, it is no use for you to look sullen; you may as well carry your
3468: banner to our San Giovanni with a good grace. ‘Pisans false,
3469: Florentines blind’—the second half of that proverb will hold no longer.
3470: There come the ensigns of our subject towns and signories, Melema; they
3471: will all be suspended in San Giovanni until this day next year, when
3472: they will give place to new ones.”
3473: 
3474: “They are a fair sight,” said Tito; “and San Giovanni will surely be as
3475: well satisfied with that produce of Italian looms as Minerva with her
3476: peplos, especially as he contents himself with so little drapery. But
3477: my eyes are less delighted with those whirling towers, which would soon
3478: make me fall from the window in sympathetic vertigo.”
3479: 
3480: The “towers” of which Tito spoke were a part of the procession esteemed
3481: very glorious by the Florentine populace; and being perhaps chiefly a
3482: kind of hyperbole for the all-efficacious wax taper, were also called
3483: _ceri_. But inasmuch as hyperbole is impracticable in a real and
3484: literal fashion, these gigantic _ceri_, some of them so large as to be
3485: of necessity carried on wheels, were not solid but hollow, and had
3486: their surface made not solely of wax, but of wood and pasteboard,
3487: gilded, carved, and painted, as real sacred tapers often are, with
3488: successive circles of figures—warriors on horseback, foot-soldiers with
3489: lance and shield, dancing maidens, animals, trees and fruits, and in
3490: fine, says the old chronicler, “all things that could delight the eye
3491: and the heart;” the hollowness having the further advantage that men
3492: could stand inside these hyperbolic tapers and whirl them continually,
3493: so as to produce a phantasmagoric effect, which, considering the towers
3494: were numerous, must have been calculated to produce dizziness on a
3495: truly magnificent scale.
3496: 
3497: “_Pestilenza_!” said Piero di Cosimo, moving from the window, “those
3498: whirling circles one above the other are worse than the jangling of all
3499: the bells. Let me know when the last taper has passed.”
3500: 
3501: “Nay, you will surely like to be called when the contadini come
3502: carrying their torches,” said Nello; “you would not miss the
3503: country-folk of the Mugello and the Casentino, of whom your favourite
3504: Leonardo would make a hundred grotesque sketches.”
3505: 
3506: “No,” said Piero, resolutely, “I will see nothing till the car of the
3507: Zecca comes. I have seen clowns enough holding tapers aslant, both with
3508: and without cowls, to last me for my life.”
3509: 
3510: “Here it comes, then, Piero—the car of the Zecca,” called out Nello,
3511: after an interval during which towers and tapers in a descending scale
3512: of size had been making their slow transit.
3513: 
3514: “_Fediddio_!” exclaimed Francesco Cei, “that is a well-tanned San
3515: Giovanni! some sturdy Romagnole beggar-man, I’ll warrant. Our Signoria
3516: plays the host to all the Jewish and Christian scum that every other
3517: city shuts its gates against, and lets them fatten on us like Saint
3518: Anthony’s swine.”
3519: 
3520: The car of the Zecca or Mint, which had just rolled into sight, was
3521: originally an immense wooden tower or _cero_ adorned after the same
3522: fashion as the other tributary _ceri_, mounted on a splendid car, and
3523: drawn by two mouse-coloured oxen, whose mild heads looked out from rich
3524: trappings bearing the arms of the Zecca. But the latter half of the
3525: century was getting rather ashamed of the towers with their circular or
3526: spiral paintings, which had delighted the eyes and the hearts of the
3527: other half, so that they had become a contemptuous proverb, and any
3528: ill-painted figure looking, as will sometimes happen to figures in the
3529: best ages of art, as if it had been boned for a pie, was called a
3530: _fantoccio da cero_, a tower-puppet; consequently improved taste, with
3531: Cecca to help it, had devised for the magnificent Zecca a triumphal car
3532: like a pyramidal catafalque, with ingenious wheels warranted to turn
3533: all corners easily. Round the base were living figures of saints and
3534: angels arrayed in sculpturesque fashion; and on the summit, at the
3535: height of thirty feet, well bound to an iron rod and holding an iron
3536: cross also firmly infixed, stood a living representative of Saint John
3537: the Baptist, with arms and legs bare, a garment of tiger-skins about
3538: his body, and a golden nimbus fastened on his head—as the Precursor was
3539: wont to appear in the cloisters and churches, not having yet revealed
3540: himself to painters as the brown and sturdy boy who made one of the
3541: Holy Family. For where could the image of the patron saint be more
3542: fitly placed than on the symbol of the Zecca? Was not the royal
3543: prerogative of coining money the surest token that a city had won its
3544: independence? and by the blessing of San Giovanni this “beautiful
3545: sheepfold” of his had shown that token earliest among the Italian
3546: cities. Nevertheless, the annual function of representing the patron
3547: saint was not among the high prizes of public life; it was paid for
3548: with something like ten shillings, a cake weighing fourteen pounds, two
3549: bottles of wine, and a handsome supply of light eatables; the money
3550: being furnished by the magnificent Zecca, and the payment in kind being
3551: by peculiar “privilege” presented in a basket suspended on a pole from
3552: an upper window of a private house, whereupon the eidolon of the
3553: austere saint at once invigorated himself with a reasonable share of
3554: the sweets and wine, threw the remnants to the crowd, and embraced the
3555: mighty cake securely with his right arm through the remainder of his
3556: passage. This was the attitude in which the mimic San Giovanni
3557: presented himself as the tall car jerked and vibrated on its slow way
3558: round the piazza to the northern gate of the Baptistery.
3559: 
3560: “There go the Masters of the Zecca, and there is my brother—you see
3561: him, Melema?” cried Cennini, with an agreeable stirring of pride at
3562: showing a stranger what was too familiar to be remarkable to
3563: fellow-citizens. “Behind come the members of the Corporation of
3564: Calimara,[2] the dealers in foreign cloth, to which we have given our
3565: Florentine finish; men of ripe years, you see, who were matriculated
3566: before you were born; and then comes the famous Art of Money-changers.”
3567: 
3568:  [2] “Arte di Calimara,” “arte” being, in this use of it, equivalent to
3569:  corporation.
3570: 
3571: 
3572: “Many of them matriculated also to the noble art of usury before you
3573: were born,” interrupted Francesco Cei, “as you may discern by a certain
3574: fitful glare of the eye and sharp curve of the nose which manifest
3575: their descent from the ancient Harpies, whose portraits you saw
3576: supporting the arms of the Zecca. Shaking off old prejudices now, such
3577: a procession as that of some four hundred passably ugly men carrying
3578: their tapers in open daylight, Diogenes-fashion, as if they were
3579: looking for a lost quattrino, would make a merry spectacle for the
3580: Feast of Fools.”
3581: 
3582: “Blaspheme not against the usages of our city,” said Pietro Cennini,
3583: much offended. “There are new wits who think they see things more truly
3584: because they stand on their heads to look at them, like tumblers and
3585: mountebanks, instead of keeping the attitude of rational men. Doubtless
3586: it makes little difference to Maestro Vaiano’s monkeys whether they see
3587: our Donatello’s statue of Judith with their heads or their tails
3588: uppermost.”
3589: 
3590: “Your solemnity will allow some quarter to playful fancy, I hope,” said
3591: Cei, with a shrug, “else what becomes of the ancients, whose example
3592: you scholars are bound to revere, Messer Pietro? Life was never
3593: anything but a perpetual see-saw between gravity and jest.”
3594: 
3595: “Keep your jest then till your end of the pole is uppermost,” said
3596: Cennini, still angry, “and that is not when the great bond of our
3597: Republic is expressing itself in ancient symbols, without which the
3598: vulgar would be conscious of nothing beyond their own petty wants of
3599: back and stomach, and never rise to the sense of community in religion
3600: and law. There has been no great people without processions, and the
3601: man who thinks himself too wise to be moved by them to anything but
3602: contempt, is like the puddle that was proud of standing alone while the
3603: river rushed by.”
3604: 
3605: No one said anything after this indignant burst of Cennini’s till he
3606: himself spoke again.
3607: 
3608: “Hark! the trumpets of the Signoria: now comes the last stage of the
3609: show, Melema. That is our Gonfaloniere in the middle, in the starred
3610: mantle, with the sword carried before him. Twenty years ago we used to
3611: see our foreign Podesta, who was our judge in civil causes, walking on
3612: his right-hand; but our Republic has been over-doctored by clever
3613: _Medici_. That is the Proposto (Spokesman or Moderator) of the Priori
3614: on the left; then come the other seven Priori; then all the other
3615: magistracies and officials of our Republic. You see your patron the
3616: Segretario?”
3617: 
3618: “There is Messer Bernardo del Nero also,” said Tito; “his visage is a
3619: fine and venerable one, though it has worn rather a petrifying look
3620: towards me.”
3621: 
3622: “Ah,” said Nello, “he is the dragon that guards the remnant of old
3623: Bardo’s gold, which, I fancy, is chiefly that virgin gold that falls
3624: about the fair Romola’s head and shoulders; eh, my Apollino?” he added,
3625: patting Tito’s head.
3626: 
3627: Tito had the youthful grace of blushing, but he had also the adroit and
3628: ready speech that prevents a blush from looking like embarrassment. He
3629: replied at once—
3630: 
3631: “And a very Pactolus it is—a stream with golden ripples. If I were an
3632: alchemist—”
3633: 
3634: He was saved from the need for further speech by the sudden fortissimo
3635: of drums and trumpets and fifes, bursting into the breadth of the
3636: piazza in a grand storm of sound—a roar, a blast, and a whistling, well
3637: befitting a city famous for its musical instruments, and reducing the
3638: members of the closest group to a state of deaf isolation.
3639: 
3640: During this interval Nello observed Tito’s fingers moving in
3641: recognition of some one in the crowd below, but not seeing the
3642: direction of his glance he failed to detect the object of this
3643: greeting—the sweet round blue-eyed face under a white hood—immediately
3644: lost in the narrow border of heads, where there was a continual eclipse
3645: of round contadina cheeks by the harsh-lined features or bent shoulders
3646: of an old spadesman, and where profiles turned as sharply from north to
3647: south as weathercocks under a shifting wind.
3648: 
3649: But when it was felt that the show was ended—when the twelve prisoners
3650: released in honour of the day, and the very _barberi_ or race-horses,
3651: with the arms of their owners embroidered on their cloths, had followed
3652: up the Signoria, and been duly consecrated to San Giovanni, and every
3653: one was moving from the window—Nello, whose Florentine curiosity was of
3654: that lively canine sort which thinks no trifle too despicable for
3655: investigation, put his hand on Tito’s shoulder and said—
3656: 
3657: “What acquaintance was that you were making signals to, eh, _giovane
3658: mio_?”
3659: 
3660: “Some little contadina who probably mistook me for an acquaintance, for
3661: she had honoured me with a greeting.”
3662: 
3663: “Or who wished to begin an acquaintance,” said Nello. “But you are
3664: bound for the Via de’ Bardi and the feast of the Muses: there is no
3665: counting on you for a frolic, else we might have gone in search of
3666: adventures together in the crowd, and had some pleasant fooling in
3667: honour of San Giovanni. But your high fortune has come on you too soon:
3668: I don’t mean the professor’s mantle—_that_ is roomy enough to hide a
3669: few stolen chickens, but— Messer Endymion minded his manners after that
3670: singular good fortune of his; and what says our Luigi Pulci?
3671: 
3672: 
3673: “‘Da quel giorno in qua ch’amor m’accese
3674: Per lei son fatto e gentile e cortese.’”
3675: 
3676: 
3677: “Nello, _amico mio_, thou hast an intolerable trick of making life
3678: stale by forestalling it with thy talk,” said Tito, shrugging his
3679: shoulders, with a look of patient resignation, which was his nearest
3680: approach to anger: “not to mention that such ill-founded babbling would
3681: be held a great offence by that same goddess whose humble worshipper
3682: you are always professing yourself.”
3683: 
3684: “I will be mute,” said Nello, laying his finger on his lips, with a
3685: responding shrug. “But it is only under our four eyes that I talk any
3686: folly about her.”
3687: 
3688: “Pardon! you were on the verge of it just now in the hearing of others.
3689: If you want to ruin me in the minds of Bardo and his daughter—”
3690: 
3691: “Enough, enough!” said Nello. “I am an absurd old barber. It all comes
3692: from that abstinence of mine, in not making bad verses in my youth: for
3693: want of letting my folly run out that way when I was eighteen, it runs
3694: out at my tongue’s end now I am at the unseemly age of fifty. But Nello
3695: has not got his head muffled for all that; he can see a buffalo in the
3696: snow. _Addio, giovane mio_.”
3697: 
3698: 
3699: 
3700: 
3701: CHAPTER IX.
3702: A Man’s Ransom.
3703: 
3704: 
3705: Tito was soon down among the crowd, and, notwithstanding his
3706: indifferent reply to Nello’s question about his chance acquaintance, he
3707: was not without a passing wish, as he made his way round the piazza to
3708: the Corso degli Adimari, that he might encounter the pair of blue eyes
3709: which had looked up towards him from under the square bit of white
3710: linen drapery that formed the ordinary hood of the contadina at festa
3711: time. He was perfectly well aware that that face was Tessa’s; but he
3712: had not chosen to say so. What had Nello to do with the matter? Tito
3713: had an innate love of reticence—let us say a talent for it—which acted
3714: as other impulses do, without any conscious motive, and, like all
3715: people to whom concealment is easy, he would now and then conceal
3716: something which had as little the nature of a secret as the fact that
3717: he had seen a flight of crows.
3718: 
3719: But the passing wish about pretty Tessa was almost immediately eclipsed
3720: by the recurrent recollection of that friar whose face had some
3721: irrecoverable association for him. Why should a sickly fanatic, worn
3722: with fasting, have looked at _him_ in particular, and where in all his
3723: travels could he remember encountering that face before? Folly! such
3724: vague memories hang about the mind like cobwebs, with tickling
3725: importunity—best to sweep them away at a dash: and Tito had pleasanter
3726: occupation for his thoughts. By the time he was turning out of the
3727: Corso degli Adimari into a side-street he was caring only that the sun
3728: was high, and that the procession had kept him longer than he had
3729: intended from his visit to that room in the Via de’ Bardi, where his
3730: coming, he knew, was anxiously awaited. He felt the scene of his
3731: entrance beforehand: the joy beaming diffusedly in the blind face like
3732: the light in a semi-transparent lamp; the transient pink flush on
3733: Romola’s face and neck, which subtracted nothing from her majesty, but
3734: only gave it the exquisite charm of womanly sensitiveness, heightened
3735: still more by what seemed the paradoxical boy-like frankness of her
3736: look and smile. They were the best comrades in the world during the
3737: hours they passed together round the blind man’s chair: she was
3738: constantly appealing to Tito, and he was informing her, yet he felt
3739: himself strangely in subjection to Romola with that simplicity of hers:
3740: he felt for the first time, without defining it to himself, that loving
3741: awe in the presence of noble womanhood, which is perhaps something like
3742: the worship paid of old to a great nature-goddess, who was not
3743: all-knowing, but whose life and power were something deeper and more
3744: primordial than knowledge. They had never been alone together, and he
3745: could frame to himself no probable image of love-scenes between them:
3746: he could only fancy and wish wildly—what he knew was impossible—that
3747: Romola would some day tell him that she loved him. One day in Greece,
3748: as he was leaning over a wall in the sunshine, a little black-eyed
3749: peasant girl, who had rested her water-pot on the wall, crept gradually
3750: nearer and nearer to him, and at last shyly asked him to kiss her,
3751: putting up her round olive cheek very innocently. Tito was used to love
3752: that came in this unsought fashion. But Romola’s love would never come
3753: in that way: would it ever come at all?—and yet it was that topmost
3754: apple on which he had set his mind. He was in his fresh youth—not
3755: passionate, but impressible: it was as inevitable that he should feel
3756: lovingly towards Romola as that the white irises should be reflected in
3757: the clear sunlit stream; but he had no coxcombry, and he had an
3758: intimate sense that Romola was something very much above him. Many men
3759: have felt the same before a large-eyed, simple child.
3760: 
3761: Nevertheless, Tito had had the rapid success which would have made some
3762: men presuming, or would have warranted him in thinking that there would
3763: be no great presumption in entertaining an agreeable confidence that he
3764: might one day be the husband of Romola—nay, that her father himself was
3765: not without a vision of such a future for him. His first auspicious
3766: interview with Bartolommeo Scala had proved the commencement of a
3767: growing favour on the secretary’s part, and had led to an issue which
3768: would have been enough to make Tito decide on Florence as the place in
3769: which to establish himself, even if it had held no other magnet.
3770: Politian was professor of Greek as well as Latin at Florence,
3771: professorial chairs being maintained there, although the university had
3772: been removed to Pisa; but for a long time Demetrio Calcondila, one of
3773: the most eminent and respectable among the emigrant Greeks, had also
3774: held a Greek chair, simultaneously with the too predominant Italian.
3775: Calcondila was now gone to Milan, and there was no counterpoise or
3776: rival to Politian such as was desired for him by the friends who wished
3777: him to be taught a little propriety and humility. Scala was far from
3778: being the only friend of this class, and he found several who, if they
3779: were not among those thirsty admirers of mediocrity that were glad to
3780: be refreshed with his verses in hot weather, were yet quite willing to
3781: join him in doing that moral service to Politian. It was finally agreed
3782: that Tito should be supported in a Greek chair, as Demetrio Calcondila
3783: had been by Lorenzo himself, who, being at the same time the
3784: affectionate patron of Politian, had shown by precedent that there was
3785: nothing invidious in such a measure, but only a zeal for true learning
3786: and for the instruction of the Florentine youth.
3787: 
3788: Tito was thus sailing under the fairest breeze, and besides convincing
3789: fair judges that his talents squared with his good fortune, he wore
3790: that fortune so easily and unpretentiously that no one had yet been
3791: offended by it. He was not unlikely to get into the best Florentine
3792: society: society where there was much more plate than the circle of
3793: enamelled silver in the centre of the brass dishes, and where it was
3794: not forbidden by the Signory to wear the richest brocade. For where
3795: could a handsome young scholar not be welcome when he could touch the
3796: lute and troll a gay song? That bright face, that easy smile, that
3797: liquid voice, seemed to give life a holiday aspect; just as a strain of
3798: gay music and the hoisting of colours make the work-worn and the sad
3799: rather ashamed of showing themselves. Here was a professor likely to
3800: render the Greek classics amiable to the sons of great houses.
3801: 
3802: And that was not the whole of Tito’s good fortune; for he had sold all
3803: his jewels, except the ring he did not choose to part with, and he was
3804: master of full five hundred gold florins.
3805: 
3806: Yet the moment when he first had this sum in his possession was the
3807: crisis of the first serious struggle his facile, good-humoured nature
3808: had known. An importunate thought, of which he had till now refused to
3809: see more than the shadow as it dogged his footsteps, at last rushed
3810: upon him and grasped him: he was obliged to pause and decide whether he
3811: would surrender and obey, or whether he would give the refusal that
3812: must carry irrevocable consequences. It was in the room above Nello’s
3813: shop, which Tito had now hired as a lodging, that the elder Cennini
3814: handed him the last quota of the sum on behalf of Bernardo Rucellai,
3815: the purchaser of the two most valuable gems.
3816: 
3817: “_Ecco, giovane mio_!” said the respectable printer and goldsmith, “you
3818: have now a pretty little fortune; and if you will take my advice, you
3819: will let me place your florins in a safe quarter, where they may
3820: increase and multiply, instead of slipping through your fingers for
3821: banquets and other follies which are rife among our Florentine youth.
3822: And it has been too much the fashion of scholars, especially when, like
3823: our Pietro Crinito, they think their scholarship needs to be scented
3824: and broidered, to squander with one hand till they have been fain to
3825: beg with the other. I have brought you the money, and you are free to
3826: make a wise choice or an unwise: I shall see on which side the balance
3827: dips. We Florentines hold no man a member of an Art till he has shown
3828: his skill and been matriculated; and no man is matriculated to the art
3829: of life till he has been well tempted. If you make up your mind to put
3830: your florins out to usury, you can let me know to-morrow. A scholar may
3831: marry, and should have something in readiness for the _morgen-cap.
3832: Addio_.”[1]
3833: 
3834:  [1] A sum given by the bridegroom to the bride the day after the
3835:  marriage. _Morgengabe_.
3836: 
3837: 
3838: As Cennini closed the door behind him, Tito turned round with the smile
3839: dying out of his face, and fixed his eyes on the table where the
3840: florins lay. He made no other movement, but stood with his thumbs in
3841: his belt, looking down, in that transfixed state which accompanies the
3842: concentration of consciousness on some inward image.
3843: 
3844: “A man’s ransom!”—who was it that had said five hundred florins was
3845: more than a man’s ransom? If now, under this mid-day sun, on some hot
3846: coast far away, a man somewhat stricken in years—a man not without high
3847: thoughts and with the most passionate heart—a man who long years ago
3848: had rescued a little boy from a life of beggary, filth, and cruel
3849: wrong, had reared him tenderly, and been to him as a father—if that man
3850: _were_ now under this summer sun toiling as a slave, hewing wood and
3851: drawing water, perhaps being smitten and buffeted because he was not
3852: deft and active? If he were saying to himself, “Tito will find me: he
3853: had but to carry our manuscripts and gems to Venice; he will have
3854: raised money, and will never rest till he finds me out”? If that were
3855: certain, could he, Tito, see the price of the gems lying before him,
3856: and say, “I will stay at Florence, where I am fanned by soft airs of
3857: promised love and prosperity; I will not risk myself for his sake”? No,
3858: surely not, _if it were certain_. But nothing could be farther from
3859: certainty. The galley had been taken by a Turkish vessel on its way to
3860: Delos: _that_ was known by the report of the companion galley, which
3861: had escaped. But there had been resistance, and probable bloodshed; a
3862: man had been seen falling overboard: who were the survivors, and what
3863: had befallen them amongst all the multitude of possibilities? Had not
3864: he, Tito, suffered shipwreck, and narrowly escaped drowning? He had
3865: good cause for feeling the omnipresence of casualties that threatened
3866: all projects with futility. The rumour that there were pirates who had
3867: a settlement in Delos was not to be depended on, or might be nothing to
3868: the purpose. What, probably enough, would be the result if he were to
3869: quit Florence and go to Venice; get authoritative letters—yes, he knew
3870: that might be done—and set out for the Archipelago? Why, that he should
3871: be himself seized, and spend all his florins on preliminaries, and be
3872: again a destitute wanderer—with no more gems to sell.
3873: 
3874: Tito had a clearer vision of that result than of the possible moment
3875: when he might find his father again, and carry him deliverance. It
3876: would surely be an unfairness that he, in his full ripe youth, to whom
3877: life had hitherto had some of the stint and subjection of a school,
3878: should turn his back on promised love and distinction, and perhaps
3879: never be visited by that promise again. “And yet,” he said to himself,
3880: “if I were certain that Baldassarre Calvo was alive, and that I could
3881: free him, by whatever exertions or perils, I would go now—now I have
3882: the money: it was useless to debate the matter before. I would go now
3883: to Bardo and Bartolommeo Scala, and tell them the whole truth.” Tito
3884: did not say to himself so distinctly that if those two men had known
3885: the whole truth he was aware there would have been no alternative for
3886: him but to go in search of his benefactor, who, if alive, was the
3887: rightful owner of the gems, and whom he had always equivocally spoken
3888: of as “lost;” he did not say to himself—what he was not ignorant
3889: of—that Greeks of distinction had made sacrifices, taken voyages again
