3890: and again, and sought help from crowned and mitred heads for the sake
3891: of freeing relatives from slavery to the Turks. Public opinion did not
3892: regard this as exceptional virtue.
3893: 
3894: This was his first real colloquy with himself: he had gone on following
3895: the impulses of the moment, and one of those impulses had been to
3896: conceal half the fact; he had never considered this part of his conduct
3897: long enough to face the consciousness of his motives for the
3898: concealment. What was the use of telling the whole? It was true, the
3899: thought had crossed his mind several times since he had quitted Nauplia
3900: that, after all, it was a great relief to be quit of Baldassarre, and
3901: he would have liked to know _who_ it was that had fallen overboard. But
3902: such thoughts spring inevitably out of a relation that is irksome.
3903: Baldassarre was exacting, and had got stranger as he got older: he was
3904: constantly scrutinising Tito’s mind to see whether it answered to his
3905: own exaggerated expectations; and age—the age of a thickset,
3906: heavy-browed, bald man beyond sixty, whose intensity and eagerness in
3907: the grasp of ideas have long taken the character of monotony and
3908: repetition, may be looked at from many points of view without being
3909: found attractive. Such a man, stranded among new acquaintances, unless
3910: he had the philosopher’s stone, would hardly find rank, youth, and
3911: beauty at his feet. The feelings that gather fervour from novelty will
3912: be of little help towards making the world a home for dimmed and faded
3913: human beings; and if there is any love of which they are not widowed,
3914: it must be the love that is rooted in memories and distils perpetually
3915: the sweet balms of fidelity and forbearing tenderness.
3916: 
3917: But surely such memories were not absent from Tito’s mind? Far in the
3918: backward vista of his remembered life, when he was only seven years
3919: old, Baldassarre had rescued him from blows, had taken him to a home
3920: that seemed like opened paradise, where there was sweet food and
3921: soothing caresses, all had on Baldassarre’s knee; and from that time
3922: till the hour they had parted, Tito had been the one centre of
3923: Baldassarre’s fatherly cares.
3924: 
3925: And he had been docile, pliable, quick of apprehension, ready to
3926: acquire: a very bright lovely boy, a youth of even splendid grace, who
3927: seemed quite without vices, as if that beautiful form represented a
3928: vitality so exquisitely poised and balanced that it could know no
3929: uneasy desires, no unrest—a radiant presence for a lonely man to have
3930: won for himself. If he were silent when his father expected some
3931: response, still he did not look moody; if he declined some labour—why,
3932: he flung himself down with such a charming, half-smiling, half-pleading
3933: air, that the pleasure of looking at him made amends to one who had
3934: watched his growth with a sense of claim and possession: the curves of
3935: Tito’s mouth had ineffable good-humour in them. And then, the quick
3936: talent to which everything came readily, from philosophical systems to
3937: the rhymes of a street ballad caught up at a hearing! Would any one
3938: have said that Tito had not made a rich return to his benefactor, or
3939: that his gratitude and affection would fail on any great demand?
3940: 
3941: He did not admit that his gratitude had failed; but _it was not
3942: certain_ that Baldassarre was in slavery, not certain that he was
3943: living.
3944: 
3945: “Do I not owe something to myself?” said Tito, inwardly, with a slight
3946: movement of his shoulders, the first he had made since he had turned to
3947: look down at the florins. “Before I quit everything, and incur again
3948: all the risks of which I am even now weary, I must at least have a
3949: reasonable hope. Am I to spend my life in a wandering search? _I
3950: believe he is dead_. Cennini was right about my florins: I will place
3951: them in his hands to-morrow.”
3952: 
3953: When, the next morning, Tito put this determination into act he had
3954: chosen his colour in the game, and had given an inevitable bent to his
3955: wishes. He had made it impossible that he should not from henceforth
3956: desire it to be the truth that his father was dead; impossible that he
3957: should not be tempted to baseness rather than that the precise facts of
3958: his conduct should not remain for ever concealed.
3959: 
3960: Under every guilty secret there is hidden a brood of guilty wishes,
3961: whose unwholesome infecting life is cherished by the darkness. The
3962: contaminating effect of deeds often lies less in the commission than in
3963: the consequent adjustment of our desires—the enlistment of our
3964: self-interest on the side of falsity; as, on the other hand, the
3965: purifying influence of public confession springs from the fact, that by
3966: it the hope in lies is for ever swept away, and the soul recovers the
3967: noble attitude of simplicity.
3968: 
3969: Besides, in this first distinct colloquy with himself the ideas which
3970: had previously been scattered and interrupted had now concentrated
3971: themselves; the little rills of selfishness had united and made a
3972: channel, so that they could never again meet with the same resistance.
3973: Hitherto Tito had left in vague indecision the question whether, with
3974: the means in his power, he would not return, and ascertain his father’s
3975: fate; he had now made a definite excuse to himself for not taking that
3976: course; he had avowed to himself a choice which he would have been
3977: ashamed to avow to others, and which would have made him ashamed in the
3978: resurgent presence of his father. But the inward shame, the reflex of
3979: that outward law which the great heart of mankind makes for every
3980: individual man, a reflex which will exist even in the absence of the
3981: sympathetic impulses that need no law, but rush to the deed of fidelity
3982: and pity as inevitably as the brute mother shields her young from the
3983: attack of the hereditary enemy—that inward shame was showing its
3984: blushes in Tito’s determined assertion to himself that his father was
3985: dead, or that at least search was hopeless.
3986: 
3987: 
3988: 
3989: 
3990: CHAPTER X.
3991: Under the Plane-Tree.
3992: 
3993: 
3994: On the day of San Giovanni it was already three weeks ago that Tito had
3995: handed his florins to Cennini, and we have seen that as he set out
3996: towards the Via de’ Bardi he showed all the outward signs of a mind at
3997: ease. How should it be otherwise? He never jarred with what was
3998: immediately around him, and his nature was too joyous, too
3999: unapprehensive, for the hidden and the distant to grasp him in the
4000: shape of a dread. As he turned out of the hot sunshine into the shelter
4001: of a narrow street, took off the black cloth berretta, or simple cap
4002: with upturned lappet, which just crowned his brown curls, pushing his
4003: hair and tossing his head backward to court the cooler air, there was
4004: no brand of duplicity on his brow; neither was there any stamp of
4005: candour: it was simply a finely-formed, square, smooth young brow. And
4006: the slow absent glance he cast around at the upper windows of the
4007: houses had neither more dissimulation in it, nor more ingenuousness,
4008: than belongs to a youthful well-opened eyelid with its unwearied
4009: breadth of gaze; to perfectly pellucid lenses; to the undimmed dark of
4010: a rich brown iris; and to a pure cerulean-tinted angle of whiteness
4011: streaked with the delicate shadows of long eyelashes. Was it that
4012: Tito’s face attracted or repelled according to the mental attitude of
4013: the observer? Was it a cypher with more than one key? The strong,
4014: unmistakable expression in his whole air and person was a negative one,
4015: and it was perfectly veracious; it declared the absence of any uneasy
4016: claim, any restless vanity, and it made the admiration that followed
4017: him as he passed among the troop of holiday-makers a thoroughly willing
4018: tribute.
4019: 
4020: For by this time the stir of the Festa was felt even in the narrowest
4021: side-streets; the throng which had at one time been concentrated in the
4022: lines through which the procession had to pass, was now streaming out
4023: in all directions in pursuit of a new object. Such intervals of a Festa
4024: are precisely the moments when the vaguely active animal spirits of a
4025: crowd are likely to be the most petulant and most ready to sacrifice a
4026: stray individual to the greater happiness of the greater number. As
4027: Tito entered the neighbourhood of San Martino, he found the throng
4028: rather denser; and near the hostelry of the _Bertucce_, or Baboons,
4029: there was evidently some object which was arresting the passengers and
4030: forming them into a knot. It needed nothing of great interest to draw
4031: aside passengers unfreighted with a purpose, and Tito was preparing to
4032: turn aside into an adjoining street, when, amidst the loud laughter,
4033: his ear discerned a distressed childish voice crying, “Loose me! Holy
4034: Virgin, help me!” which at once determined him to push his way into the
4035: knot of gazers. He had just had time to perceive that the distressed
4036: voice came from a young contadina, whose white hood had fallen off in
4037: the struggle to get her hands free from the grasp of a man in the
4038: parti-coloured dress of a _cerretano_, or conjuror, who was making
4039: laughing attempts to soothe and cajole her, evidently carrying with him
4040: the amused sympathy of the spectators. These, by a persuasive variety
4041: of words signifying simpleton, for which the Florentine dialect is rich
4042: in equivalents, seemed to be arguing with the contadina against her
4043: obstinacy. At the first moment the girl’s face was turned away, and he
4044: saw only her light-brown hair plaited and fastened with a long silver
4045: pin; but in the next, the struggle brought her face opposite Tito’s,
4046: and he saw the baby features of Tessa, her blue eyes filled with tears,
4047: and her under-lip quivering. Tessa, too, saw _him_, and through the
4048: mist of her swelling tears there beamed a sudden hope, like that in the
4049: face of a little child, when, held by a stranger against its will, it
4050: sees a familiar hand stretched out.
4051: 
4052: In an instant Tito had pushed his way through the barrier of
4053: bystanders, whose curiosity made them ready to turn aside at the sudden
4054: interference of this handsome young signor, had grasped Tessa’s waist,
4055: and had said, “Loose this child! What right have you to hold her
4056: against her will?”
4057: 
4058: The conjuror—a man with one of those faces in which the angles of the
4059: eyes and eyebrows, of the nostrils, mouth, and sharply-defined jaw, all
4060: tend upward—showed his small regular teeth in an impish but not
4061: ill-natured grin, as he let go Tessa’s hands, and stretched out his own
4062: backward, shrugging his shoulders, and bending them forward a little in
4063: a half-apologetic, half-protesting manner.
4064: 
4065: “I mean the ragazza no evil in the world, Messere: ask this respectable
4066: company. I was only going to show them a few samples of my skill, in
4067: which this little damsel might have helped me the better because of her
4068: kitten face, which would have assured them of open dealing; and I had
4069: promised her a lapful of confetti as a reward. But what then? Messer
4070: has doubtless better confetti at hand, and she knows it.”
4071: 
4072: A general laugh among the bystanders accompanied these last words of
4073: the conjuror, raised, probably, by the look of relief and confidence
4074: with which Tessa clung to Tito’s arm, as he drew it from her waist, and
4075: placed her hand within it. She only cared about the laugh as she might
4076: have cared about the roar of wild beasts from which she was escaping,
4077: not attaching any meaning to it; but Tito, who had no sooner got her on
4078: his arm than he foresaw some embarrassment in the situation, hastened
4079: to get clear of observers who, having been despoiled of an expected
4080: amusement, were sure to re-establish the balance by jests.
4081: 
4082: “See, see, little one! here is your hood,” said the conjuror, throwing
4083: the bit of white drapery over Tessa’s head. “_Orsù_, bear me no malice;
4084: come back to me when Messere can spare you.”
4085: 
4086: “Ah! Maestro Vaiano, she’ll come back presently, as the toad said to
4087: the harrow,” called out one of the spectators, seeing how Tessa started
4088: and shrank at the action of the conjuror.
4089: 
4090: Tito pushed his way vigorously towards the corner of a side-street, a
4091: little vexed at this delay in his progress to the Via de’ Bardi, and
4092: intending to get rid of the poor little contadina as soon as possible.
4093: The next street, too, had its passengers inclined to make holiday
4094: remarks on so unusual a pair; but they had no sooner entered it than he
4095: said, in a kind but hurried manner, “Now, little one, where were you
4096: going? Are you come by yourself to the Festa?”
4097: 
4098: “Ah, no!” said Tessa, looking frightened and distressed again; “I have
4099: lost my mother in the crowd—her and my father-in-law. They will be
4100: angry—he will beat me. It was in the crowd in San Pulinari—somebody
4101: pushed me along and I couldn’t stop myself, so I got away from them.
4102: Oh, I don’t know where they’re gone! Please, don’t leave me!”
4103: 
4104: Her eyes had been swelling with tears again, and she ended with a sob.
4105: 
4106: Tito hurried along again: the Church of the Badia was not far off. They
4107: could enter it by the cloister that opened at the back, and in the
4108: church he could talk to Tessa—perhaps leave her. No! it was an hour at
4109: which the church was not open; but they paused under the shelter of the
4110: cloister, and he said, “Have you no cousin or friend in Florence, my
4111: little Tessa, whose house you could find; or are you afraid of walking
4112: by yourself since you have been frightened by the conjuror? I am in a
4113: hurry to get to Oltrarno, but if I could take you anywhere near—”
4114: 
4115: “Oh, I _am_ frightened: he was the devil—I know he was. And I don’t
4116: know where to go. I have nobody: and my mother meant to have her dinner
4117: somewhere, and I don’t know where. Holy Madonna! I shall be beaten.”
4118: 
4119: The corners of the pouting mouth went down piteously, and the poor
4120: little bosom with the beads on it above the green serge gown heaved so,
4121: that there was no longer any help for it: a loud sob _would_ come, and
4122: the big tears fell as if they were making up for lost time. Here was a
4123: situation! It would have been brutal to leave her, and Tito’s nature
4124: was all gentleness. He wished at that moment that he had not been
4125: expected in the Via de’ Bardi. As he saw her lifting up her holiday
4126: apron to catch the hurrying tears, he laid his hand, too, on the apron,
4127: and rubbed one of the cheeks and kissed the baby-like roundness.
4128: 
4129: “My poor little Tessa! leave off crying. Let us see what can be done.
4130: Where is your home—where do you live?”
4131: 
4132: There was no answer, but the sobs began to subside a little and the
4133: drops to fall less quickly.
4134: 
4135: “Come! I’ll take you a little way, if you’ll tell me where you want to
4136: go.”
4137: 
4138: The apron fell, and Tessa’s face began to look as contented as a
4139: cherub’s budding from a cloud. The diabolical conjuror, the anger and
4140: the beating, seemed a long way off.
4141: 
4142: “I think I’ll go home, if you’ll take me,” she said, in a half whisper,
4143: looking up at Tito with wide blue eyes, and with something sweeter than
4144: a smile—with a childlike calm.
4145: 
4146: “Come, then, little one,” said Tito, in a caressing tone, putting her
4147: arm within his again. “Which way is it?”
4148: 
4149: “Beyond Peretola—where the large pear-tree is.”
4150: 
4151: “Peretola? Out at which gate, pazzarella? I am a stranger, you must
4152: remember.”
4153: 
4154: “Out at the Por del Prato,” said Tessa, moving along with a very fast
4155: hold on Tito’s arm.
4156: 
4157: He did not know all the turnings well enough to venture on an attempt
4158: at choosing the quietest streets; and besides, it occurred to him that
4159: where the passengers were most numerous there was, perhaps, the most
4160: chance of meeting with Monna Ghita and finding an end to his
4161: knight-errant-ship. So he made straight for Porta Rossa, and on to
4162: Ognissanti, showing his usual bright propitiatory face to the mixed
4163: observers who threw their jests at him and his little heavy-shod maiden
4164: with much liberality. Mingled with the more decent holiday-makers there
4165: were frolicsome apprentices, rather envious of his good fortune;
4166: bold-eyed women with the badge of the yellow veil; beggars who thrust
4167: forward their caps for alms, in derision at Tito’s evident haste;
4168: dicers, sharpers, and loungers of the worst sort; boys whose tongues
4169: were used to wag in concert at the most brutal street games: for the
4170: streets of Florence were not always a moral spectacle in those times,
4171: and Tessa’s terror at being lost in the crowd was not wholly
4172: unreasonable.
4173: 
4174: When they reached the Piazza d’Ognissanti, Tito slackened his pace:
4175: they were both heated with their hurried walk, and here was a wider
4176: space where they could take breath. They sat down on one of the stone
4177: benches which were frequent against the walls of old Florentine houses.
4178: 
4179: “Holy Virgin!” said Tessa; “I am glad we have got away from those women
4180: and boys; but I was not frightened, because you could take care of me.”
4181: 
4182: “Pretty little Tessa!” said Tito, smiling at her. “What makes you feel
4183: so safe with me?”
4184: 
4185: “Because you are so beautiful—like the people going into Paradise: they
4186: are all good.”
4187: 
4188: “It is a long while since you had your breakfast, Tessa,” said Tito,
4189: seeing some stalls near, with fruit and sweetmeats upon them. “Are you
4190: hungry?”
4191: 
4192: “Yes, I think I am—if you will have some too.”
4193: 
4194: Tito bought some apricots, and cakes, and comfits, and put them into
4195: her apron.
4196: 
4197: “Come,” he said, “let us walk on to the Prato, and then perhaps you
4198: will not be afraid to go the rest of the way alone.”
4199: 
4200: “But you will have some of the apricots and things,” said Tessa, rising
4201: obediently and gathering up her apron as a bag for her store.
4202: 
4203: “We will see,” said Tito aloud; and to himself he said, “Here is a
4204: little contadina who might inspire a better idyl than Lorenzo de’
4205: Medici’s ‘Nencia da Barberino,’ that Nello’s friends rave about; if I
4206: were only a Theocritus, or had time to cultivate the necessary
4207: experience by unseasonable walks of this sort! However, the mischief is
4208: done now: I am so late already that another half-hour will make no
4209: difference. Pretty little pigeon!”
4210: 
4211: “We have a garden and plenty of pears,” said Tessa, “and two cows,
4212: besides the mules; and I’m very fond of them. But my father-in-law is a
4213: cross man: I wish my mother had not married him. I think he is wicked;
4214: he is very ugly.”
4215: 
4216: “And does your mother let him beat you, poverina? You said you were
4217: afraid of being beaten.”
4218: 
4219: “Ah, my mother herself scolds me: she loves my young sister better, and
4220: thinks I don’t do work enough. Nobody speaks kindly to me, only the
4221: Pievano (parish priest) when I go to confession. And the men in the
4222: Mercato laugh at me and make fun of me. Nobody ever kissed me and spoke
4223: to me as you do; just as I talk to my little black-faced kid, because
4224: I’m very fond of it.”
4225: 
4226: It seemed not to have entered Tessa’s mind that there was any change in
4227: Tito’s appearance since the morning he begged the milk from her, and
4228: that he looked now like a personage for whom she must summon her little
4229: stock of reverent words and signs. He had impressed her too differently
4230: from any human being who had ever come near her before, for her to make
4231: any comparison of details; she took no note of his dress; he was simply
4232: a voice and a face to her, something come from Paradise into a world
4233: where most things seemed hard and angry; and she prattled with as
4234: little restraint as if he had been an imaginary companion born of her
4235: own lovingness and the sunshine.
4236: 
4237: They had now reached the Prato, which at that time was a large open
4238: space within the walls, where the Florentine youth played at their
4239: favourite _Calcio_—a peculiar kind of football—and otherwise exercised
4240: themselves. At this mid-day time it was forsaken and quiet to the very
4241: gates, where a tent had been erected in preparation for the race. On
4242: the border of this wide meadow, Tito paused and said—
4243: 
4244: “Now, Tessa, you will not be frightened if I leave you to walk the rest
4245: of the way by yourself. Addio! Shall I come and buy a cup of milk from
4246: you in the Mercato to-morrow morning, to see that you are quite safe?”
4247: 
4248: He added this question in a soothing tone, as he saw her eyes widening
4249: sorrowfully, and the corners of her mouth falling. She said nothing at
4250: first; she only opened her apron and looked down at her apricots and
4251: sweetmeats. Then she looked up at him again and said complainingly—
4252: 
4253: “I thought you would have some, and we could sit down under a tree
4254: outside the gate, and eat them together.”
4255: 
4256: “Tessa, Tessa, you little siren, you would ruin me,” said Tito,
4257: laughing, and kissing both her cheeks. “I ought to have been in the Via
4258: de’ Bardi long ago. No! I must go back now; you are in no danger.
4259: There—I’ll take an apricot. Addio!”
4260: 
4261: He had already stepped two yards from her when he said the last word.
4262: Tessa could not have spoken; she was pale, and a great sob was rising;
4263: but she turned round as if she felt there was no hope for her, and
4264: stepped on, holding her apron so forgetfully that the apricots began to
4265: roll out on the grass.
4266: 
4267: Tito could not help looking after her, and seeing her shoulders rise to
4268: the bursting sob, and the apricots fall—could not help going after her
4269: and picking them up. It was very hard upon him: he was a long way off
4270: the Via de’ Bardi, and very near to Tessa.
4271: 
4272: “See, my silly one,” he said, picking up the apricots. “Come, leave off
4273: crying, I will go with you, and we’ll sit down under the tree. Come, I
4274: don’t like to see you cry; but you know I must go back some time.”
4275: 
4276: So it came to pass that they found a great plane-tree not far outside
4277: the gates, and they sat down under it, and all the feast was spread out
4278: on Tessa’s lap, she leaning with her back against the trunk of the
4279: tree, and he stretched opposite to her, resting his elbows on the rough
4280: green growth cherished by the shade, while the sunlight stole through
4281: the boughs and played about them like a winged thing. Tessa’s face was
4282: all contentment again, and the taste of the apricots and sweetmeats
4283: seemed very good.
4284: 
4285: “You pretty bird!” said Tito, looking at her as she sat eyeing the
4286: remains of the feast with an evident mental debate about saving them,
4287: since he had said he would not have any more. “To think of any one
4288: scolding you! What sins do you tell of at confession, Tessa?”
4289: 
4290: “Oh, a great many. I am often naughty. I don’t like work, and I can’t
4291: help being idle, though I know I shall be beaten and scolded; and I
4292: give the mules the best fodder when nobody sees me, and then when the
4293: Madre is angry I say I didn’t do it, and that makes me frightened at
4294: the devil. I think the conjuror was the devil. I am not so frightened
4295: after I’ve been to confession. And see, I’ve got a _Breve_ here that a
4296: good father, who came to Prato preaching this Easter, blessed and gave
4297: us all.” Here Tessa drew from her bosom a tiny bag carefully fastened
4298: up. “And I think the holy Madonna will take care of me; she looks as if
4299: she would; and perhaps if I wasn’t idle, she wouldn’t let me be
4300: beaten.”
4301: 
4302: “If they are so cruel to you, Tessa, shouldn’t you like to leave them,
4303: and go and live with a beautiful lady who would be kind to you, if she
4304: would have you to wait upon her?”
4305: 
4306: Tessa seemed to hold her breath for a moment or two. Then she said
4307: doubtfully, “I don’t know.”
4308: 
4309: “Then should you like to be my little servant, and live with me?” said
4310: Tito, smiling. He meant no more than to see what sort of pretty look
4311: and answer she would give.
4312: 
4313: There was a flush of joy immediately. “Will you take me with you now?
4314: Ah! I shouldn’t go home and be beaten then.” She paused a little while,
4315: and then added more doubtfully, “But I should like to fetch my
4316: black-faced kid.”
4317: 
4318: “Yes, you must go back to your kid, my Tessa,” said Tito, rising, “and
4319: I must go the other way.”
4320: 
4321: “By Jupiter!” he added, as he went from under the shade of the tree,
4322: “it is not a pleasant time of day to walk from here to the Via de’
4323: Bardi; I am more inclined to lie down and sleep in this shade.”
4324: 
4325: It ended so. Tito had an unconquerable aversion to anything unpleasant,
4326: even when an object very much loved and desired was on the other side
4327: of it. He had risen early; had waited; had seen sights, and had been
4328: already walking in the sun: he was inclined for a siesta, and inclined
4329: all the more because little Tessa was there, and seemed to make the air
4330: softer. He lay down on the grass again, putting his cap under his head
4331: on a green tuft by the side of Tessa. That was not quite comfortable;
4332: so he moved again, and asked Tessa to let him rest his head against her
4333: lap; and in that way he soon fell asleep. Tessa sat quiet as a dove on
4334: its nest, just venturing, when he was fast asleep, to touch the
4335: wonderful dark curls that fell backward from his ear. She was too happy
4336: to go to sleep—too happy to think that Tito would wake up, and that
4337: then he would leave her, and she must go home. It takes very little
4338: water to make a perfect pool for a tiny fish, where it will find its
4339: world and paradise all in one, and never have a presentiment of the dry
4340: bank. The fretted summer shade, and stillness, and the gentle breathing
4341: of some loved life near—it would be paradise to us all, if eager
4342: thought, the strong angel with the implacable brow, had not long since
4343: closed the gates.
4344: 
4345: It really was a long while before the waking came—before the long dark
4346: eyes opened at Tessa, first with a little surprise, and then with a
4347: smile, which was soon quenched by some preoccupying thought. Tito’s
4348: deeper sleep had broken into a doze, in which he felt himself in the
4349: Via de’ Bardi, explaining his failure to appear at the appointed time.
4350: The clear images of that doze urged him to start up at once to a
4351: sitting posture, and as he stretched his arms and shook his cap, he
4352: said—
4353: 
4354: “Tessa, little one, you have let me sleep too long. My hunger and the
4355: shadows together tell me that the sun has done much travel since I fell
4356: asleep. I must lose no more time. Addio,” he ended, patting her cheek
4357: with one hand, and settling his cap with the other.
4358: 
4359: She said nothing, but there were signs in her face which made him speak
4360: again in as serious and as chiding a tone as he could command—
4361: 
4362: “Now, Tessa, you must not cry. I shall be angry; I shall not love you
4363: if you cry. You must go home to your black-faced kid, or if you like
4364: you may go back to the gate and see the horses start. But I can stay
4365: with you no longer, and if you cry, I shall think you are troublesome
4366: to me.”
4367: 
4368: The rising tears were checked by terror at this change in Tito’s voice.
4369: Tessa turned very pale, and sat in trembling silence, with her blue
4370: eyes widened by arrested tears.
4371: 
4372: “Look now,” Tito went on, soothingly, opening the wallet that hung at
4373: his belt, “here is a pretty charm that I have had a long while—ever
4374: since I was in Sicily, a country a long way off.”
4375: 
4376: His wallet had many little matters in it mingled with small coins, and
4377: he had the usual difficulty in laying his finger on the right thing. He
4378: unhooked his wallet, and turned out the contents on Tessa’s lap. Among
4379: them was his onyx ring.
4380: 
4381: “Ah, my ring!” he exclaimed, slipping it on the forefinger of his
4382: right-hand. “I forgot to put it on again this morning. Strange, I never
4383: missed it! See, Tessa,” he added, as he spread out the smaller
4384: articles, and selected the one he was in search of. “See this pretty
4385: little pointed bit of red coral—like your goat’s horn, is it not?—and
4386: here is a hole in it, so you can put it on the cord round your neck
4387: along with your _Breve_, and then the evil spirits can’t hurt you: if
4388: you ever see them coming in the shadow round the corner, point this
4389: little coral horn at them, and they will run away. It is a ‘buona
4390: fortuna,’ and will keep you from harm when I am not with you. Come,
4391: undo the cord.”
4392: 
4393: Tessa obeyed with a tranquillising sense that life was going to be
4394: something quite new, and that Tito would be with her often. All who
4395: remember their childhood remember the strange vague sense, when some
4396: new experience came, that everything else was going to be changed, and
4397: that there would be no lapse into the old monotony. So the bit of coral
4398: was hung beside the tiny bag with the scrap of scrawled parchment in
4399: it, and Tessa felt braver.
4400: 
4401: “And now you will give me a kiss,” said Tito, economising time by
4402: speaking while he swept in the contents of the wallet and hung it at
4403: his waist again, “and look happy, like a good girl, and then—”
4404: 
4405: But Tessa had obediently put forward her lips in a moment, and kissed
4406: his cheek as he hung down his head.
4407: 
4408: “Oh, you pretty pigeon!” cried Tito, laughing, pressing her round
4409: cheeks with his hands and crushing her features together so as to give
4410: them a general impartial kiss.
4411: 
4412: Then he started up and walked away, not looking round till he was ten
4413: yards from her, when he just turned and gave a parting beck. Tessa was
4414: looking after him, but he could see that she was making no signs of
4415: distress. It was enough for Tito if she did not cry while he was
4416: present. The softness of his nature required that all sorrow should be
4417: hidden away from him.
4418: 
4419: “I wonder when Romola will kiss my cheek in that way?” thought Tito, as
4420: he walked along. It seemed a tiresome distance now, and he almost
4421: wished he had not been so soft-hearted, or so tempted to linger in the
4422: shade. No other excuse was needed to Bardo and Romola than saying
4423: simply that he had been unexpectedly hindered; he felt confident their
4424: proud delicacy would inquire no farther. He lost no time in getting to
4425: Ognissanti, and hastily taking some food there, he crossed the Arno by
4426: the Ponte alia Carraja, and made his way as directly as possible
4427: towards the Via de’ Bardi.
4428: 
4429: But it was the hour when all the world who meant to be in particularly
4430: good time to see the Corso were returning from the Borghi, or villages
4431: just outside the gates, where they had dined and reposed themselves;
4432: and the thoroughfares leading to the bridges were of course the issues
4433: towards which the stream of sightseers tended. Just as Tito reached the
4434: Ponte Vecchio and the entrance of the Via de’ Bardi, he was suddenly
4435: urged back towards the angle of the intersecting streets. A company on
4436: horseback, coming from the Via Guicciardini, and turning up the Via de’
4437: Bardi, had compelled the foot-passengers to recede hurriedly. Tito had
4438: been walking, as his manner was, with the thumb of his right-hand
4439: resting in his belt; and as he was thus forced to pause, and was
4440: looking carelessly at the passing cavaliers, he felt a very thin cold
4441: hand laid on his. He started round, and saw the Dominican friar whose
4442: upturned face had so struck him in the morning. Seen closer, the face
4443: looked more evidently worn by sickness and not by age; and again it
4444: brought some strong but indefinite reminiscences to Tito.
4445: 
4446: “Pardon me, but—from your face and your ring,”—said the friar, in a
4447: faint voice, “is not your name Tito Melema?”
4448: 
4449: “Yes,” said Tito, also speaking faintly, doubly jarred by the cold
4450: touch and the mystery. He was not apprehensive or timid through his
4451: imagination, but through his sensations and perceptions he could easily
4452: be made to shrink and turn pale like a maiden.
4453: 
4454: “Then I shall fulfil my commission.”
4455: 
4456: The friar put his hand under his scapulary, and drawing out a small
4457: linen bag which hung round his neck, took from it a bit of parchment,
4458: doubled and stuck firmly together with some black adhesive substance,
4459: and placed it in Tito’s hand. On the outside was written in Italian, in
4460: a small but distinct character—
4461: 
4462: “_Tito Melema, aged twenty-three, with a dark, beautiful face, long
4463: dark curls, the brightest smile, and a large onyx ring on his right
4464: forefinger_.”
4465: 
4466: Tito did not look at the friar, but tremblingly broke open the bit of
4467: parchment. Inside, the words were—
4468: 
4469: “_I am sold for a slave: I think they are going to take me to Antioch.
4470: The gems alone will serve to ransom me_.”
4471: 
4472: Tito looked round at the friar, but could only ask a question with his
4473: eyes.
4474: 
4475: “I had it at Corinth,” the friar said, speaking with difficulty, like
4476: one whose small strength had been overtaxed—“I had it from a man who
4477: was dying.”
4478: 
4479: “He is dead, then?” said Tito, with a bounding of the heart.
4480: 
4481: “Not the writer. The man who gave it me was a pilgrim, like myself, to
4482: whom the writer had intrusted it, because he was journeying to Italy.”
4483: 
4484: “You know the contents?”
4485: 
4486: “I do not know them, but I conjecture them. Your friend is in slavery:
4487: you will go and release him. But I am unable to talk now.” The friar,
4488: whose voice had become feebler and feebler, sank down on the stone
4489: bench against the wall from which he had risen to touch Tito’s hand,
4490: adding—
4491: 
4492: “I am at San Marco; my name is Fra Luca.”
4493: 
4494: 
4495: 
4496: 
4497: CHAPTER XI.
4498: Tito’s Dilemma.
4499: 
4500: 
4501: When Fra Luca had ceased to speak, Tito still stood by him in
4502: irresolution, and it was not till, the pressure of the passengers being
4503: removed, the friar rose and walked slowly into the church of Santa
4504: Felicita, that Tito also went on his way along the Via de’ Bardi.
4505: 
4506: “If this monk is a Florentine,” he said to himself; “if he is going to
4507: remain at Florence, everything must be disclosed.” He felt that a new
4508: crisis had come, but he was not, for all that, too evidently agitated
4509: to pay his visit to Bardo, and apologise for his previous
4510: non-appearance. Tito’s talent for concealment was being fast developed
4511: into something less neutral. It was still possible—perhaps it might be
4512: inevitable—for him to accept frankly the altered conditions, and avow
4513: Baldassarre’s existence; but hardly without casting an unpleasant light
4514: backward on his original reticence as studied equivocation in order to
4515: avoid the fulfilment of a secretly recognised claim, to say nothing of
4516: his quiet settlement of himself and investment of his florins, when, it
4517: would be clear, his benefactor’s fate had not been certified. It was at
4518: least provisionally wise to act as if nothing had happened, and for the
4519: present he would suspend decisive thought; there was all the night for
4520: meditation, and no one would know the precise moment at which he had
4521: received the letter.
4522: 
4523: So he entered the room on the second storey—where Romola and her father
4524: sat among the parchment and the marble, aloof from the life of the
4525: streets on holidays as well as on common days—with a face only a little
4526: less bright than usual, from regret at appearing so late: a regret
4527: which wanted no testimony, since he had given up the sight of the Corso
4528: in order to express it; and then set himself to throw extra animation
4529: into the evening, though all the while his consciousness was at work
4530: like a machine with complex action, leaving deposits quite distinct
4531: from the line of talk; and by the time he descended the stone stairs
4532: and issued from the grim door in the starlight, his mind had really
4533: reached a new stage in its formation of a purpose.
4534: 
4535: And when, the next day, after he was free from his professorial work,
4536: he turned up the Via del Cocomero towards the convent of San Marco, his
4537: purpose was fully shaped. He was going to ascertain from Fra Luca
4538: precisely how much he conjectured of the truth, and on what grounds he
4539: conjectured it; and, further, how long he was to remain at San Marco.
4540: And on that fuller knowledge he hoped to mould a statement which would
4541: in any case save him from the necessity of quitting Florence. Tito had
4542: never had occasion to fabricate an ingenious lie before: the occasion
4543: was come now—the occasion which circumstance never fails to beget on
4544: tacit falsity; and his ingenuity was ready. For he had convinced
4545: himself that he was not bound to go in search of Baldassarre. He had
4546: once said that on a fair assurance of his father’s existence and
4547: whereabout, he would unhesitatingly go after him. But, after all, _why_
4548: was he bound to go? What, looked at closely, was the end of all life,
4549: but to extract the utmost sum of pleasure? And was not his own blooming
4550: life a promise of incomparably more pleasure, not for himself only, but
4551: for others, than the withered wintry life of a man who was past the
4552: time of keen enjoyment, and whose ideas had stiffened into barren
4553: rigidity? Those ideas had all been sown in the fresh soil of Tito’s
4554: mind, and were lively germs there: that was the proper order of
4555: things—the order of nature, which treats all maturity as a mere nidus
4556: for youth. Baldassarre had done his work, had had his draught of life:
4557: Tito said it was _his_ turn now.
4558: 
4559: And the prospect was so vague:—“I think they are going to take me to
4560: Antioch:” here was a vista! After a long voyage, to spend months,
4561: perhaps years, in a search for which even now there was no guarantee
4562: that it would not prove vain: and to leave behind at starting a life of
4563: distinction and love: and to find, if he found anything, the old
4564: exacting companionship which was known by rote beforehand. Certainly
4565: the gems and therefore the florins were, in a sense, Baldassarre’s: in
4566: the narrow sense by which the right of possession is determined in
4567: ordinary affairs; but in that large and more radically natural view by
4568: which the world belongs to youth and strength, they were rather his who
4569: could extract the most pleasure out of them. That, he was conscious,
4570: was not the sentiment which the complicated play of human feelings had
4571: engendered in society. The men around him would expect that he should
4572: immediately apply those florins to his benefactor’s rescue. But what
4573: was the sentiment of society?—a mere tangle of anomalous traditions and
4574: opinions, which no wise man would take as a guide, except so far as his
4575: own comfort was concerned. Not that he cared for the florins save
4576: perhaps for Romola’s sake: he would give up the florins readily enough.
4577: It was the joy that was due to him and was close to his lips, which he
4578: felt he was not bound to thrust away from him and so travel on,
4579: thirsting. Any maxims that required a man to fling away the good that
4580: was needed to make existence sweet, were only the lining of human
4581: selfishness turned outward: they were made by men who wanted others to
4582: sacrifice themselves for their sake. He would rather that Baldassarre
4583: should not suffer: he liked no one to suffer; but could any philosophy
4584: prove to him that he was bound to care for another’s suffering more
4585: than for his own? To do so he must have loved Baldassarre devotedly,
4586: and he did _not_ love him: was that his own fault? Gratitude! seen
4587: closely, it made no valid claim: his father’s life would have been
4588: dreary without him: are we convicted of a debt to men for the pleasures
4589: they give themselves?
4590: 
4591: Having once begun to explain away Baldassarre’s claim, Tito’s thought
4592: showed itself as active as a virulent acid, eating its rapid way
4593: through all the tissues of sentiment. His mind was destitute of that
4594: dread which has been erroneously decried as if it were nothing higher
4595: than a man’s animal care for his own skin: that awe of the Divine
4596: Nemesis which was felt by religious pagans, and, though it took a more
4597: positive form under Christianity, is still felt by the mass of mankind
4598: simply as a vague fear at anything which is called wrong-doing. Such
4599: terror of the unseen is so far above mere sensual cowardice that it
4600: will annihilate that cowardice: it is the initial recognition of a
4601: moral law restraining desire, and checks the hard bold scrutiny of
4602: imperfect thought into obligations which can never be proved to have
4603: any sanctity in the absence of feeling. “It is good,” sing the old
4604: Eumenides, in Aeschylus, “that fear should sit as the guardian of the
4605: soul, forcing it into wisdom—good that men should carry a threatening
4606: shadow in their hearts under the full sunshine; else, how should they
4607: learn to revere the right?” That guardianship may become needless; but
4608: only when all outward law has become needless—only when duty and love
4609: have united in one stream and made a common force.
4610: 
4611: As Tito entered the outer cloister of San Marco, and inquired for Fra
4612: Luca, there was no shadowy presentiment in his mind: he felt himself
4613: too cultured and sceptical for that: he had been nurtured in contempt
4614: for the tales of priests whose impudent lives were a proverb, and in
4615: erudite familiarity with disputes concerning the Chief Good, which had
4616: after all, he considered, left it a matter of taste. Yet fear was a
4617: strong element in Tito’s nature—the fear of what he believed or saw was
4618: likely to rob him of pleasure: and he had a definite fear that Fra Luca
4619: might be the means of driving him from Florence.
4620: 
4621: “Fra Luca? ah, he is gone to Fiesole—to the Dominican monastery there.
4622: He was taken on a litter in the cool of the morning. The poor Brother
4623: is very ill. Could you leave a message for him?”
4624: 
4625: This answer was given by a _fra converso_, or lay brother, whose accent
4626: told plainly that he was a raw contadino, and whose dull glance implied
4627: no curiosity.
4628: 
4629: “Thanks; my business can wait.”
4630: 
4631: Tito turned away with a sense of relief. “This friar is not likely to
4632: live,” he said to himself. “I saw he was worn to a shadow. And at
4633: Fiesole there will be nothing to recall me to his mind. Besides, if he
4634: should come back, my explanation will serve as well then as now. But I
4635: wish I knew what it was that his face recalled to me.”
4636: 
4637: 
4638: 
4639: 
4640: CHAPTER XII.
4641: The Prize is nearly Grasped.
4642: 
4643: 
4644: Tito walked along with a light step, for the immediate fear had
4645: vanished; the usual joyousness of his disposition reassumed its
4646: predominance, and he was going to see Romola. Yet Romola’s life seemed
4647: an image of that loving, pitying devotedness, that patient endurance of
4648: irksome tasks, from which he had shrunk and excused himself. But he was
4649: not out of love with goodness, or prepared to plunge into vice: he was
4650: in his fresh youth, with soft pulses for all charm and loveliness; he
4651: had still a healthy appetite for ordinary human joys, and the poison
4652: could only work by degrees. He had sold himself to evil, but at present
4653: life seemed so nearly the same to him that he was not conscious of the
4654: bond. He meant all things to go on as they had done before, both within
4655: and without him: he meant to win golden opinions by meritorious
4656: exertion, by ingenious learning, by amiable compliance: he was not
4657: going to do anything that would throw him out of harmony with the
4658: beings he cared for. And he cared supremely for Romola; he wished to
4659: have her for his beautiful and loving wife. There might be a wealthier
4660: alliance within the ultimate reach of successful accomplishments like
4661: his, but there was no woman in all Florence like Romola. When she was
4662: near him, and looked at him with her sincere hazel eyes, he was subdued
4663: by a delicious influence as strong and inevitable as those musical
4664: vibrations which take possession of us with a rhythmic empire that no
4665: sooner ceases than we desire it to begin again.
4666: 
4667: As he trod the stone stairs, when he was still outside the door, with
4668: no one but Maso near him, the influence seemed to have begun its work
4669: by the mere nearness of anticipation.
4670: 
4671: “Welcome, Tito mio,” said the old man’s voice, before Tito had spoken.
4672: There was a new vigour in the voice, a new cheerfulness in the blind
4673: face, since that first interview more than two months ago. “You have
4674: brought fresh manuscript, doubtless; but since we were talking last
4675: night I have had new ideas: we must take a wider scope—we must go back
4676: upon our footsteps.”
4677: 
4678: Tito, paying his homage to Romola as he advanced, went, as his custom
4679: was, straight to Bardo’s chair, and put his hand in the palm that was
4680: held to receive it, placing himself on the cross-legged leather seat
4681: with scrolled ends, close to Bardo’s elbow.
4682: 
4683: “Yes,” he said, in his gentle way; “I have brought the new manuscript,
4684: but that can wait your pleasure. I have young limbs, you know, and can
4685: walk back up the hill without any difficulty.”
4686: 
4687: He did not look at Romola as he said this, but he knew quite well that
4688: her eyes were fixed on him with delight.
4689: 
4690: “That is well said, my son.” Bardo had already addressed Tito in this
4691: way once or twice of late. “And I perceive with gladness that you do
4692: not shrink from labour, without which, the poet has wisely said, life
4693: has given nothing to mortals. It is too often the ‘palma sine pulvere,’
4694: the prize of glory without the dust of the race, that attracts young
4695: ambition. But what says the Greek? ‘In the morning of life, work; in
4696: the mid-day, give counsel; in the evening, pray.’ It is true, I might
4697: be thought to have reached that helpless evening; but not so, while I
4698: have counsel within me which is yet unspoken. For my mind, as I have
4699: often said, was shut up as by a dam; the plenteous waters lay dark and
4700: motionless; but you, my Tito, have opened a duct for them, and they
4701: rush forward with a force that surprises myself. And now, what I want
4702: is, that we should go over our preliminary ground again, with a wider
4703: scheme of comment and illustration: otherwise I may lose opportunities
4704: which I now see retrospectively, and which may never occur again. You
4705: mark what I am saying, Tito?”
4706: 
4707: He had just stooped to reach his manuscript, which had rolled down, and
4708: Bardo’s jealous ear was alive to the slight movement.
4709: 
4710: Tito might have been excused for shrugging his shoulders at the
4711: prospect before him, but he was not naturally impatient; moreover, he
4712: had been bred up in that laborious erudition, at once minute and
4713: copious, which was the chief intellectual task of the age; and with
4714: Romola near, he was floated along by waves of agreeable sensation that
4715: made everything seem easy.
4716: 
4717: “Assuredly,” he said; “you wish to enlarge your comments on certain
4718: passages we have cited.”
4719: 
4720: “Not only so; I wish to introduce an occasional _excursus_, where we
4721: have noticed an author to whom I have given special study; for I may
4722: die too soon to achieve any separate work. And this is not a time for
4723: scholarly integrity and well-sifted learning to lie idle, when it is
4724: not only rash ignorance that we have to fear, but when there are men
4725: like Calderino, who, as Poliziano has well shown, have recourse to
4726: impudent falsities of citation to serve the ends of their vanity and
4727: secure a triumph to their own mistakes. Wherefore, my Tito, I think it
4728: not well that we should let slip the occasion that lies under our
4729: hands. And now we will turn back to the point where we have cited the
4730: passage from Thucydides, and I wish you, by way of preliminary, to go
4731: with me through all my notes on the Latin translation made by Lorenzo
4732: Valla, for which the incomparable Pope Nicholas the Fifth—with whose
4733: personal notice I was honoured while I was yet young, and when he was
4734: still Thomas of Sarzana—paid him (I say not unduly) the sum of five
4735: hundred gold scudi. But inasmuch as Valla, though otherwise of dubious
4736: fame, is held in high honour for his severe scholarship, whence the
4737: epigrammatist has jocosely said of him that since he went among the
4738: shades, Pluto himself has not dared to speak in the ancient languages,
4739: it is the more needful that his name should not be as a stamp
4740: warranting false wares; and therefore I would introduce an _excursus_
4741: on Thucydides, wherein my castigations of Valla’s text may find a
4742: fitting place. My Romola, thou wilt reach the needful volumes—thou
4743: knowest them—on the fifth shelf of the cabinet.”
4744: 
4745: Tito rose at the same moment with Romola, saying, “I will reach them,
4746: if you will point them out,” and followed her hastily into the
4747: adjoining small room, where the walls were also covered with ranges of
4748: books in perfect order.
4749: 
4750: “There they are,” said Romola, pointing upward; “every book is just
4751: where it was when my father ceased to see them.”
4752: 
4753: Tito stood by her without hastening to reach the books. They had never
4754: been in this room together before.
4755: 
4756: “I hope,” she continued, turning her eyes full on Tito, with a look of
4757: grave confidence—“I hope he will not weary you; this work makes him so
4758: happy.”
4759: 
4760: “And me too, Romola—if you will only let me say, I love you—if you will
4761: only think me worth loving a little.”
4762: 
4763: His speech was the softest murmur, and the dark beautiful face, nearer
4764: to hers than it had ever been before, was looking at her with
4765: beseeching tenderness.
4766: 
4767: “I do love you,” murmured Romola; she looked at him with the same
4768: simple majesty as ever, but her voice had never in her life before sunk
4769: to that murmur. It seemed to them both that they were looking at each
4770: other a long while before her lips moved again; yet it was but a moment
4771: till she said, “I know _now_ what it is to be happy.”
4772: 
4773: The faces just met, and the dark curls mingled for an instant with the
4774: rippling gold. Quick as lightning after that, Tito set his foot on a
4775: projecting ledge of the book-shelves and reached down the needful
4776: volumes. They were both contented to be silent and separate, for that
4777: first blissful experience of mutual consciousness was all the more
4778: exquisite for being unperturbed by immediate sensation.
4779: 
4780: It had all been as rapid as the irreversible mingling of waters, for
4781: even the eager and jealous Bardo had not become impatient.
4782: 
4783: “You have the volumes, my Romola?” the old man said, as they came near
4784: him again. “And now you will get your pen ready; for, as Tito marks off
4785: the scholia we determine on extracting, it will be well for you to copy
4786: them without delay—numbering them carefully, mind, to correspond with
4787: the numbers in the text which he will write.”
4788: 
4789: Romola always had some task which gave her a share in this joint work.
4790: Tito took his stand at the leggio, where he both wrote and read, and
4791: she placed herself at a table just in front of him, where she was ready
4792: to give into her father’s hands anything that he might happen to want,
4793: or relieve him of a volume that he had done with. They had always been
4794: in that position since the work began, yet on this day it seemed new;
4795: it was so different now for them to be opposite each other; so
4796: different for Tito to take a book from her, as she lifted it from her
4797: father’s knee. Yet there was no finesse to secure an additional look or
4798: touch. Each woman creates in her own likeness the love-tokens that are
4799: offered to her; and Romola’s deep calm happiness encompassed Tito like
4800: the rich but quiet evening light which dissipates all unrest.
4801: 
4802: They had been two hours at their work, and were just desisting because
4803: of the fading light, when the door opened and there entered a figure
4804: strangely incongruous with the current of their thoughts and with the
4805: suggestions of every object around them. It was the figure of a short
4806: stout black-eyed woman, about fifty, wearing a black velvet berretta,
4807: or close cap, embroidered with pearls, under which surprisingly massive
4808: black braids surmounted the little bulging forehead, and fell in rich
4809: plaited curves over the ears, while an equally surprising carmine tint
4810: on the upper region of the fat cheeks contrasted with the surrounding
4811: sallowness. Three rows of pearls and a lower necklace of gold reposed
4812: on the horizontal cushion of her neck; the embroidered border of her
4813: trailing black velvet gown and her embroidered long-drooping sleeves of
4814: rose-coloured damask, were slightly faded, but they conveyed to the
4815: initiated eye the satisfactory assurance that they were the splendid
4816: result of six months’ labour by a skilled workman; and the
4817: rose-coloured petticoat, with its dimmed white fringe and seed-pearl
4818: arabesques, was duly exhibited in order to suggest a similar pleasing
4819: reflection. A handsome coral rosary hung from one side of an
4820: inferential belt, which emerged into certainty with a large clasp of
4821: silver wrought in niello; and, on the other side, where the belt again
4822: became inferential, hung a scarsella, or large purse, of crimson
4823: velvet, stitched with pearls. Her little fat right-hand, which looked
4824: as if it had been made of paste, and had risen out of shape under
4825: partial baking, held a small book of devotions, also splendid with
4826: velvet, pearls, and silver.
4827: 
4828: The figure was already too familiar to Tito to be startling, for Monna
4829: Brigida was a frequent visitor at Bardo’s, being excepted from the
4830: sentence of banishment passed on feminine triviality, on the ground of
4831: her cousinship to his dead wife and her early care for Romola, who now
4832: looked round at her with an affectionate smile, and rose to draw the
4833: leather seat to a due distance from her father’s chair, that the coming
4834: gush of talk might not be too near his ear.
4835: 
4836: “_La cugina_?” said Bardo, interrogatively, detecting the short steps
4837: and the sweeping drapery.
4838: 
4839: “Yes, it is your cousin,” said Monna Brigida, in an alert voice,
4840: raising her fingers smilingly at Tito, and then lifting up her face to
4841: be kissed by Romola. “Always the troublesome cousin breaking in on your
4842: wisdom,” she went on, seating herself and beginning to fan herself with
4843: the white veil hanging over her arm. “Well, well; if I didn’t bring you
4844: some news of the world now and then, I do believe you’d forget there
4845: was anything in life but these mouldy ancients, who want sprinkling
4846: with holy water if all I hear about them is true. Not but what the
4847: world is bad enough nowadays, for the scandals that turn up under one’s
4848: nose at every corner—_I_ don’t want to hear and see such things, but
4849: one can’t go about with one’s head in a bag; and it was only
4850: yesterday—well, well, you needn’t burst out at me, Bardo, I’m not going
4851: to tell anything; if I’m not as wise as the three kings, I know how
4852: many legs go into one boot. But, nevertheless, Florence is a wicked
4853: city—is it not true, Messer Tito? for you go into the world. Not but
4854: what one must sin a little—Messer Domeneddio expects that of us, else
4855: what are the blessed sacraments for? And what I say is, we’ve got to
4856: reverence the saints, and not to set ourselves up as if we could be
4857: like them, else life would be unbearable; as it will be if things go on
4858: after this new fashion. For what do you think? I’ve been at the wedding
4859: to-day—Dianora Acciajoli’s with the young Albizzi that there has been
4860: so much talk of—and everybody wondered at its being to-day instead of
4861: yesterday; but, _cieli_! such a wedding as it was might have been put
4862: off till the next Quaresima for a penance. For there was the bride
4863: looking like a white nun—not so much as a pearl about her—and the
4864: bridegroom as solemn as San Giuseppe. It’s true! And half the people
4865: invited were _Piagnoni_—they call them _Piagnoni_ (funeral mourners:
4866: properly, paid mourners) now, these new saints of Fra Girolamo’s
4867: making. And to think of two families like the Albizzi and the Acciajoli
4868: taking up such notions, when they could afford to wear the best! Well,
4869: well, they invited me—but they could do no other, seeing my husband was
4870: Luca Antonio’s uncle by the mother’s side—and a pretty time I had of it
4871: while we waited under the canopy in front of the house, before they let
4872: us in. I couldn’t stand in my clothes, it seemed, without giving
4873: offence; for there was Monna Berta, who has had worse secrets in her
4874: time than any I could tell of myself, looking askance at me from under
4875: her hood like a _pinzochera_, (a Sister of the Third Order of Saint
4876: Francis: an uncloistered nun) and telling me to read the Frate’s book
4877: about widows, from which she had found great guidance. Holy Madonna! it
4878: seems as if widows had nothing to do now but to buy their coffins, and
4879: think it a thousand years till they get into them, instead of enjoying
4880: themselves a little when they’ve got their hands free for the first
4881: time. And what do you think was the music we had, to make our dinner
4882: lively? A long discourse from Fra Domenico of San Marco, about the
4883: doctrines of their blessed Fra Girolamo—the three doctrines we are all
4884: to get by heart; and he kept marking them off on his fingers till he
4885: made my flesh creep: and the first is, Florence, or the Church—I don’t
4886: know which, for first he said one and then the other—shall be scourged;
4887: but if he means the pestilence, the Signory ought to put a stop to such
4888: preaching, for it’s enough to raise the swelling under one’s arms with
4889: fright: but then, after that, he says Florence is to be regenerated;
4890: but what will be the good of that when we’re all dead of the plague, or
4891: something else? And then, the third thing, and what he said oftenest,
4892: is, that it’s all to be in our days: and he marked that off on his
4893: thumb, till he made me tremble like the very jelly before me. They had
4894: jellies, to be sure, with the arms of the Albizzi and the Acciajoli
4895: raised on them in all colours; they’ve not turned the world quite
4896: upside down yet. But all their talk is, that we are to go back to the
4897: old ways: for up starts Francesco Valori, that I’ve danced with in the
4898: Via Larga when he was a bachelor and as fond of the Medici as anybody,
4899: and he makes a speech about the old times, before the Florentines had
4900: left off crying ‘Popolo’ and begun to cry ‘Palle’—as if that had
4901: anything to do with a wedding!—and how we ought to keep to the rules
4902: the Signory laid down heaven knows when, that we were not to wear this
4903: and that, and not to eat this and that—and how our manners were
4904: corrupted and we read bad books; though he can’t say that of _me_—”
4905: 
4906: “Stop, cousin!” said Bardo, in his imperious tone, for he had a remark
4907: to make, and only desperate measures could arrest the rattling
4908: lengthiness of Monna Brigida’s discourse. But now she gave a little
4909: start, pursed up her mouth, and looked at him with round eyes.
4910: 
4911: “Francesco Valori is not altogether wrong,” Bardo went on. “Bernardo,
4912: indeed, rates him not highly, and is rather of opinion that he
4913: christens private grudges by the name of public zeal; though I must
4914: admit that my good Bernardo is too slow of belief in that unalloyed
4915: patriotism which was found in all its lustre amongst the ancients. But
4916: it is true, Tito, that our manners have degenerated somewhat from that
4917: noble frugality which, as has been well seen in the public acts of our
4918: citizens, is the parent of true magnificence. For men, as I hear, will
4919: now spend on the transient show of a Giostra sums which would suffice
4920: to found a library, and confer a lasting possession on mankind. Still,
4921: I conceive, it remains true of us Florentines that we have more of that
4922: magnanimous sobriety which abhors a trivial lavishness that it may be
4923: grandly open-handed on grand occasions, than can be found in any other
4924: city of Italy; for I understand that the Neapolitan and Milanese
4925: courtiers laugh at the scarcity of our plate, and think scorn of our
4926: great families for borrowing from each other that furniture of the
4927: table at their entertainments. But in the vain laughter of folly wisdom
4928: hears half its applause.”
4929: 
4930: “Laughter, indeed!” burst forth Monna Brigida again, the moment, Bardo
4931: paused. “If anybody wanted to hear laughter at the wedding to-day they
4932: were disappointed, for when young Niccolò Macchiavelli tried to make a
4933: joke, and told stories out of Franco Sacchetti’s book, how it was no
4934: use for the Signoria to make rules for us women, because we were
4935: cleverer than all the painters, and architects, and doctors of logic in
4936: the world, for we could make black look white, and yellow look pink,
4937: and crooked look straight, and, if anything was forbidden, we could
4938: find a new name for it—Holy Virgin! the Piagnoni looked more dismal
4939: than before, and somebody said Sacchetti’s book was wicked. Well, I
4940: don’t read it—they can’t accuse _me_ of reading anything. Save me from
4941: going to a wedding again, if that’s to be the fashion; for all of us
4942: who were not Piagnoni were as comfortable as wet chickens. I was never
4943: caught in a worse trap but once before, and that was when I went to
4944: hear their precious Frate last Quaresima in San Lorenzo. Perhaps I
4945: never told you about it, Messer Tito?—it almost freezes my blood when I
4946: think of it. How he rated us poor women! and the men, too, to tell the
4947: truth, but I didn’t mind that so much. He called us cows, and lumps of
4948: flesh, and wantons, and mischief-makers—and I could just bear that, for
4949: there were plenty others more fleshy and spiteful than I was, though
4950: every now and then his voice shook the very bench under me like a
4951: trumpet; but then he came to the false hair, and, O misericordia! he
4952: made a picture—I see it now—of a young woman lying a pale corpse, and
4953: us light-minded widows—of course he meant me as well as the rest, for I
4954: had my plaits on, for if one is getting old, one doesn’t want to look
4955: as ugly as the Befana,[1]—us widows rushing up to the corpse, like
4956: bare-pated vultures as we were, and cutting off its young dead hair to
4957: deck our old heads with. Oh, the dreams I had after that! And then he
4958: cried, and wrung his hands at us, and I cried too. And to go home, and
4959: to take off my jewels, this very clasp, and everything, and to make
4960: them into a packet, _fù tutt’uno_; and I was within a hair of sending
4961: them to the Good Men of Saint Martin to give to the poor, but, by
4962: heaven’s mercy, I bethought me of going first to my confessor, Fra
4963: Cristoforo, at Santa Croce, and he told me how it was all the work of
4964: the devil, this preaching and prophesying of their Fra Girolamo, and
4965: the Dominicans were trying to turn the world upside down, and I was
4966: never to go and hear him again, else I must do penance for it; for the
4967: great preachers Fra Mariano and Fra Menico had shown how Fra Girolamo
4968: preached lies—and that was true, for I heard them both in the Duomo—and
4969: how the Pope’s dream of San Francesco propping up the Church with his
4970: arms was being fulfilled still, and the Dominicans were beginning to
4971: pull it down. Well and good: I went away _con Dio_, and made myself
4972: easy. I am not going to be frightened by a Frate Predicatore again. And
4973: all I say is, I wish it hadn’t been the Dominicans that poor Dino
4974: joined years ago, for then I should have been glad when I heard them
4975: say he was come back—”
4976: 
4977:  [1] The name given to the grotesque black-faced figures, supposed to
4978:  represent the Magi, carried about or placed in the windows on Twelfth
4979:  Night: a corruption of Epifania.
4980: 
4981: 
4982: “Silenzio!” said Bardo, in a loud agitated voice, while Romola half
4983: started from her chair, clasped her hands, and looked round at Tito, as
4984: if now she might appeal to him. Monna Brigida gave a little scream, and
4985: bit her lip.
4986: 
4987: “Donna!” said Bardo, again, “hear once more my will. Bring no reports
4988: about that name to this house; and thou, Romola, I forbid thee to ask.
4989: My son is dead.”
4990: 
4991: Bardo’s whole frame seemed vibrating with passion, and no one dared to
4992: break silence again. Monna Brigida lifted her shoulders and her hands
4993: in mute dismay; then she rose as quietly as possible, gave many
4994: significant nods to Tito and Romola, motioning to them that they were
4995: not to move, and stole out of the room like a culpable fat spaniel who
4996: has barked unseasonably.
4997: 
4998: Meanwhile, Tito’s quick mind had been combining ideas with
4999: lightning-like rapidity. Bardo’s son was not really dead, then, as he
5000: had supposed: he was a monk; he was “come back:” and Fra Luca—yes! it
5001: was the likeness to Bardo and Romola that had made the face seem
5002: half-known to him. If he were only dead at Fiesole at that moment! This
5003: importunate selfish wish inevitably thrust itself before every other
5004: thought. It was true that Bardo’s rigid will was a sufficient safeguard
5005: against any intercourse between Romola and her brother; but _not_
5006: against the betrayal of what he knew to others, especially when the
5007: subject was suggested by the coupling of Romola’s name with that of the
5008: very Tito Melema whose description he had carried round his neck as an
5009: index. No! nothing but Fra Luca’s death could remove all danger; but
5010: his death was highly probable, and after the momentary shock of the
5011: discovery, Tito let his mind fall back in repose on that confident
5012: hope.
5013: 
5014: They had sat in silence, and in a deepening twilight for many minutes,
5015: when Romola ventured to say—
5016: 
5017: “Shall I light the lamp, father, and shall we go on?”
5018: 
5019: “No, my Romola, we will work no more to-night. Tito, come and sit by me
5020: here.”
5021: 
5022: Tito moved from the reading-desk, and seated himself on the other side
5023: of Bardo, close to his left elbow.
5024: 
5025: “Come nearer to me, figliuola mia,” said Bardo again, after a moment’s
5026: pause. And Romola seated herself on a low stool and let her arm rest on
5027: her father’s right knee, that he might lay his hand on her hair, as he
5028: was fond of doing.
5029: 
5030: “Tito, I never told you that I had once a son,” said Bardo, forgetting
5031: what had fallen from him in the emotion raised by their first
5032: interview. The old man had been deeply shaken, and was forced to pour
5033: out his feelings in spite of pride. “But he left me—he is dead to me. I
5034: have disowned him for ever. He was a ready scholar as you are, but more
5035: fervid and impatient, and yet sometimes rapt and self-absorbed, like a
5036: flame fed by some fitful source; showing a disposition from the very
5037: first to turn away his eyes from the clear lights of reason and
5038: philosophy, and to prostrate himself under the influences of a dim
5039: mysticism which eludes all rules of human duty as it eludes all
5040: argument. And so it ended. We will speak no more of him: he is dead to
5041: me. I wish his face could be blotted from that world of memory in which
5042: the distant seems to grow clearer and the near to fade.”
5043: 
5044: Bardo paused, but neither Romola nor Tito dared to speak—his voice was
5045: too tremulous, the poise of his feelings too doubtful. But he presently
5046: raised his hand and found Tito’s shoulder to rest it on, while he went
5047: on speaking, with an effort to be calmer.
5048: 
5049: “But _you_ have come to me, Tito—not quite too late. I will lose no
5050: time in vain regret. When you are working by my side I seem to have
5051: found a son again.”
5052: 
5053: The old man, preoccupied with the governing interest of his life, was
5054: only thinking of the much-meditated book which had quite thrust into
5055: the background the suggestion, raised by Bernardo del Nero’s warning,
5056: of a possible marriage between Tito and Romola. But Tito could not
5057: allow the moment to pass unused.
5058: 
5059: “Will you let me be always and altogether your son? Will you let me
5060: take care of Romola—be her husband? I think she will not deny me. She
5061: has said she loves me. I know I am not equal to her in birth—in
5062: anything; but I am no longer a destitute stranger.”
5063: 
5064: “Is it true, my Romola?” said Bardo, in a lower tone, an evident
5065: vibration passing through him and dissipating the saddened aspect of
5066: his features.
5067: 
5068: “Yes, father,” said Romola, firmly. “I love Tito—I wish to marry him,
5069: that we may both be your children and never part.”
5070: 
5071: Tito’s hand met hers in a strong clasp for the first time, while she
5072: was speaking, but their eyes were fixed anxiously on her father.
5073: 
5074: “Why should it not be?” said Bardo, as if arguing against any
5075: opposition to his assent, rather than assenting. “It would be a
5076: happiness to me; and thou, too, Romola, wouldst be the happier for it.”
5077: 
5078: He stroked her long hair gently and bent towards her.
5079: 
5080: “Ah, I have been apt to forget that thou needest some other love than
5081: mine. And thou wilt be a noble wife. Bernardo thinks I shall hardly
5082: find a husband fitting for thee. And he is perhaps right. For thou art
5083: not like the herd of thy sex: thou art such a woman as the immortal
5084: poets had a vision of when they sang the lives of the heroes—tender but
5085: strong, like thy voice, which has been to me instead of the light in
5086: the years of my blindness... And so thou lovest him?”
5087: 
5088: He sat upright again for a minute, and then said, in the same tone as
5089: before, “Why should it not be? I will think of it; I will talk with
5090: Bernardo.”
5091: 
5092: Tito felt a disagreeable chill at this answer, for Bernardo del Nero’s
5093: eyes had retained their keen suspicion whenever they looked at him, and
5094: the uneasy remembrance of Fra Luca converted all uncertainty into fear.
5095: 
5096: “Speak for me, Romola,” he said, pleadingly. “Messer Bernardo is sure
5097: to be against me.”
5098: 
5099: “No, Tito,” said Romola, “my godfather will not oppose what my father
5100: firmly wills. And it is your will that I should marry Tito—is it not
5101: true, father? Nothing has ever come to me before that I have wished for
5102: strongly: I did not think it possible that I could care so much for
5103: anything that could happen to myself.”
5104: 
5105: It was a brief and simple plea; but it was the condensed story of
5106: Romola’s self-repressing colourless young life, which had thrown all
5107: its passion into sympathy with aged sorrows, aged ambition, aged pride
5108: and indignation. It had never occurred to Romola that she should not
5109: speak as directly and emphatically of her love for Tito as of any other
5110: subject.
5111: 
5112: “Romola mia!” said her father fondly, pausing on the words, “it is true
5113: thou hast never urged on me any wishes of thy own. And I have no will
5114: to resist thine; rather, my heart met Tito’s entreaty at its very first
5115: utterance. Nevertheless, I must talk with Bernardo about the measures
5116: needful to be observed. For we must not act in haste, or do anything
5117: unbeseeming my name. I am poor, and held of little account by the
5118: wealthy of our family—nay, I may consider myself a lonely man—but I
5119: must nevertheless remember that generous birth has its obligations. And
5120: I would not be reproached by my fellow-citizens for rash haste in
5121: bestowing my daughter. Bartolommeo Scala gave his Alessandra to the
5122: Greek Marullo, but Marullo’s lineage was well-known, and Scala himself
5123: is of no extraction. I know Bernardo will hold that we must take time:
5124: he will, perhaps, reproach me with want of due forethought. Be patient,
5125: my children: you are very young.”
5126: 
5127: No more could be said, and Romola’s heart was perfectly satisfied. Not
5128: so Tito’s. If the subtle mixture of good and evil prepares suffering
5129: for human truth and purity, there is also suffering prepared for the
5130: wrong-doer by the same mingled conditions. As Tito kissed Romola on
5131: their parting that evening, the very strength of the thrill that moved
5132: his whole being at the sense that this woman, whose beauty it was
5133: hardly possible to think of as anything but the necessary consequence
5134: of her noble nature, loved him with all the tenderness that spoke in
5135: her clear eyes, brought a strong reaction of regret that he had not
5136: kept himself free from that first deceit which had dragged him into the
5137: danger of being disgraced before her. There was a spring of bitterness
5138: mingling with that fountain of sweets. Would the death of Fra Luca
5139: arrest it? He hoped it would.
5140: 
5141: 
5142: 
5143: 
5144: CHAPTER XIII.
5145: The Shadow of Nemesis.
5146: 
5147: 
5148: It was the lazy afternoon time on the seventh of September, more than
5149: two months after the day on which Romola and Tito had confessed their
5150: love to each other.
5151: 
5152: Tito, just descended into Nello’s shop, had found the barber stretched
5153: on the bench with his cap over his eyes; one leg was drawn up, and the
5154: other had slipped towards the ground, having apparently carried with it
5155: a manuscript volume of verse, which lay with its leaves crushed. In a
5156: corner sat Sandro, playing a game at _mora_ by himself, and watching
5157: the slow reply of his left fingers to the arithmetical demands of his
5158: right with solemn-eyed interest.
5159: 
5160: Treading with the gentlest step, Tito snatched up the lute, and bending
5161: over the barber, touched the strings lightly while he sang—
5162: 
5163: “Quant’ è bella giovinezza,
5164: Che si fugge tuttavia!
5165: Chi vuol esser lieto sia,
5166: Di doman non c’è certezza.”[1]
5167: 
5168: 
5169:  [1] “Beauteous is life in blossom!
5170: And it fleeteth—fleeteth ever;
5171: Whoso would be joyful—let him!
5172: There’s no surety for the morrow.”
5173: 
5174: _Carnival Song by Lorenzo de’ Medici_.
5175: 
5176: 
5177: Nello was as easily awaked as a bird. The cap was off his eyes in an
5178: instant, and he started up.
5179: 
5180: “Ah, my Apollino! I am somewhat late with my siesta on this hot day, it
5181: seems. That comes of not going to sleep in the natural way, but taking
5182: a potion of potent poesy. Hear you, how I am beginning to match my
5183: words by the initial letter, like a Trovatore? That is one of my bad
5184: symptoms: I am sorely afraid that the good wine of my understanding is
5185: going to run off at the spigot of authorship, and I shall be left an
5186: empty cask with an odour of dregs, like many another incomparable
5187: genius of my acquaintance. What is it, my Orpheus?” here Nello
5188: stretched out his arms to their full length, and then brought them
5189: round till his hands grasped Tito’s curls, and drew them out playfully.
5190: “What is it you want of your well-tamed Nello? For I perceive a coaxing
5191: sound in that soft strain of yours. Let me see the very needle’s eye of
5192: your desire, as the sublime poet says, that I may thread it.”
5193: 
5194: “That is but a tailor’s image of your sublime poet’s,” said Tito, still
5195: letting his fingers fall in a light dropping way on the strings. “But
5196: you have divined the reason of my affectionate impatience to see your
5197: eyes open. I want you to give me an extra touch of your art—not on my
5198: chin, no; but on the zazzera, which is as tangled as your Florentine
5199: politics. You have an adroit way of inserting your comb, which flatters
5200: the skin, and stirs the animal spirits agreeably in that region; and a
5201: little of your most delicate orange-scent would not lie amiss, for I am
5202: bound to the Scala palace, and am to present myself in radiant company.
5203: The young cardinal Giovanni de’ Medici is to be there, and he brings
5204: with him a certain young Bernardo Dovizi of Bibbiena, whose wit is so
5205: rapid that I see no way of out-rivalling it save by the scent of
5206: orange-blossoms.”
5207: 
5208: Nello had already seized and flourished his comb, and pushed Tito
