5209: gently backward into the chair, wrapping the cloth round him.
5210: 
5211: “Never talk of rivalry, bel giovane mio: Bernardo Dovizi is a keen
5212: youngster, who will never carry a net out to catch the wind; but he has
5213: something of the same sharp-muzzled look as his brother Ser Piero, the
5214: weasel that Piero de’ Medici keeps at his beck to slip through small
5215: holes for him. No! you distance all rivals, and may soon touch the sky
5216: with your forefinger. They tell me you have even carried enough honey
5217: with you to sweeten the sour Messer Angelo; for he has pronounced you
5218: less of an ass than might have been expected, considering there is such
5219: a good understanding between you and the Secretary.”
5220: 
5221: “And between ourselves, Nello mio, that Messer Angelo has more genius
5222: and erudition than I can find in all the other Florentine scholars put
5223: together. It may answer very well for them to cry me up now, when
5224: Poliziano is beaten down with grief, or illness, or something else; I
5225: can try a flight with such a sparrow-hawk as Pietro Crinito, but for
5226: Poliziano, he is a large-beaked eagle who would swallow me, feathers
5227: and all, and not feel any difference.”
5228: 
5229: “I will not contradict your modesty there, if you will have it so; but
5230: you don’t expect us clever Florentines to keep saying the same things
5231: over again every day of our lives, as we must do if we always told the
5232: truth. We cry down Dante, and we cry up Francesco Cei, just for the
5233: sake of variety; and if we cry you up as a new Poliziano, heaven has
5234: taken care that it shall not be quite so great a lie as it might have
5235: been. And are you not a pattern of virtue in this wicked city? with
5236: your ears double-waxed against all siren invitations that would lure
5237: you from the Via de’ Bardi, and the great work which is to astonish
5238: posterity?”
5239: 
5240: “Posterity in good truth, whom it will probably astonish as the
5241: universe does, by the impossibility of seeing what was the plan of it.”
5242: 
5243: “Yes, something like that was being prophesied here the other day.
5244: Cristoforo Landino said that the excellent Bardo was one of those
5245: scholars who lie overthrown in their learning, like cavaliers in heavy
5246: armour, and then get angry because they are over-ridden—which pithy
5247: remark, it seems to me, was not a herb out of his own garden; for of
5248: all men, for feeding one with an empty spoon and gagging one with vain
5249: expectation by long discourse, Messer Cristoforo is the pearl. Ecco!
5250: you are perfect now.” Here Nello drew away the cloth. “Impossible to
5251: add a grace more! But love is not always to be fed on learning, eh? I
5252: shall have to dress the zazzera for the betrothal before long—is it not
5253: true?”
5254: 
5255: “Perhaps,” said Tito, smiling, “unless Messer Bernardo should next
5256: recommend Bardo to require that I should yoke a lion and a wild boar to
5257: the car of the Zecca before I can win my Alcestis. But I confess he is
5258: right in holding me unworthy of Romola; she is a Pleiad that may grow
5259: dim by marrying any mortal.”
5260: 
5261: “_Gnaffè_, your modesty is in the right place there. Yet fate seems to
5262: have measured and chiselled you for the niche that was left empty by
5263: the old man’s son, who, by the way, Cronaca was telling me, is now at
5264: San Marco. Did you know?”
5265: 
5266: A slight electric shock passed through Tito as he rose from the chair,
5267: but it was not outwardly perceptible, for he immediately stooped to
5268: pick up the fallen book, and busied his fingers with flattening the
5269: leaves, while he said—
5270: 
5271: “No; he was at Fiesole, I thought. Are you sure he is come back to San
5272: Marco?”
5273: 
5274: “Cronaca is my authority,” said Nello, with a shrug. “I don’t frequent
5275: that sanctuary, but he does. Ah,” he added, taking the book from Tito’s
5276: hands, “my poor Nencia da Barberino! It jars your scholarly feelings to
5277: see the pages dog’s-eared. I was lulled to sleep by the well-rhymed
5278: charms of that rustic maiden—‘prettier than the turnip-flower,’ ‘with a
5279: cheek more savoury than cheese.’ But to get such a well-scented notion
5280: of the contadina, one must lie on velvet cushions in the Via Larga—not
5281: go to look at the Fierucoloni stumping in to the Piazza della Nunziata
5282: this evening after sundown.”
5283: 
5284: “And pray who are the Fierucoloni?” said Tito, indifferently, settling
5285: his cap.
5286: 
5287: “The contadine who came from the mountains of Pistoia, and the
5288: Casentino, and heaven knows where, to keep their vigil in the church of
5289: the Nunziata, and sell their yarn and dried mushrooms at the Fierucola
5290: (the little Fair), as we call it. They make a queer show, with their
5291: paper lanterns, howling their hymns to the Virgin on this eve of her
5292: nativity—if you had the leisure to see them. No?—well, I have had
5293: enough of it myself, for there is wild work in the Piazza. One may
5294: happen to get a stone or two about one’s ears or shins without asking
5295: for it, and I was never fond of that pressing attention. Addio.”
5296: 
5297: Tito carried a little uneasiness with him on his visit, which ended
5298: earlier than he had expected, the boy-cardinal Giovanni de’ Medici,
5299: youngest of red-hatted fathers, who has since presented his broad dark
5300: cheek very conspicuously to posterity as Pope Leo the Tenth, having
5301: been detained at his favourite pastime of the chase, and having failed
5302: to appear. It still wanted half an hour of sunset as he left the door
5303: of the Scala palace, with the intention of proceeding forthwith to the
5304: Via de’ Bardi; but he had not gone far when, to his astonishment, he
5305: saw Romola advancing towards him along the Borgo Pinti.
5306: 
5307: She wore a thick black veil and black mantle, but it was impossible to
5308: mistake her figure and her walk; and by her side was a short stout
5309: form, which he recognised as that of Monna Brigida, in spite of the
5310: unusual plainness of her attire. Romola had not been bred up to
5311: devotional observances, and the occasions on which she took the air
5312: elsewhere than under the loggia on the roof of the house, were so rare
5313: and so much dwelt on beforehand, because of Bardo’s dislike to be left
5314: without her, that Tito felt sure there must have been some sudden and
5315: urgent ground for an absence of which he had heard nothing the day
5316: before. She saw him through her veil and hastened her steps.
5317: 
5318: “Romola, has anything happened?” said Tito, turning to walk by her
5319: side.
5320: 
5321: She did not answer at the first moment, and Monna Brigida broke in.
5322: 
5323: “Ah, Messer Tito, you do well to turn round, for we are in haste. And
5324: is it not a misfortune?—we are obliged to go round by the walls and
5325: turn up the Via del Maglio, because of the Fair; for the contadine
5326: coming in block up the way by the Nunziata, which would have taken us
5327: to San Marco in half the time.”
5328: 
5329: Tito’s heart gave a great bound, and began to beat violently.
5330: 
5331: “Romola,” he said, in a lower tone, “are you going to San Marco?”
5332: 
5333: They were now out of the Borgo Pinti and were under the city walls,
5334: where they had wide gardens on their left-hand, and all was quiet.
5335: Romola put aside her veil for the sake of breathing the air, and he
5336: could see the subdued agitation in her face.
5337: 
5338: “Yes, Tito mio,” she said, looking directly at him with sad eyes. “For
5339: the first time I am doing something unknown to my father. It comforts
5340: me that I have met you, for at least I can tell _you_. But if you are
5341: going to him, it will be well for you not to say that you met me. He
5342: thinks I am only gone to my cousin, because she sent for me. I left my
5343: godfather with him: _he_ knows where I am going, and why. You remember
5344: that evening when my brother’s name was mentioned and my father spoke
5345: of him to you?”
5346: 
5347: “Yes,” said Tito, in a low tone. There was a strange complication in
5348: his mental state. His heart sank at the probability that a great change
5349: was coming over his prospects, while at the same time his thoughts were
5350: darting over a hundred details of the course he would take when the
5351: change had come; and yet he returned Romola’s gaze with a hungry sense
5352: that it might be the last time she would ever bend it on him with full
5353: unquestioning confidence.
5354: 
5355: “The _cugina_ had heard that he was come back, and the evening
5356: before—the evening of San Giovanni—as I afterwards found, he had been
5357: seen by our good Maso near the door of our house; but when Maso went to
5358: inquire at San Marco, Dino, that is, my brother—he was christened
5359: Bernardino, after our godfather, but now he calls himself Fra Luca—had
5360: been taken to the monastery at Fiesole, because he was ill. But this
5361: morning a message came to Maso, saying that he was come back to San
5362: Marco, and Maso went to him there. He is very ill, and he has adjured
5363: me to go and see him. I cannot refuse it, though I hold him guilty; I
5364: still remember how I loved him when I was a little girl, before I knew
5365: that he would forsake my father. And perhaps he has some word of
5366: penitence to send by me. It cost me a struggle to act in opposition to
5367: my father’s feeling, which I have always held to be just. I am almost
5368: sure you will think I have chosen rightly, Tito, because I have noticed
5369: that your nature is less rigid than mine, and nothing makes you angry:
5370: it would cost you less to be forgiving; though, if you had seen your
5371: father forsaken by one to whom he had given his chief love—by one in
5372: whom he had planted his labour and his hopes—forsaken when his need was
5373: becoming greatest—even you, Tito, would find it hard to forgive.”
5374: 
5375: What could he say? He was not equal to the hypocrisy of telling Romola
5376: that such offences ought not to be pardoned; and he had not the courage
5377: to utter any words of dissuasion.
5378: 
5379: “You are right, my Romola; you are always right, except in thinking too
5380: well of me.”
5381: 
5382: There was really some genuineness in those last words, and Tito looked
5383: very beautiful as he uttered them, with an unusual pallor in his face,
5384: and a slight quivering of his lip. Romola, interpreting all things
5385: largely, like a mind prepossessed with high beliefs, had a tearful
5386: brightness in her eyes as she looked at him, touched with keen joy that
5387: he felt so strongly whatever she felt. But without pausing in her walk,
5388: she said—
5389: 
5390: “And now, Tito, I wish you to leave me, for the _cugina_ and I shall be
5391: less noticed if we enter the piazza alone.”
5392: 
5393: “Yes, it were better you should leave us,” said Monna Brigida; “for to
5394: say the truth, Messer Tito, all eyes follow you, and let Romola muffle
5395: herself as she will, every one wants to see what there is under her
5396: veil, for she has that way of walking like a procession. Not that I
5397: find fault with her for it, only it doesn’t suit my steps. And, indeed,
5398: I would rather not have us seen going to San Marco, and that’s why I am
5399: dressed as if I were one of the Piagnoni themselves, and as old as
5400: Sant’ Anna; for if it had been anybody but poor Dino, who ought to be
5401: forgiven if he’s dying, for what’s the use of having a grudge against
5402: dead people?—make them feel while they live, say I—”
5403: 
5404: No one made a scruple of interrupting Monna Brigida, and Tito, having
5405: just raised Romola’s hand to his lips, and said, “I understand, I obey
5406: you,” now turned away, lifting his cap—a sign of reverence rarely made
5407: at that time by native Florentines, and which excited Bernardo del
5408: Nero’s contempt for Tito as a fawning Greek, while to Romola, who loved
5409: homage, it gave him an exceptional grace.
5410: 
5411: He was half glad of the dismissal, half disposed to cling to Romola to
5412: the last moment in which she would love him without suspicion. For it
5413: seemed to him certain that this brother would before all things want to
5414: know, and that Romola would before all things confide to him, what was
5415: her father’s position and her own after the years which must have
5416: brought so much change. She would tell him that she was soon to be
5417: publicly betrothed to a young scholar, who was to fill up the place
5418: left vacant long ago by a wandering son. He foresaw the impulse that
5419: would prompt Romola to dwell on that prospect, and what would follow on
5420: the mention of the future husband’s name. Fra Luca would tell all he
5421: knew and conjectured, and Tito saw no possible falsity by which he
5422: could now ward off the worst consequences of his former dissimulation.
5423: It was all over with his prospects in Florence. There was Messer
5424: Bernardo del Nero, who would be delighted at seeing confirmed the
5425: wisdom of his advice about deferring the betrothal until Tito’s
5426: character and position had been established by a longer residence; and
5427: the history of the young Greek professor, whose benefactor was in
5428: slavery, would be the talk under every loggia. For the first time in
5429: his life he felt too fevered and agitated to trust his power of
5430: self-command; he gave up his intended visit to Bardo, and walked up and
5431: down under the walls until the yellow light in the west had quite
5432: faded, when, without any distinct purpose, he took the first turning,
5433: which happened to be the Via San Sebastiano, leading him directly
5434: towards the Piazza dell’ Annunziata.
5435: 
5436: He was at one of those lawless moments which come to us all if we have
5437: no guide but desire, and if the pathway where desire leads us seems
5438: suddenly closed; he was ready to follow any beckoning that offered him
5439: an immediate purpose.
5440: 
5441: 
5442: 
5443: 
5444: CHAPTER XIV.
5445: The Peasants’ Fair.
5446: 
5447: 
5448: The moving crowd and the strange mixture of noises that burst on him at
5449: the entrance of the piazza, reminded Tito of what Nello had said to him
5450: about the Fierucoloni, and he pushed his way into the crowd with a sort
5451: of pleasure in the hooting and elbowing, which filled the empty
5452: moments, and dulled that calculation of the future which had so new a
5453: dreariness for him, as he foresaw himself wandering away solitary in
5454: pursuit of some unknown fortune, that his thought had even glanced
5455: towards going in search of Baldassarre after all.
5456: 
5457: At each of the opposite inlets he saw people struggling into the
5458: piazza, while above them paper lanterns, held aloft on sticks, were
5459: waving uncertainly to and fro. A rude monotonous chant made a
5460: distinctly traceable strand of noise, across which screams, whistles,
5461: gibing chants in piping boyish voices, the beating of drums, and the
5462: ringing of little bells, met each other in confused din. Every now and
5463: then one of the dim floating lights disappeared with a smash from a
5464: stone launched more or less vaguely in pursuit of mischief, followed by
5465: a scream and renewed shouts. But on the outskirts of the whirling
5466: tumult there were groups who were keeping this vigil of the Nativity of
5467: the Virgin in a more methodical manner than by fitful stone-throwing
5468: and gibing. Certain ragged men, darting a hard sharp glance around them
5469: while their tongues rattled merrily, were inviting country people to
5470: game with them on fair and open-handed terms; two masquerading figures
5471: on stilts, who had snatched lanterns from the crowd, were swaying the
5472: lights to and fro in meteoric fashion, as they strode hither and
5473: thither; a sage trader was doing a profitable business at a small
5474: covered stall, in hot _berlingozzi_, a favourite farinaceous delicacy;
5475: one man standing on a barrel, with his back firmly planted against a
5476: pillar of the loggia in front of the Foundling Hospital (Spedale degl’
5477: Innocenti), was selling efficacious pills, invented by a doctor of
5478: Salerno, warranted to prevent toothache and death by drowning; and not
5479: far off, against another pillar, a tumbler was showing off his tricks
5480: on a small platform; while a handful of ’prentices, despising the slack
5481: entertainment of guerilla stone-throwing, were having a private
5482: concentrated match of that favourite Florentine sport at the narrow
5483: entrance of the Via de’ Febbrai.
5484: 
5485: Tito, obliged to make his way through chance openings in the crowd,
5486: found himself at one moment close to the trotting procession of
5487: barefooted, hard-heeled contadine, and could see their sun-dried,
5488: bronzed faces, and their strange, fragmentary garb, dim with hereditary
5489: dirt, and of obsolete stuffs and fashions, that made them look, in the
5490: eyes of the city people, like a way-worn ancestry returning from a
5491: pilgrimage on which they had set out a century ago. Just then it was
5492: the hardy, scant-feeding peasant-women from the mountains of Pistoia,
5493: who were entering with a year’s labour in a moderate bundle of yarn on
5494: their backs, and in their hearts that meagre hope of good and that wide
5495: dim fear of harm, which were somehow to be cared for by the Blessed
5496: Virgin, whose miraculous image, painted by the angels, was to have the
5497: curtain drawn away from it on this Eve of her Nativity, that its
5498: potency might stream forth without obstruction.
5499: 
5500: At another moment he was forced away towards the boundary of the
5501: piazza, where the more stationary candidates for attention and small
5502: coin had judiciously placed themselves, in order to be safe in their
5503: rear. Among these Tito recognised his acquaintance Bratti, who stood
5504: with his back against a pillar, and his mouth pursed up in disdainful
5505: silence, eyeing every one who approached him with a cold glance of
5506: superiority, and keeping his hand fast on a serge covering which
5507: concealed the contents of the basket slung before him. Rather surprised
5508: at a deportment so unusual in an anxious trader, Tito went nearer and
5509: saw two women go up to Bratti’s basket with a look of curiosity,
5510: whereupon the pedlar drew the covering tighter, and looked another way.
5511: It was quite too provoking, and one of the women was fain to ask what
5512: there was in his basket?
5513: 
5514: “Before I answer that, Monna, I must know whether you mean to buy. I
5515: can’t show such wares as mine in this fair for every fly to settle on
5516: and pay nothing. My goods are a little too choice for that. Besides,
5517: I’ve only two left, and I’ve no mind to soil them; for with the chances
5518: of the pestilence that wise men talk of, there is likelihood of their
5519: being worth their weight in gold. No, no: _andate con Dio_.”
5520: 
5521: The two women looked at each other.
5522: 
5523: “And what may be the price?” said the second.
5524: 
5525: “Not within what you are likely to have in your purse, buona donna,”
5526: said Bratti, in a compassionately supercilious tone. “I recommend you
5527: to trust in Messer Domeneddio and the saints: poor people can do no
5528: better for themselves.”
5529: 
5530: “Not so poor!” said the second woman, indignantly, drawing out her
5531: money-bag. “Come, now! what do you say to a grosso?”
5532: 
5533: “I say you may get twenty-one quattrini for it,” said Bratti, coolly;
5534: “but not of me, for I haven’t got that small change.”
5535: 
5536: “Come; two, then?” said the woman, getting exasperated, while her
5537: companion looked at her with some envy. “It will hardly be above two, I
5538: think.”
5539: 
5540: After further bidding, and further mercantile coquetry, Bratti put on
5541: an air of concession.
5542: 
5543: “Since you’ve set your mind on it,” he said, slowly raising the cover,
5544: “I should be loth to do you a mischief; for Maestro Gabbadeo used to
5545: say, when a woman sets her mind on a thing and doesn’t get it, she’s in
5546: worse danger of the pestilence than before. Ecco! I have but two left;
5547: and let me tell you, the fellow to them is on the finger of Maestro
5548: Gabbadeo, who is gone to Bologna—as wise a doctor as sits at any door.”
5549: 
5550: The precious objects were two clumsy iron rings, beaten into the
5551: fashion of old Roman rings, such as were sometimes disinterred. The
5552: rust on them, and the entirely hidden character of their potency, were
5553: so satisfactory, that the grossi were paid without grumbling, and the
5554: first woman, destitute of those handsome coins, succeeded after much
5555: show of reluctance on Bratti’s part in driving a bargain with some of
5556: her yarn, and carried off the remaining ring in triumph. Bratti covered
5557: up his basket, which was now filled with miscellanies, probably
5558: obtained under the same sort of circumstances as the yarn, and, moving
5559: from his pillar, came suddenly upon Tito, who, if he had had time,
5560: would have chosen to avoid recognition.
5561: 
5562: “By the head of San Giovanni, now,” said Bratti, drawing Tito back to
5563: the pillar, “this is a piece of luck. For I was talking of you this
5564: morning, Messer Greco; but, I said, he is mounted up among the signori
5565: now—and I’m glad of it, for I was at the bottom of his fortune—but I
5566: can rarely get speech of him, for he’s not to be caught lying on the
5567: stones now—not he! But it’s your luck, not mine, Messer Greco, save and
5568: except some small trifle to satisfy me for my trouble in the
5569: transaction.”
5570: 
5571: “You speak in riddles, Bratti,” said Tito. “Remember, I don’t sharpen
5572: my wits, as you do, by driving hard bargains for iron rings: you must
5573: be plain.”
5574: 
5575: “By the Holy ’Vangels! it was an easy bargain I gave them. If a Hebrew
5576: gets thirty-two per cent, I hope a Christian may get a little more. If
5577: I had not borne a conscience, I should have got twice the money and
5578: twice the yarn. But, talking of rings, it is your ring—that very ring
5579: you’ve got on your finger—that I could get you a purchaser for; ay, and
5580: a purchaser with a deep money-bag.”
5581: 
5582: “Truly?” said Tito, looking at his ring and listening.
5583: 
5584: “A Genoese who is going straight away into Hungary, as I understand. He
5585: came and looked all over my shop to see if I had any old things I
5586: didn’t know the price of; I warrant you, he thought I had a pumpkin on
5587: my shoulders. He had been rummaging all the shops in Florence. And he
5588: had a ring on—not like yours, but something of the same fashion; and as
5589: he was talking of rings, I said I knew a fine young man, a particular
5590: acquaintance of mine, who had a ring of that sort. And he said, ‘Who is
5591: he, pray? Tell him I’ll give him his price for it.’ And I thought of
5592: going after you to Nello’s to-morrow; for it’s my opinion of you,
5593: Messer Greco, that you’re not one who’d see the Arno run broth, and
5594: stand by without dipping your finger.”
5595: 
5596: Tito had lost no word of what Bratti had said, yet his mind had been
5597: very busy all the while. Why should he keep the ring? It had been a
5598: mere sentiment, a mere fancy, that had prevented him from selling it
5599: with the other gems; if he had been wiser and had sold it, he might
5600: perhaps have escaped that identification by Fra Luca. It was true that
5601: it had been taken from Baldassarre’s finger and put on his own as soon
5602: as his young hand had grown to the needful size; but there was really
5603: no valid good to anybody in those superstitious scruples about
5604: inanimate objects. The ring had helped towards the recognition of him.
5605: Tito had begun to dislike recognition, which was a claim from the past.
5606: This foreigner’s offer, if he would really give a good price, was an
5607: opportunity for getting rid of the ring without the trouble of seeking
5608: a purchaser.
5609: 
5610: “You speak with your usual wisdom, Bratti,” said Tito. “I have no
5611: objection to hear what your Genoese will offer. But when and where
5612: shall I have speech of him?”
5613: 
5614: “To-morrow, at three hours after sunrise, he will be at my shop, and if
5615: your wits are of that sharpness I have always taken them to be, Messer
5616: Greco, you will ask him a heavy price; for he minds not money. It’s my
5617: belief he’s buying for somebody else, and not for himself—perhaps for
5618: some great signor.”
5619: 
5620: “It is well,” said Tito. “I will be at your shop, if nothing hinders.”
5621: 
5622: “And you will doubtless deal nobly by me for old acquaintance’ sake,
5623: Messer Greco, so I will not stay to fix the small sum you will give me
5624: in token of my service in the matter. It seems to me a thousand years
5625: now till I get out of the piazza, for a fair is a dull, not to say a
5626: wicked thing, when one has no more goods to sell.”
5627: 
5628: Tito made a hasty sign of assent and adieu, and moving away from the
5629: pillar, again found himself pushed towards the middle of the piazza and
5630: back again, without the power of determining his own course. In this
5631: zigzag way he was carried along to the end of the piazza opposite the
5632: church, where, in a deep recess formed by an irregularity in the line
5633: of houses, an entertainment was going forward which seemed to be
5634: especially attractive to the crowd. Loud bursts of laughter interrupted
5635: a monologue which was sometimes slow and oratorical, at others rattling
5636: and buffoonish. Here a girl was being pushed forward into the inner
5637: circle with apparent reluctance, and there a loud laughing minx was
5638: finding a way with her own elbows. It was a strange light that was
5639: spread over the piazza. There were the pale stars breaking out above,
5640: and the dim waving lanterns below, leaving all objects indistinct
5641: except when they were seen close under the fitfully moving lights; but
5642: in this recess there was a stronger light, against which the heads of
5643: the encircling spectators stood in dark relief as Tito was gradually
5644: pushed towards them, while above them rose the head of a man wearing a
5645: white mitre with yellow cabalistic figures upon it.
5646: 
5647: “Behold, my children!” Tito heard him saying, “behold your opportunity!
5648: neglect not the holy sacrament of matrimony when it can be had for the
5649: small sum of a white quattrino—the cheapest matrimony ever offered, and
5650: dissolved by special bull beforehand at every man’s own will and
5651: pleasure. Behold the bull!” Here the speaker held up a piece of
5652: parchment with huge seals attached to it. “Behold the indulgence
5653: granted by his Holiness Alexander the Sixth, who, being newly elected
5654: Pope for his peculiar piety, intends to reform and purify the Church,
5655: and wisely begins by abolishing that priestly abuse which keeps too
5656: large a share of this privileged matrimony to the clergy and stints the
5657: laity. Spit once, my sons, and pay a white quattrino! This is the whole
5658: and sole price of the indulgence. The quattrino is the only difference
5659: the Holy Father allows to be put any longer between us and the
5660: clergy—who spit and pay nothing.”
5661: 
5662: Tito thought he knew the voice, which had a peculiarly sharp ring, but
5663: the face was too much in shadow from the lights behind for him to be
5664: sure of the features. Stepping as near as he could, he saw within the
5665: circle behind the speaker an altar-like table raised on a small
5666: platform, and covered with a red drapery stitched all over with yellow
5667: cabalistical figures. Half-a-dozen thin tapers burned at the back of
5668: this table, which had a conjuring apparatus scattered over it, a large
5669: open book in the centre, and at one of the front angles a monkey
5670: fastened by a cord to a small ring and holding a small taper, which in
5671: his incessant fidgety movements fell more or less aslant, whilst an
5672: impish boy in a white surplice occupied himself chiefly in cuffing the
5673: monkey, and adjusting the taper. The man in the mitre also wore a
5674: surplice, and over it a chasuble on which the signs of the zodiac were
5675: rudely marked in black upon a yellow ground. Tito was sure now that he
5676: recognised the sharp upward-tending angles of the face under the mitre:
5677: it was that of Maestro Vaiano, the mountebank, from whom he had rescued
5678: Tessa. Pretty little Tessa! Perhaps she too had come in among the
5679: troops of contadine.
5680: 
5681: “Come, my maidens! This is the time for the pretty who can have many
5682: chances, and for the ill-favoured who have few. Matrimony to be
5683: had—hot, eaten, and done with as easily as _berlingozzi_! And see!”
5684: here the conjuror held up a cluster of tiny bags. “To every bride I
5685: give a _Breve_ with a secret in it—the secret alone worth the money you
5686: pay for the matrimony. The secret how to—no, no, I will not tell you
5687: what the secret is about, and that makes it a double secret. Hang it
5688: round your neck if you like, and never look at it; I don’t say _that_
5689: will not be the best, for then you will see many things you don’t
5690: expect: though if you open it you may break your leg, _è vero_, but you
5691: will know a secret! Something nobody knows but me! And mark—I give you
5692: the _Breve_, I don’t sell it, as many another holy man would: the
5693: quattrino is for the matrimony, and the _Breve_ you get for nothing.
5694: _Orsù, giovanetti_, come like dutiful sons of the Church and buy the
5695: Indulgence of his Holiness Alexander the Sixth.”
5696: 
5697: This buffoonery just fitted the taste of the audience; the _fierucola_
5698: was but a small occasion, so the townsmen might be contented with jokes
5699: that were rather less indecent than those they were accustomed to hear
5700: at every carnival, put into easy rhyme by the Magnifico and his poetic
5701: satellites; while the women, over and above any relish of the fun,
5702: really began to have an itch for the _Brevi_. Several couples had
5703: already gone through the ceremony, in which the conjuror’s solemn
5704: gibberish and grimaces over the open book, the antics of the monkey,
5705: and even the preliminary spitting, had called forth peals of laughter;
5706: and now a well-looking, merry-eyed youth of seventeen, in a loose tunic
5707: and red cap, pushed forward, holding by the hand a plump brunette,
5708: whose scanty ragged dress displayed her round arms and legs very
5709: picturesquely.
5710: 
5711: “Fetter us without delay, Maestro!” said the youth, “for I have got to
5712: take my bride home and paint her under the light of a lantern.”
5713: 
5714: “Ha! Mariotto, my son, I commend your pious observance...” The conjuror
5715: was going on, when a loud chattering behind warned him that an
5716: unpleasant crisis had arisen with his monkey.
5717: 
5718: The temper of that imperfect acolyth was a little tried by the
5719: over-active discipline of his colleague in the surplice, and a sudden
5720: cuff administered as his taper fell to a horizontal position, caused
5721: him to leap back with a violence that proved too much for the slackened
5722: knot by which his cord was fastened. His first leap was to the other
5723: end of the table, from which position his remonstrances were so
5724: threatening that the imp in the surplice took up a wand by way of an
5725: equivalent threat, whereupon the monkey leaped on to the head of a tall
5726: woman in the foreground, dropping his taper by the way, and chattering
5727: with increased emphasis from that eminence. Great was the screaming and
5728: confusion, not a few of the spectators having a vague dread of the
5729: Maestro’s monkey, as capable of more hidden mischief than mere teeth
5730: and claws could inflict; and the conjuror himself was in some alarm
5731: lest any harm should happen to his familiar. In the scuffle to seize
5732: the monkey’s string, Tito got out of the circle, and, not caring to
5733: contend for his place again, he allowed himself to be gradually pushed
5734: towards the church of the Nunziata, and to enter amongst the
5735: worshippers.
5736: 
5737: The brilliant illumination within seemed to press upon his eyes with
5738: palpable force after the pale scattered lights and broad shadows of the
5739: piazza, and for the first minute or two he could see nothing
5740: distinctly. That yellow splendour was in itself something supernatural
5741: and heavenly to many of the peasant-women, for whom half the sky was
5742: hidden by mountains, and who went to bed in the twilight; and the
5743: uninterrupted chant from the choir was repose to the ear after the
5744: hellish hubbub of the crowd outside. Gradually the scene became
5745: clearer, though still there was a thin yellow haze from incense
5746: mingling with the breath of the multitude. In a chapel on the left-hand
5747: of the nave, wreathed with silver lamps, was seen unveiled the
5748: miraculous fresco of the Annunciation, which, in Tito’s oblique view of
5749: it from the right-hand side of the nave, seemed dark with the excess of
5750: light around it. The whole area of the great church was filled with
5751: peasant-women, some kneeling, some standing; the coarse bronzed skins,
5752: and the dingy clothing of the rougher dwellers on the mountains,
5753: contrasting with the softer-lined faces and white or red head-drapery
5754: of the well-to-do dwellers in the valley, who were scattered in
5755: irregular groups. And spreading high and far over the walls and ceiling
5756: there was another multitude, also pressing close against each other,
5757: that they might be nearer the potent Virgin. It was the crowd of votive
5758: waxen images, the effigies of great personages, clothed in their habit
5759: as they lived: Florentines of high name in their black silk lucco, as
5760: when they sat in council; popes, emperors, kings, cardinals, and famous
5761: condottieri with plumed morion seated on their chargers; all notable
5762: strangers who passed through Florence or had aught to do with its
5763: affairs—Mohammedans, even, in well-tolerated companionship with
5764: Christian cavaliers; some of them with faces blackened and robes
5765: tattered by the corroding breath of centuries, others fresh and bright
5766: in new red mantle or steel corselet, the exact doubles of the living.
5767: And wedged in with all these were detached arms, legs, and other
5768: members, with only here and there a gap where some image had been
5769: removed for public disgrace, or had fallen ominously, as Lorenzo’s had
5770: done six months before. It was a perfect resurrection-swarm of remote
5771: mortals and fragments of mortals, reflecting, in their varying degrees
5772: of freshness, the sombre dinginess and sprinkled brightness of the
5773: crowd below.
5774: 
5775: Tito’s glance wandered over the wild multitude in search of something.
5776: He had already thought of Tessa, and the white hoods suggested the
5777: possibility that he might detect her face under one of them. It was at
5778: least a thought to be courted, rather than the vision of Romola looking
5779: at him with changed eyes. But he searched in vain; and he was leaving
5780: the church, weary of a scene which had no variety, when, just against
5781: the doorway, he caught sight of Tessa, only two yards off him. She was
5782: kneeling with her back against the wall, behind a group of
5783: peasant-women, who were standing and looking for a spot nearer to the
5784: sacred image. Her head hung a little aside with a look of weariness,
5785: and her blue eyes were directed rather absently towards an altar-piece
5786: where the Archangel Michael stood in his armour, with young face and
5787: floating hair, amongst bearded and tonsured saints. Her right-hand,
5788: holding a bunch of cocoons, fell by her side listlessly, and her round
5789: cheek was paled, either by the light or by the weariness that was
5790: expressed in her attitude: her lips were pressed poutingly together,
5791: and every now and then her eyelids half fell: she was a large image of
5792: a sweet sleepy child. Tito felt an irresistible desire to go up to her
5793: and get her pretty trusting looks and prattle: this creature who was
5794: without moral judgment that could condemn him, whose little loving
5795: ignorant soul made a world apart, where he might feel in freedom from
5796: suspicions and exacting demands, had a new attraction for him now. She
5797: seemed a refuge from the threatened isolation that would come with
5798: disgrace. He glanced cautiously round, to assure himself that Monna
5799: Ghita was not near, and then, slipping quietly to her side, kneeled on
5800: one knee, and said, in the softest voice, “Tessa!”
5801: 
5802: She hardly started, any more than she would have started at a soft
5803: breeze that fanned her gently when she was needing it. She turned her
5804: head and saw Tito’s face close to her: it was very much more beautiful
5805: than the Archangel Michael’s, who was so mighty and so good that he
5806: lived with the Madonna and all the saints and was prayed to along with
5807: them. She smiled in happy silence, for that nearness of Tito quite
5808: filled her mind.
5809: 
5810: “My little Tessa! you look very tired. How long have you been kneeling
5811: here?”
5812: 
5813: She seemed to be collecting her thoughts for a minute or two, and at
5814: last she said—
5815: 
5816: “I’m very hungry.”
5817: 
5818: “Come, then; come with me.”
5819: 
5820: He lifted her from her knees, and led her out under the cloisters
5821: surrounding the atrium, which were then open, and not yet adorned with
5822: the frescoes of Andrea del Sarto.
5823: 
5824: “How is it you are all by yourself, and so hungry, Tessa?”
5825: 
5826: “The Madre is ill; she has very bad pains in her legs, and sent me to
5827: bring these cocoons to the Santissima Nunziata, because they’re so
5828: wonderful; see!”—she held up the bunch of cocoons, which were arranged
5829: with fortuitous regularity on a stem,—“and she had kept them to bring
5830: them herself, but she couldn’t, and so she sent me because she thinks
5831: the Holy Madonna may take away her pains; and somebody took my bag with
5832: the bread and chestnuts in it, and the people pushed me back, and I was
5833: so frightened coming in the crowd, and I couldn’t get anywhere near the
5834: Holy Madonna, to give the cocoons to the Padre, but I must—oh, I must.”
5835: 
5836: “Yes, my little Tessa, you shall take them; but first come and let me
5837: give you some berlingozzi. There are some to be had not far off.”
5838: 
5839: “Where did you come from?” said Tessa, a little bewildered. “I thought
5840: you would never come to me again, because you never came to the Mercato
5841: for milk any more. I set myself Aves to say, to see if they would bring
5842: you back, but I left off, because they didn’t.”
5843: 
5844: “You see I come when you want some one to take care of you, Tessa.
5845: Perhaps the Aves fetched me, only it took them a long while. But what
5846: shall you do if you are here all alone? Where shall you go?”
5847: 
5848: “Oh, I shall stay and sleep in the church—a great many of them do—in
5849: the church and all about here—I did once when I came with my mother;
5850: and the _patrigno_ is coming with the mules in the morning.”
5851: 
5852: They were out in the piazza now, where the crowd was rather less
5853: riotous than before, and the lights were fewer, the stream of pilgrims
5854: having ceased. Tessa clung fast to Tito’s arm in satisfied silence,
5855: while he led her towards the stall where he remembered seeing the
5856: eatables. Their way was the easier because there was just now a great
5857: rush towards the middle of the piazza, where the masqued figures on
5858: stilts had found space to execute a dance. It was very pretty to see
5859: the guileless thing giving her cocoons into Tito’s hand, and then
5860: eating her berlingozzi with the relish of a hungry child. Tito had
5861: really come to take care of her, as he did before, and that wonderful
5862: happiness of being with him had begun again for her. Her hunger was
5863: soon appeased, all the sooner for the new stimulus of happiness that
5864: had roused her from her languor, and, as they turned away from the
5865: stall, she said nothing about going into the church again, but looked
5866: round as if the sights in the piazza were not without attraction to her
5867: now she was safe under Tito’s arm.
5868: 
5869: “How can they do that?” she exclaimed, looking up at the dancers on
5870: stilts. Then, after a minute’s silence, “Do you think Saint Christopher
5871: helps them?”
5872: 
5873: “Perhaps. What do you think about it, Tessa?” said Tito, slipping his
5874: right arm round her, and looking down at her fondly.
5875: 
5876: “Because Saint Christopher is so very tall; and he is very good: if
5877: anybody looks at him he takes care of them all day. He is on the wall
5878: of the church—too tall to stand up there—but I saw him walking through
5879: the streets one San Giovanni, carrying the little Gesu.”
5880: 
5881: “You pretty pigeon! Do you think anybody could help taking care of
5882: _you_, if you looked at them?”
5883: 
5884: “Shall you always come and take care of me?” said Tessa, turning her
5885: face up to him, as he crushed her cheek with his left-hand. “And shall
5886: you always be a long while first?”
5887: 
5888: Tito was conscious that some bystanders were laughing at them, and
5889: though the licence of street fun, among artists and young men of the
5890: wealthier sort as well as among the populace, made few adventures
5891: exceptional, still less disreputable, he chose to move away towards the
5892: end of the piazza.
5893: 
5894: “Perhaps I shall come again to you very soon, Tessa,” he answered,
5895: rather dreamily, when they had moved away. He was thinking that when
5896: all the rest had turned their backs upon him, it would be pleasant to
5897: have this little creature adoring him and nestling against him. The
5898: absence of presumptuous self-conceit in Tito made him feel all the more
5899: defenceless under prospective obloquy: he needed soft looks and
5900: caresses too much ever to be impudent.
5901: 
5902: “In the Mercato?” said Tessa. “Not to-morrow morning, because the
5903: _patrigno_ will be there, and he is so cross. Oh! but you have money,
5904: and he will not be cross if you buy some salad. And there are some
5905: chestnuts. Do you like chestnuts?”
5906: 
5907: He said nothing, but continued to look down at her with a dreamy
5908: gentleness, and Tessa felt herself in a state of delicious wonder;
5909: everything seemed as new as if she were being carried on a chariot of
5910: clouds.
5911: 
5912: “Holy Virgin!” she exclaimed again presently. “There is a holy father
5913: like the Bishop I saw at Prato.”
5914: 
5915: Tito looked up too, and saw that he had unconsciously advanced to
5916: within a few yards of the conjuror, Maestro Vaiano, who for the moment
5917: was forsaken by the crowd. His face was turned away from them, and he
5918: was occupied with the apparatus on his altar or table, preparing a new
5919: diversion by the time the interest in the dancing should be exhausted.
5920: The monkey was imprisoned under the red cloth, out of reach of
5921: mischief, and the youngster in the white surplice was holding a sort of
5922: dish or salver, from which his master was taking some ingredient. The
5923: altar-like table, with its gorgeous cloth, the row of tapers, the sham
5924: episcopal costume, the surpliced attendant, and even the movements of
5925: the mitred figure, as he alternately bent his head and then raised
5926: something before the lights, were a sufficiently near parody of sacred
5927: things to rouse poor little Tessa’s veneration; and there was some
5928: additional awe produced by the mystery of their apparition in this
5929: spot, for when she had seen an altar in the street before, it had been
5930: on Corpus Christi Day, and there had been a procession to account for
5931: it. She crossed herself and looked up at Tito, but then, as if she had
5932: had time for reflection, said, “It is because of the Nativita.”
5933: 
5934: Meanwhile Vaiano had turned round, raising his hands to his mitre with
5935: the intention of changing his dress, when his quick eye recognised Tito
5936: and Tessa who were both looking at him, their faces being shone upon by
5937: the light of his tapers, while his own was in shadow.
5938: 
5939: “Ha! my children!” he said, instantly, stretching out his hands in a
5940: benedictory attitude, “you are come to be married. I commend your
5941: penitence—the blessing of Holy Church can never come too late.”
5942: 
5943: But whilst he was speaking, he had taken in the whole meaning of
5944: Tessa’s attitude and expression, and he discerned an opportunity for a
5945: new kind of joke which required him to be cautious and solemn.
5946: 
5947: “Should you like to be married to me, Tessa?” said Tito, softly, half
5948: enjoying the comedy, as he saw the pretty childish seriousness on her
5949: face, half prompted by hazy previsions which belonged to the
5950: intoxication of despair.
5951: 
5952: He felt her vibrating before she looked up at him and said, timidly,
5953: “Will you let me?”
5954: 
5955: He answered only by a smile, and by leading her forward in front of the
5956: _cerretano_, who, seeing an excellent jest in Tessa’s evident delusion,
5957: assumed a surpassing sacerdotal solemnity, and went through the mimic
5958: ceremony with a liberal expenditure of _lingua furbesca_ or thieves’
5959: Latin. But some symptoms of a new movement in the crowd urged him to
5960: bring it to a speedy conclusion and dismiss them with hands
5961: outstretched in a benedictory attitude over their kneeling figures.
5962: Tito, disposed always to cultivate goodwill, though it might be the
5963: least select, put a piece of four grossi into his hand as he moved
5964: away, and was thanked by a look which, the conjuror felt sure, conveyed
5965: a perfect understanding of the whole affair.
5966: 
5967: But Tito himself was very far from that understanding, and did not, in
5968: fact, know whether, the next moment, he should tell Tessa of the joke
5969: and laugh at her for a little goose, or whether he should let her
5970: delusion last, and see what would come of it—see what she would say and
5971: do next.
5972: 
5973: “Then you will not go away from me again,” said Tessa, after they had
5974: walked a few steps, “and you will take me to where you live.” She spoke
5975: meditatively, and not in a questioning tone. But presently she added,
5976: “I must go back once to the Madre though, to tell her I brought the
5977: cocoons, and that I am married, and shall not go back again.”
5978: 
5979: Tito felt the necessity of speaking now; and in the rapid thought
5980: prompted by that necessity, he saw that by undeceiving Tessa he should
5981: be robbing himself of some at least of that pretty trustfulness which
5982: might, by-and-by, be his only haven from contempt. It would spoil Tessa
5983: to make her the least particle wiser or more suspicious.
5984: 
5985: “Yes, my little Tessa,” he said, caressingly, “you must go back to the
5986: Madre; but you must not tell her you are married—you must keep that a
5987: secret from everybody; else some very great harm would happen to me,
5988: and you would never see me again.”
5989: 
5990: She looked up at him with fear in her face.
5991: 
5992: “You must go back and feed your goats and mules, and do just as you
5993: have always done before, and say no word to any one about me.”
5994: 
5995: The corners of her mouth fell a little.
5996: 
5997: “And then, perhaps, I shall come and take care of you again when you
5998: want me, as I did before. But you must do just what I tell you, else
5999: you will not see me again.”
6000: 
6001: “Yes, I will, I will,” she said, in a loud whisper, frightened at that
6002: blank prospect.
6003: 
6004: They were silent a little while; and then Tessa, looking at her hand,
6005: said—
6006: 
6007: “The Madre wears a betrothal ring. She went to church and had it put
6008: on, and then after that, another day, she was married. And so did the
6009: cousin Nannina. But then _she_ married Gollo,” added the poor little
6010: thing, entangled in the difficult comparison between her own case and
6011: others within her experience.
6012: 
6013: “But you must not wear a betrothal ring, my Tessa, because no one must
6014: know you are married,” said Tito, feeling some insistence necessary.
6015: “And the _buona fortuna_ that I gave you did just as well for
6016: betrothal. Some people are betrothed with rings and some are not.”
6017: 
6018: “Yes, it is true, they would see the ring,” said Tessa, trying to
6019: convince herself that a thing she would like very much was really not
6020: good for her.
6021: 
6022: They were now near the entrance of the church again, and she remembered
6023: her cocoons which were still in Tito’s hand.
6024: 
6025: “Ah, you must give me the _boto_,” she said; “and we must go in, and I
6026: must take it to the Padre, and I must tell the rest of my beads,
6027: because I was too tired before.”
6028: 
6029: “Yes, you must go in, Tessa; but I will not go in. I must leave you
6030: now,” said Tito, too feverish and weary to re-enter that stifling heat,
6031: and feeling that this was the least difficult way of parting with her.
6032: 
6033: “And not come back? Oh, where do you go?” Tessa’s mind had never formed
6034: an image of his whereabout or his doings when she did not see him: he
6035: had vanished, and her thought, instead of following him, had stayed in
6036: the same spot where he was with her.
6037: 
6038: “I shall come back some time, Tessa,” said Tito, taking her under the
6039: cloisters to the door of the church. “You must not cry—you must go to
6040: sleep, when you have said your beads. And here is money to buy your
6041: breakfast. Now kiss me, and look happy, else I shall not come again.”
6042: 
6043: She made a great effort over herself as she put up her lips to kiss
6044: him, and submitted to be gently turned round, with her face towards the
6045: door of the church. Tito saw her enter; and then with a shrug at his
6046: own resolution, leaned against a pillar, took off his cap, rubbed his
6047: hair backward, and wondered where Romola was now, and what she was
6048: thinking of him. Poor little Tessa had disappeared behind the curtain
6049: among the crowd of peasants; but the love which formed one web with all
6050: his worldly hopes, with the ambitions and pleasures that must make the
6051: solid part of his days—the love that was identified with his larger
6052: self—was not to be banished from his consciousness. Even to the man who
6053: presents the most elastic resistance to whatever is unpleasant, there
6054: will come moments when the pressure from without is too strong for him,
6055: and he must feel the smart and the bruise in spite of himself. Such a
6056: moment had come to Tito. There was no possible attitude of mind, no
6057: scheme of action by which the uprooting of all his newly-planted hopes
6058: could be made otherwise than painful.
6059: 
6060: 
6061: 
6062: 
6063: CHAPTER XV.
6064: The Dying Message.
6065: 
6066: 
6067: When Romola arrived at the entrance of San Marco she found one of the
6068: Frati waiting there in expectation of her arrival. Monna Brigida
6069: retired into the adjoining church, and Romola was conducted to the door
6070: of the chapter-house in the outer cloister, whither the invalid had
6071: been conveyed; no woman being allowed admission beyond this precinct.
6072: 
6073: When the door opened, the subdued external light blending with that of
6074: two tapers placed behind a truckle-bed, showed the emaciated face of
6075: Fra Luca, with the tonsured crown of golden hair above it, and with
6076: deep-sunken hazel eyes fixed on a small crucifix which he held before
6077: him. He was propped up into nearly a sitting posture; and Romola was
6078: just conscious, as she threw aside her veil, that there was another
6079: monk standing by the bed, with the black cowl drawn over his head, and
6080: that he moved towards the door as she entered; just conscious that in
6081: the background there was a crucified form rising high and pale on the
6082: frescoed wall, and pale faces of sorrow looking out from it below.
6083: 
6084: The next moment her eyes met Fra Luca’s as they looked up at her from
6085: the crucifix, and she was absorbed in that pang of recognition which
6086: identified this monkish emaciated form with the image of her fair young
6087: brother.
6088: 
6089: “Dino!” she said, in a voice like a low cry of pain. But she did not
6090: bend towards him; she held herself erect, and paused at two yards’
6091: distance from him. There was an unconquerable repulsion for her in that
6092: monkish aspect; it seemed to her the brand of the dastardly
6093: undutifulness which had left her father desolate—of the grovelling
6094: superstition which could give such undutifulness the name of piety. Her
6095: father, whose proud sincerity and simplicity of life had made him one
6096: of the few frank pagans of his time, had brought her up with a silent
6097: ignoring of any claims the Church could have to regulate the belief and
6098: action of beings with a cultivated reason. The Church, in her mind,
6099: belonged to that actual life of the mixed multitude from which they had
6100: always lived apart, and she had no ideas that could render her
6101: brother’s course an object of any other feeling than incurious,
6102: indignant contempt. Yet the lovingness of Romola’s soul had clung to
6103: that image in the past, and while she stood rigidly aloof, there was a
6104: yearning search in her eyes for something too faintly discernible.
6105: 
6106: But there was no corresponding emotion in the face of the monk. He
6107: looked at the little sister returned to him in her full womanly beauty,
6108: with the far-off gaze of a revisiting spirit.
6109: 
6110: “My sister!” he said, with a feeble and interrupted but yet distinct
6111: utterance, “it is well thou hast not longer delayed to come, for I have
6112: a message to deliver to thee, and my time is short.”
6113: 
6114: Romola took a step nearer: the message, she thought, would be one of
6115: affectionate penitence to her father, and her heart began to open.
6116: Nothing could wipe out the long years of desertion; but the culprit,
6117: looking back on those years with the sense of irremediable wrong
6118: committed, would call forth pity. Now, at the last, there would be
6119: understanding and forgiveness. Dino would pour out some natural filial
6120: feeling; he would ask questions about his father’s blindness—how
6121: rapidly it had come on? how the long dark days had been filled? what
6122: the life was now in the home where he himself had been nourished?—and
6123: the last message from the dying lips would be one of tenderness and
6124: regret.
6125: 
6126: “Romola,” Fra Luca began, “I have had a vision concerning thee. Thrice
6127: I have had it in the last two months: each time it has been clearer.
6128: Therefore I came from Fiesole, deeming it a message from heaven that I
6129: was bound to deliver. And I gather a promise of mercy to thee in this,
6130: that my breath is preserved in order to—”
6131: 
6132: The difficult breathing which continually interrupted him would not let
6133: him finish the sentence.
6134: 
6135: Romola had felt her heart chilling again. It was a vision, then, this
6136: message—one of those visions she had so often heard her father allude
6137: to with bitterness. Her indignation rushed to her lips.
6138: 
6139: “Dino, I thought you had some words to send to my father. You forsook
6140: him when his sight was failing; you made his life very desolate. Have
6141: you never cared about that? never repented? What is this religion of
6142: yours, that places visions before natural duties?”
6143: 
6144: The deep-sunken hazel eyes turned slowly towards her, and rested upon
6145: her in silence for some moments, as if he were meditating whether he
6146: should answer her.
6147: 
6148: “No,” he said at last; speaking as before, in a low passionless tone,
6149: as of some spirit not human, speaking through dying human organs. “No;
6150: I have never repented fleeing from the stifling poison-breath of sin
6151: that was hot and thick around me, and threatened to steal over my
6152: senses like besotting wine. My father could not hear the voice that
6153: called me night and day; he knew nothing of the demon-tempters that
6154: tried to drag me back from following it. My father has lived amidst
6155: human sin and misery without believing in them: he has been like one
6156: busy picking shining stones in a mine, while there was a world dying of
6157: plague above him. I spoke, but he listened with scorn. I told him the
6158: studies he wished me to live for were either childish trifling—dead
6159: toys—or else they must be made warm and living by pulses that beat to
6160: worldly ambitions and fleshly lusts, for worldly ambitions and fleshly
6161: lusts made all the substance of the poetry and history he wanted me to
6162: bend my eyes on continually.”
6163: 
6164: “Has not my father led a pure and noble life, then?” Romola burst
6165: forth, unable to hear in silence this implied accusation against her
6166: father. “He has sought no worldly honours; he has been truthful; he has
6167: denied himself all luxuries; he has lived like one of the ancient
6168: sages. He never wished you to live for worldly ambitions and fleshly
6169: lusts; he wished you to live as he himself has done, according to the
6170: purest maxims of philosophy, in which he brought you up.”
6171: 
6172: Romola spoke partly by rote, as all ardent and sympathetic young
6173: creatures do; but she spoke with intense belief. The pink flush was in
6174: her face, and she quivered from head to foot. Her brother was again
6175: slow to answer; looking at her passionate face with strange passionless
6176: eyes.
6177: 
6178: “What were the maxims of philosophy to me? They told me to be strong,
6179: when I felt myself weak; when I was ready, like the blessed Saint
6180: Benedict, to roll myself among thorns, and court smarting wounds as a
6181: deliverance from temptation. For the Divine love had sought me, and
6182: penetrated me, and created a great need in me; like a seed that wants
6183: room to grow. I had been brought up in carelessness of the true faith;
6184: I had not studied the doctrines of our religion; but it seemed to take
6185: possession of me like a rising flood. I felt that there was a life of
6186: perfect love and purity for the soul; in which there would be no uneasy
6187: hunger after pleasure, no tormenting questions, no fear of suffering.
6188: Before I knew the history of the saints, I had a foreshadowing of their
6189: ecstasy. For the same truth had penetrated even into pagan philosophy:
6190: that it is a bliss within the reach of man to die to mortal needs, and
6191: live in the life of God as the Unseen Perfectness. But to attain that I
6192: must forsake the world: I must have no affection, no hope, wedding me
6193: to that which passeth away; I must live with my fellow-beings only as
6194: human souls related to the eternal unseen life. That need was urging me
6195: continually: it came over me in visions when my mind fell away weary
6196: from the vain words which record the passions of dead men: it came over
6197: me after I had been tempted into sin and had turned away with loathing
6198: from the scent of the emptied cup. And in visions I saw the meaning of
6199: the Crucifix.”
6200: 
6201: He paused, breathing hard for a minute or two: but Romola was not
6202: prompted to speak again. It was useless for her mind to attempt any
6203: contact with the mind of this unearthly brother: as useless as for her
6204: hand to try and grasp a shadow. When he spoke again his heaving chest
6205: was quieter.
6206: 
6207: “I felt whom I must follow: but I saw that even among the servants of
6208: the Cross who professed to have renounced the world, my soul would be
6209: stifled with the fumes of hypocrisy, and lust, and pride. God had not
6210: chosen me, as he chose Saint Dominic and Saint Francis, to wrestle with
6211: evil in the Church and in the world. He called upon me to flee: I took
6212: the sacred vows and I fled—fled to lands where danger and scorn and
6213: want bore me continually, like angels, to repose on the bosom of God. I
6214: have lived the life of a hermit, I have ministered to pilgrims; but my
6215: task has been short: the veil has worn very thin that divides me from
6216: my everlasting rest. I came back to Florence that—”
6217: 
6218: “Dino, you _did_ want to know if my father was alive,” interrupted
6219: Romola, the picture of that suffering life touching her again with the
6220: desire for union and forgiveness.
6221: 
6222: ”—That before I died I might urge others of our brethren to study the
6223: Eastern tongues, as I had not done, and go out to greater ends than I
6224: did; and I find them already bent on the work. And since I came,
6225: Romola, I have felt that I was sent partly to thee—not to renew the
6226: bonds of earthly affection, but to deliver the heavenly warning
6227: conveyed in a vision. For I have had that vision thrice. And through
6228: all the years since first the Divine voice called me, while I was yet
6229: in the world, I have been taught and guided by visions. For in the
6230: painful linking together of our waking thoughts we can never be sure
6231: that we have not mingled our own error with the light we have prayed
6232: for; but in visions and dreams we are passive, and our souls are as an
6233: instrument in the Divine hand. Therefore listen, and speak not
6234: again—for the time is short.”
6235: 
6236: Romola’s mind recoiled strongly from listening to this vision. Her
6237: indignation had subsided, but it was only because she had felt the
6238: distance between her brother and herself widening. But while Fra Luca
6239: was speaking, the figure of another monk had entered, and again stood
6240: on the other side of the bed, with the cowl drawn over his head.
6241: 
6242: “Kneel, my daughter, for the Angel of Death is present, and waits while
6243: the message of heaven is delivered: bend thy pride before it is bent
6244: for thee by a yoke of iron,” said a strong rich voice, startlingly in
6245: contrast with Fra Luca’s.
6246: 
6247: The tone was not that of imperious command, but of quiet
6248: self-possession and assurance of the right, blended with benignity.
6249: Romola, vibrating to the sound, looked round at the figure on the
6250: opposite side of the bed. His face was hardly discernible under the
6251: shadow of the cowl, and her eyes fell at once on his hands, which were
6252: folded across his breast and lay in relief on the edge of his black
6253: mantle. They had a marked physiognomy which enforced the influence of
6254: the voice: they were very beautiful and almost of transparent delicacy.
6255: Romola’s disposition to rebel against command, doubly active in the
6256: presence of monks, whom she had been taught to despise, would have
6257: fixed itself on any repulsive detail as a point of support. But the
6258: face was hidden, and the hands seemed to have an appeal in them against
6259: all hardness. The next moment the right-hand took the crucifix to
6260: relieve the fatigued grasp of Fra Luca, and the left touched his lips
6261: with a wet sponge which lay near. In the act of bending, the cowl was
6262: pushed back, and the features of the monk had the full light of the
6263: tapers on them. They were very marked features, such as lend themselves
6264: to popular description. There was the high arched nose, the prominent
6265: under-lip, the coronet of thick dark hair above the brow, all seeming
6266: to tell of energy and passion; there were the blue-grey eyes, shining
6267: mildly under auburn eyelashes, seeming, like the hands, to tell of
6268: acute sensitiveness. Romola felt certain they were the features of Fra
6269: Girolamo Savonarola, the prior of San Marco, whom she had chiefly
6270: thought of as more offensive than other monks, because he was more
6271: noisy. Her rebellion was rising against the first impression, which had
6272: almost forced her to bend her knees.
6273: 
6274: “Kneel, my daughter,” the penetrating voice said again, “the pride of
6275: the body is a barrier against the gifts that purify the soul.”
6276: 
6277: He was looking at her with mild fixedness while he spoke, and again she
6278: felt that subtle mysterious influence of a personality by which it has
6279: been given to some rare men to move their fellows.
6280: 
6281: Slowly Romola fell on her knees, and in the very act a tremor came over
6282: her; in the renunciation of her proud erectness, her mental attitude
6283: seemed changed, and she found herself in a new state of passiveness.
6284: Her brother began to speak again—
6285: 
6286: “Romola, in the deep night, as I lay awake, I saw my father’s room—the
6287: library—with all the books and the marbles and the leggio, where I used
6288: to stand and read; and I saw you—you were revealed to me as I see you
6289: now, with fair long hair, sitting before my father’s chair. And at the
6290: leggio stood a man whose face I could not see. I looked, and looked,
6291: and it was a blank to me, even as a painting effaced; and I saw him
6292: move and take thee, Romola, by the hand; and then I saw thee take my
6293: father by the hand; and you all three went down the stone steps into
6294: the streets, the man whose face was a blank to me leading the way. And
6295: you stood at the altar in Santa Croce, and the priest who married you
6296: had the face of death; and the graves opened, and the dead in their
6297: shrouds rose and followed you like a bridal train. And you passed on
6298: through the streets and the gates into the valley, and it seemed to me
6299: that he who led you hurried you more than you could bear, and the dead
6300: were weary of following you, and turned back to their graves. And at
6301: last you came to a stony place where there was no water, and no trees
6302: or herbage; but instead of water, I saw written parchment unrolling
6303: itself everywhere, and instead of trees and herbage I saw men of bronze
6304: and marble springing up and crowding round you. And my father was faint
6305: for want of water and fell to the ground; and the man whose face was a
6306: blank loosed thy hand and departed: and as he went I could see his
6307: face; and it was the face of the Great Tempter. And thou, Romola, didst
6308: wring thy hands and seek for water, and there was none. And the bronze
6309: and marble figures seemed to mock thee and hold out cups of water, and
6310: when thou didst grasp them and put them to my father’s lips, they
6311: turned to parchment. And the bronze and marble figures seemed to turn
6312: into demons and snatch my father’s body from thee, and the parchments
6313: shrivelled up, and blood ran everywhere instead of them, and fire upon
6314: the blood, till they all vanished, and the plain was bare and stony
6315: again, and thou wast alone in the midst of it. And then it seemed that
6316: the night fell and I saw no more... Thrice I have had that vision,
6317: Romola. I believe it is a revelation meant for thee: to warn thee
6318: against marriage as a temptation of the enemy; it calls upon thee to
6319: dedicate thyself—”
6320: 
6321: His pauses had gradually become longer and more frequent, and he was
6322: now compelled to cease by a severe fit of gasping, in which his eyes
6323: were turned on the crucifix as on a light that was vanishing. Presently
6324: he found strength to speak again, but in a feebler, scarcely audible
6325: tone.
6326: 
6327: “To renounce the vain philosophy and corrupt thoughts of the heathens:
6328: for in the hour of sorrow and death their pride will turn to mockery,
6329: and the unclean gods will—”
6330: 
6331: The words died away.
6332: 
6333: In spite of the thought that was at work in Romola, telling her that
6334: this vision was no more than a dream, fed by youthful memories and
6335: ideal convictions, a strange awe had come over her. Her mind was not
6336: apt to be assailed by sickly fancies; she had the vivid intellect and
6337: the healthy human passion, which are too keenly alive to the constant
6338: relations of things to have any morbid craving after the exceptional.
6339: Still the images of the vision she despised jarred and distressed her
6340: like painful and cruel cries. And it was the first time she had
6341: witnessed the struggle with approaching death: her young life had been
6342: sombre, but she had known nothing of the utmost human needs; no acute
6343: suffering—no heart-cutting sorrow; and this brother, come back to her
6344: in his hour of supreme agony, was like a sudden awful apparition from
6345: an invisible world. The pale faces of sorrow in the fresco on the
6346: opposite wall seemed to have come nearer, and to make one company with
6347: the pale face on the bed.
6348: 
6349: “Frate,” said the dying voice.
6350: 
6351: Fra Girolamo leaned down. But no other word came for some moments.
6352: 
6353: “Romola,” it said next.
6354: 
6355: She leaned forward too: but again there was silence. The words were
6356: struggling in vain.
6357: 
6358: “Fra Girolamo, give her—”
6359: 
6360: “The crucifix,” said the voice of Fra Girolamo.
6361: 
6362: No other sound came from the dying lips.
6363: 
6364: “Dino!” said Romola, with a low but piercing cry, as the certainty came
6365: upon her that the silence of misunderstanding could never be broken.
6366: 
6367: “Take the crucifix, my daughter,” said Fra Girolamo, after a few
6368: minutes. “His eyes behold it no more.”
6369: 
6370: Romola stretched out her hand to the crucifix, and this act appeared to
6371: relieve the tension of her mind. A great sob burst from her. She bowed
6372: her head by the side of her dead brother, and wept aloud.
6373: 
6374: It seemed to her as if this first vision of death must alter the
6375: daylight for her for evermore.
6376: 
6377: Fra Girolamo moved towards the door, and called in a lay Brother who
6378: was waiting outside. Then he went up to Romola and said in a tone of
6379: gentle command, “Rise, my daughter, and be comforted. Our brother is
6380: with the blessed. He has left you the crucifix, in remembrance of the
6381: heavenly warning—that it may be a beacon to you in the darkness.”
6382: 
6383: She rose from her knees, trembling, folded her veil over her head, and
6384: hid the crucifix under her mantle. Fra Girolamo then led the way out
6385: into the cloistered court, lit now only by the stars and by a lantern
6386: which was held by some one near the entrance. Several other figures in
6387: the dress of the dignified laity were grouped about the same spot. They
6388: were some of the numerous frequenters of San Marco, who had come to
6389: visit the Prior, and having heard that he was in attendance on the
6390: dying Brother in the chapter-house, had awaited him here.
6391: 
6392: Romola was dimly conscious of footsteps and rustling forms moving
6393: aside: she heard the voice of Fra Girolamo saying, in a low tone, “Our
6394: brother is departed;” she felt a hand laid on her arm. The next moment
6395: the door was opened, and she was out in the wide piazza of San Marco,
6396: with no one but Monna Brigida, and the servant carrying the lantern.
6397: 
6398: The fresh sense of space revived her, and helped her to recover her
6399: self-mastery. The scene which had just closed upon her was terribly
6400: distinct and vivid, but it began to narrow under the returning
6401: impressions of the life that lay outside it. She hastened her steps,
6402: with nervous anxiety to be again with her father—and with Tito—for were
6403: they not together in her absence? The images of that vision, while they
6404: clung about her like a hideous dream not yet to be shaken off, made her
6405: yearn all the more for the beloved faces and voices that would assure
6406: her of her waking life.
6407: 
6408: Tito, we know, was not with Bardo; his destiny was being shaped by a
6409: guilty consciousness, urging on him the despairing belief that by this
6410: time Romola possessed the knowledge which would lead to their final
6411: separation.
6412: 
6413: And the lips that could have conveyed that knowledge were for ever
6414: closed. The prevision that Fra Luca’s words had imparted to Romola had
6415: been such as comes from the shadowy region where human souls seek
6416: wisdom apart from the human sympathies which are the very life and
6417: substance of our wisdom; the revelation that might have come from the
6418: simple questions of filial and brotherly affection had been carried
6419: into irrevocable silence.
6420: 
6421: 
6422: 
6423: 
6424: CHAPTER XVI.
6425: A Florentine Joke.
6426: 
6427: 
6428: Early the next morning Tito was returning from Bratti’s shop in the
6429: narrow thoroughfare of the Ferravecchi. The Genoese stranger had
6430: carried away the onyx ring, and Tito was carrying away fifty florins.
6431: It did just cross his mind that if, after all, Fortune, by one of her
6432: able devices, saved him from the necessity of quitting Florence, it
6433: would be better for him not to have parted with his ring, since he had
6434: been understood to wear it for the sake of peculiar memories and
6435: predilections; still, it was a slight matter, not worth dwelling on
6436: with any emphasis, and in those moments he had lost his confidence in
6437: fortune. The feverish excitement of the first alarm which had impelled
6438: his mind to travel into the future had given place to a dull, regretful
6439: lassitude. He cared so much for the pleasures that could only come to
6440: him through the good opinion of his fellow-men, that he wished now he
6441: had never risked ignominy by shrinking from what his fellow-men called
6442: obligations.
6443: 
6444: But our deeds are like children that are born to us; they live and act
6445: apart from our own will. Nay, children may be strangled, but deeds
6446: never: they have an indestructible life both in and out of our
6447: consciousness; and that dreadful vitality of deeds was pressing hard on
6448: Tito for the first time.
6449: 
6450: He was going back to his lodgings in the Piazza di San Giovanni, but he
6451: avoided passing through the Mercato Vecchio, which was his nearest way,
6452: lest he should see Tessa. He was not in the humour to seek anything; he
6453: could only await the first sign of his altering lot.
6454: 
6455: The piazza with its sights of beauty was lit up by that warm morning
6456: sunlight under which the autumn dew still lingers, and which invites to
6457: an idleness undulled by fatigue. It was a festival morning, too, when
6458: the soft warmth seems to steal over one with a special invitation to
6459: lounge and gaze. Here, too, the signs of the fair were present; in the
6460: spaces round the octagonal baptistery, stalls were being spread with
6461: fruit and flowers, and here and there laden mules were standing quietly
6462: absorbed in their nose-bags, while their drivers were perhaps gone
6463: through the hospitable sacred doors to kneel before the blessed Virgin
6464: on this morning of her Nativity. On the broad marble steps of the Duomo
6465: there were scattered groups of beggars and gossiping talkers: here an
6466: old crone with white hair and hard sunburnt face encouraging a
6467: round-capped baby to try its tiny bare feet on the warmed marble, while
6468: a dog sitting near snuffed at the performance suspiciously; there a
6469: couple of shaggy-headed boys leaning to watch a small pale cripple who
6470: was cutting a face on a cherry-stone; and above them on the wide
6471: platform men were making changing knots in laughing desultory chat, or
6472: else were standing in close couples gesticulating eagerly.
6473: 
6474: But the largest and most important company of loungers was that towards
6475: which Tito had to direct his steps. It was the busiest time of the day
6476: with Nello, and in this warm season and at an hour when clients were
6477: numerous, most men preferred being shaved under the pretty red and
6478: white awning in front of the shop rather than within narrow walls. It
6479: is not a sublime attitude for a man, to sit with lathered chin thrown
6480: backward, and have his nose made a handle of; but to be shaved was a
6481: fashion of Florentine respectability, and it is astonishing how gravely
6482: men look at each other when they are all in the fashion. It was the
6483: hour of the day, too, when yesterday’s crop of gossip was freshest, and
6484: the barber’s tongue was always in its glory when his razor was busy;
6485: the deft activity of those two instruments seemed to be set going by a
6486: common spring. Tito foresaw that it would be impossible for him to
6487: escape being drawn into the circle; he must smile and retort, and look
6488: perfectly at his ease. Well! it was but the ordeal of swallowing bread
6489: and cheese pills after all. The man who let the mere anticipation of
6490: discovery choke him was simply a man of weak nerves.
6491: 
6492: But just at that time Tito felt a hand laid on his shoulder, and no
6493: amount of previous resolution could prevent the very unpleasant
6494: sensation with which that sudden touch jarred him. His face, as he
6495: turned it round, betrayed the inward shock; but the owner of the hand
6496: that seemed to have such evil magic in it broke into a light laugh. He
6497: was a young man about Tito’s own age, with keen features, small
6498: close-clipped head, and close-shaven lip and chin, giving the idea of a
6499: mind as little encumbered as possible with material that was not
6500: nervous. The keen eyes were bright with hope and friendliness, as so
6501: many other young eyes have been that have afterwards closed on the
6502: world in bitterness and disappointment; for at that time there were
6503: none but pleasant predictions about Niccolò Macchiavelli, as a young
6504: man of promise, who was expected to mend the broken fortunes of his
6505: ancient family.
6506: 
6507: “Why, Melema, what evil dream did you have last night, that you took my
6508: light grasp for that of a _sbirro_ or something worse?”
6509: 
6510: “Ah, Messer Niccolò!” said Tito, recovering himself immediately; “it
6511: must have been an extra amount of dulness in my veins this morning that
6512: shuddered at the approach of your wit. But the fact is, I have had a
6513: bad night.”
6514: 
6515: “That is unlucky, because you will be expected to shine without any
