6516: obstructing fog to-day in the Rucellai Gardens. I take it for granted
6517: you are to be there.”
6518: 
6519: “Messer Bernardo did me the honour to invite me,” said Tito; “but I
6520: shall be engaged elsewhere.”
6521: 
6522: “Ah! I remember, you are in love,” said Macchiavelli, with a shrug,
6523: “else you would never have such inconvenient engagements. Why, we are
6524: to eat a peacock and ortolans under the loggia among Bernardo
6525: Rucellai’s rare trees; there are to be the choicest spirits in Florence
6526: and the choicest wines. Only, as Piero de’ Medici is to be there, the
6527: choice spirits may happen to be swamped in the capping of impromptu
6528: verses. I hate that game; it is a device for the triumph of small wits,
6529: who are always inspired the most by the smallest occasions.”
6530: 
6531: “What is that you are saying about Piero de’ Medici and small wits,
6532: Messer Niccolò?” said Nello, whose light figure was at that moment
6533: predominating over the Herculean frame of Niccolò Caparra.
6534: 
6535: That famous worker in iron, whom we saw last with bared muscular arms
6536: and leathern apron in the Mercato Vecchio, was this morning dressed in
6537: holiday suit, and as he sat submissively while Nello skipped round him,
6538: lathered him, seized him by the nose, and scraped him with magical
6539: quickness, he looked much as a lion might if it had donned linen and
6540: tunic and was preparing to go into society.
6541: 
6542: “A private secretary will never rise in the world if he couples great
6543: and small in that way,” continued Nello. “When great men are not
6544: allowed to marry their sons and daughters as they like, small men must
6545: not expect to marry their words as they like. Have you heard the news
6546: Domenico Cennini, here, has been telling us?—that Pagolantonio Soderini
6547: has given Ser Piero da Bibbiena a box on the ear for setting on Piero
6548: de’ Medici to interfere with the marriage between young Tommaso
6549: Soderini and Fiammetta Strozzi, and is to be sent ambassador to Venice
6550: as a punishment?”
6551: 
6552: “I don’t know which I envy him most,” said Macchiavelli, “the offence
6553: or the punishment. The offence will make him the most popular man in
6554: all Florence, and the punishment will take him among the only people in
6555: Italy who have known how to manage their own affairs.”
6556: 
6557: “Yes, if Soderini stays long enough at Venice,” said Cennini, “he may
6558: chance to learn the Venetian fashion, and bring it home with him. The
6559: Soderini have been fast friends of the Medici, but what has happened is
6560: likely to open Pagolantonio’s eyes to the good of our old Florentine
6561: trick of choosing a new harness when the old one galls us; if we have
6562: not quite lost the trick in these last fifty years.”
6563: 
6564: “Not we,” said Niccolò Caparra, who was rejoicing in the free use of
6565: his lips again. “Eat eggs in Lent and the snow will melt. That’s what I
6566: say to our people when they get noisy over their cups at San Gallo, and
6567: talk of raising a _romor_ (insurrection): I say, never do you plan a
6568: _romor_; you may as well try to fill Arno with buckets. When there’s
6569: water enough Arno will be full, and that will not be till the torrent
6570: is ready.”
6571: 
6572: “Caparra, that oracular speech of yours is due to my excellent
6573: shaving,” said Nello. “You could never have made it with that dark rust
6574: on your chin. Ecco, Messer Domenico, I am ready for you now. By the
6575: way, my bel erudito,” continued Nello, as he saw Tito moving towards
6576: the door, “here has been old Maso seeking for you, but your nest was
6577: empty. He will come again presently. The old man looked mournful, and
6578: seemed in haste. I hope there is nothing wrong in the Via de’ Bardi.”
6579: 
6580: “Doubtless Messer Tito knows that Bardo’s son is dead,” said Cronaca,
6581: who had just come up.
6582: 
6583: Tito’s heart gave a leap—had the death happened before Romola saw him?
6584: 
6585: “No, I had not heard it,” he said, with no more discomposure than the
6586: occasion seemed to warrant, turning and leaning against the doorpost,
6587: as if he had given up his intention of going away. “I knew that his
6588: sister had gone to see him. Did he die before she arrived?”
6589: 
6590: “No,” said Cronaca; “I was in San Marco at the time, and saw her come
6591: out from the chapter-house with Fra Girolamo, who told us that the
6592: dying man’s breath had been preserved as by a miracle, that he might
6593: make a disclosure to his sister.”
6594: 
6595: Tito felt that his fate was decided. Again his mind rushed over all the
6596: circumstances of his departure from Florence, and he conceived a plan
6597: of getting back his money from Cennini before the disclosure had become
6598: public. If he once had his money he need not stay long in endurance of
6599: scorching looks and biting words. He would wait now, and go away with
6600: Cennini and get the money from him at once. With that project in his
6601: mind he stood motionless—his hands in his belt, his eyes fixed absently
6602: on the ground. Nello, glancing at him, felt sure that he was absorbed
6603: in anxiety about Romola, and thought him such a pretty image of
6604: self-forgetful sadness, that he just perceptibly pointed his razor at
6605: him, and gave a challenging look at Piero di Cosimo, whom he had never
6606: forgiven for his refusal to see any prognostics of character in his
6607: favourite’s handsome face. Piero, who was leaning against the other
6608: doorpost, close to Tito, shrugged his shoulders: the frequent
6609: recurrence of such challenges from Nello had changed the painter’s
6610: first declaration of neutrality into a positive inclination to believe
6611: ill of the much-praised Greek.
6612: 
6613: “So you have got your Fra Girolamo back again, Cronaca? I suppose we
6614: shall have him preaching again this next Advent,” said Nello.
6615: 
6616: “And not before there is need,” said Cronaca, gravely. “We have had the
6617: best testimony to his words since the last Quaresima; for even to the
6618: wicked wickedness has become a plague; and the ripeness of vice is
6619: turning to rottenness in the nostrils even of the vicious. There has
6620: not been a change since the Quaresima, either in Rome or at Florence,
6621: but has put a new seal on the Frate’s words—that the harvest of sin is
6622: ripe, and that God will reap it with a sword.”
6623: 
6624: “I hope he has had a new vision, however,” said Francesco Cei,
6625: sneeringly. “The old ones are somewhat stale. Can’t your Frate get a
6626: poet to help out his imagination for him?”
6627: 
6628: “He has no lack of poets about him,” said Cronaca, with quiet contempt,
6629: “but they are great poets and not little ones; so they are contented to
6630: be taught by him, and no more think the truth stale which God has given
6631: him to utter, than they think the light of the moon is stale. But
6632: perhaps certain high prelates and princes who dislike the Frate’s
6633: denunciations might be pleased to hear that, though Giovanni Pico, and
6634: Poliziano, and Marsilio Ficino, and most other men of mark in Florence,
6635: reverence Fra Girolamo, Messer Francesco Cei despises him.”
6636: 
6637: “Poliziano?” said Cei, with a scornful laugh. “Yes, doubtless he
6638: believes in your new Jonah; witness the fine orations he wrote for the
6639: envoys of Sienna, to tell Alexander the Sixth that the world and the
6640: Church were never so well off as since he became Pope.”
6641: 
6642: “Nay, Francesco,” said Macchiavelli, smiling, “a various scholar must
6643: have various opinions. And as for the Frate, whatever we may think of
6644: his saintliness, you judge his preaching too narrowly. The secret of
6645: oratory lies, not in saying new things, but in saying things with a
6646: certain power that moves the hearers—without which, as old Filelfo has
6647: said, your speaker deserves to be called, ‘non oratorem, sed aratorem.’
6648: And, according to that test, Fra Girolamo is a great orator.”
6649: 
6650: “That is true, Niccolò,” said Cennini, speaking from the shaving-chair,
6651: “but part of the secret lies in the prophetic visions. Our people—no
6652: offence to you, Cronaca—will run after anything in the shape of a
6653: prophet, especially if he prophesies terrors and tribulations.”
6654: 
6655: “Rather say, Cennini,” answered Cronaca, “that the chief secret lies in
6656: the Frate’s pure life and strong faith, which stamp him as a messenger
6657: of God.”
6658: 
6659: “I admit it—I admit it,” said Cennini, opening his palms, as he rose
6660: from the chair. “His life is spotless: no man has impeached it.”
6661: 
6662: “He is satisfied with the pleasant lust of arrogance,” Cei burst out,
6663: bitterly. “I can see it in that proud lip and satisfied eye of his. He
6664: hears the air filled with his own name—Fra Girolamo Savonarola, of
6665: Ferrara; the prophet, the saint, the mighty preacher, who frightens the
6666: very babies of Florence into laying down their wicked baubles.”
6667: 
6668: “Come, come, Francesco, you are out of humour with waiting,” said the
6669: conciliatory Nello. “Let me stop your mouth with a little lather. I
6670: must not have my friend Cronaca made angry: I have a regard for his
6671: chin; and his chin is in no respect altered since he became a Piagnone.
6672: And for my own part, I confess, when the Frate was preaching in the
6673: Duomo last Advent, I got into such a trick of slipping in to listen to
6674: him that I might have turned Piagnone too, if I had not been hindered
6675: by the liberal nature of my art; and also by the length of the sermons,
6676: which are sometimes a good while before they get to the moving point.
6677: But, as Messer Niccolò here says, the Frate lays hold of the people by
6678: some power over and above his prophetic visions. Monks and nuns who
6679: prophesy are not of that rareness. For what says Luigi Pulci?
6680: ‘Dombruno’s sharp-cutting scimitar had the fame of being enchanted;
6681: but,’ says Luigi, ‘I am rather of opinion that it cut sharp because it
6682: was of strongly-tempered steel.’ Yes, yes; Paternosters may shave
6683: clean, but they must be said over a good razor.”
6684: 
6685: “See, Nello!” said Macchiavelli, “what doctor is this advancing on his
6686: Bucephalus? I thought your piazza was free from those furred and
6687: scarlet-robed lackeys of death. This man looks as if he had had some
6688: such night adventure as Boccaccio’s Maestro Simone, and had his bonnet
6689: and mantle pickled a little in the gutter; though he himself is as
6690: sleek as a miller’s rat.”
6691: 
6692: “A–ah!” said Nello, with a low long-drawn intonation, as he looked up
6693: towards the advancing figure—a round-headed, round-bodied personage,
6694: seated on a raw young horse, which held its nose out with an air of
6695: threatening obstinacy, and by a constant effort to back and go off in
6696: an oblique line showed free views about authority very much in advance
6697: of the age.
6698: 
6699: “And I have a few more adventures in pickle for him,” continued Nello,
6700: in an undertone, “which I hope will drive his inquiring nostrils to
6701: another quarter of the city. He’s a doctor from Padua; they say he has
6702: been at Prato for three months, and now he’s come to Florence to see
6703: what he can net. But his great trick is making rounds among the
6704: contadini. And do you note those great saddle-bags he carries? They are
6705: to hold the fat capons and eggs and meal he levies on silly clowns with
6706: whom coin is scarce. He vends his own secret medicines, so he keeps
6707: away from the doors of the druggists; and for this last week he has
6708: taken to sitting in my piazza for two or three hours every day, and
6709: making it a resort for asthmas and squalling bambini. It stirs my gall
6710: to see the toad-faced quack fingering the greasy quattrini, or bagging
6711: a pigeon in exchange for his pills and powders. But I’ll put a few
6712: thorns in his saddle, else I’m no Florentine. Laudamus! he is coming to
6713: be shaved; that’s what I’ve waited for. Messer Domenico, go not away:
6714: wait; you shall see a rare bit of fooling, which I devised two days
6715: ago. Here, Sandro!”
6716: 
6717: Nello whispered in the ear of Sandro, who rolled his solemn eyes,
6718: nodded, and, following up these signs of understanding with a slow
6719: smile, took to his heels with surprising rapidity.
6720: 
6721: “How is it with you, Maestro Tacco?” said Nello, as the doctor, with
6722: difficulty, brought his horse’s head round towards the barber’s shop.
6723: “That is a fine young horse of yours, but something raw in the mouth,
6724: eh?”
6725: 
6726: “He is an accursed beast, the _vermocane_ seize him!” said Maestro
6727: Tacco, with a burst of irritation, descending from his saddle and
6728: fastening the old bridle, mended with string, to an iron staple in the
6729: wall. “Nevertheless,” he added, recollecting himself, “a sound beast
6730: and a valuable, for one who wanted to purchase, and get a profit by
6731: training him. I had him cheap.”
6732: 
6733: “Rather too hard riding for a man who carries your weight of learning:
6734: eh, Maestro?” said Nello. “You seem hot.”
6735: 
6736: “Truly, I am likely to be hot,” said the doctor, taking off his bonnet,
6737: and giving to full view a bald low head and flat broad face, with high
6738: ears, wide lipless mouth, round eyes, and deep arched lines above the
6739: projecting eyebrows, which altogether made Nello’s epithet “toad-faced”
6740: dubiously complimentary to the blameless batrachian. “Riding from
6741: Peretola, when the sun is high, is not the same thing as kicking your
6742: heels on a bench in the shade, like your Florence doctors. Moreover, I
6743: have had not a little pulling to get through the carts and mules into
6744: the Mercato, to find out the husband of a certain Monna Ghita, who had
6745: had a fatal seizure before I was called in; and if it had not been that
6746: I had to demand my fees—”
6747: 
6748: “Monna Ghita!” said Nello, as the perspiring doctor interrupted himself
6749: to rub his head and face. “Peace be with her angry soul! The Mercato
6750: will want a whip the more if her tongue is laid to rest.”
6751: 
6752: Tito, who had roused himself from his abstraction, and was listening to
6753: the dialogue, felt a new rush of the vague half-formed ideas about
6754: Tessa, which had passed through his mind the evening before: if Monna
6755: Ghita were really taken out of the way, it would be easier for him to
6756: see Tessa again—whenever he wanted to see her.
6757: 
6758: “_Gnaffè_, Maestro,” Nello went on, in a sympathising tone, “you are
6759: the slave of rude mortals, who, but for you, would die like brutes,
6760: without help of pill or powder. It is pitiful to see your learned lymph
6761: oozing from your pores as if it were mere vulgar moisture. You think my
6762: shaving will cool and disencumber you? One moment and I have done with
6763: Messer Francesco here. It seems to me a thousand years till I wait upon
6764: a man who carries all the science of Arabia in his head and
6765: saddle-bags. Ecco!”
6766: 
6767: Nello held up the shaving-cloth with an air of invitation, and Maestro
6768: Tacco advanced and seated himself under a preoccupation with his heat
6769: and his self-importance, which made him quite deaf to the irony
6770: conveyed in Nello’s officiously polite speech.
6771: 
6772: “It is but fitting that a great medicus like you,” said Nello,
6773: adjusting the cloth, “should be shaved by the same razor that has
6774: shaved the illustrious Antonio Benevieni, the greatest master of the
6775: chirurgic art.”
6776: 
6777: “The chirurgic art!” interrupted the doctor, with an air of
6778: contemptuous disgust. “Is it your Florentine fashion to put the masters
6779: of the science of medicine on a level with men who do carpentry on
6780: broken limbs, and sew up wounds like tailors, and carve away
6781: excrescences as a butcher trims meat? _Via_! A manual art, such as any
6782: artificer might learn, and which has been practised by simple barbers
6783: like yourself—on a level with the noble science of Hippocrates, Galen,
6784: and Avicenna, which penetrates into the occult influences of the stars
6785: and plants and gems!—a science locked up from the vulgar!”
6786: 
6787: “No, in truth, Maestro,” said Nello, using his lather very
6788: deliberately, as if he wanted to prolong the operation to the utmost,
6789: “I never thought of placing them on a level: I know your science comes
6790: next to the miracles of Holy Church for mystery. But there, you see, is
6791: the pity of it,”—here Nello fell into a tone of regretful
6792: sympathy—“your high science is sealed from the profane and the vulgar,
6793: and so you become an object of envy and slander. I grieve to say it,
6794: but there are low fellows in this city—mere _sgherri_, who go about in
6795: nightcaps and long beards, and make it their business to sprinkle gall
6796: in every man’s broth who is prospering. Let me tell you—for you are a
6797: stranger—this is a city where every man had need carry a large nail
6798: ready to fasten on the wheel of Fortune when his side happens to be
6799: uppermost. Already there are stories—mere fables doubtless—beginning to
6800: be buzzed about concerning you, that make me wish I could hear of your
6801: being well on your way to Arezzo. I would not have a man of your metal
6802: stoned, for though San Stefano was stoned, he was not great in medicine
6803: like San Cosmo and San Damiano...”
6804: 
6805: “What stories? what fables?” stammered Maestro Tacco. “What do you
6806: mean?”
6807: 
6808: “_Lasso_! I fear me you are come into the trap for your cheese,
6809: Maestro. The fact is, there is a company of evil youths who go prowling
6810: about the houses of our citizens carrying sharp tools in their
6811: pockets;—no sort of door, or window, or shutter, but they will pierce
6812: it. They are possessed with a diabolical patience to watch the doings
6813: of people who fancy themselves private. It must be they who have done
6814: it—it must be they who have spread the stories about you and your
6815: medicines. Have you by chance detected any small aperture in your door,
6816: or window-shutter? No? Well, I advise you to look; for it is now
6817: commonly talked of that you have been seen in your dwelling at the
6818: Canto di Paglia, making your secret specifics by night: pounding dried
6819: toads in a mortar, compounding a salve out of mashed worms, and making
6820: your pills from the dried livers of rats which you mix with saliva
6821: emitted during the utterance of a blasphemous incantation—which indeed
6822: these witnesses profess to repeat.”
6823: 
6824: “It is a pack of lies!” exclaimed the doctor, struggling to get
6825: utterance, and then desisting in alarm at the approaching razor.
6826: 
6827: “It is not to me, or any of this respectable company, that you need to
6828: say that, doctor. _We_ are not the heads to plant such carrots as those
6829: in. But what of that? What are a handful of reasonable men against a
6830: crowd with stones in their hands? There are those among us who think
6831: Cecco d’Ascoli was an innocent sage—and we all know how he was burnt
6832: alive for being wiser than his fellows. Ah, doctor, it is not by living
6833: at Padua that you can learn to know Florentines. My belief is, they
6834: would stone the Holy Father himself, if they could find a good excuse
6835: for it; and they are persuaded that you are a necromancer, who is
6836: trying to raise the pestilence by selling secret medicines—and I am
6837: told your specifics have in truth an evil smell.”
6838: 
6839: “It is false!” burst out the doctor, as Nello moved away his razor; “it
6840: is false! I will show the pills and the powders to these honourable
6841: signori—and the salve—it has an excellent odour—an odour of—of salve.”
6842: He started up with the lather on his chin, and the cloth round his
6843: neck, to search in his saddle-bag for the belied medicines, and Nello
6844: in an instant adroitly shifted the shaving-chair till it was in the
6845: close vicinity of the horse’s head, while Sandro, who had now returned,
6846: at a sign from his master placed himself near the bridle.
6847: 
6848: “Behold, Messeri!” said the doctor, bringing a small box of medicines
6849: and opening it before them.
6850: 
6851: “Let any signor apply this box to his nostrils and he will find an
6852: honest odour of medicaments—not indeed of pounded gems, or rare
6853: vegetables from the East, or stones found in the bodies of birds; for I
6854: practise on the diseases of the vulgar, for whom heaven has provided
6855: cheaper and less powerful remedies according to their degree: and there
6856: are even remedies known to our science which are entirely free of
6857: cost—as the new _tussis_ may be counteracted in the poor, who can pay
6858: for no specifics, by a resolute holding of the breath. And here is a
6859: paste which is even of savoury odour, and is infallible against
6860: melancholia, being concocted under the conjunction of Jupiter and
6861: Venus; and I have seen it allay spasms.”
6862: 
6863: “Stay, Maestro,” said Nello, while the doctor had his lathered face
6864: turned towards the group near the door, eagerly holding out his box,
6865: and lifting out one specific after another; “here comes a crying
6866: contadina with her baby. Doubtless she is in search of you; it is
6867: perhaps an opportunity for you to show this honourable company a proof
6868: of your skill. Here, buona donna! here is the famous doctor. Why, what
6869: is the matter with the sweet _bimbo_?”
6870: 
6871: This question was addressed to a sturdy-looking, broad-shouldered
6872: contadina, with her head-drapery folded about her face so that little
6873: was to be seen but a bronzed nose and a pair of dark eyes and eyebrows.
6874: She carried her child packed up in the stiff mummy-shaped case in which
6875: Italian babies have been from time immemorial introduced into society,
6876: turning its face a little towards her bosom, and making those sorrowful
6877: grimaces which women are in the habit of using as a sort of pulleys to
6878: draw down reluctant tears.
6879: 
6880: “Oh, for the love of the Holy Madonna!” said the woman, in a wailing
6881: voice; “will you look at my poor bimbo? I know I can’t pay you for it,
6882: but I took it into the Nunziata last night, and it’s turned a worse
6883: colour than before; it’s the convulsions. But when I was holding it
6884: before the Santissima Nunziata, I remembered they said there was a new
6885: doctor come who cured everything; and so I thought it might be the will
6886: of the Holy Madonna that I should bring it to you.”
6887: 
6888: “Sit down, Maestro, sit down,” said Nello. “Here is an opportunity for
6889: you; here are honourable witnesses who will declare before the
6890: Magnificent Eight that they have seen you practising honestly and
6891: relieving a poor woman’s child. And then if your life is in danger, the
6892: Magnificent Eight will put you in prison a little while just to insure
6893: your safety, and after that, their sbirri will conduct you out of
6894: Florence by night, as they did the zealous Frate Minore who preached
6895: against the Jews. What! our people are given to stone-throwing; but we
6896: have magistrates.”
6897: 
6898: The doctor, unable to refuse, seated himself in the shaving-chair,
6899: trembling, half with fear and half with rage, and by this time quite
6900: unconscious of the lather which Nello had laid on with such
6901: profuseness. He deposited his medicine-case on his knees, took out his
6902: precious spectacles (wondrous Florentine device!) from his wallet,
6903: lodged them carefully above his flat nose and high ears, and lifting up
6904: his brows, turned towards the applicant.
6905: 
6906: “O Santiddio! look at him,” said the woman, with a more piteous wail
6907: than ever, as she held out the small mummy, which had its head
6908: completely concealed by dingy drapery wound round the head of the
6909: portable cradle, but seemed to be struggling and crying in a demoniacal
6910: fashion under this imprisonment. “The fit is on him! _Ohimè_! I know
6911: what colour he is; it’s the evil eye—oh!”
6912: 
6913: The doctor, anxiously holding his knees together to support his box,
6914: bent his spectacles towards the baby, and said cautiously, “It may be a
6915: new disease; unwind these rags, Monna!”
6916: 
6917: The contadina, with sudden energy, snatched off the encircling linen,
6918: when out struggled—scratching, grinning, and screaming—what the doctor
6919: in his fright fully believed to be a demon, but what Tito recognised as
6920: Vaiano’s monkey, made more formidable by an artificial blackness, such
6921: as might have come from a hasty rubbing up the chimney.
6922: 
6923: Up started the unfortunate doctor, letting his medicine-box fall, and
6924: away jumped the no less terrified and indignant monkey, finding the
6925: first resting-place for his claws on the horse’s mane, which he used as
6926: a sort of rope-ladder till he had fairly found his equilibrium, when he
6927: continued to clutch it as a bridle. The horse wanted no spur under such
6928: a rider, and, the already loosened bridle offering no resistance,
6929: darted off across the piazza, with the monkey, clutching, grinning, and
6930: blinking, on his neck.
6931: 
6932: “_Il cavallo! Il Diavolo_!” was now shouted on all sides by the idle
6933: rascals who gathered from all quarters of the piazza, and was echoed in
6934: tones of alarm by the stall-keepers, whose vested interests seemed in
6935: some danger; while the doctor, out of his wits with confused terror at
6936: the Devil, the possible stoning, and the escape of his horse, took to
6937: his heels with spectacles on nose, lathered face, and the shaving-cloth
6938: about his neck, crying—“Stop him! stop him! for a powder—a florin—stop
6939: him for a florin!” while the lads, outstripping him, clapped their
6940: hands and shouted encouragement to the runaway.
6941: 
6942: The _cerretano_, who had not bargained for the flight of his monkey
6943: along with the horse, had caught up his petticoats with much celerity,
6944: and showed a pair of parti-coloured hose above his contadina’s shoes,
6945: far in advance of the doctor. And away went the grotesque race up the
6946: Corso degli Adimari—the horse with the singular jockey, the contadina
6947: with the remarkable hose, and the doctor in lather and spectacles, with
6948: furred mantle outflying.
6949: 
6950: It was a scene such as Florentines loved, from the potent and reverend
6951: signor going to council in his lucco, down to the grinning youngster,
6952: who felt himself master of all situations when his bag was filled with
6953: smooth stones from the convenient dry bed of the torrent. The
6954: grey-headed Domenico Cennini laughed no less heartily than the younger
6955: men, and Nello was triumphantly secure of the general admiration.
6956: 
6957: “Aha!” he exclaimed, snapping his fingers when the first burst of
6958: laughter was subsiding. “I have cleared my piazza of that unsavoury
6959: fly-trap, _mi pare_. Maestro Tacco will no more come here again to sit
6960: for patients than he will take to licking marble for his dinner.”
6961: 
6962: “You are going towards the Piazza della Signoria, Messer Domenico,”
6963: said Macchiavelli. “I will go with you, and we shall perhaps see who
6964: has deserved the _palio_ among these racers. Come, Melema, will you go
6965: too?”
6966: 
6967: It had been precisely Tito’s intention to accompany Cennini, but before
6968: he had gone many steps, he was called back by Nello, who saw Maso
6969: approaching.
6970: 
6971: Maso’s message was from Romola. She wished Tito to go to the Via de’
6972: Bardi as soon as possible. She would see him under the loggia, at the
6973: top of the house, as she wished to speak to him alone.
6974: 
6975: 
6976: 
6977: 
6978: CHAPTER XVII.
6979: Under the Loggia.
6980: 
6981: 
6982: The loggia at the top of Bardo’s house rose above the buildings on each
6983: side of it, and formed a gallery round quadrangular walls. On the side
6984: towards the street the roof was supported by columns; but on the
6985: remaining sides, by a wall pierced with arched openings, so that at the
6986: back, looking over a crowd of irregular, poorly-built dwellings towards
6987: the hill of Bogoli, Romola could at all times have a walk sheltered
6988: from observation. Near one of those arched openings, close to the door
6989: by which he had entered the loggia, Tito awaited her, with a sickening
6990: sense of the sunlight that slanted before him and mingled itself with
6991: the ruin of his hopes. He had never for a moment relied on Romola’s
6992: passion for him as likely to be too strong for the repulsion created by
6993: the discovery of his secret; he had not the presumptuous vanity which
6994: might have hindered him from feeling that her love had the same root
6995: with her belief in him. But as he imagined her coming towards him in
6996: her radiant beauty, made so loveably mortal by her soft hazel eyes, he
6997: fell into wishing that she had been something lower, if it were only
6998: that she might let him clasp her and kiss her before they parted. He
6999: had had no real caress from her—nothing but now and then a long glance,
7000: a kiss, a pressure of the hand; and he had so often longed that they
7001: should be alone together. They were going to be alone now; but he saw
7002: her standing inexorably aloof from him. His heart gave a great throb as
7003: he saw the door move: Romola was there. It was all like a flash of
7004: lightning: he felt, rather than saw, the glory about her head, the
7005: tearful appealing eyes; he felt, rather than heard, the cry of love
7006: with which she said, “Tito!”
7007: 
7008: And in the same moment she was in his arms, and sobbing with her face
7009: against his.
7010: 
7011: How poor Romola had yearned through the watches of the night to see
7012: that bright face! The new image of death; the strange bewildering doubt
7013: infused into her by the story of a life removed from her understanding
7014: and sympathy; the haunting vision, which she seemed not only to hear
7015: uttered by the low gasping voice, but to live through, as if it had
7016: been her own dream, had made her more conscious than ever that it was
7017: Tito who had first brought the warm stream of hope and gladness into
7018: her life, and who had first turned away the keen edge of pain in the
7019: remembrance of her brother. She would tell Tito everything; there was
7020: no one else to whom she could tell it. She had been restraining herself
7021: in the presence of her father all the morning; but now, that
7022: long-pent-up sob might come forth. Proud and self-controlled to all the
7023: world beside, Romola was as simple and unreserved as a child in her
7024: love for Tito. She had been quite contented with the days when they had
7025: only looked at each other; but now, when she felt the need of clinging
7026: to him, there was no thought that hindered her.
7027: 
7028: “My Romola! my goddess!” Tito murmured with passionate fondness, as he
7029: clasped her gently, and kissed the thick golden ripples on her neck. He
7030: was in paradise: disgrace, shame, parting—there was no fear of them any
7031: longer. This happiness was too strong to be marred by the sense that
7032: Romola was deceived in him; nay, he could only rejoice in her delusion;
7033: for, after all, concealment had been wisdom. The only thing he could
7034: regret was his needless dread; if, indeed, the dread had not been worth
7035: suffering for the sake of this sudden rapture.
7036: 
7037: The sob had satisfied itself, and Romola raised her head. Neither of
7038: them spoke; they stood looking at each other’s faces with that sweet
7039: wonder which belongs to young love—she with her long white hands on the
7040: dark-brown curls, and he with his dark fingers bathed in the streaming
7041: gold. Each was so beautiful to the other; each was experiencing that
7042: undisturbed mutual consciousness for the first time. The cold pressure
7043: of a new sadness on Romola’s heart made her linger the more in that
7044: silent soothing sense of nearness and love; and Tito could not even
7045: seek to press his lips to hers, because that would be change.
7046: 
7047: “Tito,” she said at last, “it has been altogether painful, but I must
7048: tell you everything. Your strength will help me to resist the
7049: impressions that will not be shaken off by reason.”
7050: 
7051: “I know, Romola—I know he is dead,” said Tito; and the long lustrous
7052: eyes told nothing of the many wishes that would have brought about that
7053: death long ago if there had been such potency in mere wishes. Romola
7054: only read her own pure thoughts in their dark depths, as we read
7055: letters in happy dreams.
7056: 
7057: “So changed, Tito! It pierced me to think that it was Dino. And so
7058: strangely hard: not a word to my father; nothing but a vision that he
7059: wanted to tell me. And yet it was so piteous—the struggling breath, and
7060: the eyes that seemed to look towards the crucifix, and yet not to see
7061: it. I shall never forget it; it seems as if it would come between me
7062: and everything I shall look at.”
7063: 
7064: Romola’s heart swelled again, so that she was forced to break off. But
7065: the need she felt to disburden her mind to Tito urged her to repress
7066: the rising anguish. When she began to speak again, her thoughts had
7067: travelled a little.
7068: 
7069: “It was strange, Tito. The vision was about our marriage, and yet he
7070: knew nothing of you.”
7071: 
7072: “What was it, my Romola? Sit down and tell me,” said Tito, leading her
7073: to the bench that stood near. A fear had come across him lest the
7074: vision should somehow or other relate to Baldassarre; and this sudden
7075: change of feeling prompted him to seek a change of position.
7076: 
7077: Romola told him all that had passed, from her entrance into San Marco,
7078: hardly leaving out one of her brother’s words, which had burnt
7079: themselves into her memory as they were spoken. But when she was at the
7080: end of the vision, she paused; the rest came too vividly before her to
7081: be uttered, and she sat looking at the distance, almost unconscious for
7082: the moment that Tito was near her. _His_ mind was at ease now; that
7083: vague vision had passed over him like white mist, and left no mark. But
7084: he was silent, expecting her to speak again.
7085: 
7086: “I took it,” she went on, as if Tito had been reading her thoughts; “I
7087: took the crucifix; it is down below in my bedroom.”
7088: 
7089: “And now, my Romola,” said Tito, entreatingly, “you will banish these
7090: ghastly thoughts. The vision was an ordinary monkish vision, bred of
7091: fasting and fanatical ideas. It surely has no weight with you.”
7092: 
7093: “No, Tito; no. But poor Dino, _he_ believed it was a divine message. It
7094: is strange,” she went on meditatively, “this life of men possessed with
7095: fervid beliefs that seem like madness to their fellow-beings. Dino was
7096: not a vulgar fanatic; and that Fra Girolamo—his very voice seems to
7097: have penetrated me with a sense that there is some truth in what moves
7098: them: some truth of which I know nothing.”
7099: 
7100: “It was only because your feelings were highly wrought, my Romola. Your
7101: brother’s state of mind was no more than a form of that theosophy which
7102: has been the common disease of excitable dreamy minds in all ages; the
7103: same ideas that your father’s old antagonist, Marsilio Ficino, pores
7104: over in the New Platonists; only your brother’s passionate nature drove
7105: him to act out what other men write and talk about. And for Fra
7106: Girolamo, he is simply a narrow-minded monk, with a gift of preaching
7107: and infusing terror into the multitude. Any words or any voice would
7108: have shaken you at that moment. When your mind has had a little repose,
7109: you will judge of such things as you have always done before.”
7110: 
7111: “Not about poor Dino,” said Romola. “I was angry with him; my heart
7112: seemed to close against him while he was speaking; but since then I
7113: have thought less of what was in my own mind and more of what was in
7114: his. Oh, Tito! it was very piteous to see his young life coming to an
7115: end in that way. That yearning look at the crucifix when he was gasping
7116: for breath—I can never forget it. Last night I looked at the crucifix a
7117: long while, and tried to see that it would help him, until at last it
7118: seemed to me by the lamplight as if the suffering face shed pity.”
7119: 
7120: “My Romola, promise me to resist such thoughts; they are fit for sickly
7121: nuns, not for my golden-tressed Aurora, who looks made to scatter all
7122: such twilight fantasies. Try not to think of them now; we shall not
7123: long be alone together.”
7124: 
7125: The last words were uttered in a tone of tender beseeching, and he
7126: turned her face towards him with a gentle touch of his right-hand.
7127: 
7128: Romola had had her eyes fixed absently on the arched opening, but she
7129: had not seen the distant hill; she had all the while been in the
7130: chapter house, looking at the pale images of sorrow and death.
7131: 
7132: Tito’s touch and beseeching voice recalled her; and now in the warm
7133: sunlight she saw that rich dark beauty which seemed to gather round it
7134: all images of joy—purple vines festooned between the elms, the strong
7135: corn perfecting itself under the vibrating heat, bright winged
7136: creatures hurrying and resting among the flowers, round limbs beating
7137: the earth in gladness with cymbals held aloft, light melodies chanted
7138: to the thrilling rhythm of strings—all objects and all sounds that tell
7139: of Nature revelling in her force. Strange, bewildering transition from
7140: those pale images of sorrow and death to this bright youthfulness, as
7141: of a sun-god who knew nothing of night! What thought could reconcile
7142: that worn anguish in her brother’s face—that straining after something
7143: invisible—with this satisfied strength and beauty, and make it
7144: intelligible that they belonged to the same world? Or was there never
7145: any reconciling of them, but only a blind worship of clashing deities,
7146: first in mad joy and then in wailing? Romola for the first time felt
7147: this questioning need like a sudden uneasy dizziness and want of
7148: something to grasp; it was an experience hardly longer than a sigh, for
7149: the eager theorising of ages is compressed, as in a seed, in the
7150: momentary want of a single mind. But there was no answer to meet the
7151: need, and it vanished before the returning rush of young sympathy with
7152: the glad loving beauty that beamed upon her in new radiance, like the
7153: dawn after we have looked away from it to the grey west.
7154: 
7155: “Your mind lingers apart from our love, my Romola,” Tito said, with a
7156: soft reproachful murmur. “It seems a forgotten thing to you.”
7157: 
7158: She looked at the beseeching eyes in silence, till the sadness all
7159: melted out of her own.
7160: 
7161: “My joy!” she said, in her full clear voice.
7162: 
7163: “Do you really care for me enough, then, to banish those chill fancies,
7164: or shall you always be suspecting me as the Great Tempter?” said Tito,
7165: with his bright smile.
7166: 
7167: “How should I not care for you more than for everything else?
7168: Everything I had felt before in all my life—about my father, and about
7169: my loneliness—was a preparation to love you. You would laugh at me,
7170: Tito, if you knew what sort of man I used to think I should marry—some
7171: scholar with deep lines in his face, like Alamanno Rinuccini, and with
7172: rather grey hair, who would agree with my father in taking the side of
7173: the Aristotelians, and be willing to live with him. I used to think
7174: about the love I read of in the poets, but I never dreamed that
7175: anything like that could happen to me here in Florence in our old
7176: library. And then _you_ came, Tito, and were so much to my father, and
7177: I began to believe that life could be happy for me too.”
7178: 
7179: “My goddess! is there any woman like you?” said Tito, with a mixture of
7180: fondness and wondering admiration at the blended majesty and simplicity
7181: in her.
7182: 
7183: “But, dearest,” he went on, rather timidly, “if you minded more about
7184: our marriage, you would persuade your father and Messer Bernardo not to
7185: think of any more delays. But you seem not to mind about it.”
7186: 
7187: “Yes, Tito, I will, I do mind. But I am sure my godfather will urge
7188: more delay now, because of Dino’s death. He has never agreed with my
7189: father about disowning Dino, and you know he has always said that we
7190: ought to wait until you have been at least a year in Florence. Do not
7191: think hardly of my godfather. I know he is prejudiced and narrow, but
7192: yet he is very noble. He has often said that it is folly in my father
7193: to want to keep his library apart, that it may bear his name; yet he
7194: would try to get my father’s wish carried out. That seems to me very
7195: great and noble—that power of respecting a feeling which he does not
7196: share or understand.”
7197: 
7198: “I have no rancour against Messer Bernardo for thinking you too
7199: precious for me, my Romola,” said Tito: and that was true. “But your
7200: father, then, knows of his son’s death?”
7201: 
7202: “Yes, I told him—I could not help it. I told him where I had been, and
7203: that I had seen Dino die; but nothing else; and he has commanded me not
7204: to speak of it again. But he has been very silent this morning, and has
7205: had those restless movements which always go to my heart; they look as
7206: if he were trying to get outside the prison of his blindness. Let us go
7207: to him now. I had persuaded him to try to sleep, because he slept
7208: little in the night. Your voice will soothe him, Tito: it always does.”
7209: 
7210: “And not one kiss? I have not had one,” said Tito, in his gentle
7211: reproachful tone, which gave him an air of dependence very charming in
7212: a creature with those rare gifts that seem to excuse presumption.
7213: 
7214: The sweet pink blush spread itself with the quickness of light over
7215: Romola’s face and neck as she bent towards him. It seemed impossible
7216: that their kisses could ever become common things.
7217: 
7218: “Let us walk once round the loggia,” said Romola, “before we go down.”
7219: 
7220: “There is something grim and grave to me always about Florence,” said
7221: Tito, as they paused in the front of the house, where they could see
7222: over the opposite roofs to the other side of the river, “and even in
7223: its merriment there is something shrill and hard—biting rather than
7224: gay. I wish we lived in Southern Italy, where thought is broken, not by
7225: weariness, but by delicious languors such as never seem to come over
7226: the ‘ingenia acerrima Florentina.’ I should like to see you under that
7227: southern sun, lying among the flowers, subdued into mere enjoyment,
7228: while I bent over you and touched the lute and sang to you some little
7229: unconscious strain that seemed all one with the light and the warmth.
7230: You have never known that happiness of the nymphs, my Romola.”
7231: 
7232: “No; but I have dreamed of it often since you came. I am very thirsty
7233: for a deep draught of joy—for a life all bright like you. But we will
7234: not think of it now, Tito; it seems to me as if there would always be
7235: pale sad faces among the flowers, and eyes that look in vain. Let us
7236: go.”
7237: 
7238: 
7239: 
7240: 
7241: CHAPTER XVIII.
7242: The Portrait.
7243: 
7244: 
7245: When Tito left the Via de’ Bardi that day in exultant satisfaction at
7246: finding himself thoroughly free from the threatened peril, his
7247: thoughts, no longer claimed by the immediate presence of Romola and her
7248: father, recurred to those futile hours of dread in which he was
7249: conscious of having not only felt but acted as he would not have done
7250: if he had had a truer foresight. He would not have parted with his
7251: ring; for Romola, and others to whom it was a familiar object, would be
7252: a little struck with the apparent sordidness of parting with a gem he
7253: had professedly cherished, unless he feigned as a reason the desire to
7254: make some special gift with the purchase-money; and Tito had at that
7255: moment a nauseating weariness of simulation. He was well out of the
7256: possible consequences that might have fallen on him from that initial
7257: deception, and it was no longer a load on his mind; kind fortune had
7258: brought him immunity, and he thought it was only fair that she should.
7259: Who was hurt by it? The results to Baldassarre were too problematical
7260: to be taken into account. But he wanted now to be free from any hidden
7261: shackles that would gall him, though ever so little, under his ties to
7262: Romola. He was not aware that that very delight in immunity which
7263: prompted resolutions not to entangle himself again, was deadening the
7264: sensibilities which alone could save him from entanglement.
7265: 
7266: But, after all, the sale of the ring was a slight matter. Was it also a
7267: slight matter that little Tessa was under a delusion which would
7268: doubtless fill her small head with expectations doomed to
7269: disappointment? Should he try to see the little thing alone again and
7270: undeceive her at once, or should he leave the disclosure to time and
7271: chance? Happy dreams are pleasant, and they easily come to an end with
7272: daylight and the stir of life. The sweet, pouting, innocent, round
7273: thing! It was impossible not to think of her. Tito thought he should
7274: like some time to take her a present that would please her, and just
7275: learn if her step-father treated her more cruelly now her mother was
7276: dead. Or, should he at once undeceive Tessa, and then tell Romola about
7277: her, so that they might find some happier lot for the poor thing? No:
7278: that unfortunate little incident of the _cerretano_ and the marriage,
7279: and his allowing Tessa to part from him in delusion, must never be
7280: known to Romola, and since no enlightenment could expel it from Tessa’s
7281: mind, there would always be a risk of betrayal; besides even little
7282: Tessa might have some gall in her when she found herself disappointed
7283: in her love—yes, she _must_ be a little in love with him, and that
7284: might make it well that he should not see her again. Yet it was a
7285: trifling adventure such as a country girl would perhaps ponder on till
7286: some ruddy contadino made acceptable love to her, when she would break
7287: her resolution of secrecy and get at the truth that she was free.
7288: _Dunque_—good-bye, Tessa! kindest wishes! Tito had made up his mind
7289: that the silly little affair of the _cerretano_ should have no further
7290: consequences for himself; and people are apt to think that resolutions
7291: taken on their own behalf will be firm. As for the fifty-five florins,
7292: the purchase-money of the ring, Tito had made up his mind what to do
7293: with some of them; he would carry out a pretty ingenious thought which
7294: would set him more at ease in accounting for the absence of his ring to
7295: Romola, and would also serve him as a means of guarding her mind from
7296: the recurrence of those monkish fancies which were especially repugnant
7297: to him; and with this thought in his mind, he went to the Via Gualfonda
7298: to find Piero di Cosimo, the artist who at that time was pre-eminent in
7299: the fantastic mythological design which Tito’s purpose required.
7300: 
7301: Entering the court on which Piero’s dwelling opened, Tito found the
7302: heavy iron knocker on the door thickly bound round with wool and
7303: ingeniously fastened with cords. Remembering the painter’s practice of
7304: stuffing his ears against obtrusive noises, Tito was not much surprised
7305: at this mode of defence against visitors’ thunder, and betook himself
7306: first to tapping modestly with his knuckles, and then to a more
7307: importunate attempt to shake the door. In vain! Tito was moving away,
7308: blaming himself for wasting his time on this visit, instead of waiting
7309: till he saw the painter again at Nello’s, when a little girl entered
7310: the court with a basket of eggs on her arm, went up to the door, and
7311: standing on tiptoe, pushed up a small iron plate that ran in grooves,
7312: and putting her mouth to the aperture thus disclosed, called out in a
7313: piping voice, “Messer Piero!”
7314: 
7315: In a few moments Tito heard the sound of bolts, the door opened, and
7316: Piero presented himself in a red night-cap and a loose brown serge
7317: tunic, with sleeves rolled up to the shoulder. He darted a look of
7318: surprise at Tito, but without further notice of him stretched out his
7319: hand to take the basket from the child, re-entered the house, and
7320: presently returning with the empty basket, said, “How much to pay?”
7321: 
7322: “Two grossoni, Messer Piero; they are all ready boiled, my mother
7323: says.”
7324: 
7325: Piero took the coin out of the leathern scarsella at his belt, and the
7326: little maiden trotted away, not without a few upward glances of awed
7327: admiration at the surprising young signor.
7328: 
7329: Piero’s glance was much less complimentary as he said—
7330: 
7331: “What do you want at my door, Messer Greco? I saw you this morning at
7332: Nello’s; if you had asked me then, I could have told you that I see no
7333: man in this house without knowing his business and agreeing with him
7334: beforehand.”
7335: 
7336: “Pardon, Messer Piero,” said Tito, with his imperturbable good-humour;
7337: “I acted without sufficient reflection. I remembered nothing but your
7338: admirable skill in inventing pretty caprices, when a sudden desire for
7339: something of that sort prompted me to come to you.”
7340: 
7341: The painter’s manners were too notoriously odd to all the world for
7342: this reception to be held a special affront; but even if Tito had
7343: suspected any offensive intention, the impulse to resentment would have
7344: been less strong in him than the desire to conquer goodwill.
7345: 
7346: Piero made a grimace which was habitual with him when he was spoken to
7347: with flattering suavity. He grinned, stretched out the corners of his
7348: mouth, and pressed down his brows, so as to defy any divination of his
7349: feelings under that kind of stroking.
7350: 
7351: “And what may that need be?” he said, after a moment’s pause. In his
7352: heart he was tempted by the hinted opportunity of applying his
7353: invention.
7354: 
7355: “I want a very delicate miniature device taken from certain fables of
7356: the poets, which you will know how to combine for me. It must be
7357: painted on a wooden case—I will show you the size—in the form of a
7358: triptych. The inside may be simple gilding: it is on the outside I want
7359: the device. It is a favourite subject with you Florentines—the triumph
7360: of Bacchus and Ariadne; but I want it treated in a new way. A story in
7361: Ovid will give you the necessary hints. The young Bacchus must be
7362: seated in a ship, his head bound with clusters of grapes, and a spear
7363: entwined with vine-leaves in his hand: dark-berried ivy must wind about
7364: the masts and sails, the oars must be thyrsi, and flowers must wreathe
7365: themselves about the poop; leopards and tigers must be crouching before
7366: him, and dolphins must be sporting round. But I want to have the
7367: fair-haired Ariadne with him, made immortal with her golden crown—that
7368: is not in Ovid’s story, but no matter, you will conceive it all—and
7369: above there must be young Loves, such as you know how to paint,
7370: shooting with roses at the points of their arrows—”
7371: 
7372: “Say no more!” said Piero. “I have Ovid in the vulgar tongue. Find me
7373: the passage. I love not to be choked with other men’s thoughts. You may
7374: come in.”
7375: 
7376: Piero led the way through the first room, where a basket of eggs was
7377: deposited on the open hearth, near a heap of broken egg-shells and a
7378: bank of ashes. In strange keeping with that sordid litter, there was a
7379: low bedstead of carved ebony, covered carelessly with a piece of rich
7380: oriental carpet, that looked as if it had served to cover the steps to
7381: a Madonna’s throne; and a carved _cassone_, or large chest, with
7382: painted devices on its sides and lid. There was hardly any other
7383: furniture in the large room, except casts, wooden steps, easels and
7384: rough boxes, all festooned with cobwebs.
7385: 
7386: The next room was still larger, but it was also much more crowded.
7387: Apparently Piero was keeping the Festa, for the double door underneath
7388: the window which admitted the painter’s light from above, was thrown
7389: open, and showed a garden, or rather thicket, in which fig-trees and
7390: vines grew in tangled trailing wildness among nettles and hemlocks, and
7391: a tall cypress lifted its dark head from a stifling mass of yellowish
7392: mulberry-leaves. It seemed as if that dank luxuriance had begun to
7393: penetrate even within the walls of the wide and lofty room; for in one
7394: corner, amidst a confused heap of carved marble fragments and rusty
7395: armour, tufts of long grass and dark feathery fennel had made their
7396: way, and a large stone vase, tilted on one side, seemed to be pouring
7397: out the ivy that streamed around. All about the walls hung pen and
7398: oil-sketches of fantastic sea-monsters; dances of satyrs and maenads;
7399: Saint Margaret’s resurrection out of the devouring dragon; Madonnas
7400: with the supernal light upon them; studies of plants and grotesque
7401: heads; and on irregular rough shelves a few books were scattered among
7402: great drooping bunches of corn, bullocks’ horns, pieces of dried
7403: honeycomb, stones with patches of rare-coloured lichen, skulls and
7404: bones, peacocks’ feathers, and large birds’ wings. Rising from amongst
7405: the dirty litter of the floor were lay figures: one in the frock of a
7406: Vallombrosan monk, strangely surmounted by a helmet with barred visor,
7407: another smothered with brocade and skins hastily tossed over it.
7408: Amongst this heterogeneous still life, several speckled and white
7409: pigeons were perched or strutting, too tame to fly at the entrance of
7410: men; three corpulent toads were crawling in an intimate friendly way
7411: near the door-stone; and a white rabbit, apparently the model for that
7412: which was frightening Cupid in the picture of Mars and Venus placed on
7413: the central easel, was twitching its nose with much content on a box
7414: full of bran.
7415: 
7416: “And now, Messer Greco,” said Piero, making a sign to Tito that he
7417: might sit down on a low stool near the door, and then standing over him
7418: with folded arms, “don’t be trying to see everything at once, like
7419: Messer Domeneddio, but let me know how large you would have this same
7420: triptych.”
7421: 
7422: Tito indicated the required dimensions, and Piero marked them on a
7423: piece of paper.
7424: 
7425: “And now for the book,” said Piero, reaching down a manuscript volume.
7426: 
7427: “There’s nothing about the Ariadne there,” said Tito, giving him the
7428: passage; “but you will remember I want the crowned Ariadne by the side
7429: of the young Bacchus: she must have golden hair.”
7430: 
7431: “Ha!” said Piero, abruptly, pursing up his lips again. “And you want
7432: them to be likenesses, eh?” he added, looking down into Tito’s face.
7433: 
7434: Tito laughed and blushed. “I know you are great at portraits, Messer
7435: Piero; but I could not ask Ariadne to sit for you, because the painting
7436: is a secret.”
7437: 
7438: “There it is! I want her to sit to me. Giovanni Vespucci wants me to
7439: paint him a picture of Oedipus and Antigone at Colonos, as he has
7440: expounded it to me: I have a fancy for the subject, and I want Bardo
7441: and his daughter to sit for it. Now, you ask them; and then I’ll put
7442: the likeness into Ariadne.”
7443: 
7444: “Agreed, if I can prevail with them. And your price for the Bacchus and
7445: Ariadne?”
7446: 
7447: “_Baie_! If you get them to let me paint them, that will pay me. I’d
7448: rather not have your money: you may pay for the case.”
7449: 
7450: “And when shall I sit for you?” said Tito; “for if we have one
7451: likeness, we must have two.”
7452: 
7453: “I don’t want _your_ likeness; I’ve got it already,” said Piero, “only
7454: I’ve made you look frightened. I must take the fright out of it for
7455: Bacchus.”
7456: 
7457: As he was speaking, Piero laid down the book and went to look among
7458: some paintings, propped with their faces against the wall. He returned
7459: with an oil-sketch in his hand.
7460: 
7461: “I call this as good a bit of portrait as I ever did,” he said, looking
7462: at it as he advanced. “Yours is a face that expresses fear well,
7463: because it’s naturally a bright one. I noticed it the first time I saw
7464: you. The rest of the picture is hardly sketched; but I’ve painted _you_
7465: in thoroughly.”
7466: 
7467: Piero turned the sketch, and held it towards Tito’s eyes. He saw
7468: himself with his right-hand uplifted, holding a wine-cup, in the
7469: attitude of triumphant joy, but with his face turned away from the cup
7470: with an expression of such intense fear in the dilated eyes and pallid
7471: lips, that he felt a cold stream through his veins, as if he were being
7472: thrown into sympathy with his imaged self.
7473: 
7474: “You are beginning to look like it already,” said Piero, with a short
7475: laugh, moving the picture away again. “He’s seeing a ghost—that fine
7476: young man. I shall finish it some day, when I’ve settled what sort of
7477: ghost is the most terrible—whether it should look solid, like a dead
7478: man come to life, or half transparent, like a mist.”
7479: 
7480: Tito, rather ashamed of himself for a sudden sensitiveness strangely
7481: opposed to his usual easy self-command, said carelessly—
7482: 
7483: “That is a subject after your own heart, Messer Piero—a revel
7484: interrupted by a ghost. You seem to love the blending of the terrible
7485: with the gay. I suppose that is the reason your shelves are so well
7486: furnished with death’s-heads, while you are painting those roguish
7487: Loves who are running away with the armour of Mars. I begin to think
7488: you are a Cynic philosopher in the pleasant disguise of a cunning
7489: painter.”
7490: 
7491: “Not I, Messer Greco; a philosopher is the last sort of animal I should
7492: choose to resemble. I find it enough to live, without spinning lies to
7493: account for life. Fowls cackle, asses bray, women chatter, and
7494: philosophers spin false reasons—that’s the effect the sight of the
7495: world brings out of them. Well, I am an animal that paints instead of
7496: cackling, or braying, or spinning lies. And now, I think, our business
7497: is done; you’ll keep to your side of the bargain about the Oedipus and
7498: Antigone?”
7499: 
7500: “I will do my best,” said Tito—on this strong hint, immediately moving
7501: towards the door.
7502: 
7503: “And you’ll let me know at Nello’s. No need to come here again.”
7504: 
7505: “I understand,” said Tito, laughingly, lifting his hand in sign of
7506: friendly parting.
7507: 
7508: 
7509: 
7510: 
7511: CHAPTER XIX.
7512: The Old Man’s Hope.
7513: 
7514: 
7515: Messer Bernardo del Nero was as inexorable as Romola had expected in
7516: his advice that the marriage should be deferred till Easter, and in
7517: this matter Bardo was entirely under the ascendancy of his sagacious
7518: and practical friend. Nevertheless, Bernardo himself, though he was as
7519: far as ever from any susceptibility to the personal fascination in Tito
7520: which was felt by others, could not altogether resist that argument of
7521: success which is always powerful with men of the world. Tito was making
7522: his way rapidly in high quarters. He was especially growing in favour
7523: with the young Cardinal Giovanni de’ Medici, who had even spoken of
7524: Tito’s forming part of his learned retinue on an approaching journey to
7525: Rome; and the bright young Greek who had a tongue that was always ready
7526: without ever being quarrelsome, was more and more wished for at gay
7527: suppers in the Via Larga, and at Florentine games in which he had no
7528: pretension to excel, and could admire the incomparable skill of Piero
7529: de’ Medici in the most graceful manner in the world. By an unfailing
7530: sequence, Tito’s reputation as an agreeable companion in “magnificent”
7531: society made his learning and talent appear more lustrous: and he was
7532: really accomplished enough to prevent an exaggerated estimate from
7533: being hazardous to him. Messer Bernardo had old prejudices and
7534: attachments which now began to argue down the newer and feebler
7535: prejudice against the young Greek stranger who was rather too supple.
7536: To the old Florentine it was impossible to despise the recommendation
7537: of standing well with the best Florentine families, and since Tito
7538: began to be thoroughly received into that circle whose views were the
7539: unquestioned standard of social value, it seemed irrational not to
7540: admit that there was no longer any check to satisfaction in the
7541: prospect of such a son-in-law for Bardo, and such a husband for Romola.
7542: It was undeniable that Tito’s coming had been the dawn of a new life
7543: for both father and daughter, and the first promise had even been
7544: surpassed. The blind old scholar—whose proud truthfulness would never
7545: enter into that commerce of feigned and preposterous admiration which,
7546: varied by a corresponding measurelessness in vituperation, made the
7547: woof of all learned intercourse—had fallen into neglect even among his
7548: fellow-citizens, and when he was alluded to at all, it had long been
7549: usual to say that, though his blindness and the loss of his son were
7550: pitiable misfortunes, he was tiresome in contending for the value of
7551: his own labours; and that his discontent was a little inconsistent in a
7552: man who had been openly regardless of religious rites, and who in days
7553: past had refused offers made to him from various quarters, on the
7554: slight condition that he would take orders, without which it was not
7555: easy for patrons to provide for every scholar. But since Tito’s coming,
7556: there was no longer the same monotony in the thought that Bardo’s name
7557: suggested; the old man, it was understood, had left off his plaints,
7558: and the fair daughter was no longer to be shut up in dowerless pride,
7559: waiting for a _parentado_. The winning manners and growing favour of
7560: the handsome Greek who was expected to enter into the double relation
7561: of son and husband helped to make the new interest a thoroughly
7562: friendly one, and it was no longer a rare occurrence when a visitor
7563: enlivened the quiet library. Elderly men came from that indefinite
7564: prompting to renew former intercourse which arises when an old
7565: acquaintance begins to be newly talked about; and young men whom Tito
7566: had asked leave to bring once, found it easy to go again when they
7567: overtook him on his way to the Via de’ Bardi, and, resting their hands
7568: on his shoulder, fell into easy chat with him. For it was pleasant to
7569: look at Romola’s beauty; to see her, like old Firenzuola’s type of
7570: womanly majesty, “sitting with a certain grandeur, speaking with
7571: gravity, smiling with modesty, and casting around, as it were, an odour
7572: of queenliness;”[1] and she seemed to unfold like a strong white lily
7573: under this genial breath of admiration and homage; it was all one to
7574: her with her new bright life in Tito’s love.
7575: 
7576:  [1] “Quando una donna è grande, ben formata, porta ben sua persona,
7577:  siede con una certa grandezza, parla con gravità, ride con modestia, e
7578:  finalmente getta quasi un odor di Regina; allora noi diciamo quella
7579:  donna pare una maestà, ella ha una maestà.”—Firenzuola: _Della
7580:  Bellezza delle Donne_.
7581: 
7582: 
7583: Tito had even been the means of strengthening the hope in Bardo’s mind
7584: that he might before his death receive the longed-for security
7585: concerning his library: that it should not be merged in another
7586: collection; that it should not be transferred to a body of monks, and
7587: be called by the name of a monastery; but that it should remain for
7588: ever the Bardi Library, for the use of Florentines. For the old habit
7589: of trusting in the Medici could not die out while their influence was
7590: still the strongest lever in the State; and Tito, once possessing the
7591: ear of the Cardinal Giovanni de’ Medici, might do more even than Messer
7592: Bernardo towards winning the desired interest, for he could demonstrate
7593: to a learned audience the peculiar value of Bardi’s collection. Tito
7594: himself talked sanguinely of such a result, willing to cheer the old
7595: man, and conscious that Romola repaid those gentle words to her father
7596: with a sort of adoration that no direct tribute to herself could have
7597: won from her.
7598: 
7599: This question of the library was the subject of more than one
7600: discussion with Bernardo del Nero when Christmas was turned and the
7601: prospect of the marriage was becoming near—but always out of Bardo’s
7602: hearing. For Bardo nursed a vague belief, which they dared not disturb,
7603: that his property, apart from the library, was adequate to meet all
7604: demands. He would not even, except under a momentary pressure of angry
7605: despondency, admit to himself that the will by which he had
7606: disinherited Dino would leave Romola the heir of nothing but debts; or
7607: that he needed anything from patronage beyond the security that a
7608: separate locality should be assigned to his library, in return for a
7609: deed of gift by which he made it over to the Florentine Republic.
7610: 
7611: “My opinion is,” said Bernardo to Romola, in a consultation they had
7612: under the loggia, “that since you are to be married, and Messer Tito
7613: will have a competent income, we should begin to wind up the affairs,
7614: and ascertain exactly the sum that would be necessary to save the
7615: library from being touched, instead of letting the debts accumulate any
7616: longer. Your father needs nothing but his shred of mutton and his
7617: macaroni every day, and I think Messer Tito may engage to supply that
7618: for the years that remain; he can let it be in place of the
7619: _morgen-cap_.”
7620: 
7621: “Tito has always known that my life is bound up with my father’s,” said
7622: Romola; “and he is better to my father than I am: he delights in making
7623: him happy.”
7624: 
7625: “Ah, he’s not made of the same clay as other men, is he?” said
7626: Bernardo, smiling. “Thy father has thought of shutting woman’s folly
7627: out of thee by cramming thee with Greek and Latin; but thou hast been
7628: as ready to believe in the first pair of bright eyes and the first soft
7629: words that have come within reach of thee, as if thou couldst say
7630: nothing by heart but Paternosters, like other Christian men’s
7631: daughters.”
7632: 
7633: “Now, godfather,” said Romola, shaking her head playfully, “as if it
7634: were only bright eyes and soft words that made me love Tito! You know
7635: better. You know I love my father and you because you are both good,
7636: and I love Tito too because he is so good. I see it, I feel it, in
7637: everything he says and does. And if he is handsome, too, why should I
7638: not love him the better for that? It seems to me beauty is part of the
7639: finished language by which goodness speaks. You know _you_ must have
7640: been a very handsome youth, godfather,”—she looked up with one of her
7641: happy, loving smiles at the stately old man—“you were about as tall as
7642: Tito, and you had very fine eyes; only you looked a little sterner and
7643: prouder, and—”
7644: 
7645: “And Romola likes to have all the pride to herself?” said Bernardo, not
7646: inaccessible to this pretty coaxing. “However, it is well that in one
7647: way Tito’s demands are more modest than those of any Florentine husband
7648: of fitting rank that we should have been likely to find for you; he
7649: wants no dowry.”
7650: 
7651: So it was settled in that way between Messer Bernardo del Nero, Romola,
7652: and Tito. Bardo assented with a wave of the hand when Bernardo told him
7653: that he thought it would be well now to begin to sell property and
7654: clear off debts; being accustomed to think of debts and property as a
7655: sort of thick wood that his imagination never even penetrated, still
7656: less got beyond. And Tito set about winning Messer Bernardo’s respect
7657: by inquiring, with his ready faculty, into Florentine money-matters,
7658: the secrets of the _Monti_ or public funds, the values of real
7659: property, and the profits of banking.
7660: 
7661: “You will soon forget that Tito is not a Florentine, godfather,” said
7662: Romola. “See how he is learning everything about Florence.”
7663: 
7664: “It seems to me he is one of the _demoni_, who are of no particular
7665: country, child,” said Bernardo, smiling. “His mind is a little too
7666: nimble to be weighted with all the stuff we men carry about in our
7667: hearts.”
7668: 
7669: Romola smiled too, in happy confidence.
7670: 
7671: 
7672: 
7673: 
7674: CHAPTER XX.
7675: The Day of the Betrothal.
7676: 
7677: 
7678: It was the last week of the Carnival, and the streets of Florence were
7679: at their fullest and noisiest: there were the masqued processions,
7680: chanting songs, indispensable now they had once been introduced by
7681: Lorenzo the Magnificent; there was the favourite rigoletto, or round
7682: dance, footed “in piazza” under the blue frosty sky; there were
7683: practical jokes of all sorts, from throwing comfits to throwing
7684: stones—especially stones. For the boys and striplings, always a strong
7685: element in Florentine crowds, became at the height of Carnival-time as
7686: loud and unmanageable as tree-crickets, and it was their immemorial
7687: privilege to bar the way with poles to all passengers, until a tribute
7688: had been paid towards furnishing those lovers of strong sensations with
7689: suppers and bonfires: to conclude with the standing entertainment of
7690: stone-throwing, which was not entirely monotonous, since the consequent
7691: maiming was various, and it was not always a single person who was
7692: killed. So that the pleasures of the Carnival were of a checkered kind,
7693: and if a painter were called upon to represent them truly, he would
7694: have to make a picture in which there would be so much grossness and
7695: barbarity that it must be turned with its face to the wall, except when
7696: it was taken down for the grave historical purpose of justifying a
7697: reforming zeal which, in ignorance of the facts, might be unfairly
7698: condemned for its narrowness. Still there was much of that more
7699: innocent picturesque merriment which is never wanting among a people
7700: with quick animal spirits and sensitive organs: there was not the heavy
7701: sottishness which belongs to the thicker northern blood, nor the
7702: stealthy fierceness which in the more southern regions of the peninsula
7703: makes the brawl lead to the dagger-thrust.
7704: 
7705: It was the high morning, but the merry spirits of the Carnival were
7706: still inclined to lounge and recapitulate the last night’s jests, when
7707: Tito Melema was walking at a brisk pace on the way to the Via de’
7708: Bardi. Young Bernardo Dovizi, who now looks at us out of Raphael’s
7709: portrait as the keen-eyed Cardinal da Bibbiena, was with him; and, as
7710: they went, they held animated talk about some subject that had
7711: evidently no relation to the sights and sounds through which they were
7712: pushing their way along the Por’ Santa Maria. Nevertheless, as they
7713: discussed, smiled, and gesticulated, they both, from time to time, cast
7714: quick glances around them, and at the turning towards the Lung’ Arno,
7715: leading to the Ponte Rubaconte, Tito had become aware, in one of these
7716: rapid surveys, that there was some one not far off him by whom he very
7717: much desired not to be recognised at that moment. His time and thoughts
7718: were thoroughly preoccupied, for he was looking forward to a unique
7719: occasion in his life: he was preparing for his betrothal, which was to
7720: take place on the evening of this very day. The ceremony had been
7721: resolved upon rather suddenly; for although preparations towards the
7722: marriage had been going forward for some time—chiefly in the
7723: application of Tito’s florins to the fitting up of rooms in Bardo’s
7724: dwelling, which, the library excepted, had always been scantily
7725: furnished—it had been intended to defer both the betrothal and the
7726: marriage until after Easter, when Tito’s year of probation, insisted on
7727: by Bernardo del Nero, would have been complete. But when an express
7728: proposition had come, that Tito should follow the Cardinal Giovanni to
7729: Rome to help Bernardo Dovizi with his superior knowledge of Greek in
7730: arranging a library, and there was no possibility of declining what lay
7731: so plainly on the road to advancement, he had become urgent in his
7732: entreaties that the betrothal might take place before his departure:
7733: there would be the less delay before the marriage on his return, and it
7734: would be less painful to part if he and Romola were outwardly as well
7735: as inwardly pledged to each other—if he had a claim which defied Messer
7736: Bernardo or any one else to nullify it. For the betrothal, at which
7737: rings were exchanged and mutual contracts were signed, made more than
7738: half the legality of marriage, to be completed on a separate occasion
7739: by the nuptial benediction. Romola’s feeling had met Tito’s in this
7740: wish, and the consent of the elders had been won.
7741: 
7742: And now Tito was hastening, amidst arrangements for his departure the
7743: next day, to snatch a morning visit to Romola, to say and hear any last
7744: words that were needful to be said before their meeting for the
7745: betrothal in the evening. It was not a time when any recognition could
7746: be pleasant that was at all likely to detain him; still less a
7747: recognition by Tessa. And it was unmistakably Tessa whom he had caught
7748: sight of moving along, with a timid and forlorn look, towards that very
7749: turn of the Lung’ Arno which he was just rounding. As he continued his
7750: talk with the young Dovizi, he had an uncomfortable undercurrent of
7751: consciousness which told him that Tessa had seen him and would
7752: certainly follow him: there was no escaping her along this direct road
7753: by the Arno, and over the Ponte Rubaconte. But she would not dare to
7754: speak to him or approach him while he was not alone, and he would
7755: continue to keep Dovizi with him till they reached Bardo’s door. He
7756: quickened his pace, and took up new threads of talk; but all the while
7757: the sense that Tessa was behind him, though he had no physical evidence
7758: of the fact, grew stronger and stronger; it was very irritating—perhaps
7759: all the more so because a certain tenderness and pity for the poor
7760: little thing made the determination to escape without any visible
7761: notice of her, a not altogether agreeable resource. Yet Tito persevered
7762: and carried his companion to the door, cleverly managing his “addio”
7763: without turning his face in a direction where it was possible for him
7764: to see an importunate pair of blue eyes; and as he went up the stone
7765: steps, he tried to get rid of unpleasant thoughts by saying to himself
7766: that after all Tessa might not have seen him, or, if she had, might not
7767: have followed him.
7768: 
7769: But—perhaps because that possibility could not be relied on
7770: strongly—when the visit was over, he came out of the doorway with a
7771: quick step and an air of unconsciousness as to anything that might be
7772: on his right-hand or his left. Our eyes are so constructed, however,
7773: that they take in a wide angle without asking any leave of our will;
7774: and Tito knew that there was a little figure in a white hood standing
7775: near the doorway—knew it quite well, before he felt a hand laid on his
7776: arm. It was a real grasp, and not a light, timid touch; for poor Tessa,
7777: seeing his rapid step, had started forward with a desperate effort. But
7778: when he stopped and turned towards her, her face wore a frightened
7779: look, as if she dreaded the effect of her boldness.
7780: 
7781: “Tessa!” said Tito, with more sharpness in his voice than she had ever
7782: heard in it before. “Why are you here? You must not follow me—you must
7783: not stand about door-places waiting for me.”
7784: 
7785: Her blue eyes widened with tears, and she said nothing. Tito was afraid
7786: of something worse than ridicule, if he were seen in the Via de’ Bardi
7787: with a girlish contadina looking pathetically at him. It was a street
7788: of high silent-looking dwellings, not of traffic; but Bernardo del
7789: Nero, or some one almost as dangerous, might come up at any moment.
7790: Even if it had not been the day of his betrothal, the incident would
7791: have been awkward and annoying. Yet it would be brutal—it was
7792: impossible—to drive Tessa away with harsh words. That accursed folly of
7793: his with the _cerretano_—that it should have lain buried in a quiet way
7794: for months, and now start up before him as this unseasonable crop of
7795: vexation! He could not speak harshly, but he spoke hurriedly.
7796: 
7797: “Tessa, I cannot—must not talk to you here. I will go on to the bridge
7798: and wait for you there. Follow me slowly.”
7799: 
7800: He turned and walked fast to the Ponte Rubaconte, and there leaned
7801: against the wall of one of the quaint little houses that rise at even
7802: distances on the bridge, looking towards the way by which Tessa would
7803: come. It would have softened a much harder heart than Tito’s to see the
7804: little thing advancing with her round face much paled and saddened
7805: since he had parted from it at the door of the “Nunziata.” Happily it
7806: was the least frequented of the bridges, and there were scarcely any
7807: passengers on it at this moment. He lost no time in speaking as soon as
7808: she came near him.
7809:
