7810: “Now, Tessa, I have very little time. You must not cry. Why did you
7811: follow me this morning? You must not do so again.”
7812: 
7813: “I thought,” said Tessa, speaking in a whisper, and struggling against
7814: a sob that _would_ rise immediately at this new voice of Tito’s—“I
7815: thought you wouldn’t be so long before you came to take care of me
7816: again. And the _patrigno_ beats me, and I can’t bear it any longer. And
7817: always when I come for a holiday I walk about to find you, and I can’t.
7818: Oh, please don’t send me away from you again! It has been so long, and
7819: I cry so now, because you never come to me. I can’t help it, for the
7820: days are so long, and I don’t mind about the goats and kids, or
7821: anything—and I can’t—”
7822: 
7823: The sobs came fast now, and the great tears. Tito felt that he could
7824: not do otherwise than comfort her. Send her away—yes; that he _must_
7825: do, at once. But it was all the more impossible to tell her anything
7826: that would leave her in a state of hopeless grief. He saw new trouble
7827: in the background, but the difficulty of the moment was too pressing
7828: for him to weigh distant consequences.
7829: 
7830: “Tessa, my little one,” he said, in his old caressing tones, “you must
7831: not cry. Bear with the cross _patrigno_ a little longer. I will come
7832: back to you. But I’m going now to Rome—a long, long way off. I shall
7833: come back in a few weeks, and then I promise you to come and see you.
7834: Promise me to be good and wait for me.”
7835: 
7836: It was the well-remembered voice again, and the mere sound was half
7837: enough to soothe Tessa. She looked up at him with trusting eyes, that
7838: still glittered with tears, sobbing all the while, in spite of her
7839: utmost efforts to obey him. Again he said, in a gentle voice—
7840: 
7841: “Promise me, my Tessa.”
7842: 
7843: “Yes,” she whispered. “But you won’t be long?”
7844: 
7845: “No, not long. But I must _go now_. And remember what I told you,
7846: Tessa. Nobody must know that you ever see me, else you will lose me for
7847: ever. And now, when I have left you, go straight home, and never follow
7848: me again. Wait till I come to you. Good-bye, my little Tessa: I _will_
7849: come.”
7850: 
7851: There was no help for it; he must turn and leave her without looking
7852: behind him to see how she bore it, for he had no time to spare. When he
7853: did look round he was in the Via de’ Benci, where there was no seeing
7854: what was happening on the bridge; but Tessa was too trusting and
7855: obedient not to do just what he had told her.
7856: 
7857: Yes, the difficulty was at an end for that day; yet this return of
7858: Tessa to him, at a moment when it was impossible for him to put an end
7859: to all difficulty with her by undeceiving her, was an unpleasant
7860: incident to carry in his memory. But Tito’s mind was just now
7861: thoroughly penetrated with a hopeful first love, associated with all
7862: happy prospects flattering to his ambition; and that future necessity
7863: of grieving Tessa could be scarcely more to him than the far-off cry of
7864: some little suffering animal buried in the thicket, to a merry
7865: cavalcade in the sunny plain. When, for the second time that day, Tito
7866: was hastening across the Ponte Rubaconte, the thought of Tessa caused
7867: no perceptible diminution of his happiness. He was well muffled in his
7868: mantle, less, perhaps, to protect him from the cold than from the
7869: additional notice that would have been drawn upon him by his dainty
7870: apparel. He leaped up the stone steps by two at a time, and said
7871: hurriedly to Maso, who met him—
7872: 
7873: “Where is the damigella?”
7874: 
7875: “In the library; she is quite ready, and Monna Brigida and Messer
7876: Bernardo are already there with Ser Braccio, but none of the rest of
7877: the company.”
7878: 
7879: “Ask her to give me a few minutes alone; I will await her in the
7880: _salotto_.”
7881: 
7882: Tito entered a room which had been fitted up in the utmost contrast
7883: with the half-pallid, half-sombre tints of the library. The walls were
7884: brightly frescoed with “caprices” of nymphs and loves sporting under
7885: the blue among flowers and birds. The only furniture besides the red
7886: leather seats and the central table were two tall white vases, and a
7887: young faun playing the flute, modelled by a promising youth named
7888: Michelangelo Buonarotti. It was a room that gave a sense of being in
7889: the sunny open air.
7890: 
7891: Tito kept his mantle round him, and looked towards the door. It was not
7892: long before Romola entered, all white and gold, more than ever like a
7893: tall lily. Her white silk garment was bound by a golden girdle, which
7894: fell with large tassels; and above that was the rippling gold of her
7895: hair, surmounted by the white mist of her long veil, which was fastened
7896: on her brow by a band of pearls, the gift of Bernardo del Nero, and was
7897: now parted off her face so that it all floated backward.
7898: 
7899: “Regina mia!” said Tito, as he took her hand and kissed it, still
7900: keeping his mantle round him. He could not help going backward to look
7901: at her again, while she stood in calm delight, with that exquisite
7902: self-consciousness which rises under the gaze of admiring love.
7903: 
7904: “Romola, will you show me the next room now?” said Tito, checking
7905: himself with the remembrance that the time might be short. “You said I
7906: should see it when you had arranged everything.”
7907: 
7908: Without speaking, she led the way into a long narrow room, painted
7909: brightly like the other, but only with birds and flowers. The furniture
7910: in it was all old; there were old faded objects for feminine use or
7911: ornament, arranged in an open cabinet between the two narrow windows;
7912: above the cabinet was the portrait of Romola’s mother; and below this,
7913: on the top of the cabinet, stood the crucifix which Romola had brought
7914: from San Marco.
7915: 
7916: “I have brought something under my mantle,” said Tito, smiling; and
7917: throwing off the large loose garment, he showed the little tabernacle
7918: which had been painted by Piero di Cosimo. The painter had carried out
7919: Tito’s intention charmingly, and so far had atoned for his long delay.
7920: “Do you know what this is for, my Romola?” added Tito, taking her by
7921: the hand, and leading her towards the cabinet. “It is a little shrine,
7922: which is to hide away from you for ever that remembrancer of sadness.
7923: You have done with sadness now; and we will bury all images of it—bury
7924: them in a tomb of joy. See!”
7925: 
7926: A slight quiver passed across Romola’s face as Tito took hold of the
7927: crucifix. But she had no wish to prevent his purpose; on the contrary,
7928: she herself wished to subdue certain importunate memories and
7929: questionings which still flitted like unexplained shadows across her
7930: happier thought.
7931: 
7932: He opened the triptych and placed the crucifix within the central
7933: space; then closing it again, taking out the key, and setting the
7934: little tabernacle in the spot where the crucifix had stood, said—
7935: 
7936: “Now, Romola, look and see if you are satisfied with the portraits old
7937: Piero has made of us. Is it not a dainty device? and the credit of
7938: choosing it is mine.”
7939: 
7940: “Ah! it is you—it is perfect!” said Romola, looking with moist joyful
7941: eyes at the miniature Bacchus, with his purple clusters. “And I am
7942: Ariadne, and you are crowning me! Yes, it is true, Tito; you have
7943: crowned my poor life.”
7944: 
7945: They held each other’s hands while she spoke, and both looked at their
7946: imaged selves. But the reality was far more beautiful; she all
7947: lily-white and golden, and he with his dark glowing beauty above the
7948: purple red-bordered tunic.
7949: 
7950: “And it was our good strange Piero who painted it?” said Romola. “Did
7951: you put it into his head to paint me as Antigone, that he might have my
7952: likeness for this?”
7953: 
7954: “No, it was he who made my getting leave for him to paint you and your
7955: father, a condition of his doing this for me.”
7956: 
7957: “Ah! I see now what it was you gave up your precious ring for. I
7958: perceived you had some cunning plan to give me pleasure.”
7959: 
7960: Tito did not blench. Romola’s little illusions about himself had long
7961: ceased to cause him anything but satisfaction. He only smiled and said—
7962: 
7963: “I might have spared my ring; Piero will accept no money from me; he
7964: thinks himself paid by painting you. And now, while I am away, you will
7965: look every day at those pretty symbols of our life together—the ship on
7966: the calm sea, and the ivy that never withers, and those Loves that have
7967: left off wounding us and shower soft petals that are like our kisses;
7968: and the leopards and tigers, they are the troubles of your life that
7969: are all quelled now; and the strange sea-monsters, with their merry
7970: eyes—let us see—they are the dull passages in the heavy books, which
7971: have begun to be amusing since we have sat by each other.”
7972: 
7973: “Tito mio!” said Romola, in a half-laughing voice of love; “but you
7974: will give me the key?” she added, holding out her hand for it.
7975: 
7976: “Not at all!” said Tito, with playful decision, opening his scarsella
7977: and dropping in the little key. “I shall drown it in the Arno.”
7978: 
7979: “But if I ever wanted to look at the crucifix again?”
7980: 
7981: “Ah! for that very reason it is hidden—hidden by these images of youth
7982: and joy.”
7983: 
7984: He pressed a light kiss on her brow, and she said no more, ready to
7985: submit, like all strong souls, when she felt no valid reason for
7986: resistance.
7987: 
7988: And then they joined the waiting company, which made a dignified little
7989: procession as it passed along the Ponte Rubaconte towards Santa Croce.
7990: Slowly it passed, for Bardo, unaccustomed for years to leave his own
7991: house, walked with a more timid step than usual; and that slow pace
7992: suited well with the gouty dignity of Messer Bartolommeo Scala, who
7993: graced the occasion by his presence, along with his daughter
7994: Alessandra. It was customary to have very long troops of kindred and
7995: friends at the _sposalizio_, or betrothal, and it had even been found
7996: necessary in time past to limit the number by law to no more than _four
7997: hundred_—two hundred on each side; for since the guests were all
7998: feasted after this initial ceremony, as well as after the _nozze_, or
7999: marriage, the very first stage of matrimony had become a ruinous
8000: expense, as that scholarly Benedict, Leonardo Bruno, complained in his
8001: own case. But Bardo, who in his poverty had kept himself proudly free
8002: from any appearance of claiming the advantages attached to a powerful
8003: family name, would have no invitations given on the strength of mere
8004: friendship; and the modest procession of twenty that followed the
8005: _sposi_ were, with three or four exceptions, friends of Bardo’s and
8006: Tito’s selected on personal grounds.
8007: 
8008: Bernardo del Nero walked as a vanguard before Bardo, who was led on the
8009: right by Tito, while Romola held her father’s other hand. Bardo had
8010: himself been married at Santa Croce, and had insisted on Romola’s being
8011: betrothed and married there, rather than in the little church of Santa
8012: Lucia close by their house, because he had a complete mental vision of
8013: the grand church where he hoped that a burial might be granted him
8014: among the Florentines who had deserved well. Happily the way was short
8015: and direct, and lay aloof from the loudest riot of the Carnival, if
8016: only they could return before any dances or shows began in the great
8017: piazza of Santa Croce. The west was red as they passed the bridge, and
8018: shed a mellow light on the pretty procession, which had a touch of
8019: solemnity in the presence of the blind father. But when the ceremony
8020: was over, and Tito and Romola came out on to the broad steps of the
8021: church, with the golden links of destiny on their fingers, the evening
8022: had deepened into struggling starlight, and the servants had their
8023: torches lit.
8024: 
8025: While they came out, a strange dreary chant, as of a _Miserere_, met
8026: their ears, and they saw that at the extreme end of the piazza there
8027: seemed to be a stream of people impelled by something approaching from
8028: the Borgo de’ Greci.
8029: 
8030: “It is one of their masqued processions, I suppose,” said Tito, who was
8031: now alone with Romola, while Bernardo took charge of Bardo.
8032: 
8033: And as he spoke there came slowly into view, at a height far above the
8034: heads of the onlookers, a huge and ghastly image of Winged Time with
8035: his scythe and hour-glass, surrounded by his winged children, the
8036: Hours. He was mounted on a high car completely covered with black, and
8037: the bullocks that drew the car were also covered with black, their
8038: horns alone standing out white above the gloom; so that in the sombre
8039: shadow of the houses it seemed to those at a distance as if Time and
8040: his children were apparitions floating through the air. And behind them
8041: came what looked like a troop of the sheeted dead gliding above
8042: blackness. And as they glided slowly, they chanted in a wailing strain.
8043: 
8044: A cold horror seized on Romola, for at the first moment it seemed as if
8045: her brother’s vision, which could never be effaced from her mind, was
8046: being half fulfilled. She clung to Tito, who, divining what was in her
8047: thoughts, said—
8048: 
8049: “What dismal fooling sometimes pleases your Florentines! Doubtless this
8050: is an invention of Piero di Cosimo, who loves such grim merriment.”
8051: 
8052: “Tito, I wish it had not happened. It will deepen the images of that
8053: vision which I would fain be rid of.”
8054: 
8055: “Nay, Romola, you will look only at the images of our happiness now. I
8056: have locked all sadness away from you.”
8057: 
8058: “But it is still there—it is only hidden,” said Romola, in a low tone,
8059: hardly conscious that she spoke.
8060: 
8061: “See, they are all gone now!” said Tito. “You will forget this ghastly
8062: mummery when we are in the light, and can see each other’s eyes. My
8063: Ariadne must never look backward now—only forward to Easter, when she
8064: will triumph with her Care-dispeller.”
8065: 
8066: 
8067: 
8068: 
8069: CHAPTER XXI.
8070: Florence expects a Guest.
8071: 
8072: 
8073: It was the 17th of November 1494: more than eighteen months since Tito
8074: and Romola had been finally united in the joyous Easter time, and had
8075: had a rainbow-tinted shower of comfits thrown over them, after the
8076: ancient Greek fashion, in token that the heavens would shower sweets on
8077: them through all their double life.
8078: 
8079: Since that Easter a great change had come over the prospects of
8080: Florence; and as in the tree that bears a myriad of blossoms, each
8081: single bud with its fruit is dependent on the primary circulation of
8082: the sap, so the fortunes of Tito and Romola were dependent on certain
8083: grand political and social conditions which made an epoch in the
8084: history of Italy.
8085: 
8086: In this very November, little more than a week ago, the spirit of the
8087: old centuries seemed to have re-entered the breasts of Florentines. The
8088: great bell in the palace tower had rung out the hammer-sound of alarm,
8089: and the people had mustered with their rusty arms, their tools and
8090: impromptu cudgels, to drive out the Medici. The gate of San Gallo had
8091: been fairly shut on the arrogant, exasperating Piero, galloping away
8092: towards Bologna with his hired horsemen frightened behind him, and shut
8093: on his keener young brother, the cardinal, escaping in the disguise of
8094: a Franciscan monk: a price had been set on both their heads. After
8095: that, there had been some sacking of houses, according to old
8096: precedent; the ignominious images, painted on the public buildings, of
8097: the men who had conspired against the Medici in days gone by, were
8098: effaced; the exiled enemies of the Medici were invited home. The
8099: half-fledged tyrants were fairly out of their splendid nest in the Via
8100: Larga, and the Republic had recovered the use of its will again.
8101: 
8102: But now, a week later, the great palace in the Via Larga had been
8103: prepared for the reception of another tenant; and if drapery roofing
8104: the streets with unwonted colour, if banners and hangings pouring out
8105: of the windows, if carpets and tapestry stretched over all steps and
8106: pavement on which exceptional feet might tread, were an unquestionable
8107: proof of joy, Florence was very joyful in the expectation of its new
8108: guest. The stream of colour flowed from the palace in the Via Larga
8109: round by the Cathedral, then by the great Piazza della Signoria, and
8110: across the Ponte Vecchio to the Porta San Frediano—the gate that looks
8111: towards Pisa. There, near the gate, a platform and canopy had been
8112: erected for the Signoria; and Messer Luca Corsini, doctor of law, felt
8113: his heart palpitating a little with the sense that he had a Latin
8114: oration to read; and every chief elder in Florence had to make himself
8115: ready, with smooth chin and well-lined silk lucco, to walk in
8116: procession; and the well-born youths were looking at their rich new
8117: tunics after the French mode which was to impress the stranger as
8118: having a peculiar grace when worn by Florentines; and a large body of
8119: the clergy, from the archbishop in his effulgence to the train of
8120: monks, black, white, and grey, were consulting betimes in the morning
8121: how they should marshal themselves, with their burden of relics and
8122: sacred banners and consecrated jewels, that their movements might be
8123: adjusted to the expected arrival of the illustrious visitor, at three
8124: o’clock in the afternoon.
8125: 
8126: An unexampled visitor! For he had come through the passes of the Alps
8127: with such an army as Italy had not seen before: with thousands of
8128: terrible Swiss, well used to fight for love and hatred as well as for
8129: hire; with a host of gallant cavaliers proud of a name; with an
8130: unprecedented infantry, in which every man in a hundred carried an
8131: arquebus; nay, with cannon of bronze, shooting not stones but iron
8132: balls, drawn not by bullocks but by horses, and capable of firing a
8133: second time before a city could mend the breach made by the first ball.
8134: Some compared the new-comer to Charlemagne, reputed rebuilder of
8135: Florence, welcome conqueror of degenerate kings, regulator and
8136: benefactor of the Church; some preferred the comparison to Cyrus,
8137: liberator of the chosen people, restorer of the Temple. For he had come
8138: across the Alps with the most glorious projects: he was to march
8139: through Italy amidst the jubilees of a grateful and admiring people; he
8140: was to satisfy all conflicting complaints at Rome; he was to take
8141: possession, by virtue of hereditary right and a little fighting, of the
8142: kingdom of Naples; and from that convenient starting-point he was to
8143: set out on the conquest of the Turks, who were partly to be cut to
8144: pieces and partly converted to the faith of Christ. It was a scheme
8145: that seemed to befit the Most Christian King, head of a nation which,
8146: thanks to the devices of a subtle Louis the Eleventh who had died in
8147: much fright as to his personal prospects ten years before, had become
8148: the strongest of Christian monarchies; and this antitype of Cyrus and
8149: Charlemagne was no other than the son of that subtle Louis—the young
8150: Charles the Eighth of France.
8151: 
8152: Surely, on a general statement, hardly anything could seem more
8153: grandiose, or fitter to revive in the breasts of men the memory of
8154: great dispensations by which new strata had been laid in the history of
8155: mankind. And there was a very widely spread conviction that the advent
8156: of the French king and his army into Italy was one of those events at
8157: which marble statues might well be believed to perspire, phantasmal
8158: fiery warriors to fight in the air, and quadrupeds to bring forth
8159: monstrous births—that it did not belong to the usual order of
8160: Providence, but was in a peculiar sense the work of God. It was a
8161: conviction that rested less on the necessarily momentous character of a
8162: powerful foreign invasion than on certain moral emotions to which the
8163: aspect of the times gave the form of presentiments: emotions which had
8164: found a very remarkable utterance in the voice of a single man.
8165: 
8166: That man was Fra Girolamo Savonarola, Prior of the Dominican convent of
8167: San Marco in Florence. On a September morning, when men’s ears were
8168: ringing with the news that the French army had entered Italy, he had
8169: preached in the Cathedral of Florence from the text, “Behold I, even I,
8170: do bring a flood of waters upon the earth.” He believed it was by
8171: supreme guidance that he had reached just so far in his exposition of
8172: Genesis the previous Lent; and he believed the “flood of water”—emblem
8173: at once of avenging wrath and purifying mercy—to be the
8174: divinely—indicated symbol of the French army. His audience, some of
8175: whom were held to be among the choicest spirits of the age—the most
8176: cultivated men in the most cultivated of Italian cities—believed it
8177: too, and listened with shuddering awe. For this man had a power rarely
8178: paralleled, of impressing his beliefs on others, and of swaying very
8179: various minds. And as long as four years ago he had proclaimed from the
8180: chief pulpit of Florence that a scourge was about to descend on Italy,
8181: and that by this scourge the Church was to be purified. Savonarola
8182: appeared to believe, and his hearers more or less waveringly believed,
8183: that he had a mission like that of the Hebrew prophets, and that the
8184: Florentines amongst whom his message was delivered were in some sense a
8185: second chosen people. The idea of prophetic gifts was not a remote one
8186: in that age: seers of visions, circumstantial heralds of things to be,
8187: were far from uncommon either outside or inside the cloister; but this
8188: very fact made Savonarola stand out the more conspicuously as a grand
8189: exception. While in others the gift of prophecy was very much like a
8190: farthing candle illuminating small corners of human destiny with
8191: prophetic gossip, in Savonarola it was like a mighty beacon shining far
8192: out for the warning and guidance of men. And to some of the soberest
8193: minds the supernatural character of his insight into the future
8194: gathered a strong attestation from the peculiar conditions of the age.
8195: 
8196: At the close of 1492, the year in which Lorenzo de’ Medici died and
8197: Tito Melema came as a wanderer to Florence, Italy was enjoying a peace
8198: and prosperity unthreatened by any near and definite danger. There was
8199: no fear of famine, for the seasons had been plenteous in corn, and
8200: wine, and oil; new palaces had been rising in all fair cities, new
8201: villas on pleasant slopes and summits; and the men who had more than
8202: their share of these good things were in no fear of the larger number
8203: who had less. For the citizens’ armour was getting rusty, and
8204: populations seemed to have become tame, licking the hands of masters
8205: who paid for a ready-made army when they wanted it, as they paid for
8206: goods of Smyrna. Even the fear of the Turk had ceased to be active, and
8207: the Pope found it more immediately profitable to accept bribes from him
8208: for a little prospective poisoning than to form plans either for
8209: conquering or for converting him.
8210: 
8211: Altogether this world, with its partitioned empire and its roomy
8212: universal Church, seemed to be a handsome establishment for the few who
8213: were lucky or wise enough to reap the advantages of human folly: a
8214: world in which lust and obscenity, lying and treachery, oppression and
8215: murder, were pleasant, useful, and when properly managed, not
8216: dangerous. And as a sort of fringe or adornment to the substantial
8217: delights of tyranny, avarice, and lasciviousness, there was the
8218: patronage of polite learning and the fine arts, so that flattery could
8219: always be had in the choicest Latin to be commanded at that time, and
8220: sublime artists were at hand to paint the holy and the unclean with
8221: impartial skill. The Church, it was said, had never been so disgraced
8222: in its head, had never shown so few signs of renovating, vital belief
8223: in its lower members; nevertheless it was much more prosperous than in
8224: some past days. The heavens were fair and smiling above; and below
8225: there were no signs of earthquake.
8226: 
8227: Yet at that time, as we have seen, there was a man in Florence who for
8228: two years and more had been preaching that a scourge was at hand; that
8229: the world was certainly not framed for the lasting convenience of
8230: hypocrites, libertines, and oppressors. From the midst of those smiling
8231: heavens he had seen a sword hanging—the sword of God’s justice—which
8232: was speedily to descend with purifying punishment on the Church and the
8233: world. In brilliant Ferrara, seventeen years before, the contradiction
8234: between men’s lives and their professed beliefs had pressed upon him
8235: with a force that had been enough to destroy his appetite for the
8236: world, and at the age of twenty-three had driven him into the cloister.
8237: He believed that God had committed to the Church the sacred lamp of
8238: truth for the guidance and salvation of men, and he saw that the
8239: Church, in its corruption, had become a sepulchre to hide the lamp. As
8240: the years went on scandals increased and multiplied, and hypocrisy
8241: seemed to have given place to impudence. Had the world, then, ceased to
8242: have a righteous Ruler? Was the Church finally forsaken? No, assuredly:
8243: in the Sacred Book there was a record of the past in which might be
8244: seen as in a glass what would be in the days to come, and the book
8245: showed that when the wickedness of the chosen people, type of the
8246: Christian Church, had become crying, the judgments of God had descended
8247: on them. Nay, reason itself declared that vengeance was imminent, for
8248: what else would suffice to turn men from their obstinacy in evil? And
8249: unless the Church were reclaimed, how could the promises be fulfilled,
8250: that the heathens should be converted and the whole world become
8251: subject to the one true law? He had seen his belief reflected in
8252: visions—a mode of seeing which had been frequent with him from his
8253: youth up.
8254: 
8255: But the real force of demonstration for Girolamo Savonarola lay in his
8256: own burning indignation at the sight of wrong; in his fervent belief in
8257: an Unseen Justice that would put an end to the wrong, and in an Unseen
8258: Purity to which lying and uncleanness were an abomination. To his
8259: ardent, power-loving soul, believing in great ends, and longing to
8260: achieve those ends by the exertion of its own strong will, the faith in
8261: a supreme and righteous Ruler became one with the faith in a speedy
8262: divine interposition that would punish and reclaim.
8263: 
8264: Meanwhile, under that splendid masquerade of dignities sacred and
8265: secular which seemed to make the life of lucky Churchmen and princely
8266: families so luxurious and amusing, there were certain conditions at
8267: work which slowly tended to disturb the general festivity. Ludovico
8268: Sforza—copious in gallantry, splendid patron of an incomparable
8269: Leonardo da Vinci—holding the ducal crown of Milan in his grasp, and
8270: wanting to put it on his own head rather than let it rest on that of a
8271: feeble nephew who would take very little to poison him, was much afraid
8272: of the Spanish-born old King Ferdinand and the Crown Prince Alfonso of
8273: Naples, who, not liking cruelty and treachery which were useless to
8274: themselves, objected to the poisoning of a near relative for the
8275: advantage of a Lombard usurper; the royalties of Naples again were
8276: afraid of their suzerain, Pope Alexander Borgia; all three were
8277: anxiously watching Florence, lest with its midway territory it should
8278: determine the game by underhand backing; and all four, with every small
8279: state in Italy, were afraid of Venice—Venice the cautious, the stable,
8280: and the strong, that wanted to stretch its arms not only along both
8281: sides of the Adriatic but across to the ports of the western coast.
8282: 
8283: Lorenzo de’ Medici, it was thought, did much to prevent the fatal
8284: outbreak of such jealousies, keeping up the old Florentine alliance
8285: with Naples and the Pope, and yet persuading Milan that the alliance
8286: was for the general advantage. But young Piero de’ Medici’s rash vanity
8287: had quickly nullified the effect of his father’s wary policy, and
8288: Ludovico Sforza, roused to suspicion of a league against him, thought
8289: of a move which would checkmate his adversaries: he determined to
8290: invite the French king to march into Italy, and, as heir of the house
8291: of Anjou, take possession of Naples. Ambassadors—“orators,” as they
8292: were called in those haranguing times—went and came; a recusant
8293: cardinal, determined not to acknowledge a Pope elected by bribery (and
8294: his own particular enemy), went and came also, and seconded the
8295: invitation with hot rhetoric; and the young king seemed to lend a
8296: willing ear. So that in 1493 the rumour spread and became louder and
8297: louder that Charles the Eighth of France was about to cross the Alps
8298: with a mighty army; and the Italian populations, accustomed, since
8299: Italy had ceased to be the heart of the Roman empire, to look for an
8300: arbitrator from afar, began vaguely to regard his coming as a means of
8301: avenging their wrongs and redressing their grievances.
8302: 
8303: And in that rumour Savonarola had heard the assurance that his prophecy
8304: was being verified. What was it that filled the ears of the prophets of
8305: old but the distant tread of foreign armies, coming to do the work of
8306: justice? He no longer looked vaguely to the horizon for the coming
8307: storm: he pointed to the rising cloud. The French army was that new
8308: deluge which was to purify the earth from iniquity; the French king,
8309: Charles the Eighth, was the instrument elected by God, as Cyrus had
8310: been of old, and all men who desired good rather than evil were to
8311: rejoice in his coming. For the scourge would fall destructively on the
8312: impenitent alone. Let any city of Italy, let Florence above
8313: all—Florence beloved of God, since to its ear the warning voice had
8314: been specially sent—repent and turn from its ways, like Nineveh of old,
8315: and the storm-cloud would roll over it and leave only refreshing
8316: raindrops.
8317: 
8318: Fra Girolamo’s word was powerful; yet now that the new Cyrus had
8319: already been three months in Italy, and was not far from the gates of
8320: Florence, his presence was expected there with mixed feelings, in which
8321: fear and distrust certainly predominated. At present it was not
8322: understood that he had redressed any grievances; and the Florentines
8323: clearly had nothing to thank him for. He held their strong frontier
8324: fortresses, which Piero de’ Medici had given up to him without securing
8325: any honourable terms in return; he had done nothing to quell the
8326: alarming revolt of Pisa, which had been encouraged by his presence to
8327: throw off the Florentine yoke; and “orators,” even with a prophet at
8328: their head, could win no assurance from him, except that he would
8329: settle everything when he was once within the walls of Florence. Still,
8330: there was the satisfaction of knowing that the exasperating Piero de’
8331: Medici had been fairly pelted out for the ignominious surrender of the
8332: fortresses, and in that act of energy the spirit of the Republic had
8333: recovered some of its old fire.
8334: 
8335: The preparations for the equivocal guest were not entirely those of a
8336: city resigned to submission. Behind the bright drapery and banners
8337: symbolical of joy, there were preparations of another sort made with
8338: common accord by government and people. Well hidden within walls there
8339: were hired soldiers of the Republic, hastily called in from the
8340: surrounding districts; there were old arms duly furbished, and sharp
8341: tools and heavy cudgels laid carefully at hand, to be snatched up on
8342: short notice; there were excellent boards and stakes to form barricades
8343: upon occasion, and a good supply of stones to make a surprising hail
8344: from the upper windows. Above all, there were people very strongly in
8345: the humour for fighting any personage who might be supposed to have
8346: designs of hectoring over them, they having lately tasted that new
8347: pleasure with much relish. This humour was not diminished by the sight
8348: of occasional parties of Frenchmen, coming beforehand to choose their
8349: quarters, with a hawk, perhaps, on their left wrist, and,
8350: metaphorically speaking, a piece of chalk in their right-hand to mark
8351: Italian doors withal; especially as creditable historians imply that
8352: many sons of France were at that time characterised by something
8353: approaching to a swagger, which must have whetted the Florentine
8354: appetite for a little stone-throwing.
8355: 
8356: And this was the temper of Florence on the morning of the 17th of
8357: November 1494.
8358: 
8359: 
8360: 
8361: 
8362: CHAPTER XXII.
8363: The Prisoners.
8364: 
8365: 
8366: The sky was grey, but that made little difference in the Piazza del
8367: Duomo, which was covered with its holiday sky of blue drapery, and its
8368: constellations of yellow lilies and coats of arms. The sheaves of
8369: banners were unfurled at the angles of the Baptistery, but there was no
8370: carpet yet on the steps of the Duomo, for the marble was being trodden
8371: by numerous feet that were not at all exceptional. It was the hour of
8372: the Advent sermons, and the very same reasons which had flushed the
8373: streets with holiday colour were reasons why the preaching in the Duomo
8374: could least of all be dispensed with.
8375: 
8376: But not all the feet in the Piazza were hastening towards the steps.
8377: People of high and low degree were moving to and fro with the brisk
8378: pace of men who had errands before them; groups of talkers were thickly
8379: scattered, some willing to be late for the sermon, and others content
8380: not to hear it at all.
8381: 
8382: The expression on the faces of these apparent loungers was not that of
8383: men who are enjoying the pleasant laziness of an opening holiday. Some
8384: were in close and eager discussion; others were listening with keen
8385: interest to a single spokesman, and yet from time to time turned round
8386: with a scanning glance at any new passer-by. At the corner, looking
8387: towards the Via de’ Cerretani—just where the artificial rainbow light
8388: of the Piazza ceased, and the grey morning fell on the sombre stone
8389: houses—there was a remarkable cluster of the working people, most of
8390: them bearing on their dress or persons the signs of their daily labour,
8391: and almost all of them carrying some weapon, or some tool which might
8392: serve as a weapon upon occasion. Standing in the grey light of the
8393: street, with bare brawny arms and soiled garments, they made all the
8394: more striking the transition from the brightness of the Piazza. They
8395: were listening to the thin notary, Ser Cioni, who had just paused on
8396: his way to the Duomo. His biting words could get only a contemptuous
8397: reception two years and a half before in the Mercato, but now he spoke
8398: with the more complacent humour of a man whose party is uppermost, and
8399: who is conscious of some influence with the people.
8400: 
8401: “Never talk to me,” he was saying, in his incisive voice, “never talk
8402: to me of bloodthirsty Swiss or fierce French infantry: they might as
8403: well be in the narrow passes of the mountains as in our streets; and
8404: peasants have destroyed the finest armies of our condottieri in time
8405: past, when they had once got them between steep precipices. I tell you,
8406: Florentines need be afraid of no army in their own streets.”
8407: 
8408: “That’s true, Ser Cioni,” said a man whose arms and hands were
8409: discoloured by crimson dye, which looked like blood-stains, and who had
8410: a small hatchet stuck in his belt; “and those French cavaliers, who
8411: came in squaring themselves in their smart doublets the other day, saw
8412: a sample of the dinner we could serve up for them. I was carrying my
8413: cloth in Ognissanti, when I saw my fine Messeri going by, looking round
8414: as if they thought the houses of the Vespucci and the Agli a poor pick
8415: of lodgings for them, and eyeing us Florentines, like top-knotted cocks
8416: as they are, as if they pitied us because we didn’t know how to strut.
8417: ‘Yes, my fine _Galli_,’ says I, ‘stick out your stomachs; I’ve got a
8418: meat-axe in my belt that will go inside you all the easier;’ when
8419: presently the old cow lowed,[1] and I knew something had happened—no
8420: matter what. So I threw my cloth in at the first doorway, and took hold
8421: of my meat-axe and ran after my fine cavaliers towards the Vigna Nuova.
8422: And, ‘What is it, Guccio?’ said I, when he came up with me. ‘I think
8423: it’s the Medici coming back,’ said Guccio. _Bembè_! I expected so! And
8424: up we reared a barricade, and the Frenchmen looked behind and saw
8425: themselves in a trap; and up comes a good swarm of our _Ciompi_[2] and
8426: one of them with a big scythe he had in his hand mowed off one of the
8427: fine cavalier’s feathers:—it’s true! And the lasses peppered a few
8428: stones down to frighten them. However, Piero de’ Medici wasn’t come
8429: after all; and it was a pity; for we’d have left him neither legs nor
8430: wings to go away with again.”
8431: 
8432:  [1] “_La vacca muglia_” was the phrase for the sounding of the great
8433:  bell in the tower of the Palazzo Vecchio.
8434: 
8435: 
8436:  [2] The poorer artisans connected with the wool trade—wool-beaters,
8437:  carders, washers, etcetera.
8438: 
8439: 
8440: “Well spoken, Oddo,” said a young butcher, with his knife at his belt;
8441: “and it’s my belief Piero will be a good while before he wants to come
8442: back, for he looked as frightened as a hunted chicken, when we hustled
8443: and pelted him in the piazza. He’s a coward, else he might have made a
8444: better stand when he’d got his horsemen. But we’ll swallow no Medici
8445: any more, whatever else the French king wants to make us swallow.”
8446: 
8447: “But I like not those French cannon they talk of,” said Goro, none the
8448: less fat for two years’ additional grievances. “San Giovanni defend us!
8449: If Messer Domeneddio means so well by us as your Frate says he does,
8450: Ser Cioni, why shouldn’t he have sent the French another way to
8451: Naples?”
8452: 
8453: “Ay, Goro,” said the dyer; “that’s a question worth putting. Thou art
8454: not such a pumpkin-head as I took thee for. Why, they might have gone
8455: to Naples by Bologna, eh, Ser Cioni? or if they’d gone to Arezzo—we
8456: wouldn’t have minded their going to Arezzo.”
8457: 
8458: “Fools! It will be for the good and glory of Florence,” Ser Cioni
8459: began. But he was interrupted by the exclamation, “Look there!” which
8460: burst from several voices at once, while the faces were all turned to a
8461: party who were advancing along the Via de’ Cerretani.
8462: 
8463: “It’s Lorenzo Tornabuoni, and one of the French noblemen who are in his
8464: house,” said Ser Cioni, in some contempt at this interruption. “He
8465: pretends to look well satisfied—that deep Tornabuoni—but he’s a
8466: Medicean in his heart: mind that.”
8467: 
8468: The advancing party was rather a brilliant one, for there was not only
8469: the distinguished presence of Lorenzo Tornabuoni, and the splendid
8470: costume of the Frenchman with his elaborately displayed white linen and
8471: gorgeous embroidery; there were two other Florentines of high birth in
8472: handsome dresses donned for the coming procession, and on the left-hand
8473: of the Frenchman was a figure that was not to be eclipsed by any amount
8474: of intention or brocade—a figure we have often seen before. He wore
8475: nothing but black, for he was in mourning; but the black was presently
8476: to be covered by a red mantle, for he too was to walk in procession as
8477: Latin Secretary to the Ten. Tito Melema had become conspicuously
8478: serviceable in the intercourse with the French guests, from his
8479: familiarity with Southern Italy, and his readiness in the French
8480: tongue, which he had spoken in his early youth; and he had paid more
8481: than one visit to the French camp at Signa. The lustre of good fortune
8482: was upon him; he was smiling, listening, and explaining, with his usual
8483: graceful unpretentious ease, and only a very keen eye bent on studying
8484: him could have marked a certain amount of change in him which was not
8485: to be accounted for by the lapse of eighteen months. It was that change
8486: which comes from the final departure of moral youthfulness—from the
8487: distinct self-conscious adoption of a part in life. The lines of the
8488: face were as soft as ever, the eyes as pellucid; but something was
8489: gone—something as indefinable as the changes in the morning twilight.
8490: 
8491: The Frenchman was gathering instructions concerning ceremonial before
8492: riding back to Signa, and now he was going to have a final survey of
8493: the Piazza del Duomo, where the royal procession was to pause for
8494: religious purposes. The distinguished party attracted the notice of all
8495: eyes as it entered the piazza, but the gaze was not entirely cordial
8496: and admiring; there were remarks not altogether allusive and mysterious
8497: to the Frenchman’s hoof-shaped shoes—delicate flattery of royal
8498: superfluity in toes; and there was no care that certain snarlings at
8499: “Mediceans” should be strictly inaudible. But Lorenzo Tornabuoni
8500: possessed that power of dissembling annoyance which is demanded in a
8501: man who courts popularity, and Tito, besides his natural disposition to
8502: overcome ill-will by good-humour, had the unimpassioned feeling of the
8503: alien towards names and details that move the deepest passions of the
8504: native.
8505: 
8506: Arrived where they could get a good oblique view of the Duomo, the
8507: party paused. The festoons and devices placed over the central doorway
8508: excited some demur, and Tornabuoni beckoned to Piero di Cosimo, who, as
8509: was usual with him at this hour, was lounging in front of Nello’s shop.
8510: There was soon an animated discussion, and it became highly amusing
8511: from the Frenchman’s astonishment at Piero’s odd pungency of statement,
8512: which Tito translated literally. Even snarling onlookers became
8513: curious, and their faces began to wear the half-smiling,
8514: half-humiliated expression of people who are not within hearing of the
8515: joke which is producing infectious laughter. It was a delightful moment
8516: for Tito, for he was the only one of the party who could have made so
8517: amusing an interpreter, and without any disposition to triumphant
8518: self-gratulation he revelled in the sense that he was an object of
8519: liking—he basked in approving glances. The rainbow light fell about the
8520: laughing group, and the grave church-goers had all disappeared within
8521: the walls. It seemed as if the piazza had been decorated for a real
8522: Florentine holiday.
8523: 
8524: Meanwhile in the grey light of the unadorned streets there were
8525: on-comers who made no show of linen and brocade, and whose humour was
8526: far from merry. Here, too, the French dress and hoofed shoes were
8527: conspicuous, but they were being pressed upon by a larger and larger
8528: number of non-admiring Florentines. In the van of the crowd were three
8529: men in scanty clothing; each had his hands bound together by a cord,
8530: and a rope was fastened round his neck and body, in such a way that he
8531: who held the extremity of the rope might easily check any rebellious
8532: movement by the threat of throttling. The men who held the ropes were
8533: French soldiers, and by broken Italian phrases and strokes from the
8534: knotted end of the rope, they from time to time stimulated their
8535: prisoners to beg. Two of them were obedient, and to every Florentine
8536: they had encountered had held out their bound hands and said in piteous
8537: tones—
8538: 
8539: “For the love of God and the Holy Madonna, give us something towards
8540: our ransom! We are Tuscans: we were made prisoners in Lunigiana.”
8541: 
8542: But the third man remained obstinately silent under all the strokes
8543: from the knotted cord. He was very different in aspect from his two
8544: fellow-prisoners. They were young and hardy, and, in the scant clothing
8545: which the avarice of their captors had left them, looked like vulgar,
8546: sturdy mendicants. But he had passed the boundary of old age, and could
8547: hardly be less than four or five and sixty. His beard, which had grown
8548: long in neglect, and the hair which fell thick and straight round his
8549: baldness, were nearly white. His thickset figure was still firm and
8550: upright, though emaciated, and seemed to express energy in spite of
8551: age—an expression that was partly carried out in the dark eyes and
8552: strong dark eyebrows, which had a strangely isolated intensity of
8553: colour in the midst of his yellow, bloodless, deep-wrinkled face with
8554: its lank grey hairs. And yet there was something fitful in the eyes
8555: which contradicted the occasional flash of energy: after looking round
8556: with quick fierceness at windows and faces, they fell again with a lost
8557: and wandering look. But his lips were motionless, and he held his hands
8558: resolutely down. He would not beg.
8559: 
8560: This sight had been witnessed by the Florentines with growing
8561: exasperation. Many standing at their doors or passing quietly along had
8562: at once given money—some in half-automatic response to an appeal in the
8563: name of God, others in that unquestioning awe of the French soldiery
8564: which had been created by the reports of their cruel warfare, and on
8565: which the French themselves counted as a guarantee of immunity in their
8566: acts of insolence. But as the group had proceeded farther into the
8567: heart of the city, that compliance had gradually disappeared, and the
8568: soldiers found themselves escorted by a gathering troop of men and
8569: boys, who kept up a chorus of exclamations sufficiently intelligible to
8570: foreign ears without any interpreter. The soldiers themselves began to
8571: dislike their position, for, with a strong inclination to use their
8572: weapons, they were checked by the necessity for keeping a secure hold
8573: on their prisoners, and they were now hurrying along in the hope of
8574: finding shelter in a hostelry.
8575: 
8576: “French dogs!”
8577: 
8578: “Bullock-feet!”
8579: 
8580: “Snatch their pikes from them!”
8581: 
8582: “Cut the cords and make them run for their prisoners. They’ll run as
8583: fast as geese—don’t you see they’re web-footed?” These were the cries
8584: which the soldiers vaguely understood to be jeers, and probably
8585: threats. But every one seemed disposed to give invitations of this
8586: spirited kind rather than to act upon them.
8587: 
8588: “Santiddio! here’s a sight!” said the dyer, as soon as he had divined
8589: the meaning of the advancing tumult, “and the fools do nothing but
8590: hoot. Come along!” he added, snatching his axe from his belt, and
8591: running to join the crowd, followed by the butcher and all the rest of
8592: his companions, except Goro, who hastily retreated up a narrow passage.
8593: 
8594: The sight of the dyer, running forward with blood-red arms and axe
8595: uplifted, and with his cluster of rough companions behind him, had a
8596: stimulating effect on the crowd. Not that he did anything else than
8597: pass beyond the soldiers and thrust himself well among his
8598: fellow-citizens, flourishing his axe; but he served as a stirring
8599: symbol of street-fighting, like the waving of a well-known gonfalon.
8600: And the first sign that fire was ready to burst out was something as
8601: rapid as a little leaping tongue of flame: it was an act of the
8602: conjuror’s impish lad Lollo, who was dancing and jeering in front of
8603: the ingenuous boys that made the majority of the crowd. Lollo had no
8604: great compassion for the prisoners, but being conscious of an excellent
8605: knife which was his unfailing companion, it had seemed to him from the
8606: first that to jump forward, cut a rope, and leap back again before the
8607: soldier who held it could use his weapon, would be an amusing and
8608: dexterous piece of mischief. And now, when the people began to hoot and
8609: jostle more vigorously, Lollo felt that his moment was come—he was
8610: close to the eldest prisoner: in an instant he had cut the cord.
8611: 
8612: “Run, old one!” he piped in the prisoner’s ear, as soon as the cord was
8613: in two; and himself set the example of running as if he were helped
8614: along with wings, like a scared fowl.
8615: 
8616: The prisoner’s sensations were not too slow for him to seize the
8617: opportunity: the idea of escape had been continually present with him,
8618: and he had gathered fresh hope from the temper of the crowd. He ran at
8619: once; but his speed would hardly have sufficed for him if the
8620: Florentines had not instantaneously rushed between him and his captor.
8621: He ran on into the piazza, but he quickly heard the tramp of feet
8622: behind him, for the other two prisoners had been released, and the
8623: soldiers were struggling and fighting their way after them, in such
8624: tardigrade fashion as their hoof-shaped shoes would allow—impeded, but
8625: not very resolutely attacked, by the people. One of the two younger
8626: prisoners turned up the Borgo di San Lorenzo, and thus made a partial
8627: diversion of the hubbub; but the main struggle was still towards the
8628: piazza, where all eyes were turned on it with alarmed curiosity. The
8629: cause could not be precisely guessed, for the French dress was screened
8630: by the impeding crowd.
8631: 
8632: “An escape of prisoners,” said Lorenzo Tornabuoni, as he and his party
8633: turned round just against the steps of the Duomo, and saw a prisoner
8634: rushing by them. “The people are not content with having emptied the
8635: Bargello the other day. If there is no other authority in sight they
8636: must fall on the sbirri and secure freedom to thieves. Ah! there is a
8637: French soldier: that is more serious.”
8638: 
8639: The soldier he saw was struggling along on the north side of the
8640: piazza, but the object of his pursuit had taken the other direction.
8641: That object was the eldest prisoner, who had wheeled round the
8642: Baptistery and was running towards the Duomo, determined to take refuge
8643: in that sanctuary rather than trust to his speed. But in mounting the
8644: steps, his foot received a shock; he was precipitated towards the group
8645: of signori, whose backs were turned to him, and was only able to
8646: recover his balance as he clutched one of them by the arm.
8647: 
8648: It was Tito Melema who felt that clutch. He turned his head, and saw
8649: the face of his adoptive father, Baldassarre Calvo, close to his own.
8650: 
8651: The two men looked at each other, silent as death: Baldassarre, with
8652: dark fierceness and a tightening grip of the soiled worn hands on the
8653: velvet-clad arm; Tito, with cheeks and lips all bloodless, fascinated
8654: by terror. It seemed a long while to them—it was but a moment.
8655: 
8656: The first sound Tito heard was the short laugh of Piero di Cosimo, who
8657: stood close by him and was the only person that could see his face.
8658: 
8659: “Ha, ha! I know what a ghost should be now.”
8660: 
8661: “This is another escaped prisoner,” said Lorenzo Tornabuoni. “Who is
8662: he, I wonder?”
8663: 
8664: “_Some madman, surely_,” said Tito.
8665: 
8666: He hardly knew how the words had come to his lips: there are moments
8667: when our passions speak and decide for us, and we seem to stand by and
8668: wonder. They carry in them an inspiration of crime, that in one instant
8669: does the work of long premeditation.
8670: 
8671: The two men had not taken their eyes off each other, and it seemed to
8672: Tito, when he had spoken, that some magical poison had darted from
8673: Baldassarre’s eyes, and that he felt it rushing through his veins. But
8674: the next instant the grasp on his arm had relaxed, and Baldassarre had
8675: disappeared within the church.
8676: 
8677: 
8678: 
8679: 
8680: CHAPTER XXIII.
8681: After-Thoughts.
8682: 
8683: 
8684: “You are easily frightened, though,” said Piero, with another scornful
8685: laugh. “My portrait is not as good as the original. But the old fellow
8686: _had_ a tiger look: I must go into the Duomo and see him again.”
8687: 
8688: “It is not pleasant to be laid hold of by a madman, if madman he be,”
8689: said Lorenzo Tornabuoni, in polite excuse of Tito, “but perhaps he is
8690: only a ruffian. We shall hear. I think we must see if we have authority
8691: enough to stop this disturbance between our people and your
8692: countrymen,” he added, addressing the Frenchman.
8693: 
8694: They advanced toward the crowd with their swords drawn, all the quiet
8695: spectators making an escort for them. Tito went too: it was necessary
8696: that he should know what others knew about Baldassarre, and the first
8697: palsy of terror was being succeeded by the rapid devices to which
8698: mortal danger will stimulate the timid.
8699: 
8700: The rabble of men and boys, more inclined to hoot at the soldier and
8701: torment him than to receive or inflict any serious wounds, gave way at
8702: the approach of signori with drawn swords, and the French soldier was
8703: interrogated. He and his companions had simply brought their prisoners
8704: into the city that they might beg money for their ransom: two of the
8705: prisoners were Tuscan soldiers taken in Lunigiana; the other, an
8706: elderly man, was with a party of Genoese, with whom the French foragers
8707: had come to blows near Fivizzano. He might be mad, but he was harmless.
8708: The soldier knew no more, being unable to understand a word the old man
8709: said. Tito heard so far, but he was deaf to everything else till he was
8710: specially addressed. It was Tornabuoni who spoke.
8711: 
8712: “Will you go back with us, Melema? Or, since Messere is going off to
8713: Signa now, will you wisely follow the fashion of the times and go to
8714: hear the Frate, who will be like the torrent at its height this
8715: morning? It’s what we must all do, you know, if we are to save our
8716: Medicean skins. _I_ should go if I had the leisure.”
8717: 
8718: Tito’s face had recovered its colour now, and he could make an effort
8719: to speak with gaiety.
8720: 
8721: “Of course I am among the admirers of the inspired orator,” he said,
8722: smilingly; “but, unfortunately, I shall be occupied with the Segretario
8723: till the time of the procession.”
8724: 
8725: “_I_ am going into the Duomo to look at that savage old man again,”
8726: said Piero.
8727: 
8728: “Then have the charity to show him to one of the hospitals for
8729: travellers, Piero mio,” said Tornabuoni. “The monks may find out
8730: whether he wants putting into a cage.”
8731: 
8732: The party separated, and Tito took his way to the Palazzo Vecchio,
8733: where he was to find Bartolommeo Scala. It was not a long walk, but,
8734: for Tito, it was stretched out like the minutes of our morning dreams:
8735: the short spaces of street and piazza held memories, and previsions,
8736: and torturing fears, that might have made the history of months. He
8737: felt as if a serpent had begun to coil round his limbs. Baldassarre
8738: living, and in Florence, was a living revenge, which would no more rest
8739: than a winding serpent would rest until it had crushed its prey. It was
8740: not in the nature of that man to let an injury pass unavenged: his love
8741: and his hatred were of that passionate fervour which subjugates all the
8742: rest of the being, and makes a man sacrifice himself to his passion as
8743: if it were a deity to be worshipped with self-destruction. Baldassarre
8744: had relaxed his hold, and had disappeared. Tito knew well how to
8745: interpret that: it meant that the vengeance was to be studied that it
8746: might be sure. If he had not uttered those decisive words—“He is a
8747: madman”—if he could have summoned up the state of mind, the courage,
8748: necessary for avowing his recognition of Baldassarre, would not the
8749: risk have been less? He might have declared himself to have had what he
8750: believed to be positive evidence of Baldassarre’s death; and the only
8751: persons who could ever have had positive knowledge to contradict him,
8752: were Fra Luca, who was dead, and the crew of the companion galley, who
8753: had brought him the news of the encounter with the pirates. The chances
8754: were infinite against Baldassarre’s having met again with any one of
8755: that crew, and Tito thought with bitterness that a timely, well-devised
8756: falsehood might have saved him from any fatal consequences. But to have
8757: told that falsehood would have required perfect self-command in the
8758: moment of a convulsive shock: he seemed to have spoken without any
8759: preconception: the words had leaped forth like a sudden birth that had
8760: been begotten and nourished in the darkness.
8761: 
8762: Tito was experiencing that inexorable law of human souls, that we
8763: prepare ourselves for sudden deeds by the reiterated choice of good or
8764: evil which gradually determines character.
8765: 
8766: There was but one chance for him now; the chance of Baldassarre’s
8767: failure in finding his revenge. And—Tito grasped at a thought more
8768: actively cruel than any he had ever encouraged before: might not his
8769: own unpremeditated words have some truth in them? Enough truth, at
8770: least, to bear him out in his denial of any declaration Baldassarre
8771: might make about him? The old man looked strange and wild; with his
8772: eager heart and brain, suffering was likely enough to have produced
8773: madness. If it were so, the vengeance that strove to inflict disgrace
8774: might be baffled.
8775: 
8776: But there was another form of vengeance not to be baffled by ingenious
8777: lying. Baldassarre belonged to a race to whom the thrust of the dagger
8778: seems almost as natural an impulse as the outleap of the tiger’s
8779: talons. Tito shrank with shuddering dread from disgrace; but he had
8780: also that physical dread which is inseparable from a soft
8781: pleasure-loving nature, and which prevents a man from meeting wounds
8782: and death as a welcome relief from disgrace. His thoughts flew at once
8783: to some hidden defensive armour that might save him from a vengeance
8784: which no subtlety could parry.
8785: 
8786: He wondered at the power of the passionate fear that possessed him. It
8787: was as if he had been smitten with a blighting disease that had
8788: suddenly turned the joyous sense of young life into pain.
8789: 
8790: There was still one resource open to Tito. He might have turned back,
8791: sought Baldassarre again, confessed everything to him—to Romola—to all
8792: the world. But he never thought of that. The repentance which cuts off
8793: all moorings to evil, demands something more than selfish fear. He had
8794: no sense that there was strength and safety in truth; the only strength
8795: he trusted to lay in his ingenuity and his dissimulation. Now that the
8796: first shock, which had called up the traitorous signs of fear, was well
8797: past, he hoped to be prepared for all emergencies by cool deceit—and
8798: defensive armour.
8799: 
8800: It was a characteristic fact in Tito’s experience at this crisis, that
8801: no direct measures for ridding himself of Baldassarre ever occurred to
8802: him. All other possibilities passed through his mind, even to his own
8803: flight from Florence; but he never thought of any scheme for removing
8804: his enemy. His dread generated no active malignity, and he would still
8805: have been glad not to give pain to any mortal. He had simply chosen to
8806: make life easy to himself—to carry his human lot, if possible, in such
8807: a way that it should pinch him nowhere; and the choice had, at various
8808: times, landed him in unexpected positions. The question now was, not
8809: whether he should divide the common pressure of destiny with his
8810: suffering fellow-men; it was whether all the resources of lying would
8811: save him from being crushed by the consequences of that habitual
8812: choice.
8813: 
8814: 
8815: 
8816: 
8817: CHAPTER XXIV.
8818: Inside the Duomo.
8819: 
8820: 
8821: When Baldassarre, with his hands bound together, and the rope round his
8822: neck and body, pushed his way behind the curtain, and saw the interior
8823: of the Duomo before him, he gave a start of astonishment, and stood
8824: still against the doorway. He had expected to see a vast nave empty of
8825: everything but lifeless emblems—side altars with candles unlit, dim
8826: pictures, pale and rigid statues—with perhaps a few worshippers in the
8827: distant choir following a monotonous chant. That was the ordinary
8828: aspect of churches to a man who never went into them with any religious
8829: purpose.
8830: 
8831: And he saw, instead, a vast multitude of warm, living faces, upturned
8832: in breathless silence towards the pulpit, at the angle between the nave
8833: and the choir. The multitude was of all ranks, from magistrates and
8834: dames of gentle nurture to coarsely-clad artisans and country people.
8835: In the pulpit was a Dominican friar, with strong features and dark
8836: hair, preaching with the crucifix in his hand.
8837: 
8838: For the first few minutes Baldassarre noted nothing of his preaching.
8839: Silent as his entrance had been, some eyes near the doorway had been
8840: turned on him with surprise and suspicion. The rope indicated plainly
8841: enough that he was an escaped prisoner, but in that case the church was
8842: a sanctuary which he had a right to claim; his advanced years and look
8843: of wild misery were fitted to excite pity rather than alarm; and as he
8844: stood motionless, with eyes that soon wandered absently from the wide
8845: scene before him to the pavement at his feet, those who had observed
8846: his entrance presently ceased to regard him, and became absorbed again
8847: in the stronger interest of listening to the sermon.
8848: 
8849: Among the eyes that had been turned towards him were Romola’s: she had
8850: entered late through one of the side doors and was so placed that she
8851: had a full view of the main entrance. She had looked long and
8852: attentively at Baldassarre, for grey hairs made a peculiar appeal to
8853: her, and the stamp of some unwonted suffering in the face, confirmed by
8854: the cord round his neck, stirred in her those sensibilities towards the
8855: sorrows of age, which her whole life had tended to develop. She fancied
8856: that his eyes had met hers in their first wandering gaze; but
8857: Baldassarre had not, in reality, noted her; he had only had a startled
8858: consciousness of the general scene, and the consciousness was a mere
8859: flash that made no perceptible break in the fierce tumult of emotion
8860: which the encounter with Tito had created. Images from the past kept
8861: urging themselves upon him like delirious visions strangely blended
8862: with thirst and anguish. No distinct thought for the future could shape
8863: itself in the midst of that fiery passion: the nearest approach to such
8864: thought was the bitter sense of enfeebled powers, and a vague
8865: determination to universal distrust and suspicion. Suddenly he felt
8866: himself vibrating to loud tones, which seemed like the thundering echo
8867: of his own passion. A voice that penetrated his very marrow with its
8868: accent of triumphant certitude was saying—“The day of vengeance is at
8869: hand!”
8870: 
8871: Baldassarre quivered and looked up. He was too distant to see more than
8872: the general aspect of the preacher standing, with his right arm
8873: outstretched, lifting up the crucifix; but he panted for the
8874: threatening voice again as if it had been a promise of bliss. There was
8875: a pause before the preacher spoke again. He gradually lowered his arm.
8876: He deposited the crucifix on the edge of the pulpit, and crossed his
8877: arms over his breast, looking round at the multitude as if he would
8878: meet the glance of every individual face.
8879: 
8880: “All ye in Florence are my witnesses, for I spoke not in a corner. Ye
8881: are my witnesses, that four years ago, when there were yet no signs of
8882: war and tribulation, I preached the coming of the scourge. I lifted up
8883: my voice as a trumpet to the prelates and princes and people of Italy
8884: and said, The cup of your iniquity is full. Behold, the thunder of the
8885: Lord is gathering, and it shall fall and break the cup, and your
8886: iniquity, which seems to you as pleasant wine, shall be poured out upon
8887: you, and shall be as molten lead. And you, O priests, who say, Ha, ha!
8888: there is no Presence in the sanctuary—the Shechinah is nought—the
8889: Mercy-seat is bare: we may sin behind the veil, and who shall punish
8890: us? To you, I said, the presence of God shall be revealed in his temple
8891: as a consuming fire, and your sacred garments shall become a
8892: winding-sheet of flame, and for sweet music there shall be shrieks and
8893: hissing, and for soft couches there shall be thorns, and for the breath
8894: of wantons shall come the pestilence. Trust not in your gold and
8895: silver, trust not in your high fortresses; for, though the walls were
8896: of iron, and the fortresses of adamant, the Most High shall put terror
8897: into your hearts and weakness into your councils, so that you shall be
8898: confounded and flee like women. He shall break in pieces mighty men
8899: without number, and put others in their stead. For God will no longer
8900: endure the pollution of his sanctuary; he will thoroughly purge his
8901: Church.
8902: 
8903: “And forasmuch as it is written that God will do nothing but he
8904: revealeth it to his servants the prophets, he has chosen me, his
8905: unworthy servant, and made his purpose present to my soul in the living
8906: word of the Scriptures, and in the deeds of his providence; and by the
8907: ministry of angels he has revealed it to me in visions. And his word
8908: possesses me so that I am but as the branch of the forest when the wind
8909: of heaven penetrates it, and it is not in me to keep silence, even
8910: though I may be a derision to the scorner. And for four years I have
8911: preached in obedience to the Divine will: in the face of scoffing I
8912: have preached three things, which the Lord has delivered to me: that
8913: _in these times God will regenerate his Church_, and that _before the
8914: regeneration must come the scourge over all Italy_, and that _these
8915: things will come quickly_.
8916: 
8917: “But hypocrites who cloak their hatred of the truth with a show of love
8918: have said to me, ‘Come now, Frate, leave your prophesyings: it is
8919: enough to teach virtue.’ To these I answer: ‘Yes, you say in your
8920: hearts, God lives afar off, and his word is as a parchment written by
8921: dead men, and he deals not as in the days of old, rebuking the nations,
8922: and punishing the oppressors, and smiting the unholy priests as he
8923: smote the sons of Eli. But I cry again in your ears: God is near and
8924: not afar off; his judgments change not. He is the God of armies; the
8925: strong men who go up to battle are his ministers, even as the storm,
8926: and fire, and pestilence. He drives them by the breath of his angels,
8927: and they come upon the chosen land which has forsaken the covenant. And
8928: thou, O Italy, art the chosen land; has not God placed his sanctuary
8929: within thee, and thou hast polluted it? Behold, the ministers of his
8930: wrath are upon thee—they are at thy very doors!’”
8931: 
8932: Savonarola’s voice had been rising in impassioned force up to this
8933: point, when he became suddenly silent, let his hands fall and clasped
8934: them quietly before him. His silence, instead of being the signal for
8935: small movements amongst his audience, seemed to be as strong a spell to
8936: them as his voice. Through the vast area of the cathedral men and women
8937: sat with faces upturned, like breathing statues, till the voice was
8938: heard again in clear low tones.
8939: 
8940: “Yet there is a pause—even as in the days when Jerusalem was destroyed
8941: there was a pause that the children of God might flee from it. There is
8942: a stillness before the storm: lo, there is blackness above, but not a
8943: leaf quakes: the winds are stayed, that the voice of God’s warning may
8944: be heard. Hear it now, O Florence, chosen city in the chosen land!
8945: Repent and forsake evil: do justice: love mercy: put away all
8946: uncleanness from among you, that the spirit of truth and holiness may
8947: fill your souls and breathe through all your streets and habitations,
8948: and then the pestilence shall not enter, and the sword shall pass over
8949: you and leave you unhurt.
8950: 
8951: “For the sword is hanging from the sky; it is quivering; it is about to
8952: fall! _The sword of God upon the earth, swift and sudden_! Did I not
8953: tell you, years ago, that I had beheld the vision and heard the voice?
8954: And behold, it is fulfilled! Is there not a king with his army at your
8955: gates? Does not the earth shake with the tread of horses and the wheels
8956: of swift cannon? Is there not a fierce multitude that can lay bare the
8957: land as with a sharp razor? I tell you the French king with his army is
8958: the minister of God: God shall guide him as the hand guides a sharp
8959: sickle, and the joints of the wicked shall melt before him, and they
8960: shall be mown down as stubble: he that fleeth of them shall not flee
8961: away, and he that escapeth of them shall not be delivered. And the
8962: tyrants who have made to themselves a throne out of the vices of the
8963: multitude, and the unbelieving priests who traffic in the souls of men
8964: and fill the very sanctuary with fornication, shall be hurled from
8965: their soft couches into burning hell; and the pagans and they who
8966: sinned under the old covenant shall stand aloof and say: ‘Lo, these men
8967: have brought the stench of a new wickedness into the everlasting fire.’
8968: 
8969: “But thou, O Florence, take the offered mercy. See! the Cross is held
8970: out to you: come and be healed. Which among the nations of Italy has
8971: had a token like unto yours? The tyrant is driven out from among you:
8972: the men who held a bribe in their left-hand and a rod in the right are
8973: gone forth, and no blood has been spilled. And now put away every other
8974: abomination from among you, and you shall be strong in the strength of
8975: the living God. Wash yourselves from the black pitch of your vices,
8976: which have made you even as the heathens: put away the envy and hatred
8977: that have made your city as a nest of wolves. And there shall no harm
8978: happen to you: and the passage of armies shall be to you as a flight of
8979: birds, and rebellious Pisa shall be given to you again, and famine and
8980: pestilence shall be far from your gates, and you shall be as a beacon
8981: among the nations. But, mark! while you suffer the accursed thing to
8982: lie in the camp you shall be afflicted and tormented, even though a
8983: remnant among you may be saved.”
8984: 
8985: These admonitions and promises had been spoken in an incisive tone of
8986: authority; but in the next sentence the preacher’s voice melted into a
8987: strain of entreaty.
8988: 
8989: “Listen, O people, over whom my heart yearns, as the heart of a mother
8990: over the children she has travailed for! God is my witness that but for
8991: your sakes I would willingly live as a turtle in the depths of the
8992: forest, singing low to my Beloved, who is mine and I am his. For you I
8993: toil, for you I languish, for you my nights are spent in watching, and
8994: my soul melteth away for very heaviness. O Lord, thou knowest I am
8995: willing—I am ready. Take me, stretch me on thy cross: let the wicked
8996: who delight in blood, and rob the poor, and defile the temple of their
8997: bodies, and harden themselves against thy mercy—let them wag their
8998: heads and shoot out the lip at me: let the thorns press upon my brow,
8999: and let my sweat be anguish—I desire to be made like thee in thy great
9000: love. But let me see the fruit of my travail—let this people be saved!
9001: Let me see them clothed in purity: let me hear their voices rise in
9002: concord as the voices of the angels: let them see no wisdom but in thy
9003: eternal law, no beauty but in holiness. Then they shall lead the way
9004: before the nations, and the people from the four winds shall follow
9005: them, and be gathered into the fold of the blessed. For it is thy will,
9006: O God, that the earth shall be converted unto thy law: it is thy will
9007: that wickedness shall cease and love shall reign. Come, O blessed
9008: promise; and behold, I am willing—lay me on the altar: let my blood
9009: flow and the fire consume me; but let my witness be remembered among
9010: men, that iniquity shall not prosper for ever.”
9011: 
9012: During the last appeal, Savonarola had stretched out his arms and
9013: lifted up his eyes to heaven; his strong voice had alternately trembled
9014: with emotion and risen again in renewed energy; but the passion with
9015: which he offered himself as a victim became at last too strong to allow
9016: of further speech, and he ended in a sob. Every changing tone,
9017: vibrating through the audience, shook them into answering emotion.
9018: There were plenty among them who had very moderate faith in the Frate’s
9019: prophetic mission, and who in their cooler moments loved him little;
9020: nevertheless, they too were carried along by the great wave of feeling
9021: which gathered its force from sympathies that lay deeper than all
9022: theory. A loud responding sob rose at once from the wide multitude,
9023: while Savonarola had fallen on his knees and buried his face in his
9024: mantle. He felt in that moment the rapture and glory of martyrdom
9025: without its agony.
9026: 
9027: In that great sob of the multitude Baldassarre’s had mingled. Among all
9028: the human beings present, there was perhaps not one whose frame
9029: vibrated more strongly than his to the tones and words of the preacher;
9030: but it had vibrated like a harp of which all the strings had been
9031: wrenched away except one. That threat of a fiery inexorable
9032: vengeance—of a future into which the hated sinner might be pursued and
9033: held by the avenger in an eternal grapple, had come to him like the
9034: promise of an unquenchable fountain to unquenchable thirst. The
9035: doctrines of the sages, the old contempt for priestly superstitions,
9036: had fallen away from his soul like a forgotten language: if he could
9037: have remembered them, what answer could they have given to his great
9038: need like the answer given by this voice of energetic conviction? The
9039: thunder of denunciation fell on his passion-wrought nerves with all the
9040: force of self-evidence: his thought never went beyond it into
9041: questions—he was possessed by it as the war-horse is possessed by the
9042: clash of sounds. No word that was not a threat touched his
9043: consciousness; he had no fibre to be thrilled by it. But the fierce
9044: exultant delight to which he was moved by the idea of perpetual
9045: vengeance found at once a climax and a relieving outburst in the
9046: preacher’s words of self-sacrifice. To Baldassarre those words only
9047: brought the vague triumphant sense that he too was devoting
9048: himself—signing with his own blood the deed by which he gave himself
9049: over to an unending fire, that would seem but coolness to his burning
9050: hatred.
9051: 
9052: “I rescued him—I cherished him—if I might clutch his heart-strings for
9053: ever! Come, O blessed promise! Let my blood flow; let the fire consume
9054: me!”
9055: 
9056: The one cord vibrated to its utmost. Baldassarre clutched his own
9057: palms, driving his long nails into them, and burst into a sob with the
9058: rest.
9059: 
9060: 
9061: 
9062: 
9063: CHAPTER XXV.
9064: Outside the Duomo.
9065: 
9066: 
9067: While Baldassarre was possessed by the voice of Savonarola, he had not
9068: noticed that another man had entered through the doorway behind him,
9069: and stood not far off observing him. It was Piero di Cosimo, who took
9070: no heed of the preaching, having come solely to look at the escaped
9071: prisoner. During the pause, in which the preacher and his audience had
9072: given themselves up to inarticulate emotion, the new-comer advanced and
9073: touched Baldassarre on the arm. He looked round with the tears still
9074: slowly rolling down his face, but with a vigorous sigh, as if he had
9075: done with that outburst. The painter spoke to him in a low tone—
9076: 
9077: “Shall I cut your cords for you? I have heard how you were made
9078: prisoner.”
9079: 
9080: Baldassarre did not reply immediately; he glanced suspiciously at the
9081: officious stranger. At last he said, “If you will.”
9082: 
9083: “Better come outside,” said Piero.
9084: 
9085: Baldassarre again looked at him suspiciously; and Piero, partly
9086: guessing his thought, smiled, took out a knife, and cut the cords. He
9087: began to think that the idea of the prisoner’s madness was not
9088: improbable, there was something so peculiar in the expression of his
9089: face. “Well,” he thought, “if he does any mischief, he’ll soon get tied
