9090: up again. The poor devil shall have a chance, at least.”
9091: 
9092: “You are afraid of me,” he said again, in an undertone; “you don’t want
9093: to tell me anything about yourself.”
9094: 
9095: Baldassarre was folding his arms in enjoyment of the long-absent
9096: muscular sensation. He answered Piero with a less suspicious look and a
9097: tone which had some quiet decision in it.
9098: 
9099: “No, I have nothing to tell.”
9100: 
9101: “As you please,” said Piero, “but perhaps you want shelter, and may not
9102: know how hospitable we Florentines are to visitors with torn doublets
9103: and empty stomachs. There’s an hospital for poor travellers outside all
9104: our gates, and, if you liked, I could put you in the way to one.
9105: There’s no danger from your French soldier. He has been sent off.”
9106: 
9107: Baldassarre nodded, and turned in silent acceptance of the offer, and
9108: he and Piero left the church together.
9109: 
9110: “You wouldn’t like to sit to me for your portrait, should you?” said
9111: Piero, as they went along the Via dell’ Oriuolo, on the way to the gate
9112: of Santa Croce. “I am a painter: I would give you money to get your
9113: portrait.”
9114: 
9115: The suspicion returned into Baldassarre’s glance, as he looked at
9116: Piero, and said decidedly, “No.”
9117: 
9118: “Ah!” said the painter, curtly. “Well, go straight on, and you’ll find
9119: the Porta Santa Croce, and outside it there’s an hospital for
9120: travellers. So you’ll not accept any service from me?”
9121: 
9122: “I give you thanks for what you have done already. I need no more.”
9123: 
9124: “It is well,” said Piero, with a shrug, and they turned away from each
9125: other.
9126: 
9127: “A mysterious old tiger!” thought the artist, “well worth painting.
9128: Ugly—with deep lines—looking as if the plough and the harrow had gone
9129: over his heart. A fine contrast to my bland and smiling Messer Greco—my
9130: _Bacco trionfante_, who has married the fair Antigone in contradiction
9131: to all history and fitness. Aha! his scholar’s blood curdled
9132: uncomfortably at the old fellow’s clutch!” When Piero re-entered the
9133: Piazza del Duomo the multitude who had been listening to Fra Girolamo
9134: were pouring out from all the doors, and the haste they made to go on
9135: their several ways was a proof how important they held the preaching
9136: which had detained them from the other occupations of the day. The
9137: artist leaned against an angle of the Baptistery and watched the
9138: departing crowd, delighting in the variety of the garb and of the keen
9139: characteristic faces—faces such as Masaccio had painted more than fifty
9140: years before: such as Domenico Ghirlandajo had not yet quite left off
9141: painting.
9142: 
9143: This morning was a peculiar occasion, and the Frate’s audience, always
9144: multifarious, had represented even more completely than usual the
9145: various classes and political parties of Florence. There were men of
9146: high birth, accustomed to public charges at home and abroad, who had
9147: become newly conspicuous not only as enemies of the Medici and friends
9148: of popular government, but as thorough Piagnoni, espousing to the
9149: utmost the doctrines and practical teaching of the Frate, and
9150: frequenting San Marco as the seat of another Samuel: some of them men
9151: of authoritative and handsome presence, like Francesco Valori, and
9152: perhaps also of a hot and arrogant temper, very much gratified by an
9153: immediate divine authority for bringing about freedom in their own way;
9154: others, like Soderini, with less of the ardent Piagnone, and more of
9155: the wise politician. There were men, also of family, like Piero
9156: Capponi, simply brave undoctrinal lovers of a sober republican liberty,
9157: who preferred fighting to arguing, and had no particular reasons for
9158: thinking any ideas false that kept out the Medici and made room for
9159: public spirit. At their elbows were doctors of law whose studies of
9160: Accursius and his brethren had not so entirely consumed their ardour as
9161: to prevent them from becoming enthusiastic Piagnoni: Messer Luca
9162: Corsini himself, for example, who on a memorable occasion yet to come
9163: was to raise his learned arms in street stone-throwing for the cause of
9164: religion, freedom, and the Frate. And among the dignities who carried
9165: their black lucco or furred mantle with an air of habitual authority,
9166: there was an abundant sprinkling of men with more contemplative and
9167: sensitive faces: scholars inheriting such high names as Strozzi and
9168: Acciajoli, who were already minded to take the cowl and join the
9169: community of San Marco; artists, wrought to a new and higher ambition
9170: by the teaching of Savonarola, like that young painter who had lately
9171: surpassed himself in his fresco of the divine child on the wall of the
9172: Frate’s bare cell—unconscious yet that he would one day himself wear
9173: the tonsure and the cowl, and be called Fra Bartolommeo. There was the
9174: mystic poet Girolamo Benevieni hastening, perhaps, to carry tidings of
9175: the beloved Frate’s speedy coming to his friend Pico della Mirandola,
9176: who was never to see the light of another morning. There were well-born
9177: women attired with such scrupulous plainness that their more refined
9178: grace was the chief distinction between them and their less
9179: aristocratic sisters. There was a predominant proportion of the genuine
9180: _popolani_ or middle class, belonging both to the Major and Minor Arts,
9181: conscious of purses threatened by war-taxes. And more striking and
9182: various, perhaps, than all the other classes of the Frate’s disciples,
9183: there was the long stream of poorer tradesmen and artisans, whose faith
9184: and hope in his Divine message varied from the rude and
9185: undiscriminating trust in him as the friend of the poor and the enemy
9186: of the luxurious oppressive rich, to that eager tasting of all the
9187: subtleties of biblical interpretation which takes a peculiarly strong
9188: hold on the sedentary artisan, illuminating the long dim spaces beyond
9189: the board where he stitches, with a pale flame that seems to him the
9190: light of Divine science.
9191: 
9192: But among these various disciples of the Frate were scattered many who
9193: were not in the least his disciples. Some were Mediceans who had
9194: already, from motives of fear and policy, begun to show the presiding
9195: spirit of the popular party a feigned deference. Others were sincere
9196: advocates of a free government, but regarded Savonarola simply as an
9197: ambitious monk—half sagacious, half fanatical—who had made himself a
9198: powerful instrument with the people, and must be accepted as an
9199: important social fact. There were even some of his bitter enemies:
9200: members of the old aristocratic anti-Medicean party—determined to try
9201: and get the reins once more tight in the hands of certain chief
9202: families; or else licentious young men, who detested him as the killjoy
9203: of Florence. For the sermons in the Duomo had already become political
9204: incidents, attracting the ears of curiosity and malice, as well as of
9205: faith. The men of ideas, like young Niccolò Macchiavelli, went to
9206: observe and write reports to friends away in country villas; the men of
9207: appetites, like Dolfo Spini, bent on hunting down the Frate, as a
9208: public nuisance who made game scarce, went to feed their hatred and lie
9209: in wait for grounds of accusation.
9210: 
9211: Perhaps, while no preacher ever had a more massive influence than
9212: Savonarola, no preacher ever had more heterogeneous materials to work
9213: upon. And one secret of the massive influence lay in the highly mixed
9214: character of his preaching. Baldassarre, wrought into an ecstasy of
9215: self-martyring revenge, was only an extreme case among the partial and
9216: narrow sympathies of that audience. In Savonarola’s preaching there
9217: were strains that appealed to the very finest susceptibilities of men’s
9218: natures, and there were elements that gratified low egoism, tickled
9219: gossiping curiosity, and fascinated timorous superstition. His need of
9220: personal predominance, his labyrinthine allegorical interpretations of
9221: the Scriptures, his enigmatic visions, and his false certitude about
9222: the Divine intentions, never ceased, in his own large soul, to be
9223: ennobled by that fervid piety, that passionate sense of the infinite,
9224: that active sympathy, that clear-sighted demand for the subjection of
9225: selfish interests to the general good, which he had in common with the
9226: greatest of mankind. But for the mass of his audience all the pregnancy
9227: of his preaching lay in his strong assertion of supernatural claims, in
9228: his denunciatory visions, in the false certitude which gave his sermons
9229: the interest of a political bulletin; and having once held that
9230: audience in his mastery, it was necessary to his nature—it was
9231: necessary for their welfare—that he should _keep_ the mastery. The
9232: effect was inevitable. No man ever struggled to retain power over a
9233: mixed multitude without suffering vitiation; his standard must be their
9234: lower needs and not his own best insight.
9235: 
9236: The mysteries of human character have seldom been presented in a way
9237: more fitted to check the judgments of facile knowingness than in
9238: Girolamo Savonarola; but we can give him a reverence that needs no
9239: shutting of the eyes to fact, if we regard his life as a drama in which
9240: there were great inward modifications accompanying the outward changes.
9241: And up to this period, when his more direct action on political affairs
9242: had only just begun, it is probable that his imperious need of
9243: ascendancy had burned undiscernibly in the strong flame of his zeal for
9244: God and man.
9245: 
9246: It was the fashion of old, when an ox was led out for sacrifice to
9247: Jupiter, to chalk the dark spots, and give the offering a false show of
9248: unblemished whiteness. Let us fling away the chalk, and boldly say,—the
9249: victim is spotted, but it is not therefore in vain that his mighty
9250: heart is laid on the altar of men’s highest hopes.
9251: 
9252: 
9253: 
9254: 
9255: CHAPTER XXVI.
9256: The Garment of Fear.
9257: 
9258: 
9259: At six o’clock that evening most people in Florence were glad the
9260: entrance of the new Charlemagne was fairly over. Doubtless when the
9261: roll of drums, the blast of trumpets, and the tramp of horses along the
9262: Pisan road began to mingle with the pealing of the excited bells, it
9263: was a grand moment for those who were stationed on turreted roofs, and
9264: could see the long-winding terrible pomp on the background of the green
9265: hills and valley. There was no sunshine to light up the splendour of
9266: banners, and spears, and plumes, and silken surcoats, but there was no
9267: thick cloud of dust to hide it, and as the picked troops advanced into
9268: close view, they could be seen all the more distinctly for the absence
9269: of dancing glitter. Tall and tough Scotch archers, Swiss halberdiers
9270: fierce and ponderous, nimble Gascons ready to wheel and climb, cavalry
9271: in which each man looked like a knight-errant with his indomitable
9272: spear and charger—it was satisfactory to be assured that they would
9273: injure nobody but the enemies of God! With that confidence at heart it
9274: was a less dubious pleasure to look at the array of strength and
9275: splendour in nobles and knights, and youthful pages of choice
9276: lineage—at the bossed and jewelled sword-hilts, at the satin scarfs
9277: embroidered with strange symbolical devices of pious or gallant
9278: meaning, at the gold chains and jewelled aigrettes, at the gorgeous
9279: horse-trappings and brocaded mantles, and at the transcendent canopy
9280: carried by select youths above the head of the Most Christian King. To
9281: sum up with an old diarist, whose spelling and diction halted a little
9282: behind the wonders of this royal visit,—“_fù gran magnificenza_.”
9283: 
9284: But for the Signoria, who had been waiting on their platform against
9285: the gates, and had to march out at the right moment, with their orator
9286: in front of them, to meet the mighty guest, the grandeur of the scene
9287: had been somewhat screened by unpleasant sensations. If Messer Luca
9288: Corsini could have had a brief Latin welcome depending from his mouth
9289: in legible characters, it would have been less confusing when the rain
9290: came on, and created an impatience in men and horses that broke off the
9291: delivery of his well-studied periods, and reduced the representatives
9292: of the scholarly city to offer a makeshift welcome in impromptu French.
9293: But that sudden confusion had created a great opportunity for Tito. As
9294: one of the secretaries he was among the officials who were stationed
9295: behind the Signoria, and with whom these highest dignities were
9296: promiscuously thrown when pressed upon by the horses.
9297: 
9298: “Somebody step forward and say a few words in French,” said Soderini.
9299: But no one of high importance chose to risk a second failure. “You,
9300: Francesco Gaddi—you can speak.” But Gaddi, distrusting his own
9301: promptness, hung back, and pushing Tito, said, “You, Melema.”
9302: 
9303: Tito stepped forward in an instant, and, with the air of profound
9304: deference that came as naturally to him as walking, said the few
9305: needful words in the name of the Signoria; then gave way gracefully,
9306: and let the king pass on. His presence of mind, which had failed him in
9307: the terrible crisis of the morning, had been a ready instrument this
9308: time. It was an excellent livery servant that never forsook him when
9309: danger was not visible. But when he was complimented on his opportune
9310: service, he laughed it off as a thing of no moment, and to those who
9311: had not witnessed it, let Gaddi have the credit of the improvised
9312: welcome. No wonder Tito was popular: the touchstone by which men try us
9313: is most often their own vanity.
9314: 
9315: Other things besides the oratorical welcome had turned out rather worse
9316: than had been expected. If everything had happened according to
9317: ingenious preconceptions, the Florentine procession of clergy and laity
9318: would not have found their way choked up and been obliged to take a
9319: makeshift course through the back streets, so as to meet the king at
9320: the Cathedral only. Also, if the young monarch under the canopy, seated
9321: on his charger with his lance upon his thigh, had looked more like a
9322: Charlemagne and less like a hastily modelled grotesque, the imagination
9323: of his admirers would have been much assisted. It might have been
9324: wished that the scourge of Italian wickedness and “Champion of the
9325: honour of women” had had a less miserable leg, and only the normal sum
9326: of toes; that his mouth had been of a less reptilian width of slit, his
9327: nose and head of a less exorbitant outline. But the thin leg rested on
9328: cloth of gold and pearls, and the face was only an interruption of a
9329: few square inches in the midst of black velvet and gold, and the blaze
9330: of rubies, and the brilliant tints of the embroidered and bepearled
9331: canopy,—“_fù gran magnificenza_.”
9332: 
9333: And the people had cried _Francia, Francia_! with an enthusiasm
9334: proportioned to the splendour of the canopy which they had torn to
9335: pieces as their spoil, according to immemorial custom; royal lips had
9336: duly kissed the altar; and after all mischances the royal person and
9337: retinue were lodged in the Palace of the Via Larga, the rest of the
9338: nobles and gentry were dispersed among the great houses of Florence,
9339: and the terrible soldiery were encamped in the Prato and other open
9340: quarters. The business of the day was ended.
9341: 
9342: But the streets still presented a surprising aspect, such as
9343: Florentines had not seen before under the November stars. Instead of a
9344: gloom unbroken except by a lamp burning feebly here and there before a
9345: saintly image at the street-corners, or by a stream of redder light
9346: from an open doorway, there were lamps suspended at the windows of all
9347: houses, so that men could walk along no less securely and commodiously
9348: than by day,—_fù gran magnificenza_.
9349: 
9350: Along those illuminated streets Tito Melema was walking at about eight
9351: o’clock in the evening, on his way homeward. He had been exerting
9352: himself throughout the day under the pressure of hidden anxieties, and
9353: had at last made his escape unnoticed from the midst of after-supper
9354: gaiety. Once at leisure thoroughly to face and consider his
9355: circumstances, he hoped that he could so adjust himself to them and to
9356: all probabilities as to get rid of his childish fear. If he had only
9357: not been wanting in the presence of mind necessary to recognise
9358: Baldassarre under that surprise!—it would have been happier for him on
9359: all accounts; for he still winced under the sense that he was
9360: deliberately inflicting suffering on his father: he would very much
9361: have preferred that Baldassarre should be prosperous and happy. But he
9362: had left himself no second path now: there could be no conflict any
9363: longer: the only thing he had to do was to take care of himself.
9364: 
9365: While these thoughts were in his mind he was advancing from the Piazza
9366: di Santa Croce along the Via dei Benci, and as he neared the angle
9367: turning into the Borgo Santa Croce his ear was struck by a music which
9368: was not that of evening revelry, but of vigorous labour—the music of
9369: the anvil. Tito gave a slight start and quickened his pace, for the
9370: sounds had suggested a welcome thought. He knew that they came from the
9371: workshop of Niccolò Caparra, famous resort of all Florentines who cared
9372: for curious and beautiful iron-work.
9373: 
9374: “What makes the giant at work so late?” thought Tito. “But so much the
9375: better for me. I can do that little bit of business to-night instead of
9376: to-morrow morning.”
9377: 
9378: Preoccupied as he was, he could not help pausing a moment in admiration
9379: as he came in front of the workshop. The wide doorway, standing at the
9380: truncated angle of a great block or “isle” of houses, was surmounted by
9381: a loggia roofed with fluted tiles, and supported by stone columns with
9382: roughly carved capitals. Against the red light framed in by the outline
9383: of the fluted tiles and columns stood in black relief the grand figure
9384: of Niccolò, with his huge arms in rhythmic rise and fall, first hiding
9385: and then disclosing the profile of his firm mouth and powerful brow.
9386: Two slighter ebony figures, one at the anvil, the other at the bellows,
9387: served to set off his superior massiveness.
9388: 
9389: Tito darkened the doorway with a very different outline, standing in
9390: silence, since it was useless to speak until Niccolò should deign to
9391: pause and notice him. That was not until the smith had beaten the head
9392: of an axe to the due sharpness of edge and dismissed it from his anvil.
9393: But in the meantime Tito had satisfied himself by a glance round the
9394: shop that the object of which he was in search had not disappeared.
9395: 
9396: Niccolò gave an unceremonious but good-humoured nod as he turned from
9397: the anvil and rested his hammer on his hip.
9398: 
9399: “What is it, Messer Tito? Business?”
9400: 
9401: “Assuredly, Niccolò; else I should not have ventured to interrupt you
9402: when you are working out of hours, since I take that as a sign that
9403: your work is pressing.”
9404: 
9405: “I’ve been at the same work all day—making axes and spear-heads. And
9406: every fool that has passed my shop has put his pumpkin-head in to say,
9407: ‘Niccolò, wilt thou not come and see the King of France and his
9408: soldiers?’ and I’ve answered, ‘No: I don’t want to see their faces—I
9409: want to see their backs.’”
9410: 
9411: “Are you making arms for the citizens, then, Niccolò, that they may
9412: have something better than rusty scythes and spits in case of an
9413: uproar?”
9414: 
9415: “We shall see. Arms are good, and Florence is likely to want them. The
9416: Frate tells us we shall get Pisa again, and I hold with the Frate; but
9417: I should be glad to know how the promise is to be fulfilled, if we
9418: don’t get plenty of good weapons forged? The Frate sees a long way
9419: before him; that I believe. But he doesn’t see birds caught with
9420: winking at them, as some of our people try to make out. He sees sense,
9421: and not nonsense. But you’re a bit of a Medicean, Messer Tito Melema.
9422: Ebbene! so I’ve been myself in my time, before the cask began to run
9423: sour. What’s your business?”
9424: 
9425: “Simply to know the price of that fine coat of mail I saw hanging up
9426: here the other day. I want to buy it for a certain personage who needs
9427: a protection of that sort under his doublet.”
9428: 
9429: “Let him come and buy it himself, then,” said Niccolò, bluntly. “I’m
9430: rather nice about what I sell, and whom I sell to. I like to know who’s
9431: my customer.”
9432: 
9433: “I know your scruples, Niccolò. But that is only defensive armour: it
9434: can hurt nobody.”
9435: 
9436: “True: but it may make the man who wears it feel himself all the safer
9437: if he should want to hurt somebody. No, no; it’s not my own work; but
9438: it’s fine work of Maso of Brescia; I should be loth for it to cover the
9439: heart of a scoundrel. I must know who is to wear it.”
9440: 
9441: “Well, then, to be plain with you, Niccolò mio, I want it myself,” said
9442: Tito, knowing it was useless to try persuasion. “The fact is, I am
9443: likely to have a journey to take—and you know what journeying is in
9444: these times. You don’t suspect _me_ of treason against the Republic?”
9445: 
9446: “No, I know no harm of you,” said Niccolò, in his blunt way again. “But
9447: have you the money to pay for the coat? For you’ve passed my shop often
9448: enough to know my sign: you’ve seen the burning account-books. I trust
9449: nobody. The price is twenty florins, and that’s because it’s
9450: second-hand. You’re not likely to have so much money with you. Let it
9451: be till to-morrow.”
9452: 
9453: “I happen to have the money,” said Tito, who had been winning at play
9454: the day before, and had not emptied his purse. “I’ll carry the armour
9455: home with me.”
9456: 
9457: Niccolò reached down the finely-wrought coat, which fell together into
9458: little more than two handfuls.
9459: 
9460: “There, then,” he said, when the florins had been told down on his
9461: palm. “Take the coat. It’s made to cheat sword, or poniard, or arrow.
9462: But, for my part, I would never put such a thing on. It’s like carrying
9463: fear about with one.”
9464: 
9465: Niccolò’s words had an unpleasant intensity of meaning for Tito. But he
9466: smiled and said—
9467: 
9468: “Ah, Niccolò, we scholars are all cowards. Handling the pen doesn’t
9469: thicken the arm as your hammer-wielding does. Addio!”
9470: 
9471: He folded the armour under his mantle, and hastened across the Ponte
9472: Rubaconte.
9473: 
9474: 
9475: 
9476: 
9477: CHAPTER XXVII.
9478: The Young Wife.
9479: 
9480: 
9481: While Tito was hastening across the bridge with the new-bought armour
9482: under his mantle, Romola was pacing up and down the old library,
9483: thinking of him and longing for his return.
9484: 
9485: It was but a few fair faces that had not looked forth from windows that
9486: day to see the entrance of the French king and his nobles. One of the
9487: few was Romola’s. She had been present at no festivities since her
9488: father had died—died quite suddenly in his chair, three months before.
9489: 
9490: “Is not Tito coming to write?” he had said, when the bell had long ago
9491: sounded the usual hour in the evening. He had not asked before, from
9492: dread of a negative; but Romola had seen by his listening face and
9493: restless movements that nothing else was in his mind.
9494: 
9495: “No, father, he had to go to a supper at the cardinal’s: you know he is
9496: wanted so much by every one,” she answered, in a tone of gentle excuse.
9497: 
9498: “Ah! then perhaps he will bring some positive word about the library;
9499: the cardinal promised last week,” said Bardo, apparently pacified by
9500: this hope.
9501: 
9502: He was silent a little while; then, suddenly flushing, he said—
9503: 
9504: “I must go on without him, Romola. Get the pen. He has brought me no
9505: new text to comment on; but I must say what I want to say about the New
9506: Platonists. I shall die and nothing will have been done. Make haste, my
9507: Romola.”
9508: 
9509: “I am ready, father,” she said, the next minute, holding the pen in her
9510: hand.
9511: 
9512: But there was silence. Romola took no note of this for a little while,
9513: accustomed to pauses in dictation; and when at last she looked round
9514: inquiringly, there was no change of attitude.
9515: 
9516: “I am quite ready, father!”
9517: 
9518: Still Bardo was silent, and his silence was never again broken.
9519: 
9520: Romola looked back on that hour with some indignation against herself,
9521: because even with the first outburst of her sorrow there had mingled
9522: the irrepressible thought, “Perhaps my life with Tito will be more
9523: perfect now.”
9524: 
9525: For the dream of a triple life with an undivided sum of happiness had
9526: not been quite fulfilled. The rainbow-tinted shower of sweets, to have
9527: been perfectly typical, should have had some invisible seeds of
9528: bitterness mingled with them; the crowned Ariadne, under the snowing
9529: roses, had felt more and more the presence of unexpected thorns. It was
9530: not Tito’s fault, Romola had continually assured herself. He was still
9531: all gentleness to her, and to her father also. But it was in the nature
9532: of things—she saw it clearly now—it was in the nature of things that no
9533: one but herself could go on month after month, and year after year,
9534: fulfilling patiently all her father’s monotonous exacting demands. Even
9535: she, whose sympathy with her father had made all the passion and
9536: religion of her young years, had not always been patient, had been
9537: inwardly very rebellious. It was true that before their marriage, and
9538: even for some time after, Tito had seemed more unwearying than herself;
9539: but then, of course, the effort had the ease of novelty. We assume a
9540: load with confident readiness, and up to a certain point the growing
9541: irksomeness of pressure is tolerable; but at last the desire for relief
9542: can no longer be resisted. Romola said to herself that she had been
9543: very foolish and ignorant in her girlish time: she was wiser now, and
9544: would make no unfair demands on the man to whom she had given her best
9545: woman’s love and worship. The breath of sadness that still cleaved to
9546: her lot while she saw her father month after month sink from elation
9547: into new disappointment as Tito gave him less and less of his time, and
9548: made bland excuses for not continuing his own share of the joint
9549: work—that sadness was no fault of Tito’s, she said, but rather of their
9550: inevitable destiny. If he stayed less and less with her, why, that was
9551: because they could hardly ever be alone. His caresses were no less
9552: tender: if she pleaded timidly on any one evening that he should stay
9553: with her father instead of going to another engagement which was not
9554: peremptory, he excused himself with such charming gaiety, he seemed to
9555: linger about her with such fond playfulness before he could quit her,
9556: that she could only feel a little heartache in the midst of her love,
9557: and then go to her father and try to soften his vexation and
9558: disappointment. But all the while inwardly her imagination was busy
9559: trying to see how Tito could be as good as she had thought he was, and
9560: yet find it impossible to sacrifice those pleasures of society which
9561: were necessarily more vivid to a bright creature like him than to the
9562: common run of men. She herself would have liked more gaiety, more
9563: admiration: it was true, she gave it up willingly for her father’s
9564: sake—she would have given up much more than that for the sake even of a
9565: slight wish on Tito’s part. It was clear that their natures differed
9566: widely; but perhaps it was no more than the inherent difference between
9567: man and woman, that made her affections more absorbing. If there were
9568: any other difference she tried to persuade herself that the inferiority
9569: was on her side. Tito was really kinder than she was, better tempered,
9570: less proud and resentful; he had no angry retorts, he met all
9571: complaints with perfect sweetness; he only escaped as quietly as he
9572: could from things that were unpleasant.
9573: 
9574: It belongs to every large nature, when it is not under the immediate
9575: power of some strong unquestioning emotion, to suspect itself, and
9576: doubt the truth of its own impressions, conscious of possibilities
9577: beyond its own horizon. And Romola was urged to doubt herself the more
9578: by the necessity of interpreting her disappointment in her life with
9579: Tito so as to satisfy at once her love and her pride. Disappointment?
9580: Yes, there was no other milder word that would tell the truth. Perhaps
9581: all women had to suffer the disappointment of ignorant hopes, if she
9582: only knew their experience. Still, there had been something peculiar in
9583: her lot: her relation to her father had claimed unusual sacrifices from
9584: her husband. Tito had once thought that his love would make those
9585: sacrifices easy; his love had not been great enough for that. She was
9586: not justified in resenting a self-delusion. No! resentment must not
9587: rise: all endurance seemed easy to Romola rather than a state of mind
9588: in which she would admit to herself that Tito acted unworthily. If she
9589: had felt a new heartache in the solitary hours with her father through
9590: the last months of his life, it had been by no inexcusable fault of her
9591: husband’s; and now—it was a hope that would make its presence felt even
9592: in the first moments when her father’s place was empty—there was no
9593: longer any importunate claim to divide her from Tito; their young lives
9594: would flow in one current, and their true marriage would begin.
9595: 
9596: But the sense of something like guilt towards her father in a hope that
9597: grew out of his death, gave all the more force to the anxiety with
9598: which she dwelt on the means of fulfilling his supreme wish. That piety
9599: towards his memory was all the atonement she could make now for a
9600: thought that seemed akin to joy at his loss. The laborious simple life,
9601: pure from vulgar corrupting ambitions, embittered by the frustration of
9602: the dearest hopes, imprisoned at last in total darkness—a long
9603: seed-time without a harvest—was at an end now, and all that remained of
9604: it besides the tablet in Sante Croce and the unfinished commentary on
9605: Tito’s text, was the collection of manuscripts and antiquities, the
9606: fruit of half a century’s toil and frugality. The fulfilment of her
9607: father’s lifelong ambition about this library was a sacramental
9608: obligation for Romola.
9609: 
9610: The precious relic was safe from creditors, for when the deficit
9611: towards their payment had been ascertained, Bernardo del Nero, though
9612: he was far from being among the wealthiest Florentines, had advanced
9613: the necessary sum of about a thousand florins—a large sum in those
9614: days—accepting a lien on the collection as a security.
9615: 
9616: “The State will repay me,” he had said to Romola, making light of the
9617: service, which had really cost him some inconvenience. “If the cardinal
9618: finds a building, as he seems to say he will, our Signoria may consent
9619: to do the rest. I have no children, I can afford the risk.”
9620: 
9621: But within the last ten days all hopes in the Medici had come to an
9622: end: and the famous Medicean collections in the Via Larga were
9623: themselves in danger of dispersion. French agents had already begun to
9624: see that such very fine antique gems as Lorenzo had collected belonged
9625: by right to the first nation in Europe; and the Florentine State, which
9626: had got possession of the Medicean library, was likely to be glad of a
9627: customer for it. With a war to recover Pisa hanging over it, and with
9628: the certainty of having to pay large subsidies to the French king, the
9629: State was likely to prefer money to manuscripts.
9630: 
9631: To Romola these grave political changes had gathered their chief
9632: interest from their bearing on the fulfilment of her father’s wish. She
9633: had been brought up in learned seclusion from the interests of actual
9634: life, and had been accustomed to think of heroic deeds and great
9635: principles as something antithetic to the vulgar present, of the Pnyx
9636: and the Forum as something more worthy of attention than the councils
9637: of living Florentine men. And now the expulsion of the Medici meant
9638: little more for her than the extinction of her best hope about her
9639: father’s library. The times, she knew, were unpleasant for friends of
9640: the Medici, like her godfather and Tito: superstitious shopkeepers and
9641: the stupid rabble were full of suspicions; but her new keen interest in
9642: public events, in the outbreak of war, in the issue of the French
9643: king’s visit, in the changes that were likely to happen in the State,
9644: was kindled solely by the sense of love and duty to her father’s
9645: memory. All Romola’s ardour had been concentrated in her affections.
9646: Her share in her father’s learned pursuits had been for her little more
9647: than a toil which was borne for his sake; and Tito’s airy brilliant
9648: faculty had no attraction for her that was not merged in the deeper
9649: sympathies that belong to young love and trust. Romola had had contact
9650: with no mind that could stir the larger possibilities of her nature;
9651: they lay folded and crushed like embryonic wings, making no element in
9652: her consciousness beyond an occasional vague uneasiness.
9653: 
9654: But this new personal interest of hers in public affairs had made her
9655: care at last to understand precisely what influence Fra Girolamo’s
9656: preaching was likely to have on the turn of events. Changes in the form
9657: of the State were talked of, and all she could learn from Tito, whose
9658: secretaryship and serviceable talents carried him into the heart of
9659: public business, made her only the more eager to fill out her lonely
9660: day by going to hear for herself what it was that was just now leading
9661: all Florence by the ears. This morning, for the first time, she had
9662: been to hear one of the Advent sermons in the Duomo. When Tito had left
9663: her, she had formed a sudden resolution, and after visiting the spot
9664: where her father was buried in Santa Croce, had walked on to the Duomo.
9665: The memory of that last scene with Dino was still vivid within her
9666: whenever she recalled it, but it had receded behind the experience and
9667: anxieties of her married life. The new sensibilities and questions
9668: which it had half awakened in her were quieted again by that subjection
9669: to her husband’s mind which is felt by every wife who loves her husband
9670: with passionate devotedness and full reliance. She remembered the
9671: effect of Fra Girolamo’s voice and presence on her as a ground for
9672: expecting that his sermon might move her in spite of his being a
9673: narrow-minded monk. But the sermon did no more than slightly deepen her
9674: previous impression, that this fanatical preacher of tribulations was
9675: after all a man towards whom it might be possible for her to feel
9676: personal regard and reverence. The denunciations and exhortations
9677: simply arrested her attention. She felt no terror, no pangs of
9678: conscience: it was the roll of distant thunder, that seemed grand, but
9679: could not shake her. But when she heard Savonarola invoke martyrdom,
9680: she sobbed with the rest: she felt herself penetrated with a new
9681: sensation—a strange sympathy with something apart from all the
9682: definable interests of her life. It was not altogether unlike the
9683: thrill which had accompanied certain rare heroic touches in history and
9684: poetry; but the resemblance was as that between the memory of music,
9685: and the sense of being possessed by actual vibrating harmonies.
9686: 
9687: But that transient emotion, strong as it was, seemed to lie quite
9688: outside the inner chamber and sanctuary of her life. She was not
9689: thinking of Fra Girolamo now; she was listening anxiously for the step
9690: of her husband. During these three months of their double solitude she
9691: had thought of each day as an epoch in which their union might begin to
9692: be more perfect. She was conscious of being sometimes a little too sad
9693: or too urgent about what concerned her father’s memory—a little too
9694: critical or coldly silent when Tito narrated the things that were said
9695: and done in the world he frequented—a little too hasty in suggesting
9696: that by living quite simply as her father had done, they might become
9697: rich enough to pay Bernardo del Nero, and reduce the difficulties about
9698: the library. It was not possible that Tito could feel so strongly on
9699: this last point as she did, and it was asking a great deal from him to
9700: give up luxuries for which he really laboured. The next time Tito came
9701: home she would be careful to suppress all those promptings that seemed
9702: to isolate her from him. Romola was labouring, as a loving woman must,
9703: to subdue her nature to her husband’s. The great need of her heart
9704: compelled her to strangle, with desperate resolution, every rising
9705: impulse of suspicion, pride, and resentment; she felt equal to any
9706: self-infliction that would save her from ceasing to love. That would
9707: have been like the hideous nightmare in which the world had seemed to
9708: break away all round her, and leave her feet overhanging the darkness.
9709: Romola had never distinctly imagined such a future for herself; she was
9710: only beginning to feel the presence of effort in that clinging trust
9711: which had once been mere repose.
9712: 
9713: She waited and listened long, for Tito had not come straight home after
9714: leaving Niccolò Caparra, and it was more than two hours after the time
9715: when he was crossing the Ponte Rubaconte that Romola heard the great
9716: door of the court turning on its hinges, and hastened to the head of
9717: the stone steps. There was a lamp hanging over the stairs, and they
9718: could see each other distinctly as he ascended. The eighteen months had
9719: produced a more definable change in Romola’s face than in Tito’s; the
9720: expression was more subdued, less cold, and more beseeching, and, as
9721: the pink flush overspread her face now, in her joy that the long
9722: waiting was at an end, she was much lovelier than on the day when Tito
9723: had first seen her. On that day, any on-looker would have said that
9724: Romola’s nature was made to command, and Tito’s to bend; yet now
9725: Romola’s mouth was quivering a little, and there was some timidity in
9726: her glance.
9727: 
9728: He made an effort to smile, as she said—
9729: 
9730: “My Tito, you are tired; it has been a fatiguing day: is it not true?”
9731: 
9732: Maso was there, and no more was said until they had crossed the
9733: ante-chamber and closed the door of the library behind them. The wood
9734: was burning brightly on the great dogs; that was one welcome for Tito,
9735: late as he was, and Romola’s gentle voice was another.
9736: 
9737: He just turned and kissed her when she took off his mantle; then he
9738: went towards a high-backed chair placed for him near the fire, threw
9739: himself into it, and flung away his cap, saying, not peevishly, but in
9740: a fatigued tone of remonstrance, as he gave a slight shudder—
9741: 
9742: “Romola, I wish you would give up sitting in this library. Surely our
9743: own rooms are pleasanter in this chill weather.”
9744: 
9745: Romola felt hurt. She had never seen Tito so indifferent in his manner;
9746: he was usually full of lively solicitous attention. And she had thought
9747: so much of his return to her after the long day’s absence! He must be
9748: very weary.
9749: 
9750: “I wonder you have forgotten, Tito,” she answered, looking at him
9751: anxiously, as if she wanted to read an excuse for him in the signs of
9752: bodily fatigue. “You know I am making the catalogue on the new plan
9753: that my father wished for; you have not time to help me, so I must work
9754: at it closely.”
9755: 
9756: Tito, instead of meeting Romola’s glance, closed his eyes and rubbed
9757: his hands over his face and hair. He felt he was behaving unlike
9758: himself, but he would make amends to-morrow. The terrible resurrection
9759: of secret fears, which, if Romola had known them, would have alienated
9760: her from him for ever, caused him to feel an alienation already begun
9761: between them—caused him to feel a certain repulsion towards a woman
9762: from whose mind he was in danger. The feeling had taken hold of him
9763: unawares, and he was vexed with himself for behaving in this new cold
9764: way to her. He could not suddenly command any affectionate looks or
9765: words; he could only exert himself to say what might serve as an
9766: excuse.
9767: 
9768: “I am not well, Romola; you must not be surprised if I am peevish.”
9769: 
9770: “Ah, you have had so much to tire you to-day,” said Romola, kneeling
9771: down close to him, and laying her arm on his chest while she put his
9772: hair back caressingly.
9773: 
9774: Suddenly she drew her arm away with a start, and a gaze of alarmed
9775: inquiry.
9776: 
9777: “What have you got under your tunic, Tito? Something as hard as iron.”
9778: 
9779: “It _is_ iron—it is chain-armour,” he said at once. He was prepared for
9780: the surprise and the question, and he spoke quietly, as of something
9781: that he was not hurried to explain.
9782: 
9783: “There was some unexpected danger to-day, then?” said Romola, in a tone
9784: of conjecture. “You had it lent to you for the procession?”
9785: 
9786: “No; it is my own. I shall be obliged to wear it constantly, for some
9787: time.”
9788: 
9789: “What is it that threatens you, my Tito?” said Romola, looking
9790: terrified, and clinging to him again.
9791: 
9792: “Every one is threatened in these times, who is not a rabid enemy of
9793: the Medici. Don’t look distressed, my Romola—this armour will make me
9794: safe against covert attacks.”
9795: 
9796: Tito put his hand on her neck and smiled. This little dialogue about
9797: the armour had broken through the new crust, and made a channel for the
9798: sweet habit of kindness.
9799: 
9800: “But my godfather, then,” said Romola; “is not he, too, in danger? And
9801: he takes no precautions—ought he not? since he must surely be in more
9802: danger than you, who have so little influence compared with him.”
9803: 
9804: “It is just because I am less important that I am in more danger,” said
9805: Tito, readily. “I am suspected constantly of being an envoy. And men
9806: like Messer Bernardo are protected by their position and their
9807: extensive family connections, which spread among all parties, while I
9808: am a Greek that nobody would avenge.”
9809: 
9810: “But, Tito, is it a fear of some particular person, or only a vague
9811: sense of danger, that has made you think of wearing this?” Romola was
9812: unable to repel the idea of a degrading fear in Tito, which mingled
9813: itself with her anxiety.
9814: 
9815: “I have had special threats,” said Tito, “but I must beg you to be
9816: silent on the subject, my Romola. I shall consider that you have broken
9817: my confidence, if you mention it to your godfather.”
9818: 
9819: “Assuredly I will not mention it,” said Romola, blushing, “if you wish
9820: it to be a secret. But, dearest Tito,” she added, after a moment’s
9821: pause, in a tone of loving anxiety, “it will make you very wretched.”
9822: 
9823: “What will make me wretched?” he said, with a scarcely perceptible
9824: movement across his face, as from some darting sensation.
9825: 
9826: “This fear—this heavy armour. I can’t help shuddering as I feel it
9827: under my arm. I could fancy it a story of enchantment—that some
9828: malignant fiend had changed your sensitive human skin into a hard
9829: shell. It seems so unlike my bright, light-hearted Tito!”
9830: 
9831: “Then you would rather have your husband exposed to danger, when he
9832: leaves you?” said Tito, smiling. “If you don’t mind my being poniarded
9833: or shot, why need I mind? I will give up the armour—shall I?”
9834: 
9835: “No, Tito, no. I am fanciful. Do not heed what I have said. But such
9836: crimes are surely not common in Florence? I have always heard my father
9837: and godfather say so. Have they become frequent lately?”
9838: 
9839: “It is not unlikely they will become frequent, with the bitter hatreds
9840: that are being bred continually.”
9841: 
9842: Romola was silent a few moments. She shrank from insisting further on
9843: the subject of the armour. She tried to shake it off.
9844: 
9845: “Tell me what has happened to-day,” she said, in a cheerful tone. “Has
9846: all gone off well?”
9847: 
9848: “Excellently well. First of all, the rain came and put an end to Luca
9849: Corsini’s oration, which nobody wanted to hear, and a ready-tongued
9850: personage—some say it was Gaddi, some say it was Melema, but really it
9851: was done so quickly no one knows who it was—had the honour of giving
9852: the Cristianissimo the briefest possible welcome in bad French.”
9853: 
9854: “Tito, it was you, I know,” said Romola, smiling brightly, and kissing
9855: him. “How is it you never care about claiming anything? And after
9856: that?”
9857: 
9858: “Oh! after that, there was a shower of armour and jewels, and
9859: trappings, such as you saw at the last Florentine _giostra_, only a
9860: great deal more of them. There was strutting, and prancing, and
9861: confusion, and scrambling, and the people shouted, and the
9862: Cristianissimo smiled from ear to ear. And after that there was a great
9863: deal of flattery, and eating, and play. I was at Tornabuoni’s. I will
9864: tell you about it to-morrow.”
9865: 
9866: “Yes, dearest, never mind now. But is there any more hope that things
9867: will end peaceably for Florence, that the Republic will not get into
9868: fresh troubles?”
9869: 
9870: Tito gave a shrug. “Florence will have no peace but what it pays well
9871: for; that is clear.”
9872: 
9873: Romola’s face saddened, but she checked herself, and said, cheerfully,
9874: “You would not guess where I went to-day, Tito. I went to the Duomo, to
9875: hear Fra Girolamo.”
9876: 
9877: Tito looked startled; he had immediately thought of Baldassarre’s
9878: entrance into the Duomo; but Romola gave his look another meaning.
9879: 
9880: “You are surprised, are you not? It was a sudden thought. I want to
9881: know all about the public affairs now, and I determined to hear for
9882: myself what the Frate promised the people about this French invasion.”
9883: 
9884: “Well, and what did you think of the prophet?”
9885: 
9886: “He certainly has a very mysterious power, that man. A great deal of
9887: his sermon was what I expected; but once I was strangely moved—I sobbed
9888: with the rest.”
9889: 
9890: “Take care, Romola,” said Tito, playfully, feeling relieved that she
9891: had said nothing about Baldassarre; “you have a touch of fanaticism in
9892: you. I shall have you seeing visions, like your brother.”
9893: 
9894: “No; it was the same with every one else. He carried them all with him;
9895: unless it were that gross Dolfo Spini, whom I saw there making
9896: grimaces. There was even a wretched-looking man, with a rope round his
9897: neck—an escaped prisoner, I should think, who had run in for shelter—a
9898: very wild-eyed old man: I saw him with great tears rolling down his
9899: cheeks, as he looked and listened quite eagerly.”
9900: 
9901: There was a slight pause before Tito spoke.
9902: 
9903: “I saw the man,” he said,—“the prisoner. I was outside the Duomo with
9904: Lorenzo Tornabuoni when he ran in. He had escaped from a French
9905: soldier. Did you see him when you came out?”
9906: 
9907: “No, he went out with our good old Piero di Cosimo. I saw Piero come in
9908: and cut off his rope, and take him out of the church. But you want
9909: rest, Tito? You feel ill?”
9910: 
9911: “Yes,” said Tito, rising. The horrible sense that he must live in
9912: continual dread of what Baldassarre had said or done pressed upon him
9913: like a cold weight.
9914: 
9915: 
9916: 
9917: 
9918: CHAPTER XXVIII.
9919: The Painted Record.
9920: 
9921: 
9922: Four days later, Romola was on her way to the house of Piero di Cosimo,
9923: in the Via Gualfonda. Some of the streets through which she had to pass
9924: were lined with Frenchmen who were gazing at Florence, and with
9925: Florentines who were gazing at the French, and the gaze was not on
9926: either side entirely friendly and admiring. The first nation in Europe,
9927: of necessity finding itself, when out of its own country, in the
9928: presence of general inferiority, naturally assumed an air of conscious
9929: pre-eminence; and the Florentines, who had taken such pains to play the
9930: host amiably, were getting into the worst humour with their too
9931: superior guests.
9932: 
9933: For after the first smiling compliments and festivities were over—after
9934: wondrous Mysteries with unrivalled machinery of floating clouds and
9935: angels had been presented in churches—after the royal guest had
9936: honoured Florentine dames with much of his Most Christian ogling at
9937: balls and suppers, and business had begun to be talked of—it appeared
9938: that the new Charlemagne regarded Florence as a conquered city,
9939: inasmuch as he had entered it with his lance in rest, talked of leaving
9940: his viceroy behind him, and had thoughts of bringing back the Medici.
9941: Singular logic this appeared to be on the part of an elect instrument
9942: of God! since the policy of Piero de’ Medici, disowned by the people,
9943: had been the only offence of Florence against the majesty of France.
9944: And Florence was determined not to submit. The determination was being
9945: expressed very strongly in consultations of citizens inside the Old
9946: Palace, and it was beginning to show itself on the broad flags of the
9947: streets and piazza wherever there was an opportunity of flouting an
9948: insolent Frenchman. Under these circumstances the streets were not
9949: altogether a pleasant promenade for well-born women; but Romola,
9950: shrouded in her black veil and mantle, and with old Maso by her side,
9951: felt secure enough from impertinent observation.
9952: 
9953: And she was impatient to visit Piero di Cosimo. A copy of her father’s
9954: portrait as Oedipus, which he had long ago undertaken to make for her,
9955: was not yet finished; and Piero was so uncertain in his work—sometimes,
9956: when the demand was not peremptory, laying aside a picture for months;
9957: sometimes thrusting it into a corner or coffer, where it was likely to
9958: be utterly forgotten—that she felt it necessary to watch over his
9959: progress. She was a favourite with the painter, and he was inclined to
9960: fulfil any wish of hers, but no general inclination could be trusted as
9961: a safeguard against his sudden whims. He had told her the week before
9962: that the picture would perhaps be finished by this time; and Romola was
9963: nervously anxious to have in her possession a copy of the only portrait
9964: existing of her father in the days of his blindness, lest his image
9965: should grow dim in her mind. The sense of defect in her devotedness to
9966: him made her cling with all the force of compunction as well as
9967: affection to the duties of memory. Love does not aim simply at the
9968: conscious good of the beloved object: it is not satisfied without
9969: perfect loyalty of heart; it aims at its own completeness.
9970: 
9971: Romola, by special favour, was allowed to intrude upon the painter
9972: without previous notice. She lifted the iron slide and called Piero in
9973: a flute-like tone, as the little maiden with the eggs had done in
9974: Tito’s presence. Piero was quick in answering, but when he opened the
9975: door he accounted for his quickness in a manner that was not
9976: complimentary.
9977: 
9978: “Ah, Madonna Romola, is it you? I thought my eggs were come; I wanted
9979: them.”
9980: 
9981: “I have brought you something better than hard eggs, Piero. Maso has
9982: got a little basket full of cakes and _confetti_ for you,” said Romola,
9983: smiling, as she put back her veil. She took the basket from Maso, and
9984: stepping into the house, said—
9985: 
9986: “I know you like these things when you can have them without trouble.
9987: Confess you do.”
9988: 
9989: “Yes, when they come to me as easily as the light does,” said Piero,
9990: folding his arms and looking down at the sweetmeats as Romola uncovered
9991: them and glanced at him archly. “And they are come along with the light
9992: now,” he added, lifting his eyes to her face and hair with a painter’s
9993: admiration, as her hood, dragged by the weight of her veil, fell
9994: backward.
9995: 
9996: “But I know what the sweetmeats are for,” he went on; “they are to stop
9997: my mouth while you scold me. Well, go on into the next room, and you
9998: will see I’ve done something to the picture since you saw it, though
9999: it’s not finished yet. But I didn’t promise, you know: I take care not
10000: to promise:—
10001: 
10002: 
10003: “‘Chi promette e non mantiene
10004: L’anima sua non va mai bene.’”
10005: 
10006: 
10007: The door opening on the wild garden was closed now, and the painter was
10008: at work. Not at Romola’s picture, however. That was standing on the
10009: floor, propped against the wall, and Piero stooped to lift it, that he
10010: might carry it into the proper light. But in lifting away this picture,
10011: he had disclosed another—the oil-sketch of Tito, to which he had made
10012: an important addition within the last few days. It was so much smaller
10013: than the other picture, that it stood far within it, and Piero, apt to
10014: forget where he had placed anything, was not aware of what he had
10015: revealed as, peering at some detail in the painting which he held in
10016: his hands, he went to place it on an easel. But Romola exclaimed,
10017: flushing with astonishment—
10018: 
10019: “That is Tito!”
10020: 
10021: Piero looked round, and gave a silent shrug. He was vexed at his own
10022: forgetfulness.
10023: 
10024: She was still looking at the sketch in astonishment; but presently she
10025: turned towards the painter, and said with puzzled alarm—
10026: 
10027: “What a strange picture! When did you paint it? What does it mean?”
10028: 
10029: “A mere fancy of mine,” said Piero, lifting off his skull-cap,
10030: scratching his head, and making the usual grimace by which he avoided
10031: the betrayal of any feeling. “I wanted a handsome young face for it,
10032: and your husband’s was just the thing.”
10033: 
10034: He went forward, stooped down to the picture, and lifting it away with
10035: its back to Romola, pretended to be giving it a passing examination,
10036: before putting it aside as a thing not good enough to show.
10037: 
10038: But Romola, who had the fact of the armour in her mind, and was
10039: penetrated by this strange coincidence of things which associated Tito
10040: with the idea of fear, went to his elbow and said—
10041: 
10042: “Don’t put it away; let me look again. That man with the rope round his
10043: neck—I saw him—I saw you come to him in the Duomo. What was it that
10044: made you put him into a picture with Tito?”
10045: 
10046: Piero saw no better resource than to tell part of the truth.
10047: 
10048: “It was a mere accident. The man was running away—running up the steps,
10049: and caught hold of your husband: I suppose he had stumbled. I happened
10050: to be there, and saw it, and I thought the savage-looking old fellow
10051: was a good subject. But it’s worth nothing—it’s only a freakish daub of
10052: mine.” Piero ended contemptuously, moving the sketch away with an air
10053: of decision, and putting it on a high shelf. “Come and look at the
10054: Oedipus.”
10055: 
10056: He had shown a little too much anxiety in putting the sketch out of her
10057: sight, and had produced the very impression he had sought to
10058: prevent—that there was really something unpleasant, something
10059: disadvantageous to Tito, in the circumstances out of which the picture
10060: arose. But this impression silenced her: her pride and delicacy shrank
10061: from questioning further, where questions might seem to imply that she
10062: could entertain even a slight suspicion against her husband. She merely
10063: said, in as quiet a tone as she could—
10064: 
10065: “He was a strange piteous-looking man, that prisoner. Do you know
10066: anything more of him?”
10067: 
10068: “No more: I showed him the way to the hospital, that’s all. See, now,
10069: the face of Oedipus is pretty nearly finished; tell me what you think
10070: of it.”
10071: 
10072: Romola now gave her whole attention to her father’s portrait, standing
10073: in long silence before it.
10074: 
10075: “Ah,” she said at last, “you have done what I wanted. You have given it
10076: more of the listening look. My good Piero,”—she turned towards him with
10077: bright moist eyes—“I am very grateful to you.”
10078: 
10079: “Now that’s what I can’t bear in you women,” said Piero, turning
10080: impatiently, and kicking aside the objects that littered the floor—“you
10081: are always pouring out feelings where there’s no call for them. Why
10082: should you be grateful to me for a picture you pay me for, especially
10083: when I make you wait for it? And if I paint a picture, I suppose it’s
10084: for my own pleasure and credit to paint it well, eh? Are you to thank a
10085: man for not being a rogue or a noodle? It’s enough if he himself thanks
10086: Messer Domeneddio, who has made him neither the one nor the other. But
10087: women think walls are held together with honey.”
10088: 
10089: “You crusty Piero! I forgot how snappish you are. Here, put this nice
10090: sweetmeat in your mouth,” said Romola, smiling through her tears, and
10091: taking something very crisp and sweet from the little basket.
10092: 
10093: Piero accepted it very much as that proverbial bear that dreams of
10094: pears might accept an exceedingly mellow “swan-egg”—really liking the
10095: gift, but accustomed to have his pleasures and pains concealed under a
10096: shaggy coat.
10097: 
10098: “It’s good, Madonna Antigone,” said Piero, putting his fingers in the
10099: basket for another. He had eaten nothing but hard eggs for a fortnight.
10100: Romola stood opposite him, feeling her new anxiety suspended for a
10101: little while by the sight of this _naïve_ enjoyment.
10102: 
10103: “Good-bye, Piero,” she said, presently, setting down the basket. “I
10104: promise not to thank you if you finish the portrait soon and well I
10105: will tell you, you were bound to do it for your own credit.”
10106: 
10107: “Good,” said Piero, curtly, helping her with much deftness to fold her
10108: mantle and veil round her.
10109: 
10110: “I’m glad she asked no more questions about that sketch,” he thought,
10111: when he had closed the door behind her. “I should be sorry for her to
10112: guess that I thought her fine husband a good model for a coward. But I
10113: made light of it; she’ll not think of it again.”
10114: 
10115: Piero was too sanguine, as open-hearted men are apt to be when they
10116: attempt a little clever simulation. The thought of the picture pressed
10117: more and more on Romola as she walked homeward. She could not help
10118: putting together the two facts of the chain-armour and the encounter
10119: mentioned by Piero between her husband and the prisoner, which had
10120: happened on the morning of the day when the armour was adopted. That
10121: look of terror which the painter had given Tito, had he seen it? What
10122: could it all mean?
10123: 
10124: “It means nothing,” she tried to assure herself. “It was a mere
10125: coincidence. Shall I ask Tito about it?” Her mind said at last, “No: I
10126: will not question him about anything he did not tell me spontaneously.
10127: It is an offence against the trust I owe him.” Her heart said, “I dare
10128: not ask him.”
10129: 
10130: There was a terrible flaw in the trust: she was afraid of any hasty
10131: movement, as men are who hold something precious and want to believe
10132: that it is not broken.
10133: 
10134: 
10135: 
10136: 
10137: CHAPTER XXIX.
10138: A Moment of Triumph.
10139: 
10140: 
10141: “The old fellow has vanished; went on towards Arezzo the next morning;
10142: not liking the smell of the French, I suppose, after being their
10143: prisoner. I went to the hospital to inquire after him; I wanted to know
10144: if those broth-making monks had found out whether he was in his right
10145: mind or not. However, they said he showed no signs of madness—only took
10146: no notice of questions, and seemed to be planting a vine twenty miles
10147: off. He was a mysterious old tiger. I should have liked to know
10148: something more about him.”
10149: 
10150: It was in Nello’s shop that Piero di Cosimo was speaking, on the
10151: twenty-fourth of November, just a week after the entrance of the
10152: French. There was a party of six or seven assembled at the rather
10153: unusual hour of three in the afternoon; for it was a day on which all
10154: Florence was excited by the prospect of some decisive political event.
10155: Every lounging-place was full, and every shopkeeper who had no wife or
10156: deputy to leave in charge, stood at his door with his thumbs in his
10157: belt; while the streets were constantly sprinkled with artisans pausing
10158: or passing lazily like floating splinters, ready to rush forward
10159: impetuously if any object attracted them.
10160: 
10161: Nello had been thrumming the lute as he half sat on the board against
10162: the shop-window, and kept an outlook towards the piazza.
10163: 
10164: “Ah,” he said, laying down the lute, with emphasis, “I would not for a
10165: gold florin have missed that sight of the French soldiers waddling in
10166: their broad shoes after their runaway prisoners! That comes of leaving
10167: my shop to shave magnificent chins. It is always so: if ever I quit
10168: this navel of the earth something takes the opportunity of happening in
10169: my piazza.”
10170: 
10171: “Yes, you ought to have been there,” said Piero, in his biting way,
10172: “just to see your favourite Greek look as frightened as if Satanasso
10173: had laid hold of him. I like to see your ready-smiling Messeri caught
10174: in a sudden wind and obliged to show their lining in spite of
10175: themselves. What colour do you think a man’s liver is, who looks like a
10176: bleached deer as soon as a chance stranger lays hold of him suddenly?”
10177: 
10178: “Piero, keep that vinegar of thine as sauce to thine own eggs! What is
10179: it against my _bel erudito_ that he looked startled when he felt a pair
10180: of claws upon him and saw an unchained madman at his elbow? Your
10181: scholar is not like those beastly Swiss and Germans, whose heads are
10182: only fit for battering-rams, and who have such large appetites that
10183: they think nothing of taking a cannon-ball before breakfast. We
10184: Florentines count some other qualities in a man besides that vulgar
10185: stuff called bravery, which is to be got by hiring dunderheads at so
10186: much per dozen. I tell you, as soon as men found out that they had more
10187: brains than oxen, they set the oxen to draw for them; and when we
10188: Florentines found out that we had more brains than other men we set
10189: them to fight for us.”
10190: 
10191: “Treason, Nello!” a voice called out from the inner sanctum; “that is
10192: not the doctrine of the State. Florence is grinding its weapons; and
10193: the last well-authenticated vision announced by the Frate was Mars
10194: standing on the Palazzo Vecchio with his arm on the shoulder of San
10195: Giovanni Battista, who was offering him a piece of honeycomb.”
10196: 
10197: “It is well, Francesco,” said Nello. “Florence has a few thicker skulls
10198: that may do to bombard Pisa with; there will still be the finer spirits
10199: left at home to do the thinking and the shaving. And as for our Piero
10200: here, if he makes such a point of valour, let him carry his biggest
10201: brush for a weapon and his palette for a shield, and challenge the
10202: widest-mouthed Swiss he can see in the Prato to a single combat.”
10203: 
10204: “_Va_, Nello,” growled Piero, “thy tongue runs on as usual, like a mill
10205: when the Arno’s full—whether there’s grist or not.”
10206: 
10207: “Excellent grist, I tell thee. For it would be as reasonable to expect
10208: a grizzled painter like thee to be fond of getting a javelin inside
10209: thee as to expect a man whose wits have been sharpened on the classics
10210: to like having his handsome face clawed by a wild beast.”
10211: 
10212: “There you go, supposing you’ll get people to put their legs into a
10213: sack because you call it a pair of hosen,” said Piero. “Who said
10214: anything about a wild beast, or about an unarmed man rushing on battle?
10215: Fighting is a trade, and it’s not my trade. I should be a fool to run
10216: after danger, but I could face it if it came to me.”
10217: 
10218: “How is it you’re so afraid of the thunder, then, my Piero?” said
10219: Nello, determined to chase down the accuser. “You ought to be able to
10220: understand why one man is shaken by a thing that seems a trifle to
10221: others—you who hide yourself with the rats as soon as a storm comes
10222: on.”
10223: 
10224: “That is because I have a particular sensibility to loud sounds; it has
10225: nothing to do with my courage or my conscience.”
10226: 
10227: “Well, and Tito Melema may have a peculiar sensibility to being laid
10228: hold of unexpectedly by prisoners who have run away from French
10229: soldiers. Men are born with antipathies; I myself can’t abide the smell
10230: of mint. Tito was born with an antipathy to old prisoners who stumble
10231: and clutch. Ecco!”
10232: 
10233: There was a general laugh at Nello’s defence, and it was clear that
10234: Piero’s disinclination towards Tito was not shared by the company. The
10235: painter, with his undecipherable grimace, took the tow from his
10236: scarsella and stuffed his ears in indignant contempt, while Nello went
10237: on triumphantly—
10238: 
10239: “No, my Piero, I can’t afford to have my _bel erudito_ decried; and
10240: Florence can’t afford it either, with her scholars moulting off her at
10241: the early age of forty. Our Phoenix Pico just gone straight to
10242: Paradise, as the Frate has informed us; and the incomparable Poliziano,
10243: not two months since, gone to—well, well, let us hope he is not gone to
10244: the eminent scholars in the Malebolge.”
10245: 
10246: “By the way,” said Francesco Cei, “have you heard that Camilla Rucellai
10247: has outdone the Frate in her prophecies? She prophesied two years ago
10248: that Pico would die in the time of lilies. He has died in November.
10249: ‘Not at all the time of lilies,’ said the scorners. ‘Go to!’ says
10250: Camilla; ‘it is the lilies of France I meant, and it seems to me they
10251: are close enough under your nostrils.’ I say, ‘Euge, Camilla!’ If the
10252: Frate can prove that any one of his visions has been as well fulfilled,
10253: I’ll declare myself a Piagnone to-morrow.”
10254: 
10255: “You are something too flippant about the Frate, Francesco,” said
10256: Pietro Cennini, the scholarly. “We are all indebted to him in these
10257: weeks for preaching peace and quietness, and the laying aside of party
10258: quarrels. They are men of small discernment who would be glad to see
10259: the people slipping the Frate’s leash just now. And if the Most
10260: Christian King is obstinate about the treaty to-day, and will not sign
10261: what is fair and honourable to Florence, Fra Girolamo is the man we
10262: must trust in to bring him to reason.”
10263: 
10264: “You speak truth, Messer Pietro,” said Nello; “the Frate is one of the
10265: firmest nails Florence has to hang on—at least, that is the opinion of
10266: the most respectable chins I have the honour of shaving. But young
10267: Messer Niccolò was saying here the other morning—and doubtless
10268: Francesco means the same thing—there is as wonderful a power of
10269: stretching in the meaning of visions as in Dido’s bull’s hide. It seems
10270: to me a dream may mean whatever comes after it. As our Franco Sacchetti
10271: says, a woman dreams over-night of a serpent biting her, breaks a
10272: drinking-cup the next day, and cries out, ‘Look you, I thought
10273: something would happen—it’s plain now what the serpent meant.’”
10274: 
10275: “But the Frate’s visions are not of that sort,” said Cronaca. “He not
10276: only says what will happen—that the Church will be scourged and
10277: renovated, and the heathens converted—he says it shall happen quickly.
10278: He is no slippery pretender who provides loopholes for himself, he is—”
10279: 
10280: “What is this? what is this?” exclaimed Nello, jumping off the board,
10281: and putting his head out at the door. “Here are people streaming into
10282: the piazza, and shouting. Something must have happened in the Via
10283: Larga. Aha!” he burst forth with delighted astonishment, stepping out
10284: laughing and waving his cap.
10285: 
10286: All the rest of the company hastened to the door. News from the Via
10287: Larga was just what they had been waiting for. But if the news had come
10288: into the piazza, they were not a little surprised at the form of its
10289: advent. Carried above the shoulders of the people, on a bench
10290: apparently snatched up in the street, sat Tito Melema, in smiling
10291: amusement at the compulsion he was under. His cap had slipped off his
10292: head, and hung by the becchetto which was wound loosely round his neck;
10293: and as he saw the group at Nello’s door he lifted up his fingers in
10294: beckoning recognition. The next minute he had leaped from the bench on
10295: to a cart filled with bales, that stood in the broad space between the
10296: Baptistery and the steps of the Duomo, while the people swarmed round
10297: him with the noisy eagerness of poultry expecting to be fed. But there
10298: was silence when he began to speak in his clear mellow voice—
10299: 
10300: “Citizens of Florence! I have no warrant to tell the news except your
10301: will. But the news is good, and will harm no man in the telling. The
10302: Most Christian King is signing a treaty that is honourable to Florence.
10303: But you owe it to one of your citizens, who spoke a word worthy of the
10304: ancient Romans—you owe it to Piero Capponi!”
10305: 
10306: Immediately there was a roar of voices. “Capponi! Capponi! What said
10307: our Piero?” “Ah! he wouldn’t stand being sent from Herod to Pilate!”
10308: “We knew Piero!” “_Orsù_! Tell us, what did he say?”
10309: 
10310: When the roar of insistence had subsided a little, Tito began again—
10311: 
10312: “The Most Christian King demanded a little too much—was obstinate—said
10313: at last, ‘I shall order my trumpets to sound.’ Then, Florentine
10314: citizens! your Piero Capponi, speaking with the voice of a free city,
10315: said, ‘If you sound your trumpets, we will ring our bells!’ He snatched
10316: the copy of the dishonouring conditions from the hands of the
10317: secretary, tore it in pieces, and turned to leave the royal presence.”
10318: 
10319: Again there were loud shouts—and again impatient demands for more.
10320: 
10321: “Then, Florentines, the high majesty of France felt, perhaps for the
10322: first time, all the majesty of a free city. And the Most Christian King
10323: himself hastened from his place to call Piero Capponi back. The great
10324: spirit of your Florentine city did its work by a great word, without
10325: need of the great actions that lay ready behind it. And the King has
10326: consented to sign the treaty, which preserves the honour, as well as
10327: the safety, of Florence. The banner of France will float over every
10328: Florentine galley in sign of amity and common privilege, but above that
10329: banner will be written the word ‘Liberty!’
10330: 
10331: “That is all the news I have to tell; is it not enough?—since it is for
10332: the glory of every one of you, citizens of Florence, that you have a
10333: fellow-citizen who knows how to speak your will.”
10334: 
10335: As the shouts rose again, Tito looked round with inward amusement at
10336: the various crowd, each of whom was elated with the notion that Piero
10337: Capponi had somehow represented him—that he was the mind of which
10338: Capponi was the mouthpiece. He enjoyed the humour of the incident,
10339: which had suddenly transformed him, an alien, and a friend of the
10340: Medici, into an orator who tickled the ears of the people blatant for
10341: some unknown good which they called liberty. He felt quite glad that he
10342: had been laid hold of and hurried along by the crowd as he was coming
10343: out of the palace in the Via Larga with a commission to the Signoria.
10344: It was very easy, very pleasant, this exercise of speaking to the
10345: general satisfaction: a man who knew how to persuade need never be in
10346: danger from any party; he could convince each that he was feigning with
10347: all the others. The gestures and faces of weavers and dyers were
10348: certainly amusing when looked at from above in this way.
10349: 
10350: Tito was beginning to get easier in his armour, and at this moment was
10351: quite unconscious of it. He stood with one hand holding his recovered
10352: cap, and with the other at his belt, the light of a complacent smile in
10353: his long lustrous eyes, as he made a parting reverence to his audience,
10354: before springing down from the bales—when suddenly his glance met that
10355: of a man who had not at all the amusing aspect of the exulting weavers,
10356: dyers, and woolcarders. The face of this man was clean-shaven, his hair
10357: close-clipped, and he wore a decent felt hat. A single glance would
10358: hardly have sufficed to assure any one but Tito that this was the face
10359: of the escaped prisoner who had laid hold of him on the steps. But to
10360: Tito it came not simply as the face of the escaped prisoner, but as a
10361: face with which he had been familiar long years before.
10362: 
10363: It seemed all compressed into a second—the sight of Baldassarre looking
10364: at him, the sensation shooting through him like a fiery arrow, and the
10365: act of leaping from the cart. He would have leaped down in the same
10366: instant, whether he had seen Baldassarre or not, for he was in a hurry
10367: to be gone to the Palazzo Vecchio: this time he had not betrayed
10368: himself by look or movement, and he said inwardly that he should not be
10369: taken by surprise again; he should be prepared to see this face rise up
10370: continually like the intermittent blotch that comes in diseased vision.
10371: But this reappearance of Baldassarre so much more in his own likeness
10372: tightened the pressure of dread: the idea of his madness lost its
10373: likelihood now he was shaven and clad like a decent though poor
10374: citizen. Certainly, there was a great change in his face; but how could
10375: it be otherwise? And yet, if he were perfectly sane—in possession of
10376: all his powers and all his learning, why was he lingering in this way
10377: before making known his identity? It must be for the sake of making his
10378: scheme of vengeance more complete. But he did linger: that at least
10379: gave an opportunity for flight. And Tito began to think that flight was
10380: his only resource.
10381: 
10382: But while he, with his back turned on the Piazza del Duomo, had lost
10383: the recollection of the new part he had been playing, and was no longer
10384: thinking of the many things which a ready brain and tongue made easy,
10385: but of a few things which destiny had somehow made very difficult, the
10386: enthusiasm which he had fed contemptuously was creating a scene in that
10387: piazza in grand contrast with the inward drama of self-centred fear
10388: which he had carried away from it.
10389: 
10390: The crowd, on Tito’s disappearance, had begun to turn their faces
10391: towards the outlets of the piazza in the direction of the Via Larga,
10392: when the sight of _mazzieri_, or mace-bearers, entering from the Via
10393: de’ Martelli, announced the approach of dignitaries. They must be the
10394: syndics, or commissioners charged with the effecting of the treaty; the
10395: treaty must be already signed, and they had come away from the royal
10396: presence. Piero Capponi was coming—the brave heart that had known how
10397: to speak for Florence. The effect on the crowd was remarkable; they
10398: parted with softening, dropping voices, subsiding into silence,—and the
10399: silence became so perfect that the tread of the syndics on the broad
10400: pavement, and the rustle of their black silk garments, could be heard,
10401: like rain in the night. There were four of them; but it was not the two
10402: learned doctors of law, Messer Guidantonio Vespucci and Messer Domenico
10403: Bonsi, that the crowd waited for; it was not Francesco Valori, popular
10404: as he had become in these late days. The moment belonged to another
10405: man, of firm presence, as little inclined to humour the people as to
10406: humour any other unreasonable claimants—loving order, like one who by
10407: force of fortune had been made a merchant, and by force of nature had
10408: become a soldier. It was not till he was seen at the entrance of the
10409: piazza that the silence was broken, and then one loud shout of
10410: “Capponi, Capponi! Well done, Capponi!” rang through the piazza.
10411: 
10412: The simple, resolute man looked round him with grave joy. His
10413: fellow-citizens gave him a great funeral two years later, when he had
10414: died in fight; there were torches carried by all the magistracy, and
