10415: torches again, and trains of banners. But it is not known that he felt
10416: any joy in the oration that was delivered in his praise, as the banners
10417: waved over his bier. Let us be glad that he got some thanks and praise
10418: while he lived.
10419: 
10420: 
10421: 
10422: 
10423: CHAPTER XXX.
10424: The Avenger’s Secret.
10425: 
10426: 
10427: It was the first time that Baldassarre had been in the Piazza del Duomo
10428: since his escape. He had a strong desire to hear the remarkable monk
10429: preach again, but he had shrunk from reappearing in the same spot where
10430: he had been seen half naked, with neglected hair, with a rope round his
10431: neck—in the same spot where he had been called a madman. The feeling,
10432: in its freshness, was too strong to be overcome by any trust he had in
10433: the change he had made in his appearance; for when the words “_some
10434: madman, surely_,” had fallen from Tito’s lips, it was not their
10435: baseness and cruelty only that had made their viper sting—it was
10436: Baldassarre’s instantaneous bitter consciousness that he might be
10437: unable to prove the words false. Along with the passionate desire for
10438: vengeance which possessed him had arisen the keen sense that his power
10439: of achieving the vengeance was doubtful. It was as if Tito had been
10440: helped by some diabolical prompter, who had whispered Baldassarre’s
10441: saddest secret in the traitor’s ear. He was not mad; for he carried
10442: within him that piteous stamp of sanity, the clear consciousness of
10443: shattered faculties; he measured his own feebleness. With the first
10444: movement of vindictive rage awoke a vague caution, like that of a wild
10445: beast that is fierce but feeble—or like that of an insect whose little
10446: fragment of earth has given way, and made it pause in a palsy of
10447: distrust. It was this distrust, this determination to take no step
10448: which might betray anything concerning himself, that had made
10449: Baldassarre reject Piero di Cosimo’s friendly advances.
10450: 
10451: He had been equally cautious at the hospital, only telling, in answer
10452: to the questions of the brethren there, that he had been made a
10453: prisoner by the French on his way from Genoa. But his age, and the
10454: indications in his speech and manner that he was of a different class
10455: from the ordinary mendicants and poor travellers who were entertained
10456: in the hospital, had induced the monks to offer him extra charity: a
10457: coarse woollen tunic to protect him from the cold, a pair of peasant’s
10458: shoes, and a few _danari_, smallest of Florentine coins, to help him on
10459: his way. He had gone on the road to Arezzo early in the morning; but he
10460: had paused at the first little town, and had used a couple of his
10461: _danari_ to get himself shaved, and to have his circle of hair clipped
10462: short, in his former fashion. The barber there had a little hand-mirror
10463: of bright steel: it was a long while, it was years, since Baldassarre
10464: had looked at himself, and now, as his eyes fell on that hand-mirror, a
10465: new thought shot through his mind. “Was he so changed that Tito really
10466: did not know him?” The thought was such a sudden arrest of impetuous
10467: currents, that it was a painful shock to him; his hand shook like a
10468: leaf, as he put away the barber’s arm and asked for the mirror. He
10469: wished to see himself before he was shaved. The barber, noticing his
10470: tremulousness, held the mirror for him.
10471: 
10472: No, he was not so changed as that. He himself had known the wrinkles as
10473: they had been three years ago; they were only deeper now: there was the
10474: same rough, clumsy skin, making little superficial bosses on the brow,
10475: like so many cipher-marks; the skin was only yellower, only looked more
10476: like a lifeless rind. That shaggy white beard—it was no disguise to
10477: eyes that had looked closely at him for sixteen years—to eyes that
10478: ought to have searched for him with the expectation of finding him
10479: changed, as men search for the beloved among the bodies cast up by the
10480: waters. There was something different in his glance, but it was a
10481: difference that should only have made the recognition of him the more
10482: startling; for is not a known voice all the more thrilling when it is
10483: heard as a cry? But the doubt was folly: he had felt that Tito knew
10484: him. He put out his hand and pushed the mirror away. The strong
10485: currents were rushing on again, and the energies of hatred and
10486: vengeance were active once more.
10487: 
10488: He went back on the way towards Florence again, but he did not wish to
10489: enter the city till dusk; so he turned aside from the highroad, and sat
10490: down by a little pool shadowed on one side by alder-bushes still
10491: sprinkled with yellow leaves. It was a calm November day, and he no
10492: sooner saw the pool than he thought its still surface might be a mirror
10493: for him. He wanted to contemplate himself slowly, as he had not dared
10494: to do in the presence of the barber. He sat down on the edge of the
10495: pool, and bent forward to look earnestly at the image of himself.
10496: 
10497: Was there something wandering and imbecile in his face—something like
10498: what he felt in his mind?
10499: 
10500: Not now; not when he was examining himself with a look of eager
10501: inquiry: on the contrary, there was an intense purpose in his eyes. But
10502: at other times? Yes, it must be so: in the long hours when he had the
10503: vague aching of an unremembered past within him—when he seemed to sit
10504: in dark loneliness, visited by whispers which died out mockingly as he
10505: strained his ear after them, and by forms that seemed to approach him
10506: and float away as he thrust out his hand to grasp them—in those hours,
10507: doubtless, there must be continual frustration and amazement in his
10508: glance. And more horrible still, when the thick cloud parted for a
10509: moment, and, as he sprang forward with hope, rolled together again, and
10510: left him helpless as before; doubtless, there was then a blank
10511: confusion in his face, as of a man suddenly smitten with blindness.
10512: 
10513: Could he prove anything? Could he even begin to allege anything, with
10514: the confidence that the links of thought would not break away? Would
10515: any believe that he had ever had a mind filled with rare knowledge,
10516: busy with close thoughts, ready with various speech? It had all slipped
10517: away from him—that laboriously-gathered store. Was it utterly and for
10518: ever gone from him, like the waters from an urn lost in the wide ocean?
10519: Or, was it still within him, imprisoned by some obstruction that might
10520: one day break asunder?
10521: 
10522: It might be so; he tried to keep his grasp on that hope. For, since the
10523: day when he had first walked feebly from his couch of straw, and had
10524: felt a new darkness within him under the sunlight, his mind had
10525: undergone changes, partly gradual and persistent, partly sudden and
10526: fleeting. As he had recovered his strength of body, he had recovered
10527: his self-command and the energy of his will; he had recovered the
10528: memory of all that part of his life which was closely enwrought with
10529: his emotions; and he had felt more and more constantly and painfully
10530: the uneasy sense of lost knowledge. But more than that—once or twice,
10531: when he had been strongly excited, he had seemed momentarily to be in
10532: entire possession of his past self, as old men doze for an instant and
10533: get back the consciousness of their youth: he seemed again to see Greek
10534: pages and understand them, again to feel his mind moving unbenumbed
10535: among familiar ideas. It had been but a flash, and the darkness closing
10536: in again seemed the more horrible; but might not the same thing happen
10537: again for longer periods? If it would only come and stay long enough
10538: for him to achieve a revenge—devise an exquisite suffering, such as a
10539: mere right arm could never inflict!
10540: 
10541: He raised himself from his stooping attitude, and, folding his arms,
10542: attempted to concentrate all his mental force on the plan he must
10543: immediately pursue. He had to wait for knowledge and opportunity, and
10544: while he waited he must have the means of living without beggary. What
10545: he dreaded of all things now was, that any one should think him a
10546: foolish, helpless old man. No one must know that half his memory was
10547: gone: the lost strength might come again; and if it were only for a
10548: little while, _that_ might be enough.
10549: 
10550: He knew how to begin to get the information he wanted about Tito. He
10551: had repeated the words “Bratti Ferravecchi” so constantly after they
10552: had been uttered to him, that they never slipped from him for long
10553: together. A man at Genoa, on whose finger he had seen Tito’s ring, had
10554: told him that he bought that ring at Florence, of a young Greek,
10555: well-dressed, and with a handsome dark face, in the shop of a
10556: _rigattiere_ called Bratti Ferravecchi, in the street also called
10557: Ferravecchi. This discovery had caused a violent agitation in
10558: Baldassarre. Until then he had clung with all the tenacity of his
10559: fervent nature to his faith in Tito, and had not for a moment believed
10560: himself to be wilfully forsaken. At first he had said, “My bit of
10561: parchment has never reached him; that is why I am still toiling at
10562: Antioch. But he is searching; he knows where I was lost: he will trace
10563: me out, and find me at last.” Then, when he was taken to Corinth, he
10564: induced his owners, by the assurance that he should be sought out and
10565: ransomed, to provide securely against the failure of any inquiries that
10566: might be made about him at Antioch; and at Corinth he thought joyfully,
10567: “Here, at last, he must find me. Here he is sure to touch, whichever
10568: way he goes.” But before another year had passed, the illness had come
10569: from which he had risen with body and mind so shattered that he was
10570: worse than worthless to his owners, except for the sake of the ransom
10571: that did not come. Then, as he sat helpless in the morning sunlight, he
10572: began to think, “Tito has been drowned, or they have made _him_ a
10573: prisoner too. I shall see him no more. He set out after me, but
10574: misfortune overtook him. I shall see his face no more.” Sitting in his
10575: new feebleness and despair, supporting his head between his hands, with
10576: blank eyes and lips that moved uncertainly, he looked so much like a
10577: hopelessly imbecile old man, that his owners were contented to be rid
10578: of him, and allowed a Genoese merchant, who had compassion on him as an
10579: Italian, to take him on board his galley. In a voyage of many months in
10580: the Archipelago and along the seaboard of Asia Minor, Baldassarre had
10581: recovered his bodily strength, but on landing at Genoa he had so weary
10582: a sense of his desolateness that he almost wished he had died of that
10583: illness at Corinth. There was just one possibility that hindered the
10584: wish from being decided: it was that Tito might not be dead, but living
10585: in a state of imprisonment or destitution; and if he lived, there was
10586: still a hope for Baldassarre—faint, perhaps, and likely to be long
10587: deferred, but still a hope, that he might find his child, his cherished
10588: son again; might yet again clasp hands and meet face to face with the
10589: one being who remembered him as he had been before his mind was broken.
10590: In this state of feeling he had chanced to meet the stranger who wore
10591: Tito’s onyx ring, and though Baldassarre would have been unable to
10592: describe the ring beforehand, the sight of it stirred the dormant
10593: fibres, and he recognised it. That Tito nearly a year after his father
10594: had been parted from him should have been living in apparent prosperity
10595: at Florence, selling the gem which he ought not to have sold till the
10596: last extremity, was a fact that Baldassarre shrank from trying to
10597: account for: he was glad to be stunned and bewildered by it, rather
10598: than to have any distinct thought; he tried to feel nothing but joy
10599: that he should behold Tito again. Perhaps Tito had thought that his
10600: father was dead; somehow the mystery would be explained. “But at least
10601: I shall meet eyes that will remember me. I am not alone in the world.”
10602: 
10603: And now again Baldassarre said, “I am not alone in the world; I shall
10604: never be alone, for my revenge is with me.”
10605: 
10606: It was as the instrument of that revenge, as something merely external
10607: and subservient to his true life, that he bent down again to examine
10608: himself with hard curiosity—not, he thought, because he had any care
10609: for a withered, forsaken old man, whom nobody loved, whose soul was
10610: like a deserted home, where the ashes were cold upon the hearth, and
10611: the walls were bare of all but the marks of what had been. It is in the
10612: nature of all human passion, the lowest as well as the highest, that
10613: there is a point where it ceases to be properly egoistic, and is like a
10614: fire kindled within our being to which everything else in us is mere
10615: fuel.
10616: 
10617: He looked at the pale black-browed image in the water till he
10618: identified it with that self from which his revenge seemed to be a
10619: thing apart; and he felt as if the image too heard the silent language
10620: of his thought.
10621: 
10622: “I was a loving fool—I worshipped a woman once, and believed she could
10623: care for me; and then I took a helpless child and fostered him; and I
10624: watched him as he grew, to see if he would care for me only a
10625: little—care for _me_ over and above the good he got from me. I would
10626: have torn open my breast to warm him with my life-blood if I could only
10627: have seen him care a little for the pain of my wound. I have laboured,
10628: I have strained to crush out of this hard life one drop of unselfish
10629: love. Fool! men love their own delights; there is no delight to be had
10630: in me. And yet I watched till I believed I saw what I watched for. When
10631: he was a child he lifted soft eyes towards me, and held my hand
10632: willingly: I thought, this boy will surely love me a little: because I
10633: give my life to him and strive that he shall know no sorrow, he will
10634: care a little when I am thirsty—the drop he lays on my parched lips
10635: will be a joy to him... Curses on him! I wish I may see him lie with
10636: those red lips white and dry as ashes, and when he looks for pity I
10637: wish he may see my face rejoicing in his pain. It is all a lie—this
10638: world is a lie—there is no goodness but in hate. Fool! not one drop of
10639: love came with all your striving: life has not given you one drop. But
10640: there are deep draughts in this world for hatred and revenge. I have
10641: memory left for that, and there is strength in my arm—there is strength
10642: in my will—and if I can do nothing but kill him—”
10643: 
10644: But Baldassarre’s mind rejected the thought of that brief punishment.
10645: His whole soul had been thrilled into immediate unreasoning belief in
10646: that eternity of vengeance where he, an undying hate, might clutch for
10647: ever an undying traitor, and hear that fair smiling hardness cry and
10648: moan with anguish. But the primary need and hope was to see a slow
10649: revenge under the same sky and on the same earth where he himself had
10650: been forsaken and had fainted with despair. And as soon as he tried to
10651: concentrate his mind on the means of attaining his end, the sense of
10652: his weakness pressed upon him like a frosty ache. This despised body,
10653: which was to be the instrument of a sublime vengeance, must be
10654: nourished and decently clad. If he had to wait he must labour, and his
10655: labour must be of a humble sort, for he had no skill. He wondered
10656: whether the sight of written characters would so stimulate his
10657: faculties that he might venture to try and find work as a copyist:
10658: _that_ might win him some credence for his past scholarship. But no! he
10659: dared trust neither hand nor brain. He must be content to do the work
10660: that was most like that of a beast of burden: in this mercantile city
10661: many porters must be wanted, and he could at least carry weights.
10662: Thanks to the justice that struggled in this confused world in behalf
10663: of vengeance, his limbs had got back some of their old sturdiness. He
10664: was stripped of all else that men would give coin for.
10665: 
10666: But the new urgency of this habitual thought brought a new suggestion.
10667: There was something hanging by a cord round his bare neck; something
10668: apparently so paltry that the piety of Turks and Frenchmen had spared
10669: it—a tiny parchment bag blackened with age. It had hung round his neck
10670: as a precious charm when he was a boy, and he had kept it carefully on
10671: his breast, not believing that it contained anything but a tiny scroll
10672: of parchment rolled up hard. He might long ago have thrown it away as a
10673: relic of his dead mother’s superstition; but he had thought of it as a
10674: relic of her love, and had kept it. It was part of the piety associated
10675: with such _brevi_, that they should never be opened, and at any
10676: previous moment in his life Baldassarre would have said that no sort of
10677: thirst would prevail upon him to open this little bag for the chance of
10678: finding that it contained, not parchment, but an engraved amulet which
10679: would be worth money. But now a thirst had come like that which makes
10680: men open their own veins to satisfy it, and the thought of the possible
10681: amulet no sooner crossed Baldassarre’s mind than with nervous fingers
10682: he snatched the _breve_ from his neck. It all rushed through his
10683: mind—the long years he had worn it, the far-off sunny balcony at Naples
10684: looking towards the blue waters, where he had leaned against his
10685: mother’s knee; but it made no moment of hesitation: all piety now was
10686: transmuted into a just revenge. He bit and tore till the doubles of
10687: parchment were laid open, and then—it was a sight that made him
10688: pant—there _was_ an amulet. It was very small, but it was as blue as
10689: those far-off waters; it was an engraved sapphire, which must be worth
10690: some gold ducats. Baldassarre no sooner saw those possible ducats than
10691: he saw some of them exchanged for a poniard. He did not want to use the
10692: poniard yet, but he longed to possess it. If he could grasp its handle
10693: and try its edge, that blank in his mind—that past which fell away
10694: continually—would not make him feel so cruelly helpless: the sharp
10695: steel that despised talents and eluded strength would be at his side,
10696: as the unfailing friend of feeble justice. There was a sparkling
10697: triumph under Baldassarre’s black eyebrows as he replaced the little
10698: sapphire inside the bits of parchment and wound the string tightly
10699: round them.
10700: 
10701: It was nearly dusk now, and he rose to walk back towards Florence. With
10702: his _danari_ to buy him some bread, he felt rich: he could lie out in
10703: the open air, as he found plenty more doing in all corners of Florence.
10704: And in the next few days he had sold his sapphire, had added to his
10705: clothing, had bought a bright dagger, and had still a pair of gold
10706: florins left. But he meant to hoard that treasure carefully: his
10707: lodging was an outhouse with a heap of straw in it, in a thinly
10708: inhabited part of Oltrarno, and he thought of looking about for work as
10709: a porter.
10710: 
10711: He had bought his dagger at Bratti’s. Paying his meditated visit there
10712: one evening at dusk, he had found that singular rag-merchant just
10713: returned from one of his rounds, emptying out his basketful of broken
10714: glass and old iron amongst his handsome show of miscellaneous
10715: second-hand goods. As Baldassarre entered the shop, and looked towards
10716: the smart pieces of apparel, the musical instruments, and weapons,
10717: which were displayed in the broadest light of the window, his eye at
10718: once singled out a dagger hanging up high against a red scarf. By
10719: buying the dagger he could not only satisfy a strong desire, he could
10720: open his original errand in a more indirect manner than by speaking of
10721: the onyx ring. In the course of bargaining for the weapon, he let drop,
10722: with cautious carelessness, that he came from Genoa, and had been
10723: directed to Bratti’s shop by an acquaintance in that city who had
10724: bought a very valuable ring here. Had the respectable trader any more
10725: such rings?
10726: 
10727: Whereupon Bratti had much to say as to the unlikelihood of such rings
10728: being within reach of many people, with much vaunting of his own rare
10729: connections, due to his known wisdom, and honesty. It might be true
10730: that he was a pedlar—he chose to be a pedlar; though he was rich enough
10731: to kick his heels in his shop all day. But those who thought they had
10732: said all there was to be said about Bratti when they had called him a
10733: pedlar, were a good deal further off the truth than the other side of
10734: Pisa. How was it that he could put that ring in a stranger’s way? It
10735: was, because he had a very particular knowledge of a handsome young
10736: signor, who did not look quite so fine a feathered bird when Bratti
10737: first set eyes on him as he did at the present time. And by a question
10738: or two Baldassarre extracted, without any trouble, such a rough and
10739: rambling account of Tito’s life as the pedlar could give, since the
10740: time when he had found him sleeping under the Loggia de’ Cerchi. It
10741: never occurred to Bratti that the decent man (who was rather deaf,
10742: apparently, asking him to say many things twice over) had any curiosity
10743: about Tito; the curiosity was doubtless about himself, as a truly
10744: remarkable pedlar.
10745: 
10746: And Baldassarre left Bratti’s shop, not only with the dagger at his
10747: side, but also with a general knowledge of Tito’s conduct and
10748: position—of his early sale of the jewels, his immediate quiet
10749: settlement of himself at Florence, his marriage, and his great
10750: prosperity.
10751: 
10752: “What story had he told about his previous life—about his father?”
10753: 
10754: It would be difficult for Baldassarre to discover the answer to that
10755: question. Meanwhile, he wanted to learn all he could about Florence.
10756: But he found, to his acute distress, that of the new details he learned
10757: he could only retain a few, and those only by continual repetition; and
10758: he began to be afraid of listening to any new discourse, lest it should
10759: obliterate what he was already striving to remember.
10760: 
10761: The day he was discerned by Tito in the Piazza del Duomo, he had the
10762: fresh anguish of this consciousness in his mind, and Tito’s ready
10763: speech fell upon him like the mockery of a glib, defying demon.
10764: 
10765: As he went home to his heap of straw, and passed by the booksellers’
10766: shops in the Via del Garbo, he paused to look at the volumes spread
10767: open. Could he by long gazing at one of those books lay hold of the
10768: slippery threads of memory? Could he, by striving, get a firm grasp
10769: somewhere, and lift himself above these waters that flowed over him?
10770: 
10771: He was tempted, and bought the cheapest Greek book he could see. He
10772: carried it home and sat on his heap of straw, looking at the characters
10773: by the light of the small window; but no inward light arose on them.
10774: Soon the evening darkness came; but it made little difference to
10775: Baldassarre. His strained eyes seemed still to see the white pages with
10776: the unintelligible black marks upon them.
10777: 
10778: 
10779: 
10780: 
10781: CHAPTER XXXI.
10782: Fruit is Seed.
10783: 
10784: 
10785: “My Romola,” said Tito, the second morning after he had made his speech
10786: in the Piazza del Duomo, “I am to receive grand visitors to-day; the
10787: Milanese Count is coming again, and the Seneschal de Beaucaire, the
10788: great favourite of the Cristianissimo. I know you don’t care to go
10789: through smiling ceremonies with these rustling magnates, whom we are
10790: not likely to see again; and as they will want to look at the
10791: antiquities and the library, perhaps you had better give up your work
10792: to-day, and go to see your cousin Brigida.”
10793: 
10794: Romola discerned a wish in this intimation, and immediately assented.
10795: But presently, coming back in her hood and mantle, she said, “Oh, what
10796: a long breath Florence will take when the gates are flung open, and the
10797: last Frenchman is walking out of them! Even you are getting tired, with
10798: all your patience, my Tito; confess it. Ah, your head is hot.”
10799: 
10800: He was leaning over his desk, writing, and she had laid her hand on his
10801: head, meaning to give a parting caress. The attitude had been a
10802: frequent one, and Tito was accustomed, when he felt her hand there, to
10803: raise his head, throw himself a little backward, and look up at her.
10804: But he felt now as unable to raise his head as if her hand had been a
10805: leaden cowl. He spoke instead, in a light tone, as his pen still ran
10806: along.
10807: 
10808: “The French are as ready to go from Florence as the wasps to leave a
10809: ripe pear when they have just fastened on it.”
10810: 
10811: Romola, keenly sensitive to the absence of the usual response, took
10812: away her hand and said, “I am going, Tito.”
10813: 
10814: “Farewell, my sweet one. I must wait at home. Take Maso with you.”
10815: 
10816: Still Tito did not look up, and Romola went out without saying any
10817: more. Very slight things make epochs in married life, and this morning
10818: for the first time she admitted to herself not only that Tito had
10819: changed, but that he had changed towards her. Did the reason lie in
10820: herself? She might perhaps have thought so, if there had not been the
10821: facts of the armour and the picture to suggest some external event
10822: which was an entire mystery to her.
10823: 
10824: But Tito no sooner believed that Romola was out of the house than he
10825: laid down his pen and looked up, in delightful security from seeing
10826: anything else than parchment and broken marble. He was rather disgusted
10827: with himself that he had not been able to look up at Romola and behave
10828: to her just as usual. He would have chosen, if he could, to be even
10829: more than usually kind; but he could not, on a sudden, master an
10830: involuntary shrinking from her, which, by a subtle relation, depended
10831: on those very characteristics in him that made him desire not to fail
10832: in his marks of affection. He was about to take a step which he knew
10833: would arouse her deep indignation; he would have to encounter much that
10834: was unpleasant before he could win her forgiveness. And Tito could
10835: never find it easy to face displeasure and anger; his nature was one of
10836: those most remote from defiance or impudence, and all his inclinations
10837: leaned towards preserving Romola’s tenderness. He was not tormented by
10838: sentimental scruples which, as he had demonstrated to himself by a very
10839: rapid course of argument, had no relation to solid utility; but his
10840: freedom from scruples did not release him from the dread of what was
10841: disagreeable. Unscrupulousness gets rid of much, but not of toothache,
10842: or wounded vanity, or the sense of loneliness, against which, as the
10843: world at present stands, there is no security but a thoroughly healthy
10844: jaw, and a just, loving soul. And Tito was feeling intensely at this
10845: moment that no devices could save him from pain in the impending
10846: collision with Romola; no persuasive blandness could cushion him
10847: against the shock towards which he was being driven like a timid animal
10848: urged to a desperate leap by the terror of the tooth and the claw that
10849: are close behind it.
10850: 
10851: The secret feeling he had previously had that the tenacious adherence
10852: to Bardo’s wishes about the library had become under existing
10853: difficulties a piece of sentimental folly, which deprived himself and
10854: Romola of substantial advantages, might perhaps never have wrought
10855: itself into action but for the events of the past week, which had
10856: brought at once the pressure of a new motive and the outlet of a rare
10857: opportunity. Nay, it was not till his dread had been aggravated by the
10858: sight of Baldassarre looking more like his sane self, not until he had
10859: begun to feel that he might be compelled to flee from Florence, that he
10860: had brought himself to resolve on using his legal right to sell the
10861: library before the great opportunity offered by French and Milanese
10862: bidders slipped through his fingers. For if he had to leave Florence he
10863: did not want to leave it as a destitute wanderer. He had been used to
10864: an agreeable existence, and he wished to carry with him all the means
10865: at hand for retaining the same agreeable conditions. He wished among
10866: other things to carry Romola with him, and _not_, if possible, to carry
10867: any infamy. Success had given him a growing appetite for all the
10868: pleasures that depend on an advantageous social position, and at no
10869: moment could it look like a temptation to him, but only like a hideous
10870: alternative, to decamp under dishonour, even with a bag of diamonds,
10871: and incur the life of an adventurer. It was not possible for him to
10872: make himself independent even of those Florentines who only greeted him
10873: with regard; still less was it possible for him to make himself
10874: independent of Romola. She was the wife of his first love—he loved her
10875: still; she belonged to that furniture of life which he shrank from
10876: parting with. He winced under her judgment, he felt uncertain how far
10877: the revulsion of her feeling towards him might go; and all that sense
10878: of power over a wife which makes a husband risk betrayals that a lover
10879: never ventures on, would not suffice to counteract Tito’s uneasiness.
10880: This was the leaden weight which had been too strong for his will, and
10881: kept him from raising his head to meet her eyes. Their pure light
10882: brought too near him the prospect of a coming struggle. But it was not
10883: to be helped; if they had to leave Florence, they must have money;
10884: indeed, Tito could not arrange life at all to his mind without a
10885: considerable sum of money. And that problem of arranging life to his
10886: mind had been the source of all his misdoing. He would have been equal
10887: to any sacrifice that was not unpleasant.
10888: 
10889: The rustling magnates came and went, the bargains had been concluded,
10890: and Romola returned home; but nothing grave was said that night. Tito
10891: was only gay and chatty, pouring forth to her, as he had not done
10892: before, stories and descriptions of what he had witnessed during the
10893: French visit. Romola thought she discerned an effort in his liveliness,
10894: and attributing it to the consciousness in him that she had been
10895: wounded in the morning, accepted the effort as an act of penitence,
10896: inwardly aching a little at that sign of growing distance between
10897: them—that there was an offence about which neither of them dared to
10898: speak.
10899: 
10900: The next day Tito remained away from home until late at night. It was a
10901: marked day to Romola, for Piero di Cosimo, stimulated to greater
10902: industry on her behalf by the fear that he might have been the cause of
10903: pain to her in the past week, had sent home her father’s portrait. She
10904: had propped it against the back of his old chair, and had been looking
10905: at it for some time, when the door opened behind her, and Bernardo del
10906: Nero came in.
10907: 
10908: “It is you, godfather! How I wish you had come sooner! it is getting a
10909: little dusk,” said Romola, going towards him.
10910: 
10911: “I have just looked in to tell you the good news, for I know Tito has
10912: not come yet,” said Bernardo. “The French king moves off to-morrow: not
10913: before it is high time. There has been another tussle between our
10914: people and his soldiers this morning. But there’s a chance now of the
10915: city getting into order once more and trade going on.”
10916: 
10917: “That is joyful,” said Romola. “But it is sudden, is it not? Tito
10918: seemed to think yesterday that there was little prospect of the king’s
10919: going soon.”
10920: 
10921: “He has been well barked at, that’s the reason,” said Bernardo,
10922: smiling. “His own generals opened their throats pretty well, and at
10923: last our Signoria sent the mastiff of the city, Fra Girolamo. The
10924: Cristianissimo was frightened at that thunder, and has given the order
10925: to move. I’m afraid there’ll be small agreement among us when he’s
10926: gone, but, at any rate, all parties are agreed in being glad not to
10927: have Florence stifled with soldiery any longer, and the Frate has
10928: barked this time to some purpose. Ah, what is this?” he added, as
10929: Romola, clasping him by the arm, led him in front of the picture. “Let
10930: us see.”
10931: 
10932: He began to unwind his long scarf while she placed a seat for him.
10933: 
10934: “Don’t you want your spectacles, godfather?” said Romola, in anxiety
10935: that he should see just what she saw.
10936: 
10937: “No, child, no,” said Bernardo, uncovering his grey head, as he seated
10938: himself with firm erectness. “For seeing at this distance, my old eyes
10939: are perhaps better than your young ones. Old men’s eyes are like old
10940: men’s memories; they are strongest for things a long way off.”
10941: 
10942: “It is better than having no portrait,” said Romola, apologetically,
10943: after Bernardo had been silent a little while. “It is less like him now
10944: than the image I have in my mind, but then that might fade with the
10945: years.” She rested her arm on the old man’s shoulder as she spoke,
10946: drawn towards him strongly by their common interest in the dead.
10947: 
10948: “I don’t know,” said Bernardo. “I almost think I see Bardo as he was
10949: when he was young, better than that picture shows him to me as he was
10950: when he was old. Your father had a great deal of fire in his eyes when
10951: he was young. It was what I could never understand, that he, with his
10952: fiery spirit, which seemed much more impatient than mine, could hang
10953: over the books and live with shadows all his life. However, he had put
10954: his heart into that.”
10955: 
10956: Bernardo gave a slight shrug as he spoke the last words, but Romola
10957: discerned in his voice a feeling that accorded with her own.
10958: 
10959: “And he was disappointed to the last,” she said, involuntarily. But
10960: immediately fearing lest her words should be taken to imply an
10961: accusation against Tito, she went on almost hurriedly, “If we could
10962: only see his longest, dearest wish fulfilled just to his mind!”
10963: 
10964: “Well, so we may,” said Bernardo, kindly, rising and putting on his
10965: cap. “The times are cloudy now, but fish are caught by waiting. Who
10966: knows? When the wheel has turned often enough, I may be Gonfaloniere
10967: yet before I die; and no creditor can touch these things.” He looked
10968: round as he spoke. Then, turning to her, and patting her cheek, said,
10969: “And you need not be afraid of my dying; my ghost will claim nothing.
10970: I’ve taken care of that in my will.”
10971: 
10972: Romola seized the hand that was against her cheek, and put it to her
10973: lips in silence.
10974: 
10975: “Haven’t you been scolding your husband for keeping away from home so
10976: much lately? I see him everywhere but here,” said Bernardo, willing to
10977: change the subject.
10978: 
10979: She felt the flush spread over her neck and face as she said, “He has
10980: been very much wanted; you know he speaks so well. I am glad to know
10981: that his value is understood.”
10982: 
10983: “You are contented then, Madonna Orgogliosa?” said Bernardo, smiling,
10984: as he moved to the door.
10985: 
10986: “Assuredly.”
10987: 
10988: Poor Romola! There was one thing that would have made the pang of
10989: disappointment in her husband harder to bear; it was, that any one
10990: should know he gave her cause for disappointment. This might be a
10991: woman’s weakness, but it is closely allied to a woman’s nobleness. She
10992: who willingly lifts up the veil of her married life has profaned it
10993: from a sanctuary into a vulgar place.
10994: 
10995: 
10996: 
10997: 
10998: CHAPTER XXXII.
10999: A Revelation.
11000: 
11001: 
11002: The next day Romola, like every other Florentine, was excited about the
11003: departure of the French. Besides her other reasons for gladness, she
11004: had a dim hope, which she was conscious was half superstitious, that
11005: those new anxieties about Tito, having come with the burdensome guests,
11006: might perhaps vanish with them. The French had been in Florence hardly
11007: eleven days, but in that space she had felt more acute unhappiness than
11008: she had known in her life before. Tito had adopted the hateful armour
11009: on the day of their arrival, and though she could frame no distinct
11010: notion why their departure should remove the cause of his fear—though,
11011: when she thought of that cause, the image of the prisoner grasping him,
11012: as she had seen it in Piero’s sketch, urged itself before her and
11013: excluded every other—still, when the French were gone, she would be rid
11014: of something that was strongly associated with her pain.
11015: 
11016: Wrapped in her mantle she waited under the loggia at the top of the
11017: house, and watched for the glimpses of the troops and the royal retinue
11018: passing the bridges on their way to the Porta San Piero, that looks
11019: towards Siena and Rome. She even returned to her station when the gates
11020: had been closed, that she might feel herself vibrating with the great
11021: peal of the bells. It was dusk then, and when at last she descended
11022: into the library, she lit her lamp with the resolution that she would
11023: overcome the agitation which had made her idle all day, and sit down to
11024: work at her copying of the catalogue. Tito had left home early in the
11025: morning, and she did not expect him yet. Before he came she intended to
11026: leave the library, and sit in the pretty saloon, with the dancing
11027: nymphs and the birds. She had done so every evening since he had
11028: objected to the library as chill and gloomy.
11029: 
11030: To her great surprise, she had not been at work long before Tito
11031: entered. Her first thought was, how cheerless he would feel in the wide
11032: darkness of this great room, with one little oil-lamp burning at the
11033: further end, and the fire nearly out. She almost ran towards him.
11034: 
11035: “Tito, dearest, I did not know you would come so soon,” she said,
11036: nervously, putting up her white arms to unwind his becchetto.
11037: 
11038: “I am not welcome then?” he said, with one of his brightest smiles,
11039: clasping her, but playfully holding his head back from her.
11040: 
11041: “Tito!” She uttered the word in a tone of pretty, loving reproach, and
11042: then he kissed her fondly, stroked her hair, as his manner was, and
11043: seemed not to mind about taking off his mantle yet. Romola quivered
11044: with delight. All the emotions of the day had been preparing in her a
11045: keener sensitiveness to the return of this habitual manner. “It will
11046: come back,” she was saying to herself, “the old happiness will perhaps
11047: come back. He is like himself again.”
11048: 
11049: Tito was taking great pains to be like himself; his heart was
11050: palpitating with anxiety.
11051: 
11052: “If I had expected you so soon,” said Romola, as she at last helped him
11053: to take off his wrappings, “I would have had a little festival prepared
11054: to this joyful ringing of the bells. I did not mean to be here in the
11055: library when you came home.”
11056: 
11057: “Never mind, sweet,” he said, carelessly. “Do not think about the fire.
11058: Come—come and sit down.”
11059: 
11060: There was a low stool against Tito’s chair, and that was Romola’s
11061: habitual seat when they were talking together. She rested her arm on
11062: his knee, as she used to do on her father’s, and looked up at him while
11063: he spoke. He had never yet noticed the presence of the portrait, and
11064: she had not mentioned it—thinking of it all the more.
11065: 
11066: “I have been enjoying the clang of the bells for the first time, Tito,”
11067: she began. “I liked being shaken and deafened by them: I fancied I was
11068: something like a Bacchante possessed by a divine rage. Are not the
11069: people looking very joyful to-night?”
11070: 
11071: “Joyful after a sour and pious fashion,” said Tito, with a shrug. “But,
11072: in truth, those who are left behind in Florence have little cause to be
11073: joyful: it seems to me, the most reasonable ground of gladness would be
11074: to have got out of Florence.”
11075: 
11076: Tito had sounded the desired key-note without any trouble, or
11077: appearance of premeditation. He spoke with no emphasis, but he looked
11078: grave enough to make Romola ask rather anxiously—
11079: 
11080: “Why, Tito? Are there fresh troubles?”
11081: 
11082: “No need of fresh ones, my Romola. There are three strong parties in
11083: the city, all ready to fly at each other’s throats. And if the Frate’s
11084: party is strong enough to frighten the other two into silence, as seems
11085: most likely, life will be as pleasant and amusing as a funeral. They
11086: have the plan of a Great Council simmering already; and if they get it,
11087: the man who sings sacred Lauds the loudest will be the most eligible
11088: for office. And besides that, the city will be so drained by the
11089: payment of this great subsidy to the French king, and by the war to get
11090: back Pisa, that the prospect would be dismal enough without the rule of
11091: fanatics. On the whole, Florence will be a delightful place for those
11092: worthies who entertain themselves in the evening by going into crypts
11093: and lashing themselves; but for everything else, the exiles have the
11094: best of it. For my own part, I have been thinking seriously that we
11095: should be wise to quit Florence, my Romola.”
11096: 
11097: She started. “Tito, how could we leave Florence? Surely you do not
11098: think I could leave it—at least, not yet—not for a long while.” She had
11099: turned cold and trembling, and did not find it quite easy to speak.
11100: Tito must know the reasons she had in her mind.
11101: 
11102: “That is all a fabric of your own imagination, my sweet one. Your
11103: secluded life has made you lay such false stress on a few things. You
11104: know I used to tell you, before we were married, that I wished we were
11105: somewhere else than in Florence. If you had seen more places and more
11106: people, you would know what I mean when I say that there is something
11107: in the Florentines that reminds me of their cutting spring winds. I
11108: like people who take life less eagerly; and it would be good for my
11109: Romola, too, to see a new life. I should like to dip her a little in
11110: the soft waters of forgetfulness.”
11111: 
11112: He leaned forward and kissed her brow, and laid his hand on her fair
11113: hair again; but she felt his caress no more than if he had kissed a
11114: mask. She was too much agitated by the sense of the distance between
11115: their minds to be conscious that his lips touched her.
11116: 
11117: “Tito, it is not because I suppose Florence is the pleasantest place in
11118: the world that I desire not to quit it. It is because I—because we have
11119: to see my father’s wish fulfilled. My godfather is old; he is
11120: seventy-one; we could not leave it to him.”
11121: 
11122: “It is precisely those superstitions which hang about your mind like
11123: bedimming clouds, my Romola, that make one great reason why I could
11124: wish we were two hundred leagues from Florence. I am obliged to take
11125: care of you in opposition to your own will: if those dear eyes, that
11126: look so tender, see falsely, I must see for them, and save my wife from
11127: wasting her life in disappointing herself by impracticable dreams.”
11128: 
11129: Romola sat silent and motionless: she could not blind herself to the
11130: direction in which Tito’s words pointed: he wanted to persuade her that
11131: they might get the library deposited in some monastery, or take some
11132: other ready means to rid themselves of a task, and of a tie to
11133: Florence; and she was determined never to submit her mind to his
11134: judgment on this question of duty to her father; she was inwardly
11135: prepared to encounter any sort of pain in resistance. But the
11136: determination was kept latent in these first moments by the
11137: heart-crushing sense that now at last she and Tito must be confessedly
11138: divided in their wishes. He was glad of her silence; for, much as he
11139: had feared the strength of her feeling, it was impossible for him, shut
11140: up in the narrowness that hedges in all merely clever, unimpassioned
11141: men, not to over-estimate the persuasiveness of his own arguments. His
11142: conduct did not look ugly to himself, and his imagination did not
11143: suffice to show him exactly how it would look to Romola. He went on in
11144: the same gentle, remonstrating tone.
11145: 
11146: “You know, dearest—your own clear judgment always showed you—that the
11147: notion of isolating a collection of books and antiquities, and
11148: attaching a single name to them for ever, was one that had no valid,
11149: substantial good for its object: and yet more, one that was liable to
11150: be defeated in a thousand ways. See what has become of the Medici
11151: collections! And, for my part, I consider it even blameworthy to
11152: entertain those petty views of appropriation: why should any one be
11153: reasonably glad that Florence should possess the benefits of learned
11154: research and taste more than any other city? I understand your feeling
11155: about the wishes of the dead; but wisdom puts a limit to these
11156: sentiments, else lives might be continually wasted in that sort of
11157: futile devotion—like praising deaf gods for ever. You gave your life to
11158: your father while he lived; why should you demand more of yourself?”
11159: 
11160: “Because it was a trust,” said Romola, in a low but distinct voice. “He
11161: trusted me, he trusted you, Tito. I did not expect you to feel anything
11162: else about it—to feel as I do—but I did expect you to feel that.”
11163: 
11164: “Yes, dearest, of course I should feel it on a point where your
11165: father’s real welfare or happiness was concerned; but there is no
11166: question of that now. If we believed in purgatory, I should be as
11167: anxious as you to have masses said; and if I believed it could now pain
11168: your father to see his library preserved and used in a rather different
11169: way from what he had set his mind on, I should share the strictness of
11170: your views. But a little philosophy should teach us to rid ourselves of
11171: those air-woven fetters that mortals hang round themselves, spending
11172: their lives in misery under the mere imagination of weight. Your mind,
11173: which seizes ideas so readily, my Romola, is able to discriminate
11174: between substantial good and these brain-wrought fantasies. Ask
11175: yourself, dearest, what possible good can these books and antiquities
11176: do, stowed together under your father’s name in Florence, more than
11177: they would do if they were divided or carried elsewhere? Nay, is not
11178: the very dispersion of such things in hands that know how to value
11179: them, one means of extending their usefulness? This rivalry of Italian
11180: cities is very petty and illiberal. The loss of Constantinople was the
11181: gain of the whole civilised world.”
11182: 
11183: Romola was still too thoroughly under the painful pressure of the new
11184: revelation Tito was making of himself, for her resistance to find any
11185: strong vent. As that fluent talk fell on her ears there was a rising
11186: contempt within her, which only made her more conscious of her bruised,
11187: despairing love, her love for the Tito she had married and believed in.
11188: Her nature, possessed with the energies of strong emotion, recoiled
11189: from this hopelessly shallow readiness which professed to appropriate
11190: the widest sympathies and had no pulse for the nearest. She still spoke
11191: like one who was restrained from showing all she felt. She had only
11192: drawn away her arm from his knee, and sat with her hands clasped before
11193: her, cold and motionless as locked waters.
11194: 
11195: “You talk of substantial good, Tito! Are faithfulness, and love, and
11196: sweet grateful memories, no good? Is it no good that we should keep our
11197: silent promises on which others build because they believe in our love
11198: and truth? Is it no good that a just life should be justly honoured?
11199: Or, is it good that we should harden our hearts against all the wants
11200: and hopes of those who have depended on us? What good can belong to men
11201: who have such souls? To talk cleverly, perhaps, and find soft couches
11202: for themselves, and live and die with their base selves as their best
11203: companions.”
11204: 
11205: Her voice had gradually risen till there was a ring of scorn in the
11206: last words; she made a slight pause, but he saw there were other words
11207: quivering on her lips, and he chose to let them come.
11208: 
11209: “I know of no good for cities or the world if they are to be made up of
11210: such beings. But I am not thinking of other Italian cities and the
11211: whole civilised world—I am thinking of my father, and of my love and
11212: sorrow for him, and of his just claims on us. I would give up anything
11213: else, Tito,—I would leave Florence,—what else did I live for but for
11214: him and you? But I will not give up that duty. What have I to do with
11215: your arguments? It was a yearning of _his_ heart, and therefore it is a
11216: yearning of mine.”
11217: 
11218: Her voice, from having been tremulous, had become full and firm. She
11219: felt that she had been urged on to say all that it was needful for her
11220: to say. She thought, poor thing, there was nothing harder to come than
11221: this struggle against Tito’s suggestions as against the meaner part of
11222: herself.
11223: 
11224: He had begun to see clearly that he could not persuade her into assent:
11225: he must take another course, and show her that the time for resistance
11226: was past. That, at least, would put an end to further struggle; and if
11227: the disclosure were not made by himself to-night, to-morrow it must be
11228: made in another way. This necessity nerved his courage; and his
11229: experience of her affectionateness and unexpected submissiveness, ever
11230: since their marriage until now, encouraged him to hope that, at last,
11231: she would accommodate herself to what had been his will.
11232: 
11233: “I am sorry to hear you speak in that spirit of blind persistence, my
11234: Romola,” he said, quietly, “because it obliges me to give you pain. But
11235: I partly foresaw your opposition, and as a prompt decision was
11236: necessary, I avoided that obstacle, and decided without consulting you.
11237: The very care of a husband for his wife’s interest compels him to that
11238: separate action sometimes—even when he has such a wife as you, my
11239: Romola.”
11240: 
11241: She turned her eyes on him in breathless inquiry.
11242: 
11243: “I mean,” he said, answering her look, “that I have arranged for the
11244: transfer, both of the books and of the antiquities, where they will
11245: find the highest use and value. The books have been bought for the Duke
11246: of Milan, the marbles and bronzes and the rest are going to France: and
11247: both will be protected by the stability of a great Power, instead of
11248: remaining in a city which is exposed to ruin.”
11249: 
11250: Before he had finished speaking, Romola had started from her seat, and
11251: stood up looking down at him, with tightened hands falling before her,
11252: and, for the first time in her life, with a flash of fierceness in her
11253: scorn and anger.
11254: 
11255: “You have _sold_ them?” she asked, as if she distrusted her ears.
11256: 
11257: “I have,” said Tito, quailing a little. The scene was unpleasant—the
11258: descending scorn already scorched him.
11259: 
11260: “You are a treacherous man!” she said, with something grating in her
11261: voice, as she looked down at him.
11262: 
11263: She was silent for a minute, and he sat still, feeling that ingenuity
11264: was powerless just now. Suddenly she turned away, and said in an
11265: agitated tone, “It may be hindered—I am going to my godfather.”
11266: 
11267: In an instant Tito started up, went to the door, locked it, and took
11268: out the key. It was time for all the masculine predominance that was
11269: latent in him to show itself. But he was not angry; he only felt that
11270: the moment was eminently unpleasant, and that when this scene was at an
11271: end he should be glad to keep away from Romola for a little while. But
11272: it was absolutely necessary first that she should be reduced to
11273: passiveness.
11274: 
11275: “Try to calm yourself a little, Romola,” he said, leaning in the
11276: easiest attitude possible against a pedestal under the bust of a grim
11277: old Roman. Not that he was inwardly easy: his heart palpitated with a
11278: moral dread, against which no chain-armour could be found. He had
11279: locked in his wife’s anger and scorn, but he had been obliged to lock
11280: himself in with it; and his blood did not rise with contest—his olive
11281: cheek was perceptibly paled.
11282: 
11283: Romola had paused and turned her eyes on him as she saw him take his
11284: stand and lodge the key in his scarsella. Her eyes were flashing, and
11285: her whole frame seemed to be possessed by impetuous force that wanted
11286: to leap out in some deed. All the crushing pain of disappointment in
11287: her husband, which had made the strongest part of her consciousness a
11288: few minutes before, was annihilated by the vehemence of her
11289: indignation. She could not care in this moment that the man she was
11290: despising as he leaned there in his loathsome beauty—she could not care
11291: that he was her husband; she could only feel that she despised him. The
11292: pride and fierceness of the old Bardo blood had been thoroughly awaked
11293: in her for the first time.
11294: 
11295: “Try at least to understand the fact,” said Tito, “and do not seek to
11296: take futile steps which may be fatal. It is of no use for you to go to
11297: your godfather. Messer Bernardo cannot reverse what I have done. Only
11298: sit down. You would hardly wish, if you were quite yourself, to make
11299: known to any third person what passes between us in private.”
11300: 
11301: Tito knew that he had touched the right fibre there. But she did not
11302: sit down; she was too unconscious of her body voluntarily to change her
11303: attitude.
11304: 
11305: “Why can it not be reversed?” she said, after a pause. “Nothing is
11306: moved yet.”
11307: 
11308: “Simply because the sale has been concluded by written agreement; the
11309: purchasers have left Florence, and I hold the bonds for the
11310: purchase-money.”
11311: 
11312: “If my father had suspected you of being a faithless man,” said Romola,
11313: in a tone of bitter scorn, which insisted on darting out before she
11314: could say anything else, “he would have placed the library safely out
11315: of your power. But death overtook him too soon, and when you were sure
11316: his ear was deaf, and his hand stiff, you robbed him.” She paused an
11317: instant, and then said, with gathered passion, “Have you robbed
11318: somebody else, who is _not_ dead? Is that the reason you wear armour?”
11319: 
11320: Romola had been driven to utter the words as men are driven to use the
11321: lash of the horsewhip. At first, Tito felt horribly cowed; it seemed to
11322: him that the disgrace he had been dreading would be worse than he had
11323: imagined it. But soon there was a reaction: such power of dislike and
11324: resistance as there was within him was beginning to rise against a wife
11325: whose voice seemed like the herald of a retributive fate. Her, at
11326: least, his quick mind told him that he might master.
11327: 
11328: “It is useless,” he said, coolly, “to answer the words of madness,
11329: Romola. Your peculiar feeling about your father has made you mad at
11330: this moment. Any rational person looking at the case from a due
11331: distance will see that I have taken the wisest course. Apart from the
11332: influence of your exaggerated feelings on him, I am convinced that
11333: Messer Bernardo would be of that opinion.”
11334: 
11335: “He would not!” said Romola. “He lives in the hope of seeing my
11336: father’s wish exactly fulfilled. We spoke of it together only
11337: yesterday. He will help me yet. Who are these men to whom you have sold
11338: my father’s property?”
11339: 
11340: “There is no reason why you should not be told, except that it
11341: signifies little. The Count di San Severino and the Seneschal de
11342: Beaucaire are now on their way with the king to Siena.”
11343: 
11344: “They may be overtaken and persuaded to give up their purchase,” said
11345: Romola, eagerly, her anger beginning to be surmounted by anxious
11346: thought.
11347: 
11348: “No, they may not,” said Tito, with cool decision.
11349: 
11350: “Why?”
11351: 
11352: “Because I do not choose that they should.”
11353: 
11354: “But if you were paid the money?—we will pay you the money,” said
11355: Romola.
11356: 
11357: No words could have disclosed more fully her sense of alienation from
11358: Tito; but they were spoken with less of bitterness than of anxious
11359: pleading. And he felt stronger, for he saw that the first impulse of
11360: fury was past.
11361: 
11362: “No, my Romola. Understand that such thoughts as these are
11363: impracticable. You would not, in a reasonable moment, ask your
11364: godfather to bury three thousand florins in addition to what he has
11365: already paid on the library. I think your pride and delicacy would
11366: shrink from that.”
11367: 
11368: She began to tremble and turn cold again with discouragement, and sank
11369: down on the carved chest near which she was standing. He went on in a
11370: clear voice, under which she shuddered, as if it had been a narrow cold
11371: stream coursing over a hot cheek.
11372: 
11373: “Moreover, it is not my will that Messer Bernardo should advance the
11374: money, even if the project were not an utterly wild one. And I beg you
11375: to consider, before you take any step or utter any word on the subject,
11376: what will be the consequences of your placing yourself in opposition to
11377: me, and trying to exhibit your husband in the odious light which your
11378: own distempered feelings cast over him. What object will you serve by
11379: injuring me with Messer Bernardo? The event is irrevocable, the library
11380: is sold, and you are my wife.”
11381: 
11382: Every word was spoken for the sake of a calculated effect, for his
11383: intellect was urged into the utmost activity by the danger of the
11384: crisis. He knew that Romola’s mind would take in rapidly enough all the
11385: wide meaning of his speech. He waited and watched her in silence.
11386: 
11387: She had turned her eyes from him, and was looking on the ground, and in
11388: that way she sat for several minutes. When she spoke, her voice was
11389: quite altered,—it was quiet and cold.
11390: 
11391: “I have one thing to ask.”
11392: 
11393: “Ask anything that I can do without injuring us both, Romola.”
11394: 
11395: “That you will give me that portion of the money which belongs to my
11396: godfather, and let me pay him.”
11397: 
11398: “I must have some assurance from you, first, of the attitude you intend
11399: to take towards me.”
11400: 
11401: “Do you believe in assurances, Tito?” she said, with a tinge of
11402: returning bitterness.
11403: 
11404: “From you, I do.”
11405: 
11406: “I will do you no harm. I shall disclose nothing. I will say nothing to
11407: pain him or you. You say truly, the event is irrevocable.”
11408: 
11409: “Then I will do what you desire to-morrow morning.”
11410: 
11411: “To-night, if possible,” said Romola, “that we may not speak of it
11412: again.”
11413: 
11414: “It is possible,” he said, moving towards the lamp, while she sat
11415: still, looking away from him with absent eyes.
11416: 
11417: Presently he came and bent down over her, to put a piece of paper into
11418: her hand. “You will receive something in return, you are aware, my
11419: Romola?” he said, gently, not minding so much what had passed, now he
11420: was secure; and feeling able to try and propitiate her.
11421: 
11422: “Yes,” she said, taking the paper, without looking at him, “I
11423: understand.”
11424: 
11425: “And you will forgive me, my Romola, when you have had time to
11426: reflect.” He just touched her brow with his lips, but she took no
11427: notice, and seemed really unconscious of the act. She was aware that he
11428: unlocked the door and went out. She moved her head and listened. The
11429: great door of the court opened and shut again. She started up as if
11430: some sudden freedom had come, and going to her father’s chair where his
11431: picture was propped, fell on her knees before it, and burst into sobs.
11432: 
11433: 
11434: 
11435: 
11436: CHAPTER XXXIII.
11437: Baldassarre makes an Acquaintance.
11438: 
11439: 
11440: When Baldassarre was wandering about Florence in search of a spare
11441: outhouse where he might have the cheapest of sheltered beds, his steps
11442: had been attracted towards that sole portion of ground within the walls
11443: of the city which is not perfectly level, and where the spectator,
11444: lifted above the roofs of the houses, can see beyond the city to the
11445: protecting hills and far-stretching valley, otherwise shut out from his
11446: view except along the welcome opening made by the course of the Arno.
11447: Part of that ground has been already seen by us as the hill of Bogoli,
11448: at that time a great stone-quarry; but the side towards which
11449: Baldassarre directed his steps was the one that sloped down behind the
11450: Via de’ Bardi, and was most commonly called the hill of San Giorgio.
11451: Bratti had told him that Tito’s dwelling was in the Via de’ Bardi; and,
11452: after surveying that street, he turned up the slope of the hill which
11453: he had observed as he was crossing the bridge. If he could find a
11454: sheltering outhouse on that hill, he would be glad: he had now for some
11455: years been accustomed to live with a broad sky about him; and,
11456: moreover, the narrow passes of the streets, with their strip of sky
11457: above, and the unknown labyrinth around them, seemed to intensify his
11458: sense of loneliness and feeble memory.
11459: 
11460: The hill was sparsely inhabited, and covered chiefly by gardens; but in
11461: one spot was a piece of rough ground jagged with great stones, which
11462: had never been cultivated since a landslip had ruined some houses there
11463: towards the end of the thirteenth century. Just above the edge of this
11464: broken ground stood a queer little square building, looking like a
11465: truncated tower roofed in with fluted tiles, and close by was a small
11466: outhouse, apparently built up against a piece of ruined stone wall.
11467: Under a large half-dead mulberry-tree that was now sending its last
11468: fluttering leaves in at the open doorways, a shrivelled, hardy old
11469: woman was untying a goat with two kids, and Baldassarre could see that
11470: part of the outbuilding was occupied by live stock; but the door of the
11471: other part was open, and it was empty of everything but some tools and
11472: straw. It was just the sort of place he wanted. He spoke to the old
11473: woman; but it was not till he got close to her and shouted in her ear,
11474: that he succeeded in making her understand his want of a lodging, and
11475: his readiness to pay for it. At first he could get no answer beyond
11476: shakes of the head and the words, “No—no lodging,” uttered in the
11477: muffled tone of the deaf. But, by dint of persistence, he made clear to
11478: her that he was a poor stranger from a long way over seas, and could
11479: not afford to go to hostelries; that he only wanted to lie on the straw
11480: in the outhouse, and would pay her a quattrino or two a week for that
11481: shelter. She still looked at him dubiously, shaking her head and
11482: talking low to herself; but presently, as if a new thought occurred to
11483: her, she fetched a hatchet from the house, and, showing him a chump
11484: that lay half covered with litter in a corner, asked him if he would
11485: chop that up for her: if he would, he might lie in the outhouse for one
11486: night. He agreed, and Monna Lisa stood with her arms akimbo to watch
11487: him, with a smile of gratified cunning, saying low to herself—
11488: 
11489: “It’s lain there ever since my old man died. What then? I might as well
11490: have put a stone on the fire. He chops very well, though he does speak
11491: with a foreign tongue, and looks odd. I couldn’t have got it done
11492: cheaper. And if he only wants a bit of straw to lie on, I might make
11493: him do an errand or two up and down the hill. Who need know? And sin
11494: that’s hidden’s half forgiven. (‘Peccato celato e mezzo perdonato.’)
11495: He’s a stranger: he’ll take no notice of _her_. And I’ll tell her to
11496: keep her tongue still.”
11497: 
11498: The antecedent to these feminine pronouns had a pair of blue eyes,
11499: which at that moment were applied to a large round hole in the shutter
11500: of the upper window. The shutter was closed, not for any penal reasons,
11501: but because only the opposite window had the luxury of glass in it: the
11502: weather was not warm, and a round hole four inches in diameter served
11503: all the purposes of observation. The hole was, unfortunately, a little
11504: too high, and obliged the small observer to stand on a low stool of a
11505: rickety character; but Tessa would have stood a long while in a much
11506: more inconvenient position for the sake of seeing a little variety in
11507: her life. She had been drawn to the opening at the first loud tones of
11508: the strange voice speaking to Monna Lisa; and darting gently across her
11509: room every now and then to peep at something, she continued to stand
11510: there until the wood had been chopped, and she saw Baldassarre enter
11511: the outhouse, as the dusk was gathering, and seat himself on the straw.
11512: 
11513: A great temptation had laid hold of Tessa’s mind; she would go and take
11514: that old man part of her supper, and talk to him a little. He was not
11515: deaf like Monna Lisa, and besides she could say a great many things to
11516: him that it was no use to shout at Monna Lisa, who knew them already.
11517: And he was a stranger—strangers came from a long way off and went away
11518: again, and lived nowhere in particular. It was naughty, she knew, for
11519: obedience made the largest part in Tessa’s idea of duty; but it would
11520: be something to confess to the Padre next Pasqua, and there was nothing
11521: else to confess except going to sleep sometimes over her beads, and
11522: being a little cross with Monna Lisa because she was so deaf; for she
11523: had as much idleness as she liked now, and was never frightened into
11524: telling white lies. She turned away from her shutter with rather an
11525: excited expression in her childish face, which was as pretty and
11526: pouting as ever. Her garb was still that of a simple contadina, but of
11527: a contadina prepared for a festa: her gown of dark-green serge, with
11528: its red girdle, was very clean and neat; she had the string of red
11529: glass beads round her neck; and her brown hair, rough from curliness,
11530: was duly knotted up, and fastened with the silver pin. She had but one
11531: new ornament, and she was very proud of it, for it was a fine gold
11532: ring.
11533: 
11534: Tessa sat on the low stool, nursing her knees, for a minute or two,
11535: with her little soul poised in fluttering excitement on the edge of
11536: this pleasant transgression. It was quite irresistible. She had been
11537: commanded to make no acquaintances, and warned that if she did, all her
11538: new happy lot would vanish away, and be like a hidden treasure that
11539: turned to lead as soon as it was brought to the daylight; and she had
11540: been so obedient that when she had to go to church she had kept her
11541: face shaded by her hood and had pursed up her lips quite tightly. It
11542: was true her obedience had been a little helped by her own dread lest
11543: the alarming stepfather Nofri should turn up even in this quarter, so
11544: far from the Por’ del Prato, and beat her at least, if he did not drag
11545: her back to work for him. But this old man was not an acquaintance; he
11546: was a poor stranger going to sleep in the outhouse, and he probably
11547: knew nothing of stepfather Nofri; and, besides, if she took him some
11548: supper, he would like her, and not want to tell anything about her.
11549: Monna Lisa would say she must not go and talk to him, therefore Monna
11550: Lisa must not be consulted. It did not signify what she found out after
11551: it had been done.
11552: 
11553: Supper was being prepared, she knew—a mountain of macaroni flavoured
11554: with cheese, fragrant enough to tame any stranger. So she tripped
11555: down-stairs with a mind full of deep designs, and first asking with an
11556: innocent look what that noise of talking had been, without waiting for
11557: an answer, knit her brow with a peremptory air, something like a kitten
11558: trying to be formidable, and sent the old woman upstairs; saying, she
11559: chose to eat her supper down below. In three minutes Tessa with her
11560: lantern in one hand and a wooden bowl of macaroni in the other, was
11561: kicking gently at the door of the outhouse; and Baldassarre, roused
11562: from sad reverie, doubted in the first moment whether he were awake as
11563: he opened the door and saw this surprising little handmaid, with
11564: delight in her wide eyes, breaking in on his dismal loneliness.
11565: 
11566: “I’ve brought you some supper,” she said, lifting her mouth towards his
11567: ear and shouting, as if he had been deaf like Monna Lisa. “Sit down and
11568: eat it, while I stay with you.”
11569: 
11570: Surprise and distrust surmounted every other feeling in Baldassarre,
11571: but though he had no smile or word of gratitude ready, there could not
11572: be any impulse to push away this visitant, and he sank down passively
11573: on his straw again, while Tessa placed herself close to him, put the
11574: wooden bowl on his lap, and set down the lantern in front of them,
11575: crossing her hands before her, and nodding at the bowl with a
11576: significant smile, as much as to say, “Yes, you may really eat it.”
11577: For, in the excitement of carrying out her deed, she had forgotten her
11578: previous thought that the stranger would not be deaf, and had fallen
11579: into her habitual alternative of dumb show and shouting.
11580: 
11581: The invitation was not a disagreeable one, for he had been gnawing a
11582: remnant of dry bread, which had left plenty of appetite for anything
11583: warm and relishing. Tessa watched the disappearance of two or three
11584: mouthfuls without speaking, for she had thought his eyes rather fierce
11585: at first; but now she ventured to put her mouth to his ear again and
11586: cry—
11587: 
11588: “I like my supper, don’t you?”
11589: 
11590: It was not a smile, but rather the milder look of a dog touched by
11591: kindness, but unable to smile, that Baldassarre turned on this round
11592: blue-eyed thing that was caring about him.
11593: 
11594: “Yes,” he said; “but I can hear well—I’m not deaf.”
11595: 
11596: “It is true; I forgot,” said Tessa, lifting her hands and clasping
11597: them. “But Monna Lisa is deaf, and I live with her. She’s a kind old
11598: woman, and I’m not frightened at her. And we live very well: we have
11599: plenty of nice things. I can have nuts if I like. And I’m not obliged
11600: to work now. I used to have to work, and I didn’t like it; but I liked
11601: feeding the mules, and I should like to see poor Giannetta, the little
11602: mule, again. We’ve only got a goat and two kids, and I used to talk to
11603: the goat a good deal, because there was nobody else but Monna Lisa. But
11604: now I’ve got something else—can you guess what it is?”
11605: 
11606: She drew her head back, and looked with a challenging smile at
11607: Baldassarre, as if she had proposed a difficult riddle to him.
11608: 
11609: “No,” said he, putting aside his bowl, and looking at her dreamily. It
11610: seemed as if this young prattling thing were some memory come back out
11611: of his own youth.
11612: 
11613: “You like me to talk to you, don’t you?” said Tessa, “but you must not
11614: tell anybody. Shall I fetch you a bit of cold sausage?”
11615: 
11616: He shook his head, but he looked so mild now that Tessa felt quite at
11617: her ease.
11618: 
11619: “Well, then, I’ve got a little baby. Such a pretty bambinetto, with
11620: little fingers and nails! Not old yet; it was born at the Nativita,
11621: Monna Lisa says. I was married one Nativita, a long, long while ago,
11622: and nobody knew. O Santa Madonna! I didn’t mean to tell you that!”
11623: 
11624: Tessa set up her shoulders and bit her lip, looking at Baldassarre as
11625: if this betrayal of secrets must have an exciting effect on him too.
11626: But he seemed not to care much; and perhaps that was in the nature of
11627: strangers.
11628: 
11629: “Yes,” she said, carrying on her thought aloud, “you are a stranger;
11630: you don’t live anywhere or know anybody, do you?”
11631: 
11632: “No,” said Baldassarre, also thinking aloud, rather than consciously
11633: answering, “I only know one man.”
11634: 
11635: “His name is not Nofri, is it?” said Tessa, anxiously.
11636: 
11637: “No,” said Baldassarre, noticing her look of fear. “Is that your
11638: husband’s name?”
11639: 
11640: That mistaken supposition was very amusing to Tessa. She laughed and
11641: clapped her hands as she said—
11642: 
11643: “No, indeed! But I must not tell you anything about my husband. You
11644: would never think what he is—not at all like Nofri!”
11645: 
11646: She laughed again at the delightful incongruity between the name of
11647: Nofri—which was not separable from the idea of the cross-grained
11648: stepfather—and the idea of her husband.
11649: 
11650: “But I don’t see him very often,” she went on, more gravely. “And
11651: sometimes I pray to the Holy Madonna to send him oftener, and once she
11652: did. But I must go back to my bimbo now. I’ll bring it to show you
11653: to-morrow. You would like to see it. Sometimes it cries and makes a
11654: face, but only when it’s hungry, Monna Lisa says. You wouldn’t think
11655: it, but Monna Lisa had babies once, and they are all dead old men. My
11656: husband says she will never die now, because she’s so well dried. I’m
11657: glad of that, for I’m fond of her. You would like to stay here
11658: to-morrow, shouldn’t you?”
11659: 
11660: “I should like to have this place to come and rest in, that’s all,”
11661: said Baldassarre. “I would pay for it, and harm nobody.”
11662: 
11663: “No, indeed; I think you are not a bad old man. But you look sorry
11664: about something. Tell me, is there anything you shall cry about when I
11665: leave you by yourself? _I_ used to cry once.”
11666: 
11667: “No, child; I think I shall cry no more.”
11668: 
11669: “That’s right; and I’ll bring you some breakfast, and show you the
11670: bimbo. Good-night.”
11671: 
11672: Tessa took up her bowl and lantern, and closed the door behind her. The
11673: pretty loving apparition had been no more to Baldassarre than a faint
11674: rainbow on the blackness to the man who is wrestling in deep waters. He
11675: hardly thought of her again till his dreamy waking passed into the more
11676: vivid images of disturbed sleep.
11677: 
11678: But Tessa thought much of him. She had no sooner entered the house than
11679: she told Monna Lisa what she had done, and insisted that the stranger
11680: should be allowed to come and rest in the outhouse when he liked. The
11681: old woman, who had had her notions of making him a useful tenant, made
11682: a great show of reluctance, shook her head, and urged that Messer Naldo
11683: would be angry if she let any one come about the house. Tessa did not
11684: believe that. Naldo had said nothing against strangers who lived
11685: nowhere; and this old man knew nobody except one person, who was not
11686: Nofri.
11687: 
11688: “Well,” conceded Monna Lisa, at last, “if I let him stay for a while
11689: and carry things up the hill for me, thou must keep thy counsel and
11690: tell nobody.”
11691: 
11692: “No,” said Tessa, “I’ll only tell the bimbo.”
11693: 
11694: “And then,” Monna Lisa went on, in her thick undertone, “God may love
11695: us well enough not to let Messer Naldo find out anything about it. For
11696: he never comes here but at dark; and as he was here two days ago, it’s
11697: likely he’ll never come at all till the old man’s gone away again.”
11698: 
11699: “Oh me! Monna,” said Tessa, clasping her hands, “I wish Naldo had not
11700: to go such a long, long way sometimes before he comes back again.”
11701: 
11702: “Ah, child! the world’s big, they say. There are places behind the
11703: mountains, and if people go night and day, night and day, they get to
11704: Rome, and see the Holy Father.”
11705: 
11706: Tessa looked submissive in the presence of this mystery, and began to
