11707: rock her baby, and sing syllables of vague loving meaning, in tones
11708: that imitated a triple chime.
11709: 
11710: The next morning she was unusually industrious in the prospect of more
11711: dialogue, and of the pleasure she should give the poor old stranger by
11712: showing him her baby. But before she could get ready to take
11713: Baldassarre his breakfast, she found that Monna Lisa had been employing
11714: him as a drawer of water. She deferred her paternosters, and hurried
11715: down to insist that Baldassarre should sit on his straw, so that she
11716: might come and sit by him again while he ate his breakfast. That
11717: attitude made the new companionship all the more delightful to Tessa,
11718: for she had been used to sitting on straw in old days along with her
11719: goats and mules.
11720: 
11721: “I will not let Monna Lisa give you too much work to do,” she said,
11722: bringing him some steaming broth and soft bread. “I don’t like much
11723: work, and I daresay you don’t. I like sitting in the sunshine and
11724: feeding things. Monna Lisa says, work is good, but she does it all
11725: herself, so I don’t mind. She’s not a cross old woman; you needn’t be
11726: afraid of her being cross. And now, you eat that, and I’ll go and fetch
11727: my baby and show it you.”
11728: 
11729: Presently she came back with the small mummy-case in her arms. The
11730: mummy looked very lively, having unusually large dark eyes, though no
11731: more than the usual indication of a future nose.
11732: 
11733: “This is my baby,” said Tessa, seating herself close to Baldassarre.
11734: “You didn’t think it was so pretty, did you? It is like the little
11735: Gesu, and I should think the Santa Madonna would be kinder to me now,
11736: is it not true? But I have not much to ask for, because I have
11737: everything now—only that I should see my husband oftener. You may hold
11738: the bambino a little if you like, but I think you must not kiss him,
11739: because you might hurt him.”
11740: 
11741: She spoke this prohibition in a tone of soothing excuse, and
11742: Baldassarre could not refuse to hold the small package. “Poor thing!
11743: poor thing!” he said, in a deep voice which had something strangely
11744: threatening in its apparent pity. It did not seem to him as if this
11745: guileless loving little woman could reconcile him to the world at all,
11746: but rather that she was with him against the world, that she was a
11747: creature who would need to be avenged.
11748: 
11749: “Oh, don’t you be sorry for me,” she said; “for though I don’t see him
11750: often, he is more beautiful and good than anybody else in the world. I
11751: say prayers to him when he’s away. You couldn’t think what he is!”
11752: 
11753: She looked at Baldassarre with a wide glance of mysterious meaning,
11754: taking the baby from him again, and almost wishing he would question
11755: her as if he wanted very much to know more.
11756: 
11757: “Yes, I could,” said Baldassarre, rather bitterly.
11758: 
11759: “No, I’m sure you never could,” said Tessa, earnestly. “You thought he
11760: might be Nofri,” she added, with a triumphant air of conclusiveness.
11761: “But never mind; you couldn’t know. What is your name?”
11762: 
11763: He rubbed his hand over his knitted brow, then looked at her blankly
11764: and said, “Ah, child, what is it?”
11765: 
11766: It was not that he did not often remember his name well enough; and if
11767: he had had presence of mind now to remember it, he would have chosen
11768: not to tell it. But a sudden question appealing to his memory, had a
11769: paralysing effect, and in that moment he was conscious of nothing but
11770: helplessness.
11771: 
11772: Ignorant as Tessa was, the pity stirred in her by his blank look taught
11773: her to say—
11774: 
11775: “_Never_ mind: you are a stranger, it is no matter about your having a
11776: name. Good-bye now, because I want my breakfast. You will come here and
11777: rest when you like; Monna Lisa says you may. And don’t you be unhappy,
11778: for we’ll be good to you.”
11779: 
11780: “Poor thing!” said Baldassarre again.
11781: 
11782: 
11783: 
11784: 
11785: CHAPTER XXXIV.
11786: No Place for Repentance.
11787: 
11788: 
11789: Messer Naldo came again sooner than was expected: he came on the
11790: evening of the twenty-eighth of November, only eleven days after his
11791: previous visit, proving that he had not gone far beyond the mountains;
11792: and a scene which we have witnessed as it took place that evening in
11793: the Via de’ Bardi may help to explain the impulse which turned his
11794: steps towards the hill of San Giorgio.
11795: 
11796: When Tito had first found this home for Tessa, on his return from Rome,
11797: more than a year and a half ago, he had acted, he persuaded himself,
11798: simply under the constraint imposed on him by his own kindliness after
11799: the unlucky incident which had made foolish little Tessa imagine him to
11800: be her husband. It was true that the kindness was manifested towards a
11801: pretty trusting thing whom it was impossible to be near without feeling
11802: inclined to caress and pet her; but it was not less true that Tito had
11803: movements of kindness towards her apart from any contemplated gain to
11804: himself. Otherwise, charming as her prettiness and prattle were in a
11805: lazy moment, he might have preferred to be free from her; for he was
11806: not in love with Tessa—he was in love for the first time in his life
11807: with an entirely different woman, whom he was not simply inclined to
11808: shower caresses on, but whose presence possessed him so that the simple
11809: sweep of her long tresses across his cheek seemed to vibrate through
11810: the hours. All the young ideal passion he had in him had been stirred
11811: by Romola, and his fibre was too fine, his intellect too bright, for
11812: him to be tempted into the habits of a gross pleasure-seeker. But he
11813: had spun a web about himself and Tessa, which he felt incapable of
11814: breaking: in the first moments after the mimic marriage he had been
11815: prompted to leave her under an illusion by a distinct calculation of
11816: his own possible need, but since that critical moment it seemed to him
11817: that the web had gone on spinning itself in spite of him, like a growth
11818: over which he had no power. The elements of kindness and
11819: self-indulgence are hard to distinguish in a soft nature like Tito’s;
11820: and the annoyance he had felt under Tessa’s pursuit of him on the day
11821: of his betrothal, the thorough intention of revealing the truth to her
11822: with which he set out to fulfil his promise of seeing her again, were a
11823: sufficiently strong argument to him that in ultimately leaving Tessa
11824: under her illusion and providing a home for her, he had been overcome
11825: by his own kindness. And in these days of his first devotion to Romola
11826: he needed a self-justifying argument. He had learned to be glad that
11827: she was deceived about some things. But every strong feeling makes to
11828: itself a conscience of its own—has its own piety; just as much as the
11829: feeling of the son towards the mother, which will sometimes survive
11830: amid the worst fumes of depravation; and Tito could not yet be easy in
11831: committing a secret offence against his wedded love.
11832: 
11833: But he was all the more careful in taking precautions to preserve the
11834: secrecy of the offence. Monna Lisa, who, like many of her class, never
11835: left her habitation except to go to one or two particular shops, and to
11836: confession once a year, knew nothing of his real name and whereabout:
11837: she only know that he paid her so as to make her very comfortable, and
11838: minded little about the rest, save that she got fond of Tessa, and
11839: found pleasure in the cares for which she was paid. There was some
11840: mystery behind, clearly, since Tessa was a contadina, and Messer Naldo
11841: was a signor; but, for aught Monna Lisa knew, he might be a real
11842: husband. For Tito had thoroughly frightened Tessa into silence about
11843: the circumstances of their marriage, by telling her that if she broke
11844: that silence she would never see him again; and Monna Lisa’s deafness,
11845: which made it impossible to say anything to her without some
11846: premeditation, had saved Tessa from any incautious revelation to her,
11847: such as had run off her tongue in talking with Baldassarre. For a long
11848: while Tito’s visits were so rare, that it seemed likely enough he took
11849: journeys between them. They were prompted chiefly by the desire to see
11850: that all things were going on well with Tessa; and though he always
11851: found his visit pleasanter than the prospect of it—always felt anew the
11852: charm of that pretty ignorant lovingness and trust—he had not yet any
11853: real need of it. But he was determined, if possible, to preserve the
11854: simplicity on which the charm depended; to keep Tessa a genuine
11855: contadina, and not place the small field-flower among conditions that
11856: would rob it of its grace. He would have been shocked to see her in the
11857: dress of any other rank than her own; the piquancy of her talk would be
11858: all gone, if things began to have new relations for her, if her world
11859: became wider, her pleasures less childish; and the squirrel-like
11860: enjoyment of nuts at discretion marked the standard of the luxuries he
11861: had provided for her. By this means, Tito saved Tessa’s charm from
11862: being sullied; and he also, by a convenient coincidence, saved himself
11863: from aggravating expenses that were already rather importunate to a man
11864: whose money was all required for his avowed habits of life.
11865: 
11866: This, in brief, had been the history of Tito’s relation to Tessa up to
11867: a very recent date. It is true that once or twice before Bardo’s death,
11868: the sense that there was Tessa up the hill, with whom it was possible
11869: to pass an hour agreeably, had been an inducement to him to escape from
11870: a little weariness of the old man, when, for lack of any positive
11871: engagement, he might otherwise have borne the weariness patiently and
11872: shared Romola’s burden. But the moment when he had first felt a real
11873: hunger for Tessa’s ignorant lovingness and belief in _him_ had not come
11874: till quite lately, and it was distinctly marked out by circumstances as
11875: little to be forgotten as the oncoming of a malady that has permanently
11876: vitiated the sight and hearing. It was the day when he had first seen
11877: Baldassarre, and had bought the armour. Returning across the bridge
11878: that night, with the coat of mail in his hands, he had felt an
11879: unconquerable shrinking from an immediate encounter with Romola. She,
11880: too, knew little of the actual world; she, too, trusted him; but he had
11881: an uneasy consciousness that behind her frank eyes there was a nature
11882: that could judge him, and that any ill-founded trust of hers sprang not
11883: from pretty brute-like incapacity, but from a nobleness which might
11884: prove an alarming touchstone. He wanted a little ease, a little repose
11885: from self-control, after the agitation and exertions of the day; he
11886: wanted to be where he could adjust his mind to the morrow, without
11887: caring how he behaved at the present moment. And there was a sweet
11888: adoring creature within reach whose presence was as safe and
11889: unconstraining as that of her own kids,—who would believe any fable,
11890: and remain quite unimpressed by public opinion. And so on that evening,
11891: when Romola was waiting and listening for him, he turned his steps up
11892: the hill.
11893: 
11894: No wonder, then, that the steps took the same course on this evening,
11895: eleven days later, when he had had to recoil under Romola’s first
11896: outburst of scorn. He could not wish Tessa in his wife’s place, or
11897: refrain from wishing that his wife should be thoroughly reconciled to
11898: him; for it was Romola, and not Tessa, that belonged to the world where
11899: all the larger desires of a man who had ambition and effective
11900: faculties must necessarily lie. But he wanted a refuge from a standard
11901: disagreeably rigorous, of which he could not make himself independent
11902: simply by thinking it folly; and Tessa’s little soul was that inviting
11903: refuge.
11904: 
11905: It was not much more than eight o’clock when he went up the stone steps
11906: to the door of Tessa’s room. Usually she heard his entrance into the
11907: house, and ran to meet him, but not to-night; and when he opened the
11908: door he saw the reason. A single dim light was burning above the dying
11909: fire, and showed Tessa in a kneeling attitude by the head of the bed
11910: where the baby lay. Her head had fallen aside on the pillow, and her
11911: brown rosary, which usually hung above the pillow over the picture of
11912: the Madonna and the golden palm-branches, lay in the loose grasp of her
11913: right-hand. She had gone fast asleep over her beads. Tito stepped
11914: lightly across the little room, and sat down close to her. She had
11915: probably heard the opening of the door as part of her dream, for he had
11916: not been looking at her two moments before she opened her eyes. She
11917: opened them without any start, and remained quite motionless looking at
11918: him, as if the sense that he was there smiling at her shut out any
11919: impulse which could disturb that happy passiveness. But when he put his
11920: hand under her chin, and stooped to kiss her, she said—
11921: 
11922: “I dreamed it, and then I said it was dreaming—and then I awoke, and it
11923: was true.”
11924: 
11925: “Little sinner!” said Tito, pinching her chin, “you have not said half
11926: your prayers. I will punish you by not looking at your baby; it is
11927: ugly.”
11928: 
11929: Tessa did not like those words, even though Tito was smiling. She had
11930: some pouting distress in her face, as she said, bending anxiously over
11931: the baby—
11932: 
11933: “Ah, it is not true! He is prettier than anything. You do not think he
11934: is ugly. You will look at him. He is even prettier than when you saw
11935: him before—only he’s asleep, and you can’t see his eyes or his tongue,
11936: and I can’t show you his hair—and it grows—isn’t that wonderful? Look
11937: at him! It’s true his face is very much all alike when he’s asleep,
11938: there is not so much to see as when he’s awake. If you kiss him very
11939: gently, he won’t wake: you want to kiss him, is it not true?”
11940: 
11941: He satisfied her by giving the small mummy a butterfly kiss, and then
11942: putting his hand on her shoulder and turning her face towards him,
11943: said, “You like looking at the baby better than looking at your
11944: husband, you false one!”
11945: 
11946: She was still kneeling, and now rested her hands on his knee, looking
11947: up at him like one of Fra Lippo Lippi’s round-cheeked adoring angels.
11948: 
11949: “No,” she said, shaking her head; “I love you always best, only I want
11950: you to look at the bambino and love him; I used only to want you to
11951: love me.”
11952: 
11953: “And did you expect me to come again so soon?” said Tito, inclined to
11954: make her prattle. He still felt the effects of the agitation he had
11955: undergone—still felt like a man who has been violently jarred; and this
11956: was the easiest relief from silence and solitude.
11957: 
11958: “Ah, no,” said Tessa, “I have counted the days—to-day I began at my
11959: right thumb again—since you put on the beautiful chain-coat, that
11960: Messer San Michele gave you to take care of you on your journey. And
11961: you have got it on now,” she said, peeping through the opening in the
11962: breast of his tunic. “Perhaps it made you come back sooner.”
11963: 
11964: “Perhaps it did, Tessa,” he said. “But don’t mind the coat now. Tell me
11965: what has happened since I was here. Did you see the tents in the Prato,
11966: and the soldiers and horsemen when they passed the bridges—did you hear
11967: the drums and trumpets?”
11968: 
11969: “Yes, and I was rather frightened, because I thought the soldiers might
11970: come up here. And Monna Lisa was a little afraid too, for she said they
11971: might carry our kids off; she said it was their business to do
11972: mischief. But the Holy Madonna took care of us, for we never saw one of
11973: them up here. But something has happened, only I hardly dare tell you,
11974: and that is what I was saying more Aves for.”
11975: 
11976: “What do you mean, Tessa?” said Tito, rather anxiously. “Make haste and
11977: tell me.”
11978: 
11979: “Yes, but will you let me sit on your knee? because then I think I
11980: shall not be so frightened.”
11981: 
11982: He took her on his knee, and put his arm round her, but looked grave:
11983: it seemed that something unpleasant must pursue him even here.
11984: 
11985: “At first I didn’t mean to tell you,” said Tessa, speaking almost in a
11986: whisper, as if that would mitigate the offence; “because we thought the
11987: old man would be gone away before you came again, and it would be as if
11988: it had not been. But now he is there, and you are come, and I never did
11989: anything you told me not to do before. And I want to tell you, and then
11990: you will perhaps forgive me, for it is a long while before I go to
11991: confession.”
11992: 
11993: “Yes, tell me everything, my Tessa.” He began to hope it was after all
11994: a trivial matter.
11995: 
11996: “Oh, you will be sorry for him: I’m afraid he cries about something
11997: when I don’t see him. But that was not the reason I went to him first;
11998: it was because I wanted to talk to him and show him my baby, and he was
11999: a stranger that lived nowhere, and I thought you wouldn’t care so much
12000: about my talking to him. And I think he is not a bad old man, and he
12001: wanted to come and sleep on the straw next to the goats, and I made
12002: Monna Lisa say, ‘Yes, he might,’ and he’s away all the day almost, but
12003: when he comes back I talk to him, and take him something to eat.”
12004: 
12005: “Some beggar, I suppose. It was naughty of you, Tessa, and I am angry
12006: with Monna Lisa. I must have him sent away.”
12007: 
12008: “No, I think he is not a beggar, for he wanted to pay Monna Lisa, only
12009: she asked him to do work for her instead. And he gets himself shaved,
12010: and his clothes are tidy: Monna Lisa says he is a decent man. But
12011: sometimes I think he is not in his right mind: Lupo, at Peretola, was
12012: not in his right mind, and he looks a little like Lupo sometimes, as if
12013: he didn’t know where he was.”
12014: 
12015: “What sort of face has he?” said Tito, his heart beginning to beat
12016: strangely. He was so haunted by the thought of Baldassarre, that it was
12017: already he whom he saw in imagination sitting on the straw not many
12018: yards from him. “Fetch your stool, my Tessa, and sit on it.”
12019: 
12020: “Shall you not forgive me?” she said, timidly, moving from his knee.
12021: 
12022: “Yes, I will not be angry—only sit down, and tell me what sort of old
12023: man this is.”
12024: 
12025: “I can’t think how to tell you: he is not like my stepfather Nofri, or
12026: anybody. His face is yellow, and he has deep marks in it; and his hair
12027: is white, but there is none on the top of his head: and his eyebrows
12028: are black, and he looks from under them at me, and says, ‘Poor thing!’
12029: to me, as if he thought I was beaten as I used to be; and that seems as
12030: if he couldn’t be in his right mind, doesn’t it? And I asked him his
12031: name once, but he couldn’t tell it me: yet everybody has a name—is it
12032: not true? And he has a book now, and keeps looking at it ever so long,
12033: as if he were a Padre. But I think he is not saying prayers, for his
12034: lips never move;—ah, you are angry with me, or is it because you are
12035: sorry for the old man?”
12036: 
12037: Tito’s eyes were still fixed on Tessa; but he had ceased to see her,
12038: and was only seeing the objects her words suggested. It was this absent
12039: glance which frightened her, and she could not help going to kneel at
12040: his side again. But he did not heed her, and she dared not touch him,
12041: or speak to him: she knelt, trembling and wondering; and this state of
12042: mind suggesting her beads to her, she took them from the floor, and
12043: began to tell them again, her pretty lips moving silently, and her blue
12044: eyes wide with anxiety and struggling tears.
12045: 
12046: Tito was quite unconscious of her movements—unconscious of his own
12047: attitude: he was in that wrapt state in which a man will grasp painful
12048: roughness, and press and press it closer, and never feel it. A new
12049: possibility had risen before him, which might dissolve at once the
12050: wretched conditions of fear and suppression that were marring his life.
12051: Destiny had brought within his reach an opportunity of retrieving that
12052: moment on the steps of the Duomo, when the Past had grasped him with
12053: living quivering hands, and he had disowned it. A few steps, and he
12054: might be face to face with his father, with no witness by; he might
12055: seek forgiveness and reconciliation; and there was money now, from the
12056: sale of the library, to enable them to leave Florence without
12057: disclosure, and go into Southern Italy, where under the probable French
12058: rule, he had already laid a foundation for patronage. Romola need never
12059: know the whole truth, for she could have no certain means of
12060: identifying that prisoner in the Duomo with Baldassarre, or of learning
12061: what had taken place on the steps, except from Baldassarre himself; and
12062: if his father forgave, he would also consent to bury, that offence.
12063: 
12064: But with this possibility of relief, by an easy spring, from present
12065: evil, there rose the other possibility, that the fierce-hearted man
12066: might refuse to be propitiated. Well—and if he did, things would only
12067: be as they had been before; for there would be _no witness by_. It was
12068: not repentance with a white sheet round it and taper in hand,
12069: confessing its hated sin in the eyes of men, that Tito was preparing
12070: for: it was a repentance that would make all things pleasant again, and
12071: keep all past unpleasant things secret. And Tito’s soft-heartedness,
12072: his indisposition to feel himself in harsh relations with any creature,
12073: was in strong activity towards his father, now his father was brought
12074: near to him. It would be a state of ease that his nature could not but
12075: desire, if the poisonous hatred in Baldassarre’s glance could be
12076: replaced by something of the old affection and complacency.
12077: 
12078: Tito longed to have his world once again completely cushioned with
12079: goodwill, and longed for it the more eagerly because of what he had
12080: just suffered from the collision with Romola. It was not difficult to
12081: him to smile pleadingly on those whom he had injured, and offer to do
12082: them much kindness: and no quickness of intellect could tell him
12083: exactly the taste of that honey on the lips of the injured. The
12084: opportunity was there, and it raised an inclination which hemmed in the
12085: calculating activity of his thought. He started up, and stepped towards
12086: the door; but Tessa’s cry, as she dropped her beads, roused him from
12087: his absorption. He turned and said—
12088: 
12089: “My Tessa, get me a lantern; and don’t cry, little pigeon, I am not
12090: angry.”
12091: 
12092: They went down the stairs, and Tessa was going to shout the need of the
12093: lantern in Monna Lisa’s ear, when Tito, who had opened the door, said,
12094: “Stay, Tessa—no, I want no lantern: go upstairs again, and keep quiet,
12095: and say nothing to Monna Lisa.”
12096: 
12097: In half a minute he stood before the closed door of the outhouse, where
12098: the moon was shining white on the old paintless wood.
12099: 
12100: In this last decisive moment, Tito felt a tremor upon him—a sudden
12101: instinctive shrinking from a possible tiger-glance, a possible
12102: tiger-leap. Yet why should he, a young man, be afraid of an old one? a
12103: young man with armour on, of an old man without a weapon? It was but a
12104: moment’s hesitation, and Tito laid his hand on the door. Was his father
12105: asleep? Was there nothing else but the door that screened him from the
12106: voice and the glance which no magic could turn into ease?
12107: 
12108: Baldassarre was not asleep. There was a square opening high in the wall
12109: of the hovel, through which the moonbeams sent in a stream of pale
12110: light; and if Tito could have looked through the opening, he would have
12111: seen his father seated on the straw, with something that shone like a
12112: white star in his hand. Baldassarre was feeling the edge of his
12113: poniard, taking refuge in that sensation from a hopeless blank of
12114: thought that seemed to lie like a great gulf between his passion and
12115: its aim.
12116: 
12117: He was in one of his most wretched moments of conscious helplessness:
12118: he had been poring, while it was light, over the book that lay open
12119: beside him; then he had been trying to recall the names of his jewels,
12120: and the symbols engraved on them; and though at certain other times he
12121: had recovered some of those names and symbols, to-night they were all
12122: gone into darkness. And this effort at inward seeing had seemed to end
12123: in utter paralysis of memory. He was reduced to a sort of mad
12124: consciousness that he was a solitary pulse of just rage in a world
12125: filled with defiant baseness. He had clutched and unsheathed his
12126: dagger, and for a long while had been feeling its edge, his mind
12127: narrowed to one image, and the dream of one sensation—the sensation of
12128: plunging that dagger into a base heart, which he was unable to pierce
12129: in any other way.
12130: 
12131: Tito had his hand on the door and was pulling it: it dragged against
12132: the ground as such old doors often do, and Baldassarre, startled out of
12133: his dreamlike state, rose from his sitting posture in vague amazement,
12134: not knowing where he was. He had not yet risen to his feet, and was
12135: still kneeling on one knee, when the door came wide open and he saw,
12136: dark against the moonlight, with the rays falling on one bright mass of
12137: curls and one rounded olive cheek, the image of his reverie—not
12138: shadowy—close and real like water at the lips after the thirsty dream
12139: of it. No thought could come athwart that eager thirst. In one moment,
12140: before Tito could start back, the old man, with the preternatural force
12141: of rage in his limbs, had sprung forward, and the dagger had flashed
12142: out. In the next moment the dagger had snapped in two, and Baldassarre,
12143: under the parrying force of Tito’s arm, had fallen back on the straw,
12144: clutching the hilt with its bit of broken blade. The pointed end lay
12145: shining against Tito’s feet.
12146: 
12147: Tito had felt one great heart-leap of terror as he had staggered under
12148: the weight of the thrust: he felt now the triumph of deliverance and
12149: safety. His armour had been proved, and vengeance lay helpless before
12150: him. But the triumph raised no devilish impulse; on the contrary, the
12151: sight of his father close to him and unable to injure him, made the
12152: effort at reconciliation easier. He was free from fear, but he had only
12153: the more unmixed and direct want to be free from the sense that he was
12154: hated. After they had looked at each other a little while, Baldassarre
12155: lying motionless in despairing rage, Tito said in his soft tones, just
12156: as they had sounded before the last parting on the shores of Greece—
12157: 
12158: “_Padre mio_!” There was a pause after those words, but no movement or
12159: sound till he said—
12160: 
12161: “I came to ask your forgiveness!”
12162: 
12163: Again he paused, that the healing balm of those words might have time
12164: to work. But there was no sign of change in Baldassarre: he lay as he
12165: had fallen, leaning on one arm: he was trembling, but it was from the
12166: shock that had thrown him down.
12167: 
12168: “I was taken by surprise that morning. I wish now to be a son to you
12169: again. I wish to make the rest of your life happy, that you may forget
12170: what you have suffered.”
12171: 
12172: He paused again. He had used the clearest and strongest words he could
12173: think of. It was useless to say more, until he had some sign that
12174: Baldassarre understood him. Perhaps his mind was too distempered or too
12175: imbecile even for that: perhaps the shock of his fall and his
12176: disappointed rage might have quite suspended the use of his faculties.
12177: 
12178: Presently Baldassarre began to move. He threw away the broken dagger,
12179: and slowly and gradually, still trembling, began to raise himself from
12180: the ground. Tito put out his hand to help him, and so strangely quick
12181: are men’s souls that in this moment, when he began to feel his
12182: atonement was accepted, he had a darting thought of the irksome efforts
12183: it entailed. Baldassarre clutched the hand that was held out, raised
12184: himself and clutched it still, going close up to Tito till their faces
12185: were not a foot off each other. Then he began to speak, in a deep
12186: trembling voice—
12187: 
12188: “I saved you—I nurtured you—I loved you. You forsook me—you robbed
12189: me—you denied me. What can you give me? You have made the world
12190: bitterness to me; but there is one draught of sweetness left—_that you
12191: shall know agony_.”
12192: 
12193: He let fall Tito’s hand, and going backwards a little, first rested his
12194: arm on a projecting stone in the wall, and then sank again in a sitting
12195: posture on the straw. The outleap of fury in the dagger-thrust had
12196: evidently exhausted him.
12197: 
12198: Tito stood silent. If it had been a deep yearning emotion which had
12199: brought him to ask his father’s forgiveness, the denial of it might
12200: have caused him a pang which would have excluded the rushing train of
12201: thought that followed those decisive words. As it was, though the
12202: sentence of unchangeable hatred grated on him and jarred him terribly,
12203: his mind glanced round with a self-preserving instinct to see how far
12204: those words could have the force of a substantial threat. When he had
12205: come down to speak to Baldassarre, he had said to himself that if his
12206: effort at reconciliation failed, things would only be as they had been
12207: before. The first glance of his mind was backward to that thought
12208: again, but the future possibilities of danger that were conjured up
12209: along with it brought the perception that things were _not_ as they had
12210: been before, and the perception came as a triumphant relief. There was
12211: not only the broken dagger, there was the certainty, from what Tessa
12212: had told him, that Baldassarre’s mind was broken too, and had no edge
12213: that could reach him. Tito felt he had no choice now: he must defy
12214: Baldassarre as a mad, imbecile old man; and the chances were so
12215: strongly on his side that there was hardly room for fear. No; except
12216: the fear of having to do many unpleasant things in order to save
12217: himself from what was yet more unpleasant. And one of those unpleasant
12218: things must be done immediately: it was very difficult.
12219: 
12220: “Do you mean to stay here?” he said.
12221: 
12222: “No,” said Baldassarre, bitterly, “you mean to turn me out.”
12223: 
12224: “Not so,” said Tito; “I only ask.”
12225: 
12226: “I tell you, you have turned me out. If it is your straw, you turned me
12227: off it three years ago.”
12228: 
12229: “Then you mean to leave this place?” said Tito, more anxious about this
12230: certainty than the ground of it.
12231: 
12232: “I have spoken,” said Baldassarre.
12233: 
12234: Tito turned and re-entered the house. Monna Lisa was nodding; he went
12235: up to Tessa, and found her crying by the side of her baby.
12236: 
12237: “Tessa,” he said, sitting down and taking her head between his hands;
12238: “leave off crying, little goose, and listen to me.”
12239: 
12240: He lifted her chin upward, that she might look at him, while he spoke
12241: very distinctly and emphatically.
12242: 
12243: “You must never speak to that old man again. He is a mad old man, and
12244: he wants to kill me. Never speak to him or listen to him again.”
12245: 
12246: Tessa’s tears had ceased, and her lips were pale with fright.
12247: 
12248: “Is he gone away?” she whispered.
12249: 
12250: “He will go away. Remember what I have said to you.”
12251: 
12252: “Yes; I will never speak to a stranger any more,” said Tessa, with a
12253: sense of guilt.
12254: 
12255: He told her, to comfort her, that he would come again to-morrow; and
12256: then went down to Monna Lisa to rebuke her severely for letting a
12257: dangerous man come about the house.
12258: 
12259: Tito felt that these were odious tasks; they were very evil-tasted
12260: morsels, but they were forced upon him. He heard Monna Lisa fasten the
12261: door behind him, and turned away, without looking towards the open door
12262: of the hovel. He felt secure that Baldassarre would go, and he could
12263: not wait to see him go. Even _his_ young frame and elastic spirit were
12264: shattered by the agitations that had been crowded into this single
12265: evening.
12266: 
12267: Baldassarre was still sitting on the straw when the shadow of Tito
12268: passed by. Before him lay the fragments of the broken dagger; beside
12269: him lay the open book, over which he had pored in vain. They looked
12270: like mocking symbols of his utter helplessness; and his body was still
12271: too trembling for him to rise and walk away.
12272: 
12273: But the next morning, very early, when Tessa peeped anxiously through
12274: the hole in her shutter, the door of the hovel was open, and the
12275: strange old man was gone.
12276: 
12277: 
12278: 
12279: 
12280: CHAPTER XXXV.
12281: What Florence was thinking of.
12282: 
12283: 
12284: For several days Tito saw little of Romola. He told her gently, the
12285: next morning, that it would be better for her to remove any small
12286: articles of her own from the library, as there would be agents coming
12287: to pack up the antiquities. Then, leaning to kiss her on the brow, he
12288: suggested that she should keep in her own room where the little painted
12289: tabernacle was, and where she was then sitting, so that she might be
12290: away from the noise of strange footsteps, Romola assented quietly,
12291: making no sign of emotion: the night had been one long waking to her,
12292: and, in spite of her healthy frame, sensation had become a dull
12293: continuous pain, as if she had been stunned and bruised. Tito divined
12294: that she felt ill, but he dared say no more; he only dared, perceiving
12295: that her hand and brow were stone cold, to fetch a furred mantle and
12296: throw it lightly round her. And in every brief interval that he
12297: returned to her, the scene was nearly the same: he tried to propitiate
12298: her by some unobtrusive act or word of tenderness, and she seemed to
12299: have lost the power of speaking to him, or of looking at him.
12300: “Patience!” he said to himself. “She will recover it, and forgive at
12301: last. The tie to me must still remain the strongest.” When the stricken
12302: person is slow to recover and look as if nothing had happened, the
12303: striker easily glides into the position of the aggrieved party; he
12304: feels no bruise himself, and is strongly conscious of his own amiable
12305: behaviour since he inflicted the blow. But Tito was not naturally
12306: disposed to feel himself aggrieved; the constant bent of his mind was
12307: towards propitiation, and he would have submitted to much for the sake
12308: of feeling Romola’s hand resting on his head again, as it did that
12309: morning when he first shrank from looking at her.
12310: 
12311: But he found it the less difficult to wait patiently for the return of
12312: his home happiness, because his life out of doors was more and more
12313: interesting to him. A course of action which is in strictness a
12314: slowly-prepared outgrowth of the entire character, is yet almost always
12315: traceable to a single impression as its point of apparent origin; and
12316: since that moment in the Piazza del Duomo, when Tito, mounted on the
12317: bales, had tasted a keen pleasure in the consciousness of his ability
12318: to tickle the ears of men with any phrases that pleased them, his
12319: imagination had glanced continually towards a sort of political
12320: activity which the troubled public life of Florence was likely enough
12321: to find occasion for. But the fresh dread of Baldassarre, waked in the
12322: same moment, had lain like an immovable rocky obstruction across that
12323: path, and had urged him into the sale of the library, as a preparation
12324: for the possible necessity of leaving Florence, at the very time when
12325: he was beginning to feel that it had a new attraction for him. That
12326: dread was nearly removed _now_: he must wear his armour still, he must
12327: prepare himself for possible demands on his coolness and ingenuity, but
12328: he did not feel obliged to take the inconvenient step of leaving
12329: Florence and seeking new fortunes. His father had refused the offered
12330: atonement—had forced him into defiance; and an old man in a strange
12331: place, with his memory gone, was weak enough to be defied.
12332: 
12333: Tito’s implicit desires were working themselves out now in very
12334: explicit thoughts. As the freshness of young passion faded, life was
12335: taking more and more decidedly for him the aspect of a game in which
12336: there was an agreeable mingling of skill and chance.
12337: 
12338: And the game that might be played in Florence promised to be rapid and
12339: exciting; it was a game of revolutionary and party struggle, sure to
12340: include plenty of that unavowed action in which brilliant ingenuity,
12341: able to get rid of all inconvenient beliefs except that “ginger is hot
12342: in the mouth,” is apt to see the path of superior wisdom.
12343: 
12344: No sooner were the French guests gone than Florence was as agitated as
12345: a colony of ants when an alarming shadow has been removed, and the camp
12346: has to be repaired. “How are we to raise the money for the French king?
12347: How are we to manage the war with those obstinate Pisan rebels? Above
12348: all, how are we to mend our plan of government, so as to hit on the
12349: best way of getting our magistrates chosen and our laws voted?” Till
12350: those questions were well answered trade was in danger of standing
12351: still, and that large body of the working men who were not counted as
12352: citizens and had not so much as a vote to serve as an anodyne to their
12353: stomachs were likely to get impatient. Something must be done.
12354: 
12355: And first the great bell was sounded, to call the citizens to a
12356: parliament in the Piazza de’ Signori; and when the crowd was wedged
12357: close, and hemmed in by armed men at all the outlets, the Signoria (or
12358: Gonfaloniere and eight Priors for the time being) came out and stood by
12359: the stone lion on the platform in front of the Old Palace, and proposed
12360: that twenty chief men of the city should have dictatorial authority
12361: given them, by force of which they should for one year choose all
12362: magistrates, and set the frame of government in order. And the people
12363: shouted their assent, and felt themselves the electors of the Twenty.
12364: This kind of “parliament” was a very old Florentine fashion, by which
12365: the will of the few was made to seem the choice of the many.
12366: 
12367: The shouting in the Piazza was soon at an end, but not so the debating
12368: inside the palace: was Florence to have a Great Council after the
12369: Venetian mode, where all the officers of government might be elected,
12370: and all laws voted by a wide number of citizens of a certain age and of
12371: ascertained qualifications, without question of rank or party? or, was
12372: it to be governed on a narrower and less popular scheme, in which the
12373: hereditary influence of good families would be less adulterated with
12374: the votes of shopkeepers. Doctors of law disputed day after day, and
12375: far on into the night. Messer Pagolantonio Soderini alleged excellent
12376: reasons on the side of the popular scheme; Messer Guidantonio Vespucci
12377: alleged reasons equally excellent on the side, of a more aristocratic
12378: form. It was a question of boiled or roast, which had been prejudged by
12379: the palates of the disputants, and the excellent arguing might have
12380: been protracted a long while without any other result than that of
12381: deferring the cooking. The majority of the men inside the palace,
12382: having power already in their hands, agreed with Vespucci, and thought
12383: change should be moderate; the majority outside the palace, conscious
12384: of little power and many grievances, were less afraid of change.
12385: 
12386: And there was a force outside the palace which was gradually tending to
12387: give the vague desires of that majority the character of a determinate
12388: will. That force was the preaching of Savonarola. Impelled partly by
12389: the spiritual necessity that was laid upon him to guide the people, and
12390: partly by the prompting of public-men who could get no measures carried
12391: without his aid, he was rapidly passing in his daily sermons from the
12392: general to the special—from telling his hearers that they must postpone
12393: their private passions and interests to the public good, to telling
12394: them precisely what sort of government they must have in order to
12395: promote that good—from “Choose whatever is best for all” to “Choose the
12396: Great Council,” and “the Great Council is the will of God.”
12397: 
12398: To Savonarola these were as good as identical propositions. The Great
12399: Council was the only practicable plan for giving an expression to the
12400: public will large enough to counteract the vitiating influence of party
12401: interests: it was a plan that would make honest impartial public action
12402: at least possible. And the purer the government of Florence would
12403: become—the more secure from the designs of men who saw their own
12404: advantage in the moral debasement of their fellows—the nearer would the
12405: Florentine people approach the character of a pure community, worthy to
12406: lead the way in the renovation of the Church and the world. And Fra
12407: Girolamo’s mind never stopped short of that sublimest end: the objects
12408: towards which he felt himself working had always the same moral
12409: magnificence. He had no private malice—he sought no petty
12410: gratification. Even in the last terrible days, when ignominy, torture,
12411: and the fear of torture, had laid bare every hidden weakness of his
12412: soul, he could say to his importunate judges: “Do not wonder if it
12413: seems to you that I have told but few things; for my purposes were few
12414: and great.”[1]
12415: 
12416:  [1] “Se vi pare che io abbia detto poche cose, non ve ne maravigliate,
12417:  perchè le mie cose erano poche e grandi.”
12418: 
12419: 
12420: 
12421: 
12422: CHAPTER XXXVI.
12423: Ariadne discrowns herself.
12424: 
12425: 
12426: It was more than three weeks before the contents of the library were
12427: all packed and carried away. And Romola, instead of shutting her eyes
12428: and ears, had watched the process. The exhaustion consequent on violent
12429: emotion is apt to bring a dreamy disbelief in the reality of its cause;
12430: and in the evening, when the workmen were gone, Romola took her
12431: hand-lamp and walked slowly round amongst the confusion of straw and
12432: wooden cases, pausing at every vacant pedestal, every well-known object
12433: laid prostrate, with a sort of bitter desire to assure herself that
12434: there was a sufficient reason why her love was gone and the world was
12435: barren for her. And still, as the evenings came, she went and went
12436: again; no longer to assure herself, but because this vivifying of pain
12437: and despair about her father’s memory was the strongest life left to
12438: her affections. On the 23rd of December, she knew that the last
12439: packages were going. She ran to the loggia at the top of the house that
12440: she might not lose the last pang of seeing the slow wheels move across
12441: the bridge.
12442: 
12443: It was a cloudy day, and nearing dusk. Arno ran dark and shivering; the
12444: hills were mournful; and Florence with its girdling stone towers had
12445: that silent, tomb-like look, which unbroken shadow gives to a city seen
12446: from above. Santa Croce, where her father lay, was dark amidst that
12447: darkness, and slowly crawling over the bridge, and slowly vanishing up
12448: the narrow street, was the white load, like a cruel, deliberate Fate
12449: carrying away her father’s lifelong hope to bury it in an unmarked
12450: grave. Romola felt less that she was seeing this herself than that her
12451: father was conscious of it as he lay helpless under the imprisoning
12452: stones, where her hand could not reach his to tell him that he was not
12453: alone.
12454: 
12455: She stood still even after the load had disappeared, heedless of the
12456: cold, and soothed by the gloom which seemed to cover her like a
12457: mourning garment and shut out the discord of joy. When suddenly the
12458: great bell in the palace-tower rang out a mighty peal: not the
12459: hammer-sound of alarm, but an agitated peal of triumph; and one after
12460: another every other bell in every other tower seemed to catch the
12461: vibration and join the chorus. And, as the chorus swelled and swelled
12462: till the air seemed made of sound—little flames, vibrating too, as if
12463: the sound had caught fire, burst out between the turrets of the palace
12464: and on the girdling towers.
12465: 
12466: That sudden clang, that leaping light, fell on Romola like sharp
12467: wounds. They were the triumph of demons at the success of her husband’s
12468: treachery, and the desolation of her life. Little more than three weeks
12469: ago she had been intoxicated with the sound of those very bells; and in
12470: the gladness of Florence, she had heard a prophecy of her own gladness.
12471: But now the general joy seemed cruel to her: she stood aloof from that
12472: common life—that Florence which was flinging out its loud exultation to
12473: stun the ears of sorrow and loneliness. She could never join hands with
12474: gladness again, but only with those whom it was in the hard nature of
12475: gladness to forget. And in her bitterness she felt that all rejoicing
12476: was mockery. Men shouted paeans with their souls full of heaviness, and
12477: then looked in their neighbours’ faces to see if there was really such
12478: a thing as joy. Romola had lost her belief in the happiness she had
12479: once thirsted for: it was a hateful, smiling, soft-handed thing, with a
12480: narrow, selfish heart.
12481: 
12482: She ran down from the loggia, with her hands pressed against her ears,
12483: and was hurrying across the antechamber, when she was startled by
12484: unexpectedly meeting her husband, who was coming to seek her.
12485: 
12486: His step was elastic, and there was a radiance of satisfaction about
12487: him not quite usual.
12488: 
12489: “What! the noise was a little too much for you?” he said; for Romola,
12490: as she started at the sight of him, had pressed her hands all the
12491: closer against her ears. He took her gently by the wrist, and drew her
12492: arm within his, leading her into the saloon surrounded with the dancing
12493: nymphs and fauns, and then went on speaking: “Florence is gone quite
12494: mad at getting its Great Council, which is to put an end to all the
12495: evils under the sun; especially to the vice of merriment. You may well
12496: look stunned, my Romola, and you are cold. You must not stay so late
12497: under that windy loggia without wrappings. I was coming to tell you
12498: that I am suddenly called to Rome about some learned business for
12499: Bernardo Rucellai. I am going away immediately, for I am to join my
12500: party at San Gaggio to-night, that we may start early in the morning. I
12501: need give you no trouble; I have had my packages made already. It will
12502: not be very long before I am back again.”
12503: 
12504: He knew he had nothing to expect from her but quiet endurance of what
12505: he said and did. He could not even venture to kiss her brow this
12506: evening, but just pressed her hand to his lips, and left her. Tito felt
12507: that Romola was a more unforgiving woman than he had imagined; her love
12508: was not that sweet clinging instinct, stronger than all judgments,
12509: which, he began to see now, made the great charm of a wife. Still, this
12510: petrified coldness was better than a passionate, futile opposition. Her
12511: pride and capability of seeing where resistance was useless had their
12512: convenience.
12513: 
12514: But when the door had closed on Tito, Romola lost the look of cold
12515: immobility which came over her like an inevitable frost whenever he
12516: approached her. Inwardly she was very far from being in a state of
12517: quiet endurance, and the days that had passed since the scene which had
12518: divided her from Tito had been days of active planning and preparation
12519: for the fulfilment of a purpose.
12520: 
12521: The first thing she did now was to call old Maso to her.
12522: 
12523: “Maso,” she said, in a decided tone, “we take our journey to-morrow
12524: morning. We shall be able now to overtake that first convoy of cloth,
12525: while they are waiting at San Piero. See about the two mules to-night,
12526: and be ready to set off with them at break of day, and wait for me at
12527: Trespiano.”
12528: 
12529: She meant to take Maso with her as far as Bologna, and then send him
12530: back with letters to her godfather and Tito, telling them that she was
12531: gone and never meant to return. She had planned her departure so that
12532: its secrecy might be perfect, and her broken love and life be hidden
12533: away unscanned by vulgar eyes. Bernardo del Nero had been absent at his
12534: villa, willing to escape from political suspicions to his favourite
12535: occupation of attending to his land, and she had paid him the debt
12536: without a personal interview. He did not even know that the library was
12537: sold, and was left to conjecture that some sudden piece of good fortune
12538: had enabled Tito to raise this sum of money. Maso had been taken into
12539: her confidence only so far that he knew her intended journey was a
12540: secret; and to do just what she told him was the thing he cared most
12541: for in his withered wintry age.
12542: 
12543: Romola did not mean to go to bed that night. When she had fastened the
12544: door she took her taper to the carved and painted chest which contained
12545: her wedding-clothes. The white silk and gold lay there, the long white
12546: veil and the circlet of pearls. A great sob rose as she looked at them:
12547: they seemed the shroud of her dead happiness. In a tiny gold loop of
12548: the circlet a sugar-plum had lodged—a pink hailstone from the shower of
12549: sweets: Tito had detected it first, and had said that it should always
12550: remain there. At certain moments—and this was one of them—Romola was
12551: carried, by a sudden wave of memory, back again into the time of
12552: perfect trust, and felt again the presence of the husband whose love
12553: made the world as fresh and wonderful to her as to a little child that
12554: sits in stillness among the sunny flowers: heard the gentle tones and
12555: saw the soft eyes without any lie in them, and breathed again that
12556: large freedom of the soul which comes from the faith that the being who
12557: is nearest to us is greater than ourselves. And in those brief moments
12558: the tears always rose: the woman’s lovingness felt something akin to
12559: what the bereaved mother feels when the tiny fingers seem to lie warm
12560: on her bosom, and yet are marble to her lips as she bends over the
12561: silent bed.
12562: 
12563: But there was something else lying in the chest besides the
12564: wedding-clothes: it was something dark and coarse, rolled up in a close
12565: bundle. She turned away her eyes from the white and gold to the dark
12566: bundle, and as her hands touched the serge, her tears began to be
12567: checked. That coarse roughness recalled her fully to the present, from
12568: which love and delight were gone. She unfastened the thick white cord
12569: and spread the bundle out on the table. It was the grey serge dress of
12570: a sister belonging to the third order of Saint Francis, living in the
12571: world but especially devoted to deeds of piety—a personage whom the
12572: Florentines were accustomed to call a Pinzochera. Romola was going to
12573: put on this dress as a disguise, and she determined to put it on at
12574: once, so that, if she needed sleep before the morning, she might wake
12575: up in perfect readiness to be gone. She put off her black garment, and
12576: as she thrust her soft white arms into the harsh sleeves of the serge
12577: mantle and felt the hard girdle of rope hurt her fingers as she tied
12578: it, she courted those rude sensations: they were in keeping with her
12579: new scorn of that thing called pleasure which made men base—that
12580: dexterous contrivance for selfish ease, that shrinking from endurance
12581: and strain, when others were bowing beneath burdens too heavy for them,
12582: which now made one image with her husband. Then she gathered her long
12583: hair together, drew it away tight from her face, bound it in a great
12584: hard knot at the back of her head, and taking a square piece of black
12585: silk, tied it in the fashion of a kerchief close across her head and
12586: under her chin; and over that she drew the cowl. She lifted the candle
12587: to the mirror. Surely her disguise would be complete to any one who had
12588: not lived very near to her. To herself she looked strangely like her
12589: brother Dino: the full oval of the cheek had only to be wasted; the
12590: eyes, already sad, had only to become a little sunken. Was she getting
12591: more like him in anything else? Only in this, that she understood now
12592: how men could be prompted to rush away for ever from earthly delights,
12593: how they could be prompted to dwell on images of sorrow rather than of
12594: beauty and joy.
12595: 
12596: But she did not linger at the mirror: she set about collecting and
12597: packing all the relics of her father and mother that were too large to
12598: be carried in her small travelling-wallet. They were all to be put in
12599: the chest along with her wedding-clothes, and the chest was to be
12600: committed to her godfather when she was safely gone. First she laid in
12601: the portraits; then one by one every little thing that had a sacred
12602: memory clinging to it was put into her wallet or into the chest.
12603: 
12604: She paused. There was still something else to be stript away from her,
12605: belonging to that past on which she was going to turn her back for
12606: ever. She put her thumb and her forefinger to her betrothal ring; but
12607: they rested there, without drawing it off. Romola’s mind had been
12608: rushing with an impetuous current towards this act, for which she was
12609: preparing: the act of quitting a husband who had disappointed all her
12610: trust, the act of breaking an outward tie that no longer represented
12611: the inward bond of love. But that force of outward symbols by which our
12612: active life is knit together so as to make an inexorable external
12613: identity for us, not to be shaken by our wavering consciousness, gave a
12614: strange effect to this simple movement towards taking off her ring—a
12615: movement which was but a small sequence of her energetic resolution. It
12616: brought a vague but arresting sense that she was somehow violently
12617: rending her life in two: a presentiment that the strong impulse which
12618: had seemed to exclude doubt and make her path clear might after all be
12619: blindness, and that there was something in human bonds which must
12620: prevent them from being broken with the breaking of illusions.
12621: 
12622: If that beloved Tito who had placed the betrothal ring on her finger
12623: was not in any valid sense the same Tito whom she had ceased to love,
12624: why should she return to him the sign of their union, and not rather
12625: retain it as a memorial? And this act, which came as a palpable
12626: demonstration of her own and his identity, had a power unexplained to
12627: herself, of shaking Romola. It is the way with half the truth amidst
12628: which we live, that it only haunts us and makes dull pulsations that
12629: are never born into sound. But there was a passionate voice speaking
12630: within her that presently nullified all such muffled murmurs.
12631: 
12632: “It cannot be! I cannot be subject to him. He is false. I shrink from
12633: him. I despise him!”
12634: 
12635: She snatched the ring from her finger and laid it on the table against
12636: the pen with which she meant to write. Again she felt that there could
12637: be no law for her but the law of her affections. That tenderness and
12638: keen fellow-feeling for the near and the loved which are the main
12639: outgrowth of the affections, had made the religion of her life: they
12640: had made her patient in spite of natural impetuosity: they would have
12641: sufficed to make her heroic. But now all that strength was gone, or,
12642: rather, it was converted into the strength of repulsion. She had
12643: recoiled from Tito in proportion to the energy of that young belief and
12644: love which he had disappointed, of that lifelong devotion to her father
12645: against which he had committed an irredeemable offence. And it seemed
12646: as if all motive had slipped away from her, except the indignation and
12647: scorn that made her tear herself asunder from him.
12648: 
12649: She was not acting after any precedent, or obeying any adopted maxims.
12650: The grand severity of the stoical philosophy in which her father had
12651: taken care to instruct her, was familiar enough to her ears and lips,
12652: and its lofty spirit had raised certain echoes within her; but she had
12653: never used it, never needed it as a rule of life. She had endured and
12654: forborne because she loved: maxims which told her to feel less, and not
12655: to cling close lest the onward course of great Nature should jar her,
12656: had been as powerless on her tenderness as they had been on her
12657: father’s yearning for just fame. She had appropriated no theories: she
12658: had simply felt strong in the strength of affection, and life without
12659: that energy came to her as an entirely new problem.
12660: 
12661: She was going to solve the problem in a way that seemed to her very
12662: simple. Her mind had never yet bowed to any obligation apart from
12663: personal love and reverence; she had no keen sense of any other human
12664: relations, and all she had to obey now was the instinct to sever
12665: herself from the man she loved no longer.
12666: 
12667: Yet the unswerving resolution was accompanied with continually varying
12668: phases of anguish. And now that the active preparation for her
12669: departure was almost finished, she lingered: she deferred writing the
12670: irrevocable words of parting from all her little world. The emotions of
12671: the past weeks seemed to rush in again with cruel hurry, and take
12672: possession even of her limbs. She was going to write, and her hand
12673: fell. Bitter tears came now at the delusion which had blighted her
12674: young years, tears very different from the sob of remembered happiness
12675: with which she had looked at the circlet of pearls and the pink
12676: hailstone. And now she felt a tingling shame at the words of ignominy
12677: she had cast, at Tito—“Have you robbed some one else who is _not_
12678: dead?” To have had such words wrung from her—to have uttered them to
12679: her husband seemed a degradation of her whole life. Hard speech between
12680: those who have loved is hideous in the memory, like the sight of
12681: greatness and beauty sunk into vice and rags.
12682: 
12683: That heart-cutting comparison of the present with the past urged itself
12684: upon Romola till it even transformed itself into wretched sensations:
12685: she seemed benumbed to everything but inward throbbings, and began to
12686: feel the need of some hard contact. She drew her hands tight along the
12687: harsh knotted cord that hung from her waist. She started to her feet
12688: and seized the rough lid of the chest: there was nothing else to go in?
12689: No. She closed the lid, pressing her hand upon the rough carving, and
12690: locked it.
12691: 
12692: Then she remembered that she had still to complete her equipment as a
12693: Pinzochera. The large leather purse or scarsella, with small coin in
12694: it, had to be hung on the cord at her waist (her florins and small
12695: jewels, presents from her godfather and cousin Brigida, were safely
12696: fastened within her serge mantle)—and on the other side must hang the
12697: rosary.
12698: 
12699: It did not occur to Romola, as she hung that rosary by her side, that
12700: something else besides the mere garb would perhaps be necessary to
12701: enable her to pass as a Pinzochera, and that her whole air and
12702: expression were as little as possible like those of a sister whose
12703: eyelids were used to be bent, and whose lips were used to move in
12704: silent iteration. Her inexperience prevented her from picturing distant
12705: details, and it helped her proud courage in shutting out any foreboding
12706: of danger and insult. She did not know that any Florentine woman had
12707: ever done exactly what she was going to do: unhappy wives often took
12708: refuge with their friends, or in the cloister, she knew, but both those
12709: courses were impossible to her; she had invented a lot for herself—to
12710: go to the most learned woman in the world, Cassandra Fedele, at Venice,
12711: and ask her how an instructed woman could support herself in a lonely
12712: life there.
12713: 
12714: She was not daunted by the practical difficulties in the way or the
12715: dark uncertainty at the end. Her life could never be happy any more,
12716: but it must not, could not, be ignoble. And by a pathetic mixture of
12717: childish romance with her woman’s trials, the philosophy which had
12718: nothing to do with this great decisive deed of hers had its place in
12719: her imagination of the future: so far as she conceived her solitary
12720: loveless life at all, she saw it animated by a proud stoical heroism,
12721: and by an indistinct but strong purpose of labour, that she might be
12722: wise enough to write something which would rescue her father’s name
12723: from oblivion. After all, she was only a young girl—this poor Romola,
12724: who had found herself at the end of her joys.
12725: 
12726: There were other things yet to be done. There was a small key in a
12727: casket on the table—but now Romola perceived that her taper was dying
12728: out, and she had forgotten to provide herself with any other light. In
12729: a few moments the room was in total darkness. Feeling her way to the
12730: nearest chair, she sat down to wait for the morning.
12731: 
12732: Her purpose in seeking the key had called up certain memories which had
12733: come back upon her during the past week with the new vividness that
12734: remembered words always have for us when we have learned to give them a
12735: new meaning. Since the shock of the revelation which had seemed to
12736: divide her for ever from Tito, that last interview with Dino had never
12737: been for many hours together out of her mind. And it solicited her all
12738: the more, because while its remembered images pressed upon her almost
12739: with the imperious force of sensations, they raised struggling thoughts
12740: which resisted their influence. She could not prevent herself from
12741: hearing inwardly the dying prophetic voice saying again and again,—“The
12742: man whose face was a blank loosed thy hand and departed; and as he
12743: went, I could see his face, and it was the face of the great Tempter...
12744: And thou, Romola, didst wring thy hands and seek for water, and there
12745: was none... and the plain was bare and stony again, and thou wast alone
12746: in the midst of it. And then it seemed that the night fell, and I saw
12747: no more.” She could not prevent herself from dwelling with a sort of
12748: agonised fascination on the wasted face; on the straining gaze at the
12749: crucifix; on the awe which had compelled her to kneel; on the last
12750: broken words and then the unbroken silence—on all the details of the
12751: death-scene, which had seemed like a sudden opening into a world apart
12752: from that of her lifelong knowledge.
12753: 
12754: But her mind was roused to resistance of impressions that, from being
12755: obvious phantoms, seemed to be getting solid in the daylight. As a
12756: strong body struggles against fumes with the more violence when they
12757: begin to be stifling, a strong soul struggles against phantasies with
12758: all the more alarmed energy when they threaten to govern in the place
12759: of thought.
12760: 
12761: What had the words of that vision to do with her real sorrows? That
12762: fitting of certain words was a mere chance; the rest was all vague—nay,
12763: those words themselves were vague; they were determined by nothing but
12764: her brother’s memories and beliefs. He believed there was something
12765: fatal in pagan learning; he believed that celibacy was more holy than
12766: marriage; he remembered their home, and all the objects in the library;
12767: and of these threads the vision was woven. What reasonable warrant
12768: could she have had for believing in such a vision and acting on it?
12769: None. True as the voice of foreboding had proved, Romola saw with
12770: unshaken conviction that to have renounced Tito in obedience to a
12771: warning like that, would have been meagre-hearted folly. Her trust had
12772: been delusive, but she would have chosen over again to have acted on it
12773: rather than be a creature led by phantoms and disjointed whispers in a
12774: world where there was the large music of reasonable speech, and the
12775: warm grasp of living hands.
12776: 
12777: But the persistent presence of these memories, linking themselves in
12778: her imagination with her actual lot, gave her a glimpse of
12779: understanding into the lives which had before lain utterly aloof from
12780: her sympathy—the lives of the men and women who were led by such inward
12781: images and voices.
12782: 
12783: “If they were only a little stronger in me,” she said to herself, “I
12784: should lose the sense of what that vision really was, and take it for a
12785: prophetic light. I might in time get to be a seer of visions myself,
12786: like the Suora Maddalena, and Camilla Rucellai, and the rest.”
12787: 
12788: Romola shuddered at the possibility. All the instruction, all the main
12789: influences of her life had gone to fortify her scorn of that sickly
12790: superstition which led men and women, with eyes too weak for the
12791: daylight, to sit in dark swamps and try to read human destiny by the
12792: chance flame of wandering vapours.
12793: 
12794: And yet she was conscious of something deeper than that coincidence of
12795: words which made the parting contact with her dying brother live anew
12796: in her mind, and gave a new sisterhood to the wasted face. If there
12797: were much more of such experience as his in the world, she would like
12798: to understand it—would even like to learn the thoughts of men who sank
12799: in ecstasy before the pictured agonies of martyrdom. There seemed to be
12800: something more than madness in that supreme fellowship with suffering.
12801: The springs were all dried up around her; she wondered what other
12802: waters there were at which men drank and found strength in the desert.
12803: And those moments in the Duomo when she had sobbed with a mysterious
12804: mingling of rapture and pain, while Fra Girolamo offered himself a
12805: willing sacrifice for the people, came back to her as if they had been
12806: a transient taste of some such far-off fountain. But again she shrank
12807: from impressions that were alluring her within the sphere of visions
12808: and narrow fears which compelled men to outrage natural affections as
12809: Dino had done.
12810: 
12811: This was the tangled web that Romola had in her mind as she sat weary
12812: in the darkness. No radiant angel came across the gloom with a clear
12813: message for her. In those times, as now, there were human beings who
12814: never saw angels or heard perfectly clear messages. Such truth as came
12815: to them was brought confusedly in the voices and deeds of men not at
12816: all like the seraphs of unfailing wing and piercing vision—men who
12817: believed falsities as well as truths, and did the wrong as well as the
12818: right. The helping hands stretched out to them were the hands of men
12819: who stumbled and often saw dimly, so that these beings unvisited by
12820: angels had no other choice than to grasp that stumbling guidance along
12821: the path of reliance and action which is the path of life, or else to
12822: pause in loneliness and disbelief, which is no path, but the arrest of
12823: inaction and death.
12824: 
12825: And so Romola, seeing no ray across the darkness, and heavy with
12826: conflict that changed nothing, sank at last to sleep.
12827: 
12828: 
12829: 
12830: 
12831: CHAPTER XXXVII.
12832: The Tabernacle Unlocked.
12833: 
12834: 
12835: Romola was waked by a tap at the door. The cold light of early morning
12836: was in the room, and Maso was come for the travelling-wallet. The old
12837: man could not help starting when she opened the door, and showed him,
12838: instead of the graceful outline he had been used to, crowned with the
12839: brightness of her hair, the thick folds of the grey mantle and the pale
12840: face shadowed by the dark cowl.
12841: 
12842: “It is well, Maso,” said Romola, trying to speak in the calmest voice,
12843: and make the old man easy. “Here is the wallet quite ready. You will go
12844: on quietly, and I shall not be far behind you. When you get out of the
12845: gates you may go more slowly, for I shall perhaps join you before you
12846: get to Trespiano.”
12847: 
12848: She closed the door behind him, and then put her hand on the key which
12849: she had taken from the casket the last thing in the night. It was the
12850: original key of the little painted tabernacle: Tito had forgotten to
12851: drown it in the Arno, and it had lodged, as such small things will, in
12852: the corner of the embroidered scarsella which he wore with the purple
12853: tunic. One day, long after their marriage, Romola had found it there,
12854: and had put it by, without using it, but with a sense of satisfaction
12855: that the key was within reach. The cabinet on which the tabernacle
12856: stood had been moved to the side of the room, close to one of the
12857: windows, where the pale morning light fell upon it so as to make the
12858: painted forms discernible enough to Romola, who knew them well,—the
12859: triumphant Bacchus, with his clusters and his vine-clad spear, clasping
12860: the crowned Ariadne; the Loves showering roses, the wreathed vessel,
12861: the cunning-eyed dolphins, and the rippled sea: all encircled by a
12862: flowery border, like a bower of paradise. Romola looked at the familiar
12863: images with new bitterness and repulsion: they seemed a more pitiable
12864: mockery than ever on this chill morning, when she had waked up to
12865: wander in loneliness. They had been no tomb of sorrow, but a lying
12866: screen. Foolish Ariadne! with her gaze of love, as if that bright face,
12867: with its hyacinthine curls like tendrils among the vines, held the deep
12868: secret of her life!
12869: 
12870: “Ariadne is wonderfully transformed,” thought Romola. “She would look
12871: strange among the vines and the roses now.”
12872: 
12873: She took up the mirror, and looked at herself once more. But the sight
12874: was so startling in this morning light that she laid it down again,
12875: with a sense of shrinking almost as strong as that with which she had
12876: turned from the joyous Ariadne. The recognition of her own face, with
12877: the cowl about it, brought back the dread lest she should be drawn at
12878: last into fellowship with some wretched superstition—into the company
12879: of the howling fanatics and weeping nuns who had been her contempt from
12880: childhood till now. She thrust the key into the tabernacle hurriedly:
12881: hurriedly she opened it, and took out the crucifix, without looking at
12882: it; then, with trembling fingers, she passed a cord through the little
12883: ring, hung the crucifix round her neck, and hid it in the bosom of her
12884: mantle. “For Dino’s sake,” she said to herself. Still there were the
12885: letters to be written which Maso was to carry back from Bologna. They
12886: were very brief. The first said—
12887: 
12888: “Tito, my love for you is dead; and therefore, so far as I was yours, I
12889: too am dead. Do not try to put in force any laws for the sake of
12890: fetching me back: that would bring you no happiness. The Romola you
12891: married can never return. I need explain nothing to you after the words
12892: I uttered to you the last time we spoke long together. If you supposed
12893: them to be words of transient anger, you will know now that they were
12894: the sign of an irreversible change.
12895: 
12896: “I think you will fulfil my wish that my bridal chest should be sent to
12897: my godfather, who gave it me. It contains my wedding-clothes and the
12898: portraits and other relics of my father and mother.”
12899: 
12900: She folded the ring inside this letter, and wrote Tito’s name outside.
12901: The next letter was to Bernardo del Nero:—
12902: 
12903: “Dearest Godfather,—If I could have been any good to your life by
12904: staying I would not have gone away to a distance. But now I am gone. Do
12905: not ask the reason; and if you love my father, try to prevent any one
12906: from seeking me. I could not bear my life at Florence. I cannot bear to
12907: tell any one why. Help to cover my lot in silence. I have asked that my
12908: bridal chest should be sent to you: when you open it, you will know the
12909: reason. Please to give all the things that were my mother’s to my
12910: cousin Brigida, and ask her to forgive me for not saying any words of
12911: parting to her.
12912: 
12913: “Farewell, my second father. The best thing I have in life is still to
12914: remember your goodness and be grateful to you.
12915: 
12916: “Romola.”
12917: 
12918: Romola put the letters, along with the crucifix, within the bosom of
12919: her mantle, and then felt that everything was done. She was ready now
12920: to depart.
12921: 
12922: No one was stirring in the house, and she went almost as quietly as a
12923: grey phantom down the stairs and into the silent street. Her heart was
12924: palpitating violently, yet she enjoyed the sense of her firm tread on
12925: the broad flags—of the swift movement, which was like a chained-up
12926: resolution set free at last. The anxiety to carry out her act, and the
12927: dread of any obstacle, averted sorrow; and as she reached the Ponte
12928: Rubaconte, she felt less that Santa Croce was in her sight than that
12929: the yellow streak of morning which parted the grey was getting broader
12930: and broader, and that, unless she hastened her steps, she should have
12931: to encounter faces.
12932: 
12933: Her simplest road was to go right on to the Borgo Pinti, and then along
12934: by the walls to the Porta San Gallo, from which she must leave the
12935: city, and this road carried her by the Piazza di Santa Croce. But she
12936: walked as steadily and rapidly as ever through the piazza, not trusting
12937: herself to look towards the church. The thought that any eyes might be
12938: turned on her with a look of curiosity and recognition, and that
12939: indifferent minds might be set speculating on her private sorrows, made
12940: Romola shrink physically as from the imagination of torture. She felt
12941: degraded even by that act of her husband from which she was helplessly
12942: suffering. But there was no sign that any eyes looked forth from
12943: windows to notice this tall grey sister, with the firm step, and proud
12944: attitude of the cowled head. Her road lay aloof from the stir of early
12945: traffic, and when she reached the Porta San Gallo, it was easy to pass
12946: while a dispute was going forward about the toll for panniers of eggs
12947: and market produce which were just entering.
12948: 
12949: Out! Once past the houses of the Borgo, she would be beyond the last
12950: fringe of Florence, the sky would be broad above her, and she would
12951: have entered on her new life—a life of loneliness and endurance, but of
12952: freedom. She had been strong enough to snap asunder the bonds she had
12953: accepted in blind faith: whatever befell her, she would no more feel
12954: the breath of soft hated lips warm upon her cheek, no longer feel the
12955: breath of an odious mind stifling her own. The bare wintry morning, the
12956: chill air, were welcome in their severity: the leafless trees, the
12957: sombre hills, were not haunted by the gods of beauty and joy, whose
12958: worship she had forsaken for ever.
12959: 
12960: But presently the light burst forth with sudden strength, and shadows
12961: were thrown across the road. It seemed that the sun was going to chase
12962: away the greyness. The light is perhaps never felt more strongly as a
12963: divine presence stirring all those inarticulate sensibilities which are
12964: our deepest life, than in these moments when it instantaneously awakens
12965: the shadows. A certain awe which inevitably accompanied this most
12966: momentous act of her life became a more conscious element in Romola’s
12967: feeling as she found herself in the sudden presence of the impalpable
