12968: golden glory and the long shadow of herself that was not to be escaped.
12969: Hitherto she had met no one but an occasional contadino with mules, and
12970: the many turnings of the road on the level prevented her from seeing
12971: that Maso was not very far ahead of her. But when she had passed Pietra
12972: and was on rising ground, she lifted up the hanging roof of her cowl
12973: and looked eagerly before her.
12974: 
12975: The cowl was dropped again immediately. She had seen, not Maso, but—two
12976: monks, who were approaching within a few yards of her. The edge of her
12977: cowl making a pent-house on her brow had shut out the objects above the
12978: level of her eyes, and for the last few moments she had been looking at
12979: nothing but the brightness on the path and at her own shadow, tall and
12980: shrouded like a dread spectre.
12981: 
12982: She wished now that she had not looked up. Her disguise made her
12983: especially dislike to encounter monks: they might expect some pious
12984: passwords of which she knew nothing, and she walked along with a
12985: careful appearance of unconsciousness till she had seen the skirts of
12986: the black mantles pass by her. The encounter had made her heart beat
12987: disagreeably, for Romola had an uneasiness in her religious disguise, a
12988: shame at this studied concealment, which was made more distinct by a
12989: special effort to appear unconscious under actual glances.
12990: 
12991: But the black skirts would be gone the faster because they were going
12992: down-hill; and seeing a great flat stone against a cypress that rose
12993: from a projecting green bank, she yielded to the desire which the
12994: slight shock had given her, to sit down and rest.
12995: 
12996: She turned her back on Florence, not meaning to look at it till the
12997: monks were quite out of sight, and raising the edge of her cowl again
12998: when she had seated herself, she discerned Maso and the mules at a
12999: distance where it was not hopeless for her to overtake them, as the old
13000: man would probably linger in expectation of her.
13001: 
13002: Meanwhile she might pause a little. She was free and alone.
13003: 
13004: 
13005: 
13006: 
13007: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
13008: The Black Marks become Magical.
13009: 
13010: 
13011: That journey of Tito’s to Rome, which had removed many difficulties
13012: from Romola’s departure, had been resolved on quite suddenly, at a
13013: supper, only the evening before.
13014: 
13015: Tito had set out towards that supper with agreeable expectations. The
13016: meats were likely to be delicate, the wines choice, the company
13017: distinguished; for the place of entertainment was the Selva or Orto de’
13018: Rucellai, or, as we should say, the Rucellai Gardens; and the host,
13019: Bernardo Rucellai, was quite a typical Florentine grandee. Even his
13020: family name has a significance which is prettily symbolic: properly
13021: understood, it may bring before us a little lichen, popularly named
13022: _orcella_ or _roccella_, which grows on the rocks of Greek isles and in
13023: the Canaries; and having drunk a great deal of light into its little
13024: stems and button-heads, will, under certain circumstances, give it out
13025: again as a reddish purple dye, very grateful to the eyes of men. By
13026: bringing the excellent secret of this dye, called _oricello_, from the
13027: Levant to Florence, a certain merchant, who lived nearly a hundred
13028: years before our Bernardo’s time, won for himself and his descendants
13029: much wealth, and the pleasantly-suggestive surname of Oricellari, or
13030: Roccellari, which on Tuscan tongues speedily became Rucellai.
13031: 
13032: And our Bernardo, who stands out more prominently than the rest on this
13033: purple background, had added all sorts of distinction to the family
13034: name: he had married the sister of Lorenzo de’ Medici, and had had the
13035: most splendid wedding in the memory of Florentine upholstery; and for
13036: these and other virtues he had been sent on embassies to France and
13037: Venice, and had been chosen Gonfaloniere; he had not only built himself
13038: a fine palace, but had finished putting the black and white marble
13039: façade to the church of Santa Maria Novella; he had planted a garden
13040: with rare trees, and had made it classic ground by receiving within it
13041: the meetings of the Platonic Academy, orphaned by the death of Lorenzo;
13042: he had written an excellent, learned book, of a new topographical sort,
13043: about ancient Rome; he had collected antiquities; he had a pure
13044: Latinity. The simplest account of him, one sees, reads like a laudatory
13045: epitaph, at the end of which the Greek and Ausonian Muses might be
13046: confidently requested to tear their hair, and Nature to desist from any
13047: second attempt to combine so many virtues with one set of viscera.
13048: 
13049: His invitation had been conveyed to Tito through Lorenzo Tornabuoni,
13050: with an emphasis which would have suggested that the object of the
13051: gathering was political, even if the public questions of the time had
13052: been less absorbing. As it was, Tito felt sure that some party purposes
13053: were to be furthered by the excellent flavours of stewed fish and old
13054: Greek wine; for Bernardo Rucellai was not simply an influential
13055: personage, he was one of the elect Twenty who for three weeks had held
13056: the reins of Florence. This assurance put Tito in the best spirits as
13057: he made his way to the Via della Scala, where the classic garden was to
13058: be found: without it, he might have had some uneasy speculation as to
13059: whether the high company he would have the honour of meeting was likely
13060: to be dull as well as distinguished; for he had had experience of
13061: various dull suppers even in the Rucellai gardens, and especially of
13062: the dull philosophic sort, wherein he had not only been called upon to
13063: accept an entire scheme of the universe (which would have been easy to
13064: him), but to listen to an exposition of the same, from the origin of
13065: things to their complete ripeness in the tractate of the philosopher
13066: then speaking.
13067: 
13068: It was a dark evening, and it was only when Tito crossed the occasional
13069: light of a lamp suspended before an image of the Virgin, that the
13070: outline of his figure was discernible enough for recognition. At such
13071: moments any one caring to watch his passage from one of these lights to
13072: another might have observed that the tall and graceful personage with
13073: the mantle folded round him was followed constantly by a very different
13074: form, thickset and elderly, in a serge tunic and felt hat. The
13075: conjunction might have been taken for mere chance, since there were
13076: many passengers along the streets at this hour. But when Tito stopped
13077: at the gate of the Rucellai gardens, the figure behind stopped too. The
13078: _sportello_, or smaller door of the gate, was already being held open
13079: by the servant, who, in the distraction of attending to some question,
13080: had not yet closed it since the last arrival, and Tito turned in
13081: rapidly, giving his name to the servant, and passing on between the
13082: evergreen bushes that shone like metal in the torchlight. The follower
13083: turned in too.
13084: 
13085: “Your name?” said the servant.
13086: 
13087: “Baldassarre Calvo,” was the immediate answer.
13088: 
13089: “You are not a guest; the guests have all passed.”
13090: 
13091: “I belong to Tito Melema, who has just gone in. I am to wait in the
13092: gardens.”
13093: 
13094: The servant hesitated. “I had orders to admit only guests. Are you a
13095: servant of Messer Tito?”
13096: 
13097: “No, friend, I am not a servant; I am a scholar.”
13098: 
13099: There are men to whom you need only say, “I am a buffalo,” in a certain
13100: tone of quiet confidence, and they will let you pass. The porter gave
13101: way at once, Baldassarre entered, and heard the door closed and chained
13102: behind him, as he too disappeared among the shining bushes.
13103: 
13104: Those ready and firm answers argued a great change in Baldassarre since
13105: the last meeting face to face with Tito, when the dagger broke in two.
13106: 
13107: The change had declared itself in a startling way.
13108: 
13109: At the moment when the shadow of Tito passed in front of the hovel as
13110: he departed homeward, Baldassarre was sitting in that state of
13111: after-tremor known to every one who is liable to great outbursts of
13112: passion: a state in which physical powerlessness is sometimes
13113: accompanied by an exceptional lucidity of thought, as if that
13114: disengagement of excited passion had carried away a fire-mist and left
13115: clearness behind it. He felt unable to rise and walk away just yet; his
13116: limbs seemed benumbed; he was cold, and his hands shook. But in that
13117: bodily helplessness he sat surrounded, not by the habitual dimness and
13118: vanishing shadows, but by the clear images of the past; he was living
13119: again in an unbroken course through that life which seemed a long
13120: preparation for the taste of bitterness.
13121: 
13122: For some minutes he was too thoroughly absorbed by the images to
13123: reflect on the fact that he saw them, and note the fact as a change.
13124: But when that sudden clearness had travelled through the distance, and
13125: came at last to rest on the scene just gone by, he felt fully where he
13126: was: he remembered Monna Lisa and Tessa. Ah! _he_ then was the
13127: mysterious husband; he who had another wife in the Via de’ Bardi. It
13128: was time to pick up the broken dagger and go—go and leave no trace of
13129: himself; for to hide his feebleness seemed the thing most like power
13130: that was left to him. He leaned to take up the fragments of the dagger;
13131: then he turned towards the book which lay open at his side. It was a
13132: fine large manuscript, an odd volume of Pausanias. The moonlight was
13133: upon it, and he could see the large letters at the head of the page:
13134: 
13135: ΜΕΣΣΕΝΙΚΑ. ΚΒ′.
13136: 
13137: 
13138: In old days he had known Pausanias familiarly; yet an hour or two ago
13139: he had been looking hopelessly at that page, and it had suggested no
13140: more meaning to him than if the letters had been black weather-marks on
13141: a wall; but at this moment they were once more the magic signs that
13142: conjure up a world. That moonbeam falling on the letters had raised
13143: Messenia before him, and its struggle against the Spartan oppression.
13144: 
13145: He snatched up the book, but the light was too pale for him to read
13146: further by. No matter: he knew that chapter; he read inwardly. He saw
13147: the stoning of the traitor Aristocrates—stoned by a whole people, who
13148: cast him out from their borders to lie unburied, and set up a pillar
13149: with verses upon it telling how Time had brought home justice to the
13150: unjust. The words arose within him, and stirred innumerable vibrations
13151: of memory. He forgot that he was old: he could almost have shouted. The
13152: light was come again, mother of knowledge and joy! In that exultation
13153: his limbs recovered their strength: he started up with his broken
13154: dagger and book, and went out under the broad moonlight.
13155: 
13156: It was a nipping frosty air, but Baldassarre could feel no chill—he
13157: only felt the glow of conscious power. He walked about and paused on
13158: all the open spots of that high ground, and looked down on the domed
13159: and towered city, sleeping darkly under its sleeping guardians, the
13160: mountains; on the pale gleam of the river; on the valley vanishing
13161: towards the peaks of snow; and felt himself master of them all.
13162: 
13163: That sense of mental empire which belongs to us all in moments of
13164: exceptional clearness was intensified for him by the long days and
13165: nights in which memory had been little more than the consciousness of
13166: something gone. That city, which had been a weary labyrinth, was
13167: material that he could subdue to his purposes now: his mind glanced
13168: through its affairs with flashing conjecture; he was once more a man
13169: who knew cities, whose sense of vision was instructed with large
13170: experience, and who felt the keen delight of holding all things in the
13171: grasp of language. Names! Images!—his mind rushed through its wealth
13172: without pausing, like one who enters on a great inheritance.
13173: 
13174: But amidst all that rushing eagerness there was one End presiding in
13175: Baldassarre’s consciousness,—a dark deity in the inmost cell, who only
13176: seemed forgotten while his hecatomb was being prepared. And when the
13177: first triumph in the certainty of recovered power had had its way, his
13178: thoughts centred themselves on Tito. That fair slippery viper could not
13179: escape him now; thanks to struggling justice, the heart that never
13180: quivered with tenderness for another had its sensitive selfish fibres
13181: that could be reached by the sharp point of anguish. The soul that
13182: bowed to no right, bowed to the great lord of mortals, Pain.
13183: 
13184: He could search into every secret of Tito’s life now: he knew some of
13185: the secrets already, and the failure of the broken dagger, which seemed
13186: like frustration, had been the beginning of achievement. Doubtless that
13187: sudden rage had shaken away the obstruction which stifled his soul.
13188: Twice before, when his memory had partially returned, it had been in
13189: consequence of sudden excitation: once when he had had to defend
13190: himself from an enraged dog: once when he had been overtaken by the
13191: waves, and had had to scramble up a rock to save himself.
13192: 
13193: Yes, but if this time, as then, the light were to die out, and the
13194: dreary conscious blank come back again! This time the light was
13195: stronger and steadier; but what security was there that before the
13196: morrow the dark fog would not be round him again? Even the fear seemed
13197: like the beginning of feebleness: he thought with alarm that he might
13198: sink the faster for this excited vigil of his on the hill, which was
13199: expending his force; and after seeking anxiously for a sheltered corner
13200: where he might lie down, he nestled at last against a heap of warm
13201: garden straw, and so fell asleep.
13202: 
13203: When he opened his eyes again it was daylight. The first moments were
13204: filled with strange bewilderment: he was a man with a double identity;
13205: to which had he awaked? to the life of dim-sighted sensibilities like
13206: the sad heirship of some fallen greatness, or to the life of recovered
13207: power? Surely the last, for the events of the night all came back to
13208: him: the recognition of the page in Pausanias, the crowding resurgence
13209: of facts and names, the sudden wide prospect which had given him such a
13210: moment as that of the Maenad in the glorious amaze of her morning
13211: waking on the mountain top.
13212: 
13213: He took up the book again, he read, he remembered without reading. He
13214: saw a name, and the images of deeds rose with it: he saw the mention of
13215: a deed, and he linked it with a name. There were stories of inexpiable
13216: crimes, but stories also of guilt that seemed successful. There were
13217: sanctuaries for swift-footed miscreants: baseness had its armour, and
13218: the weapons of justice sometimes broke against it. What then? If
13219: baseness triumphed everywhere else, if it could heap to itself all the
13220: goods of the world and even hold the keys of hell, it would never
13221: triumph over the hatred which it had itself awakened. It could devise
13222: no torture that would seem greater than the torture of submitting to
13223: its smile. Baldassarre felt the indestructible independent force of a
13224: supreme emotion, which knows no terror, and asks for no motive, which
13225: is itself an ever-burning motive, consuming all other desire. And now
13226: in this morning light, when the assurance came again that the fine
13227: fibres of association were active still, and that his recovered self
13228: had not departed, all his gladness was but the hope of vengeance.
13229: 
13230: From that time till the evening on which we have seen him enter the
13231: Rucellai gardens, he had been incessantly, but cautiously, inquiring
13232: into Tito’s position and all his circumstances, and there was hardly a
13233: day on which he did not contrive to follow his movements. But he wished
13234: not to arouse any alarm in Tito: he wished to secure a moment when the
13235: hated favourite of blind fortune was at the summit of confident ease,
13236: surrounded by chief men on whose favour he depended. It was not any
13237: retributive payment or recognition of himself for his own behoof, on
13238: which Baldassarre’s whole soul was bent: it was to find the sharpest
13239: edge of disgrace and shame by which a selfish smiler could be pierced;
13240: it was to send through his marrow the most sudden shock of dread. He
13241: was content to lie hard, and live stintedly—he had spent the greater
13242: part of his remaining money in buying another poniard: his hunger and
13243: his thirst were after nothing exquisite but an exquisite vengeance. He
13244: had avoided addressing himself to any one whom he suspected of intimacy
13245: with Tito, lest an alarm raised in Tito’s mind should urge him either
13246: to flight or to some other counteracting measure which hard-pressed
13247: ingenuity might devise. For this reason he had never entered Nello’s
13248: shop, which he observed that Tito frequented, and he had turned aside
13249: to avoid meeting Piero di Cosimo.
13250: 
13251: The possibility of frustration gave added eagerness to his desire that
13252: the great opportunity he sought should not be deferred. The desire was
13253: eager in him on another ground; he trembled lest his memory should go
13254: again. Whether from the agitating presence of that fear, or from some
13255: other causes, he had twice felt a sort of mental dizziness, in which
13256: the inward sense or imagination seemed to be losing the distinct forms
13257: of things. Once he had attempted to enter the Palazzo Vecchio and make
13258: his way into a council-chamber where Tito was, and had failed. But now,
13259: on this evening, he felt that his occasion was come.
13260: 
13261: 
13262: 
13263: 
13264: CHAPTER XXXIX.
13265: A Supper in the Rucellai Gardens.
13266: 
13267: 
13268: On entering the handsome pavilion, Tito’s quick glance soon discerned
13269: in the selection of the guests the confirmation of his conjecture that
13270: the object of the gathering was political, though, perhaps, nothing
13271: more distinct than that strengthening of party which comes from
13272: good-fellowship. Good dishes and good wine were at that time believed
13273: to heighten the consciousness of political preferences, and in the
13274: inspired ease of after-supper talk it was supposed that people
13275: ascertained their own opinions with a clearness quite inaccessible to
13276: uninvited stomachs. The Florentines were a sober and frugal people; but
13277: wherever men have gathered wealth, Madonna della Gozzoviglia and San
13278: Buonvino have had their worshippers; and the Rucellai were among the
13279: few Florentine families who kept a great table and lived splendidly. It
13280: was not probable that on this evening there would be any attempt to
13281: apply high philosophic theories; and there could be no objection to the
13282: bust of Plato looking on, or even to the modest presence of the
13283: cardinal virtues in fresco on the walls.
13284: 
13285: That bust of Plato had been long used to look down on conviviality of a
13286: more transcendental sort, for it had been brought from Lorenzo’s villa
13287: after his death, when the meetings of the Platonic Academy had been
13288: transferred to these gardens. Especially on every thirteenth of
13289: November, reputed anniversary of Plato’s death, it had looked down from
13290: under laurel leaves on a picked company of scholars and philosophers,
13291: who met to eat and drink with moderation, and to discuss and admire,
13292: perhaps with less moderation, the doctrines of the great master:—on
13293: Pico della Mirandola, once a Quixotic young genius with long curls,
13294: astonished at his own powers and astonishing Rome with heterodox
13295: theses; afterwards a more humble student with a consuming passion for
13296: inward perfection, having come to find the universe more astonishing
13297: than his own cleverness:—on innocent, laborious Marsilio Ficino, picked
13298: out young to be reared as a Platonic philosopher, and fed on Platonism
13299: in all its stages till his mind was perhaps a little pulpy from that
13300: too exclusive diet:—on Angelo Poliziano, chief literary genius of that
13301: age, a born poet, and a scholar without dulness, whose phrases had
13302: blood in them and are alive still:—or, further back, on Leon Battista
13303: Alberti, a reverend senior when those three were young, and of a much
13304: grander type than they, a robust, universal mind, at once practical and
13305: theoretic, artist, man of science, inventor, poet:—and on many more
13306: valiant workers whose names are not registered where every day we turn
13307: the leaf to read them, but whose labours make a part, though an
13308: unrecognised part, of our inheritance, like the ploughing and sowing of
13309: past generations.
13310: 
13311: Bernardo Rucellai was a man to hold a distinguished place in that
13312: Academy even before he became its host and patron. He was still in the
13313: prime of life, not more than four and forty, with a somewhat haughty,
13314: cautiously dignified presence; conscious of an amazingly pure Latinity,
13315: but, says Erasmus, not to be caught speaking Latin—no word of Latin to
13316: be sheared off him by the sharpest of Teutons. He welcomed Tito with
13317: more marked favour than usual and gave him a place between Lorenzo
13318: Tornabuoni and Giannozzo Pucci, both of them accomplished young members
13319: of the Medicean party.
13320: 
13321: Of course the talk was the lightest in the world while the brass bowl
13322: filled with scented water was passing round, that the company might
13323: wash their hands, and rings flashed on white fingers under the
13324: wax-lights, and there was the pleasant fragrance of fresh white damask
13325: newly come from France. The tone of remark was a very common one in
13326: those times. Some one asked what Dante’s pattern old Florentine would
13327: think if the life could come into him again under his leathern belt and
13328: bone clasp, and he could see silver forks on the table? And it was
13329: agreed on all hands that the habits of posterity would be very
13330: surprising to ancestors, if ancestors could only know them.
13331: 
13332: And while the silver forks were just dallying with the appetising
13333: delicacies that introduced the more serious business of the supper—such
13334: as morsels of liver, cooked to that exquisite point that they would
13335: melt in the mouth—there was time to admire the designs on the enamelled
13336: silver centres of the brass service, and to say something, as usual,
13337: about the silver dish for confetti, a masterpiece of Antonio
13338: Pollajuolo, whom patronising Popes had seduced from his native Florence
13339: to more gorgeous Rome.
13340: 
13341: “Ah, I remember,” said Niccolò Ridolfi, a middle-aged man, with that
13342: negligent ease of manner which, seeming to claim nothing, is really
13343: based on the lifelong consciousness of commanding rank—“I remember our
13344: Antonio getting bitter about his chiselling and enamelling of these
13345: metal things, and taking in a fury to painting, because, said he, ‘the
13346: artist who puts his work into gold and silver, puts his brains into the
13347: melting-pot.’”
13348: 
13349: “And that is not unlikely to be a true foreboding of Antonio’s,” said
13350: Giannozzo Pucci. “If this pretty war with Pisa goes on, and the revolt
13351: only spreads a little to our other towns, it is not only our silver
13352: dishes that are likely to go; I doubt whether Antonio’s silver saints
13353: round the altar of San Giovanni will not some day vanish from the eyes
13354: of the faithful to be worshipped more devoutly in the form of coin.”
13355: 
13356: “The Frate is preparing us for that already,” said Tornabuoni. “He is
13357: telling the people that God will not have silver crucifixes and
13358: starving stomachs; and that the church is best adorned with the gems of
13359: holiness and the fine gold of brotherly love.”
13360: 
13361: “A very useful doctrine of war-finance, as many a Condottiere has
13362: found,” said Bernardo Rucellai, drily. “But politics come on after the
13363: confetti, Lorenzo, when we can drink wine enough to wash them down;
13364: they are too solid to be taken with roast and boiled.”
13365: 
13366: “Yes, indeed,” said Niccolò Ridolfi. “Our Luigi Pulci would have said
13367: this delicate boiled kid must be eaten with an impartial mind. I
13368: remember one day at Careggi, when Luigi was in his rattling vein, he
13369: was maintaining that nothing perverted the palate like opinion.
13370: ‘Opinion,’ said he, ‘corrupts the saliva—that’s why men took to pepper.
13371: Scepticism is the only philosophy that doesn’t bring a taste in the
13372: mouth.’ ‘Nay,’ says poor Lorenzo de’ Medici, ‘you must be out there,
13373: Luigi. Here is this untainted sceptic, Matteo Franco, who wants hotter
13374: sauce than any of us.’ ‘Because he has a strong opinion of himself,’
13375: flashes out Luigi, which is the original egg of all other opinion. _He_
13376: a sceptic? He believes in the immortality of his own verses. He is such
13377: a logician as that preaching friar who described the pavement of the
13378: bottomless pit. Poor Luigi! his mind was like sharpest steel that can
13379: touch nothing without cutting.”
13380: 
13381: “And yet a very gentle-hearted creature,” said Giannozzo Pucci. “It
13382: seemed to me his talk was a mere blowing of soap-bubbles. What
13383: dithyrambs he went into about eating and drinking! and yet he was as
13384: temperate as a butterfly.”
13385: 
13386: The light talk and the solid eatables were not soon at an end, for
13387: after the roast and boiled meats came the indispensable capon and game,
13388: and, crowning glory of a well-spread table, a peacock cooked according
13389: to the receipt of Apicius for cooking partridges, namely, with the
13390: feathers on, but not plucked afterwards, as that great authority
13391: ordered concerning his partridges; on the contrary, so disposed on the
13392: dish that it might look as much as possible like a live peacock taking
13393: its unboiled repose. Great was the skill required in that confidential
13394: servant who was the official carver, respectfully to turn the classical
13395: though insipid bird on its back, and expose the plucked breast from
13396: which he was to dispense a delicate slice to each of the honourable
13397: company, unless any one should be of so independent a mind as to
13398: decline that expensive toughness and prefer the vulgar digestibility of
13399: capon.
13400: 
13401: Hardly any one was so bold. Tito quoted Horace and dispersed his slice
13402: in small particles over his plate; Bernardo Rucellai made a learned
13403: observation about the ancient price of peacocks’ eggs, but did not
13404: pretend to eat his slice; and Niccolò Ridolfi held a mouthful on his
13405: fork while he told a favourite story of Luigi Pulci’s, about a man of
13406: Siena, who, wanting to give a splendid entertainment at moderate
13407: expense, bought a wild goose, cut off its beak and webbed feet, and
13408: boiled it in its feathers, to pass for a pea-hen.
13409: 
13410: In fact, very little peacock was eaten; but there was the satisfaction
13411: of sitting at a table where peacock was served up in a remarkable
13412: manner, and of knowing that such caprices were not within reach of any
13413: but those who supped with the very wealthiest men. And it would have
13414: been rashness to speak slightingly of peacock’s flesh, or any other
13415: venerable institution, at a time when Fra Girolamo was teaching the
13416: disturbing doctrine that it was not the duty of the rich to be
13417: luxurious for the sake of the poor.
13418: 
13419: Meanwhile, in the chill obscurity that surrounded this centre of
13420: warmth, and light, and savoury odours, the lonely disowned man was
13421: walking in gradually narrowing circuits. He paused among the trees, and
13422: looked in at the windows, which made brilliant pictures against the
13423: gloom. He could hear the laughter; he could see Tito gesticulating with
13424: careless grace, and hear his voice, now alone, now mingling in the
13425: merry confusion of interlacing speeches. Baldassarre’s mind was highly
13426: strung. He was preparing himself for the moment when he could win his
13427: entrance into this brilliant company; and he had a savage satisfaction
13428: in the sight of Tito’s easy gaiety, which seemed to be preparing the
13429: unconscious victim for more effective torture.
13430: 
13431: But the men seated among the branching tapers and the flashing cups
13432: could know nothing of the pale fierce face that watched them from
13433: without. The light can be a curtain as well as the darkness.
13434: 
13435: And the talk went on with more eagerness as it became less disconnected
13436: and trivial. The sense of citizenship was just then strongly forced
13437: even on the most indifferent minds. What the overmastering Fra Girolamo
13438: was saying and prompting was really uppermost in the thoughts of every
13439: one at table; and before the stewed fish was removed, and while the
13440: favourite sweets were yet to come, his name rose to the surface of the
13441: conversation, and, in spite of Rucellai’s previous prohibition, the
13442: talk again became political. At first, while the servants remained
13443: present, it was mere gossip: what had been done in the Palazzo on the
13444: first day’s voting for the Great Council; how hot-tempered and
13445: domineering Francesco Valori was, as if he were to have everything his
13446: own way by right of his austere virtue, and how it was clear to
13447: everybody who heard Soderini’s speeches in favour of the Great Council
13448: and also heard the Frate’s sermons, that they were both kneaded in the
13449: same trough.
13450: 
13451: “My opinion is,” said Niccolò Ridolfi, “that the Frate has a longer
13452: head for public matters than Soderini or any Piagnone among them: you
13453: may depend on it that Soderini is his mouthpiece more than he is
13454: Soderini’s.”
13455: 
13456: “No, Niccolò; there I differ from you,” said Bernardo Ruccellai: “the
13457: Frate has an acute mind, and readily sees what will serve his own ends;
13458: but it is not likely that Pagolantonio Soderini, who has had long
13459: experience of affairs, and has specially studied the Venetian Council,
13460: should be much indebted to a monk for ideas on that subject. No, no;
13461: Soderini loads the cannon; though, I grant you, Fra Girolamo brings the
13462: powder and lights the match. He is master of the people, and the people
13463: are getting master of us. Ecco!”
13464: 
13465: “Well,” said Lorenzo Tornabuoni, presently, when the room was clear of
13466: servants, and nothing but wine was passing round, “whether Soderini is
13467: indebted or not, _we_ are indebted to the Frate for the general amnesty
13468: which has gone along with the scheme of the Council. We might have done
13469: without the fear of God and the reform of morals being passed by a
13470: majority of black beans; but that excellent proposition, that our
13471: Medicean heads should be allowed to remain comfortably on our
13472: shoulders, and that we should not be obliged to hand over our property
13473: in fines, has my warm approval, and it is my belief that nothing but
13474: the Frate’s predominance could have procured that for us. And you may
13475: rely on it that Fra Girolamo is as firm as a rock on that point of
13476: promoting peace. I have had an interview with him.”
13477: 
13478: There was a murmur of surprise and curiosity at the farther end of the
13479: table; but Bernardo Rucellai simply nodded, as if he knew what
13480: Tornabuoni had to say, and wished him to go on.
13481: 
13482: “Yes,” proceeded Tornabuoni, “I have been favoured with an interview in
13483: the Frate’s own cell, which, let me tell you, is not a common favour;
13484: for I have reason to believe that even Francesco Valori very seldom
13485: sees him in private. However, I think he saw me the more willingly
13486: because I was not a ready-made follower, but had to be converted. And,
13487: for my part, I see clearly enough that the only safe and wise policy
13488: for us Mediceans to pursue is to throw our strength into the scale of
13489: the Frate’s party. We are not strong enough to make head on our own
13490: behalf; and if the Frate and the popular party were upset, every one
13491: who hears me knows perfectly well what other party would be uppermost
13492: just now: Nerli, Alberti, Pazzi, and the rest—_Arrabbiati_, as somebody
13493: christened them the other day—who, instead of giving us an amnesty,
13494: would be inclined to fly at our throats like mad dogs, and not be
13495: satisfied till they had banished half of us.”
13496: 
13497: There were strong interjections of assent to this last sentence of
13498: Tornabuoni’s, as he paused and looked round a moment.
13499: 
13500: “A wise dissimulation,” he went on, “is the only course for moderate
13501: rational men in times of violent party feeling. I need hardly tell this
13502: company what are my real political attachments: I am not the only man
13503: here who has strong personal ties to the banished family; but, apart
13504: from any such ties, I agree with my more experienced friends, who are
13505: allowing me to speak for them in their presence, that the only lasting
13506: and peaceful state of things for Florence is the predominance of some
13507: single family interest. This theory of the Frate’s, that we are to have
13508: a popular government, in which every man is to strive only for the
13509: general good, and know no party names, is a theory that may do for some
13510: isle of Cristoforo Colombo’s finding, but will never do for our fine
13511: old quarrelsome Florence. A change must come before long, and with
13512: patience and caution we have every chance of determining the change in
13513: our favour. Meanwhile, the best thing we can do will be to keep the
13514: Frate’s flag flying, for if any other were to be hoisted just now it
13515: would be a black flag for us.”
13516: 
13517: “It’s true,” said Niccolò Ridolfi, in a curt decisive way. “What you
13518: say is true, Lorenzo. For my own part, I am too old for anybody to
13519: believe that I’ve changed my feathers. And there are certain of us—our
13520: old Bernardo del Nero for one—whom you would never persuade to borrow
13521: another man’s shield. But we can lie still, like sleepy old dogs; and
13522: it’s clear enough that barking would be of no use just now. As for this
13523: psalm-singing party, who vote for nothing but the glory of God, and
13524: want to make believe we can all love each other, and talk as if vice
13525: could be swept out with a besom by the Magnificent Eight, their day
13526: will not be a long one. After all the talk of scholars, there are but
13527: two sorts of government: one where men show their teeth at each other,
13528: and one where men show their tongues and lick the feet of the
13529: strongest. They’ll get their Great Council finally voted
13530: to-morrow—that’s certain enough—and they’ll think they’ve found out a
13531: new plan of government; but as sure as there’s a human skin under every
13532: lucco in the Council, their new plan will end like every other, in
13533: snarling or in licking. That’s my view of things as a plain man. Not
13534: that I consider it becoming in men of family and following, who have
13535: got others depending on their constancy and on their sticking to their
13536: colours, to go a-hunting with a fine net to catch reasons in the air,
13537: like doctors of law. I say frankly that, as the head of my family, I
13538: shall be true to my old alliances; and I have never yet seen any
13539: chalk-mark on political reasons to tell me which is true and which is
13540: false. My friend Bernardo Rucellai here is a man of reasons, I know,
13541: and I have no objection to anybody’s finding fine-spun reasons for me,
13542: so that they don’t interfere with my actions as a man of family who has
13543: faith to keep with his connections.”
13544: 
13545: “If that is an appeal to me, Niccolò,” said Bernardo Rucellai, with a
13546: formal dignity, in amusing contrast with Ridolfi’s curt and pithy ease,
13547: “I may take this opportunity of saying, that while my wishes are partly
13548: determined by long-standing personal relations, I cannot enter into any
13549: positive schemes with persons over whose actions I have no control. I
13550: myself might be content with a restoration of the old order of things;
13551: but with modifications—with important modifications. And the one point
13552: on which I wish to declare my concurrence with Lorenzo Tornabuoni is,
13553: that the best policy to be pursued by our friends is, to throw the
13554: weight of their interest into the scale of the popular party. For
13555: myself, I condescend to no dissimulation; nor do I at present see the
13556: party or the scheme that commands my full assent. In all alike there is
13557: crudity and confusion of ideas, and of all the twenty men who are my
13558: colleagues in the present crisis, there is not one with whom I do not
13559: find myself in wide disagreement.”
13560: 
13561: Niccolò Ridolfi shrugged his shoulders, and left it to some one else to
13562: take up the ball. As the wine went round the talk became more and more
13563: frank and lively, and the desire of several at once to be the chief
13564: speaker, as usual caused the company to break up into small knots of
13565: two and three.
13566: 
13567: It was a result which had been foreseen by Lorenzo Tornabuoni and
13568: Giannozzo Pucci, and they were among the first to turn aside from the
13569: highroad of general talk and enter into a special conversation with
13570: Tito, who sat between them; gradually pushing away their seats, and
13571: turning their backs on the table and wine.
13572: 
13573: “In truth, Melema,” Tornabuoni was saying at this stage, laying one
13574: hose-clad leg across the knee of the other, and caressing his ankle, “I
13575: know of no man in Florence who can serve our party better than you. You
13576: see what most of our friends are: men who can no more hide their
13577: prejudices than a dog can hide the natural tone of his bark, or else
13578: men whose political ties are so notorious, that they must always be
13579: objects of suspicion. Giannozzo here, and I, I flatter myself, are able
13580: to overcome that suspicion; we have that power of concealment and
13581: finesse, without which a rational cultivated man, instead of having any
13582: prerogative, is really at a disadvantage compared with a wild bull or a
13583: savage. But, except yourself, I know of no one else on whom we could
13584: rely for the necessary discretion.”
13585: 
13586: “Yes,” said Giannozzo Pucci, laying his hand on Tito’s shoulder, “the
13587: fact is, Tito mio, you can help us better than if you were Ulysses
13588: himself, for I am convinced that Ulysses often made himself
13589: disagreeable. To manage men one ought to have a sharp mind in a velvet
13590: sheath. And there is not a soul in Florence who could undertake a
13591: business like this journey to Rome, for example, with the same safety
13592: that you can. There is your scholarship, which may always be a pretext
13593: for such journeys; and what is better, there is your talent, which it
13594: would be harder to match than your scholarship. Niccolò Macchiavelli
13595: might have done for us if he had been on our side, but hardly so well.
13596: He is too much bitten with notions, and has not your power of
13597: fascination. All the worse for him. He has lost a great chance in life,
13598: and you have got it.”
13599: 
13600: “Yes,” said Tornabuoni, lowering his voice in a significant manner,
13601: “you have only to play your game well, Melema, and the future belongs
13602: to you. For the Medici, you may rely upon it, will keep a foot in Rome
13603: as well as in Florence, and the time may not be far-off when they will
13604: be able to make a finer career for their adherents even than they did
13605: in old days. Why shouldn’t you take orders some day? There’s a
13606: cardinal’s hat at the end of that road, and you would not be the first
13607: Greek who has worn that ornament.”
13608: 
13609: Tito laughed gaily. He was too acute not to measure Tornabuoni’s
13610: exaggerated flattery, but still the flattery had a pleasant flavour.
13611: 
13612: “My joints are not so stiff yet,” he said, “that I can’t be induced to
13613: run without such a high prize as that. I think the income of an abbey
13614: or two held ‘in commendam,’ without the trouble of getting my head
13615: shaved, would satisfy me at present.”
13616: 
13617: “I was not joking,” said Tornabuoni, with grave suavity; “I think a
13618: scholar would always be the better off for taking orders. But we’ll
13619: talk of that another time. One of the objects to be first borne in
13620: mind, is that you should win the confidence of the men who hang about
13621: San Marco; that is what Giannozzo and I shall do, but you may carry it
13622: farther than we can, because you are less observed. In that way you can
13623: get a thorough knowledge of their doings, and you will make a broader
13624: screen for your agency on our side. Nothing of course can be done
13625: before you start for Rome, because this bit of business between Piero
13626: de’ Medici and the French nobles must be effected at once. I mean when
13627: you come back, of course; I need say no more. I believe you could make
13628: yourself the pet votary of San Marco, if you liked; but you are wise
13629: enough to know that effective dissimulation is never immoderate.”
13630: 
13631: “If it were not that an adhesion to the popular side is necessary to
13632: your safety as an agent of our party, Tito mio,” said Giannozzo Pucci,
13633: who was more fraternal and less patronising in his manner than
13634: Tornabuoni, “I could have wished your skill to have been employed in
13635: another way, for which it is still better fitted. But now we must look
13636: out for some other man among us who will manage to get into the
13637: confidence of our sworn enemies, the Arrabbiati; we need to know their
13638: movements more than those of the Frate’s party, who are strong enough
13639: to play above-board. Still, it would have been a difficult thing for
13640: you, from your known relations with the Medici a little while back, and
13641: that sort of kinship your wife has with Bernardo del Nero. We must find
13642: a man who has no distinguished connections, and who has not yet taken
13643: any side.”
13644: 
13645: Tito was pushing his hair backward automatically, as his manner was,
13646: and looking straight at Pucci with a scarcely perceptible smile on his
13647: lip.
13648: 
13649: “No need to look out for any one else,” he said, promptly. “I can
13650: manage the whole business with perfect ease. I will engage to make
13651: myself the special confidant of that thick-headed Dolfo Spini, and know
13652: his projects before he knows them himself.”
13653: 
13654: Tito seldom spoke so confidently of his own powers, but he was in a
13655: state of exaltation at the sudden opening of a new path before him,
13656: where fortune seemed to have hung higher prizes than any he had thought
13657: of hitherto. Hitherto he had seen success only in the form of favour;
13658: it now flashed on him in the shape of power—of such power as is
13659: possible to talent without traditional ties, and without beliefs. Each
13660: party that thought of him as a tool might become dependent on him. His
13661: position as an alien, his indifference to the ideas or prejudices of
13662: the men amongst whom he moved, were suddenly transformed into
13663: advantages; he became newly conscious of his own adroitness in the
13664: presence of a game that he was called on to play. And all the motives
13665: which might have made Tito shrink from the triple deceit that came
13666: before him as a tempting game, had been slowly strangled in him by the
13667: successive falsities of his life.
13668: 
13669: Our lives make a moral tradition for our individual selves, as the life
13670: of mankind at large makes a moral tradition for the race; and to have
13671: once acted nobly seems a reason why we should always be noble. But Tito
13672: was feeling the effect of an opposite tradition: he had won no memories
13673: of self-conquest and perfect faithfulness from which he could have a
13674: sense of falling.
13675: 
13676: The triple colloquy went on with growing spirit till it was interrupted
13677: by a call from the table. Probably the movement came from the listeners
13678: in the party, who were afraid lest the talkers should tire themselves.
13679: At all events it was agreed that there had been enough of gravity, and
13680: Rucellai had just ordered new flasks of Montepulciano.
13681: 
13682: “How many minstrels are there among us?” he said, when there had been a
13683: general rallying round the table. “Melema, I think you are the chief:
13684: Matteo will give you the lute.”
13685: 
13686: “Ah, yes!” said Giannozzo Pucci, “lead the last chorus from Poliziano’s
13687: ‘Orfeo,’ that you have found such an excellent measure for, and we will
13688: all fall in:—
13689: 
13690: 
13691: “‘Ciascum segua, o Bacco, te:
13692: Bacco, Bacco, evoe, evoe!’”
13693: 
13694: 
13695: The servant put the lute into Tito’s hands, and then said something in
13696: an undertone to his master. A little subdued questioning and answering
13697: went on between them, while Tito touched the lute in a preluding way to
13698: the strain of the chorus, and there was a confusion of speech and
13699: musical humming all round the table. Bernardo Rucellai had said, “Wait
13700: a moment, Melema;” but the words had been unheard by Tito, who was
13701: leaning towards Pucci, and singing low to him the phrases of the
13702: Maenad-chorus. He noticed nothing until the buzz round the table
13703: suddenly ceased, and the notes of his own voice, with its soft
13704: low-toned triumph, “Evoe, evoe!” fell in startling isolation.
13705: 
13706: It was a strange moment. Baldassarre had moved round the table till he
13707: was opposite Tito, and as the hum ceased there might be seen for an
13708: instant Baldassarre’s fierce dark eyes bent on Tito’s bright smiling
13709: unconsciousness, while the low notes of triumph dropped from his lips
13710: into the silence.
13711: 
13712: Tito looked up with a slight start, and his lips turned pale, but he
13713: seemed hardly more moved than Giannozzo Pucci, who had looked up at the
13714: same moment—or even than several others round the table; for that
13715: sallow deep-lined face with the hatred in its eyes seemed a terrible
13716: apparition across the wax-lit ease and gaiety. And Tito quickly
13717: recovered some self-command. “A mad old man—he looks like it—he _is_
13718: mad!” was the instantaneous thought that brought some courage with it;
13719: for he could conjecture no inward change in Baldassarre since they had
13720: met before. He just let his eyes fall and laid the lute on the table
13721: with apparent ease; but his fingers pinched the neck of the lute hard
13722: while he governed his head and his glance sufficiently to look with an
13723: air of quiet appeal towards Bernardo Rucellai, who said at once—
13724: 
13725: “Good man, what is your business? What is the important declaration
13726: that you have to make?”
13727: 
13728: “Messer Bernardo Rucellai, I wish you and your honourable friends to
13729: know in what sort of company you are sitting. There is a traitor among
13730: you.”
13731: 
13732: There was a general movement of alarm. Every one present, except Tito,
13733: thought of political danger and not of private injury.
13734: 
13735: Baldassarre began to speak as if he were thoroughly assured of what he
13736: had to say; but, in spite of his long preparation for this moment,
13737: there was the tremor of overmastering excitement in his voice. His
13738: passion shook him. He went on, but he did not say what he had meant to
13739: say. As he fixed his eyes on Tito again the passionate words were like
13740: blows—they defied premeditation.
13741: 
13742: “There is a man among you who is a scoundrel, a liar, a robber. I was a
13743: father to him. I took him from beggary when he was a child. I reared
13744: him, I cherished him, I taught him, I made him a scholar. My head has
13745: lain hard that his might have a pillow. And he left me in slavery; he
13746: sold the gems that were mine, and when I came again, he denied me.”
13747: 
13748: The last words had been uttered with almost convulsed agitation, and
13749: Baldassarre paused, trembling. All glances were turned on Tito, who was
13750: now looking straight at Baldassarre. It was a moment of desperation
13751: that annihilated all feeling in him, except the determination to risk
13752: anything for the chance of escape. And he gathered confidence from the
13753: agitation by which Baldassarre was evidently shaken. He had ceased to
13754: pinch the neck of the lute, and had thrust his thumbs into his belt,
13755: while his lips had begun to assume a slight curl. He had never yet done
13756: an act of murderous cruelty even to the smallest animal that could
13757: utter a cry, but at that moment he would have been capable of treading
13758: the breath from a smiling child for the sake of his own safety.
13759: 
13760: “What does this mean, Melema?” said Bernardo Rucellai, in a tone of
13761: cautious surprise. He, as well as the rest of the company, felt
13762: relieved that the tenor of the accusation was not political.
13763: 
13764: “Messer Bernardo,” said Tito, “I believe this man is mad. I did not
13765: recognise him the first time he encountered me in Florence, but I know
13766: now that he is the servant who years ago accompanied me and my adoptive
13767: father to Greece, and was dismissed on account of misdemeanours. His
13768: name is Jacopo di Nola. Even at that time I believe his mind was
13769: unhinged, for, without any reason, he had conceived a strange hatred
13770: towards me; and now I am convinced that he is labouring under a mania
13771: which causes him to mistake his identity. He has already attempted my
13772: life since he has been in Florence; and I am in constant danger from
13773: him. But he is an object of pity rather than of indignation. It is too
13774: certain that my father is dead. You have only my word for it; but I
13775: must leave it to your judgment how far it is probable that a man of
13776: intellect and learning would have been lurking about in dark corners
13777: for the last month with the purpose of assassinating me; or how far it
13778: is probable that, if this man were my second father, I could have any
13779: motive for denying him. That story about my being rescued from beggary
13780: is the vision of a diseased brain. But it will be a satisfaction to me
13781: at least if you will demand from him proofs of his identity, lest any
13782: malignant person should choose to make this mad impeachment a reproach
13783: to me.”
13784: 
13785: Tito had felt more and more confidence as he went on; the lie was not
13786: so difficult when it was once begun; and as the words fell easily from
13787: his lips, they gave him a sense of power such as men feel when they
13788: have begun a muscular feat successfully. In this way he acquired
13789: boldness enough to end with a challenge for proofs.
13790: 
13791: Baldassarre, while he had been walking in the gardens and afterwards
13792: waiting in an outer room of the pavilion with the servants, had been
13793: making anew the digest of the evidence he would bring to prove his
13794: identity and Tito’s baseness, recalling the description and history of
13795: his gems, and assuring himself by rapid mental glances that he could
13796: attest his learning and his travels. It might be partly owing to this
13797: nervous strain that the new shock of rage he felt as Tito’s lie fell on
13798: his ears brought a strange bodily effect with it: a cold stream seemed
13799: to rush over him, and the last words of the speech seemed to be drowned
13800: by ringing chimes. Thought gave way to a dizzy horror, as if the earth
13801: were slipping away from under him. Every one in the room was looking at
13802: him as Tito ended, and saw that the eyes which had had such fierce
13803: intensity only a few minutes before had now a vague fear in them. He
13804: clutched the back of a seat, and was silent.
13805: 
13806: Hardly any evidence could have been more in favour of Tito’s assertion.
13807: 
13808: “Surely I have seen this man before, somewhere,” said Tornabuoni.
13809: 
13810: “Certainly you have,” said Tito, readily, in a low tone. “He is the
13811: escaped prisoner who clutched me on the steps of the Duomo. I did not
13812: recognise him then; he looks now more as he used to do, except that he
13813: has a more unmistakable air of mad imbecility.”
13814: 
13815: “I cast no doubt on your word, Melema,” said Bernardo Rucellai, with
13816: cautious gravity, “but you are right to desire some positive test of
13817: the fact.” Then turning to Baldassarre, he said, “If you are the person
13818: you claim to be, you can doubtless give some description of the gems
13819: which were your property. I myself was the purchaser of more than one
13820: gem from Messer Tito—the chief rings, I believe, in his collection. One
13821: of them is a fine sard, engraved with a subject from Homer. If, as you
13822: allege, you are a scholar, and the rightful owner of that ring, you can
13823: doubtless turn to the noted passage in Homer from which that subject is
13824: taken. Do you accept this test, Melema? or have you anything to allege
13825: against its validity? The Jacopo you speak of, was he a scholar?”
13826: 
13827: It was a fearful crisis for Tito. If he said “Yes,” his quick mind told
13828: him that he would shake the credibility of his story: if he said “No,”
13829: he risked everything on the uncertain extent of Baldassarre’s
13830: imbecility. But there was no noticeable pause before he said, “No. I
13831: accept the test.”
13832: 
13833: There was a dead silence while Rucellai moved towards the recess where
13834: the books were, and came back with the fine Florentine Homer in his
13835: hand. Baldassarre, when he was addressed, had turned his head towards
13836: the speaker, and Rucellai believed that he had understood him. But he
13837: chose to repeat what he had said, that there might be no mistake as to
13838: the test.
13839: 
13840: “The ring I possess,” he said, “is a fine sard, engraved with a subject
13841: from Homer. There was no other at all resembling it in Messer Tito’s
13842: collection. Will you turn to the passage in Homer from which that
13843: subject is taken? Seat yourself here,” he added, laying the book on the
13844: table, and pointing to his own seat while he stood beside it.
13845: 
13846: Baldassarre had so far recovered from the first confused horror
13847: produced by the sensation of rushing coldness and chiming din in the
13848: ears as to be partly aware of what was said to him: he was aware that
13849: something was being demanded from him to prove his identity, but he
13850: formed no distinct idea of the details. The sight of the book recalled
13851: the habitual longing and faint hope that he could read and understand,
13852: and he moved towards the chair immediately.
13853: 
13854: The book was open before him, and he bent his head a little towards it,
13855: while everybody watched him eagerly. He turned no leaf. His eyes
13856: wandered over the pages that lay before him, and then fixed on them a
13857: straining gaze. This lasted for two or three minutes in dead silence.
13858: Then he lifted his hands to each side of his head, and said, in a low
13859: tone of despair, “Lost, lost!”
13860: 
13861: There was something so piteous in the wandering look and the low cry,
13862: that while they confirmed the belief in his madness they raised
13863: compassion. Nay, so distinct sometimes is the working of a double
13864: consciousness within us, that Tito himself, while he triumphed in the
13865: apparent verification of his lie, wished that he had never made the lie
13866: necessary to himself—wished he had recognised his father on the
13867: steps—wished he had gone to seek him—wished everything had been
13868: different. But he had borrowed from the terrible usurer Falsehood, and
13869: the loan had mounted and mounted with the years, till he belonged to
13870: the usurer, body and soul.
13871: 
13872: The compassion excited in all the witnesses was not without its danger
13873: to Tito; for conjecture is constantly guided by feeling, and more than
13874: one person suddenly conceived that this man might have been a scholar
13875: and have lost his faculties. On the other hand, they had not present to
13876: their minds the motives which could have led Tito to the denial of his
13877: benefactor, and having no ill-will towards him, it would have been
13878: difficult to them to believe that he had been uttering the basest of
13879: lies. And the originally common type of Baldassarre’s person, coarsened
13880: by years of hardship, told as a confirmation of Tito’s lie. If
13881: Baldassarre, to begin with, could have uttered precisely the words he
13882: had premeditated, there might have been something in the form of his
13883: accusation which would have given it the stamp not only of true
13884: experience but of mental refinement. But there had been no such
13885: testimony in his impulsive agitated words: and there seemed the very
13886: opposite testimony in the rugged face and the coarse hands that
13887: trembled beside it, standing out in strong contrast in the midst of
13888: that velvet-clad, fair-handed company.
13889: 
13890: His next movement, while he was being watched in silence, told against
13891: him too. He took his hands from his head, and felt for something under
13892: his tunic. Every one guessed what that movement meant—guessed that
13893: there was a weapon at his side. Glances were interchanged; and Bernardo
13894: Rucellai said, in a quiet tone, touching Baldassarre’s shoulder—
13895: 
13896: “My friend, this is an important business of yours. You shall have all
13897: justice. Follow me into a private room.”
13898: 
13899: Baldassarre was still in that half-stunned state in which he was
13900: susceptible to any prompting, in the same way as an insect that forms
13901: no conception of what the prompting leads to. He rose from his seat,
13902: and followed Rucellai out of the room.
13903: 
13904: In two or three minutes Rucellai came back again, and said—
13905: 
13906: “He is safe under lock and key. Piero Pitti, you are one of the
13907: Magnificent Eight, what do you think of our sending Matteo to the
13908: palace for a couple of sbirri, who may escort him to the Stinche? (The
13909: largest prison in Florence.) If there is any danger in him, as I think
13910: there is, he will be safe there; and we can inquire about him
13911: to-morrow.”
13912: 
13913: Pitti assented, and the order was given.
13914: 
13915: “He is certainly an ill-looking fellow,” said Tornabuoni. “And you say
13916: he has attempted your life already, Melema?”
13917: 
13918: And the talk turned on the various forms of madness, and the fierceness
13919: of the southern blood. If the seeds of conjecture unfavourable to Tito
13920: had been planted in the mind of any one present, they were hardly
13921: strong enough to grow without the aid of much daylight and ill-will.
13922: The common-looking, wild-eyed old man, clad in serge, might have won
13923: belief without very strong evidence, if he had accused a man who was
13924: envied and disliked. As it was, the only congruous and probable view of
13925: the case seemed to be the one that sent the unpleasant accuser safely
13926: out of sight, and left the pleasant serviceable Tito just where he was
13927: before.
13928: 
13929: The subject gradually floated away, and gave place to others, till a
13930: heavy tramp, and something like the struggling of a man who was being
13931: dragged away, were heard outside. The sounds soon died out, and the
13932: interruption seemed to make the last hour’s conviviality more resolute
13933: and vigorous. Every one was willing to forget a disagreeable incident.
13934: 
13935: Tito’s heart was palpitating, and the wine tasted no better to him than
13936: if it had been blood.
13937: 
13938: To-night he had paid a heavier price than ever to make himself safe. He
13939: did not like the price, and yet it was inevitable that he should be
13940: glad of the purchase.
13941: 
13942: And after all he led the chorus. He was in a state of excitement in
13943: which oppressive sensations, and the wretched consciousness of
13944: something hateful but irrevocable, were mingled with a feeling of
13945: triumph which seemed to assert itself as the feeling that would subsist
13946: and be master of the morrow.
13947: 
13948: And it _was_ master. For on the morrow, as we saw, when he was about to
13949: start on his mission to Rome, he had the air of a man well satisfied
13950: with the world.
13951: 
13952: 
13953: 
13954: 
13955: CHAPTER XL.
13956: An Arresting Voice.
13957: 
13958: 
13959: When Romola sat down on the stone under the cypress, all things
13960: conspired to give her the sense of freedom and solitude: her escape
13961: from the accustomed walls and streets; the widening distance from her
13962: husband, who was by this time riding towards Siena, while every hour
13963: would take her farther on the opposite way; the morning stillness; the
13964: great dip of ground on the roadside making a gulf between her and the
13965: sombre calm of the mountains. For the first time in her life she felt
13966: alone in the presence of the earth and sky, with no human presence
13967: interposing and making a law for her.
13968: 
13969: Suddenly a voice close to her said—
13970: 
13971: “You are Romola de’ Bardi, the wife of Tito Melema.”
13972: 
13973: She knew the voice: it had vibrated through her more than once before;
13974: and because she knew it, she did not turn round or look up. She sat
13975: shaken by awe, and yet inwardly rebelling against the awe. It was one
13976: of those black-skirted monks who was daring to speak to her, and
13977: interfere with her privacy: that was all. And yet she was shaken, as if
13978: that destiny which men thought of as a sceptred deity had come to her,
13979: and grasped her with fingers of flesh.
13980: 
13981: “You are fleeing from Florence in disguise. I have a command from God
13982: to stop you. You are not permitted to flee.”
13983: 
13984: Romola’s anger at the intrusion mounted higher at these imperative
13985: words. She would not turn round to look at the speaker, whose examining
13986: gaze she resented. Sitting quite motionless, she said—
13987: 
13988: “What right have you to speak to me, or to hinder me?”
13989: 
13990: “The right of a messenger. You have put on a religious garb, and you
13991: have no religious purpose. You have sought the garb as a disguise. But
13992: you were not suffered to pass me without being discerned. It was
13993: declared to me who you were: it is declared to me that you are seeking
13994: to escape from the lot God has laid upon you. You wish your true name
13995: and your true place in life to be hidden, that you may choose for
13996: yourself a new name and a new place, and have no rule but your own
13997: will. And I have a command to call you back. My daughter, you must
13998: return to your place.”
13999: 
14000: Romola’s mind rose in stronger rebellion with every sentence. She was
14001: the more determined not to show any sign of submission, because the
14002: consciousness of being inwardly shaken made her dread lest she should
14003: fall into irresolution. She spoke with more irritation than before.
14004: 
14005: “I will not return. I acknowledge no right of priests and monks to
14006: interfere with my actions. You have no power over me.”
14007: 
14008: “I know—I know you have been brought up in scorn of obedience. But it
14009: is not the poor monk who claims to interfere with you: it is the truth
14010: that commands you. And you cannot escape it. Either you must obey it,
14011: and it will lead you; or you must disobey it, and it will hang on you
14012: with the weight of a chain which you will drag for ever. But you will
14013: obey it, my daughter. Your old servant will return to you with the
14014: mules; my companion is gone to fetch him; and you will go back to
14015: Florence.”
14016: 
14017: She started up with anger in her eyes, and faced the speaker. It was
14018: Fra Girolamo: she knew that well enough before. She was nearly as tall
14019: as he was, and their faces were almost on a level. She had started up
14020: with defiant words ready to burst from her lips, but they fell back
14021: again without utterance. She had met Fra Girolamo’s calm glance, and
14022: the impression from it was so new to her, that her anger sank ashamed
14023: as something irrelevant.
14024: 
14025: There was nothing transcendent in Savonarola’s face. It was not
14026: beautiful. It was strong-featured, and owed all its refinement to
14027: habits of mind and rigid discipline of the body. The source of the
14028: impression his glance produced on Romola was the sense it conveyed to
14029: her of interest in her and care for her apart from any personal
14030: feeling. It was the first time she had encountered a gaze in which
14031: simple human fellowship expressed itself as a strongly-felt bond. Such
14032: a glance is half the vocation of the priest or spiritual guide of men,
14033: and Romola felt it impossible again to question his authority to speak
14034: to her. She stood silent, looking at him. And he spoke again.
14035: 
14036: “You assert your freedom proudly, my daughter. But who is so base as
14037: the debtor that thinks himself free?”
14038: 
14039: There was a sting in those words, and Romola’s countenance changed as
14040: if a subtle pale flash had gone over it.
14041: 
14042: “And you are flying from your debts: the debt of a Florentine woman;
14043: the debt of a wife. You are turning your back on the lot that has been
14044: appointed for you—you are going to choose another. But can man or woman
14045: choose duties? No more than they can choose their birthplace or their
14046: father and mother. My daughter, you are fleeing from the presence of
14047: God into the wilderness.”
14048: 
14049: As the anger melted from Romola’s mind, it had given place to a new
14050: presentiment of the strength there might be in submission, if this man,
14051: at whom she was beginning to look with a vague reverence, had some
14052: valid law to show her. But no—it was impossible; he could not know what
14053: determined her. Yet she could not again simply refuse to be guided; she
14054: was constrained to plead; and in her new need to be reverent while she
14055: resisted, the title which she had never given him before came to her
14056: lips without forethought, “My father, you cannot know the reasons which
14057: compel me to go. None can know them but myself. None can judge for me.
14058: I have been driven by great sorrow. I am resolved to go.”
14059: 
14060: “I know enough, my daughter: my mind has been so far illuminated
14061: concerning you, that I know enough. You are not happy in your married
14062: life; but I am not a confessor, and I seek to know nothing that should
14063: be reserved for the seal of confession. I have a divine warrant to stop
14064: you, which does not depend on such knowledge. You were warned by a
14065: message from heaven, delivered in my presence—you were warned before
14066: marriage, when you might still have lawfully chosen to be free from the
14067: marriage-bond. But you chose the bond; and in wilfully breaking it—I
14068: speak to you as a pagan, if the holy mystery of matrimony is not sacred
14069: to you—you are breaking a pledge. Of what wrongs will you complain, my
14070: daughter, when you yourself are committing one of the greatest wrongs a
14071: woman and a citizen can be guilty of—withdrawing in secrecy and
14072: disguise from a pledge which you have given in the face of God and your
14073: fellow-men? Of what wrongs will you complain, when you yourself are
14074: breaking the simplest law that lies at the foundation of the trust
14075: which binds man to man—faithfulness to the spoken word? This, then, is
14076: the wisdom you have gained by scorning the mysteries of the Church?—not
14077: to see the bare duty of integrity, where the Church would have taught
14078: you to see, not integrity only, but religion.”
14079: 
14080: The blood had rushed to Romola’s face, and she shrank as if she had
14081: been stricken. “I would not have put on a disguise,” she began; but she
14082: could not go on,—she was too much shaken by the suggestion in the
14083: Frate’s words of a possible affinity between her own conduct and
14084: Tito’s.
14085: 
14086: “And to break that pledge you fly from Florence: Florence, where there
14087: are the only men and women in the world to whom you owe the debt of a
14088: fellow-citizen.”
14089: 
14090: “I should never have quitted Florence,” said Romola, tremulously, “as
14091: long as there was any hope of my fulfilling a duty to my father there.”
14092: 
14093: “And do you own no tie but that of a child to her father in the flesh?
14094: Your life has been spent in blindness, my daughter. You have lived with
14095: those who sit on a hill aloof, and look down on the life of their
14096: fellow-men. I know their vain discourse. It is of what has been in the
14097: times which they fill with their own fancied wisdom, while they scorn
14098: God’s work in the present. And doubtless you were taught how there were
14099: pagan women who felt what it was to live for the Republic; yet you have
14100: never felt that you, a Florentine woman, should live for Florence. If
14101: your own people are wearing a yoke, will you slip from under it,
14102: instead of struggling with them to lighten it? There is hunger and
14103: misery in our streets, yet you say, ‘I care not; I have my own sorrows;
14104: I will go away, if peradventure I can ease them.’ The servants of God
14105: are struggling after a law of justice, peace, and charity, that the
14106: hundred thousand citizens among whom you were born may be governed
14107: righteously; but you think no more of this than if you were a bird,
14108: that may spread its wings and fly whither it will in search of food to
14109: its liking. And yet you have scorned the teaching of the Church, my
14110: daughter. As if you, a wilful wanderer, following your own blind
14111: choice, were not below the humblest Florentine woman who stretches
14112: forth her hands with her own people, and craves a blessing for them;
14113: and feels a close sisterhood with the neighbour who kneels beside her
14114: and is not of her own blood; and thinks of the mighty purpose that God
14115: has for Florence; and waits and endures because the promised work is
14116: great, and she feels herself little.”
14117: 
14118: “I was not going away to ease and self-indulgence,” said Romola,
14119: raising her head again, with a prompting to vindicate herself. “I was
14120: going away to hardship. I expect no joy: it is gone from my life.”
14121: 
14122: “You are seeking your own will, my daughter. You are seeking some good
14123: other than the law you are bound to obey. But how will you find good?
14124: It is not a thing of choice: it is a river that flows from the foot of
14125: the Invisible Throne, and flows by the path of obedience. I say again,
14126: man cannot choose his duties. You may choose to forsake your duties,
14127: and choose not to have the sorrow they bring. But you will go forth;
14128: and what will you find, my daughter? Sorrow without duty—bitter herbs,
14129: and no bread with them.”
14130: 
14131: “But if you knew,” said Romola, clasping her hands and pressing them
14132: tight, as she looked pleadingly at Fra Girolamo; “if you knew what it
14133: was to me—how impossible it seemed to me to bear it.”
14134: 
14135: “My daughter,” he said, pointing to the cord round Romola’s neck, “you
14136: carry something within your mantle; draw it forth, and look at it.”
14137: 
14138: Romola gave a slight start, but her impulse now was to do just what
14139: Savonarola told her. Her self-doubt was grappled by a stronger will and
14140: a stronger conviction than her own. She drew forth the crucifix. Still
14141: pointing towards it, he said—
14142: 
14143: “There, my daughter, is the image of a Supreme Offering, made by
14144: Supreme Love, because the need of man was great.”
14145: 
14146: He paused, and she held the crucifix trembling—trembling under a sudden
14147: impression of the wide distance between her present and her past self.
14148: What a length of road she had travelled through since she first took
14149: that crucifix from the Frate’s hands! Had life as many secrets before
14150: her still as it had for her then, in her young blindness? It was a
14151: thought that helped all other subduing influences; and at the sound of
14152: Fra Girolamo’s voice again, Romola, with a quick involuntary movement,
14153: pressed the crucifix against her mantle and looked at him with more
14154: submission than before.
14155: 
14156: “Conform your life to that image, my daughter; make your sorrow an
14157: offering: and when the fire of Divine charity burns within you, and you
14158: behold the need of your fellow-men by the light of that flame, you will
14159: not call your offering great. You have carried yourself proudly, as one
14160: who held herself not of common blood or of common thoughts; but you
14161: have been as one unborn to the true life of man. What! you say your
14162: love for your father no longer tells you to stay in Florence? Then,
14163: since that tie is snapped, you are without a law, without religion: you
14164: are no better than a beast of the field when she is robbed of her
14165: young. If the yearning of a fleshly love is gone, you are without love,
14166: without obligation. See, then, my daughter, how you are below the life
14167: of the believer who worships that image of the Supreme Offering, and
14168: feels the glow of a common life with the lost multitude for whom that
14169: offering was made, and beholds the history of the world as the history
14170: of a great redemption in which he is himself a fellow-worker, in his
14171: own place and among his own people! If you held that faith, my beloved
14172: daughter, you would not be a wanderer flying from suffering, and
14173: blindly seeking the good of a freedom which is lawlessness. You would
14174: feel that Florence was the home of your soul as well as your
14175: birthplace, because you would see the work that was given you to do
14176: there. If you forsake your place, who will fill it? You ought to be in
14177: your place now, helping in the great work by which God will purify
14178: Florence, and raise it to be the guide of the nations. What! the earth
14179: is full of iniquity—full of groans—the light is still struggling with a
14180: mighty darkness, and you say, ‘I cannot bear my bonds; I will burst
14181: them asunder; I will go where no man claims me’? My daughter, every
14182: bond of your life is a debt: the right lies in the payment of that
14183: debt; it can lie nowhere else. In vain will you wander over the earth;
14184: you will be wandering for ever away from the right.”
14185: 
14186: Romola was inwardly struggling with strong forces: that immense
14187: personal influence of Savonarola, which came from the energy of his
14188: emotions and beliefs: and her consciousness, surmounting all prejudice,
14189: that his words implied a higher law than any she had yet obeyed. But
14190: the resisting thoughts were not yet overborne.
14191: 
14192: “How, then, could Dino be right? He broke ties. He forsook his place.”
14193: 
14194: “That was a special vocation. He was constrained to depart, else he
14195: could not have attained the higher life. It would have been stifled
14196: within him.”
14197: 
14198: “And I too,” said Romola, raising her hands to her brow, and speaking
14199: in a tone of anguish, as if she were being dragged to some torture.
14200: “Father, you may be wrong.”
14201: 
14202: “Ask your conscience, my daughter. You have no vocation such as your
14203: brother had. You are a wife. You seek to break your ties in self-will
14204: and anger, not because the higher life calls upon you to renounce them.
14205: The higher life begins for us, my daughter, when we renounce our own
14206: will to bow before a Divine law. That seems hard to you. It is the
14207: portal of wisdom, and freedom, and blessedness. And the symbol of it
14208: hangs before you. That wisdom is the religion of the Cross. And you
14209: stand aloof from it: you are a pagan; you have been taught to say, ‘I
14210: am as the wise men who lived before the time when the Jew of Nazareth
14211: was crucified.’ And that is your wisdom! To be as the dead whose eyes
14212: are closed, and whose ear is deaf to the work of God that has been
14213: since their time. What has your dead wisdom done for you, my daughter?
14214: It has left you without a heart for the neighbours among whom you
14215: dwell, without care for the great work by which Florence is to be
14216: regenerated and the world made holy; it has left you without a share in
14217: the Divine life which quenches the sense of suffering Self in the
14218: ardours of an ever-growing love. And now, when the sword has pierced
14219: your soul, you say, ‘I will go away; I cannot bear my sorrow.’ And you
14220: think nothing of the sorrow and the wrong that are within the walls of
14221: the city where you dwell: you would leave your place empty, when it
14222: ought to be filled with your pity and your labour. If there is
14223: wickedness in the streets, your steps should shine with the light of
14224: purity; if there is a cry of anguish, you, my daughter, because you
