14225: know the meaning of the cry, should be there to still it. My beloved
14226: daughter, sorrow has come to teach you a new worship: the sign of it
14227: hangs before you.”
14228: 
14229: Romola’s mind was still torn by conflict. She foresaw that she should
14230: obey Savonarola and go back: his words had come to her as if they were
14231: an interpretation of that revulsion from self-satisfied ease, and of
14232: that new fellowship with suffering, which had already been awakened in
14233: her. His arresting voice had brought a new condition into her life,
14234: which made it seem impossible to her that she could go on her way as if
14235: she had not heard it; yet she shrank as one who sees the path she must
14236: take, but sees, too, that the hot lava lies there. And the instinctive
14237: shrinking from a return to her husband brought doubts. She turned away
14238: her eyes from Fra Girolamo, and stood for a minute or two with her
14239: hands hanging clasped before her, like a statue. At last she spoke, as
14240: if the words were being wrung from her, still looking on the ground.
14241: 
14242: “My husband... he is not... my love is gone!”
14243: 
14244: “My daughter, there is the bond of a higher love. Marriage is not
14245: carnal only, made for selfish delight. See what that thought leads you
14246: to! It leads you to wander away in a false garb from all the
14247: obligations of your place and name. That would not have been, if you
14248: had learned that it is a sacramental vow, from which none but God can
14249: release you. My daughter, your life is not as a grain of sand, to be
14250: blown by the winds; it is a thing of flesh and blood, that dies if it
14251: be sundered. Your husband is not a malefactor?”
14252: 
14253: Romola started. “Heaven forbid! No; I accuse him of nothing.”
14254: 
14255: “I did not suppose he was a malefactor. I meant, that if he were a
14256: malefactor, your place would be in the prison beside him. My daughter,
14257: if the cross comes to you as a wife, you must carry it as a wife. You
14258: may say, ‘I will forsake my husband,’ but you cannot cease to be a
14259: wife.”
14260: 
14261: “Yet if—oh, how could I bear—” Romola had involuntarily begun to say
14262: something which she sought to banish from her mind again.
14263: 
14264: “Make your marriage-sorrows an offering too, my daughter: an offering
14265: to the great work by which sin and sorrow are being made to cease. The
14266: end is sure, and is already beginning. Here in Florence it is
14267: beginning, and the eyes of faith behold it. And it may be our
14268: blessedness to die for it: to die daily by the crucifixion of our
14269: selfish will—to die at last by laying our bodies on the altar. My
14270: daughter, you are a child of Florence; fulfil the duties of that great
14271: inheritance. Live for Florence—for your own people, whom God is
14272: preparing to bless the earth. Bear the anguish and the smart. The iron
14273: is sharp—I know, I know—it rends the tender flesh. The draught is
14274: bitterness on the lips. But there is rapture in the cup—there is the
14275: vision which makes all life below it dross for ever. Come, my daughter,
14276: come back to your place!”
14277: 
14278: While Savonarola spoke with growing intensity, his arms tightly folded
14279: before him still, as they had been from the first, but his face alight
14280: as from an inward flame, Romola felt herself surrounded and possessed
14281: by the glow of his passionate faith. The chill doubts all melted away;
14282: she was subdued by the sense of something unspeakably great to which
14283: she was being called by a strong being who roused a new strength within
14284: herself. In a voice that was like a low, prayerful cry, she said—
14285: 
14286: “Father, I will be guided. Teach me! I will go back.”
14287: 
14288: Almost unconsciously she sank on her knees. Savonarola stretched out
14289: his hands over her; but feeling would no longer pass through the
14290: channel of speech, and he was silent.
14291: 
14292: 
14293: 
14294: 
14295: CHAPTER XLI.
14296: Coming Back.
14297: 
14298: 
14299: “Rise, my daughter,” said Fra Girolamo at last. “Your servant is
14300: waiting not far off with the mules. It is time that I should go onward
14301: to Florence.”
14302: 
14303: Romola arose from her knees. That silent attitude had been a sort of
14304: sacrament to her, confirming the state of yearning passivity on which
14305: she had newly entered. By the one act of renouncing her resolve to quit
14306: her husband, her will seemed so utterly bruised that she felt the need
14307: of direction even in small things. She lifted up the edge of her cowl,
14308: and saw Maso and the second Dominican standing with their backs towards
14309: her on the edge of the hill about ten yards from her; but she looked at
14310: Savonarola again without speaking, as if the order to Maso to turn back
14311: must come from him and not from her.
14312: 
14313: “I will go and call them,” he said, answering her glance of appeal;
14314: “and I will recommend you, my daughter, to the Brother who is with me.
14315: You desire to put yourself under guidance, and to learn that wisdom
14316: which has been hitherto as foolishness to you. A chief gate of that
14317: wisdom is the sacrament of confession. You will need a confessor, my
14318: daughter, and I desire to put you under the care of Fra Salvestro, one
14319: of the brethren of San Marco, in whom I most confide.”
14320: 
14321: “I would rather have no guidance but yours, father,” said Romola,
14322: looking anxious.
14323: 
14324: “My daughter, I do not act as a confessor. The vocation I have
14325: withdraws me from offices that would force me into frequent contact
14326: with the laity, and interfere with my special duties.”
14327: 
14328: “Then shall I not be able to speak to you in private? if I waver, if—”
14329: Romola broke off from rising agitation. She felt a sudden alarm lest
14330: her new strength in renunciation should vanish if the immediate
14331: personal influence of Savonarola vanished.
14332: 
14333: “My daughter, if your soul has need of the word in private from my
14334: lips, you will let me know it through Fra Salvestro, and I will see you
14335: in the sacristy or in the choir of San Marco. And I will not cease to
14336: watch over you. I will instruct my brother concerning you, that he may
14337: guide you into that path of labour for the suffering and the hungry to
14338: which you are called as a daughter of Florence in these times of hard
14339: need. I desire to behold you among the feebler and more ignorant
14340: sisters as the apple-tree among the trees of the forest, so that your
14341: fairness and all natural gifts may be but as a lamp through which the
14342: Divine light shines the more purely. I will go now and call your
14343: servant.”
14344: 
14345: When Maso had been sent a little way in advance, Fra Salvestro came
14346: forward, and Savonarola led Romola towards him. She had beforehand felt
14347: an inward shrinking from a new guide who was a total stranger to her:
14348: but to have resisted Savonarola’s advice would have been to assume an
14349: attitude of independence at a moment when all her strength must be
14350: drawn from the renunciation of independence. And the whole bent of her
14351: mind now was towards doing what was painful rather than what was easy.
14352: She bowed reverently to Fra Salvestro before looking directly at him;
14353: but when she raised her head and saw him fully, her reluctance became a
14354: palpitating doubt. There are men whose presence infuses trust and
14355: reverence; there are others to whom we have need to carry our trust and
14356: reverence ready-made; and that difference flashed on Romola as she
14357: ceased to have Savonarola before her, and saw in his stead Fra
14358: Salvestro Maruffi. It was not that there was anything manifestly
14359: repulsive in Fra Salvestro’s face and manner, any air of hypocrisy, any
14360: tinge of coarseness; his face was handsomer than Fra Girolamo’s, his
14361: person a little taller. He was the long-accepted confessor of many
14362: among the chief personages in Florence, and had therefore had large
14363: experience as a spiritual director. But his face had the vacillating
14364: expression of a mind unable to concentrate itself strongly in the
14365: channel of one great emotion or belief—an expression which is fatal to
14366: influence over an ardent nature like Romola’s. Such an expression is
14367: not the stamp of insincerity; it is the stamp simply of a shallow soul,
14368: which will often be found sincerely striving to fill a high vocation,
14369: sincerely composing its countenance to the utterance of sublime
14370: formulas, but finding the muscles twitch or relax in spite of belief,
14371: as prose insists on coming instead of poetry to the man who has not the
14372: divine frenzy. Fra Salvestro had a peculiar liability to visions,
14373: dependent apparently on a constitution given to somnambulism.
14374: Savonarola believed in the supernatural character of these visions,
14375: while Fra Salvestro himself had originally resisted such an
14376: interpretation of them, and had even rebuked Savonarola for his
14377: prophetic preaching: another proof, if one were wanted, that the
14378: relative greatness of men is not to be gauged by their tendency to
14379: disbelieve the superstitions of their age. For of these two there can
14380: be no question which was the great man and which the small.
14381: 
14382: The difference between them was measured very accurately by the change
14383: in Romola’s feeling as Fra Salvestro began to address her in words of
14384: exhortation and encouragement. After her first angry resistance of
14385: Savonarola had passed away, she had lost all remembrance of the old
14386: dread lest any influence should drag her within the circle of
14387: fanaticism and sour monkish piety. But now again, the chill breath of
14388: that dread stole over her. It could have no decisive effect against the
14389: impetus her mind had just received; it was only like the closing of the
14390: grey clouds over the sunrise, which made her returning path monotonous
14391: and sombre.
14392: 
14393: And perhaps of all sombre paths that on which we go back after treading
14394: it with a strong resolution is the one that most severely tests the
14395: fervour of renunciation. As they re-entered the city gates the light
14396: snow-flakes fell about them; and as the grey sister walked hastily
14397: homeward from the Piazza di San Marco, and trod the bridge again, and
14398: turned in at the large door in the Via de’ Bardi, her footsteps were
14399: marked darkly on the thin carpet of snow, and her cowl fell laden and
14400: damp about her face.
14401: 
14402: She went up to her room, threw off her serge, destroyed the parting
14403: letters, replaced all her precious trifles, unbound her hair, and put
14404: on her usual black dress. Instead of taking a long exciting journey,
14405: she was to sit down in her usual place. The snow fell against the
14406: windows, and she was alone.
14407: 
14408: She felt the dreariness, yet her courage was high, like that of a
14409: seeker who has come on new signs of gold. She was going to thread life
14410: by a fresh clue. She had thrown all the energy of her will into
14411: renunciation. The empty tabernacle remained locked, and she placed
14412: Dino’s crucifix outside it.
14413: 
14414: Nothing broke the outward monotony of her solitary home, till the night
14415: came like a white ghost at the windows. Yet it was the most memorable
14416: Christmas-eve in her life to Romola, this of 1494.
14417: 
14418: 
14419: 
14420: 
14421: CHAPTER XLII.
14422: Romola in her Place.
14423: 
14424: 
14425: It was the thirtieth of October 1496. The sky that morning was clear
14426: enough, and there was a pleasant autumnal breeze. But the Florentines
14427: just then thought very little about the land breezes: they were
14428: thinking of the gales at sea, which seemed to be uniting with all other
14429: powers to disprove the Frate’s declaration that Heaven took special
14430: care of Florence.
14431: 
14432: For those terrible gales had driven away from the coast of Leghorn
14433: certain ships from Marseilles, freighted with soldiery and corn; and
14434: Florence was in the direst need, first of food, and secondly of
14435: fighting men. Pale Famine was in her streets, and her territory was
14436: threatened on all its borders.
14437: 
14438: For the French king, that new Charlemagne, who had entered Italy in
14439: anticipatory triumph, and had conquered Naples without the least
14440: trouble, had gone away again fifteen months ago, and was even, it was
14441: feared, in his grief for the loss of a new-born son, losing the languid
14442: intention of coming back again to redress grievances and set the Church
14443: in order. A league had been formed against him—a Holy League, with Pope
14444: Borgia at its head—to “drive out the barbarians,” who still garrisoned
14445: the fortress of Naples. That had a patriotic sound; but, looked at more
14446: closely, the Holy League seemed very much like an agreement among
14447: certain wolves to drive away all other wolves, and then to see which
14448: among themselves could snatch the largest share of the prey. And there
14449: was a general disposition to regard Florence not as a fellow-wolf, but
14450: rather as a desirable carcass. Florence, therefore, of all the chief
14451: Italian States, had alone declined to join the League, adhering still
14452: to the French alliance.
14453: 
14454: She had declined at her peril. At this moment Pisa, still fighting
14455: savagely for liberty, was being encouraged not only by strong forces
14456: from Venice and Milan, but by the presence of the German Emperor
14457: Maximilian, who had been invited by the League, and was joining the
14458: Pisans with such troops as he had in the attempt to get possession of
14459: Leghorn, while the coast was invested by Venetian and Genoese ships.
14460: And if Leghorn should fall into the hands of the enemy, woe to
14461: Florence! For if that one outlet towards the sea were closed, hedged in
14462: as she was on the land by the bitter ill-will of the Pope and the
14463: jealousy of smaller States, how could succours reach her?
14464: 
14465: The government of Florence had shown a great heart in this urgent need,
14466: meeting losses and defeats with vigorous effort, raising fresh money,
14467: raising fresh soldiers, but not neglecting the good old method of
14468: Italian defence—conciliatory embassies. And while the scarcity of food
14469: was every day becoming greater, they had resolved, in opposition to old
14470: precedent, not to shut out the starving country people, and the
14471: mendicants driven from the gates of other cities, who came flocking to
14472: Florence like birds from a land of snow.
14473: 
14474: These acts of a government in which the disciples of Savonarola made
14475: the strongest element were not allowed to pass without criticism. The
14476: disaffected were plentiful, and they saw clearly that the government
14477: took the worst course for the public welfare. Florence ought to join
14478: the League and make common cause with the other great Italian States,
14479: instead of drawing down their hostility by a futile adherence to a
14480: foreign ally. Florence ought to take care of her own citizens, instead
14481: of opening her gates to famine and pestilence in the shape of starving
14482: contadini and alien mendicants.
14483: 
14484: Every day the distress became sharper: every day the murmurs became
14485: louder. And, to crown the difficulties of the government, for a month
14486: and more—in obedience to a mandate from Rome—Fra Girolamo had ceased to
14487: preach. But on the arrival of the terrible news that the ships from
14488: Marseilles had been driven back, and that no corn was coming, the need
14489: for the voice that could infuse faith and patience into the people
14490: became too imperative to be resisted. In defiance of the Papal mandate
14491: the Signoria requested Savonarola to preach. And two days ago he had
14492: mounted again the pulpit of the Duomo, and had told the people only to
14493: wait and be steadfast and the divine help would certainly come.
14494: 
14495: It was a bold sermon: he consented to have his frock stripped off him
14496: if, when Florence persevered in fulfilling the duties of piety and
14497: citizenship, God did not come to her rescue.
14498: 
14499: Yet at present, on this morning of the thirtieth, there were no signs
14500: of rescue. Perhaps if the precious Tabernacle of the Madonna dell’
14501: Impruneta were brought into Florence and carried in devout procession
14502: to the Duomo, that Mother, rich in sorrows and therefore in mercy,
14503: would plead for the suffering city? For a century and a half there were
14504: records how the Florentines, suffering from drought, or flood, or
14505: famine, or pestilence, or the threat of wars, had fetched the potent
14506: image within their walls, and had found deliverance. And grateful
14507: honour had been done to her and her ancient church of L’Impruneta; the
14508: high house of Buondelmonti, patrons of the church, had to guard her
14509: hidden image with bare sword; wealth had been poured out for prayers at
14510: her shrine, for chantings, and chapels, and ever-burning lights; and
14511: lands had been added, till there was much quarrelling for the privilege
14512: of serving her. The Florentines were deeply convinced of her
14513: graciousness to them, so that the sight of her tabernacle within their
14514: walls was like the parting of the cloud, and the proverb ran, that the
14515: Florentines had a Madonna who would do what they pleased.
14516: 
14517: When were they in more need of her pleading pity than now? And already,
14518: the evening before, the tabernacle containing the miraculous hidden
14519: image had been brought with high and reverend escort from L’Impruneta,
14520: the privileged spot six miles beyond the gate of San Piero that looks
14521: towards Rome, and had been deposited in the church of San Gaggio,
14522: outside the gate, whence it was to be fetched in solemn procession by
14523: all the fraternities, trades, and authorities of Florence.
14524: 
14525: But the Pitying Mother had not yet entered within the walls, and the
14526: morning arose on unchanged misery and despondency. Pestilence was
14527: hovering in the track of famine. Not only the hospitals were full, but
14528: the courtyards of private houses had been turned into refuges and
14529: infirmaries; and still there was unsheltered want. And early this
14530: morning, as usual, members of the various fraternities who made it part
14531: of their duty to bury the unfriended dead, were bearing away the
14532: corpses that had sunk by the wayside. As usual, sweet womanly forms,
14533: with the refined air and carriage of the well-born, but in the plainest
14534: garb, were moving about the streets on their daily errands of tending
14535: the sick and relieving the hungry.
14536: 
14537: One of these forms was easily distinguishable as Romola de’ Bardi. Clad
14538: in the simplest garment of black serge, with a plain piece of black
14539: drapery drawn over her head, so as to hide all her hair, except the
14540: bands of gold that rippled apart on her brow, she was advancing from
14541: the Ponte Vecchio towards the Por’ Santa Maria—the street in a direct
14542: line with the bridge—when she found her way obstructed by the pausing
14543: of a bier, which was being carried by members of the company of San
14544: Jacopo del Popolo, in search for the unburied dead. The brethren at the
14545: head of the bier were stooping to examine something, while a group of
14546: idle workmen, with features paled and sharpened by hunger, were
14547: clustering around and all talking at once.
14548: 
14549: “He’s dead, I tell you! Messer Domeneddio has loved him well enough to
14550: take him.”
14551: 
14552: “Ah, and it would be well for us all if we could have our legs
14553: stretched out and go with our heads two or three _bracci_ foremost!
14554: It’s ill standing upright with hunger to prop you.”
14555: 
14556: “Well, well, he’s an old fellow. Death has got a poor bargain. Life’s
14557: had the best of him.”
14558: 
14559: “And no Florentine, ten to one! A beggar turned out of Siena. San
14560: Giovanni defend us! They’ve no need of soldiers to fight us. They send
14561: us an army of starving men.”
14562: 
14563: “No, no! This man is one of the prisoners turned out of the Stinche. I
14564: know by the grey patch where the prison badge was.”
14565: 
14566: “Keep quiet! Lend a hand! Don’t you see the brethren are going to lift
14567: him on the bier?”
14568: 
14569: “It’s likely he’s alive enough if he could only look it. The soul may
14570: be inside him if it had only a drop of _vernaccia_ to warm it.”
14571: 
14572: “In truth, I think he is not dead,” said one of the brethren, when they
14573: had lifted him on the bier. “He has perhaps only sunk down for want of
14574: food.”
14575: 
14576: “Let me try to give him some wine,” said Romola, coming forward. She
14577: loosened the small flask which she carried at her belt, and, leaning
14578: towards the prostrate body, with a deft hand she applied a small ivory
14579: implement between the teeth, and poured into the mouth a few drops of
14580: wine. The stimulus acted: the wine was evidently swallowed. She poured
14581: more, till the head was moved a little towards her, and the eyes of the
14582: old man opened full upon her with the vague look of returning
14583: consciousness.
14584: 
14585: Then for the first time a sense of complete recognition came over
14586: Romola. Those wild dark eyes opening in the sallow deep-lined face,
14587: with the white beard, which was now long again, were like an
14588: unmistakable signature to a remembered handwriting. The light of two
14589: summers had not made that image any fainter in Romola’s memory: the
14590: image of the escaped prisoner, whom she had seen in the Duomo the day
14591: when Tito first wore the armour—at whose grasp Tito was paled with
14592: terror in the strange sketch she had seen in Piero’s studio. A wretched
14593: tremor and palpitation seized her. Now at last, perhaps, she was going
14594: to know some secret which might be more bitter than all that had gone
14595: before. She felt an impulse to dart away as from a sight of horror; and
14596: again, a more imperious need to keep close by the side of this old man
14597: whom, the divination of keen feeling told her, her husband had injured.
14598: In the very instant of this conflict she still leaned towards him and
14599: kept her right-hand ready to administer more wine, while her left was
14600: passed under his neck. Her hands trembled, but their habit of soothing
14601: helpfulness would have served to guide them without the direction of
14602: her thought.
14603: 
14604: Baldassarre was looking at _her_ for the first time. The close
14605: seclusion in which Romola’s trouble had kept her in the weeks preceding
14606: her flight and his arrest, had denied him the opportunity he had sought
14607: of seeing the Wife who lived in the Via de’ Bardi: and at this moment
14608: the descriptions he had heard of the fair golden-haired woman were all
14609: gone, like yesterday’s waves.
14610: 
14611: “Will it not be well to carry him to the steps of San Stefano?” said
14612: Romola. “We shall cease then to stop up the street, and you can go on
14613: your way with your bier.”
14614: 
14615: They had only to move onward for about thirty yards before reaching the
14616: steps of San Stefano, and by this time Baldassarre was able himself to
14617: make some efforts towards getting off the bier, and propping himself on
14618: the steps against the church-doorway. The charitable brethren passed
14619: on, but the group of interested spectators, who had nothing to do and
14620: much to say, had considerably increased. The feeling towards the old
14621: man was not so entirely friendly now it was quite certain that he was
14622: alive, but the respect inspired by Romola’s presence caused the passing
14623: remarks to be made in a rather more subdued tone than before.
14624: 
14625: “Ah, they gave him his morsel every day in the Stinche—that’s why he
14626: can’t do so well without it. You and I, Cecco, know better what it is
14627: to go to bed fasting.”
14628: 
14629: “_Gnaffè_! that’s why the Magnificent Eight have turned out some of the
14630: prisoners, that they may shelter honest people instead. But if every
14631: thief is to be brought to life with good wine and wheaten bread, we
14632: Ciompi had better go and fill ourselves in Arno while the water’s
14633: plenty.”
14634: 
14635: Romola had seated herself on the steps by Baldassarre, and was saying,
14636: “Can you eat a little bread now? perhaps by-and-by you will be able, if
14637: I leave it with you. I must go on, because I have promised to be at the
14638: hospital. But I will come back if you will wait here, and then I will
14639: take you to some shelter. Do you understand? Will you wait? I will come
14640: back.”
14641: 
14642: He looked dreamily at her, and repeated her words, “come back.” It was
14643: no wonder that his mind was enfeebled by his bodily exhaustion, but she
14644: hoped that he apprehended her meaning. She opened her basket, which was
14645: filled with pieces of soft bread, and put one of the pieces into his
14646: hand.
14647: 
14648: “Do you keep your bread for those that can’t swallow, madonna?” said a
14649: rough-looking fellow, in a red night-cap, who had elbowed his way into
14650: the inmost circle of spectators—a circle that was pressing rather
14651: closely on Romola.
14652: 
14653: “If anybody isn’t hungry,” said another, “I say, let him alone. He’s
14654: better off than people who’ve got craving stomachs and no breakfast.”
14655: 
14656: “Yes, indeed; if a man’s a mind to die, it’s a time to encourage him,
14657: instead of making him come back to life against his will. Dead men want
14658: no trencher.”
14659: 
14660: “Oh, you don’t understand the Frate’s charity,” said a young man in an
14661: excellent cloth tunic, whose face showed no signs of want. “The Frate
14662: has been preaching to the birds, like Saint Anthony, and he’s been
14663: telling the hawks they were made to feed the sparrows, as every good
14664: Florentine citizen was made to feed six starving beggar-men from Arezzo
14665: or Bologna. Madonna, there, is a pious Piagnone: she’s not going to
14666: throw away her good bread on honest citizens who’ve got all the Frate’s
14667: prophecies to swallow.”
14668: 
14669: “Come, madonna,” said he of the red cap, “the old thief doesn’t eat the
14670: bread, you see: you’d better try _us_. We fast so much, we’re half
14671: saints already.”
14672: 
14673: The circle had narrowed till the coarse men—most of them gaunt from
14674: privation—had left hardly any margin round Romola. She had been taking
14675: from her basket a small horn-cup, into which she put the piece of bread
14676: and just moistened it with wine; and hitherto she had not appeared to
14677: heed them. But now she rose to her feet, and looked round at them.
14678: Instinctively the men who were nearest to her pushed backward a little,
14679: as if their rude nearness were the fault of those behind. Romola held
14680: out the basket of bread to the man in the night-cap, looking at him
14681: without any reproach in her glance, as she said—
14682: 
14683: “Hunger is hard to bear, I know, and you have the power to take this
14684: bread if you will. It was saved for sick women and children. You are
14685: strong men; but if you do not choose to suffer because you are strong,
14686: you have the power to take everything from the weak. You can take the
14687: bread from this basket; but I shall watch by this old man; I shall
14688: resist your taking the bread from _him_.”
14689: 
14690: For a few moments there was perfect silence, while Romola looked at the
14691: faces before her, and held out the basket of bread. Her own pale face
14692: had the slightly pinched look and the deepening of the eye-socket which
14693: indicate unusual fasting in the habitually temperate, and the large
14694: direct gaze of her hazel eyes was all the more impressive.
14695: 
14696: The man in the night-cap looked rather silly, and backed, thrusting his
14697: elbow into his neighbour’s ribs with an air of moral rebuke. The
14698: backing was general, every one wishing to imply that he had been pushed
14699: forward against his will; and the young man in the fine cloth tunic had
14700: disappeared.
14701: 
14702: But at this moment the armed servitors of the Signoria, who had begun
14703: to patrol the line of streets through which the procession was to pass,
14704: came up to disperse the group which was obstructing the narrow street.
14705: The man addressed as Cecco retreated from a threatening mace up the
14706: church-steps, and said to Romola, in a respectful tone—
14707: 
14708: “Madonna, if you want to go on your errands, I’ll take care of the old
14709: man.”
14710: 
14711: Cecco was a wild-looking figure: a very ragged tunic, made shaggy and
14712: variegated by cloth-dust and clinging fragments of wool, gave relief to
14713: a pair of bare bony arms and a long sinewy neck; his square jaw shaded
14714: by a bristly black beard, his bridgeless nose and low forehead, made
14715: his face look as if it had been crushed down for purposes of packing,
14716: and a narrow piece of red rag tied over his ears seemed to assist in
14717: the compression. Romola looked at him with some hesitation.
14718: 
14719: “Don’t distrust me, madonna,” said Cecco, who understood her look
14720: perfectly; “I am not so pretty as you, but I’ve got an old mother who
14721: eats my porridge for me. What! there’s a heart inside me, and I’ve
14722: bought a candle for the most Holy Virgin before now. Besides, see
14723: there, the old fellow is eating his sop. He’s hale enough: he’ll be on
14724: his legs as well as the best of us by-and-by.”
14725: 
14726: “Thank you for offering to take care of him, friend,” said Romola,
14727: rather penitent for her doubting glance. Then leaning to Baldassarre,
14728: she said, “Pray wait for me till I come again.”
14729: 
14730: He assented with a slight movement of the head and hand, and Romola
14731: went on her way towards the hospital of San Matteo, in the Piazza di
14732: San Marco.
14733: 
14734: 
14735: 
14736: 
14737: CHAPTER XLIII.
14738: The Unseen Madonna.
14739: 
14740: 
14741: In returning from the hospital, more than an hour later, Romola took a
14742: different road, making a wider circuit towards the river, which she
14743: reached at some distance from the Ponte Vecchio. She turned her steps
14744: towards that bridge, intending to hasten to San Stefano in search of
14745: Baldassarre. She dreaded to know more about him, yet she felt as if, in
14746: forsaking him, she would be forsaking some near claim upon her.
14747: 
14748: But when she approached the meeting of the roads where the Por’ Santa
14749: Maria would be on her right-hand and the Ponte Vecchio on her left, she
14750: found herself involved in a crowd who suddenly fell on their knees; and
14751: she immediately knelt with them. The Cross was passing—the Great Cross
14752: of the Duomo—which headed the procession. Romola was later than she had
14753: expected to be, and now she must wait till the procession had passed.
14754: As she rose from her knees, when the Cross had disappeared, the return
14755: to a standing posture, with nothing to do but gaze, made her more
14756: conscious of her fatigue than she had been while she had been walking
14757: and occupied. A shopkeeper by her side said—
14758: 
14759: “Madonna Romola, you will be weary of standing: Gian Fantoni will be
14760: glad to give you a seat in his house. Here is his door close at hand.
14761: Let me open it for you. What! he loves God and the Frate as we do. His
14762: house is yours.”
14763: 
14764: Romola was accustomed now to be addressed in this fraternal way by
14765: ordinary citizens, whose faces were familiar to her from her having
14766: seen them constantly in the Duomo. The idea of home had come to be
14767: identified for her less with the house in the Via de’ Bardi, where she
14768: sat in frequent loneliness, than with the towered circuit of Florence,
14769: where there was hardly a turn of the streets at which she was not
14770: greeted with looks of appeal or of friendliness. She was glad enough to
14771: pass through the open door on her right-hand and be led by the
14772: fraternal hose-vendor to an upstairs-window, where a stout woman with
14773: three children, all in the plain garb of Piagnoni, made a place for her
14774: with much reverence above the bright hanging draperies. From this
14775: corner station she could see, not only the procession pouring in solemn
14776: slowness between the lines of houses on the Ponte Vecchio, but also the
14777: river and the Lung’ Arno on towards the bridge of the Santa Trinita.
14778: 
14779: In sadness and in stillness came the slow procession. Not even a
14780: wailing chant broke the silent appeal for mercy: there was only the
14781: tramp of footsteps, and the faint sweep of woollen garments. They were
14782: young footsteps that were passing when Romola first looked from the
14783: window—a long train of the Florentine youth, bearing high in the midst
14784: of them the white image of the youthful Jesus, with a golden glory
14785: above his head, standing by the tall cross where the thorns and the
14786: nails lay ready.
14787: 
14788: After that train of fresh beardless faces came the mysterious-looking
14789: Companies of Discipline, bound by secret rules to self-chastisement,
14790: and devout praise, and special acts of piety; all wearing a garb which
14791: concealed the whole head and face except the eyes. Every one knew that
14792: these mysterious forms were Florentine citizens of various ranks, who
14793: might be seen at ordinary times going about the business of the shop,
14794: the counting-house, or the State; but no member now was discernible as
14795: son, husband, or father. They had dropped their personality, and walked
14796: as symbols of a common vow. Each company had its colour and its badge,
14797: but the garb of all was a complete shroud, and left no expression but
14798: that of fellowship.
14799: 
14800: In comparison with them, the multitude of monks seemed to be strongly
14801: distinguished individuals, in spite of the common tonsure and the
14802: common frock. First came a white stream of reformed Benedictines; and
14803: then a much longer stream of the Frati Minori, or Franciscans, in that
14804: age all clad in grey, with the knotted cord round their waists, and
14805: some of them with the _zoccoli_, or wooden sandals, below their bare
14806: feet;—perhaps the most numerous order in Florence, owning many zealous
14807: members who loved mankind and hated the Dominicans. And after the grey
14808: came the black of the Augustinians of San Spirito with more cultured
14809: human faces above it—men who had inherited the library of Boccaccio,
14810: and had made the most learned company in Florence when learning was
14811: rarer; then the white over dark of the Carmelites; and then again the
14812: unmixed black of the Servites, that famous Florentine order founded by
14813: seven merchants who forsook their gains to adore the Divine Mother.
14814: 
14815: And now the hearts of all onlookers began to beat a little faster,
14816: either with hatred or with love, for there was a stream of black and
14817: white coming over the bridge—of black mantles over white scapularies;
14818: and every one knew that the Dominicans were coming. Those of Fiesole
14819: passed first. One black mantle parted by white after another, one
14820: tonsured head after another, and still expectation was suspended. They
14821: were very coarse mantles, all of them, and many were threadbare, if not
14822: ragged; for the Prior of San Marco had reduced the fraternities under
14823: his rule to the strictest poverty and discipline. But in the long line
14824: of black and white there was at last singled out a mantle only a little
14825: more worn than the rest, with a tonsured head above it which might not
14826: have appeared supremely remarkable to a stranger who had not seen it on
14827: bronze medals, with the sword of God as its obverse; or surrounded by
14828: an armed guard on the way to the Duomo; or transfigured by the inward
14829: flame of the orator as it looked round on a rapt multitude.
14830: 
14831: As the approach of Savonarola was discerned, none dared conspicuously
14832: to break the stillness by a sound which would rise above the solemn
14833: tramp of footsteps and the faint sweep of garments; nevertheless his
14834: ear, as well as other ears, caught a mingled sound of slow hissing that
14835: longed to be curses, and murmurs that longed to be blessings. Perhaps
14836: it was the sense that the hissing predominated which made two or three
14837: of his disciples in the foreground of the crowd, at the meeting of the
14838: roads, fall on their knees as if something divine were passing. The
14839: movement of silent homage spread: it went along the sides of the
14840: streets like a subtle shock, leaving some unmoved, while it made the
14841: most bend the knee and bow the head. But the hatred, too, gathered a
14842: more intense expression; and as Savonarola passed up the Por’ Santa
14843: Maria, Romola could see that some one at an upper window spat upon him.
14844: 
14845: Monks again—Frati Umiliati, or Humbled Brethren, from Ognissanti, with
14846: a glorious tradition of being the earliest workers in the wool-trade;
14847: and again more monks—Vallombrosan and other varieties of Benedictines,
14848: reminding the instructed eye by niceties of form and colour that in
14849: ages of abuse, long ago, reformers had arisen who had marked a change
14850: of spirit by a change of garb; till at last the shaven crowns were at
14851: an end, and there came the train of untonsured secular priests.
14852: 
14853: Then followed the twenty-one incorporated Arts of Florence in long
14854: array, with their banners floating above them in proud declaration that
14855: the bearers had their distinct functions, from the bakers of bread to
14856: the judges and notaries. And then all the secondary officers of State,
14857: beginning with the less and going on to the greater, till the line of
14858: secularities was broken by the Canons of the Duomo, carrying a sacred
14859: relic—the very head, enclosed in silver, of San Zenobio, immortal
14860: bishop of Florence, whose virtues were held to have saved the city
14861: perhaps a thousand years before.
14862: 
14863: Here was the nucleus of the procession. Behind the relic came the
14864: archbishop in gorgeous cope, with canopy held above him; and after him
14865: the mysterious hidden Image—hidden first by rich curtains of brocade
14866: enclosing an outer painted tabernacle, but within this, by the more
14867: ancient tabernacle which had never been opened in the memory of living
14868: men, or the fathers of living men. In that inner shrine was the image
14869: of the Pitying Mother, found ages ago in the soil of L’Impruneta,
14870: uttering a cry as the spade struck it. Hitherto the unseen Image had
14871: hardly ever been carried to the Duomo without having rich gifts borne
14872: before it. There was no reciting the list of precious offerings made by
14873: emulous men and communities, especially of veils and curtains and
14874: mantles. But the richest of all these, it was said, had been given by a
14875: poor abbess and her nuns, who, having no money to buy materials, wove a
14876: mantle of gold brocade with their prayers, embroidered it and adorned
14877: it with their prayers, and, finally, saw their work presented to the
14878: Blessed Virgin in the great Piazza by two beautiful youths who spread
14879: out white wings and vanished in the blue.
14880: 
14881: But to-day there were no gifts carried before the tabernacle: no
14882: donations were to be given to-day except to the poor. That had been the
14883: advice of Fra Girolamo, whose preaching never insisted on gifts to the
14884: invisible powers, but only on help to visible need; and altars had been
14885: raised at various points in front of the churches, on which the
14886: oblations for the poor were deposited. Not even a torch was carried.
14887: Surely the hidden Mother cared less for torches and brocade than for
14888: the wail of the hungry people. Florence was in extremity: she had done
14889: her utmost, and could only wait for something divine that was not in
14890: her own power.
14891: 
14892: The Frate in the torn mantle had said that help would certainly come,
14893: and many of the faint-hearted were clinging more to their faith in the
14894: Frate’s word, than to their faith in the virtues of the unseen Image.
14895: But there were not a few of the fierce-hearted who thought with secret
14896: rejoicing that the Frate’s word might be proved false.
14897: 
14898: Slowly the tabernacle moved forward, and knees were bent. There was
14899: profound stillness; for the train of priests and chaplains from
14900: L’Impruneta stirred no passion in the onlookers. The procession was
14901: about to close with the Priors and the Gonfaloniere: the long train of
14902: companies and symbols, which have their silent music and stir the mind
14903: as a chorus stirs it, was passing out of sight, and now a faint
14904: yearning hope was all that struggled with the accustomed despondency.
14905: 
14906: Romola, whose heart had been swelling, half with foreboding, half with
14907: that enthusiasm of fellowship which the life of the last two years had
14908: made as habitual to her as the consciousness of costume to a vain and
14909: idle woman, gave a deep sigh, as at the end of some long mental
14910: tension, and remained on her knees for very languor; when suddenly
14911: there flashed from between the houses on to the distant bridge
14912: something bright-coloured. In the instant, Romola started up and
14913: stretched out her arms, leaning from the window, while the black
14914: drapery fell from her head, and the golden gleam of her hair and the
14915: flush in her face seemed the effect of one illumination. A shout arose
14916: in the same instant; the last troops of the procession paused, and all
14917: faces were turned towards the distant bridge.
14918: 
14919: But the bridge was passed now: the horseman was pressing at full gallop
14920: along by the Arno; the sides of his bay horse, just streaked with foam,
14921: looked all white from swiftness; his cap was flying loose by his red
14922: becchetto, and he waved an olive-branch in his hand. It was a
14923: messenger—a messenger of good tidings! The blessed olive-branch spoke
14924: afar off. But the impatient people could not wait. They rushed to meet
14925: the on-comer, and seized his horse’s rein, pushing and trampling.
14926: 
14927: And now Romola could see that the horseman was her husband, who had
14928: been sent to Pisa a few days before on a private embassy. The
14929: recognition brought no new flash of joy into her eyes. She had checked
14930: her first impulsive attitude of expectation; but her governing anxiety
14931: was still to know what news of relief had come for Florence.
14932: 
14933: “Good news!”
14934: 
14935: “Best news!”
14936: 
14937: “News to be paid with hose!” (_novelle da calze_) were the vague
14938: answers with which Tito met the importunities of the crowd, until he
14939: had succeeded in pushing on his horse to the spot at the meeting of the
14940: ways where the Gonfaloniere and the Priors were awaiting him. There he
14941: paused, and, bowing low, said—
14942: 
14943: “Magnificent Signori! I have to deliver to you the joyful news that the
14944: galleys from France, laden with corn and men, have arrived safely in
14945: the port of Leghorn, by favour of a strong wind, which kept the enemy’s
14946: fleet at a distance.”
14947: 
14948: The words had no sooner left Tito’s lips than they seemed to vibrate up
14949: the streets. A great shout rang through the air, and rushed along the
14950: river; and then another, and another; and the shouts were heard
14951: spreading along the line of the procession towards the Duomo; and then
14952: there were fainter answering shouts, like the intermediate plash of
14953: distant waves in a great lake whose waters obey one impulse.
14954: 
14955: For some minutes there was no attempt to speak further: the Signoria
14956: themselves lifted up their caps, and stood bare-headed in the presence
14957: of a rescue which had come from outside the limit of their own
14958: power—from that region of trust and resignation which has been in all
14959: ages called divine.
14960: 
14961: At last, as the signal was given to move forward, Tito said, with a
14962: smile—
14963: 
14964: “I ought to say, that any hose to be bestowed by the Magnificent
14965: Signoria in reward of these tidings are due, not to me, but to another
14966: man who had ridden hard to bring them, and would have been here in my
14967: place if his horse had not broken down just before he reached Signa.
14968: Meo di Sasso will doubtless be here in an hour or two, and may all the
14969: more justly claim the glory of the messenger, because he has had the
14970: chief labour and has lost the chief delight.”
14971: 
14972: It was a graceful way of putting a necessary statement, and after a
14973: word of reply from the _Proposto_, or spokesman of the Signoria, this
14974: dignified extremity of the procession passed on, and Tito turned his
14975: horse’s head to follow in its train, while the great bell of the
14976: Palazzo Vecchio was already beginning to swing, and give a louder voice
14977: to the people’s joy in that moment, when Tito’s attention had ceased to
14978: be imperatively directed, it might have been expected that he would
14979: look round and recognise Romola; but he was apparently engaged with his
14980: cap, which, now the eager people were leading his horse, he was able to
14981: seize and place on his head, while his right-hand was still encumbered
14982: by the olive-branch. He had a becoming air of lassitude after his
14983: exertions; and Romola, instead of making any effort to be recognised by
14984: him, threw her black drapery over her head again, and remained
14985: perfectly quiet. Yet she felt almost sure that Tito had seen her; he
14986: had the power of seeing everything without seeming to see it.
14987: 
14988: 
14989: 
14990: 
14991: CHAPTER XLIV.
14992: The Visible Madonna.
14993: 
14994: 
14995: The crowd had no sooner passed onward than Romola descended to the
14996: street, and hastened to the steps of San Stefano. Cecco had been
14997: attracted with the rest towards the Piazza, and she found Baldassarre
14998: standing alone against the church-door, with the horn-cup in his hand,
14999: waiting for her. There was a striking change in him: the blank, dreamy
15000: glance of a half-returned consciousness had given place to a fierceness
15001: which, as she advanced and spoke to him, flashed upon her as if she had
15002: been its object. It was the glance of caged fury that sees its prey
15003: passing safe beyond the bars.
15004: 
15005: Romola started as the glance was turned on her, but her immediate
15006: thought was that he had seen Tito. And as she felt the look of hatred
15007: grating on her, something like a hope arose that this man might be the
15008: criminal, and that her husband might not have been guilty towards him.
15009: If she could learn that now, by bringing Tito face to face with him,
15010: and have her mind set at rest!
15011: 
15012: “If you will come with me,” she said, “I can give you shelter and food
15013: until you are quite rested and strong. Will you come?”
15014: 
15015: “Yes,” said Baldassarre, “I shall be glad to get my strength. I want to
15016: get my strength,” he repeated, as if he were muttering to himself,
15017: rather than speaking to her.
15018: 
15019: “Come!” she said, inviting him to walk by her side, and taking the way
15020: by the Arno towards the Ponte Rubaconte as the more private road.
15021: 
15022: “I think you are not a Florentine,” she said, presently, as they turned
15023: on to the bridge.
15024: 
15025: He looked round at her without speaking. His suspicious caution was
15026: more strongly upon him than usual, just now that the fog of confusion
15027: and oblivion was made denser by bodily feebleness. But she was looking
15028: at him too, and there was something in her gentle eyes which at last
15029: compelled him to answer her. But he answered cautiously—
15030: 
15031: “No, I am no Florentine; I am a lonely man.”
15032: 
15033: She observed his reluctance to speak to her, and dared not question him
15034: further, lest he should desire to quit her. As she glanced at him from
15035: time to time, her mind was busy with thoughts which quenched the faint
15036: hope that there was nothing painful to be revealed about her husband.
15037: If this old man had been in the wrong, where was the cause for dread
15038: and secrecy!
15039: 
15040: They walked on in silence till they reached the entrance into the Via
15041: de’ Bardi, and Romola noticed that he turned and looked at her with a
15042: sudden movement as if some shock had passed through him. A few moments
15043: after, she paused at the half-open door of the court and turned towards
15044: him.
15045: 
15046: “Ah!” he said, not waiting for her to speak, “you are his wife.”
15047: 
15048: “Whose wife?” said Romola.
15049: 
15050: It would have been impossible for Baldassarre to recall any name at
15051: that moment. The very force with which the image of Tito pressed upon
15052: him seemed to expel any verbal sign. He made no answer, but looked at
15053: her with strange fixedness.
15054: 
15055: She opened the door wide and showed the court covered with straw, on
15056: which lay four or five sick people, while some little children crawled
15057: or sat on it at their ease—tiny pale creatures, biting straws and
15058: gurgling.
15059: 
15060: “If you will come in,” said Romola, tremulously, “I will find you a
15061: comfortable place, and bring you some more food.”
15062: 
15063: “No, I will not come in,” said Baldassarre. But he stood still,
15064: arrested by the burden of impressions under which his mind was too
15065: confused to choose a course.
15066: 
15067: “Can I do nothing for you?” said Romola. “Let me give you some money
15068: that you may buy food. It will be more plentiful soon.”
15069: 
15070: She had put her hand into her scarsella as she spoke, and held out her
15071: palm with several _grossi_ in it. She purposely offered him more than
15072: she would have given to any other man in the same circumstances. He
15073: looked at the coins a little while, and then said—
15074: 
15075: “Yes, I will take them.”
15076: 
15077: She poured the coins into his palm, and he grasped them tightly.
15078: 
15079: “Tell me,” said Romola, almost beseechingly. “What shall you—”
15080: 
15081: But Baldassarre had turned away from her, and was walking again towards
15082: the bridge. Passing from it, straight on up the Via del Fosso, he came
15083: upon the shop of Niccolò Caparra, and turned towards it without a
15084: pause, as if it had been the very object of his search. Niccolò was at
15085: that moment in procession with the armourers of Florence, and there was
15086: only one apprentice in the shop. But there were all sorts of weapons in
15087: abundance hanging there, and Baldassarre’s eyes discerned what he was
15088: more hungry for than for bread. Niccolò himself would probably have
15089: refused to sell anything that might serve as a weapon to this man with
15090: signs of the prison on him; but the apprentice, less observant and
15091: scrupulous, took three _grossi_ for a sharp hunting-knife without any
15092: hesitation. It was a conveniently small weapon, which Baldassarre could
15093: easily thrust within the breast of his tunic, and he walked on, feeling
15094: stronger. That sharp edge might give deadliness to the thrust of an
15095: aged arm: at least it was a companion, it was a power in league with
15096: him, even if it failed. It would break against armour, but was the
15097: armour sure to be always there? In those long months while vengeance
15098: had lain in prison, baseness had perhaps become forgetful and secure.
15099: The knife had been bought with the traitor’s own money. That was just.
15100: Before he took the money, he had felt what he should do with it—buy a
15101: weapon. Yes, and if possible, food too; food to nourish the arm that
15102: would grasp the weapon, food to nourish the body which was the temple
15103: of vengeance. When he had had enough bread, he should be able to think
15104: and act—to think first how he could hide himself, lest Tito should have
15105: him dragged away again.
15106: 
15107: With that idea of hiding in his mind, Baldassarre turned up the
15108: narrowest streets, bought himself some meat and bread, and sat down
15109: under the first loggia to eat. The bells that swung out louder and
15110: louder peals of joy, laying hold of him and making him vibrate along
15111: with all the air, seemed to him simply part of that strong world which
15112: was against him.
15113: 
15114: Romola had watched Baldassarre until he had disappeared round the
15115: turning into the Piazza de’ Mozzi, half feeling that his departure was
15116: a relief, half reproaching herself for not seeking with more decision
15117: to know the truth about him, for not assuring herself whether there
15118: were any guiltless misery in his lot which she was not helpless to
15119: relieve. Yet what could she have done if the truth had proved to be the
15120: burden of some painful secret about her husband, in addition to the
15121: anxieties that already weighed upon her? Surely a wife was permitted to
15122: desire ignorance of a husband’s wrong-doing, since she alone must not
15123: protest and warn men against him. But that thought stirred too many
15124: intricate fibres of feeling to be pursued now in her weariness. It was
15125: a time to rejoice, since help had come to Florence; and she turned into
15126: the court to tell the good news to her patients on their straw beds.
15127: 
15128: She closed the door after her, lest the bells should drown her voice,
15129: and then throwing the black drapery from her head, that the women might
15130: see her better, she stood in the midst and told them that corn was
15131: coming, and that the bells were ringing for gladness at the news. They
15132: all sat up to listen, while the children trotted or crawled towards
15133: her, and pulled her black skirts, as if they were impatient at being
15134: all that long way off her face. She yielded to them, weary as she was,
15135: and sat down on the straw, while the little pale things peeped into her
15136: basket and pulled her hair down, and the feeble voices around her said,
15137: “The Holy Virgin be praised!”
15138: 
15139: “It was the procession!”
15140: 
15141: “The Mother of God has had pity on us!”
15142: 
15143: At last Romola rose from the heap of straw, too tired to try and smile
15144: any longer, saying as she turned up the stone steps—
15145: 
15146: “I will come by-and-by, to bring you your dinner.”
15147: 
15148: “Bless you, madonna! bless you!” said the faint chorus, in much the
15149: same tone as that in which they had a few minutes before praised and
15150: thanked the unseen Madonna.
15151: 
15152: Romola cared a great deal for that music. She had no innate taste for
15153: tending the sick and clothing the ragged, like some women to whom the
15154: details of such work are welcome in themselves, simply as an
15155: occupation. Her early training had kept her aloof from such womanly
15156: labours; and if she had not brought to them the inspiration of her
15157: deepest feelings, they would have been irksome to her. But they had
15158: come to be the one unshaken resting-place of her mind, the one narrow
15159: pathway on which the light fell clear. If the gulf between herself and
15160: Tito which only gathered a more perceptible wideness from her attempts
15161: to bridge it by submission, brought a doubt whether, after all, the
15162: bond to which she had laboured to be true might not itself be false—if
15163: she came away from her confessor, Fra Salvestro, or from some contact
15164: with the disciples of Savonarola amongst whom she worshipped, with a
15165: sickening sense that these people were miserably narrow, and with an
15166: almost impetuous reaction towards her old contempt for their
15167: superstition—she found herself recovering a firm footing in her works
15168: of womanly sympathy. Whatever else made her doubt, the help she gave to
15169: her fellow-citizens made her sure that Fra Girolamo had been right to
15170: call her back. According to his unforgotten words, her place had not
15171: been empty: it had been filled with her love and her labour. Florence
15172: had had need of her, and the more her own sorrow pressed upon her, the
15173: more gladness she felt in the memories, stretching through the two long
15174: years, of hours and moments in which she had lightened the burden of
15175: life to others. All that ardour of her nature which could no longer
15176: spend itself in the woman’s tenderness for father and husband, had
15177: transformed itself into an enthusiasm of sympathy with the general
15178: life. She had ceased to think that her own lot could be happy—had
15179: ceased to think of happiness at all: the one end of her life seemed to
15180: her to be the diminishing of sorrow.
15181: 
15182: Her enthusiasm was continually stirred to fresh vigour by the influence
15183: of Savonarola. In spite of the wearisome visions and allegories from
15184: which she recoiled in disgust when they came as stale repetitions from
15185: other lips than his, her strong affinity for his passionate sympathy
15186: and the splendour of his aims had lost none of its power. His burning
15187: indignation against the abuses and oppression that made the daily story
15188: of the Church and of States had kindled the ready fire in her too. His
15189: special care for liberty and purity of government in Florence, with his
15190: constant reference of this immediate object to the wider end of a
15191: universal regeneration, had created in her a new consciousness of the
15192: great drama of human existence in which her life was a part; and
15193: through her daily helpful contact with the less fortunate of her
15194: fellow-citizens this new consciousness became something stronger than a
15195: vague sentiment; it grew into a more and more definite motive of
15196: self-denying practice. She thought little about dogmas, and shrank from
15197: reflecting closely on the Frate’s prophecies of the immediate scourge
15198: and closely following regeneration. She had submitted her mind to his
15199: and had entered into communion with the Church, because in this way she
15200: had found an immediate satisfaction for moral needs which all the
15201: previous culture and experience of her life had left hungering. Fra
15202: Girolamo’s voice had waked in her mind a reason for living, apart from
15203: personal enjoyment and personal affection; but it was a reason that
15204: seemed to need feeding with greater forces than she possessed within
15205: herself, and her submissive use of all offices of the Church was simply
15206: a watching and waiting if by any means fresh strength might come. The
15207: pressing problem for Romola just then was not to settle questions of
15208: controversy, but to keep alive that flame of unselfish emotion by which
15209: a life of sadness might still be a life of active love.
15210: 
15211: Her trust in Savonarola’s nature as greater than her own made a large
15212: part of the strength she had found. And the trust was not to be lightly
15213: shaken. It is not force of intellect which causes ready repulsion from
15214: the aberration and eccentricities of greatness, any more than it is
15215: force of vision that causes the eye to explore the warts on a face
15216: bright with human expression; it is simply the negation of high
15217: sensibilities. Romola was so deeply moved by the grand energies of
15218: Savonarola’s nature, that she found herself listening patiently to all
15219: dogmas and prophecies, when they came in the vehicle of his ardent
15220: faith and believing utterance.[1]
15221: 
15222: No soul is desolate as long as there is a human being for whom it can
15223: feel trust and reverence. Romola’s trust in Savonarola was something
15224: like a rope suspended securely by her path, making her step elastic
15225: while she grasped it; if it were suddenly removed, no firmness of the
15226: ground she trod could save her from staggering, or perhaps from
15227: falling.
15228: 
15229:  [1] He himself had had occasion enough to note the efficacy of that
15230:  vehicle. “If,” he says in the _Compendium Revelationum_, “you speak of
15231:  such as have not heard these things from me, I admit that they who
15232:  disbelieve are more than they who believe, because it is one thing to
15233:  hear him who inwardly feels these things, and another to hear him who
15234:  feels them not; ... and, therefore, it is well said by Saint Jerome,
15235:  ‘Habet nescio quid latentis energiae vivae vocis actus, et in aures
15236:  discipuli de auctoris ore transfusa fortis sonat.’”
15237: 
15238: 
15239: 
15240: 
15241: CHAPTER XLV.
15242: At the Barber’s Shop.
15243: 
15244: 
15245: After that welcome appearance as the messenger with the olive-branch,
15246: which was an unpromised favour of fortune, Tito had other commissions
15247: to fulfil of a more premeditated character. He paused at the Palazzo
15248: Vecchio, and awaited there the return of the Ten, who managed external
15249: and war affairs, that he might duly deliver to them the results of his
15250: private mission to Pisa, intended as a preliminary to an avowed embassy
15251: of which Bernardo Rucellai was to be the head, with the object of
15252: coming, if possible, to a pacific understanding with the Emperor
15253: Maximilian and the League.
15254: 
15255: Tito’s talents for diplomatic work had been well ascertained, and as he
15256: gave with fulness and precision the results of his inquiries and
15257: interviews, Bernardo del Nero, who was at that time one of the Ten,
15258: could not withhold his admiration. He would have withheld it if he
15259: could; for his original dislike of Tito had returned, and become
15260: stronger, since the sale of the library. Romola had never uttered a
15261: word to her godfather on the circumstances of the sale, and Bernardo
15262: had understood her silence as a prohibition to him to enter on the
15263: subject, but he felt sure that the breach of her father’s wish had been
15264: a blighting grief to her, and the old man’s observant eyes discerned
15265: other indications that her married life was not happy.
15266: 
15267: “Ah,” he said, inwardly, “that doubtless is the reason she has taken to
15268: listening to Fra Girolamo, and going amongst the Piagnoni, which I
15269: never expected from her. These women, if they are not happy, and have
15270: no children, must either take to folly or to some overstrained religion
15271: that makes them think they’ve got all heaven’s work on their shoulders.
15272: And as for my poor child Romola, it is as I always said—the cramming
15273: with Latin and Greek has left her as much a woman as if she had done
15274: nothing all day but prick her fingers with the needle. And this husband
15275: of hers, who gets employed everywhere, because he’s a tool with a
15276: smooth handle, I wish Tornabuoni and the rest may not find their
15277: fingers cut. Well, well, _solco torto, sacco dritto_—many a full sack
15278: comes from a crooked furrow; and he who will be captain of none but
15279: honest men will have small hire to pay.”
15280: 
15281: With this long-established conviction that there could be no moral
15282: sifting of political agents, the old Florentine abstained from all
15283: interference in Tito’s disfavour. Apart from what must be kept sacred
15284: and private for Romola’s sake, Bernardo had nothing direct to allege
15285: against the useful Greek, except that he was a Greek, and that he,
15286: Bernardo, did not like him; for the doubleness of feigning attachment
15287: to the popular government, while at heart a Medicean, was common to
15288: Tito with more than half the Medicean party. He only feigned with more
15289: skill than the rest: that was all. So Bernardo was simply cold to Tito,
15290: who returned the coldness with a scrupulous, distant respect. And it
15291: was still the notion in Florence that the old tie between Bernardo and
15292: Bardo made any service done to Romola’s husband an acceptable homage to
15293: her godfather.
15294: 
15295: After delivering himself of his charge at the Old Palace, Tito felt
15296: that the avowed official work of the day was done. He was tired and
15297: adust with long riding; but he did not go home. There were certain
15298: things in his scarsella and on his mind, from which he wished to free
15299: himself as soon as possible, but the opportunities must be found so
15300: skilfully that they must not seem to be sought. He walked from the
15301: Palazzo in a sauntering fashion towards the Piazza del Duomo. The
15302: procession was at an end now, but the bells were still ringing, and the
15303: people were moving about the streets restlessly, longing for some more
15304: definite vent to their joy. If the Frate could have stood up in the
15305: great Piazza and preached to them, they might have been satisfied, but
15306: now, in spite of the new discipline which declared Christ to be the
15307: special King of the Florentines and required all pleasures to be of a
15308: Christian sort, there was a secret longing in many of the youngsters
15309: who shouted “Viva Gesu!” for a little vigorous stone throwing in sign
15310: of thankfulness.
15311: 
15312: Tito, as he passed along, could not escape being recognised by some as
15313: the welcome bearer of the olive-branch, and could only rid himself of
15314: an inconvenient ovation, chiefly in the form of eager questions, by
15315: telling those who pressed on him that Meo di Sasso, the true messenger
15316: from Leghorn, must now be entering, and might certainly be met towards
15317: the Porta San Frediano. He could tell much more than Tito knew.
15318: 
15319: Freeing himself from importunities in this adroit manner, he made his
15320: way to the Piazza del Duomo, casting his long eyes round the space with
15321: an air of the utmost carelessness, but really seeking to detect some
15322: presence which might furnish him with one of his desired opportunities.
15323: The fact of the procession having terminated at the Duomo made it
15324: probable that there would be more than the usual concentration of
15325: loungers and talkers in the Piazza and round Nello’s shop. It was as he
15326: expected. There was a group leaning against the rails near the north
15327: gates of the Baptistery, so exactly what he sought, that he looked more
15328: indifferent than ever, and seemed to recognise the tallest member of
15329: the group entirely by chance as he had half passed him, just turning
15330: his head to give him a slight greeting, while he tossed the end of his
15331: _becchetto_ over his left shoulder.
15332: 
15333: Yet the tall, broad-shouldered personage greeted in that slight way
15334: looked like one who had considerable claims. He wore a
15335: richly-embroidered tunic, with a great show of linen, after the newest
15336: French mode, and at his belt there hung a sword and poniard of fine
15337: workmanship. His hat, with a red plume in it, seemed a scornful protest
15338: against the gravity of Florentine costume, which had been exaggerated
15339: to the utmost under the influence of the Piagnoni. Certain undefinable
15340: indications of youth made the breadth of his face and the large
15341: diameter of his waist appear the more emphatically a stamp of
15342: coarseness, and his eyes had that rude desecrating stare at all men and
15343: things which to a refined mind is as intolerable as a bad odour or a
15344: flaring light.
15345: 
15346: He and his companions, also young men dressed expensively and wearing
15347: arms, were exchanging jokes with that sort of ostentatious laughter
15348: which implies a desire to prove that the laughter is not mortified
15349: though some people might suspect it. There were good reasons for such a
15350: suspicion; for this broad-shouldered man with the red feather was Dolfo
15351: Spini, leader of the Compagnacci, or Evil Companions—that is to say, of
15352: all the dissolute young men belonging to the old aristocratic party,
15353: enemies of the Mediceans, enemies of the popular government, but still
15354: more bitter enemies of Savonarola. Dolfo Spini, heir of the great house
15355: with the loggia, over the bridge of the Santa Trinita, had organised
15356: these young men into an armed band, as sworn champions of extravagant
15357: suppers and all the pleasant sins of the flesh, against reforming
15358: pietists who threatened to make the world chaste and temperate to so
15359: intolerable a degree that there would soon be no reason for living,
15360: except the extreme unpleasantness of the alternative. Up to this very
15361: morning he had been loudly declaring that Florence was given up to
15362: famine and ruin entirely through its blind adherence to the advice of
15363: the Frate, and that there could be no salvation for Florence but in
15364: joining the League and driving the Frate out of the city—sending him to
15365: Rome, in fact, whither he ought to have gone long ago in obedience to
15366: the summons of the Pope. It was suspected, therefore, that Messer Dolfo
15367: Spini’s heart was not aglow with pure joy at the unexpected succours
15368: which had come in apparent fulfilment of the Frate’s prediction, and
15369: the laughter, which was ringing out afresh as Tito joined the group at
15370: Nello’s door, did not serve to dissipate the suspicion. For leaning
15371: against the door-post in the centre of the group was a close-shaven,
15372: keen-eyed personage, named Niccolò Macchiavelli, who, young as he was,
15373: had penetrated all the small secrets of egoism.
15374: 
15375: “Messer Dolfo’s head,” he was saying, “is more of a pumpkin than I
15376: thought. I measure men’s dulness by the devices they trust in for
15377: deceiving others. Your dullest animal of all is he who grins and says
15378: he doesn’t mind just after he has had his shins kicked. If I were a
15379: trifle duller, now,” he went on, smiling as the circle opened to admit
15380: Tito, “I should pretend to be fond of this Melema, who has got a
15381: secretaryship that would exactly suit me—as if Latin ill-paid could
15382: love better Latin that’s better paid! Melema, you are a pestiferously
15383: clever fellow, very much in my way, and I’m sorry to hear you’ve had
15384: another piece of good-luck to-day.”
15385: 
15386: “Questionable luck, Niccolò,” said Tito, touching him on the shoulder
15387: in a friendly way; “I have got nothing by it yet but being laid hold of
15388: and breathed upon by wool-beaters, when I am as soiled and battered
15389: with riding as a _tabellario_ (letter-carrier) from Bologna.”
15390: 
15391: “Ah! you want a touch of my art, Messer Oratore,” said Nello, who had
15392: come forward at the sound of Tito’s voice; “your chin, I perceive, has
15393: yesterday’s crop upon it. Come, come—consign yourself to the priest of
15394: all the Muses. Sandro, quick with the lather!”
15395: 
15396: “In truth, Nello, that is just what I most desire at this moment,” said
15397: Tito, seating himself; “and that was why I turned my steps towards thy
15398: shop, instead of going home at once, when I had done my business at the
15399: Palazzo.”
15400: 
15401: “Yes, indeed, it is not fitting that you should present yourself to
15402: Madonna Romola with a rusty chin and a tangled _zazzera_. Nothing that
15403: is not dainty ought to approach the Florentine lily; though I see her
15404: constantly going about like a sunbeam amongst the rags that line our
15405: corners—if indeed she is not more like a moonbeam now, for I thought
15406: yesterday, when I met her, that she looked as pale and worn as that
15407: fainting Madonna of Fra Giovanni’s. You must see to it, my bel erudito:
15408: she keeps too many fasts and vigils in your absence.”
15409: 
15410: Tito gave a melancholy shrug. “It is too true, Nello. She has been
15411: depriving herself of half her proper food _every_ day during this
15412: famine. But what can I do? Her mind has been set all aflame. A
15413: husband’s influence is powerless against the Frate’s.”
15414: 
15415: “As every other influence is likely to be, that of the Holy Father
15416: included,” said Domenico Cennini, one of the group at the door, who had
15417: turned in with Tito. “I don’t know whether you have gathered anything
15418: at Pisa about the way the wind sits at Rome, Melema?”
15419: 
15420: “Secrets of the council-chamber, Messer Domenico!” said Tito, smiling
15421: and opening his palms in a deprecatory manner. “An envoy must be as
15422: dumb as a father confessor.”
15423: 
15424: “Certainly, certainly,” said Cennini. “I ask for no breach of that
15425: rule. Well, my belief is, that if his Holiness were to drive Fra
15426: Girolamo to extremity, the Frate would move heaven and earth to get a
15427: General Council of the Church—ay, and would get it too; and I, for one,
15428: should not be sorry, though I’m no Piagnone.”
15429: 
15430: “With leave of your greater experience, Messer Domenico,” said
15431: Macchiavelli, “I must differ from you—not in your wish to see a General
15432: Council which might reform the Church, but in your belief that the
15433: Frate will checkmate his Holiness. The Frate’s game is an impossible
15434: one. If he had contented himself with preaching against the vices of
15435: Rome, and with prophesying that in some way, not mentioned, Italy would
15436: be scourged, depend upon it Pope Alexander would have allowed him to
15437: spend his breath in that way as long as he could find hearers. Such
15438: spiritual blasts as those knock no walls down. But the Frate wants to
15439: be something more than a spiritual trumpet: he wants to be a lever, and
15440: what is more, he _is_ a lever. He wants to spread the doctrine of
15441: Christ by maintaining a popular government in Florence, and the Pope,
15442: as I know, on the best authority, has private views to the contrary.”
15443: 
15444: “Then Florence will stand by the Frate,” Cennini broke in, with some
15445: fervour. “I myself should prefer that he would let his prophesying
15446: alone, but if our freedom to choose our own government is to be
15447: attacked—I am an obedient son of the Church, but I would vote for
15448: resisting Pope Alexander the Sixth, as our forefathers resisted Pope
15449: Gregory the Eleventh.”
15450: 
15451: “But pardon me, Messer Domenico,” said Macchiavelli, sticking his
15452: thumbs into his belt, and speaking with that cool enjoyment of
15453: exposition which surmounts every other force in discussion. “Have you
15454: correctly seized the Frate’s position? How is it that he has become a
15455: lever, and made himself worth attacking by an acute man like his
15456: Holiness? Because he has got the ear of the people: because he gives
15457: them threats and promises, which they believe come straight from God,
15458: not only about hell, purgatory, and paradise, but about Pisa and our
15459: Great Council. But let events go against him, so as to shake the
15460: people’s faith, and the cause of his power will be the cause of his
15461: fall. He is accumulating three sorts of hatred on his head—the hatred
15462: of average mankind against every one who wants to lay on them a strict
15463: yoke of virtue; the hatred of the stronger powers in Italy who want to
15464: farm Florence for their own purposes; and the hatred of the people, to
15465: whom he has ventured to promise good in this world, instead of
15466: confining his promises to the next. If a prophet is to keep his power,
15467: he must be a prophet like Mahomet, with an army at his back, that when
15468: the people’s faith is fainting it may be frightened into life again.”
15469: 
15470: “Rather sum up the three sorts of hatred in one,” said Francesco Cei,
15471: impetuously, “and say he has won the hatred of all men who have sense
15472: and honesty, by inventing hypocritical lies. His proper place is among
15473: the false prophets in the Inferno, who walk with their heads turned
15474: hind-foremost.”
15475: 
15476: “You are too angry, my Francesco,” said Macchiavelli, smiling; “you
15477: poets are apt to cut the clouds in your wrath. I am no votary of the
15478: Frate’s, and would not lay down my little finger for his veracity. But
15479: veracity is a plant of paradise, and the seeds have never flourished
15480: beyond the walls. You, yourself, my Francesco, tell poetical lies only;
15481: partly compelled by the poet’s fervour, partly to please your audience;
15482: but _you_ object to lies in prose. Well, the Frate differs from you as
15483: to the boundary of poetry, that’s all. When he gets into the pulpit of
15484: the Duomo, he has the fervour within him, and without him he has the
15485: audience to please. Ecco!”
15486: 
15487: “You are somewhat lax there, Niccolò,” said Cennini, gravely. “I myself
15488: believe in the Frate’s integrity, though I don’t believe in his
15489: prophecies, and as long as his integrity is not disproved, we have a
15490: popular party strong enough to protect him and resist foreign
15491: interference.”
15492: 
15493: “A party that seems strong enough,” said Macchiavelli, with a shrug,
15494: and an almost imperceptible glance towards Tito, who was abandoning
15495: himself with much enjoyment to Nello’s combing and scenting. “But how
15496: many Mediceans are there among you? How many who will not be turned
15497: round by a private grudge?”
15498: 
15499: “As to the Mediceans,” said Cennini, “I believe there is very little
15500: genuine feeling left on behalf of the Medici. Who would risk much for
15501: Piero de’ Medici? A few old staunch friends, perhaps, like Bernardo del
15502: Nero; but even some of those most connected with the family are hearty
15503: friends of the popular government, and would exert themselves for the
15504: Frate. I was talking to Giannozzo Pucci only a little while ago, and I
15505: am convinced there’s nothing he would set his face against more than
