15506: against any attempt to alter the new order of things.”
15507: 
15508: “You are right there, Messer Domenico,” said Tito, with a laughing
15509: meaning in his eyes, as he rose from the shaving-chair; “and I fancy
15510: the tender passion came in aid of hard theory there. I am persuaded
15511: there was some jealousy at the bottom of Giannozzo’s alienation from
15512: Piero de’ Medici; else so amiable a creature as he would never feel the
15513: bitterness he sometimes allows to escape him in that quarter. He was in
15514: the procession with you, I suppose?”
15515: 
15516: “No,” said Cennini; “he is at his villa—went there three days ago.”
15517: 
15518: Tito was settling his cap and glancing down at his splashed hose as if
15519: he hardly heeded the answer. In reality he had obtained a much-desired
15520: piece of information. He had at that moment in his scarsella a crushed
15521: gold ring which he had engaged to deliver to Giannozzo Pucci. He had
15522: received it from an envoy of Piero de’ Medici, whom he had ridden out
15523: of his way to meet at Certaldo on the Siena road. Since Pucci was not
15524: in the town, he would send the ring by Fra Michele, a Carthusian lay
15525: Brother in the service of the Mediceans, and the receipt of that sign
15526: would bring Pucci back to hear the verbal part of Tito’s mission.
15527: 
15528: “Behold him!” said Nello, flourishing his comb and pointing it at Tito,
15529: “the handsomest scholar in the world or in the wolds, (‘Del mondo o di
15530: maremma’) now he has passed through my hands! A trifle thinner in the
15531: face, though, than when he came in his first bloom to Florence—eh? and,
15532: I vow, there are some lines just faintly hinting themselves about your
15533: mouth, Messer Oratore! Ah, mind is an enemy to beauty! I myself was
15534: thought beautiful by the women at one time—when I was in my
15535: swaddling-bands. But now—oimè! I carry my unwritten poems in cipher on
15536: my face!”
15537: 
15538: Tito, laughing with the rest as Nello looked at himself tragically in
15539: the hand-mirror, made a sign of farewell to the company generally, and
15540: took his departure.
15541: 
15542: “I’m of our old Piero di Cosimo’s mind,” said Francesco Cei. “I don’t
15543: half like Melema. That trick of smiling gets stronger than ever—no
15544: wonder he has lines about the mouth.”
15545: 
15546: “He’s too successful,” said Macchiavelli, playfully. “I’m sure there’s
15547: something wrong about him, else he wouldn’t have that secretaryship.”
15548: 
15549: “He’s an able man,” said Cennini, in a tone of judicial fairness. “I
15550: and my brother have always found him useful with our Greek sheets, and
15551: he gives great satisfaction to the Ten. I like to see a young man work
15552: his way upward by merit. And the secretary Scala, who befriended him
15553: from the first, thinks highly of him still, I know.”
15554: 
15555: “Doubtless,” said a notary in the background. “He writes Scala’s
15556: official letters for him, or corrects them, and gets well paid for it
15557: too.”
15558: 
15559: “I wish Messer Bartolommeo would pay _me_ to doctor his gouty Latin,”
15560: said Macchiavelli, with a shrug. “Did _he_ tell you about the pay, Ser
15561: Ceccone, or was it Melema himself?” he added, looking at the notary
15562: with a face ironically innocent.
15563: 
15564: “Melema? no, indeed,” answered Ser Ceccone. “He is as close as a nut.
15565: He never brags. That’s why he’s employed everywhere. They say he’s
15566: getting rich with doing all sorts of underhand work.”
15567: 
15568: “It _is_ a little too bad,” said Macchiavelli, “and so many able
15569: notaries out of employment!”
15570: 
15571: “Well, I must say I thought that was a nasty story a year or two ago
15572: about the man who said he had stolen jewels,” said Cei. “It got hushed
15573: up somehow; but I remember Piero di Cosimo said, at the time, he
15574: believed there was something in it, for he saw Melema’s face when the
15575: man laid hold of him, and he never saw a visage so ‘painted with fear,’
15576: as our sour old Dante says.”
15577: 
15578: “Come, spit no more of that venom, Francesco,” said Nello, getting
15579: indignant, “else I shall consider it a public duty to cut your hair
15580: awry the next time I get you under my scissors. That story of the
15581: stolen jewels was a lie. Bernardo Rucellai and the Magnificent Eight
15582: knew all about it. The man was a dangerous madman, and he was very
15583: properly kept out of mischief in prison. As for our Piero di Cosimo,
15584: his wits are running after the wind of Mongibello: he has such an
15585: extravagant fancy that he would take a lizard for a crocodile. No: that
15586: story has been dead and buried too long—our noses object to it.”
15587: 
15588: “It is true,” said Macchiavelli. “You forget the danger of the
15589: precedent, Francesco. The next mad beggarman may accuse you of stealing
15590: his verses, or me, God help me! of stealing his coppers. Ah!” he went
15591: on, turning towards the door, “Dolfo Spini has carried his red feather
15592: out of the Piazza. That captain of swaggerers would like the Republic
15593: to lose Pisa just for the chance of seeing the people tear the frock
15594: off the Frate’s back. With your pardon, Francesco—I know he is a friend
15595: of yours—there are few things I should like better than to see him play
15596: the part of Capo d’Oca, who went out to the tournament blowing his
15597: trumpets and returned with them in a bag.”
15598: 
15599: 
15600: 
15601: 
15602: CHAPTER XLVI.
15603: By a Street Lamp.
15604: 
15605: 
15606: That evening, when it was dark and threatening rain, Romola, returning
15607: with Maso and the lantern by her side, from the hospital of San Matteo,
15608: which she had visited after vespers, encountered her husband just
15609: issuing from the monastery of San Marco. Tito, who had gone out again
15610: shortly after his arrival in the Via de’ Bardi, and had seen little of
15611: Romola during the day, immediately proposed to accompany her home,
15612: dismissing Maso, whose short steps annoyed him. It was only usual for
15613: him to pay her such an official attention when it was obviously
15614: demanded from him. Tito and Romola never jarred, never remonstrated
15615: with each other. They were too hopelessly alienated in their inner life
15616: ever to have that contest which is an effort towards agreement. They
15617: talked of all affairs, public and private, with careful adherence to an
15618: adopted course. If Tito wanted a supper prepared in the old library,
15619: now pleasantly furnished as a banqueting-room, Romola assented, and saw
15620: that everything needful was done: and Tito, on his side, left her
15621: entirely uncontrolled in her daily habits, accepting the help she
15622: offered him in transcribing or making digests, and in return meeting
15623: her conjectured want of supplies for her charities. Yet he constantly,
15624: as on this very morning, avoided exchanging glances with her; affected
15625: to believe that she was out of the house, in order to avoid seeking her
15626: in her own room; and playfully attributed to her a perpetual preference
15627: of solitude to his society.
15628: 
15629: In the first ardour of her self-conquest, after she had renounced her
15630: resolution of flight, Romola had made many timid efforts towards the
15631: return of a frank relation between them. But to her such a relation
15632: could only come by open speech about their differences, and the attempt
15633: to arrive at a moral understanding; while Tito could only be saved from
15634: alienation from her by such a recovery of her effusive tenderness as
15635: would have presupposed oblivion of their differences. He cared for no
15636: explanation between them; he felt any thorough explanation impossible:
15637: he would have cared to have Romola fond again, and to her, fondness was
15638: impossible. She could be submissive and gentle, she could repress any
15639: sign of repulsion; but tenderness was not to be feigned. She was
15640: helplessly conscious of the result: her husband was alienated from her.
15641: 
15642: It was an additional reason why she should be carefully kept outside of
15643: secrets which he would in no case have chosen to communicate to her.
15644: With regard to his political action he sought to convince her that he
15645: considered the cause of the Medici hopeless; and that on that practical
15646: ground, as well as in theory, he heartily served the popular
15647: government, in which she had now a warm interest. But impressions
15648: subtle as odours made her uneasy about his relations with San Marco.
15649: She was painfully divided between the dread of seeing any evidence to
15650: arouse her suspicions, and the impulse to watch lest any harm should
15651: come that she might have arrested.
15652: 
15653: As they walked together this evening, Tito said—“The business of the
15654: day is not yet quite ended for me. I shall conduct you to our door, my
15655: Romola, and then I must fulfil another commission, which will take me
15656: an hour, perhaps, before I can return and rest, as I very much need to
15657: do.”
15658: 
15659: And then he talked amusingly of what he had seen at Pisa, until they
15660: were close upon a loggia, near which there hung a lamp before a picture
15661: of the Virgin. The street was a quiet one, and hitherto they had passed
15662: few people; but now there was a sound of many approaching footsteps and
15663: confused voices.
15664: 
15665: “We shall not get home without a wetting, unless we take shelter under
15666: this convenient loggia,” Tito said, hastily, hurrying Romola, with a
15667: slightly startled movement, up the step of the loggia.
15668: 
15669: “Surely it is useless to wait for this small drizzling rain,” said
15670: Romola, in surprise.
15671: 
15672: “No: I felt it becoming heavier. Let us wait a little.” With that
15673: wakefulness to the faintest indication which belongs to a mind
15674: habitually in a state of caution, Tito had detected by the glimmer of
15675: the lamp that the leader of the advancing group wore a red feather and
15676: a glittering sword-hilt—in fact, was almost the last person in the
15677: world he would have chosen to meet at this hour with Romola by his
15678: side. He had already during the day had one momentous interview with
15679: Dolfo Spini, and the business he had spoken of to Romola as yet to be
15680: done was a second interview with that personage, a sequence of the
15681: visit he had paid at San Marco. Tito, by a long-preconcerted plan, had
15682: been the bearer of letters to Savonarola—carefully-forged letters; one
15683: of them, by a stratagem, bearing the very signature and seal of the
15684: Cardinal of Naples, who of all the Sacred College had most exerted his
15685: influence at Rome in favour of the Frate. The purport of the letters
15686: was to state that the Cardinal was on his progress from Pisa, and,
15687: unwilling for strong reasons to enter Florence, yet desirous of taking
15688: counsel with Savonarola at this difficult juncture, intended to pause
15689: this very day at San Casciano, about ten miles from the city, whence he
15690: would ride out the next morning in the plain garb of a priest, and meet
15691: Savonarola, as if casually, five miles on the Florence road, two hours
15692: after sunrise. The plot, of which these forged letters were the initial
15693: step, was that Dolfo Spini with a band of his Compagnacci was to be
15694: posted in ambush on the road, at a lonely spot about five miles from
15695: the gates; that he was to seize Savonarola with the Dominican brother
15696: who would accompany him according to rule, and deliver him over to a
15697: small detachment of Milanese horse in readiness near San Casciano, by
15698: whom he was to be carried into the Roman territory.
15699: 
15700: There was a strong chance that the penetrating Frate would suspect a
15701: trap, and decline to incur the risk, which he had for some time
15702: avoided, of going beyond the city walls. Even when he preached, his
15703: friends held it necessary that he should be attended by an armed guard;
15704: and here he was called on to commit himself to a solitary road, with no
15705: other attendant than a fellow-monk. On this ground the minimum of time
15706: had been given him for decision, and the chance in favour of his acting
15707: on the letters was, that the eagerness with which his mind was set on
15708: the combining of interests within and without the Church towards the
15709: procuring of a General Council, and also the expectation of immediate
15710: service from the Cardinal in the actual juncture of his contest with
15711: the Pope, would triumph over his shrewdness and caution in the brief
15712: space allowed for deliberation.
15713: 
15714: Tito had had an audience of Savonarola, having declined to put the
15715: letters into any hands but his, and with consummate art had admitted
15716: that incidentally, and by inference, he was able so far to conjecture
15717: their purport as to believe they referred to a rendezvous outside the
15718: gates, in which case he urged that the Frate should seek an armed guard
15719: from the Signoria, and offered his services in carrying the request
15720: with the utmost privacy. Savonarola had replied briefly that this was
15721: impossible: an armed guard was incompatible with privacy. He spoke with
15722: a flashing eye, and Tito felt convinced that he meant to incur the
15723: risk.
15724: 
15725: Tito himself did not much care for the result. He managed his affairs
15726: so cleverly, that all results, he considered, must turn to his
15727: advantage. Whichever party came uppermost, he was secure of favour and
15728: money. That is an indecorously naked statement; the fact, clothed as
15729: Tito habitually clothed it, was that his acute mind, discerning the
15730: equal hollowness of all parties, took the only rational course in
15731: making them subservient to his own interest.
15732: 
15733: If Savonarola fell into the snare, there were diamonds in question and
15734: papal patronage; if not, Tito’s adroit agency had strengthened his
15735: position with Savonarola and with Spini, while any confidences he
15736: obtained from them made him the more valuable as an agent of the
15737: Mediceans.
15738: 
15739: But Spini was an inconvenient colleague. He had cunning enough to
15740: delight in plots, but not the ability or self-command necessary to so
15741: complex an effect as secrecy. He frequently got excited with drinking,
15742: for even sober Florence had its “Beoni,” or topers, both lay and
15743: clerical, who became loud at taverns and private banquets; and in spite
15744: of the agreement between him and Tito, that their public recognition of
15745: each other should invariably be of the coolest sort, there was always
15746: the possibility that on an evening encounter he would be suddenly
15747: blurting and affectionate. The delicate sign of casting the becchetto
15748: over the left shoulder was understood in the morning, but the strongest
15749: hint short of a threat might not suffice to keep off a fraternal grasp
15750: of the shoulder in the evening.
15751: 
15752: Tito’s chief hope now was that Dolfo Spini had not caught sight of him,
15753: and the hope would have been well founded if Spini had had no clearer
15754: view of him than he had caught of Spini. But, himself in shadow, he had
15755: seen Tito illuminated for an instant by the direct rays of the lamp,
15756: and Tito in his way was as strongly marked a personage as the captain
15757: of the Compagnacci. Romola’s black-shrouded figure had escaped notice,
15758: and she now stood behind her husband’s shoulder in the corner of the
15759: loggia. Tito was not left to hope long.
15760: 
15761: “Ha! my carrier-pigeon!” grated Spini’s harsh voice, in what he meant
15762: to be an undertone, while his hand grasped Tito’s shoulder; “what did
15763: you run into hiding for? You didn’t know it was comrades who were
15764: coming. It’s well I caught sight of you; it saves time. What of the
15765: chase to-morrow morning? Will the bald-headed game rise? Are the
15766: falcons to be got ready?”
15767: 
15768: If it had been in Tito’s nature to feel an access of rage, he would
15769: have felt it against this bull-faced accomplice, unfit either for a
15770: leader or a tool. His lips turned white, but his excitement came from
15771: the pressing difficulty of choosing a safe device. If he attempted to
15772: hush Spini, that would only deepen Romola’s suspicion, and he knew her
15773: well enough to know that if some strong alarm were roused in her, she
15774: was neither to be silenced nor hoodwinked: on the other hand, if he
15775: repelled Spini angrily the wine-breathing Compagnaccio might become
15776: savage, being more ready at resentment than at the divination of
15777: motives. He adopted a third course, which proved that Romola retained
15778: one sort of power over him—the power of dread.
15779: 
15780: He pressed her hand, as if intending a hint to her, and said in a
15781: good-humoured tone of comradeship—
15782: 
15783: “Yes, my Dolfo, you may prepare in all security. But take no trumpets
15784: with you.”
15785: 
15786: “Don’t be afraid,” said Spini, a little piqued. “No need to play Ser
15787: Saccente with me. I know where the devil keeps his tail as well as you
15788: do. What! he swallowed the bait whole? The prophetic nose didn’t scent
15789: the hook at all?” he went on, lowering his tone a little, with a
15790: blundering sense of secrecy.
15791: 
15792: “The brute will not be satisfied till he has emptied the bag,” thought
15793: Tito: but aloud he said,—“Swallowed all as easily as you swallow a cup
15794: of Trebbiano. Ha! I see torches: there must be a dead body coming. The
15795: pestilence has been spreading, I hear.”
15796: 
15797: “Santiddio! I hate the sight of those biers. Good-night,” said Spini,
15798: hastily moving off.
15799: 
15800: The torches were really coming, but they preceded a church dignitary
15801: who was returning homeward; the suggestion of the dead body and the
15802: pestilence was Tito’s device for getting rid of Spini without telling
15803: him to go. The moment he had moved away, Tito turned to Romola, and
15804: said, quietly—
15805: 
15806: “Do not be alarmed by anything that _bestia_ has said, my Romola. We
15807: will go on now: I think the rain has not increased.”
15808: 
15809: She was quivering with indignant resolution; it was of no use for Tito
15810: to speak in that unconcerned way. She distrusted every word he could
15811: utter.
15812: 
15813: “I will not go on,” she said. “I will not move nearer home until I have
15814: some security against this treachery being perpetrated.”
15815: 
15816: “Wait, at least, until these torches have passed,” said Tito, with
15817: perfect self-command, but with a new rising of dislike to a wife who
15818: this time, he foresaw, might have the power of thwarting him in spite
15819: of the husband’s predominance.
15820: 
15821: The torches passed, with the Vicario dell’ Arcivescovo, and due
15822: reverence was done by Tito, but Romola saw nothing outward. If for the
15823: defeat of this treachery, in which she believed with all the force of
15824: long presentiment, it had been necessary at that moment for her to
15825: spring on her husband and hurl herself with him down a precipice, she
15826: felt as if she could have done it. Union with this man! At that moment
15827: the self-quelling discipline of two years seemed to be nullified: she
15828: felt nothing but that they were divided.
15829: 
15830: They were nearly in darkness again, and could only see each other’s
15831: faces dimly.
15832: 
15833: “Tell me the truth, Tito—this time tell me the truth,” said Romola, in
15834: a low quivering voice. “It will be safer for you.”
15835: 
15836: “Why should I desire to tell you anything else, my angry saint?” said
15837: Tito, with a slight touch of contempt, which was the vent of his
15838: annoyance; “since the truth is precisely that over which you have most
15839: reason to rejoice—namely, that my knowing a plot of Spini’s enables me
15840: to secure the Frate from falling a victim to it.”
15841: 
15842: “What is the plot?”
15843: 
15844: “That I decline to tell,” said Tito. “It is enough that the Frate’s
15845: safety will be secured.”
15846: 
15847: “It is a plot for drawing him outside the gates that Spini may murder
15848: him.”
15849: 
15850: “There has been no intention of murder. It is simply a plot for
15851: compelling him to obey the Pope’s summons to Rome. But as I serve the
15852: popular government, and think the Frate’s presence here is a necessary
15853: means of maintaining it at present, I choose to prevent his departure.
15854: You may go to sleep with entire ease of mind to-night.”
15855: 
15856: For a moment Romola was silent. Then she said, in a voice of anguish,
15857: “Tito, it is of no use: I have no belief in you.”
15858: 
15859: She could just discern his action as he shrugged his shoulders, and
15860: spread out his palms in silence. That cold dislike which is the anger
15861: of unimpassioned beings was hardening within him.
15862: 
15863: “If the Frate leaves the city—if any harm happens to him,” said Romola,
15864: after a slight pause, in a new tone of indignant resolution,—“I will
15865: declare what I have heard to the Signoria, and you will be disgraced.
15866: What if I am your wife?” she went on, impetuously; “I will be disgraced
15867: with you. If we are united, I am that part of you that will save you
15868: from crime. Others shall not be betrayed.”
15869: 
15870: “I am quite aware of what you would be likely to do, _anima mia_,” said
15871: Tito, in the coolest of his liquid tones; “therefore if you have a
15872: small amount of reasoning at your disposal just now, consider that if
15873: you believe me in nothing else, you may believe me when I say I will
15874: take care of myself, and not put it in your power to ruin me.”
15875: 
15876: “Then you assure me that the Frate is warned—he will not go beyond the
15877: gates?”
15878: 
15879: “He shall not go beyond the gates.”
15880: 
15881: There was a moment’s pause, but distrust was not to be expelled.
15882: 
15883: “I will go back to San Marco now and find out,” Romola said, making a
15884: movement forward.
15885: 
15886: “You shall not!” said Tito, in a bitter whisper, seizing her wrists
15887: with all his masculine force. “I am master of you. You shall not set
15888: yourself in opposition to me.”
15889: 
15890: There were passers-by approaching. Tito had heard them, and that was
15891: why he spoke in a whisper. Romola was too conscious of being mastered
15892: to have struggled, even if she had remained unconscious that witnesses
15893: were at hand. But she was aware now of footsteps and voices, and her
15894: habitual sense of personal dignity made her at once yield to Tito’s
15895: movement towards leading her from the loggia.
15896: 
15897: They walked on in silence for some time, under the small drizzling
15898: rain. The first rush of indignation and alarm in Romola had begun to
15899: give way to more complicated feelings, which rendered speech and action
15900: difficult. In that simpler state of vehemence, open opposition to the
15901: husband from whom she felt her soul revolting had had the aspect of
15902: temptation for her; it seemed the easiest of all courses. But now,
15903: habits of self-questioning, memories of impulse subdued, and that proud
15904: reserve which all discipline had left unmodified, began to emerge from
15905: the flood of passion. The grasp of her wrists, which asserted her
15906: husband’s physical predominance, instead of arousing a new fierceness
15907: in her, as it might have done if her impetuosity had been of a more
15908: vulgar kind, had given her a momentary shuddering horror at this form
15909: of contest with him. It was the first time they had been in declared
15910: hostility to each other since her flight and return, and the check
15911: given to her ardent resolution then, retained the power to arrest her
15912: now. In this altered condition her mind began to dwell on the
15913: probabilities that would save her from any desperate course: Tito would
15914: not risk betrayal by her; whatever had been his original intention, he
15915: must be determined now by the fact that she knew of the plot. She was
15916: not bound now to do anything else than to hang over him that certainty,
15917: that if he deceived her, her lips would not be closed. And then, it was
15918: possible—yes, she must cling to that possibility till it was
15919: disproved—that Tito had never meant to aid in the betrayal of the
15920: Frate.
15921: 
15922: Tito, on his side, was busy with thoughts, and did not speak again till
15923: they were near home. Then he said—
15924: 
15925: “Well, Romola, have you now had time to recover calmness? If so, you
15926: can supply your want of belief in me by a little rational inference:
15927: you can see, I presume, that if I had had any intention of furthering
15928: Spini’s plot, I should now be aware that the possession of a fair
15929: Piagnone for my wife, who knows the secret of the plot, would be a
15930: serious obstacle in my way.”
15931: 
15932: Tito assumed the tone which was just then the easiest to him,
15933: conjecturing that in Romola’s present mood persuasive deprecation would
15934: be lost upon her.
15935: 
15936: “Yes, Tito,” she said, in a low voice, “I think you believe that I
15937: would guard the Republic from further treachery. You are right to
15938: believe it: if the Frate is betrayed, I will denounce you.” She paused
15939: a moment, and then said, with an effort, “But it was not so. I have
15940: perhaps spoken too hastily—you never meant it. Only, why will you seem
15941: to be that man’s comrade?”
15942: 
15943: “Such relations are inevitable to practical men, my Romola,” said Tito,
15944: gratified by discerning the struggle within her. “You fair creatures
15945: live in the clouds. Pray go to rest with an easy heart,” he added,
15946: opening the door for her.
15947: 
15948: 
15949: 
15950: 
15951: CHAPTER XLVII.
15952: Check.
15953: 
15954: 
15955: Tito’s clever arrangements had been unpleasantly frustrated by trivial
15956: incidents which could not enter into a clever man’s calculations. It
15957: was very seldom that he walked with Romola in the evening, yet he had
15958: happened to be walking with her precisely on this evening when her
15959: presence was supremely inconvenient. Life was so complicated a game
15960: that the devices of skill were liable to be defeated at every turn by
15961: air-blown chances, incalculable as the descent of thistle-down.
15962: 
15963: It was not that he minded about the failure of Spini’s plot, but he
15964: felt an awkward difficulty in so adjusting his warning to Savonarola on
15965: the one hand, and to Spini on the other, as not to incur suspicion.
15966: Suspicion roused in the popular party might be fatal to his reputation
15967: and ostensible position in Florence: suspicion roused in Dolfo Spini
15968: might be as disagreeable in its effects as the hatred of a fierce dog
15969: not to be chained.
15970: 
15971: If Tito went forthwith to the monastery to warn Savonarola before the
15972: monks went to rest, his warning would follow so closely on his delivery
15973: of the forged letters that he could not escape unfavourable surmises.
15974: He could not warn Spini at once without telling him the true reason,
15975: since he could not immediately allege the discovery that Savonarola had
15976: changed his purpose; and he knew Spini well enough to know that his
15977: understanding would discern nothing but that Tito had “turned round”
15978: and frustrated the plot. On the other hand, by deferring his warning to
15979: Savonarola until the morning, he would be almost sure to lose the
15980: opportunity of warning Spini that the Frate had changed his mind; and
15981: the band of Compagnacci would come back in all the rage of
15982: disappointment. This last, however, was the risk he chose, trusting to
15983: his power of soothing Spini by assuring him that the failure was due
15984: only to the Frate’s caution.
15985: 
15986: Tito was annoyed. If he had had to smile it would have been an unusual
15987: effort to him. He was determined not to encounter Romola again, and he
15988: did not go home that night.
15989: 
15990: She watched through the night, and never took off her clothes. She
15991: heard the rain become heavier and heavier. She liked to hear the rain:
15992: the stormy heavens seemed a safeguard against men’s devices, compelling
15993: them to inaction. And Romola’s mind was again assailed, not only by the
15994: utmost doubt of her husband, but by doubt as to her own conduct. What
15995: lie might he not have told her? What project might he not have, of
15996: which she was still ignorant? Every one who trusted Tito was in danger;
15997: it was useless to try and persuade herself of the contrary. And was not
15998: she selfishly listening to the promptings of her own pride, when she
15999: shrank from warning men against him? “If her husband was a malefactor,
16000: her place was in the prison by his side”—that might be; she was
16001: contented to fulfil that claim. But was she, a wife, to allow a husband
16002: to inflict the injuries that would make him a malefactor, when it might
16003: be in her power to prevent them? Prayer seemed impossible to her. The
16004: activity of her thought excluded a mental state of which the essence is
16005: expectant passivity.
16006: 
16007: The excitement became stronger and stronger. Her imagination, in a
16008: state of morbid activity, conjured up possible schemes by which, after
16009: all, Tito would have eluded her threat; and towards daybreak the rain
16010: became less violent, till at last it ceased, the breeze rose again and
16011: dispersed the clouds, and the morning fell clear on all the objects
16012: around her. It made her uneasiness all the less endurable. She wrapped
16013: her mantle round her, and ran up to the loggia, as if there could be
16014: anything in the wide landscape that might determine her action; as if
16015: there could be anything but roofs hiding the line of street along which
16016: Savonarola might be walking towards betrayal.
16017: 
16018: If she went to her godfather, might she not induce him, without any
16019: specific revelation, to take measures for preventing Fra Girolamo from
16020: passing the gates? But that might be too late. Romola thought, with new
16021: distress, that she had failed to learn any guiding details from Tito,
16022: and it was already long past seven. She must go to San Marco: there was
16023: nothing else to be done.
16024: 
16025: She hurried down the stairs, she went out into the street without
16026: looking at her sick people, and walked at a swift pace along the Via
16027: de’ Bardi towards the Ponte Vecchio. She would go through the heart of
16028: the city; it was the most direct road, and, besides, in the great
16029: Piazza there was a chance of encountering her husband, who, by some
16030: possibility to which she still clung, might satisfy her of the Frate’s
16031: safety, and leave no need for her to go to San Marco. When she arrived
16032: in front of the Palazzo Vecchio, she looked eagerly into the pillared
16033: court; then her eyes swept the Piazza; but the well-known figure, once
16034: painted in her heart by young love, and now branded there by eating
16035: pain, was nowhere to be seen. She hurried straight on to the Piazza del
16036: Duomo. It was already full of movement: there were worshippers passing
16037: up and down the marble steps, there were men pausing for chat, and
16038: there were market-people carrying their burdens. Between those moving
16039: figures Romola caught a glimpse of her husband. On his way from San
16040: Marco he had turned into Nello’s shop, and was now leaning against the
16041: door-post. As Romola approached she could see that he was standing and
16042: talking, with the easiest air in the world, holding his cap in his
16043: hand, and shaking back his freshly-combed hair. The contrast of this
16044: ease with the bitter anxieties he had created convulsed her with
16045: indignation: the new vision of his hardness heightened her dread. She
16046: recognised Cronaca and two other frequenters of San Marco standing near
16047: her husband. It flashed through her mind—“I will compel him to speak
16048: before those men.” And her light step brought her close upon him before
16049: he had time to move, while Cronaca was saying, “Here comes Madonna
16050: Romola.”
16051: 
16052: A slight shock passed through Tito’s frame as he felt himself face to
16053: face with his wife. She was haggard with her anxious watching, but
16054: there was a flash of something else than anxiety in her eyes as she
16055: said—
16056: 
16057: “Is the Frate gone beyond the gates?”
16058: 
16059: “No,” said Tito, feeling completely helpless before this woman, and
16060: needing all the self-command he possessed to preserve a countenance in
16061: which there should seem to be nothing stronger than surprise.
16062: 
16063: “And you are certain that he is not going?” she insisted.
16064: 
16065: “I am certain that he is not going.”
16066: 
16067: “That is enough,” said Romola, and she turned up the steps, to take
16068: refuge in the Duomo, till she could recover from her agitation.
16069: 
16070: Tito never had a feeling so near hatred as that with which his eyes
16071: followed Romola retreating up the steps.
16072: 
16073: There were present not only genuine followers of the Frate, but Ser
16074: Ceccone, the notary, who at that time, like Tito himself, was secretly
16075: an agent of the Mediceans.
16076: 
16077: Ser Francesco di Ser Barone, more briefly known to infamy as Ser
16078: Ceccone, was not learned, not handsome, not successful, and the reverse
16079: of generous. He was a traitor without charm. It followed that he was
16080: not fond of Tito Melema.
16081: 
16082: 
16083: 
16084: 
16085: CHAPTER XLVIII.
16086: Counter-Check.
16087: 
16088: 
16089: It was late in the afternoon when Tito returned home. Romola, seated
16090: opposite the cabinet in her narrow room, copying documents, was about
16091: to desist from her work because the light was getting dim, when her
16092: husband entered. He had come straight to this room to seek her, with a
16093: thoroughly defined intention, and there was something new to Romola in
16094: his manner and expression as he looked at her silently on entering,
16095: and, without taking off his cap and mantle, leaned one elbow on the
16096: cabinet, and stood directly in front of her.
16097: 
16098: Romola, fully assured during the day of the Frate’s safety, was feeling
16099: the reaction of some penitence for the access of distrust and
16100: indignation which had impelled her to address her husband publicly on a
16101: matter that she knew he wished to be private. She told herself that she
16102: had probably been wrong. The scheming duplicity which she had heard
16103: even her godfather allude to as inseparable from party tactics might be
16104: sufficient to account for the connection with Spini, without the
16105: supposition that Tito had ever meant to further the plot. She wanted to
16106: atone for her impetuosity by confessing that she had been too hasty,
16107: and for some hours her mind had been dwelling on the possibility that
16108: this confession of hers might lead to other frank words breaking the
16109: two years’ silence of their hearts. The silence had been so complete,
16110: that Tito was ignorant of her having fled from him and come back again;
16111: they had never approached an avowal of that past which, both in its
16112: young love and in the shock that shattered the love, lay locked away
16113: from them like a banquet-room where death had once broken the feast.
16114: 
16115: She looked up at him with that submission in her glance which belonged
16116: to her state of self-reproof; but the subtle change in his face and
16117: manner arrested her speech. For a few moments they remained silent,
16118: looking at each other.
16119: 
16120: Tito himself felt that a crisis was come in his married life. The
16121: husband’s determination to mastery, which lay deep below all blandness
16122: and beseechingness, had risen permanently to the surface now, and
16123: seemed to alter his face, as a face is altered by a hidden muscular
16124: tension with which a man is secretly throttling or stamping out the
16125: life from something feeble, yet dangerous.
16126: 
16127: “Romola,” he began, in the cool liquid tone that made her shiver, “it
16128: is time that we should understand each other.” He paused.
16129: 
16130: “That is what I most desire, Tito,” she said, faintly. Her sweet pale
16131: face; with all its anger gone and nothing but the timidity of
16132: self-doubt in it, seemed to give a marked predominance to her husband’s
16133: dark strength.
16134: 
16135: “You took a step this morning,” Tito went on, “which you must now
16136: yourself perceive to have been useless—which exposed you to remark and
16137: may involve me in serious practical difficulties.”
16138: 
16139: “I acknowledge that I was too hasty; I am sorry for any injustice I may
16140: have done you.” Romola spoke these words in a fuller and firmer tone;
16141: Tito, she hoped, would look less hard when she had expressed her
16142: regret, and then she could say other things.
16143: 
16144: “I wish you once for all to understand,” he said, without any change of
16145: voice, “that such collisions are incompatible with our position as
16146: husband and wife. I wish you to reflect on the mode in which you were
16147: led to that step, that the process may not be repeated.”
16148: 
16149: “That depends chiefly on you, Tito,” said Romola, taking fire slightly.
16150: It was not at all what she had thought of saying, but we see a very
16151: little way before us in mutual speech.
16152: 
16153: “You would say, I suppose,” answered Tito, “that nothing is to occur in
16154: future which can excite your unreasonable suspicions. You were frank
16155: enough to say last night that you have no belief in me. I am not
16156: surprised at any exaggerated conclusion you may draw from slight
16157: premises, but I wish to point out to you what is likely to be the fruit
16158: of your making such exaggerated conclusions a ground for interfering in
16159: affairs of which you are ignorant. Your attention is thoroughly awake
16160: to what I am saying?”
16161: 
16162: He paused for a reply.
16163: 
16164: “Yes,” said Romola, flushing in irrepressible resentment at this cold
16165: tone of superiority.
16166: 
16167: “Well, then, it may possibly not be very long before some other chance
16168: words or incidents set your imagination at work devising crimes for me,
16169: and you may perhaps rush to the Palazzo Vecchio to alarm the Signoria
16170: and set the city in an uproar. Shall I tell you what may be the result?
16171: Not simply the disgrace of your husband, to which you look forward with
16172: so much courage, but the arrest and ruin of many among the chief men in
16173: Florence, including Messer Bernardo del Nero.”
16174: 
16175: Tito had meditated a decisive move, and he had made it. The flush died
16176: out of Romola’s face, and her very lips were pale—an unusual effect
16177: with her, for she was little subject to fear. Tito perceived his
16178: success.
16179: 
16180: “You would perhaps flatter yourself,” he went on, “that you were
16181: performing a heroic deed of deliverance; you might as well try to turn
16182: locks with fine words as apply such notions to the politics of
16183: Florence. The question now is, not whether you can have any belief in
16184: me, but whether, now you have been warned, you will dare to rush, like
16185: a blind man with a torch in his hand, amongst intricate affairs of
16186: which you know nothing.”
16187: 
16188: Romola felt as if her mind were held in a vice by Tito’s: the
16189: possibilities he had indicated were rising before her with terrible
16190: clearness.
16191: 
16192: “I am too rash,” she said. “I will try not to be rash.”
16193: 
16194: “Remember,” said Tito, with unsparing insistence, “that your act of
16195: distrust towards me this morning might, for aught you knew, have had
16196: more fatal effects than that sacrifice of your husband which you have
16197: learned to contemplate without flinching.”
16198: 
16199: “Tito, it is not so,” Romola burst forth in a pleading tone, rising and
16200: going nearer to him, with a desperate resolution to speak out. “It is
16201: false that I would willingly sacrifice you. It has been the greatest
16202: effort of my life to cling to you. I went away in my anger two years
16203: ago, and I came back again because I was more bound to you than to
16204: anything else on earth. But it is useless. You shut me out from your
16205: mind. You affect to think of me as a being too unreasonable to share in
16206: the knowledge of your affairs. You will be open with me about nothing.”
16207: 
16208: She looked like his good angel pleading with him, as she bent her face
16209: towards him with dilated eyes, and laid her hand upon his arm. But
16210: Romola’s touch and glance no longer stirred any fibre of tenderness in
16211: her husband. The good-humoured, tolerant Tito, incapable of hatred,
16212: incapable almost of impatience, disposed always to be gentle towards
16213: the rest of the world, felt himself becoming strangely hard towards
16214: this wife whose presence had once been the strongest influence he had
16215: known. With all his softness of disposition, he had a masculine
16216: effectiveness of intellect and purpose which, like sharpness of edge,
16217: is itself an energy, working its way without any strong momentum.
16218: Romola had an energy of her own which thwarted his, and no man, who is
16219: not exceptionally feeble, will endure being thwarted by his wife.
16220: Marriage must be a relation either of sympathy or of conquest.
16221: 
16222: No emotion darted across his face as he heard Romola for the first time
16223: speak of having gone away from him. His lips only looked a little
16224: harder as he smiled slightly and said—
16225: 
16226: “My Romola, when certain conditions are ascertained, we must make up
16227: our minds to them. No amount of wishing will fill the Arno, as your
16228: people say, or turn a plum into an orange. I have not observed even
16229: that prayers have much efficacy that way. You are so constituted as to
16230: have certain strong impressions inaccessible to reason: I cannot share
16231: those impressions, and you have withdrawn all trust from me in
16232: consequence. You have changed towards me; it has followed that I have
16233: changed towards you. It is useless to take any retrospect. We have
16234: simply to adapt ourselves to altered conditions.”
16235: 
16236: “Tito, it would not be useless for us to speak openly,” said Romola,
16237: with the sort of exasperation that comes from using living muscle
16238: against some lifeless insurmountable resistance. “It was the sense of
16239: deception in you that changed me, and that has kept us apart. And it is
16240: not true that I changed first. You changed towards me the night you
16241: first wore that chain-armour. You had some secret from me—it was about
16242: that old man—and I saw him again yesterday. Tito,” she went on, in a
16243: tone of agonised entreaty, “if you would once tell me everything, let
16244: it be what it may—I would not mind pain—that there might be no wall
16245: between us! Is it not possible that we could begin a new life?”
16246: 
16247: This time there was a flash of emotion across Tito’s face. He stood
16248: perfectly still; but the flash seemed to have whitened him. He took no
16249: notice of Romola’s appeal, but after a moment’s pause, said quietly—
16250: 
16251: “Your impetuosity about trifles, Romola, has a freezing influence that
16252: would cool the baths of Nero.” At these cutting words, Romola shrank
16253: and drew herself up into her usual self-sustained attitude. Tito went
16254: on. “If by ‘that old man’ you mean the mad Jacopo di Nola who attempted
16255: my life and made a strange accusation against me, of which I told you
16256: nothing because it would have alarmed you to no purpose, he, poor
16257: wretch, has died in prison. I saw his name in the list of dead.”
16258: 
16259: “I know nothing about his accusation,” said Romola. “But I know he is
16260: the man whom I saw with the rope round his neck in the Duomo—the man
16261: whose portrait Piero di Cosimo painted, grasping your arm as he saw him
16262: grasp it the day the French entered, the day you first wore the
16263: armour.”
16264: 
16265: “And where is he now, pray?” said Tito, still pale, but governing
16266: himself.
16267: 
16268: “He was lying lifeless in the street from starvation,” said Romola. “I
16269: revived him with bread and wine. I brought him to our door, but he
16270: refused to come in. Then I gave him some money, and he went away
16271: without telling me anything. But he had found out that I was your wife.
16272: Who is he?”
16273: 
16274: “A man, half mad, half imbecile, who was once my father’s servant in
16275: Greece, and who has a rancorous hatred towards me because I got him
16276: dismissed for theft. Now you have the whole mystery, and the further
16277: satisfaction of knowing that I am again in danger of assassination. The
16278: fact of my wearing the armour, about which you seem to have thought so
16279: much, must have led you to infer that I was in danger from this man.
16280: Was that the reason you chose to cultivate his acquaintance and invite
16281: him into the house?”
16282: 
16283: Romola was mute. To speak was only like rushing with bare breast
16284: against a shield.
16285: 
16286: Tito moved from his leaning posture, slowly took off his cap and
16287: mantle, and pushed back his hair. He was collecting himself for some
16288: final words. And Romola stood upright looking at him as she might have
16289: looked at some on-coming deadly force, to be met only by silent
16290: endurance.
16291: 
16292: “We need not refer to these matters again, Romola,” he said, precisely
16293: in the same tone as that in which he had spoken at first. “It is enough
16294: if you will remember that the next time your generous ardour leads you
16295: to interfere in political affairs, you are likely, not to save any one
16296: from danger, but to be raising scaffolds and setting houses on fire.
16297: You are not yet a sufficiently ardent Piagnone to believe that Messer
16298: Bernardo del Nero is the prince of darkness, and Messer Francesco
16299: Valori the archangel Michael. I think I need demand no promise from
16300: you?”
16301: 
16302: “I have understood you too well, Tito.”
16303: 
16304: “It is enough,” he said, leaving the room.
16305: 
16306: Romola turned round with despair in her face and sank into her seat. “O
16307: God, I have tried—I cannot help it. We shall always be divided.” Those
16308: words passed silently through her mind. “Unless,” she said aloud, as if
16309: some sudden vision had startled her into speech—“unless misery should
16310: come and join us!”
16311: 
16312: Tito, too, had a new thought in his mind after he had closed the door
16313: behind him. With the project of leaving Florence as soon as his life
16314: there had become a high enough stepping-stone to a life elsewhere,
16315: perhaps at Rome or Milan, there was now for the first time associated a
16316: desire to be free from Romola, and to leave her behind him. She had
16317: ceased to belong to the desirable furniture of his life: there was no
16318: possibility of an easy relation between them without genuineness on his
16319: part. Genuineness implied confession of the past, and confession
16320: involved a change of purpose. But Tito had as little bent that way as a
16321: leopard has to lap milk when its teeth are grown. From all relations
16322: that were not easy and agreeable, we know that Tito shrank: why should
16323: he cling to them?
16324: 
16325: And Romola had made his relations difficult with others besides
16326: herself. He had had a troublesome interview with Dolfo Spini, who had
16327: come back in a rage after an ineffectual soaking with rain and long
16328: waiting in ambush, and that scene between Romola and himself at Nello’s
16329: door, once reported in Spini’s ear, might be a seed of something more
16330: unmanageable than suspicion. But now, at least, he believed that he had
16331: mastered Romola by a terror which appealed to the strongest forces of
16332: her nature. He had alarmed her affection and her conscience by the
16333: shadowy image of consequences; he had arrested her intellect by hanging
16334: before it the idea of a hopeless complexity in affairs which defied any
16335: moral judgment.
16336: 
16337: Yet Tito was not at ease. The world was not yet quite cushioned with
16338: velvet, and, if it had been, he could not have abandoned himself to
16339: that softness with thorough enjoyment; for before he went out again
16340: this evening he put on his coat of chain-armour.
16341: 
16342: 
16343: 
16344: 
16345: CHAPTER XLIX.
16346: The Pyramid of Vanities.
16347: 
16348: 
16349: The wintry days passed for Romola as the white ships pass one who is
16350: standing lonely on the shore—passing in silence and sameness, yet each
16351: bearing a hidden burden of coming change. Tito’s hint had mingled so
16352: much dread with her interest in the progress of public affairs that she
16353: had begun to court ignorance rather than knowledge. The threatening
16354: German Emperor was gone again; and, in other ways besides, the position
16355: of Florence was alleviated; but so much distress remained that Romola’s
16356: active duties were hardly diminished, and in these, as usual, her mind
16357: found a refuge from its doubt.
16358: 
16359: She dared not rejoice that the relief which had come in extremity and
16360: had appeared to justify the policy of the Frate’s party was making that
16361: party so triumphant, that Francesco Valori, hot-tempered chieftain of
16362: the Piagnoni, had been elected Gonfaloniere at the beginning of the
16363: year, and was making haste to have as much of his own liberal way as
16364: possible during his two months of power. That seemed for the moment
16365: like a strengthening of the party most attached to freedom, and a
16366: reinforcement of protection to Savonarola; but Romola was now alive to
16367: every suggestion likely to deepen her foreboding, that whatever the
16368: present might be, it was only an unconscious brooding over the mixed
16369: germs of Change which might any day become tragic. And already by
16370: Carnival time, a little after mid-February, her presentiment was
16371: confirmed by the signs of a very decided change: the Mediceans had
16372: ceased to be passive, and were openly exerting themselves to procure
16373: the election of Bernardo del Nero as the new Gonfaloniere.
16374: 
16375: On the last day of the Carnival, between ten and eleven in the morning,
16376: Romola walked out, according to promise, towards the Corso degli
16377: Albizzi, to fetch her cousin Brigida, that they might both be ready to
16378: start from the Via de’ Bardi early in the afternoon, and take their
16379: places at a window which Tito had had reserved for them in the Piazza
16380: della Signoria, where there was to be a scene of so new and striking a
16381: sort, that all Florentine eyes must desire to see it. For the Piagnoni
16382: were having their own way thoroughly about the mode of keeping the
16383: Carnival. In vain Dolfo Spini and his companions had struggled to get
16384: up the dear old masques and practical jokes, well spiced with
16385: indecency. Such things were not to be in a city where Christ had been
16386: declared king.
16387: 
16388: Romola set out in that languid state of mind with which every one
16389: enters on a long day of sight-seeing purely for the sake of gratifying
16390: a child, or some dear childish friend. The day was certainly an epoch
16391: in carnival-keeping; but this phase of reform had not touched her
16392: enthusiasm: and she did not know that it was an epoch in her own life
16393: when _another_ lot would begin to be no longer secretly but visibly
16394: entwined with her own.
16395: 
16396: She chose to go through the great Piazza that she might take a first
16397: survey of the unparalleled sight there while she was still alone.
16398: Entering it from the south, she saw something monstrous and
16399: many-coloured in the shape of a pyramid, or, rather, like a huge
16400: fir-tree, sixty feet high, with shelves on the branches, widening and
16401: widening towards the base till they reached a circumference of eighty
16402: yards. The Piazza was full of life: slight young figures, in white
16403: garments, with olive wreaths on their heads, were moving to and fro
16404: about the base of the pyramidal tree, carrying baskets full of
16405: bright-coloured things; and maturer forms, some in the monastic frock,
16406: some in the loose tunics and dark-red caps of artists, were helping and
16407: examining, or else retreating to various points in the distance to
16408: survey the wondrous whole: while a considerable group, amongst whom
16409: Romola recognised Piero di Cosimo, standing on the marble steps of
16410: Orgagna’s Loggia, seemed to be keeping aloof in discontent and scorn.
16411: 
16412: Approaching nearer, she paused to look at the multifarious objects
16413: ranged in gradation from the base to the summit of the pyramid. There
16414: were tapestries and brocades of immodest design, pictures and
16415: sculptures held too likely to incite to vice; there were boards and
16416: tables for all sorts of games, playing-cards along with the blocks for
16417: printing them, dice, and other apparatus for gambling; there were
16418: worldly music-books, and musical instruments in all the pretty
16419: varieties of lute, drum, cymbal, and trumpet; there were masks and
16420: masquerading-dresses used in the old Carnival shows; there were
16421: handsome copies of Ovid, Boccaccio, Petrarca, Pulci, and other books of
16422: a vain or impure sort; there were all the implements of feminine
16423: vanity—rouge-pots, false hair, mirrors, perfumes, powders, and
16424: transparent veils intended to provoke inquisitive glances: lastly, at
16425: the very summit, there was the unflattering effigy of a probably
16426: mythical Venetian merchant, who was understood to have offered a heavy
16427: sum for this collection of marketable abominations, and, soaring above
16428: him in surpassing ugliness, the symbolic figure of the old debauched
16429: Carnival.
16430: 
16431: This was the preparation for a new sort of bonfire—the Burning of
16432: Vanities. Hidden in the interior of the pyramid was a plentiful store
16433: of dry fuel and gunpowder; and on this last day of the festival, at
16434: evening, the pile of vanities was to be set ablaze to the sound of
16435: trumpets, and the ugly old Carnival was to tumble into the flames amid
16436: the songs of reforming triumph.
16437: 
16438: This crowning act of the new festivities could hardly have been
16439: prepared but for a peculiar organisation which had been started by
16440: Savonarola two years before. The mass of the Florentine boyhood and
16441: youth was no longer left to its own genial promptings towards street
16442: mischief and crude dissoluteness. Under the training of Fra Domenico, a
16443: sort of lieutenant to Savonarola, lads and striplings, the hope of
16444: Florence, were to have none but pure words on their lips, were to have
16445: a zeal for Unseen Good that should put to shame the lukewarmness of
16446: their elders, and were to know no pleasures save of an angelic
16447: sort—singing divine praises and walking in white robes. It was for them
16448: that the ranges of seats had been raised high against the walls of the
16449: Duomo; and they had been used to hear Savonarola appeal to them as the
16450: future glory of a city specially appointed to do the work of God.
16451: 
16452: These fresh-cheeked troops were the chief agents in the regenerated
16453: merriment of the new Carnival, which was a sort of sacred parody of the
16454: old. Had there been bonfires in the old time? There was to be a bonfire
16455: now, consuming impurity from off the earth. Had there been symbolic
16456: processions? There were to be processions now, but the symbols were to
16457: be white robes and red crosses and olive wreaths—emblems of peace and
16458: innocent gladness—and the banners and images held aloft were to tell
16459: the triumphs of goodness. Had there been dancing in a ring under the
16460: open sky of the Piazza, to the sound of choral voices chanting loose
16461: songs? There was to be dancing in a ring now, but dancing of monks and
16462: laity in fraternal love and divine joy, and the music was to be the
16463: music of hymns. As for the collections from street passengers, they
16464: were to be greater than ever—not for gross and superfluous suppers, but
16465: for the benefit of the hungry and needy; and, besides, there was the
16466: collecting of the _Anathema_, or the Vanities to be laid on the great
16467: pyramidal bonfire.
16468: 
16469: Troops of young inquisitors went from house to house on this exciting
16470: business of asking that the Anathema should be given up to them.
16471: Perhaps, after the more avowed vanities had been surrendered, Madonna,
16472: at the head of the household, had still certain little reddened balls
16473: brought from the Levant, intended to produce on a sallow cheek a sudden
16474: bloom of the most ingenuous falsity? If so, let her bring them down and
16475: cast them into the basket of doom. Or, perhaps, she had ringlets and
16476: coils of “dead hair?”—if so, let her bring them to the streetdoor, not
16477: on her head, but in her hands, and publicly renounce the Anathema which
16478: hid the respectable signs of age under a ghastly mockery of youth. And,
16479: in reward, she would hear fresh young voices pronounce a blessing on
16480: her and her house.
16481: 
16482: The beardless inquisitors, organised into little regiments, doubtless
16483: took to their work very willingly. To coerce people by shame, or other
16484: spiritual pelting, into the giving up of things it will probably vex
16485: them to part with, is a form of piety to which the boyish mind is most
16486: readily converted; and if some obstinately wicked men got enraged and
16487: threatened the whip or the cudgel, this also was exciting. Savonarola
16488: himself evidently felt about the training of these boys the difficulty
16489: weighing on all minds with noble yearnings towards great ends, yet with
16490: that imperfect perception of means which forces a resort to some
16491: supernatural constraining influence as the only sure hope. The
16492: Florentine youth had had very evil habits and foul tongues: it seemed
16493: at first an unmixed blessing when they were got to shout “_Viva Gesù_!”
16494: But Savonarola was forced at last to say from the pulpit, “There is a
16495: little too much shouting of ‘_Viva Gesù_!’ This constant utterance of
16496: sacred words brings them into contempt. Let me have no more of that
16497: shouting till the next Festa.”
16498: 
16499: Nevertheless, as the long stream of white-robed youthfulness, with its
16500: little red crosses and olive wreaths, had gone to the Duomo at dawn
16501: this morning to receive the communion from the hands of Savonarola, it
16502: was a sight of beauty; and, doubtless, many of those young souls were
16503: laying up memories of hope and awe that might save them from ever
16504: resting in a merely vulgar view of their work as men and citizens.
16505: There is no kind of conscious obedience that is not an advance on
16506: lawlessness, and these boys became the generation of men who fought
16507: greatly and endured greatly in the last struggle of their Republic.
16508: Now, in the intermediate hours between the early communion and
16509: dinner-time, they were making their last perambulations to collect alms
16510: and vanities, and this was why Romola saw the slim white figures moving
16511: to and fro about the base of the great pyramid.
16512: 
16513: “What think you of this folly, Madonna Romola?” said a brusque voice
16514: close to her ear. “Your Piagnoni will make _l’inferno_ a pleasant
16515: prospect to us, if they are to carry things their own way on earth.
16516: It’s enough to fetch a cudgel over the mountains to see painters, like
16517: Lorenzo di Credi and young Baccio there, helping to burn colour out of
16518: life in this fashion.”
16519: 
16520: “My good Piero,” said Romola, looking up and smiling at the grim man,
16521: “even you must be glad to see some of these things burnt. Look at those
16522: gewgaws and wigs and rouge-pots: I have heard you talk as indignantly
16523: against those things as Fra Girolamo himself.”
16524: 
16525: “What then?” said Piero, turning round on her sharply. “I never said a
16526: woman should make a black patch of herself against the background. Va!
16527: Madonna Antigone, it’s a shame for a woman with your hair and shoulders
16528: to run into such nonsense—leave it to women who are not worth painting.
16529: What! the most holy Virgin herself has always been dressed well; that’s
16530: the doctrine of the Church:—talk of heresy, indeed! And I should like
16531: to know what the excellent Messer Bardo would have said to the burning
16532: of the divine poets by these Frati, who are no better an imitation of
16533: men than if they were onions with the bulbs uppermost. Look at that
16534: Petrarca sticking up beside a rouge-pot: do the idiots pretend that the
16535: heavenly Laura was a painted harridan? And Boccaccio, now: do you mean
16536: to say, Madonna Romola—you who are fit to be a model for a wise Saint
16537: Catherine of Egypt—do you mean to say you have never read the stories
16538: of the immortal Messer Giovanni?”
16539: 
16540: “It is true I have read them, Piero,” said Romola. “Some of them a
16541: great many times over, when I was a little girl. I used to get the book
16542: down when my father was asleep, so that I could read to myself.”
16543: 
16544: “_Ebbene_?” said Piero, in a fiercely challenging tone.
16545: 
16546: “There are some things in them I do not want ever to forget,” said
16547: Romola; “but you must confess, Piero, that a great many of those
16548: stories are only about low deceit for the lowest ends. Men do not want
16549: books to make them think lightly of vice, as if life were a vulgar
16550: joke. And I cannot blame Fra Girolamo for teaching that we owe our time
16551: to something better.”
16552: 
16553: “Yes, yes, it’s very well to say so now you’ve read them,” said Piero,
16554: bitterly, turning on his heel and walking away from her.
16555: 
16556: Romola, too, walked on, smiling at Piero’s innuendo, with a sort of
16557: tenderness towards the old painter’s anger, because she knew that her
16558: father would have felt something like it. For herself, she was
16559: conscious of no inward collision with the strict and sombre view of
16560: pleasure which tended to repress poetry in the attempt to repress vice.
16561: Sorrow and joy have each their peculiar narrowness; and a religious
16562: enthusiasm like Savonarola’s which ultimately blesses mankind by giving
16563: the soul a strong propulsion towards sympathy with pain, indignation
16564: against wrong, and the subjugation of sensual desire, must always incur
16565: the reproach of a great negation. Romola’s life had given her an
16566: affinity for sadness which inevitably made her unjust towards
16567: merriment. That subtle result of culture which we call Taste was
16568: subdued by the need for deeper motive; just as the nicer demands of the
16569: palate are annihilated by urgent hunger. Moving habitually amongst
16570: scenes of suffering, and carrying woman’s heaviest disappointment in
16571: her heart, the severity which allied itself with self-renouncing
16572: beneficent strength had no dissonance for her.
16573: 
16574: 
16575: 
16576: 
16577: CHAPTER L.
16578: Tessa Abroad and at Home.
16579: 
16580: 
16581: Another figure easily recognised by us—a figure not clad in black, but
16582: in the old red, green, and white—was approaching the Piazza that
16583: morning to see the Carnival. She came from an opposite point, for Tessa
16584: no longer lived on the hill of San Giorgio. After what had happened
16585: there with Baldassarre, Tito had thought it best for that and other
16586: reasons to find her a new home, but still in a quiet airy quarter, in a
16587: house bordering on the wide garden grounds north of the Porta Santa
16588: Croce.
16589: 
16590: Tessa was not come out sight-seeing without special leave. Tito had
16591: been with her the evening before, and she had kept back the entreaty
16592: which she felt to be swelling her heart and throat until she saw him in
16593: a state of radiant ease, with one arm round the sturdy Lillo, and the
16594: other resting gently on her own shoulder as she tried to make the tiny
16595: Ninna steady on her legs. She was sure then that the weariness with
16596: which he had come in and flung himself into his chair had quite melted
16597: away from his brow and lips. Tessa had not been slow at learning a few
16598: small stratagems by which she might avoid vexing Naldo and yet have a
16599: little of her own way. She could read nothing else, but she had learned
16600: to read a good deal in her husband’s face.
16601: 
16602: And certainly the charm of that bright, gentle-humoured Tito who woke
16603: up under the Loggia de’ Cerchi on a Lenten morning five years before,
16604: not having yet given any hostages to deceit, never returned so nearly
16605: as in the person of Naldo, seated in that straight-backed, carved
16606: arm-chair which he had provided for his comfort when he came to see
16607: Tessa and the children. Tito himself was surprised at the growing sense
16608: of relief which he felt in these moments. No guile was needed towards
16609: Tessa: she was too ignorant and too innocent to suspect him of
16610: anything. And the little voices calling him “Babbo” were very sweet in
16611: his ears for the short while that he heard them. When he thought of
16612: leaving Florence, he never thought of leaving Tessa and the little ones
16613: behind. He was very fond of these round-cheeked, wide-eyed human things
16614: that clung about him and knew no evil of him. And wherever affection
16615: can spring, it is like the green leaf and the blossom—pure, and
16616: breathing purity, whatever soil it may grow in. Poor Romola, with all
16617: her self-sacrificing effort, was really helping to harden Tito’s nature
16618: by chilling it with a positive dislike which had beforehand seemed
16619: impossible in him; but Tessa kept open the fountains of kindness.
16620: 
16621: “Ninna is very good without me now,” began Tessa, feeling her request
16622: rising very high in her throat, and letting Ninna seat herself on the
16623: floor. “I can leave her with Monna Lisa any time, and if she is in the
16624: cradle and cries, Lillo is as sensible as can be—he goes and thumps
16625: Monna Lisa.”
16626: 
16627: Lillo, whose great dark eyes looked all the darker because his curls
16628: were of a light-brown like his mother’s, jumped off Babbo’s knee, and
16629: went forthwith to attest his intelligence by thumping Monna Lisa, who
16630: was shaking her head slowly over her spinning at the other end of the
16631: room. “A wonderful boy!” said Tito, laughing. “Isn’t he?” said Tessa,
16632: eagerly, getting a little closer to him; “and I might go and see the
16633: Carnival to-morrow, just for an hour or two, mightn’t I?”
16634: 
16635: “Oh, you wicked pigeon!” said Tito, pinching her cheek; “those are your
16636: longings, are they? What have you to do with carnivals now you are an
16637: old woman with two children?”
16638: 
16639: “But old women like to see things,” said Tessa, her lower lip hanging a
16640: little. “Monna Lisa said she should like to go, only she’s so deaf she
16641: can’t hear what is behind her, and she thinks we couldn’t take care of
16642: both the children.”
16643: 
16644: “No, indeed, Tessa,” said Tito, looking rather grave, “you must not
16645: think of taking the children into the crowded streets, else I shall be
16646: angry.”
16647: 
16648: “But I have never been into the Piazza without leave,” said Tessa, in a
16649: frightened, pleading tone, “since the Holy Saturday, and I think Nofri
16650: is dead, for you know the poor _madre_ died; and I shall never forget
16651: the Carnival I saw once; it was so pretty—all roses and a king and
16652: queen under them—and singing. I liked it better than the San Giovanni.”
16653: 
16654: “But there’s nothing like that now, my Tessa. They are going to make a
16655: bonfire in the Piazza—that’s all. But I cannot let you go out by
16656: yourself in the evening.”
16657: 
16658: “Oh no, no! I don’t want to go in the evening. I only want to go and
16659: see the procession by daylight. There _will_ be a procession—is it not
16660: true?”
16661: 
16662: “Yes, after a sort,” said Tito, “as lively as a flight of cranes. You
16663: must not expect roses and glittering kings and queens, my Tessa.
16664: However, I suppose any string of people to be called a procession will
16665: please your blue eyes. And there’s a thing they have raised in the
16666: Piazza de’ Signori for the bonfire. You may like to see that. But come
16667: home early, and look like a grave little old woman; and if you see any
16668: men with feathers and swords, keep out of their way: they are very
16669: fierce, and like to cut old women’s heads off.”
16670: 
16671: “Santa Madonna! where do they come from? Ah! you are laughing; it is
16672: not so bad. But I will keep away from them. Only,” Tessa went on in a
16673: whisper, putting her lips near Naldo’s ear, “if I might take Lillo with
16674: me! He is very sensible.”
16675: 
16676: “But who will thump Monna Lisa then, if she doesn’t hear?” said Tito,
16677: finding it difficult not to laugh, but thinking it necessary to look
16678: serious. “No, Tessa, you could not take care of Lillo if you got into a
16679: crowd, and he’s too heavy for you to carry him.”
16680: 
16681: “It is true,” said Tessa, rather sadly, “and he likes to run away. I
16682: forgot that. Then I will go alone. But now look at Ninna—you have not
16683: looked at her enough.”
16684: 
16685: Ninna was a blue-eyed thing, at the tottering, tumbling age—a fair
16686: solid, which, like a loaded die, found its base with a constancy that
16687: warranted prediction. Tessa went to snatch her up, and when Babbo was
16688: paying due attention to the recent teeth and other marvels, she said,
16689: in a whisper, “And shall I buy some confetti for the children?”
16690: 
16691: Tito drew some small coins from his scarsella, and poured them into her
16692: palm.
16693: 
16694: “That will buy no end,” said Tessa, delighted at this abundance. “I
16695: shall not mind going without Lillo so much, if I bring him something.”
16696: 
16697: So Tessa set out in the morning towards the great Piazza where the
16698: bonfire was to be. She did not think the February breeze cold enough to
16699: demand further covering than her green woollen dress. A mantle would
16700: have been oppressive, for it would have hidden a new necklace and a new
16701: clasp, mounted with silver, the only ornamental presents Tito had ever
16702: made her. Tessa did not think at all of showing her figure, for no one
16703: had ever told her it was pretty; but she was quite sure that her
16704: necklace and clasp were of the prettiest sort ever worn by the richest
16705: contadina, and she arranged her white hood over her head so that the
16706: front of her necklace might be well displayed. These ornaments, she
16707: considered, must inspire respect for her as the wife of some one who
16708: could afford to buy them.
16709: 
16710: She tripped along very cheerily in the February sunshine, thinking much
16711: of the purchases for the little ones, with which she was to fill her
16712: small basket, and not thinking at all of any one who might be observing
16713: her. Yet her descent from her upper storey into the street had been
16714: watched, and she was being kept in sight as she walked by a person who
16715: had often waited in vain to see if it were not Tessa who lived in that
16716: house to which he had more than once dogged Tito. Baldassarre was
16717: carrying a package of yarn: he was constantly employed in that way, as
16718: a means of earning his scanty bread, and keeping the sacred fire of
16719: vengeance alive; and he had come out of his way this morning, as he had
16720: often done before, that he might pass by the house to which he had
16721: followed Tito in the evening. His long imprisonment had so intensified
16722: his timid suspicion and his belief in some diabolic fortune favouring
16723: Tito, that he had not dared to pursue him, except under cover of a
16724: crowd or of the darkness; he felt, with instinctive horror, that if
16725: Tito’s eyes fell upon him, he should again be held up to obloquy, again
16726: be dragged away; his weapon would be taken from him, and he should be
16727: cast helpless into a prison-cell. His fierce purpose had become as
16728: stealthy as a serpent’s, which depends for its prey on one dart of the
16729: fang. Justice was weak and unfriended; and he could not hear again the
16730: voice that pealed the promise of vengeance in the Duomo; he had been
16731: there again and again, but that voice, too, had apparently been stifled
16732: by cunning strong-armed wickedness. For a long while, Baldassarre’s
16733: ruling thought was to ascertain whether Tito still wore the armour, for
16734: now at last his fainting hope would have been contented with a
16735: successful stab on this side the grave; but he would never risk his
16736: precious knife again. It was a weary time he had had to wait for the
16737: chance of answering this question by touching Tito’s back in the press
16738: of the street. Since then, the knowledge that the sharp steel was
16739: useless, and that he had no hope but in some new device, had fallen
16740: with leaden weight on his enfeebled mind. A dim vision of winning one
16741: of those two wives to aid him came before him continually, and
16742: continually slid away. The wife who had lived on the hill was no longer
16743: there. If he could find her again, he might grasp some thread of a
16744: project, and work his way to more clearness.
16745: 
16746: And this morning he had succeeded. He was quite certain now where this
16747: wife lived, and as he walked, bent a little under his burden of yarn,
16748: yet keeping the green and white figure in sight, his mind was dwelling
16749: upon her and her circumstances as feeble eyes dwell on lines and
16750: colours, trying to interpret them into consistent significance.
16751: 
16752: Tessa had to pass through various long streets without seeing any other
16753: sign of the Carnival than unusual groups of the country people in their
16754: best garments, and that disposition in everybody to chat and loiter
16755: which marks the early hours of a holiday, before the spectacle has
16756: begun. Presently, in her disappointed search for remarkable objects,
16757: her eyes fell on a man with a pedlar’s basket before him, who seemed to
16758: be selling nothing but little red crosses to all the passengers. A
16759: little red cross would be pretty to hang up over her bed; it would also
16760: help to keep off harm, and would perhaps make Ninna stronger. Tessa
16761: went to the other side of the street that she might ask the pedlar the
16762: price of the crosses, fearing that they would cost a little too much
16763: for her to spare from her purchase of sweets. The pedlar’s back had
16764: been turned towards her hitherto, but when she came near him she
16765: recognised an old acquaintance of the Mercato, Bratti Ferravecchi, and,
16766: accustomed to feel that she was to avoid old acquaintances, she turned
16767: away again and passed to the other side of the street. But Bratti’s eye
16768: was too well practised in looking out at the corner after possible
16769: customers, for her movement to have escaped him, and she was presently
16770: arrested by a tap on the arm from one of the red crosses.
16771: 
16772: “Young woman,” said Bratti, as she unwillingly turned her head, “you
16773: come from some castello a good way off, it seems to me, else you’d
16774: never think of walking about, this blessed Carnival, without a red
16775: cross in your hand. Santa Madonna! Four white quattrini is a small
16776: price to pay for your soul—prices rise in purgatory, let me tell you.”
16777: 
16778: “Oh, I should like one,” said Tessa, hastily, “but I couldn’t spare
16779: four white quattrini.”
16780: 
16781: Bratti had at first regarded Tessa too abstractedly as a mere customer
16782: to look at her with any scrutiny, but when she began to speak he
16783: exclaimed, “By the head of San Giovanni, it must be the little Tessa,
16784: and looking as fresh as a ripe apple! What! you’ve done none the worse,
16785: then, for running away from father Nofri? You were in the right of it,
16786: for he goes on crutches now, and a crabbed fellow with crutches is
16787: dangerous; he can reach across the house and beat a woman as he sits.”
16788: 
16789: “I’m married,” said Tessa, rather demurely, remembering Naldo’s command
16790: that she should behave with gravity; “and my husband takes great care
16791: of me.”
16792: 
16793: “Ah, then, you’ve fallen on your feet! Nofri said you were
16794: good-for-nothing vermin; but what then? An ass may bray a good while
16795: before he shakes the stars down. I always said you did well to run
16796: away, and it isn’t often Bratti’s in the wrong. Well, and so you’ve got
16797: a husband and plenty of money? Then you’ll never think much of giving
16798: four white quattrini for a red cross. I get no profit; but what with
16799: the famine and the new religion, all other merchandise is gone down.
16800: You live in the country where the chestnuts are plenty, eh? You’ve
16801: never wanted for polenta, I can see.”
16802: 
16803: “No, I’ve never wanted anything,” said Tessa, still on her guard.
16804: 
16805: “Then you can afford to buy a cross. I got a Padre to bless them, and
16806: you get blessing and all for four quattrini. It isn’t for the profit; I
16807: hardly get a danaro by the whole lot. But then they’re holy wares, and
16808: it’s getting harder and harder work to see your way to Paradise: the
16809: very Carnival is like Holy Week, and the least you can do to keep the
