16810: Devil from getting the upper hand is to buy a cross. God guard you!
16811: think what the Devil’s tooth is! You’ve seen him biting the man in San
16812: Giovanni, I should hope?”
16813: 
16814: Tessa felt much teased and frightened. “Oh, Bratti,” she said, with a
16815: discomposed face, “I want to buy a great many confetti: I’ve got little
16816: Lillo and Ninna at home. And nice coloured sweet things cost a great
16817: deal. And they will not like the cross so well, though I know it would
16818: be good to have it.”
16819: 
16820: “Come, then,” said Bratti, fond of laying up a store of merits by
16821: imagining possible extortions and then heroically renouncing them,
16822: “since you’re an old acquaintance, you shall have it for two quattrini.
16823: It’s making you a present of the cross, to say nothing of the
16824: blessing.”
16825: 
16826: Tessa was reaching out her two quattrini with trembling hesitation,
16827: when Bratti said abruptly, “Stop a bit! Where do you live?”
16828: 
16829: “Oh, a long way off,” she answered, almost automatically, being
16830: preoccupied with her quattrini; “beyond San Ambrogio, in the Via
16831: Piccola, at the top of the house where the wood is stacked below.”
16832: 
16833: “Very good,” said Bratti, in a patronising tone; “then I’ll let you
16834: have the cross on trust, and call for the money. So you live inside the
16835: gates? Well, well, I shall be passing.”
16836: 
16837: “No, no!” said Tessa, frightened lest Naldo should be angry at this
16838: revival of an old acquaintance. “I can spare the money. Take it now.”
16839: 
16840: “No,” said Bratti, resolutely; “I’m not a hard-hearted pedlar. I’ll
16841: call and see if you’ve got any rags, and you shall make a bargain. See,
16842: here’s the cross: and there’s Pippo’s shop not far behind you: you can
16843: go and fill your basket, and I must go and get mine empty. _Addio,
16844: piccina_.”
16845: 
16846: Bratti went on his way, and Tessa, stimulated to change her money into
16847: confetti before further accident, went into Pippo’s shop, a little
16848: fluttered by the thought that she had let Bratti know more about her
16849: than her husband would approve. There were certainly more dangers in
16850: coming to see the Carnival than in staying at home; and she would have
16851: felt this more strongly if she had known that the wicked old man, who
16852: had wanted to kill her husband on the hill, was still keeping her in
16853: sight. But she had not noticed the man with the burden on his back.
16854: 
16855: The consciousness of having a small basketful of things to make the
16856: children glad dispersed her anxiety, and as she entered the Via de’
16857: Libraj her face had its visual expression of childlike content. And now
16858: she thought there was really a procession coming, for she saw white
16859: robes and a banner, and her heart began to palpitate with expectation.
16860: She stood a little aside, but in that narrow street there was the
16861: pleasure of being obliged to look very close. The banner was pretty: it
16862: was the Holy Mother with the Babe, whose love for her Tessa had
16863: believed in more and more since she had had her babies; and the figures
16864: in white had not only green wreaths on their heads, but little red
16865: crosses by their side, which caused her some satisfaction that she also
16866: had her red cross. Certainly, they looked as beautiful as the angels on
16867: the clouds, and to Tessa’s mind they too had a background of cloud,
16868: like everything else that came to her in life. How and whence did they
16869: come? She did not mind much about knowing. But one thing surprised her
16870: as newer than wreaths and crosses; it was that some of the white
16871: figures carried baskets between them. What could the baskets be for?
16872: 
16873: But now they were very near, and, to her astonishment, they wheeled
16874: aside and came straight up to her. She trembled as she would have done
16875: if Saint Michael in the picture had shaken his head at her, and was
16876: conscious of nothing but terrified wonder till she saw close to her a
16877: round boyish face, lower than her own, and heard a treble voice saying,
16878: “Sister, you carry the Anathema about you. Yield it up to the blessed
16879: Gesu, and He will adorn you with the gems of His grace.”
16880: 
16881: Tessa was only more frightened, understanding nothing. Her first
16882: conjecture settled on her basket of sweets. They wanted that, these
16883: alarming angels. Oh dear, dear! She looked down at it.
16884: 
16885: “No, sister,” said a taller youth, pointing to her necklace and the
16886: clasp of her belt, “it is those vanities that are the Anathema. Take
16887: off that necklace and unclasp that belt, that they may be burned in the
16888: holy Bonfire of Vanities, and save _you_ from burning.”
16889: 
16890: “It is the truth, my sister,” said a still taller youth, evidently the
16891: archangel of this band. “Listen to these voices speaking the divine
16892: message. You already carry a red cross: let that be your only
16893: adornment. Yield up your necklace and belt, and you shall obtain
16894: grace.”
16895: 
16896: This was too much. Tessa, overcome with awe, dared not say “no,” but
16897: she was equally unable to render up her beloved necklace and clasp. Her
16898: pouting lips were quivering, the tears rushed to her eyes, and a great
16899: drop fell. For a moment she ceased to see anything; she felt nothing
16900: but confused terror and misery. Suddenly a gentle hand was laid on her
16901: arm, and a soft, wonderful voice, as if the Holy Madonna were speaking,
16902: said, “Do not be afraid; no one shall harm you.”
16903: 
16904: Tessa looked up and saw a lady in black, with a young heavenly face and
16905: loving hazel eyes. She had never seen any one like this lady before,
16906: and under other circumstances might have had awestruck thoughts about
16907: her; but now everything else was overcome by the sense that loving
16908: protection was near her. The tears only fell the faster, relieving her
16909: swelling heart, as she looked up at the heavenly face, and, putting her
16910: hand to her necklace, said sobbingly—
16911: 
16912: “I can’t give them to be burnt. My husband—he bought them for me—and
16913: they are so pretty—and Ninna—oh, I wish I’d never come!”
16914: 
16915: “Do not ask her for them,” said Romola, speaking to the white-robed
16916: boys in a tone of mild authority. “It answers no good end for people to
16917: give up such things against their will. That is not what Fra Girolamo
16918: approves: he would have such things given up freely.”
16919: 
16920: Madonna Romola’s word was not to be resisted, and the white train moved
16921: on. They even moved with haste, as if some new object had caught their
16922: eyes; and Tessa felt with bliss that they were gone, and that her
16923: necklace and clasp were still with her.
16924: 
16925: “Oh, I will go back to the house,” she said, still agitated; “I will go
16926: nowhere else. But if I should meet them again, and you not be there?”
16927: she added, expecting everything from this heavenly lady.
16928: 
16929: “Stay a little,” said Romola. “Come with me under this doorway, and we
16930: will hide the necklace and clasp, and then you will be in no danger.”
16931: 
16932: She led Tessa under the archway, and said, “Now, can we find room for
16933: your necklace and belt in your basket? Ah! your basket is full of crisp
16934: things that will break: let us be careful, and lay the heavy necklace
16935: under them.”
16936: 
16937: It was like a change in a dream to Tessa—the escape from nightmare into
16938: floating safety and joy—to find herself taken care of by this lady, so
16939: lovely, and powerful, and gentle. She let Romola unfasten her necklace
16940: and clasp, while she herself did nothing but look up at the face that
16941: bent over her.
16942: 
16943: “They are sweets for Lillo and Ninna,” she said, as Romola carefully
16944: lifted up the light parcels in the basket, and placed the ornaments
16945: below them.
16946: 
16947: “Those are your children?” said Romola, smiling. “And you would rather
16948: go home to them than see any more of the Carnival? Else you have not
16949: far to go to the Piazza de’ Signori, and there you would see the pile
16950: for the great bonfire.”
16951: 
16952: “No, oh no!” said Tessa, eagerly; “I shall never like bonfires again. I
16953: will go back.”
16954: 
16955: “You live at some castello, doubtless,” said Romola, not waiting for an
16956: answer. “Towards which gate do you go?”
16957: 
16958: “Towards Por’ Santa Croce.”
16959: 
16960: “Come, then,” said Romola, taking her by the hand and leading her to
16961: the corner of a street nearly opposite. “If you go down there,” she
16962: said, pausing, “you will soon be in a straight road. And I must leave
16963: you now, because some one else expects me. You will not be frightened.
16964: Your pretty things are quite safe now. Addio.”
16965: 
16966: “Addio, Madonna,” said Tessa, almost in a whisper, not knowing what
16967: else it would be right to say; and in an instant the heavenly lady was
16968: gone. Tessa turned to catch a last glimpse, but she only saw the tall
16969: gliding figure vanish round the projecting stonework. So she went on
16970: her way in wonder, longing to be once more safely housed with Monna
16971: Lisa, undesirous of carnivals for evermore.
16972: 
16973: Baldassarre had kept Tessa in sight till the moment of her parting with
16974: Romola: then he went away with his bundle of yarn. It seemed to him
16975: that he had discerned a clue which might guide him if he could only
16976: grasp the necessary details firmly enough. He had seen the two wives
16977: together, and the sight had brought to his conceptions that vividness
16978: which had been wanting before. His power of imagining facts needed to
16979: be reinforced continually by the senses. The tall wife was the noble
16980: and rightful wife; she had the blood in her that would be readily
16981: kindled to resentment; she would know what scholarship was, and how it
16982: might lie locked in by the obstructions of the stricken body, like a
16983: treasure buried by earthquake. She could believe him: she would be
16984: _inclined_ to believe him, if he proved to her that her husband was
16985: unfaithful. Women cared about that: they would take vengeance for that.
16986: If this wife of Tito’s loved him, she would have a sense of injury
16987: which Baldassarre’s mind dwelt on with keen longing, as if it would be
16988: the strength of another Will added to his own, the strength of another
16989: mind to form devices.
16990: 
16991: Both these wives had been kind to Baldassarre, and their acts towards
16992: him, being bound up with the very image of them, had not vanished from
16993: his memory; yet the thought of their pain could not present itself to
16994: him as a check. To him it seemed that pain was the order of the world
16995: for all except the hard and base. If any were innocent, if any were
16996: noble, where could the utmost gladness lie for them? Where it lay for
16997: him—in unconquerable hatred and triumphant vengeance. But he must be
16998: cautious: he must watch this wife in the Via de’ Bardi, and learn more
16999: of her; for even here frustration was possible. There was no power for
17000: him now but in patience.
17001: 
17002: 
17003: 
17004: 
17005: CHAPTER LI.
17006: Monna Brigida’s Conversion.
17007: 
17008: 
17009: When Romola said that some one else expected her, she meant her cousin
17010: Brigida, but she was far from suspecting how much that good kinswoman
17011: was in need of her. Returning together towards the Piazza, they had
17012: descried the company of youths coming to a stand before Tessa, and when
17013: Romola, having approached near enough to see the simple little
17014: contadina’s distress, said, “Wait for me a moment, cousin,” Monna
17015: Brigida said hastily, “Ah, I will not go on: come for me to Boni’s
17016: shop,—I shall go back there.”
17017: 
17018: The truth was, Monna Brigida had a consciousness on the one hand of
17019: certain “vanities” carried on her person, and on the other of a growing
17020: alarm lest the Piagnoni should be right in holding that rouge, and
17021: false hair, and pearl embroidery, endamaged the soul. Their serious
17022: view of things filled the air like an odour; nothing seemed to have
17023: exactly the same flavour as it used to have; and there was the dear
17024: child Romola, in her youth and beauty, leading a life that was
17025: uncomfortably suggestive of rigorous demands on woman. A widow at
17026: fifty-five whose satisfaction has been largely drawn from what she
17027: thinks of her own person, and what she believes others think of it,
17028: requires a great fund of imagination to keep her spirits buoyant. And
17029: Monna Brigida had begun to have frequent struggles at her toilet. If
17030: her soul would prosper better without them, was it really worth while
17031: to put on the rouge and the braids? But when she lifted up the
17032: hand-mirror and saw a sallow face with baggy cheeks, and crows’-feet
17033: that were not to be dissimulated by any simpering of the lips—when she
17034: parted her grey hair, and let it lie in simple Piagnone fashion round
17035: her face, her courage failed. Monna Berta would certainly burst out
17036: laughing at her, and call her an old hag, and as Monna Berta was really
17037: only fifty-two, she had a superiority which would make the observation
17038: cutting. Every woman who was not a Piagnone would give a shrug at the
17039: sight of her, and the men would accost her as if she were their
17040: grandmother. Whereas, at fifty-five a woman was not so very old—she
17041: only required making up a little. So the rouge and the braids and the
17042: embroidered berretta went on again, and Monna Brigida was satisfied
17043: with the accustomed effect; as for her neck, if she covered it up,
17044: people might suppose it was too old to show, and, on the contrary, with
17045: the necklaces round it, it looked better than Monna Berta’s. This very
17046: day, when she was preparing for the Piagnone Carnival, such a struggle
17047: had occurred, and the conflicting fears and longings which caused the
17048: struggle, caused her to turn back and seek refuge in the druggist’s
17049: shop rather than encounter the collectors of the Anathema when Romola
17050: was not by her side. But Monna Brigida was not quite rapid enough in
17051: her retreat. She had been descried, even before she turned away, by the
17052: white-robed boys in the rear of those who wheeled round towards Tessa,
17053: and the willingness with which Tessa was given up was, perhaps,
17054: slightly due to the fact that part of the troop had already accosted a
17055: personage carrying more markedly upon her the dangerous weight of the
17056: Anathema. It happened that several of this troop were at the youngest
17057: age taken into peculiar training; and a small fellow of ten, his olive
17058: wreath resting above cherubic cheeks and wide brown eyes, his
17059: imagination really possessed with a hovering awe at existence as
17060: something in which great consequences impended on being good or bad,
17061: his longings nevertheless running in the direction of mastery and
17062: mischief, was the first to reach Monna Brigida and place himself across
17063: her path. She felt angry, and looked for an open door, but there was
17064: not one at hand, and by attempting to escape now, she would only make
17065: things worse. But it was not the cherubic-faced young one who first
17066: addressed her; it was a youth of fifteen, who held one handle of a wide
17067: basket.
17068: 
17069: “Venerable mother!” he began, “the blessed Jesus commands you to give
17070: up the Anathema which you carry upon you. That cap embroidered with
17071: pearls, those jewels that fasten up your false hair—let them be given
17072: up and sold for the poor; and cast the hair itself away from you, as a
17073: lie that is only fit for burning. Doubtless, too, you have other jewels
17074: under your silk mantle.”
17075: 
17076: “Yes, lady,” said the youth at the other handle, who had many of Fra
17077: Girolamo’s phrases by heart, “they are too heavy for you: they are
17078: heavier than a millstone, and are weighting you for perdition. Will you
17079: adorn yourself with the hunger of the poor, and be proud to carry God’s
17080: curse upon your head?”
17081: 
17082: “In truth you are old, buona madre,” said the cherubic boy, in a sweet
17083: soprano. “You look very ugly with the red on your cheeks and that black
17084: glistening hair, and those fine things. It is only Satan who can like
17085: to see you. Your Angel is sorry. He wants you to rub away the red.”
17086: 
17087: The little fellow snatched a soft silk scarf from the basket, and held
17088: it towards Monna Brigida, that she might use it as her guardian angel
17089: desired. Her anger and mortification were fast giving way to spiritual
17090: alarm. Monna Berta and that cloud of witnesses, highly-dressed society
17091: in general, were not looking at her, and she was surrounded by young
17092: monitors, whose white robes, and wreaths, and red crosses, and dreadful
17093: candour, had something awful in their unusualness. Her Franciscan
17094: confessor, Fra Cristoforo, of Santa Croce, was not at hand to reinforce
17095: her distrust of Dominican teaching, and she was helplessly possessed
17096: and shaken by a vague sense that a supreme warning was come to her.
17097: Unvisited by the least suggestion of any other course that was open to
17098: her, she took the scarf that was held out, and rubbed her cheeks, with
17099: trembling submissiveness.
17100: 
17101: “It is well, madonna,” said the second youth. “It is a holy beginning.
17102: And when you have taken those vanities from your head, the dew of
17103: heavenly grace will descend on it.” The infusion of mischief was
17104: getting stronger, and putting his hand to one of the jewelled pins that
17105: fastened her braids to the berretta, he drew it out. The heavy black
17106: plait fell down over Monna Brigida’s face, and dragged the rest of the
17107: head-gear forward. It was a new reason for not hesitating: she put up
17108: her hands hastily, undid the other fastenings, and flung down into the
17109: basket of doom her beloved crimson-velvet berretta, with all its
17110: unsurpassed embroidery of seed-pearls, and stood an unrouged woman,
17111: with grey hair pushed backward from a face where certain deep lines of
17112: age had triumphed over _embonpoint_.
17113: 
17114: But the berretta was not allowed to lie in the basket. With impish zeal
17115: the youngsters lifted it, and held it up pitilessly, with the false
17116: hair dangling.
17117: 
17118: “See, venerable mother,” said the taller youth, “what ugly lies you
17119: have delivered yourself from! And now you look like the blessed Saint
17120: Anna, the mother of the Holy Virgin.”
17121: 
17122: Thoughts of going into a convent forthwith, and never showing herself
17123: in the world again, were rushing through Monna Brigida’s mind. There
17124: was nothing possible for her but to take care of her soul.
17125: 
17126: Of course, there were spectators laughing: she had no need to look
17127: round to assure herself of that. Well! it would, perhaps, be better to
17128: be forced to think more of Paradise. But at the thought that the dear
17129: accustomed world was no longer in her choice, there gathered some of
17130: those hard tears which just moisten elderly eyes, and she could see but
17131: dimly a large rough hand holding a red cross, which was suddenly thrust
17132: before her over the shoulders of the boys, while a strong guttural
17133: voice said—
17134: 
17135: “Only four quattrini, madonna, blessing and all! Buy it. You’ll find a
17136: comfort in it now your wig’s gone. Deh! what are we sinners doing all
17137: our lives? Making soup in a basket, and getting nothing but the scum
17138: for our stomachs. Better buy a blessing, madonna! Only four quattrini;
17139: the profit is not so much as the smell of a danaro, and it goes to the
17140: poor.”
17141: 
17142: Monna Brigida, in dim-eyed confusion, was proceeding to the further
17143: submission of reaching money from her embroidered scarsella, at present
17144: hidden by her silk mantle, when the group round her, which she had not
17145: yet entertained the idea of escaping, opened before a figure as welcome
17146: as an angel loosing prison-bolts.
17147: 
17148: “Romola, look at me!” said Monna Brigida, in a piteous tone, putting
17149: out both her hands.
17150: 
17151: The white troop was already moving away, with a slight consciousness
17152: that its zeal about the head-gear had been superabundant enough to
17153: afford a dispensation from any further demand for penitential
17154: offerings.
17155: 
17156: “Dear cousin, don’t be distressed,” said Romola, smitten with pity, yet
17157: hardly able to help smiling at the sudden apparition of her kinswoman
17158: in a genuine, natural guise, strangely contrasted with all memories of
17159: her. She took the black drapery from her own head, and threw it over
17160: Monna Brigida’s. “There,” she went on soothingly, “no one will remark
17161: you now. We will turn down the Via del Palagio and go straight to our
17162: house.”
17163: 
17164: They hastened away, Monna Brigida grasping Romola’s hand tightly, as if
17165: to get a stronger assurance of her being actually there.
17166: 
17167: “Ah, my Romola, my dear child!” said the short fat woman, hurrying with
17168: frequent steps to keep pace with the majestic young figure beside her;
17169: “what an old scarecrow I am! I must be good—I mean to be good!”
17170: 
17171: “Yes, yes; buy a cross!” said the guttural voice, while the rough hand
17172: was thrust once more before Monna Brigida: for Bratti was not to be
17173: abashed by Romola’s presence into renouncing a probable customer, and
17174: had quietly followed up their retreat. “Only four quattrini, blessing
17175: and all—and if there was any profit, it would all go to the poor.”
17176: 
17177: Monna Brigida would have been compelled to pause, even if she had been
17178: in a less submissive mood. She put up one hand deprecatingly to arrest
17179: Romola’s remonstrance, and with the other reached out a grosso, worth
17180: many white quattrini, saying, in an entreating tone—
17181: 
17182: “Take it, good man, and begone.”
17183: 
17184: “You’re in the right, madonna,” said Bratti, taking the coin quickly,
17185: and thrusting the cross into her hand; “I’ll not offer you change, for
17186: I might as well rob you of a mass. What! we must all be scorched a
17187: little, but you’ll come off the easier; better fall from the window
17188: than the roof. A good Easter and a good year to you!”
17189: 
17190: “Well, Romola,” cried Monna Brigida, pathetically, as Bratti left them,
17191: “if I’m to be a Piagnone it’s no matter how I look!”
17192: 
17193: “Dear cousin,” said Romola, smiling at her affectionately, “you don’t
17194: know how much better you look than you ever did before. I see now how
17195: good-natured your face is, like yourself. That red and finery seemed to
17196: thrust themselves forward and hide expression. Ask our Piero or any
17197: other painter if he would not rather paint your portrait now than
17198: before. I think all lines of the human face have something either
17199: touching or grand, unless they seem to come from low passions. How fine
17200: old men are, like my godfather! Why should not old women look grand and
17201: simple?”
17202: 
17203: “Yes, when one gets to be sixty, my Romola,” said Brigida, relapsing a
17204: little; “but I’m only fifty-five, and Monna Berta, and everybody—but
17205: it’s no use: I will be good, like you. Your mother, if she’d been
17206: alive, would have been as old as I am; we were cousins together. One
17207: _must_ either die or get old. But it doesn’t matter about being old, if
17208: one’s a Piagnone.”
17209: 
17210: 
17211: 
17212: 
17213: CHAPTER LII.
17214: A Prophetess.
17215: 
17216: 
17217: The incidents of that Carnival day seemed to Romola to carry no other
17218: personal consequences to her than the new care of supporting poor
17219: cousin Brigida in her fluctuating resignation to age and grey hairs;
17220: but they introduced a Lenten time in which she was kept at a high pitch
17221: of mental excitement and active effort.
17222: 
17223: Bernardo del Nero had been elected Gonfaloniere. By great exertions the
17224: Medicean party had so far triumphed, and that triumph had deepened
17225: Romola’s presentiment of some secretly-prepared scheme likely to ripen
17226: either into success or betrayal during these two months of her
17227: godfather’s authority. Every morning the dim daybreak as it peered into
17228: her room seemed to be that haunting fear coming back to her. Every
17229: morning the fear went with her as she passed through the streets on her
17230: way to the early sermon in the Duomo: but there she gradually lost the
17231: sense of its chill presence, as men lose the dread of death in the
17232: clash of battle.
17233: 
17234: In the Duomo she felt herself sharing in a passionate conflict which
17235: had wider relations than any enclosed within the walls of Florence. For
17236: Savonarola was preaching—preaching the last course of Lenten sermons he
17237: was ever allowed to finish in the Duomo: he knew that excommunication
17238: was imminent, and he had reached the point of defying it. He held up
17239: the condition of the Church in the terrible mirror of his unflinching
17240: speech, which called things by their right names and dealt in no polite
17241: periphrases; he proclaimed with heightening confidence the advent of
17242: renovation—of a moment when there would be a general revolt against
17243: corruption. As to his own destiny, he seemed to have a double and
17244: alternating prevision: sometimes he saw himself taking a glorious part
17245: in that revolt, sending forth a voice that would be heard through all
17246: Christendom, and making the dead body of the Church tremble into new
17247: life, as the body of Lazarus trembled when the Divine voice pierced the
17248: sepulchre; sometimes he saw no prospect for himself but persecution and
17249: martyrdom:—this life for him was only a vigil, and only after death
17250: would come the dawn.
17251: 
17252: The position was one which must have had its impressiveness for all
17253: minds that were not of the dullest order, even if they were inclined,
17254: as Macchiavelli was, to interpret the Frate’s character by a key that
17255: presupposed no loftiness. To Romola, whose kindred ardour gave her a
17256: firm belief in Savonarola’s genuine greatness of purpose, the crisis
17257: was as stirring as if it had been part of her personal lot. It blent
17258: itself as an exalting memory with all her daily labours; and those
17259: labours were calling not only for difficult perseverance, but for new
17260: courage. Famine had never yet taken its flight from Florence, and all
17261: distress, by its long continuance, was getting harder to bear; disease
17262: was spreading in the crowded city, and the Plague was expected. As
17263: Romola walked, often in weariness, among the sick, the hungry, and the
17264: murmuring, she felt it good to be inspired by something more than her
17265: pity—by the belief in a heroism struggling for sublime ends, towards
17266: which the daily action of her pity could only tend feebly, as the dews
17267: that freshen the weedy ground to-day tend to prepare an unseen harvest
17268: in the years to come.
17269: 
17270: But that mighty music which stirred her in the Duomo was not without
17271: its jarring notes. Since those first days of glowing hope when the
17272: Frate, seeing the near triumph of good in the reform of the Republic
17273: and the coming of the French deliverer, had preached peace, charity,
17274: and oblivion of political differences, there had been a marked change
17275: of conditions: political intrigue had been too obstinate to allow of
17276: the desired oblivion; the belief in the French deliverer, who had
17277: turned his back on his high mission, seemed to have wrought harm; and
17278: hostility, both on a petty and on a grand scale, was attacking the
17279: Prophet with new weapons and new determination.
17280: 
17281: It followed that the spirit of contention and self-vindication pierced
17282: more and more conspicuously in his sermons; that he was urged to meet
17283: the popular demands not only by increased insistence and detail
17284: concerning visions and private revelations, but by a tone of defiant
17285: confidence against objectors; and from having denounced the desire for
17286: the miraculous, and declared that miracles had no relation to true
17287: faith, he had come to assert that at the right moment the Divine power
17288: would attest the truth of his prophetic preaching by a miracle. And
17289: continually, in the rapid transitions of excited feeling, as the vision
17290: of triumphant good receded behind the actual predominance of evil, the
17291: threats of coming vengeance against vicious tyrants and corrupt priests
17292: gathered some impetus from personal exasperation, as well as from
17293: indignant zeal.
17294: 
17295: In the career of a great public orator who yields himself to the
17296: inspiration of the moment, that conflict of selfish and unselfish
17297: emotion which in most men is hidden in the chamber of the soul, is
17298: brought into terrible evidence: the language of the inner voices is
17299: written out in letters of fire.
17300: 
17301: But if the tones of exasperation jarred on Romola, there was often
17302: another member of Fra Girolamo’s audience to whom they were the only
17303: thrilling tones, like the vibration of deep bass notes to the deaf.
17304: Baldassarre had found out that the wonderful Frate was preaching again,
17305: and as often as he could, he went to hear the Lenten sermon, that he
17306: might drink in the threats of a voice which seemed like a power on the
17307: side of justice. He went the more because he had seen that Romola went
17308: too; for he was waiting and watching for a time when not only outward
17309: circumstances, but his own varying mental state, would mark the right
17310: moment for seeking an interview with her. Twice Romola had caught sight
17311: of his face in the Duomo—once when its dark glance was fixed on hers.
17312: She wished not to see it again, and yet she looked for it, as men look
17313: for the reappearance of a portent. But any revelation that might be yet
17314: to come about this old man was a subordinate fear now: it referred, she
17315: thought, only to the past, and her anxiety was almost absorbed by the
17316: present.
17317: 
17318: Yet the stirring Lent passed by; April, the second and final month of
17319: her godfather’s supreme authority, was near its close; and nothing had
17320: occurred to fulfil her presentiment. In the public mind, too, there had
17321: been fears, and rumours had spread from Rome of a menacing activity on
17322: the part of Piero de’ Medici; but in a few days the suspected Bernardo
17323: would go out of power.
17324: 
17325: Romola was trying to gather some courage from the review of her futile
17326: fears, when on the twenty-seventh, as she was walking out on her usual
17327: errands of mercy in the afternoon, she was met by a messenger from
17328: Camilla Rucellai, chief among the feminine seers of Florence, desiring
17329: her presence forthwith on matters of the highest moment. Romola, who
17330: shrank with unconquerable repulsion from the shrill volubility of those
17331: illuminated women, and had just now a special repugnance towards
17332: Camilla because of a report that she had announced revelations hostile
17333: to Bernardo del Nero, was at first inclined to send back a flat
17334: refusal. Camilla’s message might refer to public affairs, and Romola’s
17335: immediate prompting was to close her ears against knowledge that might
17336: only make her mental burden heavier. But it had become so thoroughly
17337: her habit to reject her impulsive choice, and to obey passively the
17338: guidance of outward claims, that, reproving herself for allowing her
17339: presentiments to make her cowardly and selfish, she ended by
17340: compliance, and went straight to Camilla.
17341: 
17342: She found the nervous grey-haired woman in a chamber arranged as much
17343: as possible like a convent cell. The thin fingers clutching Romola as
17344: she sat, and the eager voice addressing her at first in a loud whisper,
17345: caused her a physical shrinking that made it difficult for her to keep
17346: her seat.
17347: 
17348: Camilla had a vision to communicate—a vision in which it had been
17349: revealed to her by Romola’s Angel, that Romola knew certain secrets
17350: concerning her godfather, Bernardo del Nero, which, if disclosed, might
17351: save the Republic from peril. Camilla’s voice rose louder and higher as
17352: she narrated her vision, and ended by exhorting Romola to obey the
17353: command of her Angel, and separate herself from the enemy of God.
17354: 
17355: Romola’s impetuosity was that of a massive nature, and, except in
17356: moments when she was deeply stirred, her manner was calm and
17357: self-controlled. She had a constitutional disgust for the shallow
17358: excitability of women like Camilla, whose faculties seemed all wrought
17359: up into fantasies, leaving nothing for emotion and thought. The
17360: exhortation was not yet ended when she started up and attempted to
17361: wrench her arm from Camilla’s tightening grasp. It was of no use. The
17362: prophetess kept her hold like a crab, and, only incited to more eager
17363: exhortation by Romola’s resistance, was carried beyond her own
17364: intention into a shrill statement of other visions which were to
17365: corroborate this. Christ himself had appeared to her and ordered her to
17366: send his commands to certain citizens in office that they should throw
17367: Bernardo del Nero from the window of the Palazzo Vecchio. Fra Girolamo
17368: himself knew of it, and had not dared this time to say that the vision
17369: was not of Divine authority.
17370: 
17371: “And since then,” said Camilla, in her excited treble, straining upward
17372: with wild eyes towards Romola’s face, “the Blessed Infant has come to
17373: me and laid a wafer of sweetness on my tongue in token of his pleasure
17374: that I had done his will.”
17375: 
17376: “Let me go!” said Romola, in a deep voice of anger. “God grant you are
17377: mad! else you are detestably wicked!”
17378: 
17379: The violence of her effort to be free was too strong for Camilla now.
17380: She wrenched away her arm and rushed out of the room, not pausing till
17381: she had hurriedly gone far along the street, and found herself close to
17382: the church of the Badia. She had but to pass behind the curtain under
17383: the old stone arch, and she would find a sanctuary shut in from the
17384: noise and hurry of the street, where all objects and all uses suggested
17385: the thought of an eternal peace subsisting in the midst of turmoil.
17386: 
17387: She turned in, and sinking down on the step of the altar in front of
17388: Filippino Lippi’s serene Virgin appearing to Saint Bernard, she waited
17389: in hope that the inward tumult which agitated her would by-and-by
17390: subside.
17391: 
17392: The thought which pressed on her the most acutely was that Camilla
17393: could allege Savonarola’s countenance of her wicked folly. Romola did
17394: not for a moment believe that he had sanctioned the throwing of
17395: Bernardo del Nero from the window as a Divine suggestion; she felt
17396: certain that there was falsehood or mistake in that allegation.
17397: Savonarola had become more and more severe in his views of resistance
17398: to malcontents; but the ideas of strict law and order were fundamental
17399: to all his political teaching. Still, since he knew the possibly fatal
17400: effects of visions like Camilla’s, since he had a marked distrust of
17401: such spirit-seeing women, and kept aloof from them as much as possible,
17402: why, with his readiness to denounce wrong from the pulpit, did he not
17403: publicly denounce these pretended revelations which brought new
17404: darkness instead of light across the conception of a Supreme Will? Why?
17405: The answer came with painful clearness: he was fettered inwardly by the
17406: consciousness that such revelations were not, in their basis,
17407: distinctly separable from his own visions; he was fettered outwardly by
17408: the foreseen consequence of raising a cry against himself even among
17409: members of his own party, as one who would suppress all Divine
17410: inspiration of which he himself was not the vehicle—he or his
17411: confidential and supplementary seer of visions, Fra Salvestro.
17412: 
17413: Romola, kneeling with buried face on the altar-step, was enduring one
17414: of those sickening moments, when the enthusiasm which had come to her
17415: as the only energy strong enough to make life worthy, seemed to be
17416: inevitably bound up with vain dreams and wilful eye-shutting. Her mind
17417: rushed back with a new attraction towards the strong worldly sense, the
17418: dignified prudence, the untheoretic virtues of her godfather, who was
17419: to be treated as a sort of Agag because he held that a more restricted
17420: form of government was better than the Great Council, and because he
17421: would not pretend to forget old ties to the banished family.
17422: 
17423: But with this last thought rose the presentiment of some plot to
17424: restore the Medici; and then again she felt that the popular party was
17425: half justified in its fierce suspicion. Again she felt that to keep the
17426: Government of Florence pure, and to keep out a vicious rule, was a
17427: sacred cause; the Frate was right there, and had carried her
17428: understanding irrevocably with him. But at this moment the assent of
17429: her understanding went alone; it was given unwillingly. Her heart was
17430: recoiling from a right allied to so much narrowness; a right apparently
17431: entailing that hard systematic judgment of men which measures them by
17432: assents and denials quite superficial to the manhood within them. Her
17433: affection and respect were clinging with new tenacity to her godfather,
17434: and with him to those memories of her father which were in the same
17435: opposition to the division of men into sheep and goats by the easy mark
17436: of some political or religious symbol.
17437: 
17438: After all has been said that can be said about the widening influence
17439: of ideas, it remains true that they would hardly be such strong agents
17440: unless they were taken in a solvent of feeling. The great
17441: world-struggle of developing thought is continually foreshadowed in the
17442: struggle of the affections, seeking a justification for love and hope.
17443: 
17444: If Romola’s intellect had been less capable of discerning the
17445: complexities in human things, all the early loving associations of her
17446: life would have forbidden her to accept implicitly the denunciatory
17447: exclusiveness of Savonarola. She had simply felt that his mind had
17448: suggested deeper and more efficacious truth to her than any other, and
17449: the large breathing-room she found in his grand view of human duties
17450: had made her patient towards that part of his teaching which she could
17451: not absorb, so long as its practical effect came into collision with no
17452: strong force in her. But now a sudden insurrection of feeling had
17453: brought about that collision. Her indignation, once roused by Camilla’s
17454: visions, could not pause there, but ran like an illuminating fire over
17455: all the kindred facts in Savonarola’s teaching, and for the moment she
17456: felt what was true in the scornful sarcasms she heard continually flung
17457: against him, more keenly than she felt what was false.
17458: 
17459: But it was an illumination that made all life look ghastly to her.
17460: Where were the beings to whom she could cling, with whom she could work
17461: and endure, with the belief that she was working for the right? On the
17462: side from which moral energy came lay a fanaticism from which she was
17463: shrinking with newly-startled repulsion; on the side to which she was
17464: drawn by affection and memory, there was the presentiment of some
17465: secret plotting, which her judgment told her would not be unfairly
17466: called crime. And still surmounting every other thought was the dread
17467: inspired by Tito’s hints, lest that presentiment should be converted
17468: into knowledge, in such a way that she would be torn by irreconcilable
17469: claims.
17470: 
17471: Calmness would not come even on the altar-steps; it would not come from
17472: looking at the serene picture where the saint, writing in the rocky
17473: solitude, was being visited by faces with celestial peace in them.
17474: Romola was in the hard press of human difficulties, and that rocky
17475: solitude was too far off. She rose from her knees that she might hasten
17476: to her sick people in the courtyard, and by some immediate beneficent
17477: action, revive that sense of worth in life which at this moment was
17478: unfed by any wider faith. But when she turned round, she found herself
17479: face to face with a man who was standing only two yards off her. The
17480: man was Baldassarre.
17481: 
17482: 
17483: 
17484: 
17485: CHAPTER LIII.
17486: On San Miniato.
17487: 
17488: 
17489: “I would speak with you,” said Baldassarre, as Romola looked at him in
17490: silent expectation. It was plain that he had followed her, and had been
17491: waiting for her. She was going at last to know the secret about him.
17492: 
17493: “Yes,” she said, with the same sort of submission that she might have
17494: shown under an imposed penance. “But you wish to go where no one can
17495: hear us?”
17496: 
17497: “Where _he_ will not come upon us,” said Baldassarre, turning and
17498: glancing behind him timidly. “Out—in the air—away from the streets.”
17499: 
17500: “I sometimes go to San Miniato at this hour,” said Romola. “If you
17501: like, I will go now, and you can follow me. It is far, but we can be
17502: solitary there.”
17503: 
17504: He nodded assent, and Romola set out. To some women it might have
17505: seemed an alarming risk to go to a comparatively solitary spot with a
17506: man who had some of the outward signs of that madness which Tito
17507: attributed to him. But Romola was not given to personal fears, and she
17508: was glad of the distance that interposed some delay before another blow
17509: fell on her. The afternoon was far advanced, and the sun was already
17510: low in the west, when she paused on some rough ground in the shadow of
17511: the cypress-trunks, and looked round for Baldassarre. He was not far
17512: off, but when he reached her, he was glad to sink down on an edge of
17513: stony earth. His thickset frame had no longer the sturdy vigour which
17514: belonged to it when he first appeared with the rope round him in the
17515: Duomo; and under the transient tremor caused by the exertion of walking
17516: up the hill, his eyes seemed to have a more helpless vagueness.
17517: 
17518: “The hill is steep,” said Romola, with compassionate gentleness,
17519: seating herself by him. “And I fear you have been weakened by want?”
17520: 
17521: He turned his head and fixed his eyes on her in silence, unable, now
17522: the moment of speech was come, to seize the words that would convey the
17523: thought he wanted to utter: and she remained as motionless as she
17524: could, lest he should suppose her impatient. He looked like nothing
17525: higher than a common-bred, neglected old man; but she was used now to
17526: be very near to such people, and to think a great deal about their
17527: troubles. Gradually his glance gathered a more definite expression, and
17528: at last he said with abrupt emphasis—
17529: 
17530: “Ah! you would have been my daughter!”
17531: 
17532: The swift flush came in Romola’s face and went back again as swiftly,
17533: leaving her with white lips a little apart, like a marble image of
17534: horror. For her mind, the revelation was made. She divined the facts
17535: that lay behind that single word, and in the first moment there could
17536: be no check to the impulsive belief which sprang from her keen
17537: experience of Tito’s nature. The sensitive response of her face was a
17538: stimulus to Baldassarre; for the first time his words had wrought their
17539: right effect. He went on with gathering eagerness and firmness, laying
17540: his hand on her arm.
17541: 
17542: “You are a woman of proud blood—is it not true? You go to hear the
17543: preacher; you hate baseness—baseness that smiles and triumphs. You hate
17544: your husband?”
17545: 
17546: “Oh God! were you really his father?” said Romola, in a low voice, too
17547: entirely possessed by the images of the past to take any note of
17548: Baldassarre’s question. “Or was it as he said? Did you take him when he
17549: was little?”
17550: 
17551: “Ah, you believe me—you know what he is!” said Baldassarre, exultingly,
17552: tightening the pressure on her arm, as if the contact gave him power.
17553: “You will help me?”
17554: 
17555: “Yes,” said Romola, not interpreting the words as he meant them. She
17556: laid her palm gently on the rough hand that grasped her arm, and the
17557: tears came to her eyes as she looked at him. “Oh, it is piteous! Tell
17558: me—you were a great scholar; you taught him. How is it?”
17559: 
17560: She broke off. Tito’s allegation of this man’s madness had come across
17561: her; and where were the signs even of past refinement? But she had the
17562: self-command not to move her hand. She sat perfectly still, waiting to
17563: listen with new caution.
17564: 
17565: “It is gone!—it is all gone!” said Baldassarre; “and they would not
17566: believe me, because he lied, and said I was mad; and they had me
17567: dragged to prison. And I am old—my mind will not come back. And the
17568: world is against me.”
17569: 
17570: He paused a moment, and his eyes sank as if he were under a wave of
17571: despondency. Then he looked up at her again, and said with renewed
17572: eagerness—“But _you_ are not against me. He made you love him, and he
17573: has been false to you; and you hate him. Yes, he made _me_ love him: he
17574: was beautiful and gentle, and I was a lonely man. I took him when they
17575: were beating him. He slept in my bosom when he was little, and I
17576: watched him as he grew, and gave him all my knowledge, and everything
17577: that was mine I meant to be his. I had many things; money, and books,
17578: and gems. He had my gems—he sold them; and he left me in slavery. He
17579: never came to seek me, and when I came back poor and in misery, he
17580: denied me. He said I was a madman.”
17581: 
17582: “He told us his father was dead—was drowned,” said Romola, faintly.
17583: “Surely he must have believed it then. Oh! he could not have been so
17584: base _then_!”
17585: 
17586: A vision had risen of what Tito was to her in those first days when she
17587: thought no more of wrong in him than a child thinks of poison in
17588: flowers. The yearning regret that lay in that memory brought some
17589: relief from the tension of horror. With one great sob the tears rushed
17590: forth.
17591: 
17592: “Ah, you are young, and the tears come easily,” said Baldassarre, with
17593: some impatience. “But tears are no good; they only put out the fire
17594: within, and it is the fire that works. Tears will hinder us. Listen to
17595: me.”
17596: 
17597: Romola turned towards him with a slight start. Again the possibility of
17598: his madness had darted through her mind, and checked the rush of
17599: belief. If, after all, this man were only a mad assassin? But her deep
17600: belief in this story still lay behind, and it was more in sympathy than
17601: in fear that she avoided the risk of paining him by any show of doubt.
17602: 
17603: “Tell me,” she said, as gently as she could, “how did you lose your
17604: memory—your scholarship?”
17605: 
17606: “I was ill. I can’t tell how long—it was a blank. I remember nothing,
17607: only at last I was sitting in the sun among the stones, and everything
17608: else was darkness. And slowly, and by degrees, I felt something besides
17609: that: a longing for something—I did not know what—that never came. And
17610: when I was in the ship on the waters I began to know what I longed for;
17611: it was for the Boy to come back—it was to find all my thoughts again,
17612: for I was locked away outside them all. And I am outside now. I feel
17613: nothing but a wall and darkness.”
17614: 
17615: Baldassarre had become dreamy again, and sank into silence, resting his
17616: head between his hands; and again Romola’s belief in him had submerged
17617: all cautioning doubts. The pity with which she dwelt on his words
17618: seemed like the revival of an old pang. Had she not daily seen how her
17619: father missed Dino and the future he had dreamed of in that son?
17620: 
17621: “It all came back once,” Baldassarre went on presently. “I was master
17622: of everything. I saw all the world again, and my gems, and my books;
17623: and I thought I had him in my power, and I went to expose him
17624: where—where the lights were and the trees; and he lied again, and said
17625: I was mad, and they dragged me away to prison... Wickedness is strong;
17626: and he wears armour.”
17627: 
17628: The fierceness had flamed up again. He spoke with his former intensity,
17629: and again he grasped Romola’s arm.
17630: 
17631: “But you will help me? He has been false to you too. He has another
17632: wife, and she has children. He makes her believe he is her husband, and
17633: she is a foolish, helpless thing. I will show you where she lives.”
17634: 
17635: The first shock that passed through Romola was visibly one of anger.
17636: The woman’s sense of indignity was inevitably foremost. Baldassarre
17637: instinctively felt her in sympathy with him.
17638: 
17639: “You hate him,” he went on. “Is it not true? There is no love between
17640: you; I know that. I know women can hate; and you have proud blood. You
17641: hate falseness, and you can love revenge.”
17642: 
17643: Romola sat paralysed by the shock of conflicting feelings. She was not
17644: conscious of the grasp that was bruising her tender arm.
17645: 
17646: “You shall contrive it,” said Baldassarre, presently, in an eager
17647: whisper. “I have learned by heart that you are his rightful wife. You
17648: are a noble woman. You go to hear the preacher of vengeance; you will
17649: help justice. But you will think for me. My mind goes—everything goes
17650: sometimes—all but the fire. The fire is God: it is justice: it will not
17651: die. You believe that—is it not true? If they will not hang him for
17652: robbing me, you will take away his armour—you will make him go without
17653: it, and I will stab him. I have a knife, and my arm is still strong
17654: enough.”
17655: 
17656: He put his hand under his tunic, and reached out the hidden knife,
17657: feeling the edge abstractedly, as if he needed the sensation to keep
17658: alive his ideas.
17659: 
17660: It seemed to Romola as if every fresh hour of her life were to become
17661: more difficult than the last. Her judgment was too vigorous and rapid
17662: for her to fall into the mistake of using futile deprecatory words to a
17663: man in Baldassarre’s state of mind. She chose not to answer his last
17664: speech. She would win time for his excitement to allay itself by asking
17665: something else that she cared to know. She spoke rather tremulously—
17666: 
17667: “You say she is foolish and helpless—that other wife—and believes him
17668: to be her real husband. Perhaps he is: perhaps he married her before he
17669: married me.”
17670: 
17671: “I cannot tell,” said Baldassarre, pausing in that action of feeling
17672: the knife, and looking bewildered. “I can remember no more. I only know
17673: where she lives. You shall see her. I will take you; but not now,” he
17674: added hurriedly, “_he_ may be there. The night is coming on.”
17675: 
17676: “It is true,” said Romola, starting up with a sudden consciousness that
17677: the sun had set and the hills were darkening; “but you will come and
17678: take me—when?”
17679: 
17680: “In the morning,” said Baldassarre, dreaming that she, too, wanted to
17681: hurry to her vengeance.
17682: 
17683: “Come to me, then, where you came to me to-day, in the church. I will
17684: be there at ten; and if you are not there, I will go again towards
17685: mid-day. Can you remember?”
17686: 
17687: “Mid-day,” said Baldassarre—“only mid-day. The same place, and mid-day.
17688: And, after that,” he added, rising and grasping her arm again with his
17689: left hand, while he held the knife in his right; “we will have our
17690: revenge. He shall feel the sharp edge of justice. The world is against
17691: me, but you will help me.”
17692: 
17693: “I would help you in other ways,” said Romola, making a first, timid
17694: effort to dispel his illusion about her. “I fear you are in want; you
17695: have to labour, and get little. I should like to bring you comforts,
17696: and make you feel again that there is some one who cares for you.”
17697: 
17698: “Talk no more about that,” said Baldassarre, fiercely. “I will have
17699: nothing else. Help me to wring one drop of vengeance on this side of
17700: the grave. I have nothing but my knife. It is sharp; but there is a
17701: moment after the thrust when men see the face of death,—and it shall be
17702: my face that he will see.”
17703: 
17704: He loosed his hold, and sank down again in a sitting posture. Romola
17705: felt helpless: she must defer all intentions till the morrow.
17706: 
17707: “Mid-day, then,” she said, in a distinct voice.
17708: 
17709: “Yes,” he answered, with an air of exhaustion. “Go; I will rest here.”
17710: 
17711: She hastened away. Turning at the last spot whence he was likely to be
17712: in sight, she saw him seated still.
17713: 
17714: 
17715: 
17716: 
17717: CHAPTER LIV.
17718: The Evening and the Morning.
17719: 
17720: 
17721: Romola had a purpose in her mind as she was hastening away; a purpose
17722: which had been growing through the afternoon hours like a side-stream,
17723: rising higher and higher along with the main current. It was less a
17724: resolve than a necessity of her feeling. Heedless of the darkening
17725: streets, and not caring to call for Maso’s slow escort, she hurried
17726: across the bridge where the river showed itself black before the
17727: distant dying red, and took the most direct way to the Old Palace. She
17728: might encounter her husband there. No matter. She could not weigh
17729: probabilities; she must discharge her heart. She did not know what she
17730: passed in the pillared court or up the wide stairs; she only knew that
17731: she asked an usher for the Gonfaloniere, giving her name, and begging
17732: to be shown into a private room.
17733: 
17734: She was not left long alone with the frescoed figures and the newly-lit
17735: tapers. Soon the door opened, and Bernardo del Nero entered, still
17736: carrying his white head erect above his silk lucco.
17737: 
17738: “Romola, my child, what is this?” he said, in a tone of anxious
17739: surprise as he closed the door.
17740: 
17741: She had uncovered her head and went towards him without speaking. He
17742: laid his hand on her shoulder, and held her a little way from him that
17743: he might see her better. Her face was haggard from fatigue and long
17744: agitation, her hair had rolled down in disorder; but there was an
17745: excitement in her eyes that seemed to have triumphed over the bodily
17746: consciousness.
17747: 
17748: “What has he done?” said Bernardo, abruptly. “Tell me everything,
17749: child; throw away pride. I am your father.”
17750: 
17751: “It is not about myself—nothing about myself,” said Romola, hastily.
17752: “Dearest godfather, it is about you. I have heard things—some I cannot
17753: tell you. But you are in danger in the palace; you are in danger
17754: everywhere. There are fanatical men who would harm you, and—and there
17755: are traitors. Trust nobody. If you trust, you will be betrayed.”
17756: 
17757: Bernardo smiled.
17758: 
17759: “Have you worked yourself up into this agitation, my poor child,” he
17760: said, raising his hand to her head and patting it gently, “to tell such
17761: old truth as that to an old man like me?”
17762: 
17763: “Oh no, no! they are not old truths that I mean,” said Romola, pressing
17764: her clasped hands painfully together, as if that action would help her
17765: to suppress what must not be told. “They are fresh things that I know,
17766: but cannot tell. Dearest godfather, you know I am not foolish. I would
17767: not come to you without reason. Is it too late to warn you against any
17768: one, _every_ one who seems to be working on your side? Is it too late
17769: to say, ‘Go to your villa and keep away in the country when these three
17770: more days of office are over?’ Oh God! perhaps it is too late! and if
17771: any harm comes to you, it will be as if I had done it!”
17772: 
17773: The last words had burst from Romola involuntarily: a long-stifled
17774: feeling had found spasmodic utterance. But she herself was startled and
17775: arrested.
17776: 
17777: “I mean,” she added, hesitatingly, “I know nothing positive. I only
17778: know what fills me with fears.”
17779: 
17780: “Poor child!” said Bernardo, looking at her with quiet penetration for
17781: a moment or two. Then he said: “Go, Romola—go home and rest. These
17782: fears may be only big ugly shadows of something very little and
17783: harmless. Even traitors must see their interest in betraying; the rats
17784: will run where they smell the cheese, and there is no knowing yet which
17785: way the scent will come.”
17786: 
17787: He paused, and turned away his eyes from her with an air of
17788: abstraction, till, with a slow shrug, he added—
17789: 
17790: “As for warnings, they are of no use to me, child. I enter into no
17791: plots, but I never forsake my colours. If I march abreast with
17792: obstinate men, who will rush on guns and pikes, I must share the
17793: consequences. Let us say no more about that. I have not many years left
17794: at the bottom of my sack for them to rob me of. Go, child; go home and
17795: rest.”
17796: 
17797: He put his hand on her head again caressingly, and she could not help
17798: clinging to his arm, and pressing her brow against his shoulder. Her
17799: godfather’s caress seemed the last thing that was left to her out of
17800: that young filial life, which now looked so happy to her even in its
17801: troubles, for they were troubles untainted by anything hateful.
17802: 
17803: “Is silence best, my Romola?” said the old man.
17804: 
17805: “Yes, now; but I cannot tell whether it always will be,” she answered,
17806: hesitatingly, raising her head with an appealing look.
17807: 
17808: “Well, you have a father’s ear while I am above ground,”—he lifted the
17809: black drapery and folded it round her head, adding—“and a father’s
17810: home; remember that.” Then opening the door, he said: “There, hasten
17811: away. You are like a black ghost; you will be safe enough.”
17812: 
17813: When Romola fell asleep that night, she slept deep. Agitation had
17814: reached its limits; she must gather strength before she could suffer
17815: more; and, in spite of rigid habit, she slept on far beyond sunrise.
17816: 
17817: When she awoke, it was to the sound of guns. Piero de’ Medici, with
17818: thirteen hundred men at his back, was before the gate that looks
17819: towards Rome.
17820: 
17821: So much Romola learned from Maso, with many circumstantial additions of
17822: dubious quality. A countryman had come in and alarmed the Signoria
17823: before it was light, else the city would have been taken by surprise.
17824: His master was not in the house, having been summoned to the Palazzo
17825: long ago. She sent out the old man again, that he might gather news,
17826: while she went up to the loggia from time to time to try and discern
17827: any signs of the dreaded entrance having been made, or of its having
17828: been effectively repelled. Maso brought her word that the great Piazza
17829: was full of armed men, and that many of the chief citizens suspected as
17830: friends of the Medici had been summoned to the palace and detained
17831: there. Some of the people seemed not to mind whether Piero got in or
17832: not, and some said the Signoria itself had invited him; but however
17833: that might be, they were giving him an ugly welcome; and the soldiers
17834: from Pisa were coming against him.
17835: 
17836: In her memory of those morning hours, there were not many things that
17837: Romola could distinguish as actual external experiences standing
17838: markedly out above the tumultuous waves of retrospect and anticipation.
17839: She knew that she had really walked to the Badia by the appointed time
17840: in spite of street alarms; she knew that she had waited there in vain.
17841: And the scene she had witnessed when she came out of the church, and
17842: stood watching on the steps while the doors were being closed behind
17843: her for the afternoon interval, always came back to her like a
17844: remembered waking.
17845: 
17846: There was a change in the faces and tones of the people, armed and
17847: unarmed, who were pausing or hurrying along the streets. The guns were
17848: firing again, but the sound only provoked laughter. She soon knew the
17849: cause of the change. Piero de’ Medici and his horsemen had turned their
17850: backs on Florence, and were galloping as fast as they could along the
17851: Siena road. She learned this from a substantial shop-keeping Piagnone,
17852: who had not yet laid down his pike.
17853: 
17854: “It is true,” he ended, with a certain bitterness in his emphasis.
17855: “Piero is gone, but there are those left behind who were in the secret
17856: of his coming—we all know that; and if the new Signoria does its duty
17857: we shall soon know who they are.”
17858: 
17859: The words darted through Romola like a sharp spasm; but the evil they
17860: foreshadowed was not yet close upon her, and as she entered her home
17861: again, her most pressing anxiety was the possibility that she had lost
17862: sight for a long while of Baldassarre.
17863: 
17864: 
17865: 
17866: 
17867: CHAPTER LV.
17868: Waiting.
17869: 
17870: 
17871: The lengthening sunny days went on without bringing either what Romola
17872: most desired or what she most dreaded. They brought no sign from
17873: Baldassarre, and, in spite of special watch on the part of the
17874: Government, no revelation of the suspected conspiracy. But they brought
17875: other things which touched her closely, and bridged the phantom-crowded
17876: space of anxiety with active sympathy in immediate trial. They brought
17877: the spreading Plague and the Excommunication of Savonarola.
17878: 
17879: Both these events tended to arrest her incipient alienation from the
17880: Frate, and to rivet again her attachment to the man who had opened to
17881: her the new life of duty, and who seemed now to be worsted in the fight
17882: for principle against profligacy. For Romola could not carry from day
17883: to day into the abodes of pestilence and misery the sublime excitement
17884: of a gladness that, since such anguish existed, she too existed to make
17885: some of the anguish less bitter, without remembering that she owed this
17886: transcendent moral life to Fra Girolamo. She could not witness the
17887: silencing and excommunication of a man whose distinction from the great
17888: mass of the clergy lay, not in any heretical belief, not in his
17889: superstitions, but in the energy with which he sought to make the
17890: Christian life a reality, without feeling herself drawn strongly to his
17891: side.
17892: 
17893: Far on in the hot days of June the Excommunication, for some weeks
17894: arrived from Rome, was solemnly published in the Duomo. Romola went to
17895: witness the scene, that the resistance it inspired might invigorate
17896: that sympathy with Savonarola which was one source of her strength. It
17897: was in memorable contrast with the scene she had been accustomed to
17898: witness there.
17899: 
17900: Instead of upturned citizen-faces filling the vast area under the
17901: morning light, the youngest rising amphitheatre-wise towards the walls,
17902: and making a garland of hope around the memories of age—instead of the
17903: mighty voice thrilling all hearts with the sense of great things,
17904: visible and invisible, to be struggled for—there were the bare walls at
17905: evening made more sombre by the glimmer of tapers; there was the black
17906: and grey flock of monks and secular clergy with bent, unexpectant
17907: faces; there was the occasional tinkling of little bells in the pauses
17908: of a monotonous voice reading a sentence which had already been long
17909: hanging up in the churches; and at last there was the extinction of the
17910: tapers, and the slow, shuffling tread of monkish feet departing in the
17911: dim silence.
17912: 
17913: Romola’s ardour on the side of the Frate was doubly strengthened by the
17914: gleeful triumph she saw in hard and coarse faces, and by the
17915: fear-stricken confusion in the faces and speech of many among his
17916: strongly-attached friends. The question where the duty of obedience
17917: ends, and the duty of resistance begins, could in no case be an easy
17918: one; but it was made overwhelmingly difficult by the belief that the
17919: Church was—not a compromise of parties to secure a more or less
17920: approximate justice in the appropriation of funds, but—a living
17921: organism, instinct with Divine power to bless and to curse. To most of
17922: the pious Florentines, who had hitherto felt no doubt in their
17923: adherence to the Frate, that belief in the Divine potency of the Church
17924: was not an embraced opinion, it was an inalienable impression, like the
17925: concavity of the blue firmament; and the boldness of Savonarola’s
17926: written arguments that the Excommunication was unjust, and that, being
17927: unjust, it was not valid, only made them tremble the more, as a
17928: defiance cast at a mystic image, against whose subtle immeasurable
17929: power there was neither weapon nor defence.
17930: 
17931: But Romola, whose mind had not been allowed to draw its early
17932: nourishment from the traditional associations of the Christian
17933: community in which her father had lived a life apart, felt her relation
17934: to the Church only through Savonarola; his moral force had been the
17935: only authority to which she had bowed; and in his excommunication she
17936: only saw the menace of hostile vice: on one side she saw a man whose
17937: life was devoted to the ends of public virtue and spiritual purity, and
17938: on the other the assault of alarmed selfishness, headed by a lustful,
17939: greedy, lying, and murderous old man, once called Rodrigo Borgia, and
17940: now lifted to the pinnacle of infamy as Pope Alexander the Sixth. The
17941: finer shades of fact which soften the edge of such antitheses are not
17942: apt to be seen except by neutrals, who are not distressed to discern
17943: some folly in martyrs and some judiciousness in the men who burnt them.
17944: But Romola required a strength that neutrality could not give; and this
17945: Excommunication, which simplified and ennobled the resistant position
17946: of Savonarola by bringing into prominence its wider relations, seemed
17947: to come to her like a rescue from the threatening isolation of
17948: criticism and doubt. The Frate was now withdrawn from that smaller
17949: antagonism against Florentine enemies into which he continually fell in
17950: the unchecked excitement of the pulpit, and presented himself simply as
17951: appealing to the Christian world against a vicious exercise of
17952: ecclesiastical power. He was a standard-bearer leaping into the breach.
17953: Life never seems so clear and easy as when the heart is beating faster
17954: at the sight of some generous self-risking deed. We feel no doubt then
17955: what is the highest prize the soul can win; we almost believe in our
17956: own power to attain it. By a new current of such enthusiasm Romola was
17957: helped through these difficult summer days. She had ventured on no
17958: words to Tito that would apprise him of her late interview with
17959: Baldassarre, and the revelation he had made to her. What would such
17960: agitating, difficult words win from him? No admission of the truth;
17961: nothing, probably, but a cool sarcasm about her sympathy with his
17962: assassin. Baldassarre was evidently helpless: the thing to be feared
17963: was, not that he should injure Tito, but that Tito, coming upon his
17964: traces, should carry out some new scheme for ridding himself of the
17965: injured man who was a haunting dread to him. Romola felt that she could
17966: do nothing decisive until she had seen Baldassarre again, and learned
17967: the full truth about that “other wife”—learned whether she were the
17968: wife to whom Tito was first bound.
17969: 
17970: The possibilities about that other wife, which involved the worst wound
17971: to her hereditary pride, mingled themselves as a newly-embittering
17972: suspicion with the earliest memories of her illusory love, eating away
17973: the lingering associations of tenderness with the past image of her
17974: husband; and her irresistible belief in the rest of Baldassarre’s
17975: revelation made her shrink from Tito with a horror which would perhaps
17976: have urged some passionate speech in spite of herself if he had not
17977: been more than usually absent from home. Like many of the wealthier
17978: citizens in that time of pestilence, he spent the intervals of business
17979: chiefly in the country: the agreeable Melema was welcome at many
17980: villas, and since Romola had refused to leave the city, he had no need
17981: to provide a country residence of his own.
17982: 
17983: But at last, in the later days of July, the alleviation of those public
17984: troubles which had absorbed her activity and much of her thought, left
17985: Romola to a less counteracted sense of her personal lot. The Plague had
17986: almost disappeared, and the position of Savonarola was made more
17987: hopeful by a favourable magistracy, who were writing urgent vindicatory
17988: letters to Rome on his behalf, entreating the withdrawal of the
17989: Excommunication.
17990: 
17991: Romola’s healthy and vigorous frame was undergoing the reaction of
17992: languor inevitable after continuous excitement and over-exertion; but
17993: her mental restlessness would not allow her to remain at home without
17994: peremptory occupation, except during the sultry hours. In the cool of
17995: the morning and evening she walked out constantly, varying her
17996: direction as much as possible, with the vague hope that if Baldassarre
17997: were still alive she might encounter him. Perhaps some illness had
17998: brought a new paralysis of memory, and he had forgotten where she
17999: lived—forgotten even her existence. That was her most sanguine
18000: explanation of his non-appearance. The explanation she felt to be most
18001: probable was, that he had died of the Plague.
18002: 
18003: 
18004: 
18005: 
18006: CHAPTER LVI.
18007: The Other Wife.
18008: 
18009: 
18010: The morning warmth was already beginning to be rather oppressive to
18011: Romola, when, after a walk along by the walls on her way from San
18012: Marco, she turned towards the intersecting streets again at the gate of
18013: Santa Croce.
18014: 
18015: The Borgo La Croce was so still, that she listened to her own footsteps
18016: on the pavement in the sunny silence, until, on approaching a bend in
18017: the street, she saw, a few yards before her, a little child not more
18018: than three years old, with no other clothing than his white shirt,
18019: pause from a waddling run and look around him. In the first moment of
18020: coming nearer she could only see his back—a boy’s back, square and
18021: sturdy, with a cloud of reddish-brown curls above it; but in the next
18022: he turned towards her, and she could see his dark eyes wide with tears,
18023: and his lower lip pushed up and trembling, while his fat brown fists
18024: clutched his shirt helplessly. The glimpse of a tall black figure
18025: sending a shadow over him brought his bewildered fear to a climax, and
18026: a loud crying sob sent the big tears rolling.
18027: 
18028: Romola, with the ready maternal instinct which was one hidden source of
18029: her passionate tenderness, instantly uncovered her head, and, stooping
18030: down on the pavement, put her arms round him, and her cheeks against
18031: his, while she spoke to him in caressing tones. At first his sobs were
18032: only the louder, but he made no effort to get away, and presently the
18033: outburst ceased with that strange abruptness which belongs to childish
18034: joys and griefs: his face lost its distortion, and was fixed in an
18035: open-mouthed gaze at Romola.
18036: 
18037: “You have lost yourself, little one,” she said, kissing him. “Never
18038: mind! we will find the house again. Perhaps mamma will meet us.”
18039: 
18040: She divined that he had made his escape at a moment when the mother’s
18041: eyes were turned away from him, and thought it likely that he would
18042: soon be followed.
18043: 
18044: “Oh, what a heavy, heavy boy!” she said, trying to lift him. “I cannot
18045: carry you. Come, then, you must toddle back by my side.”
18046: 
18047: The parted lips remained motionless in awed silence, and one brown fist
18048: still clutched the shirt with as much tenacity as ever; but the other
18049: yielded itself quite willingly to the wonderful white hand, strong but
18050: soft.
18051: 
18052: “You _have_ a mamma?” said Romola, as they set out, looking down at the
18053: boy with a certain yearning. But he was mute. A girl under those
18054: circumstances might perhaps have chirped abundantly; not so this
18055: square-shouldered little man with the big cloud of curls.
18056: 
18057: He was awake to the first sign of his whereabout, however. At the
18058: turning by the front of San Ambrogio he dragged Romola towards it,
18059: looking up at her.
18060: 
18061: “Ah, that is the way home, is it?” she said, smiling at him. He only
18062: thrust his head forward and pulled, as an admonition that they should
18063: go faster.
18064: 
18065: There was still another turning that he had a decided opinion about,
18066: and then Romola found herself in a short street leading to open garden
18067: ground. It was in front of a house at the end of this street that the
18068: little fellow paused, pulling her towards some stone stairs. He had
18069: evidently no wish for her to loose his hand, and she would not have
18070: been willing to leave him without being sure that she was delivering
18071: him to his friends. They mounted the stairs, seeing but dimly in that
18072: sudden withdrawal from the sunlight, till, at the final landing-place,
18073: an extra stream of light came from an open doorway. Passing through a
18074: small lobby, they came to another open door, and there Romola paused.
18075: Her approach had not been heard.
18076: 
18077: On a low chair at the farther end of the room, opposite the light, sat
18078: Tessa, with one hand on the edge of the cradle, and her head hanging a
18079: little on one side, fast asleep. Near one of the windows, with her back
18080: turned towards the door, sat Monna Lisa at her work of preparing salad,
18081: in deaf unconsciousness. There was only an instant for Romola’s eyes to
18082: take in that still scene; for Lillo snatched his hand away from her and
18083: ran up to his mother’s side, not making any direct effort to wake her,
18084: but only leaning his head back against her arm, and surveying Romola
18085: seriously from that distance.
18086: 
18087: As Lillo pushed against her, Tessa opened her eyes, and looked up in
18088: bewilderment; but her glance had no sooner rested on the figure at the
18089: opposite doorway than she started up, blushed deeply, and began to
18090: tremble a little, neither speaking nor moving forward.
18091: 
18092: “Ah! we have seen each other before,” said Romola, smiling, and coming
18093: forward. “I am glad it was _your_ little boy. He was crying in the
18094: street; I suppose he had run away. So we walked together a little way,
18095: and then he knew where he was, and brought me here. But you had not
18096: missed him? That is well, else you would have been frightened.”
18097: 
18098: The shock of finding that Lillo had run away overcame every other
18099: feeling in Tessa for the moment. Her colour went again, and, seizing
18100: Lillo’s arm, she ran with him to Monna Lisa, saying, with a half sob,
18101: loud in the old woman’s ear—
18102: 
18103: “Oh, Lisa, you are wicked! Why will you stand with your back to the
18104: door? Lillo ran away ever so far into the street.”
18105: 
18106: “Holy Mother!” said Monna Lisa, in her meek, thick tone, letting the
18107: spoon fall from her hands. “Where were _you_, then? I thought you were
18108: there, and had your eye on him.”
18109: 
18110: “But you _know_ I go to sleep when I am rocking,” said Tessa, in
18111: pettish remonstrance.
18112: 
18113: “Well, well, we must keep the outer door shut, or else tie him up,”
18114: said Monna Lisa, “for he’ll be as cunning as Satan before long, and
18115: that’s the holy truth. But how came he back, then?”
18116: 
18117: This question recalled Tessa to the consciousness of Romola’s presence.
18118: Without answering, she turned towards her, blushing and timid again,
18119: and Monna Lisa’s eyes followed her movement. The old woman made a low
18120: reverence, and said—
18121: 
18122: “Doubtless the most noble lady brought him back.” Then, advancing a
18123: little nearer to Romola, she added, “It’s my shame for him to have been
18124: found with only his shirt on; but he kicked, and wouldn’t have his
18125: other clothes on this morning, and the mother, poor thing, will never
18126: hear of his being beaten. But what’s an old woman to do without a stick
18127: when the lad’s legs get so strong? Let your nobleness look at his
18128: legs.”
18129: 
18130: Lillo, conscious that his legs were in question, pulled his shirt up a
18131: little higher, and looked down at their olive roundness with a
18132: dispassionate and curious air. Romola laughed, and stooped to give him
