18133: a caressing shake and a kiss, and this action helped the reassurance
18134: that Tessa had already gathered from Monna Lisa’s address to Romola.
18135: For when Naldo had been told about the adventure at the Carnival, and
18136: Tessa had asked him who the heavenly lady that had come just when she
18137: was wanted, and had vanished so soon, was likely to be—whether she
18138: could be the Holy Madonna herself?—he had answered, “Not exactly, my
18139: Tessa; only one of the saints,” and had not chosen to say more. So that
18140: in the dreamlike combination of small experience which made up Tessa’s
18141: thought, Romola had remained confusedly associated with the pictures in
18142: the churches, and when she reappeared, the grateful remembrance of her
18143: protection was slightly tinctured with religious awe—not deeply, for
18144: Tessa’s dread was chiefly of ugly and evil beings. It seemed unlikely
18145: that good beings would be angry and punish her, as it was the nature of
18146: Nofri and the devil to do. And now that Monna Lisa had spoken freely
18147: about Lillo’s legs and Romola had laughed, Tessa was more at her ease.
18148: 
18149: “Ninna’s in the cradle,” she said. “_She’s_ pretty too.”
18150: 
18151: Romola went to look at the sleeping Ninna, and Monna Lisa, one of the
18152: exceptionally meek deaf, who never expect to be spoken to, returned to
18153: her salad.
18154: 
18155: “Ah! she is waking: she has opened her blue eyes,” said Romola. “You
18156: must take her up, and I will sit down in this chair—may I?—and nurse
18157: Lillo. Come, Lillo!”
18158: 
18159: She sat down in Tito’s chair, and put out her arms towards the lad,
18160: whose eyes had followed her. He hesitated: and, pointing his small
18161: fingers at her with a half-puzzled, half-angry feeling, said, “That’s
18162: Babbo’s chair,” not seeing his way out of the difficulty if Babbo came
18163: and found Romola in his place.
18164: 
18165: “But Babbo is not here, and I shall go soon. Come, let me nurse you as
18166: he does,” said Romola, wondering to herself for the first time what
18167: sort of Babbo he was whose wife was dressed in contadina fashion, but
18168: had a certain daintiness about her person that indicated idleness and
18169: plenty. Lillo consented to be lifted up, and, finding the lap
18170: exceedingly comfortable, began to explore her dress and hands, to see
18171: if there were any ornaments beside the rosary.
18172: 
18173: Tessa, who had hitherto been occupied in coaxing Ninna out of her
18174: waking peevishness, now sat down in her low chair, near Romola’s knee,
18175: arranging Ninna’s tiny person to advantage, jealous that the strange
18176: lady too seemed to notice the boy most, as Naldo did.
18177: 
18178: “Lillo was going to be angry with me, because I sat in Babbo’s chair,”
18179: said Romola, as she bent forward to kiss Ninna’s little foot. “Will he
18180: come soon and want it?”
18181: 
18182: “Ah, no!” said Tessa, “you can sit in it a long while. I shall be sorry
18183: when you go. When you first came to take care of me at the Carnival, I
18184: thought it was wonderful; you came and went away again so fast. And
18185: Naldo said, perhaps you were a saint, and that made me tremble a
18186: little, though the saints are very good, I know; and you were good to
18187: me, and now you have taken care of Lillo. Perhaps you will always come
18188: and take care of me. That was how Naldo did a long while ago; he came
18189: and took care of me when I was frightened, one San Giovanni. I couldn’t
18190: think where he came from—he was so beautiful and good. And so are you,”
18191: ended Tessa, looking up at Romola with devout admiration.
18192: 
18193: “Naldo is your husband. His eyes are like Lillo’s,” said Romola,
18194: looking at the boy’s darkly-pencilled eyebrows, unusual at his age. She
18195: did not speak interrogatively, but with a quiet certainty of inference
18196: which was necessarily mysterious to Tessa.
18197: 
18198: “Ah! you know him!” she said, pausing a little in wonder. “Perhaps you
18199: know Nofri and Peretola, and our house on the hill, and everything.
18200: Yes, like Lillo’s; but not his hair. His hair is dark and long—” she
18201: went on, getting rather excited. “Ah! if you know it, ecco!”
18202: 
18203: She had put her hand to a thin red silk cord that hung round her neck,
18204: and drew from her bosom the tiny old parchment _Breve_, the horn of red
18205: coral, and a long dark curl carefully tied at one end and suspended
18206: with those mystic treasures. She held them towards Romola, away from
18207: Ninna’s snatching hand.
18208: 
18209: “It is a fresh one. I cut it lately. See how bright it is!” she said,
18210: laying it against the white background of Romola’s fingers. “They get
18211: dim, and then he lets me cut another when his hair is grown; and I put
18212: it with the _Breve_, because sometimes he is away a long while, and
18213: then I think it helps to take care of me.”
18214: 
18215: A slight shiver passed through Romola as the curl was laid across her
18216: fingers. At Tessa’s first mention of her husband as having come
18217: mysteriously she knew not whence, a possibility had risen before Romola
18218: that made her heart beat faster; for to one who is anxiously in search
18219: of a certain object the faintest suggestions have a peculiar
18220: significance. And when the curl was held towards her, it seemed for an
18221: instant like a mocking phantasm of the lock she herself had cut to wind
18222: with one of her own five years ago. But she preserved her outward
18223: calmness, bent not only on knowing the truth, but also on coming to
18224: that knowledge in a way that would not pain this poor, trusting,
18225: ignorant thing, with the child’s mind in the woman’s body. “Foolish and
18226: helpless:” yes; so far she corresponded to Baldassarre’s account.
18227: 
18228: “It is a beautiful curl,” she said, resisting the impulse to withdraw
18229: her hand. “Lillo’s curls will be like it, perhaps, for _his_ cheek,
18230: too, is dark. And you never know where your husband goes to when he
18231: leaves you?”
18232: 
18233: “No,” said Tessa, putting back her treasures out of the children’s way.
18234: “But I know Messer San Michele takes care of him, for he gave him a
18235: beautiful coat, all made of little chains; and if he puts that on,
18236: nobody can kill him. And perhaps, if—”
18237: 
18238: Tessa hesitated a little, under a recurrence of that original dreamy
18239: wonder about Romola which had been expelled by chatting contact—“if you
18240: _were_ a saint, you would take care of him, too, because you have taken
18241: care of me and Lillo.”
18242: 
18243: An agitated flush came over Romola’s face in the first moment of
18244: certainty, but she had bent her cheek against Lillo’s head. The feeling
18245: that leaped out in that flush was something like exultation at the
18246: thought that the wife’s burden might be about to slip from her
18247: overladen shoulders; that this little ignorant creature might prove to
18248: be Tito’s lawful wife. A strange exultation for a proud and high-born
18249: woman to have been brought to! But it seemed to Romola as if that were
18250: the only issue that would make duty anything else for her than an
18251: insoluble problem. Yet she was not deaf to Tessa’s last appealing
18252: words; she raised her head, and said, in her clearest tones—
18253: 
18254: “I will always take care of you if I see you need me. But that
18255: beautiful coat? your husband did not wear it when you were first
18256: married? Perhaps he used not to be so long away from you then?”
18257: 
18258: “Ah, yes! he was. Much—much longer. So long, I thought he would never
18259: come back. I used to cry. Oh me! I was beaten then; a long, long while
18260: ago at Peretola, where we had the goats and mules.”
18261: 
18262: “And how long had you been married before your husband had that
18263: chain-coat?” said Romola, her heart beating faster and faster.
18264: 
18265: Tessa looked meditative, and began to count on her fingers, and Romola
18266: watched the fingers as if they would tell the secret of her destiny.
18267: 
18268: “The chestnuts were ripe when we were married,” said Tessa, marking off
18269: her thumb and fingers again as she spoke; “and then again they were
18270: ripe at Peretola before he came back, and then again, after that, on
18271: the hill. And soon the soldiers came, and we heard the trumpets, and
18272: then Naldo had the coat.”
18273: 
18274: “You had been married more than two years. In which church were you
18275: married?” said Romola, too entirely absorbed by one thought to put any
18276: question that was less direct. Perhaps before the next morning she
18277: might go to her godfather and say that she was not Tito Melema’s lawful
18278: wife—that the vows which had bound her to strive after an impossible
18279: union had been made void beforehand.
18280: 
18281: Tessa gave a slight start at Romola’s new tone of inquiry, and looked
18282: up at her with a hesitating expression. Hitherto she had prattled on
18283: without consciousness that she was making revelations, any more than
18284: when she said old things over and over again to Monna Lisa.
18285: 
18286: “Naldo said I was never to tell about that,” she said, doubtfully. “Do
18287: you think he would not be angry if I told you?”
18288: 
18289: “It is right that you should tell me. Tell me everything,” said Romola,
18290: looking at her with mild authority.
18291: 
18292: If the impression from Naldo’s command had been much more recent than
18293: it was, the constraining effect of Romola’s mysterious authority would
18294: have overcome it. But the sense that she was telling what she had never
18295: told before made her begin with a lowered voice.
18296: 
18297: “It was not in a church—it was at the Nativita, when there was a fair,
18298: and all the people went overnight to see the Madonna in the Nunziata,
18299: and my mother was ill and couldn’t go, and I took the bunch of cocoons
18300: for her; and then he came to me in the church and I heard him say,
18301: ‘Tessa!’ I knew him because he had taken care of me at the San
18302: Giovanni, and then we went into the piazza where the fair was, and I
18303: had some _berlingozzi_, for I was hungry and he was very good to me;
18304: and at the end of the piazza there was a holy father, and an altar like
18305: what they have at the processions outside the churches. So he married
18306: us, and then Naldo took me back into the church and left me; and I went
18307: home, and my mother died, and Nofri began to beat me more, and Naldo
18308: never came back. And I used to cry, and once at the Carnival I saw him
18309: and followed him, and he was angry, and said he would come some time, I
18310: must wait. So I went and waited; but, oh! it was a long while before he
18311: came; but he would have come if he could, for he was good; and then he
18312: took me away, because I cried and said I could not bear to stay with
18313: Nofri. And, oh! I was so glad, and since then I have been always happy,
18314: for I don’t mind about the goats and mules, because I have Lillo and
18315: Ninna now; and Naldo is never angry, only I think he doesn’t love Ninna
18316: so well as Lillo, and she _is_ pretty.”
18317: 
18318: Quite forgetting that she had thought her speech rather momentous at
18319: the beginning, Tessa fell to devouring Ninna with kisses, while Romola
18320: sat in silence with absent eyes. It was inevitable that in this moment
18321: she should think of the three beings before her chiefly in their
18322: relation to her own lot, and she was feeling the chill of
18323: disappointment that her difficulties were not to be solved by external
18324: law. She had relaxed her hold of Lillo, and was leaning her cheek
18325: against her hand, seeing nothing of the scene around her. Lillo was
18326: quick in perceiving a change that was not agreeable to him; he had not
18327: yet made any return to her caresses, but he objected to their
18328: withdrawal, and putting up both his brown arms to pull her head towards
18329: him, he said, “Play with me again!”
18330: 
18331: Romola, roused from her self-absorption, clasped the lad anew, and
18332: looked from him to Tessa, who had now paused from her shower of kisses,
18333: and seemed to have returned to the more placid delight of contemplating
18334: the heavenly lady’s face. That face was undergoing a subtle change,
18335: like the gradual oncoming of a warmer, softer light. Presently Romola
18336: took her scissors from her scarsella, and cut off one of her long wavy
18337: locks, while the three pair of wide eyes followed her movements with
18338: kitten-like observation.
18339: 
18340: “I must go away from you now,” she said, “but I will leave this lock of
18341: hair that it may remind you of me, because if you are ever in trouble
18342: you can think that perhaps God will send me to take care of you again.
18343: I cannot tell you where to find me, but if I ever know that you want
18344: me, I will come to you. Addio!”
18345: 
18346: She had set down Lillo hurriedly, and held out her hand to Tessa, who
18347: kissed it with a mixture of awe and sorrow at this parting. Romola’s
18348: mind was oppressed with thoughts; she needed to be alone as soon as
18349: possible, but with her habitual care for the least fortunate, she
18350: turned aside to put her hand in a friendly way on Monna Lisa’s shoulder
18351: and make her a farewell sign. Before the old woman had finished her
18352: deep reverence, Romola had disappeared.
18353: 
18354: Monna Lisa and Tessa moved towards each other by simultaneous impulses,
18355: while the two children stood clinging to their mother’s skirts as if
18356: they, too, felt the atmosphere of awe.
18357: 
18358: “Do you think she _was_ a saint?” said Tessa, in Lisa’s ear, showing
18359: her the lock.
18360: 
18361: Lisa rejected that notion very decidedly by a backward movement of her
18362: fingers, and then stroking the rippled gold, said—
18363: 
18364: “She’s a great and noble lady. I saw such in my youth.”
18365: 
18366: Romola went home and sat alone through the sultry hours of that day
18367: with the heavy certainty that her lot was unchanged. She was thrown
18368: back again on the conflict between the demands of an outward law, which
18369: she recognised as a widely-ramifying obligation, and the demands of
18370: inner moral facts which were becoming more and more peremptory. She had
18371: drunk in deeply the spirit of that teaching by which Savonarola had
18372: urged her to return to her place. She felt that the sanctity attached
18373: to all close relations, and, therefore, pre-eminently to the closest,
18374: was but the expression in outward law of that result towards which all
18375: human goodness and nobleness must spontaneously tend; that the light
18376: abandonment of ties, whether inherited or voluntary, because they had
18377: ceased to be pleasant, was the uprooting of social and personal virtue.
18378: What else had Tito’s crime towards Baldassarre been but that
18379: abandonment working itself out to the most hideous extreme of falsity
18380: and ingratitude?
18381: 
18382: And the inspiring consciousness breathed into her by Savonarola’s
18383: influence that her lot was vitally united with the general lot had
18384: exalted even the minor details of obligation into religion. She was
18385: marching with a great army; she was feeling the stress of a common
18386: life. If victims were needed, and it was uncertain on whom the lot
18387: might fall, she would stand ready to answer to her name. She had stood
18388: long; she had striven hard to fulfil the bond, but she had seen all the
18389: conditions which made the fulfilment possible gradually forsaking her.
18390: The one effect of her marriage-tie seemed to be the stifling
18391: predominance over her of a nature that she despised. All her efforts at
18392: union had only made its impossibility more palpable, and the relation
18393: had become for her simply a degrading servitude. The law was sacred.
18394: Yes, but rebellion might be sacred too. It flashed upon her mind that
18395: the problem before her was essentially the same as that which had lain
18396: before Savonarola—the problem where the sacredness of obedience ended,
18397: and where the sacredness of rebellion began. To her, as to him, there
18398: had come one of those moments in life when the soul must dare to act on
18399: its own warrant, not only without external law to appeal to, but in the
18400: face of a law which is not unarmed with Divine lightnings—lightnings
18401: that may yet fall if the warrant has been false.
18402: 
18403: Before the sun had gone down she had adopted a resolve. She would ask
18404: no counsel of her godfather or of Savonarola until she had made one
18405: determined effort to speak freely with Tito and obtain his consent that
18406: she should live apart from him. She desired not to leave him
18407: clandestinely again, or to forsake Florence. She would tell him that if
18408: he ever felt a real need of her, she would come back to him. Was not
18409: that the utmost faithfulness to her bond that could be required of her?
18410: A shuddering anticipation came over her that he would clothe a refusal
18411: in a sneering suggestion that she should enter a convent as the only
18412: mode of quitting him that would not be scandalous. He knew well that
18413: her mind revolted from that means of escape, not only because of her
18414: own repugnance to a narrow rule, but because all the cherished memories
18415: of her father forbade that she should adopt a mode of life which was
18416: associated with his deepest griefs and his bitterest dislike.
18417: 
18418: Tito had announced his intention of coming home this evening. She would
18419: wait for him, and say what she had to say at once, for it was difficult
18420: to get his ear during the day. If he had the slightest suspicion that
18421: personal words were coming, he slipped away with an appearance of
18422: unpremeditated ease. When she sent for Maso to tell him that she would
18423: wait for his master, she observed that the old man looked at her and
18424: lingered with a mixture of hesitation and wondering anxiety; but
18425: finding that she asked him no question, he slowly turned away. Why
18426: should she ask questions? Perhaps Maso only knew or guessed something
18427: of what she knew already.
18428: 
18429: It was late before Tito came. Romola had been pacing up and down the
18430: long room which had once been the library, with the windows open, and a
18431: loose white linen robe on instead of her usual black garment. She was
18432: glad of that change after the long hours of heat and motionless
18433: meditation; but the coolness and exercise made her more intensely
18434: wakeful, and as she went with the lamp in her hand to open the door for
18435: Tito, he might well have been startled by the vividness of her eyes and
18436: the expression of painful resolution, which was in contrast with her
18437: usual self-restrained quiescence before him. But it seemed that this
18438: excitement was just what he expected.
18439: 
18440: “Ah! it is you, Romola. Maso is gone to bed,” he said, in a grave,
18441: quiet tone, interposing to close the door for her. Then, turning round,
18442: he said, looking at her more fully than he was wont, “You have heard it
18443: all, I see.”
18444: 
18445: Romola quivered. _He_ then was inclined to take the initiative. He had
18446: been to Tessa. She led the way through the nearest door, set down her
18447: lamp, and turned towards him again.
18448: 
18449: “You must not think despairingly of the consequences,” said Tito, in a
18450: tone of soothing encouragement, at which Romola stood wondering, until
18451: he added, “The accused have too many family ties with all parties not
18452: to escape; and Messer Bernardo del Nero has other things in his favour
18453: besides his age.”
18454: 
18455: Romola started, and gave a cry as if she had been suddenly stricken by
18456: a sharp weapon.
18457: 
18458: “What! you did not know it?” said Tito, putting his hand under her arm
18459: that he might lead her to a seat; but she seemed to be unaware of his
18460: touch.
18461: 
18462: “Tell me,” she said, hastily—“tell me what it is.”
18463: 
18464: “A man, whose name you may forget—Lamberto dell’ Antella—who was
18465: banished, has been seized within the territory: a letter has been found
18466: on him of very dangerous import to the chief Mediceans, and the
18467: scoundrel, who was once a favourite hound of Piero de’ Medici, is ready
18468: now to swear what any one pleases against him or his friends. Some have
18469: made their escape, but five are now in prison.”
18470: 
18471: “My godfather?” said Romola, scarcely above a whisper, as Tito made a
18472: slight pause.
18473: 
18474: “Yes: I grieve to say it. But along with him there are three, at least,
18475: whose names have a commanding interest even among the popular
18476: party—Niccolò Ridolfi, Lorenzo Tornabuoni, and Giannozzo Pucci.”
18477: 
18478: The tide of Romola’s feelings had been violently turned into a new
18479: channel. In the tumult of that moment there could be no check to the
18480: words which came as the impulsive utterance of her long-accumulating
18481: horror. When Tito had named the men of whom she felt certain he was the
18482: confederate, she said, with a recoiling gesture and low-toned
18483: bitterness—
18484: 
18485: “And _you_—you are safe?”
18486: 
18487: “You are certainly an amiable wife, my Romola,” said Tito, with the
18488: coldest irony. “Yes; I am safe.”
18489: 
18490: They turned away from each other in silence.
18491: 
18492: 
18493: 
18494: 
18495: CHAPTER LVII.
18496: Why Tito was Safe.
18497: 
18498: 
18499: Tito had good reasons for saying that he was safe. In the last three
18500: months, during which he had foreseen the discovery of the Medicean
18501: conspirators as a probable event, he had had plenty of time to provide
18502: himself with resources. He had been strengthening his influence at Rome
18503: and at Milan, by being the medium of secret information and indirect
18504: measures against the Frate and the popular party; he had cultivated
18505: more assiduously than ever the regard of this party, by showing subtle
18506: evidence that his political convictions were entirely on their side;
18507: and all the while, instead of withdrawing his agency from the
18508: Mediceans, he had sought to be more actively employed and exclusively
18509: trusted by them. It was easy to him to keep up this triple game. The
18510: principle of duplicity admitted by the Mediceans on their own behalf
18511: deprived them of any standard by which they could measure the
18512: trustworthiness of a colleague who had not, like themselves, hereditary
18513: interests, alliances, and prejudices, which were intensely Medicean. In
18514: their minds, to deceive the opposite party was fair stratagem; to
18515: deceive their own party was a baseness to which they felt no
18516: temptation; and, in using Tito’s facile ability, they were not keenly
18517: awake to the fact that the absence of traditional attachments which
18518: made him a convenient agent was also the absence of what among
18519: themselves was the chief guarantee of mutual honour. Again, the Roman
18520: and Milanese friends of the aristocratic party, or Arrabbiati, who were
18521: the bitterest enemies of Savonarola, carried on a system of underhand
18522: correspondence and espionage, in which the deepest hypocrisy was the
18523: best service, and demanded the heaviest pay; so that to suspect an
18524: agent because he played a part strongly would have been an absurd want
18525: of logic. On the other hand, the Piagnoni of the popular party, who had
18526: the directness that belongs to energetic conviction, were the more
18527: inclined to credit Tito with sincerity in his political adhesion to
18528: them, because he affected no religious sympathies.
18529: 
18530: By virtue of these conditions, the last three months had been a time of
18531: flattering success to Tito. The result he most cared for was the
18532: securing of a future position for himself at Rome or at Milan; for he
18533: had a growing determination, when the favourable moment should come, to
18534: quit Florence for one of those great capitals where life was easier,
18535: and the rewards of talent and learning were more splendid. At present,
18536: the scale dipped in favour of Milan; and if within the year he could
18537: render certain services to Duke Ludovico Sforza, he had the prospect of
18538: a place at the Milanese court which outweighed the advantages of Rome.
18539: 
18540: The revelation of the Medicean conspiracy, then, had been a subject of
18541: forethought to Tito; but he had not been able to foresee the mode in
18542: which it would be brought about. The arrest of Lamberto dell’ Antella
18543: with a tell-tale letter on his person, and a bitter rancour against the
18544: Medici in his heart, was an incalculable event. It was not possible, in
18545: spite of the careful pretexts with which his agency had been guarded,
18546: that Tito should escape implication: he had never expected this in case
18547: of any wide discovery concerning the Medicean plots. But his quick mind
18548: had soon traced out the course that would secure his own safety with
18549: the fewest unpleasant concomitants. It is agreeable to keep a whole
18550: skin; but the skin still remains an organ sensitive to the atmosphere.
18551: 
18552: His reckoning had not deceived him. That night, before he returned
18553: home, he had secured the three results for which he most cared: he was
18554: to be freed from all proceedings against him on account of complicity
18555: with the Mediceans; he was to retain his secretaryship for another
18556: year, unless he previously resigned it; and, lastly, the price by which
18557: he had obtained these guarantees was to be kept as a State secret. The
18558: price would have been thought heavy by most men; and Tito himself would
18559: rather not have paid it.
18560: 
18561: He had applied himself first to win the mind of Francesco Valori, who
18562: was not only one of the Ten under whom he immediately held his
18563: secretaryship, but one of the special council appointed to investigate
18564: the evidence of the plot. Francesco Valori, as we have seen, was the
18565: head of the Piagnoni, a man with certain fine qualities that were not
18566: incompatible with violent partisanship, with an arrogant temper that
18567: alienated his friends, nor with bitter personal animosities—one of the
18568: bitterest being directed against Bernardo del Nero. To him, in a brief
18569: private interview, after obtaining a pledge of secrecy, Tito avowed his
18570: own agency for the Mediceans—an agency induced by motives about which
18571: he was very frank, declaring at the same time that he had always
18572: believed their efforts futile, and that he sincerely preferred the
18573: maintenance of the popular government; affected to confide to Valori,
18574: as a secret, his own personal dislike for Bernardo del Nero; and, after
18575: this preparation, came to the important statement that there was
18576: another Medicean plot, of which, if he obtained certain conditions from
18577: the government, he could, by a journey to Siena and into Romagna, where
18578: Piero de’ Medici was again trying to gather forces, obtain documentary
18579: evidence to lay before the council. To this end it was essential that
18580: his character as a Medicean agent should be unshaken for all Mediceans,
18581: and hence the fact that he had been a source of information to the
18582: authorities must be wrapped in profound secrecy. Still, some odour of
18583: the facts might escape in spite of precaution, and before Tito could
18584: incur the unpleasant consequences of acting against his friends, he
18585: must be assured of immunity from any prosecution as a Medicean, and
18586: from deprivation of office for a year to come.
18587: 
18588: These propositions did not sound in the ear of Francesco Valori
18589: precisely as they sound to us. Valori’s mind was not intensely bent on
18590: the estimation of Tito’s conduct; and it _was_ intensely bent on
18591: procuring an extreme sentence against the five prisoners. There were
18592: sure to be immense efforts to save them; and it was to be wished (on
18593: public grounds) that the evidence against them should be of the
18594: strongest, so as to alarm all well-affected men at the dangers of
18595: clemency. The character of legal proceedings at that time implied that
18596: evidence was one of those desirable things which could only be come at
18597: by foul means. To catch a few people and torture them into confessing
18598: everybody’s guilt was one step towards justice; and it was not always
18599: easy to see the next, unless a traitor turned up. Lamberto dell’
18600: Antella had been tortured in aid of his previous willingness to tell
18601: more than he knew; nevertheless, additional and stronger facts were
18602: desirable, especially against Bernardo del Nero, who, so far as
18603: appeared hitherto, had simply refrained from betraying the late plot
18604: after having tried in vain to discourage it; for the welfare of
18605: Florence demanded that the guilt of Bernardo del Nero should be put in
18606: the strongest light. So Francesco Valori zealously believed; and
18607: perhaps he was not himself aware that the strength of his zeal was
18608: determined by his hatred. He decided that Tito’s proposition ought to
18609: be accepted, laid it before his colleagues without disclosing Tito’s
18610: name, and won them over to his opinion. Late in the day, Tito was
18611: admitted to an audience of the Special Council, and produced a deep
18612: sensation among them by revealing another plot for insuring the mastery
18613: of Florence to Piero de’ Medici, which was to have been carried into
18614: execution in the middle of this very month of August. Documentary
18615: evidence on this subject would do more than anything else to make the
18616: right course clear. He received a commission to start for Siena by
18617: break of day; and, besides this, he carried away with him from the
18618: council-chamber a written guarantee of his immunity and of his
18619: retention of office.
18620: 
18621: Among the twenty Florentines who bent their grave eyes on Tito, as he
18622: stood gracefully before them, speaking of startling things with easy
18623: periphrasis, and with that apparently unaffected admission of being
18624: actuated by motives short of the highest, which is often the intensest
18625: affectation, there were several whose minds were not too entirely
18626: preoccupied to pass a new judgment on him in these new circumstances;
18627: they silently concluded that this ingenious and serviceable Greek was
18628: in future rather to be used for public needs than for private intimacy.
18629: Unprincipled men were useful, enabling those who had more scruples to
18630: keep their hands tolerably clean in a world where there was much dirty
18631: work to be done. Indeed, it was not clear to respectable Florentine
18632: brains, unless they held the Frate’s extravagant belief in a possible
18633: purity and loftiness to be striven for on this earth, how life was to
18634: be carried on in any department without human instruments whom it would
18635: not be unbecoming to kick or to spit upon in the act of handing them
18636: their wages. Some of these very men who passed a tacit judgment on Tito
18637: were shortly to be engaged in a memorable transaction that could by no
18638: means have been carried through without the use of an unscrupulousness
18639: as decided as his; but, as their own bright poet Pulci had said for
18640: them, it is one thing to love the fruits of treachery, and another
18641: thing to love traitors—
18642: 
18643: 
18644: “Il tradimento a molti piace assai,
18645: Ma il traditore a gnun non piacque mal.”
18646: 
18647: 
18648: The same society has had a gibbet for the murderer and a gibbet for the
18649: martyr, an execrating hiss for a dastardly act, and as loud a hiss for
18650: many a word of generous truthfulness or just insight: a mixed condition
18651: of things which is the sign, not of hopeless confusion, but of
18652: struggling order.
18653: 
18654: For Tito himself, he was not unaware that he had sunk a little in the
18655: estimate of the men who had accepted his services. He had that degree
18656: of self-contemplation which necessarily accompanies the habit of acting
18657: on well-considered reasons, of whatever quality; and if he could have
18658: chosen, he would have declined to see himself disapproved by men of the
18659: world. He had never meant to be disapproved; he had meant always to
18660: conduct himself so ably that if he acted in opposition to the standard
18661: of other men they should not be aware of it; and the barrier between
18662: himself and Romola had been raised by the impossibility of such
18663: concealment with her. He shrank from condemnatory judgments as from a
18664: climate to which he could not adapt himself. But things were not so
18665: plastic in the hands of cleverness as could be wished, and events had
18666: turned out inconveniently. He had really no rancour against Messer
18667: Bernardo del Nero: he had a personal liking for Lorenzo Tornabuoni and
18668: Giannozzo Pucci. He had served them very ably, and in such a way that
18669: if their party had been winners he would have merited high reward; but
18670: was he to relinquish all the agreeable fruits of life because their
18671: party had failed? His proffer of a little additional proof against them
18672: would probably have no influence on their fate; in fact, he felt
18673: convinced they would escape any extreme consequences; but if he had not
18674: given it, his own fortunes, which made a promising fabric, would have
18675: been utterly ruined. And what motive could any man really have, except
18676: his own interest? Florentines whose passions were engaged in their
18677: petty and precarious political schemes might have no self-interest
18678: separable from family pride and tenacity in old hatreds and
18679: attachments; a modern simpleton who swallowed whole one of the old
18680: systems of philosophy, and took the indigestion it occasioned for the
18681: signs of a divine afflux or the voice of an inward monitor, might see
18682: his interest in a form of self-conceit which he called self-rewarding
18683: virtue; fanatics who believed in the coming Scourge and Renovation
18684: might see their own interest in a future palm-branch and white robe:
18685: but no man of clear intellect allowed his course to be determined by
18686: such puerile impulses or questionable inward fumes. Did not Pontanus,
18687: poet and philosopher of unrivalled Latinity, make the finest possible
18688: oration at Naples to welcome the French king, who had come to dethrone
18689: the learned orator’s royal friend and patron? and still Pontanus held
18690: up his head and prospered. Men did not really care about these things,
18691: except when their personal spleen was touched. It was weakness only
18692: that was despised; power of any sort carried its immunity; and no man,
18693: unless by very rare good fortune, could mount high in the world without
18694: incurring a few unpleasant necessities which laid him open to enmity,
18695: and perhaps to a little hissing, when enmity wanted a pretext.
18696: 
18697: It was a faint prognostic of that hissing, gathered by Tito from
18698: certain indications when he was before the council, which gave his
18699: present conduct the character of an epoch to him, and made him dwell on
18700: it with argumentative vindication. It was not that he was taking a
18701: deeper step in wrong-doing, for it was not possible that he should feel
18702: any tie to the Mediceans to be stronger than the tie to his father; but
18703: his conduct to his father had been hidden by successful lying: his
18704: present act did not admit of total concealment—in its very nature it
18705: was a revelation. And Tito winced under his new liability to disesteem.
18706: 
18707: Well! a little patience, and in another year, or perhaps in half a
18708: year, he might turn his back on these hard, eager Florentines, with
18709: their futile quarrels and sinking fortunes. His brilliant success at
18710: Florence had had some ugly flaws in it: he had fallen in love with the
18711: wrong woman, and Baldassarre had come back under incalculable
18712: circumstances. But as Tito galloped with a loose rein towards Siena, he
18713: saw a future before him in which he would no longer be haunted by those
18714: mistakes. He had much money safe out of Florence already; he was in the
18715: fresh ripeness of eight-and-twenty; he was conscious of well-tried
18716: skill. Could he not strip himself of the past, as of rehearsal
18717: clothing, and throw away the old bundle, to robe himself for the real
18718: scene?
18719: 
18720: It did not enter into Tito’s meditations on the future, that, on
18721: issuing from the council-chamber and descending the stairs, he had
18722: brushed against a man whose face he had not stayed to recognise in the
18723: lamplight. The man was Ser Ceccone—also willing to serve the State by
18724: giving information against unsuccessful employers.
18725: 
18726: 
18727: 
18728: 
18729: CHAPTER LVIII.
18730: A Final Understanding.
18731: 
18732: 
18733: Tito soon returned from Siena, but almost immediately set out on
18734: another journey, from which he did not return till the seventeenth of
18735: August. Nearly a fortnight had passed since the arrest of the accused,
18736: and still they were in prison, still their fate was uncertain. Romola
18737: had felt during this interval as if all cares were suspended for her,
18738: other than watching the fluctuating probabilities concerning that fate.
18739: Sometimes they seemed strongly in favour of the prisoners; for the
18740: chances of effective interest on their behalf were heightened by delay,
18741: and an indefinite prospect of delay was opened by the reluctance of all
18742: persons in authority to incur the odium attendant on any decision. On
18743: the one side there was a loud cry that the Republic was in danger, and
18744: that lenity to the prisoners would be the signal of attack for all its
18745: enemies; on the other, there was a certainty that a sentence of death
18746: and confiscation of property passed on five citizens of distinguished
18747: name, would entail the rancorous hatred of their relatives on all who
18748: were conspicuously instrumental to such a sentence.
18749: 
18750: The final judgment properly lay with the Eight, who presided over the
18751: administration of criminal justice; and the sentence depended on a
18752: majority of six votes. But the Eight shrank from their onerous
18753: responsibility, and asked in this exceptional case to have it shared by
18754: the Signoria (or the Gonfaloniere and the eight Priors). The Signoria
18755: in its turn shrugged its shoulders, and proposed the appeal to the
18756: Great Council. For, according to a law passed by the earnest persuasion
18757: of Savonarola nearly three years before, whenever a citizen was
18758: condemned to death by the fatal six votes (called the _set fave_ or
18759: _six beans_, beans being in more senses than one the political pulse of
18760: Florence), he had the right of appealing from that sentence to the
18761: Great Council.
18762: 
18763: But in this stage of the business, the friends of the accused resisted
18764: the appeal, determined chiefly by the wish to gain delay; and, in fact,
18765: strict legality required that sentence should have been passed prior to
18766: the appeal. Their resistance prevailed, and a middle course was taken;
18767: the sentence was referred to a large assembly convened on the
18768: seventeenth, consisting of all the higher magistracies, the smaller
18769: council or Senate of Eighty, and a select number of citizens.
18770: 
18771: On this day Romola, with anxiety heightened by the possibility that
18772: before its close her godfather’s fate might be decided, had obtained
18773: leave to see him for the second time, but only in the presence of
18774: witnesses. She had returned to the Via de’ Bardi in company with her
18775: cousin Brigida, still ignorant whether the council had come to any
18776: decisive issue; and Monna Brigida had gone out again to await the
18777: momentous news at the house of a friend belonging to one of the
18778: magistracies, that she might bring back authentic tidings as soon as
18779: they were to be had.
18780: 
18781: Romola had sunk on the first seat in the bright saloon, too much
18782: agitated, too sick at heart, to care about her place, or be conscious
18783: of discordance in the objects that surrounded her. She sat with her
18784: back to the door, resting her head on her hands. It seemed a long while
18785: since Monna Brigida had gone, and Romola was expecting her return. But
18786: when the door opened she knew it was not Monna Brigida who entered.
18787: 
18788: Since she had parted from Tito on that memorable night, she had had no
18789: external proof to warrant her belief that he had won his safety by
18790: treachery; on the contrary, she had had evidence that he was still
18791: trusted by the Mediceans, and was believed by them to be accomplishing
18792: certain errands of theirs in Romagna, under cover of fulfilling a
18793: commission of the government. For the obscurity in which the evidence
18794: concerning the conspirators was shrouded allowed it to be understood
18795: that Tito had escaped any implication.
18796: 
18797: But Romola’s suspicion was not to be dissipated: her horror of his
18798: conduct towards Baldassarre projected itself over every conception of
18799: his acts; it was as if she had seen him committing a murder, and had
18800: had a diseased impression ever after that his hands were covered with
18801: fresh blood.
18802: 
18803: As she heard his step on the stone floor, a chill shudder passed
18804: through her; she could not turn round, she could not rise to give any
18805: greeting. He did not speak, but after an instant’s pause took a seat on
18806: the other side of the table just opposite to her. Then she raised her
18807: eyes and looked at him; but she was mute. He did not show any
18808: irritation, but said, coolly—
18809: 
18810: “This meeting corresponds with our parting, Romola. But I understand
18811: that it is a moment of terrible suspense. I am come, however, if you
18812: will listen to me, to bring you the relief of hope.”
18813: 
18814: She started, and altered her position, but looked at him dubiously.
18815: 
18816: “It will not be unwelcome to you to hear—even though it is I who tell
18817: it—that the council is prorogued till the twenty-first. The Eight have
18818: been frightened at last into passing a sentence of condemnation, but
18819: the demand has now been made on behalf of the condemned for the Appeal
18820: to the Great Council.”
18821: 
18822: Romola’s face lost its dubious expression; she asked eagerly—
18823: 
18824: “And when is it to be made?”
18825: 
18826: “It has not yet been granted; but it _may_ be granted. The Special
18827: Council is to meet again on the twenty-first to deliberate whether the
18828: Appeal shall be allowed or not. In the meantime there is an interval of
18829: three days, in which chances may occur in favour of the prisoners—in
18830: which interest may be used on their behalf.”
18831: 
18832: Romola started from her seat. The colour had risen to her face like a
18833: visible thought, and her hands trembled. In that moment her feeling
18834: towards Tito was forgotten.
18835: 
18836: “Possibly,” said Tito, also rising, “your own intention may have
18837: anticipated what I was going to say. You are thinking of the Frate.”
18838: 
18839: “I am,” said Romola, looking at him with surprise. “Has he done
18840: anything? Is there anything to tell me?”
18841: 
18842: “Only this. It was Messer Francesco Valori’s bitterness and violence
18843: which chiefly determined the course of things in the council to-day.
18844: Half the men who gave in their opinion against the prisoners were
18845: frightened into it, and there are numerous friends of Fra Girolamo both
18846: in this Special Council and out of it who are strongly opposed to the
18847: sentence of death—Piero Guicciardini, for example, who is one member of
18848: the Signoria that made the stoutest resistance; and there is Giovan
18849: Battista Ridolfi, who, Piagnone as he is, will not lightly forgive the
18850: death of his brother Niccolò.”
18851: 
18852: “But how can the Appeal be denied,” said Romola, indignantly, “when it
18853: is the law—when it was one of the chief glories of the popular
18854: government to have passed the law?”
18855: 
18856: “They call this an exceptional case. Of course there are ingenious
18857: arguments, but there is much more of loud bluster about the danger of
18858: the Republic. But, you see, no opposition could prevent the assembly
18859: from being prorogued, and a certain powerful influence rightly applied
18860: during the next three days might determine the wavering courage of
18861: those who desire that the Appeal should be granted, and might even give
18862: a check to the headlong enmity of Francesco Valori. It happens to have
18863: come to my knowledge that the Frate has so far interfered as to send a
18864: message to him in favour of Lorenzo Tornabuoni. I know you can
18865: sometimes have access to the Frate: it might at all events be worth
18866: while to use your privilege now.”
18867: 
18868: “It is true,” said Romola, with an air of abstraction. “I cannot
18869: believe that the Frate would approve denying the Appeal.”
18870: 
18871: “I heard it said by more than one person in the court of the Palazzo,
18872: before I came away, that it would be to the everlasting discredit of
18873: Fra Girolamo if he allowed a government which is almost entirely made
18874: up of his party, to deny the Appeal, without entering his protest, when
18875: he has been boasting in his books and sermons that it was he who got
18876: the law passed.[1] But between ourselves, with all respect for your
18877: Frate’s ability, my Romola, he has got into the practice of preaching
18878: that form of human sacrifices called killing tyrants and wicked
18879: malcontents, which some of his followers are likely to think
18880: inconsistent with lenity in the present case.”
18881: 
18882:  [1] The most recent, and in some respects the best, biographer of
18883:  Savonarola, Signor Villari, endeavours to show that the Law of Appeal
18884:  ultimately enacted, being wider than the law originally contemplated
18885:  by Savonarola, was a source of bitter annoyance to him, as a
18886:  contrivance of the aristocratic party for attaching to the measures of
18887:  the popular government the injurious results of licence. But in taking
18888:  this view the estimable biographer lost sight of the fact that, not
18889:  only in his sermons, but in a deliberately prepared book (the
18890:  _Compendium Revelationum_) written long after the Appeal had become
18891:  law, Savonarola enumerates among the benefits secured to Florence,
18892:  “_the Appeal from the Six Votes, advocated by me, for the greater
18893:  security of the citizens_.”
18894: 
18895: 
18896: “I know, I know,” said Romola, with a look and tone of pain. “But he is
18897: driven into those excesses of speech. It used to be different. I _will_
18898: ask for an interview. I cannot rest without it. I trust in the
18899: greatness of his heart.”
18900: 
18901: She was not looking at Tito; her eyes were bent with a vague gaze
18902: towards the ground, and she had no distinct consciousness that the
18903: words she heard came from her husband.
18904: 
18905: “Better lose no time, then,” said Tito, with unmixed suavity, moving
18906: his cap round in his hands as if he were about to put it on and depart.
18907: “And now, Romola, you will perhaps be able to see, in spite of
18908: prejudice, that my wishes go with yours in this matter. You will not
18909: regard the misfortune of my safety as an offence.”
18910: 
18911: Something like an electric shock passed through Romola: it was the full
18912: consciousness of her husband’s presence returning to her. She looked at
18913: him without speaking.
18914: 
18915: “At least,” he added, in a slightly harder tone, “you will endeavour to
18916: base our intercourse on some other reasonings than that because an evil
18917: deed is possible, _I_ have done it. Am I alone to be beyond the pale of
18918: your extensive charity?”
18919: 
18920: The feeling which had been driven back from Romola’s lips a fortnight
18921: before rose again with the gathered force of a tidal wave. She spoke
18922: with a decision which told him that she was careless of consequences.
18923: 
18924: “It is too late, Tito. There is no killing the suspicion that deceit
18925: has once begotten. And now I know everything. I know who that old man
18926: was: he was your father, to whom you owe everything—to whom you owe
18927: more than if you had been his own child. By the side of that, it is a
18928: small thing that you broke my trust and my father’s. As long as you
18929: deny the truth about that old man, there is a horror rising between us:
18930: the law that should make us one can never be obeyed. I too am a human
18931: being. I have a soul of my own that abhors your actions. Our union is a
18932: pretence—as if a perpetual lie could be a sacred marriage.”
18933: 
18934: Tito did not answer immediately. When he did speak it was with a
18935: calculated caution, that was stimulated by alarm.
18936: 
18937: “And you mean to carry out that independence by quitting me, I
18938: presume?”
18939: 
18940: “I desire to quit you,” said Romola, impetuously.
18941: 
18942: “And supposing I do not submit to part with what the law gives me some
18943: security for retaining? You will then, of course, proclaim your reasons
18944: in the ear of all Florence. You will bring forward your mad assassin,
18945: who is doubtless ready to obey your call, and you will tell the world
18946: that you believe his testimony because he is so rational as to desire
18947: to assassinate me. You will first inform the Signoria that I am a
18948: Medicean conspirator, and then you will inform the Mediceans that I
18949: have betrayed them, and in both cases you will offer the excellent
18950: proof that you believe me capable in general of everything bad. It will
18951: certainly be a striking position for a wife to adopt. And if, on such
18952: evidence, you succeed in holding me up to infamy, you will have
18953: surpassed all the heroines of the Greek drama.”
18954: 
18955: He paused a moment, but she stood mute. He went on with the sense of
18956: mastery.
18957: 
18958: “I believe you have no other grievance against me—except that I have
18959: failed in fulfilling some lofty indefinite conditions on which you gave
18960: me your wifely affection, so that, by withdrawing it, you have
18961: gradually reduced me to the careful supply of your wants as a fair
18962: Piagnone of high condition and liberal charities. I think your success
18963: in gibbeting me is not certain. But doubtless you would begin by
18964: winning the ear of Messer Bernardo del Nero?”
18965: 
18966: “Why do I speak of anything?” cried Romola, in anguish, sinking on her
18967: chair again. “It is hateful in me to be thinking of myself.”
18968: 
18969: She did not notice when Tito left the room, or know how long it was
18970: before the door opened to admit Monna Brigida. But in that instant she
18971: started up and said—
18972: 
18973: “Cousin, we must go to San Marco directly. I must see my confessor, Fra
18974: Salvestro.”
18975: 
18976: 
18977: 
18978: 
18979: CHAPTER LIX.
18980: Pleading.
18981: 
18982: 
18983: The morning was in its early brightness when Romola was again on her
18984: way to San Marco, having obtained through Fra Salvestro, the evening
18985: before, the promise of an interview with Fra Girolamo in the
18986: chapter-house of the convent. The rigidity with which Savonarola
18987: guarded his life from all the pretexts of calumny made such interviews
18988: very rare, and whenever they were granted, they were kept free from any
18989: appearance of mystery. For this reason the hour chosen was one at which
18990: there were likely to be other visitors in the outer cloisters of San
18991: Marco.
18992: 
18993: She chose to pass through the heart of the city that she might notice
18994: the signs of public feeling. Every loggia, every convenient corner of
18995: the piazza, every shop that made a rendezvous for gossips, was astir
18996: with the excitement of gratuitous debate; a languishing trade tending
18997: to make political discussion all the more vigorous. It was clear that
18998: the parties for and against the death of the conspirators were bent on
18999: making the fullest use of the three days’ interval in order to
19000: determine the popular mood. Already handbills were in circulation; some
19001: presenting, in large print, the alternative of justice on the
19002: conspirators or ruin to the Republic; others in equally large print
19003: urging the observance of the law and the granting of the Appeal. Round
19004: these jutting islets of black capitals there were lakes of smaller
19005: characters setting forth arguments less necessary to be read: for it
19006: was an opinion entertained at that time (in the first flush of triumph
19007: at the discovery of printing), that there was no argument more widely
19008: convincing than question-begging phrases in large type.
19009: 
19010: Romola, however, cared especially to become acquainted with the
19011: arguments in smaller type, and, though obliged to hasten forward, she
19012: looked round anxiously as she went that she might miss no opportunity
19013: of securing copies. For a long way she saw none but such as were in the
19014: hands of eager readers, or else fixed on the walls, from which in some
19015: places the sbirri were tearing them down. But at last, passing behind
19016: San Giovanni with a quickened pace that she might avoid the many
19017: acquaintances who frequented the piazza, she saw Bratti with a stock of
19018: handbills which he appeared to be exchanging for small coin with the
19019: passers-by. She was too familiar with the humble life of Florence for
19020: Bratti to be any stranger to her, and turning towards him she said,
19021: “Have you two sorts of handbills, Bratti? Let me have them quickly.”
19022: 
19023: “Two sorts,” said Bratti, separating the wet sheets with a slowness
19024: that tried Romola’s patience. “There’s ‘Law,’ and there’s ‘Justice.’”
19025: 
19026: “Which sort do you sell most of?”
19027: 
19028: “‘Justice’—‘Justice’ goes the quickest,—so I raised the price, and made
19029: it two danari. But then I bethought me the ‘Law’ was good ware too, and
19030: had as good a right to be charged for as ‘Justice;’ for people set no
19031: store by cheap things, and if I sold the ‘Law’ at one danaro, I should
19032: be doing it a wrong. And I’m a fair trader. ‘Law,’ or ‘Justice,’ it’s
19033: all one to me; they’re good wares. I got ’em both for nothing, and I
19034: sell ’em at a fair profit. But you’ll want more than one of a sort?”
19035: 
19036: “No, no: here’s a white quattrino for the two,” said Romola, folding up
19037: the bills and hurrying away.
19038: 
19039: She was soon in the outer cloisters of San Marco, where Fra Salvestro
19040: was awaiting her under the cloister, but did not notice the approach of
19041: her light step. He was chatting, according to his habit, with lay
19042: visitors; for under the auspices of a government friendly to the Frate,
19043: the timidity about frequenting San Marco, which had followed on the
19044: first shock of the Excommunication, had been gradually giving way. In
19045: one of these lay visitors she recognised a well-known satellite of
19046: Francesco Valori, named Andrea Cambini, who was narrating or expounding
19047: with emphatic gesticulation, while Fra Salvestro was listening with
19048: that air of trivial curiosity which tells that the listener cares very
19049: much about news and very little about its quality. This characteristic
19050: of her confessor, which was always repulsive to Romola, was made
19051: exasperating to her at this moment by the certainty she gathered, from
19052: the disjointed words which reached her ear, that Cambini was narrating
19053: something relative to the fate of the conspirators. She chose not to
19054: approach the group, but as soon as she saw that she had arrested Fra
19055: Salvestro’s attention, she turned towards the door of the
19056: chapter-house, while he, making a sign of approval, disappeared within
19057: the inner cloister. A lay Brother stood ready to open the door of the
19058: chapter-house for her, and closed it behind her as she entered.
19059: 
19060: Once more looked at by those sad frescoed figures which had seemed to
19061: be mourning with her at the death of her brother Dino, it was
19062: inevitable that something of that scene should come back to her; but
19063: the intense occupation of her mind with the present made the
19064: remembrance less a retrospect than an indistinct recurrence of
19065: impressions which blended themselves with her agitating fears, as if
19066: her actual anxiety were a revival of the strong yearning she had once
19067: before brought to this spot—to be repelled by marble rigidity. She gave
19068: no space for the remembrance to become more definite, for she at once
19069: opened the handbills, thinking she should perhaps be able to read them
19070: in the interval before Fra Girolamo appeared. But by the time she had
19071: read to the end of the one that recommended the observance of the law,
19072: the door was opening, and doubling up the papers she stood expectant.
19073: 
19074: When the Frate had entered she knelt, according to the usual practice
19075: of those who saw him in private; but as soon as he had uttered a
19076: benedictory greeting she rose and stood opposite to him at a few yards’
19077: distance. Owing to his seclusion since he had been excommunicated, it
19078: had been an unusually long while since she had seen him, and the late
19079: months had visibly deepened in his face the marks of over-taxed mental
19080: activity and bodily severities; and yet Romola was not so conscious of
19081: this change as of another, which was less definable. Was it that the
19082: expression of serene elevation and pure human fellowship which had once
19083: moved her was no longer present in the same force, or was it that the
19084: sense of his being divided from her in her feeling about her godfather
19085: roused the slumbering sources of alienation, and marred her own vision?
19086: Perhaps both causes were at work. Our relations with our fellow-men are
19087: most often determined by coincident currents of that sort; the
19088: inexcusable word or deed seldom comes until after affection or
19089: reverence has been already enfeebled by the strain of repeated excuses.
19090: 
19091: It was true that Savonarola’s glance at Romola had some of that
19092: hardness which is caused by an egotistic prepossession. He divined that
19093: the interview she had sought was to turn on the fate of the
19094: conspirators, a subject on which he had already had to quell inner
19095: voices that might become loud again when encouraged from without.
19096: Seated in his cell, correcting the sheets of his ‘Triumph of the
19097: Cross,’ it was easier to repose on a resolution of neutrality.
19098: 
19099: “It is a question of moment, doubtless, on which you wished to see me,
19100: my daughter,” he began, in a tone which was gentle rather from
19101: self-control than from immediate inclination. “I know you are not wont
19102: to lay stress on small matters.”
19103: 
19104: “Father, you know what it is before I tell you,” said Romola,
19105: forgetting everything else as soon as she began to pour forth her plea.
19106: “You know what I am caring for—it is for the life of the old man I love
19107: best in the world. The thought of him has gone together with the
19108: thought of my father as long as I remember the daylight. That is my
19109: warrant for coming to you, even if my coming should have been needless.
19110: Perhaps it is: perhaps you have already determined that your power over
19111: the hearts of men shall be used to prevent them from denying to
19112: Florentines a right which you yourself helped to earn for them.”
19113: 
19114: “I meddle not with the functions of the State, my daughter,” said Fra
19115: Girolamo, strongly disinclined to reopen externally a debate which he
19116: had already gone through inwardly. “I have preached and laboured that
19117: Florence should have a good government, for a good government is
19118: needful to the perfecting of the Christian life; but I keep away my
19119: hands from particular affairs which it is the office of experienced
19120: citizens to administer.”
19121: 
19122: “Surely, father—” Romola broke off. She had uttered this first word
19123: almost impetuously, but she was checked by the counter-agitation of
19124: feeling herself in an attitude of remonstrance towards the man who had
19125: been the source of guidance and strength to her. In the act of
19126: rebelling she was bruising her own reverence.
19127: 
19128: Savonarola was too keen not to divine something of the conflict that
19129: was arresting her—too noble, deliberately to assume in calm speech that
19130: self-justifying evasiveness into which he was often hurried in public
19131: by the crowding impulses of the orator.
19132: 
19133: “Say what is in your heart; speak on, my daughter,” he said, standing
19134: with his arms laid one upon the other, and looking at her with quiet
19135: expectation.
19136: 
19137: “I was going to say, father, that this matter is surely of higher
19138: moment than many about which I have heard you preach and exhort
19139: fervidly. If it belonged to you to urge that men condemned for offences
19140: against the State should have the right to appeal to the Great
19141: Council—if—” Romola was getting eager again—“if you count it a glory to
19142: have won that right for them, can it less belong to you to declare
19143: yourself against the right being denied to almost the first men who
19144: need it? Surely that touches the Christian life more closely than
19145: whether you knew beforehand that the Dauphin would die, or whether Pisa
19146: will be conquered.”
19147: 
19148: There was a subtle movement, like a subdued sign of pain, in
19149: Savonarola’s strong lips, before he began to speak.
19150: 
19151: “My daughter, I speak as it is given me to speak—I am not master of the
19152: times when I may become the vehicle of knowledge beyond the common
19153: lights of men. In this case I have no illumination beyond what wisdom
19154: may give to those who are charged with the safety of the State. As to
19155: the law of Appeal against the Six Votes, I laboured to have it passed
19156: in order that no Florentine should be subject to loss of life and goods
19157: through the private hatred of a few who might happen to be in power;
19158: but these five men, who have desired to overthrow a free government and
19159: restore a corrupt tyrant, have been condemned with the assent of a
19160: large assembly of their fellow-citizens. They refused at first to have
19161: their cause brought before the Great Council. They have lost the right
19162: to the appeal.”
19163: 
19164: “How can they have lost it?” said Romola. “It is the right to appeal
19165: against condemnation, and they have never been condemned till now; and,
19166: forgive me, father, it _is_ private hatred that would deny them the
19167: appeal; it _is_ the violence of the few that frightens others; else why
19168: was the assembly divided again directly after it had seemed to agree?
19169: And if anything weighs against the observance of the law, let this
19170: weigh for it—this, that you used to preach more earnestly than all
19171: else, that there should be no place given to hatred and bloodshed
19172: because of these party strifes, so that private ill-will should not
19173: find its opportunities in public acts. Father, you know that there is
19174: private hatred concerned here: will it not dishonour you not to have
19175: interposed on the side of mercy, when there are many who hold that it
19176: is also the side of law and justice?”
19177: 
19178: “My daughter,” said Fra Girolamo, with more visible emotion than
19179: before, “there is a mercy which is weakness, and even treason against
19180: the common good. The safety of Florence, which means even more than the
19181: welfare of Florentines, now demands severity, as it once demanded
19182: mercy. It is not only for a past plot that these men are condemned, but
19183: also for a plot which has not yet been executed; and the devices that
19184: were leading to its execution are not put an end to: the tyrant is
19185: still gathering his forces in Romagna, and the enemies of Florence, who
19186: sit in the highest places of Italy, are ready to hurl any stone that
19187: will crush her.”
19188: 
19189: “What plot?” said Romola, reddening, and trembling with alarmed
19190: surprise.
19191: 
19192: “You carry papers in your hand, I see,” said Fra Girolamo, pointing to
19193: the handbills. “One of them will, perhaps, tell you that the government
19194: has had new information.”
19195: 
19196: Romola hastily opened the handbill she had not yet read, and saw that
19197: the government had now positive evidence of a second plot, which was to
19198: have been carried out in this August time. To her mind it was like
19199: reading a confirmation that Tito had won his safety by foul means; his
19200: pretence of wishing that the Frate should exert himself on behalf of
19201: the condemned only helped the wretched conviction. She crushed up the
19202: paper in her hand, and, turning to Savonarola, she said, with new
19203: passion, “Father, what safety can there be for Florence when the worst
19204: man can always escape? And,” she went on, a sudden flash of remembrance
19205: coming from the thought about her husband, “have not you yourself
19206: encouraged this deception which corrupts the life of Florence, by
19207: wanting more favour to be shown to Lorenzo Tornabuoni, who has worn two
19208: faces, and flattered you with a show of affection, when my godfather
19209: has always been honest? Ask all Florence who of those five men has the
19210: truest heart, and there will not be many who will name any other name
19211: than Bernardo del Nero. You did interpose with Francesco Valori for the
19212: sake of one prisoner: you have _not_ then been neutral; and you know
19213: that your word will be powerful.”
19214: 
19215: “I do not desire the death of Bernardo,” said Savonarola, colouring
19216: deeply. “It would be enough if he were sent out of the city.”
19217: 
19218: “Then why do you not speak to save an old man of seventy-five from
19219: dying a death of ignominy—to give him at least the fair chances of the
19220: law?” burst out Romola, the impetuosity of her nature so roused that
19221: she forgot everything but her indignation. “It is not that you feel
19222: bound to be neutral; else why did you speak for Lorenzo Tornabuoni? You
19223: spoke for him because he is more friendly to San Marco; my godfather
19224: feigns no friendship. It is not, then, as a Medicean that my godfather
19225: is to die; it is as a man you have no love for!”
19226: 
19227: When Romola paused, with cheeks glowing, and with quivering lips, there
19228: was dead silence. As she saw Fra Girolamo standing motionless before
19229: her, she seemed to herself to be hearing her own words over again;
19230: words that in this echo of consciousness were in strange, painful
19231: dissonance with the memories that made part of his presence to her. The
19232: moments of silence were expanded by gathering compunction and
19233: self-doubt. She had committed sacrilege in her passion. And even the
19234: sense that she could retract nothing of her plea, that her mind could
19235: not submit itself to Savonarola’s negative, made it the more needful to
19236: her to satisfy those reverential memories. With a sudden movement
19237: towards him she said—
19238: 
19239: “Forgive me, father; it is pain to me to have spoken those words—yet I
19240: cannot help speaking. I am little and feeble compared with you; you
19241: brought me light and strength. But I submitted because I felt the
19242: proffered strength—because I saw the light. _Now_ I cannot see it.
19243: Father, you yourself declare that there comes a moment when the soul
19244: must have no guide but the voice within it, to tell whether the
19245: consecrated thing has sacred virtue. And therefore I must speak.”
19246: 
19247: Savonarola had that readily-roused resentment towards opposition,
19248: hardly separable from a power-loving and powerful nature, accustomed to
19249: seek great ends that cast a reflected grandeur on the means by which
19250: they are sought. His sermons have much of that red flame in them. And
19251: if he had been a meaner man his susceptibility might have shown itself
19252: in irritation at Romola’s accusatory freedom, which was in strong
19253: contrast with the deference he habitually received from his disciples.
19254: But at this moment such feelings were nullified by that hard struggle
19255: which made half the tragedy of his life—the struggle of a mind
19256: possessed by a never-silent hunger after purity and simplicity, yet
19257: caught in a tangle of egoistic demands, false ideas, and difficult
19258: outward conditions, that made simplicity impossible. Keenly alive to
19259: all the suggestions of Romola’s remonstrating words, he was rapidly
19260: surveying, as he had done before, the courses of action that were open
19261: to him, and their probable results. But it was a question on which
19262: arguments could seem decisive only in proportion as they were charged
19263: with feeling, and he had received no impulse that could alter his bias.
19264: He looked at Romola, and said—
19265: 
19266: “You have full pardon for your frankness, my daughter. You speak, I
19267: know, out of the fulness of your family affections. But these
19268: affections must give way to the needs of the Republic. If those men who
19269: have a close acquaintance with the affairs of the State believe, as I
19270: understand they do, that the public safety requires the extreme
19271: punishment of the law to fall on the five conspirators, I cannot
19272: control their opinion, seeing that I stand aloof from such affairs.”
19273: 
19274: “Then you desire that they should die? You desire that the Appeal
19275: should be denied them?” said Romola, feeling anew repelled by a
19276: vindication which seemed to her to have the nature of a subterfuge.
19277: 
19278: “I have said that I do not desire their death.”
19279: 
19280: “Then,” said Romola, her indignation rising again, “you can be
19281: indifferent that Florentines should inflict death which you do not
19282: desire, when you might have protested against it—when you might have
19283: helped to hinder it, by urging the observance of a law which you held
19284: it good to get passed. Father, you used not to stand aloof: you used
19285: not to shrink from protesting. Do not say you cannot protest where the
19286: lives of men are concerned; say rather, you desire their death. Say
19287: rather, you hold it good for Florence that there shall be more blood
19288: and more hatred. Will the death of five Mediceans put an end to parties
19289: in Florence? Will the death of a noble old man like Bernardo del Nero
19290: save a city that holds such men as Dolfo Spini?”
19291: 
19292: “My daughter, it is enough. The cause of freedom, which is the cause of
19293: God’s kingdom upon earth, is often most injured by the enemies who
19294: carry within them the power of certain human virtues. The wickedest man
19295: is often not the most insurmountable obstacle to the triumph of good.”
19296: 
19297: “Then why do you say again, that you do not desire my godfather’s
19298: death?” said Romola, in mingled anger and despair. “Rather, you hold it
19299: the more needful he should die because he is the better man. I cannot
19300: unravel your thoughts, father; I cannot hear the real voice of your
19301: judgment and conscience.”
19302: 
19303: There was a moment’s pause. Then Savonarola said, with keener emotion
19304: than he had yet shown—
19305: 
19306: “Be thankful, my daughter, if your own soul has been spared perplexity;
19307: and judge not those to whom a harder lot has been given. _You_ see one
19308: ground of action in this matter. I see many. I have to choose that
19309: which will further the work intrusted to me. The end I seek is one to
19310: which minor respects must be sacrificed. The death of five men—were
19311: they less guilty than these—is a light matter weighed against the
19312: withstanding of the vicious tyrannies which stifle the life of Italy,
19313: and foster the corruption of the Church; a light matter weighed against
19314: the furthering of God’s kingdom upon earth, the end for which I live
19315: and am willing myself to die.”
19316: 
19317: Under any other circumstances, Romola would have been sensitive to the
19318: appeal at the beginning of Savonarola’s speech; but at this moment she
19319: was so utterly in antagonism with him, that what he called perplexity
19320: seemed to her sophistry and doubleness; and as he went on, his words
19321: only fed that flame of indignation, which now again, more fully than
19322: ever before, lit up the memory of all his mistakes, and made her trust
19323: in him seem to have been a purblind delusion. She spoke almost with
19324: bitterness.
19325: 
19326: “Do you, then, know so well what will further the coming of God’s
19327: kingdom, father, that you will dare to despise the plea of mercy—of
19328: justice—of faithfulness to your own teaching? Has the French king,
19329: then, brought renovation to Italy? Take care, father, lest your enemies
19330: have some reason when they say, that in your visions of what will
19331: further God’s kingdom you see only what will strengthen your own
19332: party.”
19333: 
19334: “And that is true!” said Savonarola, with flashing eyes. Romola’s voice
19335: had seemed to him in that moment the voice of his enemies. “The cause
19336: of my party _is_ the cause of God’s kingdom.”
19337: 
19338: “I do not believe it!” said Romola, her whole frame shaken with
19339: passionate repugnance. “God’s kingdom is something wider—else, let me
19340: stand outside it with the beings that I love.”
19341: 
19342: The two faces were lit up, each with an opposite emotion, each with an
19343: opposite certitude. Further words were impossible. Romola hastily
19344: covered her head and went out in silence.
19345: 
19346: 
19347: 
19348: 
19349: CHAPTER LX.
19350: The Scaffold.
19351: 
19352: 
19353: Three days later the moon that was just surmounting the buildings of
19354: the piazza in front of the Old Palace within the hour of midnight, did
19355: not make the usual broad lights and shadows on the pavement. Not a
19356: hand’s-breadth of pavement was to be seen, but only the heads of an
19357: eager struggling multitude. And instead of that background of silence
19358: in which the pattering footsteps and buzzing voices, the lute-thrumming
19359: or rapid scampering of the many night wanderers of Florence stood out
19360: in obtrusive distinctness, there was the background of a roar from
19361: mingled shouts and imprecations, tramplings and pushings, and
19362: accidental clashing of weapons, across which nothing was
19363: distinguishable but a darting shriek, or the heavy dropping toll of a
19364: bell.
19365: 
19366: Almost all who could call themselves the public of Florence were awake
19367: at that hour, and either enclosed within the limits of that piazza, or
19368: struggling to enter it. Within the palace were still assembled in the
19369: council-chamber all the chief magistracies, the eighty members of the
19370: senate, and the other select citizens who had been in hot debate
19371: through long hours of daylight and torchlight whether the Appeal should
19372: be granted or whether the sentence of death should be executed on the
19373: prisoners forthwith, to forestall the dangerous chances of delay. And
19374: the debate had been so much like fierce quarrel that the noise from the
19375: council-chamber had reached the crowd outside. Only within the last
19376: hour had the question been decided: the Signoria had remained divided,
19377: four of them standing out resolutely for the Appeal in spite of the
19378: strong argument that if they did not give way their houses should be
19379: sacked, until Francesco Valori, in brief and furious speech, made the
19380: determination of his party more ominously distinct by declaring that if
19381: the Signoria would not defend the liberties of the Florentine people by
19382: executing those five perfidious citizens, there would not be wanting
19383: others who would take that cause in hand to the peril of all who
19384: opposed it. The Florentine Cato triumphed. When the votes were counted
19385: again, the four obstinate white beans no longer appeared; the whole
19386: nine were of the fatal affirmative black, deciding the death of the
19387: five prisoners without delay—deciding also, only tacitly and with much
19388: more delay, the death of Francesco Valori.
19389: 
19390: And now, while the judicial Eight were gone to the Bargello to prepare
19391: for the execution, the five condemned men were being led barefoot and
19392: in irons through the midst of the council. It was their friends who had
19393: contrived this: would not Florentines be moved by the visible
19394: association of such cruel ignominy with two venerable men like Bernardo
19395: del Nero and Niccolò Ridolfi, who had taken their bias long before the
19396: new order of things had come to make Mediceanism retrograde—with two
19397: brilliant popular young men like Tornabuoni and Pucci, whose absence
19398: would be felt as a haunting vacancy wherever there was a meeting of
19399: chief Florentines? It was useless: such pity as could be awakened now
19400: was of that hopeless sort which leads not to rescue, but to the tardier
19401: action of revenge.
19402: 
19403: While this scene was passing upstairs Romola stood below against one of
19404: the massive pillars in the court of the palace, expecting the moment
19405: when her godfather would appear, on his way to execution. By the use of
19406: strong interest she had gained permission to visit him in the evening
