19407: of this day, and remain with him until the result of the council should
19408: be determined. And now she was waiting with his confessor to follow the
19409: guard that would lead him to the Bargello. Her heart was bent on
19410: clinging to the presence of the childless old man to the last moment,
19411: as her father would have done; and she had overpowered all
19412: remonstrances. Giovan Battista Ridolfi, a disciple of Savonarola, who
19413: was going in bitterness to behold the death of his elder brother
19414: Niccolò, had promised that she should be guarded, and now stood by her
19415: side.
19416: 
19417: Tito, too, was in the palace; but Romola had not seen him. Since the
19418: evening of the seventeenth they had avoided each other, and Tito only
19419: knew by inference from the report of the Frate’s neutrality that her
19420: pleading had failed. He was now surrounded with official and other
19421: personages, both Florentine and foreign, who had been awaiting the
19422: issue of the long-protracted council, maintaining, except when he was
19423: directly addressed, the subdued air and grave silence of a man whom
19424: actual events are placing in a painful state of strife between public
19425: and private feeling. When an allusion was made to his wife in relation
19426: to those events, he implied that, owing to the violent excitement of
19427: her mind, the mere fact of his continuing to hold office under a
19428: government concerned in her godfather’s condemnation, roused in her a
19429: diseased hostility towards him; so that for her sake he felt it best
19430: not to approach her.
19431: 
19432: “Ah, the old Bardi blood!” said Cennini, with a shrug. “I shall not be
19433: surprised if this business shakes _her_ loose from the Frate, as well
19434: as some others I could name.”
19435: 
19436: “It is excusable in a woman, who is doubtless beautiful, since she is
19437: the wife of Messer Tito,” said a young French envoy, smiling and bowing
19438: to Tito, “to think that her affections must overrule the good of the
19439: State, and that nobody is to be beheaded who is anybody’s cousin; but
19440: such a view is not to be encouraged in the male population. It seems to
19441: me your Florentine polity is much weakened by it.”
19442: 
19443: “That is true,” said Niccolò Macchiavelli; “but where personal ties are
19444: strong, the hostilities they raise must be taken due account of. Many
19445: of these half-way severities are mere hot-headed blundering. The only
19446: safe blows to be inflicted on men and parties are the blows that are
19447: too heavy to be avenged.”
19448: 
19449: “Niccolò,” said Cennini, “there is a clever wickedness in thy talk
19450: sometimes that makes me mistrust thy pleasant young face as if it were
19451: a mask of Satan.”
19452: 
19453: “Not at all, my good Domenico,” said Macchiavelli, smiling, and laying
19454: his hand on the elder’s shoulder. “Satan was a blunderer, an introducer
19455: of _novita_, who made a stupendous failure. If he had succeeded, we
19456: should all have been worshipping him, and his portrait would have been
19457: more flattered.”
19458: 
19459: “Well, well,” said Cennini, “I say not thy doctrine is not too clever
19460: for Satan: I only say it is wicked enough for him.”
19461: 
19462: “I tell you,” said Macchiavelli, “my doctrine is the doctrine of all
19463: men who seek an end a little farther off than their own noses. Ask our
19464: Frate, our prophet, how his universal renovation is to be brought
19465: about: he will tell you, first, by getting a free and pure government;
19466: and since it appears that this cannot be done by making all Florentines
19467: love each other, it must be done by cutting off every head that happens
19468: to be obstinately in the way. Only if a man incurs odium by sanctioning
19469: a severity that is not thorough enough to be final, he commits a
19470: blunder. And something like that blunder, I suspect, the Frate has
19471: committed. It was an occasion on which he might have won some lustre by
19472: exerting himself to maintain the Appeal; instead of that, he has lost
19473: lustre, and has gained no strength.”
19474: 
19475: Before any one else could speak, there came the expected announcement
19476: that the prisoners were about to leave the council-chamber; and the
19477: majority of those who were present hurried towards the door, intent on
19478: securing the freest passage to the Bargello in the rear of the
19479: prisoners’ guard; for the scene of the execution was one that drew
19480: alike those who were moved by the deepest passions and those who were
19481: moved by the coldest curiosity.
19482: 
19483: Tito was one of those who remained behind. He had a native repugnance
19484: to sights of death and pain, and five days ago whenever he had thought
19485: of this execution as a possibility he had hoped that it would not take
19486: place, and that the utmost sentence would be exile: his own safety
19487: demanded no more. But now he felt that it would be a welcome guarantee
19488: of his security when he had learned that Bernardo del Nero’s head was
19489: off the shoulders. The new knowledge and new attitude towards him
19490: disclosed by Romola on the day of his return, had given him a new dread
19491: of the power she possessed to make his position insecure. If any act of
19492: hers only succeeded in making him an object of suspicion and odium, he
19493: foresaw not only frustration, but frustration under unpleasant
19494: circumstances. Her belief in Baldassarre had clearly determined her
19495: wavering feelings against further submission, and if her godfather
19496: lived she would win him to share her belief without much trouble.
19497: Romola seemed more than ever an unmanageable fact in his destiny. But
19498: if Bernardo del Nero were dead, the difficulties that would beset her
19499: in placing herself in opposition to her husband would probably be
19500: insurmountable to her shrinking pride. Therefore Tito had felt easier
19501: when he knew that the Eight had gone to the Bargello to order the
19502: instant erection of the scaffold. Four other men—his intimates and
19503: confederates—were to die, besides Bernardo del Nero. But a man’s own
19504: safety is a god that sometimes makes very grim demands. Tito felt them
19505: to be grim: even in the pursuit of what was agreeable, this paradoxical
19506: life forced upon him the desire for what was disagreeable. But he had
19507: had other experience of this sort, and as he heard through the open
19508: doorway the shuffle of many feet and the clanking of metal on the
19509: stairs, he was able to answer the questions of the young French envoy
19510: without showing signs of any other feeling than that of sad resignation
19511: to State necessities.
19512: 
19513: Those sounds fell on Romola as if her power of hearing had been exalted
19514: along with every other sensibility of her nature. She needed no arm to
19515: support her; she shed no tears. She felt that intensity of life which
19516: seems to transcend both grief and joy—in which the mind seems to itself
19517: akin to elder forces that wrought out existence before the birth of
19518: pleasure and pain. Since her godfather’s fate had been decided, the
19519: previous struggle of feeling in her had given way to an identification
19520: of herself with him in these supreme moments: she was inwardly
19521: asserting for him that, if he suffered the punishment of treason, he
19522: did not deserve the name of traitor; he was the victim to a collision
19523: between two kinds of faithfulness. It was not given him to die for the
19524: noblest cause, and yet he died because of his nobleness. He might have
19525: been a meaner man and found it easier not to incur this guilt. Romola
19526: was feeling the full force of that sympathy with the individual lot
19527: that is continually opposing itself to the formulae by which actions
19528: and parties are judged. She was treading the way with her second father
19529: to the scaffold, and nerving herself to defy ignominy by the
19530: consciousness that it was not deserved.
19531: 
19532: The way was fenced in by three hundred armed men, who had been placed
19533: as a guard by the orders of Francesco Valori, for among the apparent
19534: contradictions that belonged to this event, not the least striking was
19535: the alleged alarm on the one hand at the popular rage against the
19536: conspirators, and the alleged alarm on the other lest there should be
19537: an attempt to rescue them in the midst of a hostile crowd. When they
19538: had arrived within the court of the Bargello, Romola was allowed to
19539: approach Bernardo with his confessor for a moment of farewell. Many
19540: eyes were bent on them even in that struggle of an agitated throng, as
19541: the aged man, forgetting that his hands were bound with irons, lifted
19542: them towards the golden head that was bent towards him, and then,
19543: checking that movement, leaned to kiss her. She seized the fettered
19544: hands that were hung down again, and kissed them as if they had been
19545: sacred things.
19546: 
19547: “My poor Romola,” said Bernardo, in a low voice, “I have only to die,
19548: but thou hast to live—and I shall not be there to help thee.”
19549: 
19550: “Yes,” said Romola, hurriedly, “you _will_ help me—always—because I
19551: shall remember you.”
19552: 
19553: She was taken away and conducted up the flight of steps that led to the
19554: loggia surrounding the grand old court. She took her place there,
19555: determined to look till the moment when her godfather laid his head on
19556: the block. Now while the prisoners were allowed a brief interval with
19557: their confessor, the spectators were pressing into court until the
19558: crowd became dense around the black scaffold, and the torches fixed in
19559: iron rings against the pillars threw a varying startling light at one
19560: moment on passionless stone carvings, at another on some pale face
19561: agitated with suppressed rage or suppressed grief—the face of one among
19562: the many near relatives of the condemned, who were presently to receive
19563: their dead and carry them home.
19564: 
19565: Romola’s face looked like a marble image against the dark arch as she
19566: stood watching for the moment when her godfather would appear at the
19567: foot of the scaffold. He was to suffer first, and Battista Ridolfi, who
19568: was by her side, had promised to take her away through a door behind
19569: them when she would have seen the last look of the man who alone in all
19570: the world had shared her pitying love for her father. And still, in the
19571: background of her thought, there was the possibility striving to be a
19572: hope, that some rescue might yet come, something that would keep that
19573: scaffold unstained by blood.
19574: 
19575: For a long while there was constant movement, lights flickering, heads
19576: swaying to and fro, confused voices within the court, rushing waves of
19577: sound through the entrance from without. It seemed to Romola as if she
19578: were in the midst of a storm-troubled sea, caring nothing about the
19579: storm, caring only to hold out a signal till the eyes that looked for
19580: it could seek it no more.
19581: 
19582: Suddenly there was stillness, and the very tapers seemed to tremble
19583: into quiet. The executioner was ready on the scaffold, and Bernardo del
19584: Nero was seen ascending it with a slow firm step. Romola made no
19585: visible movement, uttered not even a suppressed sound: she stood more
19586: firmly, caring for _his_ firmness. She saw him pause, saw the white
19587: head kept erect, while he said, in a voice distinctly audible—
19588: 
19589: “It is but a short space of life that my fellow-citizens have taken
19590: from me.”
19591: 
19592: She perceived that he was gazing slowly round him as he spoke. She felt
19593: that his eyes were resting on her, and that she was stretching out her
19594: arms towards him. Then she saw no more till—a long while after, as it
19595: seemed—a voice said, “My daughter, all is peace now. I can conduct you
19596: to your house.”
19597: 
19598: She uncovered her head and saw her godfather’s confessor standing by
19599: her, in a room where there were other grave men talking in subdued
19600: tones.
19601: 
19602: “I am ready,” she said, starting up. “Let us lose no time.”
19603: 
19604: She thought all clinging was at an end for her: all her strength now
19605: should be given to escape from a grasp under which she shuddered.
19606: 
19607: 
19608: 
19609: 
19610: CHAPTER LXI.
19611: Drifting Away.
19612: 
19613: 
19614: On the eighth day from that memorable night Romola was standing on the
19615: brink of the Mediterranean, watching the gentle summer pulse of the sea
19616: just above what was then the little fishing village of Viareggio.
19617: 
19618: Again she had fled from Florence, and this time no arresting voice had
19619: called her back. Again she wore the grey religious dress; and this
19620: time, in her heart-sickness, she did not care that it was a disguise. A
19621: new rebellion had risen within her, a new despair. Why should she care
19622: about wearing one badge more than another, or about being called by her
19623: own name? She despaired of finding any consistent duty belonging to
19624: that name. What force was there to create for her that supremely
19625: hallowed motive which men call duty, but which can have no inward
19626: constraining existence save through some form of believing love?
19627: 
19628: The bonds of all strong affection were snapped. In her marriage, the
19629: highest bond of all, she had ceased to see the mystic union which is
19630: its own guarantee of indissolubleness, had ceased even to see the
19631: obligation of a voluntary pledge: had she not proved that the things to
19632: which she had pledged herself were impossible? The impulse to set
19633: herself free had risen again with overmastering force; yet the freedom
19634: could only be an exchange of calamity. There is no compensation for the
19635: woman who feels that the chief relation of her life has been no more
19636: than a mistake. She has lost her crown. The deepest secret of human
19637: blessedness has half whispered itself to her, and then for ever passed
19638: her by.
19639: 
19640: And now Romola’s best support under that supreme woman’s sorrow had
19641: slipped away from her. The vision of any great purpose, any end of
19642: existence which could ennoble endurance and exalt the common deeds of a
19643: dusty life with divine ardours, was utterly eclipsed for her now by the
19644: sense of a confusion in human things which made all effort a mere
19645: dragging at tangled threads; all fellowship, either for resistance or
19646: advocacy, mere unfairness and exclusiveness. What, after all, was the
19647: man who had represented for her the highest heroism: the heroism not of
19648: hard, self-contained endurance, but of willing, self-offering love?
19649: What was the cause he was struggling for? Romola had lost her trust in
19650: Savonarola, had lost that fervour of admiration which had made her
19651: unmindful of his aberrations, and attentive only to the grand curve of
19652: his orbit. And now that her keen feeling for her godfather had thrown
19653: her into antagonism with the Frate, she saw all the repulsive and
19654: inconsistent details in his teaching with a painful lucidity which
19655: exaggerated their proportions. In the bitterness of her disappointment
19656: she said that his striving after the renovation of the Church and the
19657: world was a striving after a mere name which told no more than the
19658: title of a book: a name that had come to mean practically the measures
19659: that would strengthen his own position in Florence; nay, often
19660: questionable deeds and words, for the sake of saving his influence from
19661: suffering by his own errors. And that political reform which had once
19662: made a new interest in her life seemed now to reduce itself to narrow
19663: devices for the safety of Florence, in contemptible contradiction with
19664: the alternating professions of blind trust in the Divine care.
19665: 
19666: It was inevitable that she should judge the Frate unfairly on a
19667: question of individual suffering, at which she looked with the eyes of
19668: personal tenderness, and _he_ with the eyes of theoretic conviction. In
19669: that declaration of his, that the cause of his party was the cause of
19670: God’s kingdom, she heard only the ring of egoism. Perhaps such words
19671: have rarely been uttered without that meaner ring in them; yet they are
19672: the implicit formula of all energetic belief. And if such energetic
19673: belief, pursuing a grand and remote end, is often in danger of becoming
19674: a demon-worship, in which the votary lets his son and daughter pass
19675: through the fire with a readiness that hardly looks like sacrifice;
19676: tender fellow-feeling for the nearest has its danger too, and is apt to
19677: be timid and sceptical towards the larger aims without which life
19678: cannot rise into religion. In this way poor Romola was being blinded by
19679: her tears.
19680: 
19681: No one who has ever known what it is thus to lose faith in a fellow-man
19682: whom he has profoundly loved and reverenced, will lightly say that the
19683: shock can leave the faith in the Invisible Goodness unshaken. With the
19684: sinking of high human trust, the dignity of life sinks too; we cease to
19685: believe in our own better self, since that also is part of the common
19686: nature which is degraded in our thought; and all the finer impulses of
19687: the soul are dulled. Romola felt even the springs of her once active
19688: pity drying up, and leaving her to barren egoistic complaining. Had not
19689: _she_ had her sorrows too? And few had cared for her, while she had
19690: cared for many. She had done enough; she had striven after the
19691: impossible, and was weary of this stifling crowded life. She longed for
19692: that repose in mere sensation which she had sometimes dreamed of in the
19693: sultry afternoons of her early girlhood, when she had fancied herself
19694: floating naïad-like in the waters.
19695: 
19696: The clear waves seemed to invite her: she wished she could lie down to
19697: sleep on them and pass from sleep into death. But Romola could not
19698: directly seek death; the fulness of young life in her forbade that. She
19699: could only wish that death would come.
19700: 
19701: At the spot where she had paused there was a deep bend in the shore,
19702: and a small boat with a sail was moored there. In her longing to glide
19703: over the waters that were getting golden with the level sun-rays, she
19704: thought of a story which had been one of the things she had loved to
19705: dwell on in Boccaccio, when her father fell asleep and she glided from
19706: her stool to sit on the floor and read the ‘Decamerone.’ It was the
19707: story of that fair Gostanza who in her lovelorn-ness desired to live no
19708: longer, but not having the courage to attack her young life, had put
19709: herself into a boat and pushed off to sea; then, lying down in the
19710: boat, had wrapt her mantle round her head, hoping to be wrecked, so
19711: that her fear would be helpless to flee from death. The memory had
19712: remained a mere thought in Romola’s mind, without budding into any
19713: distinct wish; but now, as she paused again in her walking to and fro,
19714: she saw gliding black against the red gold another boat with one man in
19715: it, making towards the bend where the first and smaller boat was
19716: moored. Walking on again, she at length saw the man land, pull his boat
19717: ashore and begin to unload something from it. He was perhaps the owner
19718: of the smaller boat also: he would be going away soon, and her
19719: opportunity would be gone with him—her opportunity of buying that
19720: smaller boat. She had not yet admitted to herself that she meant to use
19721: it, but she felt a sudden eagerness to secure the possibility of using
19722: it, which disclosed the half-unconscious growth of a thought into a
19723: desire.
19724: 
19725: “Is that little boat yours also?” she said to the fisherman, who had
19726: looked up, a little startled by the tall grey figure, and had made a
19727: reverence to this holy Sister wandering thus mysteriously in the
19728: evening solitude.
19729: 
19730: It _was_ his boat; an old one, hardly seaworthy, yet worth repairing to
19731: any man who would buy it. By the blessing of San Antonio, whose chapel
19732: was in the village yonder, his fishing had prospered, and he had now a
19733: better boat, which had once been Gianni’s who died. But he had not yet
19734: sold the old one. Romola asked him how much it was worth, and then,
19735: while he was busy, thrust the price into a little satchel lying on the
19736: ground and containing the remnant of his dinner. After that, she
19737: watched him furling his sail and asked him how he should set it if he
19738: wanted to go out to sea, and then pacing up and down again, waited to
19739: see him depart.
19740: 
19741: The imagination of herself gliding away in that boat on the darkening
19742: waters was growing more and more into a longing, as the thought of a
19743: cool brook in sultriness becomes a painful thirst. To be freed from the
19744: burden of choice when all motive was bruised, to commit herself,
19745: sleeping, to destiny which would either bring death or else new
19746: necessities that might rouse a new life in her!—it was a thought that
19747: beckoned her the more because the soft evening air made her long to
19748: rest in the still solitude, instead of going back to the noise and heat
19749: of the village.
19750: 
19751: At last the slow fisherman had gathered up all his movables and was
19752: walking away. Soon the gold was shrinking and getting duskier in sea
19753: and sky, and there was no living thing in sight, no sound but the
19754: lulling monotony of the lapping waves. In this sea there was no tide
19755: that would help to carry her away if she waited for its ebb; but Romola
19756: thought the breeze from the land was rising a little. She got into the
19757: boat, unfurled the sail, and fastened it as she had learned in that
19758: first brief lesson. She saw that it caught the light breeze, and this
19759: was all she cared for. Then she loosed the boat from its moorings, and
19760: tried to urge it with an oar, till she was far out from the land, till
19761: the sea was dark even to the west, and the stars were disclosing
19762: themselves like a palpitating life over the wide heavens. Resting at
19763: last, she threw back her cowl, and, taking off the kerchief underneath,
19764: which confined her hair, she doubled them both under her head for a
19765: pillow on one of the boat’s ribs. The fair head was still very young
19766: and could bear a hard pillow.
19767: 
19768: And so she lay, with the soft night air breathing on her while she
19769: glided on the water and watched the deepening quiet of the sky. She was
19770: alone now: she had freed herself from all claims, she had freed herself
19771: even from that burden of choice which presses with heavier and heavier
19772: weight when claims have loosed their guiding hold.
19773: 
19774: Had she found anything like the dream of her girlhood? No. Memories
19775: hung upon her like the weight of broken wings that could never be
19776: lifted—memories of human sympathy which even in its pains leaves a
19777: thirst that the Great Mother has no milk to still. Romola felt orphaned
19778: in those wide spaces of sea and sky. She read no message of love for
19779: her in that far-off symbolic writing of the heavens, and with a great
19780: sob she wished that she might be gliding into death.
19781: 
19782: She drew the cowl over her head again and covered her face, choosing
19783: darkness rather than the light of the stars, which seemed to her like
19784: the hard light of eyes that looked at her without seeing her. Presently
19785: she felt that she was in the grave, but not resting there: she was
19786: touching the hands of the beloved dead beside her, and trying to wake
19787: them.
19788: 
19789: 
19790: 
19791: 
19792: CHAPTER LXII.
19793: The Benediction.
19794: 
19795: 
19796: About ten o’clock on the morning of the twenty-seventh of February the
19797: currents of passengers along the Florentine streets set decidedly
19798: towards San Marco. It was the last morning of the Carnival, and every
19799: one knew there was a second Bonfire of Vanities being prepared in front
19800: of the Old Palace; but at this hour it was evident that the centre of
19801: popular interest lay elsewhere.
19802: 
19803: The Piazza di San Marco was filled by a multitude who showed no other
19804: movement than that which proceeded from the pressure of new-comers
19805: trying to force their way forward from all the openings: but the front
19806: ranks were already close-serried and resisted the pressure. Those ranks
19807: were ranged around a semicircular barrier in front of the church, and
19808: within this barrier were already assembling the Dominican Brethren of
19809: San Marco.
19810: 
19811: But the temporary wooden pulpit erected over the church-door was still
19812: empty. It was presently to be entered by the man whom the Pope’s
19813: command had banished from the pulpit of the Duomo, whom the other
19814: ecclesiastics of Florence had been forbidden to consort with, whom the
19815: citizens had been forbidden to hear on pain of excommunication. This
19816: man had said, “A wicked, unbelieving Pope who has gained the pontifical
19817: chair by bribery is not Christ’s Vicar. His curses are broken swords:
19818: he grasps a hilt without a blade. His commands are contrary to the
19819: Christian life: it is lawful to disobey them—nay, _it is not lawful to
19820: obey them_.” And the people still flocked to hear him as he preached in
19821: his own church of San Marco, though the Pope was hanging terrible
19822: threats over Florence if it did not renounce the pestilential
19823: schismatic and send him to Rome to be “converted”—still, as on this
19824: very morning, accepted the Communion from his excommunicated hands. For
19825: how if this Frate had really more command over the Divine lightnings
19826: than that official successor of Saint Peter? It was a momentous
19827: question, which for the mass of citizens could never be decided by the
19828: Frate’s ultimate test, namely, what was and what was not accordant with
19829: the highest spiritual law. No: in such a case as this, if God had
19830: chosen the Frate as his prophet to rebuke the High Priest who carried
19831: the mystic raiment unworthily, he would attest his choice by some
19832: unmistakable sign. As long as the belief in the Prophet carried no
19833: threat of outward calamity, but rather the confident hope of
19834: exceptional safety, no sign was needed: his preaching was a music to
19835: which the people felt themselves marching along the way they wished to
19836: go; but now that belief meant an immediate blow to their commerce, the
19837: shaking of their position among the Italian States, and an interdict on
19838: their city, there inevitably came the question, “What miracle showest
19839: thou?” Slowly at first, then faster and faster, that fatal demand had
19840: been swelling in Savonarola’s ear, provoking a response, outwardly in
19841: the declaration that at the fitting time the miracle would come;
19842: inwardly in the faith—not unwavering, for what faith is so?—that if the
19843: need for miracle became urgent, the work he had before him was too
19844: great for the Divine power to leave it halting. His faith wavered, but
19845: not his speech: it is the lot of every man who has to speak for the
19846: satisfaction of the crowd, that he must often speak in virtue of
19847: yesterday’s faith, hoping it will come back to-morrow.
19848: 
19849: It was in preparation for a scene which was really a response to the
19850: popular impatience for some supernatural guarantee of the Prophet’s
19851: mission, that the wooden pulpit had been erected above the church-door.
19852: But while the ordinary Frati in black mantles were entering and
19853: arranging themselves, the faces of the multitude were not yet eagerly
19854: directed towards the pulpit: it was felt that Savonarola would not
19855: appear just yet, and there was some interest in singling out the
19856: various monks, some of them belonging to high Florentine families, many
19857: of them having fathers, brothers, or cousins among the artisans and
19858: shopkeepers who made the majority of the crowd. It was not till the
19859: tale of monks was complete, not till they had fluttered their books and
19860: had begun to chant, that people said to each other, “Fra Girolamo must
19861: be coming now.”
19862: 
19863: That expectation rather than any spell from the accustomed wail of
19864: psalmody was what made silence and expectation seem to spread like a
19865: paling solemn light over the multitude of upturned faces, all now
19866: directed towards the empty pulpit.
19867: 
19868: The next instant the pulpit was no longer empty. A figure covered from
19869: head to foot in black cowl and mantle had entered it, and was kneeling
19870: with bent head and with face turned away. It seemed a weary time to the
19871: eager people while the black figure knelt and the monks chanted. But
19872: the stillness was not broken, for the Frate’s audiences with Heaven
19873: were yet charged with electric awe for that mixed multitude, so that
19874: those who had already the will to stone him felt their arms unnerved.
19875: 
19876: At last there was a vibration among the multitude, each seeming to give
19877: his neighbour a momentary aspen-like touch, as when men who have been
19878: watching for something in the heavens see the expected presence
19879: silently disclosing itself. The Frate had risen, turned towards the
19880: people, and partly pushed back his cowl. The monotonous wail of
19881: psalmody had ceased, and to those who stood near the pulpit, it was as
19882: if the sounds which had just been filling their ears had suddenly
19883: merged themselves in the force of Savonarola’s flashing glance, as he
19884: looked round him in the silence. Then he stretched out his hands,
19885: which, in their exquisite delicacy, seemed transfigured from an animal
19886: organ for grasping into vehicles of sensibility too acute to need any
19887: gross contact: hands that came like an appealing speech from that part
19888: of his soul which was masked by his strong passionate face, written on
19889: now with deeper lines about the mouth and brow than are made by
19890: forty-four years of ordinary life.
19891: 
19892: At the first stretching out of the hands some of the crowd in the front
19893: ranks fell on their knees, and here and there a devout disciple farther
19894: off; but the great majority stood firm, some resisting the impulse to
19895: kneel before this excommunicated man (might not a great judgment fall
19896: upon him even in this act of blessing?)—others jarred with scorn and
19897: hatred of the ambitious deceiver who was getting up this new comedy,
19898: before which, nevertheless, they felt themselves impotent, as before
19899: the triumph of a fashion.
19900: 
19901: But then came the voice, clear and low at first, uttering the words of
19902: absolution—“_Misereatur vestri_”—and more fell on their knees: and as
19903: it rose higher and yet clearer, the erect heads became fewer and fewer,
19904: till, at the words “_Benedicat vos omnipotens Deus_” it rose to a
19905: masculine cry, as if protesting its power to bless under the clutch of
19906: a demon that wanted to stifle it: it rang like a trumpet to the
19907: extremities of the Piazza, and under it every head was bowed.
19908: 
19909: After the utterance of that blessing, Savonarola himself fell on his
19910: knees and hid his face in temporary exhaustion. Those great jets of
19911: emotion were a necessary part of his life; he himself had said to the
19912: people long ago, “Without preaching I cannot live.” But it was a life
19913: that shattered him.
19914: 
19915: In a few minutes more, some had risen to their feet, but a larger
19916: number remained kneeling, and all faces were intently watching him. He
19917: had taken into his hands a crystal vessel, containing the consecrated
19918: Host, and was about to address the people.
19919: 
19920: “You remember, my children, three days ago I besought you, when I
19921: should hold this Sacrament in my hand in the face of you all, to pray
19922: fervently to the Most High that if this work of mine does not come from
19923: Him, He will send a fire and consume me, that I may vanish into the
19924: eternal darkness away from His light which I have hidden with my
19925: falsity. Again I beseech you to make that prayer, and to make it
19926: _now_.”
19927: 
19928: It was a breathless moment: perhaps no man really prayed, if some in a
19929: spirit of devout obedience made the effort to pray. Every consciousness
19930: was chiefly possessed by the sense that Savonarola was praying, in a
19931: voice not loud, but distinctly audible in the wide stillness.
19932: 
19933: “Lord, if I have not wrought in sincerity of soul, if my word cometh
19934: not from Thee, strike me in this moment with Thy thunder, and let the
19935: fires of Thy wrath enclose me.”
19936: 
19937: He ceased to speak, and stood motionless, with the consecrated Mystery
19938: in his hand, with eyes uplifted, and a quivering excitement in his
19939: whole aspect. Every one else was motionless and silent too, while the
19940: sunlight, which for the last quarter of an hour had here and there been
19941: piercing the greyness, made fitful streaks across the convent wall,
19942: causing some awe-stricken spectators to start timidly. But soon there
19943: was a wider parting, and with a gentle quickness, like a smile, a
19944: stream of brightness poured itself on the crystal vase, and then spread
19945: itself over Savonarola’s face with mild glorification.
19946: 
19947: An instantaneous shout rang through the Piazza, “Behold the answer!”
19948: 
19949: The warm radiance thrilled through Savonarola’s frame, and so did the
19950: shout. It was his last moment of untroubled triumph, and in its
19951: rapturous confidence he felt carried to a grander scene yet to come,
19952: before an audience that would represent all Christendom, in whose
19953: presence he should again be sealed as the messenger of the supreme
19954: righteousness, and feel himself full charged with Divine strength. It
19955: was but a moment that expanded itself in that prevision. While the
19956: shout was still ringing in his ears he turned away within the church,
19957: feeling the strain too great for him to bear it longer.
19958: 
19959: But when the Frate had disappeared, and the sunlight seemed no longer
19960: to have anything special in its illumination, but was spreading itself
19961: impartially over all things clean and unclean, there began, along with
19962: the general movement of the crowd, a confusion of voices in which
19963: certain strong discords and varying scales of laughter made it evident
19964: that, in the previous silence and universal kneeling, hostility and
19965: scorn had only submitted unwillingly to a momentary spell.
19966: 
19967: “It seems to me the plaudits are giving way to criticism,” said Tito,
19968: who had been watching the scene attentively from an upper loggia in one
19969: of the houses opposite the church. “Nevertheless it was a striking
19970: moment, eh, Messer Pietro? Fra Girolamo is a man to make one understand
19971: that there was a time when the monk’s frock was a symbol of power over
19972: men’s minds rather than over the keys of women’s cupboards.”
19973: 
19974: “Assuredly,” said Pietro Cennini. “And until I have seen proof that Fra
19975: Girolamo has much less faith in God’s judgments than the common run of
19976: men, instead of having considerably more, I shall not believe that he
19977: would brave Heaven in this way if his soul were laden with a conscious
19978: lie.”
19979: 
19980: 
19981: 
19982: 
19983: CHAPTER LXIII.
19984: Ripening Schemes.
19985: 
19986: 
19987: A month after that Carnival, one morning near the end of March, Tito
19988: descended the marble steps of the Old Palace, bound on a pregnant
19989: errand to San Marco. For some reason, he did not choose to take the
19990: direct road, which was but a slightly-bent line from the Old Palace; he
19991: chose rather to make a circuit by the Piazza di Santa Croce, where the
19992: people would be pouring out of the church after the early sermon.
19993: 
19994: It was in the grand church of Santa Croce that the daily Lenten sermon
19995: had of late had the largest audience. For Savonarola’s voice had ceased
19996: to be heard even in his own church of San Marco, a hostile Signoria
19997: having imposed silence on him in obedience to a new letter from the
19998: Pope, threatening the city with an immediate interdict if this
19999: “wretched worm” and “monstrous idol” were not forbidden to preach, and
20000: sent to demand pardon at Rome. And next to hearing Fra Girolamo
20001: himself, the most exciting Lenten occupation was to hear him argued
20002: against and vilified. This excitement was to be had in Santa Croce,
20003: where the Franciscan appointed to preach the Quaresimal sermons had
20004: offered to clench his arguments by walking through the fire with Fra
20005: Girolamo. Had not that schismatical Dominican said, that his prophetic
20006: doctrine would be proved by a miracle at the fitting time? Here, then,
20007: was the fitting time. Let Savonarola walk through the fire, and if he
20008: came out unhurt, the Divine origin of his doctrine would be
20009: demonstrated; but if the fire consumed him, his falsity would be
20010: manifest; and that he might have no excuse for evading the test, the
20011: Franciscan declared himself willing to be a victim to this high logic,
20012: and to be burned for the sake of securing the necessary minor premiss.
20013: 
20014: Savonarola, according to his habit, had taken no notice of these pulpit
20015: attacks. But it happened that the zealous preacher of Santa Croce was
20016: no other than the Fra Francesco di Puglia, who at Prato the year before
20017: had been engaged in a like challenge with Savonarola’s fervent follower
20018: Fra Domenico, but had been called home by his superiors while the heat
20019: was simply oratorical. Honest Fra Domenico, then, who was preaching
20020: Lenten sermons to the women in the Via del Cocomero, no sooner heard of
20021: this new challenge, than he took up the gauntlet for his master, and
20022: declared himself ready to walk through the fire with Fra Francesco.
20023: Already the people were beginning to take a strong interest in what
20024: seemed to them a short and easy method of argument (for those who were
20025: to be convinced), when Savonarola, keenly alive to the dangers that lay
20026: in the mere discussion of the case, commanded Fra Domenico to withdraw
20027: his acceptance of the challenge and secede from the affair. The
20028: Franciscan declared himself content: he had not directed his challenge
20029: to any subaltern, but to Fra Girolamo himself.
20030: 
20031: After that, the popular interest in the Lenten sermons had flagged a
20032: little. But this morning, when Tito entered the Piazza di Santa Croce,
20033: he found, as he expected, that the people were pouring from the church
20034: in large numbers. Instead of dispersing, many of them concentrated
20035: themselves towards a particular spot near the entrance of the
20036: Franciscan monastery, and Tito took the same direction, threading the
20037: crowd with a careless and leisurely air, but keeping careful watch on
20038: that monastic entrance, as if he expected some object of interest to
20039: issue from it.
20040: 
20041: It was no such expectation that occupied the crowd. The object they
20042: were caring about was already visible to them in the shape of a large
20043: placard, affixed by order of the Signoria, and covered with very
20044: legible official handwriting. But curiosity was somewhat balked by the
20045: fact that the manuscript was chiefly in Latin, and though nearly every
20046: man knew beforehand approximately what the placard contained, he had an
20047: appetite for more exact knowledge, which gave him an irritating sense
20048: of his neighbour’s ignorance in not being able to interpret the learned
20049: tongue. For that aural acquaintance with Latin phrases which the
20050: unlearned might pick up from pulpit quotations constantly interpreted
20051: by the preacher could help them little when they saw written Latin; the
20052: spelling even of the modern language being in an unorganised and
20053: scrambling condition for the mass of people who could read and
20054: write,[1] while the majority of those assembled nearest to the placard
20055: were not in the dangerous predicament of possessing that little
20056: knowledge.
20057: 
20058:  [1] The old diarists throw in their consonants with a regard rather to
20059:  quantity than position, well typified by the _Ragnolo Braghiello_
20060:  (Agnolo Gabriello) of Boccaccio’s Ferondo.
20061: 
20062: 
20063: “It’s the Frate’s doctrines that he’s to prove by being burned,” said
20064: that large public character Goro, who happened to be among the foremost
20065: gazers. “The Signoria has taken it in hand, and the writing is to let
20066: us know. It’s what the Padre has been telling us about in his sermon.”
20067: 
20068: “Nay, Goro,” said a sleek shopkeeper, compassionately, “thou hast got
20069: thy legs into twisted hose there. The Frate has to prove his doctrines
20070: by _not_ being burned: he is to walk through the fire, and come out on
20071: the other side sound and whole.”
20072: 
20073: “Yes, yes,” said a young sculptor, who wore his white-streaked cap and
20074: tunic with a jaunty air. “But Fra Girolamo objects to walking through
20075: the fire. Being sound and whole already, he sees no reason why he
20076: should walk through the fire to come out in just the same condition. He
20077: leaves such odds and ends of work to Fra Domenico.”
20078: 
20079: “Then I say he flinches like a coward,” said Goro, in a wheezy treble.
20080: “Suffocation! that was what he did at the Carnival. He had us all in
20081: the Piazza to see the lightning strike him, and nothing came of it.”
20082: 
20083: “Stop that bleating,” said a tall shoemaker, who had stepped in to hear
20084: part of the sermon, with bunches of slippers hanging over his
20085: shoulders. “It seems to me, friend, that you are about as wise as a
20086: calf with water on its brain. The Frate will flinch from nothing: he’ll
20087: say nothing beforehand, perhaps, but when the moment comes he’ll walk
20088: through the fire without asking any grey-frock to keep him company. But
20089: I would give a shoestring to know what this Latin all is.”
20090: 
20091: “There’s so much of it,” said the shopkeeper, “else I’m pretty good at
20092: guessing. Is there no scholar to be seen?” he added, with a slight
20093: expression of disgust.
20094: 
20095: There was a general turning of heads, which caused the talkers to
20096: descry Tito approaching in their rear.
20097: 
20098: “Here is one,” said the young sculptor, smiling and raising his cap.
20099: 
20100: “It is the secretary of the Ten: he is going to the convent, doubtless;
20101: make way for him,” said the shopkeeper, also doffing, though that mark
20102: of respect was rarely shown by Florentines except to the highest
20103: officials. The exceptional reverence was really exacted by the
20104: splendour and grace of Tito’s appearance, which made his black mantle,
20105: with its gold fibula, look like a regal robe, and his ordinary black
20106: velvet cap like an entirely exceptional head-dress. The hardening of
20107: his cheeks and mouth, which was the chief change in his face since he
20108: came to Florence, seemed to a superficial glance only to give his
20109: beauty a more masculine character. He raised his own cap immediately
20110: and said—
20111: 
20112: “Thanks, my friend, I merely wished, as you did, to see what is at the
20113: foot of this placard—ah, it is as I expected. I had been informed that
20114: the government permits any one who will, to subscribe his name as a
20115: candidate to enter the fire—which is an act of liberality worthy of the
20116: magnificent Signoria—reserving of course the right to make a selection.
20117: And doubtless many believers will be eager to subscribe their names.
20118: For what is it to enter the fire, to one whose faith is firm? A man is
20119: afraid of the fire, because he believes it will burn him; but if he
20120: believes the contrary?”—here Tito lifted his shoulders and made an
20121: oratorical pause—“for which reason I have never been one to disbelieve
20122: the Frate, when he has said that he would enter the fire to prove his
20123: doctrine. For in his place, if you believed the fire would not burn
20124: you, which of you, my friends, would not enter it as readily as you
20125: would walk along the dry bed of the Mugnone?”
20126: 
20127: As Tito looked round him during this appeal, there was a change in some
20128: of his audience very much like the change in an eager dog when he is
20129: invited to smell something pungent. Since the question of burning was
20130: becoming practical, it was not every one who would rashly commit
20131: himself to any general view of the relation between faith and fire. The
20132: scene might have been too much for a gravity less under command than
20133: Tito’s.
20134: 
20135: “Then, Messer Segretario,” said the young sculptor, “it seems to me Fra
20136: Francesco is the greater hero, for he offers to enter the fire for the
20137: truth, though he is sure the fire will burn him.”
20138: 
20139: “I do not deny it,” said Tito, blandly. “But if it turns out that Fra
20140: Francesco is mistaken, he will have been burned for the wrong side, and
20141: the Church has never reckoned such victims to be martyrs. We must
20142: suspend our judgment until the trial has really taken place.”
20143: 
20144: “It is true, Messer Segretario,” said the shopkeeper, with subdued
20145: impatience. “But will you favour us by interpreting the Latin?”
20146: 
20147: “Assuredly,” said Tito. “It does but express the conclusions or
20148: doctrines which the Frate specially teaches, and which the trial by
20149: fire is to prove true or false. They are doubtless familiar to you.
20150: First, that Florence—”
20151: 
20152: “Let us have the Latin bit by bit, and then tell us what it means,”
20153: said the shoemaker, who had been a frequent hearer of Fra Girolamo.
20154: 
20155: “Willingly,” said Tito, smiling. “You will then judge if I give you the
20156: right meaning.”
20157: 
20158: “Yes, yes; that’s fair,” said Goro.
20159: 
20160: “_Ecclesia Dei indiget renovatione_; that is, the Church of God needs
20161: purifying or regenerating.”
20162: 
20163: “It is true,” said several voices at once.
20164: 
20165: “That means, the priests ought to lead better lives; there needs no
20166: miracle to prove that. That’s what the Frate has always been saying,”
20167: said the shoemaker.
20168: 
20169: “_Flagellabitur_,” Tito went on. “That is, it will be scourged.
20170: _Renovabitur_: it will be purified. _Florentia quoque post flagellam
20171: renovabitur et prosperabitur_: Florence also, after the scourging,
20172: shall be purified and shall prosper.”
20173: 
20174: “That means we are to get Pisa again,” said the shopkeeper.
20175: 
20176: “And get the wool from England as we used to do, I should hope,” said
20177: an elderly man, in an old-fashioned berretta, who had been silent till
20178: now. “There’s been scourging enough with the sinking of the trade.”
20179: 
20180: At this moment, a tall personage, surmounted by a red feather, issued
20181: from the door of the convent, and exchanged an indifferent glance with
20182: Tito; who, tossing his becchetto carelessly over his left shoulder,
20183: turned to his reading again, while the bystanders, with more timidity
20184: than respect, shrank to make a passage for Messer Dolfo Spini.
20185: 
20186: “_Infideles convertentur ad Christum_,” Tito went on. “That is, the
20187: infidels shall be converted to Christ.”
20188: 
20189: “Those are the Turks and the Moors. Well, I’ve nothing to say against
20190: that,” said the shopkeeper, dispassionately.
20191: 
20192: “_Haec autem omnia erunt temporibus nostris_: and all these things
20193: shall happen in our times.”
20194: 
20195: “Why, what use would they be else?” said Goro.
20196: 
20197: “_Excommunicato nuper lata contra Reverendum Patrem nostrum Fratrem
20198: Hieronymum nulla est_: the excommunication lately pronounced against
20199: our reverend father, Fra Girolamo, is null. _Non observantes eam non
20200: peccant_: those who disregard it are not committing a sin.”
20201: 
20202: “I shall know better what to say to that when we have had the Trial by
20203: Fire,” said the shopkeeper.
20204: 
20205: “Which doubtless will clear up everything,” said Tito. “That is all the
20206: Latin—all the conclusions that are to be proved true or false by the
20207: trial. The rest you can perceive is simply a proclamation of the
20208: Signoria in good Tuscan, calling on such as are eager to walk through
20209: the fire, to come to the Palazzo and subscribe their names. Can I serve
20210: you further? If not—”
20211: 
20212: Tito, as he turned away, raised his cap and bent slightly, with so easy
20213: an air that the movement seemed a natural prompting of deference.
20214: 
20215: He quickened his pace as he left the Piazza, and after two or three
20216: turnings he paused in a quiet street before a door at which he gave a
20217: light and peculiar knock. It was opened by a young woman whom he
20218: chucked under the chin as he asked her if the Padrone was within, and
20219: he then passed, without further ceremony, through another door which
20220: stood ajar on his right-hand. It admitted him into a handsome but
20221: untidy room, where Dolfo Spini sat playing with a fine stag-hound which
20222: alternately snuffed at a basket of pups and licked his hands with that
20223: affectionate disregard of her master’s morals sometimes held to be one
20224: of the most agreeable attributes of her sex. He just looked up as Tito
20225: entered, but continued his play, simply from that disposition to
20226: persistence in some irrelevant action, by which slow-witted sensual
20227: people seem to be continually counteracting their own purposes. Tito
20228: was patient.
20229: 
20230: “A handsome _bracca_ that,” he said, quietly, standing with his thumbs
20231: in his belt. Presently he added, in that cool liquid tone which seemed
20232: mild, but compelled attention, “When you have finished such caresses as
20233: cannot possibly be deferred, my Dolfo, we will talk of business, if you
20234: please. My time, which I could wish to be eternity at your service, is
20235: not entirely my own this morning.”
20236: 
20237: “Down, Mischief, down!” said Spini, with sudden roughness.
20238: “Malediction!” he added, still more gruffly, pushing the dog aside;
20239: then, starting from his seat, he stood close to Tito, and put a hand on
20240: his shoulder as he spoke.
20241: 
20242: “I hope your sharp wits see all the ins and outs of this business, my
20243: fine necromancer, for it seems to me no clearer than the bottom of a
20244: sack.”
20245: 
20246: “What is your difficulty, my cavalier?”
20247: 
20248: “These accursed Frati Minori at Santa Croce. They are drawing back now.
20249: Fra Francesco himself seems afraid of sticking to his challenge; talks
20250: of the Prophet being likely to use magic to get up a false
20251: miracle—thinks he himself might be dragged into the fire and burned,
20252: and the Prophet might come out whole by magic, and the Church be none
20253: the better. And then, after all our talking, there’s not so much as a
20254: blessed lay brother who will offer himself to pair with that pious
20255: sheep Fra Domenico.”
20256: 
20257: “It is the peculiar stupidity of the tonsured skull that prevents them
20258: from seeing of how little consequence it is whether they are burned or
20259: not,” said Tito. “Have you sworn well to them that they shall be in no
20260: danger of entering the fire?”
20261: 
20262: “No,” said Spini, looking puzzled; “because one of them will be obliged
20263: to go in with Fra Domenico, who thinks it a thousand years till the
20264: fagots are ready.”
20265: 
20266: “Not at all. Fra Domenico himself is not likely to go in. I have told
20267: you before, my Dolfo, only your powerful mind is not to be impressed
20268: without more repetition than suffices for the vulgar—I have told you
20269: that now you have got the Signoria to take up this affair and prevent
20270: it from being hushed up by Fra Girolamo, nothing is necessary but that
20271: on a given day the fuel should be prepared in the Piazza, and the
20272: people got together with the expectation of seeing something
20273: prodigious. If, after that, the Prophet quits the Piazza without any
20274: appearance of a miracle on his side, he is ruined with the people: they
20275: will be ready to pelt him out of the city, the Signoria will find it
20276: easy to banish him from the territory, and his Holiness may do as he
20277: likes with him. Therefore, my Alcibiades, swear to the Franciscans that
20278: their grey-frocks shall not come within singeing distance of the fire.”
20279: 
20280: Spini rubbed the back of his head with one hand, and tapped his sword
20281: against his leg with the other, to stimulate his power of seeing these
20282: intangible combinations.
20283: 
20284: “But,” he said presently, looking up again, “unless we fall on him in
20285: the Piazza, when the people are in a rage, and make an end of him and
20286: his lies then and there, Valori and the Salviati and the Albizzi will
20287: take up arms and raise a fight for him. I know that was talked of when
20288: there was the hubbub on Ascension Sunday. And the people may turn round
20289: again: there may be a story raised of the French king coming again, or
20290: some other cursed chance in the hypocrite’s favour. The city will never
20291: be safe till he’s out of it.”
20292: 
20293: “He _will_ be out of it before long, without your giving yourself any
20294: further trouble than this little comedy of the Trial by Fire. The wine
20295: and the sun will make vinegar without any shouting to help them, as
20296: your Florentine sages would say. You will have the satisfaction of
20297: delivering your city from an incubus by an able stratagem, instead of
20298: risking blunders with sword-thrusts.”
20299: 
20300: “But suppose he _did_ get magic and the devil to help him, and walk
20301: through the fire after all?” said Spini, with a grimace intended to
20302: hide a certain shyness in trenching on this speculative ground. “How do
20303: you know there’s nothing in those things? Plenty of scholars believe in
20304: them, and this Frate is bad enough for anything.”
20305: 
20306: “Oh, of course there are such things,” said Tito, with a shrug: “but I
20307: have particular reasons for knowing that the Frate is not on such terms
20308: with the devil as can give him any confidence in this affair. The only
20309: magic he relies on is his own ability.”
20310: 
20311: “Ability!” said Spini. “Do you call it ability to be setting Florence
20312: at loggerheads with the Pope and all the powers of Italy—all to keep
20313: beckoning at the French king who never comes? You may call him able,
20314: but I call him a hypocrite, who wants to be master of everybody, and
20315: get himself made Pope.”
20316: 
20317: “You judge with your usual penetration, my captain, but our opinions do
20318: not clash. The Frate, wanting to be master, and to carry out his
20319: projects against the Pope, requires the lever of a foreign power, and
20320: requires Florence as a fulcrum. I used to think him a narrow-minded
20321: bigot, but now, I think him a shrewd ambitious man who knows what he is
20322: aiming at, and directs his aim as skilfully as you direct a ball when
20323: you are playing at _maglio_.”
20324: 
20325: “Yes, yes,” said Spini, cordially, “I can aim a ball.”
20326: 
20327: “It is true,” said Tito, with bland gravity; “and I should not have
20328: troubled you with my trivial remark on the Frate’s ability, but that
20329: you may see how this will heighten the credit of your success against
20330: him at Rome and at Milan, which is sure to serve you in good stead when
20331: the city comes to change its policy.”
20332: 
20333: “Well, thou art a good little demon, and shalt have good pay,” said
20334: Spini, patronisingly; whereupon he thought it only natural that the
20335: useful Greek adventurer should smile with gratification as he said—
20336: 
20337: “Of course, any advantage to me depends entirely on your—”
20338: 
20339: “We shall have our supper at my palace to-night,” interrupted Spini,
20340: with a significant nod and an affectionate pat on Tito’s shoulder, “and
20341: I shall expound the new scheme to them all.”
20342: 
20343: “Pardon, my magnificent patron,” said Tito; “the scheme has been the
20344: same from the first—it has never varied except in your memory. Are you
20345: sure you have fast hold of it now?”
20346: 
20347: Spini rehearsed.
20348: 
20349: “One thing more,” he said, as Tito was hastening away. “There is that
20350: sharp-nosed notary, Ser Ceccone; he has been handy of late. Tell me,
20351: you who can see a man wink when you’re behind him, do you think I may
20352: go on making use of him?”
20353: 
20354: Tito dared not say “No.” He knew his companion too well to trust him
20355: with advice when all Spini’s vanity and self-interest were not engaged
20356: in concealing the adviser.
20357: 
20358: “Doubtless,” he answered, promptly. “I have nothing to say against
20359: Ceccone.”
20360: 
20361: That suggestion of the notary’s intimate access to Spini caused Tito a
20362: passing twinge, interrupting his amused satisfaction in the success
20363: with which he made a tool of the man who fancied himself a patron. For
20364: he had been rather afraid of Ser Ceccone. Tito’s nature made him
20365: peculiarly alive to circumstances that might be turned to his
20366: disadvantage; his memory was much haunted by such possibilities,
20367: stimulating him to contrivances by which he might ward them off. And it
20368: was not likely that he should forget that October morning more than a
20369: year ago, when Romola had appeared suddenly before him at the door of
20370: Nello’s shop, and had compelled him to declare his certainty that Fra
20371: Girolamo was not going outside the gates. The fact that Ser Ceccone had
20372: been a witness of that scene, together with Tito’s perception that for
20373: some reason or other he was an object of dislike to the notary, had
20374: received a new importance from the recent turn of events. For after
20375: having been implicated in the Medicean plots, and having found it
20376: advisable in consequence to retire into the country for some time, Ser
20377: Ceccone had of late, since his reappearance in the city, attached
20378: himself to the Arrabbiati, and cultivated the patronage of Dolfo Spini.
20379: Now that captain of the Compagnacci was much given, when in the company
20380: of intimates, to confidential narrative about his own doings, and if
20381: Ser Ceccone’s powers of combination were sharpened by enmity, he might
20382: gather some knowledge which he could use against Tito with very
20383: unpleasant results.
20384: 
20385: It would be pitiable to be balked in well-conducted schemes by an
20386: insignificant notary; to be lamed by the sting of an insect whom he had
20387: offended unawares. “But,” Tito said to himself, “the man’s dislike to
20388: me can be nothing deeper than the ill-humour of a dinnerless dog; I
20389: shall conquer it if I can make him prosperous.” And he had been very
20390: glad of an opportunity which had presented itself of providing the
20391: notary with a temporary post as an extra _cancelliere_ or registering
20392: secretary under the Ten, believing that with this sop and the
20393: expectation of more, the waspish cur must be quite cured of the
20394: disposition to bite him.
20395: 
20396: But perfect scheming demands omniscience, and the notary’s envy had
20397: been stimulated into hatred by causes of which Tito knew nothing. That
20398: evening when Tito, returning from his critical audience with the
20399: Special Council, had brushed by Ser Ceccone on the stairs, the notary,
20400: who had only just returned from Pistoja, and learned the arrest of the
20401: conspirators, was bound on an errand which bore a humble resemblance to
20402: Tito’s. He also, without giving up a show of popular zeal, had been
20403: putting in the Medicean lottery. He also had been privy to the
20404: unexecuted plot, and was willing to tell what he knew, but knew much
20405: less to tell. He also would have been willing to go on treacherous
20406: errands, but a more eligible agent had forestalled him. His
20407: propositions were received coldly; the council, he was told, was
20408: already in possession of the needed information, and since he had been
20409: thus busy in sedition, it would be well for him to retire out of the
20410: way of mischief, otherwise the government might be obliged to take note
20411: of him. Ser Ceccone wanted no evidence to make him attribute his
20412: failure to Tito, and his spite was the more bitter because the nature
20413: of the case compelled him to hold his peace about it. Nor was this the
20414: whole of his grudge against the flourishing Melema. On issuing from his
20415: hiding-place, and attaching himself to the Arrabbiati, he had earned
20416: some pay as one of the spies who reported information on Florentine
20417: affairs to the Milanese court; but his pay had been small,
20418: notwithstanding his pains to write full letters, and he had lately been
20419: apprised that his news was seldom more than a late and imperfect
20420: edition of what was known already. Now Ser Ceccone had no positive
20421: knowledge that Tito had an underhand connection with the Arrabbiati and
20422: the Court of Milan, but he had a suspicion of which he chewed the cud
20423: with as strong a sense of flavour as if it had been a certainty.
20424: 
20425: This fine-grown vigorous hatred could swallow the feeble opiate of
20426: Tito’s favours, and be as lively as ever after it. Why should Ser
20427: Ceccone like Melema any the better for doing him favours? Doubtless the
20428: suave secretary had his own ends to serve; and what right had he to the
20429: superior position which made it possible for him to show favour? But
20430: since he had tuned his voice to flattery, Ser Ceccone would pitch his
20431: in the same key, and it remained to be seen who would win at the game
20432: of outwitting.
20433: 
20434: To have a mind well oiled with that sort of argument which prevents any
20435: claim from grasping it, seems eminently convenient sometimes: only the
20436: oil becomes objectionable when we find it anointing other minds on
20437: which we want to establish a hold.
20438: 
20439: Tito, however, not being quite omniscient, felt now no more than a
20440: passing twinge of uneasiness at the suggestion of Ser Ceccone’s power
20441: to hurt him. It was only for a little while that he cared greatly about
20442: keeping clear of suspicions and hostility. He was now playing his final
20443: game in Florence, and the skill he was conscious of applying gave him a
20444: pleasure in it even apart from the expected winnings. The errand on
20445: which he was sent to San Marco was a stroke in which he felt so much
20446: confidence that he had already given notice to the Ten of his desire to
20447: resign his office at an indefinite period within the next month or two,
20448: and had obtained permission to make that resignation suddenly, if his
20449: affairs needed it, with the understanding that Niccolò Macchiavelli was
20450: to be his provisional substitute, if not his successor. He was acting
20451: on hypothetic grounds, but this was the sort of action that had the
20452: keenest interest for his diplomatic mind. From a combination of general
20453: knowledge concerning Savonarola’s purposes with diligently observed
20454: details he had framed a conjecture which he was about to verify by this
20455: visit to San Marco. If he proved to be right, his game would be won,
20456: and he might soon turn his back on Florence. He looked eagerly towards
20457: that consummation, for many circumstances besides his own weariness of
20458: the place told him that it was time for him to be gone.
20459: 
20460: 
20461: 
20462: 
20463: CHAPTER LXIV.
20464: The Prophet in his Cell.
20465: 
20466: 
20467: Tito’s visit to San Marco had been announced beforehand, and he was at
20468: once conducted by Fra Niccolò, Savonarola’s secretary, up the spiral
20469: staircase into the long corridors lined with cells—corridors where Fra
20470: Angelico’s frescoes, delicate as the rainbow on the melting cloud,
20471: startled the unaccustomed eye here and there, as if they had been
20472: sudden reflections cast from an ethereal world, where the Madonna sat
20473: crowned in her radiant glory, and the Divine infant looked forth with
20474: perpetual promise.
20475: 
20476: It was an hour of relaxation in the monastery, and most of the cells
20477: were empty. The light through the narrow windows looked in on nothing
20478: but bare walls, and the hard pallet and the crucifix. And even behind
20479: that door at the end of a long corridor, in the inner cell opening from
20480: an antechamber where the Prior usually sat at his desk or received
20481: private visitors, the high jet of light fell on only one more object
20482: that looked quite as common a monastic sight as the bare walls and hard
20483: pallet. It was but the back of a figure in the long white Dominican
20484: tunic and scapulary, kneeling with bowed head before a crucifix. It
20485: might have been any ordinary Fra Girolamo, who had nothing worse to
20486: confess than thinking of wrong things when he was singing _in coro_, or
20487: feeling a spiteful joy when Fra Benedetto dropped the ink over his own
20488: miniatures in the breviary he was illuminating—who had no higher
20489: thought than that of climbing safely into Paradise up the narrow ladder
20490: of prayer, fasting, and obedience. But under this particular white
20491: tunic there was a heart beating with a consciousness inconceivable to
20492: the average monk, and perhaps hard to be conceived by any man who has
20493: not arrived at self-knowledge through a tumultuous inner life: a
20494: consciousness in which irrevocable errors and lapses from veracity were
20495: so entwined with noble purposes and sincere beliefs, in which
20496: self-justifying expediency was so inwoven with the tissue of a great
20497: work which the whole being seemed as unable to abandon as the body was
20498: unable to abandon glowing and trembling before the objects of hope and
20499: fear, that it was perhaps impossible, whatever course might be adopted,
20500: for the conscience to find perfect repose.
20501: 
20502: Savonarola was not only in the attitude of prayer, there were Latin
20503: words of prayer on his lips; and yet he was not praying. He had entered
20504: his cell, had fallen on his knees, and burst into words of
20505: supplication, seeking in this way for an influx of calmness which would
20506: be a warrant to him that the resolutions urged on him by crowding
20507: thoughts and passions were not wresting him away from the Divine
20508: support; but the previsions and impulses which had been at work within
20509: him for the last hour were too imperious; and while he pressed his
20510: hands against his face, and while his lips were uttering audibly, “_Cor
20511: mundum crea in me_” his mind was still filled with the images of the
20512: snare his enemies had prepared for him, was still busy with the
20513: arguments by which he could justify himself against their taunts and
20514: accusations.
20515: 
20516: And it was not only against his opponents that Savonarola had to defend
20517: himself. This morning he had had new proof that his friends and
20518: followers were as much inclined to urge on the Trial by Fire as his
20519: enemies: desiring and tacitly expecting that he himself would at last
20520: accept the challenge and evoke the long-expected miracle which was to
20521: dissipate doubt and triumph over malignity. Had he not said that God
20522: would declare himself at the fitting time? And to the understanding of
20523: plain Florentines, eager to get party questions settled, it seemed that
20524: no time could be more fitting than this. Certainly, if Fra Domenico
20525: walked through the fire unhurt, _that_ would be a miracle, and the
20526: faith and ardour of that good brother were felt to be a cheering
20527: augury; but Savonarola was acutely conscious that the secret longing of
20528: his followers to see him accept the challenge had not been dissipated
20529: by any reasons he had given for his refusal.
20530: 
20531: Yet it was impossible to him to satisfy them; and with bitter distress
20532: he saw now that it was impossible for him any longer to resist the
20533: prosecution of the trial in Fra Domenico’s case. Not that Savonarola
20534: had uttered and written a falsity when he declared his belief in a
20535: future supernatural attestation of his work; but his mind was so
20536: constituted that while it was easy for him to believe in a miracle
20537: which, being distant and undefined, was screened behind the strong
20538: reasons he saw for its occurrence, and yet easier for him to have a
20539: belief in inward miracles such as his own prophetic inspiration and
20540: divinely-wrought intuitions; it was at the same time insurmountably
20541: difficult to him to believe in the probability of a miracle which, like
20542: this of being carried unhurt through the fire, pressed in all its
20543: details on his imagination and involved a demand not only for belief
20544: but for exceptional action.
20545: 
20546: Savonarola’s nature was one of those in which opposing tendencies
20547: co-exist in almost equal strength: the passionate sensibility which,
20548: impatient of definite thought, floods every idea with emotion and tends
20549: towards contemplative ecstasy, alternated in him with a keen perception
20550: of outward facts and a vigorous practical judgment of men and things.
20551: And in this case of the Trial by Fire, the latter characteristics were
20552: stimulated into unusual activity by an acute physical sensitiveness
20553: which gives overpowering force to the conception of pain and
20554: destruction as a necessary sequence of facts which have already been
20555: causes of pain in our experience. The promptitude with which men will
20556: consent to touch red-hot iron with a wet finger is not to be measured
20557: by their theoretic acceptance of the impossibility that the iron will
20558: burn them: practical belief depends on what is most strongly
20559: represented in the mind at a given moment. And with the Frate’s
20560: constitution, when the Trial by Fire was urged on his imagination as an
20561: immediate demand, it was impossible for him to believe that he or any
20562: other man could walk through the flames unhurt—impossible for him to
20563: believe that even if he resolved to offer himself, he would not shrink
20564: at the last moment.
20565: 
20566: But the Florentines were not likely to make these fine distinctions. To
20567: the common run of mankind it has always seemed a proof of mental vigour
20568: to find moral questions easy, and judge conduct according to concise
20569: alternatives. And nothing was likely to seem plainer than that a man
20570: who at one time declared that God would not leave him without the
20571: guarantee of a miracle, and yet drew back when it was proposed to test
20572: his declaration, had said what he did not believe. Were not Fra
20573: Domenico and Fra Mariano, and scores of Piagnoni besides, ready to
20574: enter the fire? What was the cause of their superior courage, if it was
20575: not their superior faith? Savonarola could not have explained his
20576: conduct satisfactorily to his friends, even if he had been able to
20577: explain it thoroughly to himself. And he was not. Our naked feelings
20578: make haste to clothe themselves in propositions which lie at hand among
20579: our store of opinions, and to give a true account of what passes within
20580: us something else is necessary besides sincerity, even when sincerity
20581: is unmixed. In these very moments, when Savonarola was kneeling in
20582: audible prayer, he had ceased to hear the words on his lips. They were
20583: drowned by argumentative voices within him that shaped their reasons
20584: more and more for an outward audience.
20585: 
20586: “To appeal to heaven for a miracle by a rash acceptance of a challenge,
20587: which is a mere snare prepared for me by ignoble foes, would be a
20588: tempting of God, and the appeal would not be responded to. Let the
20589: Pope’s legate come, let the ambassadors of all the great Powers come
20590: and promise that the calling of a General Council and the reform of the
20591: Church shall hang on the miracle, and I will enter the flames, trusting
20592: that God will not withhold His seal from that great work. Until then I
20593: reserve myself for higher duties which are directly laid upon me: it is
20594: not permitted to me to leap from the chariot for the sake of wrestling
20595: with every loud vaunter. But Fra Domenico’s invincible zeal to enter
20596: into the trial may be the sign of a Divine vocation, may be a pledge
20597: that the miracle—”
20598: 
20599: But no! when Savonarola brought his mind close to the threatened scene
20600: in the Piazza, and imagined a human body entering the fire, his belief
20601: recoiled again. It was not an event that his imagination could simply
20602: see: he felt it with shuddering vibrations to the extremities of his
20603: sensitive fingers. The miracle could not be. Nay, the trial itself was
20604: not to happen: he was warranted in doing all in his power to hinder it.
20605: The fuel might be got ready in the Piazza, the people might be
20606: assembled, the preparatory formalities might be gone through: all this
20607: was perhaps inevitable now, and he could no longer resist it without
20608: bringing dishonour on—himself? Yes, and therefore on the cause of God.
20609: But it was not really intended that the Franciscan should enter the
20610: fire, and while _he_ hung back there would be the means of preventing
20611: Fra Domenico’s entrance. At the very worst, if Fra Domenico were
20612: compelled to enter, he should carry the consecrated Host with him, and
20613: with that Mystery in his hand, there might be a warrant for expecting
20614: that the ordinary effects of fire would be stayed; or, more probably,
20615: this demand would be resisted, and might thus be a final obstacle to
20616: the trial.
20617: 
20618: But these intentions could not be avowed: he must appear frankly to
20619: await the trial, and to trust in its issue. That dissidence between
20620: inward reality and outward seeming was not the Christian simplicity
20621: after which he had striven through years of his youth and prime, and
20622: which he had preached as a chief fruit of the Divine life. In the
20623: stress and heat of the day, with cheeks burning, with shouts ringing in
20624: the ears, who is so blest as to remember the yearnings he had in the
20625: cool and silent morning and know that he has not belied them?
20626: 
20627: “O God, it is for the sake of the people—because they are blind—because
20628: their faith depends on me. If I put on sackcloth and cast myself among
20629: the ashes, who will take up the standard and head the battle? Have I
20630: not been led by a way which I knew not to the work that lies before
20631: me?”
20632: 
20633: The conflict was one that could not end, and in the effort at prayerful
20634: pleading the uneasy mind laved its smart continually in thoughts of the
20635: greatness of that task which there was no man else to fulfil if he
20636: forsook it. It was not a thing of everyday that a man should be
20637: inspired with the vision and the daring that made a sacred rebel.
20638: 
20639: Even the words of prayer had died away. He continued to kneel, but his
20640: mind was filled with the images of results to be felt through all
20641: Europe; and the sense of immediate difficulties was being lost in the
20642: glow of that vision, when the knocking at the door announced the
20643: expected visit.
20644: 
20645: Savonarola drew on his mantle before he left his cell, as was his
20646: custom when he received visitors; and with that immediate response to
20647: any appeal from without which belongs to a power-loving nature
20648: accustomed to make its power felt by speech, he met Tito with a glance
20649: as self-possessed and strong as if he had risen from resolution instead
20650: of conflict.
20651: 
20652: Tito did not kneel, but simply made a greeting of profound deference,
20653: which Savonarola received quietly without any sacerdotal words, and
20654: then desiring him to be seated, said at once—
20655: 
20656: “Your business is something of weight, my son, that could not be
20657: conveyed through others?”
20658: 
20659: “Assuredly, father, else I should not have presumed to ask it. I will
20660: not trespass on your time by any proem. I gathered from a remark of
20661: Messer Domenico Mazzinghi that you might be glad to make use of the
20662: next special courier who is sent to France with despatches from the
20663: Ten. I must entreat you to pardon me if I have been too officious; but
20664: inasmuch as Messer Domenico is at this moment away at his villa, I
20665: wished to apprise you that a courier carrying important letters is
20666: about to depart for Lyons at daybreak to-morrow.”
20667: 
20668: The muscles of Fra Girolamo’s face were eminently under command, as
20669: must be the case with all men whose personality is powerful, and in
20670: deliberate speech he was habitually cautious, confiding his intentions
20671: to none without necessity. But under any strong mental stimulus, his
20672: eyes were liable to a dilatation and added brilliancy that no strength
20673: of will could control. He looked steadily at Tito, and did not answer
20674: immediately, as if he had to consider whether the information he had
20675: just heard met any purpose of his.
20676:
