20677: Tito, whose glance never seemed observant, but rarely let anything
20678: escape it, had expected precisely that dilatation and flash of
20679: Savonarola’s eyes which he had noted on other occasions. He saw it, and
20680: then immediately busied himself in adjusting his gold fibula, which had
20681: got wrong; seeming to imply that he awaited an answer patiently.
20682: 
20683: The fact was that Savonarola had expected to receive this intimation
20684: from Domenico Mazzinghi, one of the Ten, an ardent disciple of his whom
20685: he had already employed to write a private letter to the Florentine
20686: ambassador in France, to prepare the way for a letter to the French
20687: king himself in Savonarola’s handwriting, which now lay ready in the
20688: desk at his side. It was a letter calling on the king to assist in
20689: summoning a General Council, that might reform the abuses of the
20690: Church, and begin by deposing Pope Alexander, who was not rightfully
20691: Pope, being a vicious unbeliever, elected by corruption and governing
20692: by simony.
20693: 
20694: This fact was not what Tito knew, but what his constructive talent,
20695: guided by subtle indications, had led him to guess and hope.
20696: 
20697: “It is true, my son,” said Savonarola, quietly,—“it is true I have
20698: letters which I would gladly send by safe conveyance under cover to our
20699: ambassador. Our community of San Marco, as you know, has affairs in
20700: France, being, amongst other things, responsible for a debt to that
20701: singularly wise and experienced Frenchman, Signor Philippe de Comines,
20702: on the library of the Medici, which we purchased; but I apprehend that
20703: Domenico Mazzinghi himself may return to the city before evening, and I
20704: should gain more time for preparation of the letters if I waited to
20705: deposit them in his hands.”
20706: 
20707: “Assuredly, reverend father, that might be better on all grounds,
20708: except one, namely, that if anything occurred to hinder Messer
20709: Domenico’s return, the despatch of the letters would require either
20710: that I should come to San Marco again at a late hour, or that you
20711: should send them to me by your secretary; and I am aware that you wish
20712: to guard against the false inferences which might be drawn from a too
20713: frequent communication between yourself and any officer of the
20714: government.” In throwing out this difficulty Tito felt that the more
20715: unwillingness the Frate showed to trust him, the more certain he would
20716: be of his conjecture.
20717: 
20718: Savonarola was silent; but while he kept his mouth firm, a slight glow
20719: rose in his face with the suppressed excitement that was growing within
20720: him. It would be a critical moment—that in which he delivered the
20721: letter out of his own hands.
20722: 
20723: “It is most probable that Messer Domenico will return in time,” said
20724: Tito, affecting to consider the Frate’s determination settled, and
20725: rising from his chair as he spoke. “With your permission, I will take
20726: my leave, father, not to trespass on your time when my errand is done;
20727: but as I may not be favoured with another interview, I venture to
20728: confide to you—what is not yet known to others, except to the
20729: magnificent Ten—that I contemplate resigning my secretaryship, and
20730: leaving Florence shortly. Am I presuming too much on your interest in
20731: stating what relates chiefly to myself?”
20732: 
20733: “Speak on, my son,” said the Frate; “I desire to know your prospects.”
20734: 
20735: “I find, then, that I have mistaken my real vocation in forsaking the
20736: career of pure letters, for which I was brought up. The politics of
20737: Florence, father, are worthy to occupy the greatest mind—to occupy
20738: yours—when a man is in a position to execute his own ideas; but when,
20739: like me, he can only hope to be the mere instrument of changing
20740: schemes, he requires to be animated by the minor attachments of a born
20741: Florentine: also, my wife’s unhappy alienation from a Florentine
20742: residence since the painful events of August naturally influences me. I
20743: wish to join her.”
20744: 
20745: Savonarola inclined his head approvingly.
20746: 
20747: “I intend, then, soon to leave Florence, to visit the chief courts of
20748: Europe, and to widen my acquaintance with the men of letters in the
20749: various universities. I shall go first to the court of Hungary, where
20750: scholars are eminently welcome; and I shall probably start in a week or
20751: ten days. I have not concealed from you, father, that I am no religious
20752: enthusiast; I have not my wife’s ardour; but religious enthusiasm, as I
20753: conceive, is not necessary in order to appreciate the grandeur and
20754: justice of your views concerning the government of nations and the
20755: Church. And if you condescend to intrust me with any commission that
20756: will further the relations you wish to establish, I shall feel
20757: honoured. May I now take my leave?”
20758: 
20759: “Stay, my son. When you depart from Florence I will send a letter to
20760: your wife, of whose spiritual welfare I would fain be assured, for she
20761: left me in anger. As for the letters to France, such as I have ready—”
20762: 
20763: Savonarola rose and turned to his desk as he spoke. He took from it a
20764: letter on which Tito could see, but not read, an address in the Frate’s
20765: own minute and exquisite handwriting, still to be seen covering the
20766: margins of his Bibles. He took a large sheet of paper, enclosed the
20767: letter, and sealed it.
20768: 
20769: “Pardon me, father,” said Tito, before Savonarola had time to speak,
20770: “unless it were your decided wish, I would rather not incur the
20771: responsibility of carrying away the letter. Messer Domenico Mazzinghi
20772: will doubtless return, or, if not, Fra Niccolò can convey it to me at
20773: the second hour of the evening, when I shall place the other despatches
20774: in the courier’s hands.”
20775: 
20776: “At present, my son,” said the Frate, waiving that point, “I wish you
20777: to address this packet to our ambassador in your own handwriting, which
20778: is preferable to my secretary’s.”
20779: 
20780: Tito sat down to write the address while the Frate stood by him with
20781: folded arms, the glow mounting in his cheek, and his lip at last
20782: quivering. Tito rose and was about to move away, when Savonarola said
20783: abruptly—“Take it, my son. There is no use in waiting. It does not
20784: please me that Fra Niccolò should have needless errands to the
20785: Palazzo.”
20786: 
20787: As Tito took the letter, Savonarola stood in suppressed excitement that
20788: forbade further speech. There seems to be a subtle emanation from
20789: passionate natures like his, making their mental states tell
20790: immediately on others; when they are absent-minded and inwardly excited
20791: there is silence in the air.
20792: 
20793: Tito made a deep reverence and went out with the letter under his
20794: mantle.
20795: 
20796: The letter was duly delivered to the courier and carried out of
20797: Florence. But before that happened another messenger, privately
20798: employed by Tito, had conveyed information in cipher, which was carried
20799: by a series of relays to armed agents of Ludovico Sforza, Duke of
20800: Milan, on the watch for the very purpose of intercepting despatches on
20801: the borders of the Milanese territory.
20802: 
20803: 
20804: 
20805: 
20806: CHAPTER LXV.
20807: The Trial by Fire.
20808: 
20809: 
20810: Little more than a week after, on the seventh of April, the great
20811: Piazza della Signoria presented a stranger spectacle even than the
20812: famous Bonfire of Vanities. And a greater multitude had assembled to
20813: see it than had ever before tried to find place for themselves in the
20814: wide Piazza, even on the day of San Giovanni.
20815: 
20816: It was near mid-day, and since the early morning there had been a
20817: gradual swarming of the people at every coign of vantage or
20818: disadvantage offered by the façades and roofs of the houses, and such
20819: spaces of the pavement as were free to the public. Men were seated on
20820: iron rods that made a sharp angle with the rising wall, were clutching
20821: slim pillars with arms and legs, were astride on the necks of the rough
20822: statuary that here and there surmounted the entrances of the grander
20823: houses, were finding a palm’s-breadth of seat on a bit of architrave,
20824: and a footing on the rough projections of the rustic stonework, while
20825: they clutched the strong iron rings or staples driven into the walls
20826: beside them.
20827: 
20828: For they were come to see a Miracle: cramped limbs and abraded flesh
20829: seemed slight inconveniences with that prospect close at hand. It is
20830: the ordinary lot of mankind to hear of miracles, and more or less to
20831: believe in them; but now the Florentines were going to see one. At the
20832: very least they would see half a miracle; for if the monk did not come
20833: whole out of the fire, they would see him enter it, and infer that he
20834: was burned in the middle.
20835: 
20836: There could be no reasonable doubt, it seemed, that the fire would be
20837: kindled, and that the monks would enter it. For there, before their
20838: eyes, was the long platform, eight feet broad, and twenty yards long,
20839: with a grove of fuel heaped up terribly, great branches of dry oak as a
20840: foundation, crackling thorns above, and well-anointed tow and rags,
20841: known to make fine flames in Florentine illuminations. The platform
20842: began at the corner of the marble terrace in front of the Old Palace,
20843: close to Marzocco, the stone lion, whose aged visage looked frowningly
20844: along the grove of fuel that stretched obliquely across the Piazza.
20845: 
20846: Besides that, there were three large bodies of armed men: five hundred
20847: hired soldiers of the Signoria stationed before the palace; five
20848: hundred Compagnacci under Dolfo Spini, far-off on the opposite side of
20849: the Piazza; and three hundred armed citizens of another sort, under
20850: Marco Salviati, Savonarola’s friend, in front of Orgagna’s Loggia,
20851: where the Franciscans and Dominicans were to be placed with their
20852: champions.
20853: 
20854: Here had been much expense of money and labour, and high dignities were
20855: concerned. There could be no reasonable doubt that something great was
20856: about to happen; and it would certainly be a great thing if the two
20857: monks were simply burned, for in that case too God would have spoken,
20858: and said very plainly that Fra Girolamo was not His prophet.
20859: 
20860: And there was not much longer to wait, for it was now near mid-day.
20861: Half the monks were already at their post, and that half of the Loggia
20862: that lies towards the Palace was already filled with grey mantles; but
20863: the other half, divided off by boards, was still empty of everything
20864: except a small altar. The Franciscans had entered and taken their
20865: places in silence. But now, at the other side of the Piazza was heard
20866: loud chanting from two hundred voices, and there was general
20867: satisfaction, if not in the chanting, at least in the evidence that the
20868: Dominicans were come. That loud chanting repetition of the prayer, “Let
20869: God arise, and let His enemies be scattered,” was unpleasantly
20870: suggestive to some impartial ears of a desire to vaunt confidence and
20871: excite dismay; and so was the flame-coloured velvet cope in which Fra
20872: Domenico was arrayed as he headed the procession, cross in hand, his
20873: simple mind really exalted with faith, and with the genuine intention
20874: to enter the flames for the glory of God and Fra Girolamo. Behind him
20875: came Savonarola in the white vestment of a priest, carrying in his
20876: hands a vessel containing the consecrated Host. He, too, was chanting
20877: loudly; he, too, looked firm and confident, and as all eyes were turned
20878: eagerly on him, either in anxiety, curiosity, or malignity, from the
20879: moment when he entered the Piazza till he mounted the steps of the
20880: Loggia and deposited the Sacrament on the altar, there was an
20881: intensifying flash and energy in his countenance responding to that
20882: scrutiny.
20883: 
20884: We are so made, almost all of us, that the false seeming which we have
20885: thought of with painful shrinking when beforehand in our solitude it
20886: has urged itself on us as a necessity, will possess our muscles and
20887: move our lips as if nothing but that were easy when once we have come
20888: under the stimulus of expectant eyes and ears. And the strength of that
20889: stimulus to Savonarola can hardly be measured by the experience of
20890: ordinary lives. Perhaps no man has ever had a mighty influence over his
20891: fellows without having the innate need to dominate, and this need
20892: usually becomes the more imperious in proportion as the complications
20893: of life make Self inseparable from a purpose which is not selfish. In
20894: this way it came to pass that on the day of the Trial by Fire, the
20895: doubleness which is the pressing temptation in every public career,
20896: whether of priest, orator, or statesman, was more strongly defined in
20897: Savonarola’s consciousness as the acting of a part, than at any other
20898: period in his life. He was struggling not against impending martyrdom,
20899: but against impending ruin.
20900: 
20901: Therefore he looked and acted as if he were thoroughly confident, when
20902: all the while foreboding was pressing with leaden weight on his heart,
20903: not only because of the probable issues of this trial, but because of
20904: another event already past—an event which was spreading a sunny
20905: satisfaction through the mind of a man who was looking down at the
20906: passion-worn prophet from a window of the Old Palace. It was a common
20907: turning-point towards which those widely-sundered lives had been
20908: converging, that two evenings ago the news had come that the Florentine
20909: courier of the Ten had been arrested and robbed of all his despatches,
20910: so that Savonarola’s letter was already in the hands of the Duke of
20911: Milan, and would soon be in the hands of the Pope, not only heightening
20912: rage, but giving a new justification to extreme measures. There was no
20913: malignity in Tito Melema’s satisfaction: it was the mild
20914: self-gratulation of a man who has won a game that has employed
20915: hypothetic skill, not a game that has stirred the muscles and heated
20916: the blood. Of course that bundle of desires and contrivances called
20917: human nature, when moulded into the form of a plain-featured Frate
20918: Predicatore, more or less of an impostor, could not be a pathetic
20919: object to a brilliant-minded scholar who understood everything. Yet
20920: this tonsured Girolamo with the high nose and large under lip was an
20921: immensely clever Frate, mixing with his absurd superstitions or
20922: fabrications very remarkable notions about government: no babbler, but
20923: a man who could keep his secrets. Tito had no more spite against him
20924: than against Saint Dominic. On the contrary, Fra Girolamo’s existence
20925: had been highly convenient to Tito Melema, furnishing him with that
20926: round of the ladder from which he was about to leap on to a new and
20927: smooth footing very much to his heart’s content. And everything now was
20928: in forward preparation for that leap: let one more sun rise and set,
20929: and Tito hoped to quit Florence. He had been so industrious that he
20930: felt at full leisure to amuse himself with to-day’s comedy, which the
20931: thick-headed Dolfo Spini could never have brought about but for him.
20932: 
20933: Not yet did the loud chanting cease, but rather swelled to a deafening
20934: roar, being taken up in all parts of the Piazza by the Piagnoni, who
20935: carried their little red crosses as a badge, and, most of them, chanted
20936: the prayer for the confusion of God’s enemies with the expectation of
20937: an answer to be given through the medium of a more signal personage
20938: than Fra Domenico. This good Frate in his flame-coloured cope was now
20939: kneeling before the little altar on which the Sacrament was deposited,
20940: awaiting his summons.
20941: 
20942: On the Franciscan side of the Loggia there was no chanting and no
20943: flame-colour: only silence and greyness. But there was this
20944: counterbalancing difference, that the Franciscans had two champions: a
20945: certain Fra Giuliano was to pair with Fra Domenico, while the original
20946: champion, Fra Francesco, confined his challenge to Savonarola.
20947: 
20948: “Surely,” thought the men perched uneasily on the rods and pillars,
20949: “all must be ready now. This chanting might stop, and we should see
20950: better when the Frati are moving towards the platform.”
20951: 
20952: But the Frati were not to be seen moving yet. Pale Franciscan faces
20953: were looking uneasily over the boarding at that flame-coloured cope. It
20954: had an evil look and might be enchanted, so that a false miracle would
20955: be wrought by magic. Your monk may come whole out of the fire, and yet
20956: it may be the work of the devil.
20957: 
20958: And now there was passing to and fro between the Loggia and the marble
20959: terrace of the Palazzo, and the roar of chanting became a little
20960: quieter, for every one at a distance was beginning to watch more
20961: eagerly. But it soon appeared that the new movement was not a
20962: beginning, but an obstacle to beginning. The dignified Florentines
20963: appointed to preside over this affair as moderators on each side, went
20964: in and out of the Palace, and there was much debate with the
20965: Franciscans. But at last it was clear that Fra Domenico, conspicuous in
20966: his flame-colour, was being fetched towards the Palace. Probably the
20967: fire had already been kindled—it was difficult to see at a distance—and
20968: the miracle was going to begin.
20969: 
20970: Not at all. The flame-coloured cope disappeared within the Palace; then
20971: another Dominican was fetched away; and for a long while everything
20972: went on as before—the tiresome chanting, which was not miraculous, and
20973: Fra Girolamo in his white vestment standing just in the same place. But
20974: at last something happened: Fra Domenico was seen coming out of the
20975: Palace again, and returning to his brethren. He had changed all his
20976: clothes with a brother monk, but he was guarded on each flank by a
20977: Franciscan, lest coming into the vicinity of Savonarola he should be
20978: enchanted again.
20979: 
20980: “Ah, then,” thought the distant spectators, a little less conscious of
20981: cramped limbs and hunger, “Fra Domenico is not going to enter the fire.
20982: It is Fra Girolamo who offers himself after all. We shall see him move
20983: presently, and if he comes out of the flames we shall have a fine view
20984: of him!”
20985: 
20986: But Fra Girolamo did not move, except with the ordinary action
20987: accompanying speech. The speech was bold and firm, perhaps somewhat
20988: ironically remonstrant, like that of Elijah to the priests of Baal,
20989: demanding the cessation of these trivial delays. But speech is the most
20990: irritating kind of argument for those who are out of hearing, cramped
20991: in the limbs, and empty in the stomach. And what need was there for
20992: speech? If the miracle did not begin, it could be no one’s fault but
20993: Fra Girolamo’s, who might put an end to all difficulties by offering
20994: himself now the fire was ready, as he had been forward enough to do
20995: when there was no fuel in sight.
20996: 
20997: More movement to and fro, more discussion; and the afternoon seemed to
20998: be slipping away all the faster because the clouds had gathered, and
20999: changed the light on everything, and sent a chill through the
21000: spectators, hungry in mind and body.
21001: 
21002: _Now_ it was the crucifix which Fra Domenico wanted to carry into the
21003: fire and must not be allowed to profane in that manner. After some
21004: little resistance Savonarola gave way to this objection, and thus had
21005: the advantage of making one more concession; but he immediately placed
21006: in Fra Domenico’s hands the vessel containing the consecrated Host. The
21007: idea that the presence of the sacred Mystery might in the worst
21008: extremity avert the ordinary effects of fire hovered in his mind as a
21009: possibility; but the issue on which he counted was of a more positive
21010: kind. In taking up the Host he said quietly, as if he were only doing
21011: what had been presupposed from the first—
21012: 
21013: “Since they are not willing that you should enter with the crucifix, my
21014: brother, enter simply with the Sacrament.”
21015: 
21016: New horror in the Franciscans; new firmness in Savonarola. “It was
21017: impious presumption to carry the Sacrament into the fire: if it were
21018: burned the scandal would be great in the minds of the weak and
21019: ignorant.”
21020: 
21021: “Not at all: even if it were burned, the Accidents only would be
21022: consumed, the Substance would remain.” Here was a question that might
21023: be argued till set of sun and remain as elastic as ever; and no one
21024: could propose settling it by proceeding to the trial, since it was
21025: essentially a preliminary question. It was only necessary that both
21026: sides should remain firm—that the Franciscans should persist in not
21027: permitting the Host to be carried into the fire, and that Fra Domenico
21028: should persist in refusing to enter without it.
21029: 
21030: Meanwhile the clouds were getting darker, the air chiller. Even the
21031: chanting was missed now it had given way to inaudible argument; and the
21032: confused sounds of talk from all points of the Piazza, showing that
21033: expectation was everywhere relaxing, contributed to the irritating
21034: presentiment that nothing decisive would be done. Here and there a
21035: dropping shout was heard; then, more frequent shouts in a rising scale
21036: of scorn.
21037: 
21038: “Light the fire and drive them in!”
21039: 
21040: “Let us have a smell of roast—we want our dinner!”
21041: 
21042: “Come Prophet, let us know whether anything is to happen before the
21043: twenty-four hours are over!”
21044: 
21045: “Yes, yes, what’s your last vision?”
21046: 
21047: “Oh, he’s got a dozen in his inside; they’re the small change for a
21048: miracle!”
21049: 
21050: “Ola, Frate, where are you? Never mind wasting the fuel!”
21051: 
21052: Still the same movement to and fro between the Loggia and the Palace;
21053: still the same debate, slow and unintelligible to the multitude as the
21054: colloquies of insects that touch antennas to no other apparent effect
21055: than that of going and coming. But an interpretation was not long
21056: wanting to unheard debates in which Fra Girolamo was constantly a
21057: speaker: it was he who was hindering the trial; everybody was appealing
21058: to him now, and he was hanging back.
21059: 
21060: Soon the shouts ceased to be distinguishable, and were lost in an
21061: uproar not simply of voices, but of clashing metal and trampling feet.
21062: The suggestions of the irritated people had stimulated old impulses in
21063: Dolfo Spini and his band of Compagnacci; it seemed an opportunity not
21064: to be lost for putting an end to Florentine difficulties by getting
21065: possession of the arch-hypocrite’s person; and there was a vigorous
21066: rush of the armed men towards the Loggia, thrusting the people aside,
21067: or driving them on to the file of soldiery stationed in front of the
21068: Palace. At this movement, everything was suspended both with monks and
21069: embarrassed magistrates except the palpitating watch to see what would
21070: come of the struggle.
21071: 
21072: But the Loggia was well guarded by the band under the brave Salviati;
21073: the soldiers of the Signoria assisted in the repulse; and the trampling
21074: and rushing were all backward again towards the Tetto de’ Pisani, when
21075: the blackness of the heavens seemed to intensify in this moment of
21076: utter confusion; and the rain, which had already been felt in scattered
21077: drops, began to fall with rapidly growing violence, wetting the fuel,
21078: and running in streams off the platform, wetting the weary hungry
21079: people to the skin, and driving every man’s disgust and rage inwards to
21080: ferment there in the damp darkness.
21081: 
21082: Everybody knew now that the Trial by Fire was not to happen. The
21083: Signoria was doubtless glad of the rain, as an obvious reason, better
21084: than any pretext, for declaring that both parties might go home. It was
21085: the issue which Savonarola had expected and desired; yet it would be an
21086: ill description of what he felt to say that he was glad. As that rain
21087: fell, and plashed on the edge of the Loggia, and sent spray over the
21088: altar and all garments and faces, the Frate knew that the demand for
21089: him to enter the fire was at an end. But he knew too, with a certainty
21090: as irresistible as the damp chill that had taken possession of his
21091: frame, that the design of his enemies was fulfilled, and that his
21092: honour was not saved. He knew that he should have to make his way to
21093: San Marco again through the enraged crowd, and that the hearts of many
21094: friends who would once have defended him with their lives would now be
21095: turned against him.
21096: 
21097: When the rain had ceased he asked for a guard from the Signoria, and it
21098: was given him. Had he said that he was willing to die for the work of
21099: his life? Yes, and he had not spoken falsely. But to die in
21100: dishonour—held up to scorn as a hypocrite and a false prophet? “O God!
21101: _that_ is not martyrdom! It is the blotting out of a life that has been
21102: a protest against wrong. Let me die because of the worth that is in me,
21103: not because of my weakness.”
21104: 
21105: The rain had ceased, and the light from the breaking clouds fell on
21106: Savonarola as he left the Loggia in the midst of his guard, walking as
21107: he had come, with the Sacrament in his hand. But there seemed no glory
21108: in the light that fell on him now, no smile of heaven: it was only that
21109: light which shines on, patiently and impartially, justifying or
21110: condemning by simply showing all things in the slow history of their
21111: ripening. He heard no blessing, no tones of pity, but only taunts and
21112: threats. He knew this was a foretaste of coming bitterness; yet his
21113: courage mounted under all moral attack, and he showed no sign of
21114: dismay.
21115: 
21116: “Well parried, Frate!” said Tito, as Savonarola descended the steps of
21117: the Loggia. “But I fear your career at Florence is ended. What say you,
21118: my Niccolò?”
21119: 
21120: “It is a pity his falsehoods were not all of a wise sort,” said
21121: Macchiavelli, with a melancholy shrug. “With the times so much on his
21122: side as they are about Church affairs, he might have done something
21123: great.”
21124: 
21125: 
21126: 
21127: 
21128: CHAPTER LXVI.
21129: A Masque of the Furies.
21130: 
21131: 
21132: The next day was Palm Sunday, or Olive Sunday, as it was chiefly called
21133: in the olive-growing Valdarno; and the morning sun shone with a more
21134: delicious clearness for the yesterday’s rain. Once more Savonarola
21135: mounted the pulpit in San Marco, and saw a flock around him whose faith
21136: in him was still unshaken; and this morning in calm and sad sincerity
21137: he declared himself ready to die: in front of all visions he saw his
21138: own doom. Once more he uttered the benediction, and saw the faces of
21139: men and women lifted towards him in venerating love. Then he descended
21140: the steps of the pulpit and turned away from that sight for ever.
21141: 
21142: For before the sun had set Florence was in an uproar. The passions
21143: which had been roused the day before had been smouldering through that
21144: quiet morning, and had now burst out again with a fury not unassisted
21145: by design, and not without official connivance. The uproar had begun at
21146: the Duomo in an attempt of some Compagnacci to hinder the evening
21147: sermon, which the Piagnoni had assembled to hear. But no sooner had
21148: men’s blood mounted and the disturbances had become an affray than the
21149: cry arose, “To San Marco! the fire to San Marco!”
21150: 
21151: And long before the daylight had died, both the church and convent were
21152: being besieged by an enraged and continually increasing multitude. Not
21153: without resistance. For the monks, long conscious of growing hostility
21154: without, had arms within their walls, and some of them fought as
21155: vigorously in their long white tunics as if they had been Knights
21156: Templars. Even the command of Savonarola could not prevail against the
21157: impulse to self-defence in arms that were still muscular under the
21158: Dominican serge. There were laymen too who had not chosen to depart,
21159: and some of them fought fiercely: there was firing from the high altar
21160: close by the great crucifix, there was pouring of stones and hot embers
21161: from the convent roof, there was close fighting with swords in the
21162: cloisters. Notwithstanding the force of the assailants, the attack
21163: lasted till deep night.
21164: 
21165: The demonstrations of the Government had all been against the convent;
21166: early in the attack guards had been sent for, not to disperse the
21167: assailants, but to command all within the convent to lay down their
21168: arms, all laymen to depart from it, and Savonarola himself to quit the
21169: Florentine territory within twelve hours. Had Savonarola quitted the
21170: convent then, he could hardly have escaped being torn to pieces; he was
21171: willing to go, but his friends hindered him. It was felt to be a great
21172: risk even for some laymen of high name to depart by the garden wall,
21173: but among those who had chosen to do so was Francesco Valori, who hoped
21174: to raise rescue from without.
21175: 
21176: And now when it was deep night—when the struggle could hardly have
21177: lasted much longer, and the Compagnacci might soon have carried their
21178: swords into the library, where Savonarola was praying with the Brethren
21179: who had either not taken up arms or had laid them down at his
21180: command—there came a second body of guards, commissioned by the
21181: Signoria to demand the persons of Fra Girolamo and his two coadjutors,
21182: Fra Domenico and Fra Salvestro.
21183: 
21184: Loud was the roar of triumphant hate when the light of lanterns showed
21185: the Frate issuing from the door of the convent with a guard who
21186: promised him no other safety than that of the prison. The struggle now
21187: was, who should get first in the stream that rushed up the narrow
21188: street to see the Prophet carried back in ignominy to the Piazza where
21189: he had braved it yesterday—who should be in the best place for reaching
21190: his ear with insult, nay, if possible, for smiting him and kicking him.
21191: This was not difficult for some of the armed Compagnacci who were not
21192: prevented from mixing themselves with the guards.
21193: 
21194: When Savonarola felt himself dragged and pushed along in the midst of
21195: that hooting multitude; when lanterns were lifted to show him deriding
21196: faces; when he felt himself spit upon, smitten and kicked with grossest
21197: words of insult, it seemed to him that the worst bitterness of life was
21198: past. If men judged him guilty, and were bent on having his blood, it
21199: was only death that awaited him. But the worst drop of bitterness can
21200: never be wrung on to our lips from without: the lowest depth of
21201: resignation is not to be found in martyrdom; it is only to be found
21202: when we have covered our heads in silence and felt, “I am not worthy to
21203: be a martyr; the Truth shall prosper, but not by me.”
21204: 
21205: But that brief imperfect triumph of insulting the Frate, who had soon
21206: disappeared under the doorway of the Old Palace, was only like the
21207: taste of blood to the tiger. Were there not the houses of the
21208: hypocrite’s friends to be sacked? Already one-half of the armed
21209: multitude, too much in the rear to share greatly in the siege of the
21210: convent, had been employed in the more profitable work of attacking
21211: rich houses, not with planless desire for plunder, but with that
21212: discriminating selection of such as belonged to chief Piagnoni, which
21213: showed that the riot was under guidance, and that the rabble with clubs
21214: and staves was well officered by sword-girt Compagnacci. Was there
21215: not—next criminal after the Frate—the ambitious Francesco Valori,
21216: suspected of wanting with the Frate’s help to make himself a Doge or
21217: Gonfaloniere for life? And the grey-haired man who, eight months ago,
21218: had lifted his arm and his voice in such ferocious demand for justice
21219: on five of his fellow-citizens, only escaped from San Marco to
21220: experience what _others_ called justice—to see his house surrounded by
21221: an angry, greedy multitude, to see his wife shot dead with an arrow,
21222: and to be himself murdered, as he was on his way to answer a summons to
21223: the Palazzo, by the swords of men named Ridolfi and Tornabuoni.
21224: 
21225: In this way that Masque of the Furies, called Riot, was played on in
21226: Florence through the hours of night and early morning.
21227: 
21228: But the chief director was not visible: he had his reasons for issuing
21229: his orders from a private retreat, being of rather too high a name to
21230: let his red feather be seen waving amongst all the work that was to be
21231: done before the dawn. The retreat was the same house and the same room
21232: in a quiet street between Santa Croce and San Marco, where we have seen
21233: Tito paying a secret visit to Dolfo Spini. Here the Captain of the
21234: Compagnacci sat through this memorable night, receiving visitors who
21235: came and went, and went and came, some of them in the guise of armed
21236: Compagnacci, others dressed obscurely and without visible arms. There
21237: was abundant wine on the table, with drinking-cups for chance comers
21238: and though Spini was on his guard against excessive drinking, he took
21239: enough from time to time to heighten the excitement produced by the
21240: news that was being brought to him continually.
21241: 
21242: Among the obscurely-dressed visitors Ser Ceccone was one of the most
21243: frequent, and as the hours advanced towards the morning twilight he had
21244: remained as Spini’s constant companion, together with Francesco Cei,
21245: who was then in rather careless hiding in Florence, expecting to have
21246: his banishment revoked when the Frate’s fall had been accomplished.
21247: 
21248: The tapers had burnt themselves into low shapeless masses, and holes in
21249: the shutters were just marked by a sombre outward light, when Spini,
21250: who had started from his seat and walked up and down with an angry
21251: flush on his face at some talk that had been going forward with those
21252: two unmilitary companions, burst out—
21253: 
21254: “The devil spit him! he shall pay for it, though. Ha, ha! the claws
21255: shall be down on him when he little thinks of them. So _he_ was to be
21256: the great man after all! He’s been pretending to chuck everything
21257: towards my cap, as if I were a blind beggarman, and all the while he’s
21258: been winking and filling his own scarsella. I should like to hang skins
21259: about him and set my hounds on him! And he’s got that fine ruby of
21260: mine, I was fool enough to give him yesterday. Malediction! And he was
21261: laughing at me in his sleeve two years ago, and spoiling the best plan
21262: that ever was laid. I was a fool for trusting myself with a rascal who
21263: had long-twisted contrivances that nobody could see to the end of but
21264: himself.”
21265: 
21266: “A Greek, too, who dropped into Florence with gems packed about him,”
21267: said Francesco Cei, who had a slight smile of amusement on his face at
21268: Spini’s fuming. “You did _not_ choose your confidant very wisely, my
21269: Dolfo.”
21270: 
21271: “He’s a cursed deal cleverer than you, Francesco, and handsomer too,”
21272: said Spini, turning on his associate with a general desire to worry
21273: anything that presented itself.
21274: 
21275: “I humbly conceive,” said Ser Ceccone, “that Messer Francesco’s poetic
21276: genius will outweigh—”
21277: 
21278: “Yes, yes, rub your hands! I hate that notary’s trick of yours,”
21279: interrupted Spini, whose patronage consisted largely in this sort of
21280: frankness. “But there comes Taddeo, or somebody: now’s the time! What
21281: news, eh?” he went on, as two Compagnacci entered with heated looks.
21282: 
21283: “Bad!” said one. “The people have made up their minds they were going
21284: to have the sacking of Soderini’s house, and now they have been balked
21285: we shall have them turning on us, if we don’t take care. I suspect
21286: there are some Mediceans buzzing about among them, and we may see them
21287: attacking your palace over the bridge before long, unless we can find a
21288: bait for them another way.”
21289: 
21290: “I have it!” said Spini, and seizing Taddeo by the belt he drew him
21291: aside to give him directions, while the other went on telling Cei how
21292: the Signoria had interfered about Soderini’s house.
21293: 
21294: “Ecco!” exclaimed Spini, presently, giving Taddeo a slight push towards
21295: the door. “Go, and make quick work.”
21296: 
21297: 
21298: 
21299: 
21300: CHAPTER LXVII.
21301: Waiting by the River.
21302: 
21303: 
21304: About the time when the two Compagnacci went on their errand, there was
21305: another man who, on the opposite side of the Arno, was also going out
21306: into the chill grey twilight. His errand, apparently, could have no
21307: relation to theirs; he was making his way to the brink of the river at
21308: a spot which, though within the city walls, was overlooked by no
21309: dwellings, and which only seemed the more shrouded and lonely for the
21310: warehouses and granaries which at some little distance backward turned
21311: their shoulders to the river. There was a sloping width of long grass
21312: and rushes made all the more dank by broad gutters which here and there
21313: emptied themselves into the Arno.
21314: 
21315: The gutters and the loneliness were the attraction that drew this man
21316: to come and sit down among the grass, and bend over the waters that ran
21317: swiftly in the channelled slope at his side. For he had once had a
21318: large piece of bread brought to him by one of those friendly runlets,
21319: and more than once a raw carrot and apple-parings. It was worth while
21320: to wait for such chances in a place where there was no one to see, and
21321: often in his restless wakefulness he came to watch here before
21322: daybreak; it might save him for one day the need of that silent begging
21323: which consisted in sitting on a church-step by the wayside out beyond
21324: the Porta San Frediano.
21325: 
21326: For Baldassarre hated begging so much that he would perhaps have chosen
21327: to die rather than make even that silent appeal, but for one reason
21328: that made him desire to live. It was no longer a hope; it was only that
21329: possibility which clings to every idea that has taken complete
21330: possession of the mind: the sort of possibility that makes a woman
21331: watch on a headland for the ship which held something dear, though all
21332: her neighbours are certain that the ship was a wreck long years ago.
21333: After he had come out of the convent hospital, where the monks of San
21334: Miniato had taken care of him as long as he was helpless; after he had
21335: watched in vain for the Wife who was to help him, and had begun to
21336: think that she was dead of the pestilence that seemed to fill all the
21337: space since the night he parted from her, he had been unable to
21338: conceive any way in which sacred vengeance could satisfy itself through
21339: his arm. His knife was gone, and he was too feeble in body to win
21340: another by work, too feeble in mind, even if he had had the knife, to
21341: contrive that it should serve its one purpose. He was a shattered,
21342: bewildered, lonely old man; yet he desired to live: _he_ waited for
21343: something of which he had no distinct vision—something dim,
21344: formless—that startled him, and made strong pulsations within him, like
21345: that unknown thing which we look for when we start from sleep, though
21346: no voice or touch has waked us. Baldassarre desired to live; and
21347: therefore he crept out in the grey light, and seated himself in the
21348: long grass, and watched the waters that had a faint promise in them.
21349: 
21350: Meanwhile the Compagnacci were busy at their work. The formidable bands
21351: of armed men, left to do their will with very little interference from
21352: an embarrassed if not conniving Signoria, had parted into two masses,
21353: but both were soon making their way by different roads towards the
21354: Arno. The smaller mass was making for the Ponte Rubaconte, the larger
21355: for the Ponte Vecchio; but in both the same words had passed from mouth
21356: to mouth as a signal, and almost every man of the multitude knew that
21357: he was going to the Via de’ Bardi to sack a house there. If he knew no
21358: other reason, could he demand a better?
21359: 
21360: The armed Compagnacci knew something more, for a brief word of command
21361: flies quickly, and the leaders of the two streams of rabble had a
21362: perfect understanding that they would meet before a certain house a
21363: little towards the eastern end of the Via de’ Bardi, where the master
21364: would probably be in bed, and be surprised in his morning sleep.
21365: 
21366: But the master of that house was neither sleeping nor in bed; he had
21367: not been in bed that night. For Tito’s anxiety to quit Florence had
21368: been stimulated by the events of the previous day: investigations would
21369: follow in which appeals might be made to him delaying his departure:
21370: and in all delay he had an uneasy sense that there was danger.
21371: Falsehood had prospered and waxed strong; but it had nourished the twin
21372: life, Fear. He no longer wore his armour, he was no longer afraid of
21373: Baldassarre; but from the corpse of that dead fear a spirit had
21374: risen—the undying _habit_ of fear. He felt he should not be safe till
21375: he was out of this fierce, turbid Florence; and now he was ready to go.
21376: Maso was to deliver up his house to the new tenant; his horses and
21377: mules were awaiting him in San Gallo; Tessa and the children had been
21378: lodged for the night in the Borgo outside the gate, and would be
21379: dressed in readiness to mount the mules and join him. He descended the
21380: stone steps into the courtyard, he passed through the great doorway,
21381: not the same Tito, but nearly as brilliant as on the day when he had
21382: first entered that house and made the mistake of falling in love with
21383: Romola. The mistake was remedied now: the old life was cast off, and
21384: was soon to be far behind him.
21385: 
21386: He turned with rapid steps towards the Piazza dei Mozzi, intending to
21387: pass over the Ponte Rubaconte; but as he went along certain sounds came
21388: upon his ears that made him turn round and walk yet more quickly in the
21389: opposite direction. Was the mob coming into Oltrarno? It was a
21390: vexation, for he would have preferred the more private road. He must
21391: now go by the Ponte Vecchio; and unpleasant sensations made him draw
21392: his mantle close round him, and walk at his utmost speed. There was no
21393: one to see him in that grey twilight. But before he reached the end of
21394: the Via de’ Bardi, like sounds fell on his ear again, and this time
21395: they were much louder and nearer. Could he have been deceived before?
21396: The mob must be coming over the Ponte Vecchio. Again he turned, from an
21397: impulse of fear that was stronger than reflection; but it was only to
21398: be assured that the mob was actually entering the street from the
21399: opposite end. He chose not to go back to his house: after all they
21400: would not attack _him_. Still, he had some valuables about him; and all
21401: things except reason and order are possible with a mob. But necessity
21402: does the work of courage. He went on towards the Ponte Vecchio, the
21403: rush and the trampling and the confused voices getting so loud before
21404: him that he had ceased to hear them behind.
21405: 
21406: For he had reached the end of the street, and the crowd pouring from
21407: the bridge met him at the turning and hemmed in his way. He had not
21408: time to wonder at a sudden shout before he felt himself surrounded,
21409: not, in the first instance, by an unarmed rabble, but by armed
21410: Compagnacci; the next sensation was that his cap fell off, and that he
21411: was thrust violently forward amongst the rabble, along the narrow
21412: passage of the bridge. Then he distinguished the shouts, “Piagnone!
21413: Medicean! Piagnone! Throw him over the bridge!”
21414: 
21415: His mantle was being torn off him with strong pulls that would have
21416: throttled him if the fibula had not given way. Then his scarsella was
21417: snatched at; but all the while he was being hustled and dragged; and
21418: the snatch failed—his scarsella still hung at his side. Shouting,
21419: yelling, half motiveless execration rang stunningly in his ears,
21420: spreading even amongst those who had not yet seen him, and only knew
21421: there was a man to be reviled. Tito’s horrible dread was that he should
21422: be struck down or trampled on before he reached the open arches that
21423: surmount the centre of the bridge. There was one hope for him, that
21424: they might throw him over before they had wounded him or beaten the
21425: strength out of him; and his whole soul was absorbed in that one hope
21426: and its obverse terror.
21427: 
21428: Yes—they _were_ at the arches. In that moment Tito, with bloodless face
21429: and eyes dilated, had one of the self-preserving inspirations that come
21430: in extremity. With a sudden desperate effort he mastered the clasp of
21431: his belt, and flung belt and scarsella forward towards a yard of clear
21432: space against the parapet, crying in a ringing voice—
21433: 
21434: “There are diamonds! there is gold!”
21435: 
21436: In the instant the hold on him was relaxed, and there was a rush
21437: towards the scarsella. He threw himself on the parapet with a desperate
21438: leap, and the next moment plunged—plunged with a great plash into the
21439: dark river far below.
21440: 
21441: It was his chance of salvation; and it was a good chance. His life had
21442: been saved once before by his fine swimming, and as he rose to the
21443: surface again after his long dive he had a sense of deliverance. He
21444: struck out with all the energy of his strong prime, and the current
21445: helped him. If he could only swim beyond the Ponte alla Carrara he
21446: might land in a remote part of the city, and even yet reach San Gallo.
21447: Life was still before him. And the idiot mob, shouting and bellowing on
21448: the bridge there, would think he was drowned.
21449: 
21450: They did think so. Peering over the parapet along the dark stream, they
21451: could not see afar off the moving blackness of the floating hair, and
21452: the velvet tunic-sleeves.
21453: 
21454: It was only from the other way that a pale olive face could be seen
21455: looking white above the dark water: a face not easy even for the
21456: indifferent to forget, with its square forehead, the long low arch of
21457: the eyebrows, and the long lustrous agate-like eyes. Onward the face
21458: went on the dark current, with inflated quivering nostrils, with the
21459: blue veins distended on the temples. One bridge was passed—the bridge
21460: of Santa Trinita. Should he risk landing now rather than trust to his
21461: strength? No. He heard, or fancied he heard, yells and cries pursuing
21462: him. Terror pressed him most from the side of his fellow-men: he was
21463: less afraid of indefinite chances, and he swam on, panting and
21464: straining. He was not so fresh as he would have been if he had passed
21465: the night in sleep.
21466: 
21467: Yet the next bridge—the last bridge—was passed. He was conscious of it;
21468: but in the tumult of his blood, he could only feel vaguely that he was
21469: safe and might land. But where? The current was having its way with
21470: him: he hardly knew where he was: exhaustion was bringing on the dreamy
21471: state that precedes unconsciousness.
21472: 
21473: But now there were eyes that discerned him—aged eyes, strong for the
21474: distance. Baldassarre, looking up blankly from the search in the runlet
21475: that brought him nothing, had seen a white object coming along the
21476: broader stream. Could that be any fortunate chance for _him_? He looked
21477: and looked till the object gathered form: then he leaned forward with a
21478: start as he sat among the rank green stems, and his eyes seemed to be
21479: filled with a new light. Yet he only watched—motionless. Something was
21480: being brought to him.
21481: 
21482: The next instant a man’s body was cast violently on the grass two yards
21483: from him, and he started forward like a panther, clutching the velvet
21484: tunic as he fell forward on the body and flashed a look in the man’s
21485: face.
21486: 
21487: Dead—was he dead? The eyes were rigid. But no, it could not be—Justice
21488: had brought him. Men looked dead sometimes, and yet the life came back
21489: into them. Baldassarre did not feel feeble in that moment. He knew just
21490: what he could do. He got his large fingers within the neck of the tunic
21491: and held them there, kneeling on one knee beside the body and watching
21492: the face. There was a fierce hope in his heart, but it was mixed with
21493: trembling. In his eyes there was only fierceness: all the slow-burning
21494: remnant of life within him seemed to have leaped into flame.
21495: 
21496: Rigid—rigid still. Those eyes with the half-fallen lids were locked
21497: against vengeance. _Could_ it be that he was dead? There was nothing to
21498: measure the time: it seemed long enough for hope to freeze into
21499: despair.
21500: 
21501: Surely at last the eyelids were quivering: the eyes were no longer
21502: rigid. There was a vibrating light in them; they opened wide.
21503: 
21504: “Ah, yes! You see me—you know me!”
21505: 
21506: Tito knew him; but he did not know whether it was life or death that
21507: had brought him into the presence of his injured father. It might be
21508: death—and death might mean this chill gloom with the face of the
21509: hideous past hanging over him for ever.
21510: 
21511: But now Baldassarre’s only dread was, lest the young limbs should
21512: escape him. He pressed his knuckles against the round throat, and knelt
21513: upon the chest with all the force of his aged frame. Let death come
21514: now!
21515: 
21516: Again he kept his watch on the face. And when the eyes were rigid
21517: again, he dared not trust them. He would never lose his hold till some
21518: one came and found them. Justice would send some witness, and then he,
21519: Baldassarre, would declare that he had killed this traitor, to whom he
21520: had once been a father. They would perhaps believe him now, and then he
21521: would be content with the struggle of justice on earth—then he would
21522: desire to die with his hold on this body, and follow the traitor to
21523: hell that he might clutch him there.
21524: 
21525: And so he knelt, and so he pressed his knuckles against the round
21526: throat, without trusting to the seeming death, till the light got
21527: strong and he could kneel no longer. Then he sat on the body, still
21528: clutching the neck of the tunic. But the hours went on, and no witness
21529: came. No eyes descried afar off the two human bodies among the tall
21530: grass by the riverside. Florence was busy with greater affairs, and the
21531: preparation of a deeper tragedy.
21532: 
21533: Not long after those two bodies were lying in the grass, Savonarola was
21534: being tortured, and crying out in his agony, “I will confess!”
21535: 
21536: It was not until the sun was westward that a waggon drawn by a mild
21537: grey ox came to the edge of the grassy margin, and as the man who led
21538: it was leaning to gather up the round stones that lay heaped in
21539: readiness to be carried away, he detected some startling object in the
21540: grass. The aged man had fallen forward, and his dead clutch was on the
21541: garment of the other. It was not possible to separate them: nay, it was
21542: better to put them into the waggon and carry them as they were into the
21543: great Piazza, that notice might be given to the Eight.
21544: 
21545: As the waggon entered the frequented streets there was a growing crowd
21546: escorting it with its strange burden. No one knew the bodies for a long
21547: while, for the aged face had fallen forward, half hiding the younger.
21548: But before they had been moved out of sight, they had been recognised.
21549: 
21550: “I know that old man,” Piero di Cosimo had testified. “I painted his
21551: likeness once. He is the prisoner who clutched Melema on the steps of
21552: the Duomo.”
21553: 
21554: “He is perhaps the same old man who appeared at supper in my gardens,”
21555: said Bernardo Rucellai, one of the Eight. “I had forgotten him. I
21556: thought he had died in prison. But there is no knowing the truth now.”
21557: 
21558: Who shall put his finger on the work of justice, and say, “It is
21559: there”? Justice is like the Kingdom of God—it is not without us as a
21560: fact, it is within us as a great yearning.
21561: 
21562: 
21563: 
21564: 
21565: CHAPTER LXVIII.
21566: Romola’s waking.
21567: 
21568: 
21569: Romola in her boat passed from dreaming into long deep sleep, and then
21570: again from deep sleep into busy dreaming, till at last she felt herself
21571: stretching out her arms in the court of the Bargello, where the
21572: flickering flames of the tapers seemed to get stronger and stronger
21573: till the dark scene was blotted out with light. Her eyes opened and she
21574: saw it was the light of morning. Her boat was lying still in a little
21575: creek; on her right-hand lay the speckless sapphire-blue of the
21576: Mediterranean; on her left one of those scenes which were and still are
21577: repeated again and again like a sweet rhythm, on the shores of that
21578: loveliest sea.
21579: 
21580: In a deep curve of the mountains lay a breadth of green land, curtained
21581: by gentle tree-shadowed slopes leaning towards the rocky heights. Up
21582: these slopes might be seen here and there, gleaming between the
21583: tree-tops, a pathway leading to a little irregular mass of building
21584: that seemed to have clambered in a hasty way up the mountain-side, and
21585: taken a difficult stand there for the sake of showing the tall belfry
21586: as a sight of beauty to the scattered and clustered houses of the
21587: village below. The rays of the newly-risen sun fell obliquely on the
21588: westward horn of this crescent-shaped nook: all else lay in dewy
21589: shadow. No sound came across the stillness; the very waters seemed to
21590: have curved themselves there for rest.
21591: 
21592: The delicious sun-rays fell on Romola and thrilled her gently like a
21593: caress. She lay motionless, hardly watching the scene; rather, feeling
21594: simply the presence of peace and beauty. While we are still in our
21595: youth there can always come, in our early waking, moments when mere
21596: passive existence is itself a Lethe, when the exquisiteness of subtle
21597: indefinite sensation creates a bliss which is without memory and
21598: without desire. As the soft warmth penetrated Romola’s young limbs, as
21599: her eyes rested on this sequestered luxuriance, it seemed that the
21600: agitating past had glided away like that dark scene in the Bargello,
21601: and that the afternoon dreams of her girlhood had really come back to
21602: her. For a minute or two the oblivion was untroubled; she did not even
21603: think that she could rest here for ever, she only felt that she rested.
21604: Then she became distinctly conscious that she was lying in the boat
21605: which had been bearing her over the waters all through the night.
21606: Instead of bringing her to death, it had been the gently lulling cradle
21607: of a new life. And in spite of her evening despair she was glad that
21608: the morning had come to her again: glad to think that she was resting
21609: in the familiar sunlight rather than in the unknown regions of death.
21610: _Could_ she not rest here? No sound from Florence would reach her.
21611: Already oblivion was troubled; from behind the golden haze were
21612: piercing domes and towers and walls, parted by a river and enclosed by
21613: the green hills.
21614: 
21615: She rose from her reclining posture and sat up in the boat, willing, if
21616: she could, to resist the rush of thoughts that urged themselves along
21617: with the conjecture how far the boat had carried her. Why need she
21618: mind? This was a sheltered nook where there were simple villagers who
21619: would not harm her. For a little while, at least, she might rest and
21620: resolve on nothing. Presently she would go and get some bread and milk,
21621: and then she would nestle in the green quiet, and feel that there was a
21622: pause in her life. She turned to watch the crescent-shaped valley, that
21623: she might get back the soothing sense of peace and beauty which she had
21624: felt in her first waking.
21625: 
21626: She had not been in this attitude of contemplation more than a few
21627: minutes when across the stillness there came a piercing cry; not a
21628: brief cry, but continuous and more and more intense. Romola felt sure
21629: it was the cry of a little child in distress that no one came to help.
21630: She started up and put one foot on the side of the boat ready to leap
21631: on to the beach; but she paused there and listened: the mother of the
21632: child must be near, the cry must soon cease. But it went on, and drew
21633: Romola so irresistibly, seeming the more piteous to her for the sense
21634: of peace which had preceded it, that she jumped on to the beach and
21635: walked many paces before she knew what direction she would take. The
21636: cry, she thought, came from some rough garden growth many yards on her
21637: right-hand, where she saw a half-ruined hovel. She climbed over a low
21638: broken stone fence, and made her way across patches of weedy green
21639: crops and ripe but neglected corn. The cry grew plainer, and convinced
21640: that she was right she hastened towards the hovel; but even in that
21641: hurried walk she felt an oppressive change in the air as she left the
21642: sea behind. Was there some taint lurking amongst the green luxuriance
21643: that had seemed such an inviting shelter from the heat of the coming
21644: day? She could see the opening into the hovel now, and the cry was
21645: darting through her like a pain. The next moment her foot was within
21646: the doorway, but the sight she beheld in the sombre light arrested her
21647: with a shock of awe and horror. On the straw, with which the floor was
21648: scattered, lay three dead bodies, one of a tall man, one of a girl
21649: about eight years old, and one of a young woman whose long black hair
21650: was being clutched and pulled by a living child—the child that was
21651: sending forth the piercing cry. Romola’s experience in the haunts of
21652: death and disease made thought and action prompt: she lifted the little
21653: living child, and in trying to soothe it on her bosom, still sent to
21654: look at the bodies and see if they were really dead. The strongly
21655: marked type of race in their features, and their peculiar garb, made
21656: her conjecture that they were Spanish or Portuguese Jews, who had
21657: perhaps been put ashore and abandoned there by rapacious sailors, to
21658: whom their property remained as a prey. Such things were happening
21659: continually to Jews compelled to abandon their homes by the
21660: Inquisition: the cruelty of greed thrust them from the sea, and the
21661: cruelty of superstition thrust them back to it.
21662: 
21663: “But, surely,” thought Romola, “I shall find some woman in the village
21664: whose mother’s heart will not let her refuse to tend this helpless
21665: child—if the real mother is indeed dead.”
21666: 
21667: This doubt remained, because while the man and girl looked emaciated
21668: and also showed signs of having been long dead, the woman seemed to
21669: have been hardier, and had not quite lost the robustness of her form.
21670: Romola, kneeling, was about to lay her hand on the heart; but as she
21671: lifted the piece of yellow woollen drapery that lay across the bosom,
21672: she saw the purple spots which marked the familiar pestilence. Then it
21673: struck her that if the villagers knew of this, she might have more
21674: difficulty than she had expected in getting help from them; they would
21675: perhaps shrink from her with that child in her arms. But she had money
21676: to offer them, and they would not refuse to give her some goat’s milk
21677: in exchange for it.
21678: 
21679: She set out at once towards the village, her mind filled now with the
21680: effort to soothe the little dark creature, and with wondering how she
21681: should win some woman to be good to it. She could not help hoping a
21682: little in a certain awe she had observed herself to inspire, when she
21683: appeared, unknown and unexpected, in her religious dress. As she passed
21684: across a breadth of cultivated ground, she noticed, with wonder, that
21685: little patches of corn mingled with the other crops had been left to
21686: over-ripeness untouched by the sickle, and that golden apples and dark
21687: figs lay rotting on the weedy earth. There were grassy spaces within
21688: sight, but no cow, or sheep, or goat. The stillness began to have
21689: something fearful in it to Romola; she hurried along towards the
21690: thickest cluster of houses, where there would be the most life to
21691: appeal to on behalf of the helpless life she carried in her arms. But
21692: she had picked up two figs, and bit little pieces from the sweet pulp
21693: to still the child with.
21694: 
21695: She entered between two lines of dwellings. It was time that villagers
21696: should have been stirring long ago, but not a soul was in sight. The
21697: air was becoming more and more oppressive, laden, it seemed, with some
21698: horrible impurity. There was a door open; she looked in, and saw grim
21699: emptiness. Another open door; and through that she saw a man lying dead
21700: with all his garments on, his head lying athwart a spade handle, and an
21701: earthenware cruse in his hand, as if he had fallen suddenly.
21702: 
21703: Romola felt horror taking possession of her. Was she in a village of
21704: the unburied dead? She wanted to listen if there were any faint sound,
21705: but the child cried out afresh when she ceased to feed it, and the cry
21706: filled her ears. At last she saw a figure crawling slowly out of a
21707: house, and soon sinking back in a sitting posture against the wall. She
21708: hastened towards the figure; it was a young woman in fevered anguish,
21709: and she, too, held a pitcher in her hand. As Romola approached her she
21710: did not start; the one need was too absorbing for any other idea to
21711: impress itself on her.
21712: 
21713: “Water! get me water!” she said, with a moaning utterance.
21714: 
21715: Romola stooped to take the pitcher, and said gently in her ear, “You
21716: shall have water; can you point towards the well?”
21717: 
21718: The hand was lifted towards the more distant end of the little street,
21719: and Romola set off at once with as much speed as she could use under
21720: the difficulty of carrying the pitcher as well as feeding the child.
21721: But the little one was getting more content as the morsels of sweet
21722: pulp were repeated, and ceased to distress her with its cry, so that
21723: she could give a less distracted attention to the objects around her.
21724: 
21725: The well lay twenty yards or more beyond the end of the street, and as
21726: Romola was approaching it her eyes were directed to the opposite green
21727: slope immediately below the church. High up, on a patch of grass
21728: between the trees, she had descried a cow and a couple of goats, and
21729: she tried to trace a line of path that would lead her close to that
21730: cheering sight, when once she had done her errand to the well. Occupied
21731: in this way, she was not aware that she was very near the well, and
21732: that some one approaching it on the other side had fixed a pair of
21733: astonished eyes upon her.
21734: 
21735: Romola certainly presented a sight which, at, that moment and in that
21736: place, could hardly have been seen without some pausing and
21737: palpitation. With her gaze fixed intently on the distant slope, the
21738: long lines of her thick grey garment giving a gliding character to her
21739: rapid walk, her hair rolling backward and illuminated on the left side
21740: by the sun-rays, the little olive baby on her right arm now looking out
21741: with jet-black eyes, she might well startle that youth of fifteen,
21742: accustomed to swing the censer in the presence of a Madonna less fair
21743: and marvellous than this.
21744: 
21745: “She carries a pitcher in her hand—to fetch water for the sick. It is
21746: the Holy Mother, come to take care of the people who have the
21747: pestilence.”
21748: 
21749: It was a sight of awe: she would, perhaps, be angry with those who
21750: fetched water for themselves only. The youth flung down his vessel in
21751: terror, and Romola, aware now of some one near her, saw the black and
21752: white figure fly as if for dear life towards the slope she had just
21753: been contemplating. But remembering the parched sufferer, she
21754: half-filled her pitcher quickly and hastened back.
21755: 
21756: Entering the house to look for a small cup, she saw salt meat and meal:
21757: there were no signs of want in the dwelling. With nimble movement she
21758: seated baby on the ground, and lifted a cup of water to the sufferer,
21759: who drank eagerly and then closed her eyes and leaned her head
21760: backward, seeming to give herself up to the sense of relief. Presently
21761: she opened her eyes, and, looking at Romola, said languidly—
21762: 
21763: “Who are you?”
21764: 
21765: “I came over the sea,” said Romola, “I only came this morning. Are all
21766: the people dead in these houses?”
21767: 
21768: “I think they are all ill now—all that are not dead. My father and my
21769: sister lie dead upstairs, and there is no one to bury them: and soon I
21770: shall die.”
21771: 
21772: “Not so, I hope,” said Romola. “I am come to take care of you. I am
21773: used to the pestilence; I am not afraid. But there must be some left
21774: who are not ill. I saw a youth running towards the mountain when I went
21775: to the well.”
21776: 
21777: “I cannot tell. When the pestilence came, a great many people went
21778: away, and drove off the cows and goats. Give me more water!”
21779: 
21780: Romola, suspecting that if she followed the direction of the youth’s
21781: flight, she should find some men and women who were still healthy and
21782: able, determined to seek them out at once, that she might at least win
21783: them to take care of the child, and leave her free to come back and see
21784: how many living needed help, and how many dead needed burial. She
21785: trusted to her powers of persuasion to conquer the aid of the timorous,
21786: when once she knew what was to be done.
21787: 
21788: Promising the sick woman to come back to her, she lifted the dark
21789: bantling again, and set off towards the slope. She felt no burden of
21790: choice on her now, no longing for death. She was thinking how she would
21791: go to the other sufferers, as she had gone to that fevered woman.
21792: 
21793: But, with the child on her arm, it was not so easy to her as usual to
21794: walk up a slope, and it seemed a long while before the winding path
21795: took her near the cow and the goats. She was beginning herself to feel
21796: faint from heat, hunger, and thirst, and as she reached a double
21797: turning, she paused to consider whether she would not wait near the
21798: cow, which some one was likely to come and milk soon, rather than toil
21799: up to the church before she had taken any rest. Raising her eyes to
21800: measure the steep distance, she saw peeping between the boughs, not
21801: more than five yards off, a broad round face, watching her attentively,
21802: and lower down the black skirt of a priest’s garment, and a hand
21803: grasping a bucket. She stood mutely observing, and the face, too,
21804: remained motionless. Romola had often witnessed the overpowering force
21805: of dread in cases of pestilence, and she was cautious.
21806: 
21807: Raising her voice in a tone of gentle pleading, she said, “I came over
21808: the sea. I am hungry, and so is the child. Will you not give us some
21809: milk?”
21810: 
21811: Romola had divined part of the truth, but she had not divined that
21812: preoccupation of the priest’s mind which charged her words with a
21813: strange significance. Only a little while ago, the young acolyte had
21814: brought word to the Padre that he had seen the Holy Mother with the
21815: Babe, fetching water for the sick: she was as tall as the cypresses,
21816: and had a light about her head, and she looked up at the church. The
21817: pievano (parish priest) had not listened with entire belief: he had
21818: been more than fifty years in the world without having any vision of
21819: the Madonna, and he thought the boy might have misinterpreted the
21820: unexpected appearance of a villager. But he had been made uneasy, and
21821: before venturing to come down and milk his cow, he had repeated many
21822: Aves. The pievano’s conscience tormented him a little: he trembled at
21823: the pestilence, but he also trembled at the thought of the mild-faced
21824: Mother, conscious that that Invisible Mercy might demand something more
21825: of him than prayers and “Hails.” In this state of mind—unable to banish
21826: the image the boy had raised of the Mother with the glory about her
21827: tending the sick—the pievano had come down to milk his cow, and had
21828: suddenly caught sight of Romola pausing at the parted way. Her pleading
21829: words, with their strange refinement of tone and accent, instead of
21830: being explanatory, had a preternatural sound for him. Yet he did not
21831: quite believe he saw the Holy Mother: he was in a state of alarmed
21832: hesitation. If anything miraculous were happening, he felt there was no
21833: strong presumption that the miracle would be in his favour. He dared
21834: not run away; he dared not advance.
21835: 
21836: “Come down,” said Romola, after a pause. “Do not fear. Fear rather to
21837: deny food to the hungry when they ask you.”
21838: 
21839: A moment after, the boughs were parted, and the complete figure of a
21840: thickset priest with a broad, harmless face, his black frock much worn
21841: and soiled, stood, bucket in hand, looking at her timidly, and still
21842: keeping aloof as he took the path towards the cow in silence.
21843: 
21844: Romola followed him and watched him without speaking again, as he
21845: seated himself against the tethered cow, and, when he had nervously
21846: drawn some milk, gave it to her in a brass cup he carried with him in
21847: the bucket. As Romola put the cup to the lips of the eager child, and
21848: afterwards drank some milk herself, the Padre observed her from his
21849: wooden stool with a timidity that changed its character a little. He
21850: recognised the Hebrew baby, he was certain that he had a substantial
21851: woman before him; but there was still something strange and
21852: unaccountable in Romola’s presence in this spot, and the Padre had a
21853: presentiment that things were going to change with him. Moreover, that
21854: Hebrew baby was terribly associated with the dread of pestilence.
21855: 
21856: Nevertheless, when Romola smiled at the little one sucking its own
21857: milky lips, and stretched out the brass cup again, saying, “Give us
21858: more, good father,” he obeyed less nervously than before.
21859: 
21860: Romola on her side was not unobservant; and when the second supply of
21861: milk had been drunk, she looked down at the round-headed man, and said
21862: with mild decision—
21863: 
21864: “And now tell me, father, how this pestilence came, and why you let
21865: your people die without the sacraments; and lie unburied. For I am come
21866: over the sea to help those who are left alive—and you, too, will help
21867: them now.”
21868: 
21869: He told her the story of the pestilence: and while he was telling it,
21870: the youth, who had fled before, had come peeping and advancing
21871: gradually, till at last he stood and watched the scene from behind a
21872: neighbouring bush.
21873: 
21874: Three families of Jews, twenty souls in all, had been put ashore many
21875: weeks ago, some of them already ill of the pestilence. The villagers,
21876: said the priest, had of course refused to give shelter to the
21877: miscreants, otherwise than in a distant hovel, and under heaps of
21878: straw. But when the strangers had died of the plague, and some of the
21879: people had thrown the bodies into the sea, the sea had brought them
21880: back again in a great storm, and everybody was smitten with terror. A
21881: grave was dug, and the bodies were buried; but then the pestilence
21882: attacked the Christians, and the greater number of the villagers went
21883: away over the mountain, driving away their few cattle, and carrying
21884: provisions. The priest had not fled; he had stayed and prayed for the
21885: people, and he had prevailed on the youth Jacopo to stay with him; but
21886: he confessed that a mortal terror of the plague had taken hold of him,
21887: and he had not dared to go down into the valley.
21888: 
21889: “You will fear no longer, father,” said Romola, in a tone of
21890: encouraging authority; “you will come down with me, and we will see who
21891: is living, and we will look for the dead to bury them. I have walked
21892: about for months where the pestilence was, and see, I am strong. Jacopo
21893: will come with us,” she added, motioning to the peeping lad, who came
21894: slowly from behind his defensive bush, as if invisible threads were
21895: dragging him.
21896: 
21897: “Come, Jacopo,” said Romola again, smiling at him, “you will carry the
21898: child for me. See! your arms are strong, and I am tired.”
21899: 
21900: That was a dreadful proposal to Jacopo, and to the priest also; but
21901: they were both under a peculiar influence forcing them to obey. The
21902: suspicion that Romola was a supernatural form was dissipated, but their
21903: minds were filled instead with the more effective sense that she was a
21904: human being whom God had sent over the sea to command them.
21905: 
21906: “Now we will carry down the milk,” said Romola, “and see if any one
21907: wants it.”
21908: 
21909: So they went all together down the slope, and that morning the
21910: sufferers saw help come to them in their despair. There were hardly
21911: more than a score alive in the whole valley; but all of these were
21912: comforted, most were saved, and the dead were buried.
21913: 
21914: In this way days, weeks, and months passed with Romola till the men
21915: were digging and sowing again, till the women smiled at her as they
21916: carried their great vases on their heads to the well, and the Hebrew
21917: baby was a tottering tumbling Christian, Benedetto by name, having been
21918: baptised in the church on the mountain-side. But by that time she
21919: herself was suffering from the fatigue and languor that must come after
21920: a continuous strain on mind and body. She had taken for her dwelling
21921: one of the houses abandoned by their owners, standing a little aloof
21922: from the village street; and here on a thick heap of clean straw—a
21923: delicious bed for those who do not dream of down—she felt glad to lie
21924: still through most of the daylight hours, taken care of along with the
21925: little Benedetto by a woman whom the pestilence had widowed.
21926: 
21927: Every day the Padre and Jacopo and the small flock of surviving
21928: villagers paid their visit to this cottage to see the blessed Lady, and
21929: to bring her of their best as an offering—honey, fresh cakes, eggs, and
21930: polenta. It was a sight they could none of them forget, a sight they
21931: all told of in their old age—how the sweet and sainted lady with her
21932: fair face, her golden hair, and her brown eyes that had a blessing in
21933: them, lay weary with her labours after she had been sent over the sea
21934: to help them in their extremity, and how the queer little black
21935: Benedetto used to crawl about the straw by her side and want everything
21936: that was brought to her, and she always gave him a bit of what she
21937: took, and told them if they loved her they must be good to Benedetto.
21938: 
21939: Many legends were afterwards told in that valley about the blessed Lady
21940: who came over the sea, but they were legends by which all who heard
21941: might know that in times gone by a woman had done beautiful loving
21942: deeds there, rescuing those who were ready to perish.
21943: 
21944: 
21945: 
21946: 
21947: CHAPTER LXIX.
21948: Homeward.
21949: 
21950: 
21951: In those silent wintry hours when Romola lay resting from her
21952: weariness, her mind, travelling back over the past, and gazing across
21953: the undefined distance of the future, saw all objects from a new
21954: position. Her experience since the moment of her waking in the boat had
21955: come to her with as strong an effect as that of the fresh seal on the
21956: dissolving wax. She had felt herself without bonds, without motive;
21957: sinking in mere egoistic complaining that life could bring her no
