21958: content; feeling a right to say, “I am tired of life, I want to die.”
21959: That thought had sobbed within her as she fell asleep, but from the
21960: moment after her waking when the cry had drawn her, she had not even
21961: reflected, as she used to do in Florence, that she was glad to live
21962: because she could lighten sorrow—she had simply lived, with so
21963: energetic an impulse to share the life around her, to answer the call
21964: of need and do the work which cried aloud to be done, that the reasons
21965: for living, enduring, labouring, never took the form of argument.
21966: 
21967: The experience was like a new baptism to Romola. In Florence the
21968: simpler relations of the human being to his fellow-men had been
21969: complicated for her with all the special ties of marriage, the State,
21970: and religious discipleship, and when these had disappointed her trust,
21971: the shock seemed to have shaken her aloof from life and stunned her
21972: sympathy. But now she said, “It was mere baseness in me to desire
21973: death. If everything else is doubtful, this suffering that I can help
21974: is certain; if the glory of the cross is an illusion, the sorrow is
21975: only the truer. While the strength is in my arm I will stretch it out
21976: to the fainting; while the light visits my eyes they shall seek the
21977: forsaken.”
21978: 
21979: And then the past arose with a fresh appeal to her. Her work in this
21980: green valley was done, and the emotions that were disengaged from the
21981: people immediately around her rushed back into the old deep channels of
21982: use and affection. That rare possibility of self-contemplation which
21983: comes in any complete severance from our wonted life made her judge
21984: herself as she had never done before: the compunction which is
21985: inseparable from a sympathetic nature keenly alive to the possible
21986: experience of others, began to stir in her with growing force. She
21987: questioned the justness of her own conclusions, of her own deeds: she
21988: had been rash, arrogant, always dissatisfied that others were not good
21989: enough, while she herself had not been true to what her soul had once
21990: recognised as the best. She began to condemn her flight: after all, it
21991: had been cowardly self-care; the grounds on which Savonarola had once
21992: taken her back were truer, deeper than the grounds she had had for her
21993: second flight. How could she feel the needs of others and not feel,
21994: above all, the needs of the nearest?
21995: 
21996: But then came reaction against such self-reproach. The memory of her
21997: life with Tito, of the conditions which made their real union
21998: impossible, while their external union imposed a set of false duties on
21999: her which were essentially the concealment and sanctioning of what her
22000: mind revolted from, told her that flight had been her only resource.
22001: All minds, except such as are delivered from doubt by dulness of
22002: sensibility, must be subject to this recurring conflict where the
22003: many-twisted conditions of life have forbidden the fulfilment of a
22004: bond. For in strictness there is no replacing of relations: the
22005: presence of the new does not nullify the failure and breach of the old.
22006: Life has lost its perfection: it has been maimed; and until the wounds
22007: are quite scarred, conscience continually casts backward, doubting
22008: glances.
22009: 
22010: Romola shrank with dread from the renewal of her proximity to Tito, and
22011: yet she was uneasy that she had put herself out of reach of knowing
22012: what was his fate—uneasy that the moment might yet come when he would
22013: be in misery and need her. There was still a thread of pain within her,
22014: testifying to those words of Fra Girolamo, that she could not cease to
22015: be a wife. Could anything utterly cease for her that had once mingled
22016: itself with the current of her heart’s blood?
22017: 
22018: Florence, and all her life there, had come back to her like hunger; her
22019: feelings could not go wandering after the possible and the vague: their
22020: living fibre was fed with the memory of familiar things. And the
22021: thought that she had divided herself from them for ever became more and
22022: more importunate in these hours that were unfilled with action. What if
22023: Fra Girolamo had been wrong? What if the life of Florence was a web of
22024: inconsistencies? Was she, then, something higher, that she should shake
22025: the dust from off her feet, and say, “This world is not good enough for
22026: me”? If she had been really higher, she would not so easily have lost
22027: all her trust.
22028: 
22029: Her indignant grief for her godfather had no longer complete possession
22030: of her, and her sense of debt to Savonarola was recovering
22031: predominance. Nothing that had come, or was to come, could do away with
22032: the fact that there had been a great inspiration in him which had waked
22033: a new life in her. Who, in all her experience, could demand the same
22034: gratitude from her as he? His errors—might they not bring calamities?
22035: 
22036: She could not rest. She hardly knew whether it was her strength
22037: returning with the budding leaves that made her active again, or
22038: whether it was her eager longing to get nearer Florence. She did not
22039: imagine herself daring to enter Florence, but the desire to be near
22040: enough to learn what was happening there urged itself with a strength
22041: that excluded all other purposes.
22042: 
22043: And one March morning the people in the valley were gathered together
22044: to see the blessed Lady depart. Jacopo had fetched a mule for her, and
22045: was going with her over the mountains. The Padre, too, was going with
22046: her to the nearest town, that he might help her in learning the safest
22047: way by which she might get to Pistoja. Her store of trinkets and money,
22048: untouched in this valley, was abundant for her needs.
22049: 
22050: If Romola had been less drawn by the longing that was taking her away,
22051: it would have been a hard moment for her when she walked along the
22052: village street for the last time, while the Padre and Jacopo, with the
22053: mule, were awaiting her near the well. Her steps were hindered by the
22054: wailing people, who knelt and kissed her hands, then clung to her
22055: skirts and kissed the grey folds, crying, “Ah, why will you go, when
22056: the good season is beginning and the crops will be plentiful? Why will
22057: you go?”
22058: 
22059: “Do not be sorry,” said Romola, “you are well now, and I shall remember
22060: you. I must go and see if my own people want me.”
22061: 
22062: “Ah, yes, if they have the pestilence!”
22063: 
22064: “Look at us again, Madonna!”
22065: 
22066: “Yes, yes, we will be good to the little Benedetto!”
22067: 
22068: At last Romola mounted her mule, but a vigorous screaming from
22069: Benedetto as he saw her turn from him in this new position, was an
22070: excuse for all the people to follow her and insist that he must ride on
22071: the mule’s neck to the foot of the slope.
22072: 
22073: The parting must come at last, but as Romola turned continually before
22074: she passed out of sight, she saw the little flock lingering to catch
22075: the last waving of her hand.
22076: 
22077: 
22078: 
22079: 
22080: CHAPTER LXX.
22081: Meeting Again.
22082: 
22083: 
22084: On the fourteenth of April Romola was once more within the walls of
22085: Florence. Unable to rest at Pistoja, where contradictory reports
22086: reached her about the Trial by Fire, she had gone on to Prato; and was
22087: beginning to think that she should be drawn on to Florence in spite of
22088: dread, when she encountered that monk of San Spirito who had been her
22089: godfather’s confessor. From him she learned the full story of
22090: Savonarola’s arrest, and of her husband’s death. This Augustinian monk
22091: had been in the stream of people who had followed the waggon with its
22092: awful burthen into the Piazza, and he could tell her what was generally
22093: known in Florence—that Tito had escaped from an assaulting mob by
22094: leaping into the Arno, but had been murdered on the bank by an old man
22095: who had long had an enmity against him. But Romola understood the
22096: catastrophe as no one else did. Of Savonarola the monk told her, in
22097: that tone of unfavourable prejudice which was usual in the Black
22098: Brethren (Frati Neri) towards the brother who showed white under his
22099: black, that he had confessed himself a deceiver of the people.
22100: 
22101: Romola paused no longer. That evening she was in Florence, sitting in
22102: agitated silence under the exclamations of joy and wailing, mingled
22103: with exuberant narrative, which were poured into her ears by Monna
22104: Brigida, who had backslided into false hair in Romola’s absence, but
22105: now drew it off again and declared she would not mind being grey, if
22106: her dear child would stay with her.
22107: 
22108: Romola was too deeply moved by the main events which she had known
22109: before coming to Florence, to be wrought upon by the doubtful gossiping
22110: details added in Brigida’s narrative. The tragedy of her husband’s
22111: death, of Fra Girolamo’s confession of duplicity under the coercion of
22112: torture, left her hardly any power of apprehending minor circumstances.
22113: All the mental activity she could exert under that load of awe-stricken
22114: grief, was absorbed by two purposes which must supersede every other;
22115: to try and see Savonarola, and to learn what had become of Tessa and
22116: the children.
22117: 
22118: “Tell me, cousin,” she said abruptly, when Monna Brigida’s tongue had
22119: run quite away from troubles into projects of Romola’s living with her,
22120: “has anything been seen or said since Tito’s death of a young woman
22121: with two little children?”
22122: 
22123: Brigida started, rounded her eyes, and lifted up her hands.
22124: 
22125: “Cristo! no. What! was he so bad as that, my poor child? Ah, then, that
22126: was why you went away, and left me word only that you went of your own
22127: free will. Well, well; if I’d known that, I shouldn’t have thought you
22128: so strange and flighty. For I did say to myself, though I didn’t tell
22129: anybody else, ‘What was she to go away from her husband for, leaving
22130: him to mischief, only because they cut poor Bernardo’s head off? She’s
22131: got her father’s temper,’ I said, ‘that’s what it is.’ Well, well;
22132: never scold me, child: Bardo _was_ fierce, you can’t deny it. But if
22133: you had only told me the truth, that there was a young hussey and
22134: children, I should have understood it all. Anything seen or said of
22135: her? No; and the less the better. They say enough of ill about him
22136: without that. But since that was the reason you went—”
22137: 
22138: “No, dear cousin,” said Romola, interrupting her earnestly, “pray do
22139: not talk so. I wish above all things to find that young woman and her
22140: children, and to take care of them. They are quite helpless. Say
22141: nothing against it; that is the thing I shall do first of all.”
22142: 
22143: “Well,” said Monna Brigida, shrugging her shoulders and lowering her
22144: voice with an air of puzzled discomfiture, “if that’s being a Piagnone,
22145: I’ve been taking peas for paternosters. Why, Fra Girolamo said as good
22146: as that widows ought not to marry again. Step in at the door and it’s a
22147: sin and a shame, it seems; but come down the chimney and you’re
22148: welcome. _Two_ children—Santiddio!”
22149: 
22150: “Cousin, the poor thing has done no conscious wrong: she is ignorant of
22151: everything. I will tell you—but not now.”
22152: 
22153: Early the next morning Romola’s steps were directed to the house beyond
22154: San Ambrogio where she had once found Tessa; but it was as she had
22155: feared: Tessa was gone. Romola conjectured that Tito had sent her away
22156: beforehand to some spot where he had intended to join her, for she did
22157: not believe that he would willingly part with those children. It was a
22158: painful conjecture, because, if Tessa were out of Florence, there was
22159: hardly a chance of finding her, and Romola pictured the childish
22160: creature waiting and waiting at some wayside spot in wondering,
22161: helpless misery. Those who lived near could tell her nothing except
22162: that old deaf Lisa had gone away a week ago with her goods, but no one
22163: knew where Tessa had gone. Romola saw no further active search open to
22164: her; for she had no knowledge that could serve as a starting-point for
22165: inquiry, and not only her innate reserve but a more noble sensitiveness
22166: made her shrink from assuming an attitude of generosity in the eyes of
22167: others by publishing Tessa’s relation to Tito, along with her own
22168: desire to find her. Many days passed in anxious inaction. Even under
22169: strong solicitation from other thoughts Romola found her heart
22170: palpitating if she caught sight of a pair of round brown legs, or of a
22171: short woman in the contadina dress.
22172: 
22173: She never for a moment told herself that it was heroism or exalted
22174: charity in her to seek these beings; she needed something that she was
22175: bound specially to care for; she yearned to clasp the children and to
22176: make them love her. This at least would be some sweet result, for
22177: others as well as herself, from all her past sorrow. It appeared there
22178: was much property of Tito’s to which she had a claim; but she
22179: distrusted the cleanness of that money, and she had determined to make
22180: it all over to the State, except so much as was equal to the price of
22181: her father’s library. This would be enough for the modest support of
22182: Tessa and the children. But Monna Brigida threw such planning into the
22183: background by clamorously insisting that Romola must live with her and
22184: never forsake her till she had seen her safe in Paradise—else why had
22185: she persuaded her to turn Piagnone?—and if Romola wanted to rear other
22186: people’s children, she, Monna Brigida, must rear them too. Only they
22187: must be found first.
22188: 
22189: Romola felt the full force of that innuendo. But strong feeling
22190: unsatisfied is never without its superstition, either of hope or
22191: despair. Romola’s was the superstition of hope: _somehow_ she was to
22192: find that mother and the children. And at last another direction for
22193: active inquiry suggested itself. She learned that Tito had provided
22194: horses and mules to await him in San Gallo; he was therefore going to
22195: leave Florence by the gate of San Gallo, and she determined, though
22196: without much confidence in the issue, to try and ascertain from the
22197: gatekeepers if they had observed any one corresponding to the
22198: description of Tessa with her children, to have passed the gates before
22199: the morning of the ninth of April. Walking along the Via San Gallo, and
22200: looking watchfully about her through her long widow’s veil, lest she
22201: should miss any object that might aid her, she descried Bratti
22202: chaffering with a customer. That roaming man, she thought, might aid
22203: her: she would not mind talking of Tessa to _him_. But as she put aside
22204: her veil and crossed the street towards him, she saw something hanging
22205: from the corner of his basket which made her heart leap with a much
22206: stronger hope.
22207: 
22208: “Bratti, my friend,” she said abruptly, “where did you get that
22209: necklace?”
22210: 
22211: “Your servant, madonna,” said Bratti, looking round at her very
22212: deliberately, his mind not being subject to surprise. “It’s a necklace
22213: worth money, but I shall get little by it, for my heart’s too tender
22214: for a trader’s; I have promised to keep it in pledge.”
22215: 
22216: “Pray tell me where you got it;—from a little woman named Tessa, is it
22217: not true?”
22218: 
22219: “Ah! if you know her,” said Bratti, “and would redeem it of me at a
22220: small profit, and give it her again, you’d be doing a charity, for she
22221: cried at parting with it—you’d have thought she was running into a
22222: brook. It’s a small profit I’ll charge you. You shall have it for a
22223: florin, for I don’t like to be hard-hearted.”
22224: 
22225: “Where is she?” said Romola, giving him the money, and unclasping the
22226: necklace from the basket in joyful agitation.
22227: 
22228: “Outside the gate there, at the other end of the Borgo, at old Sibilla
22229: Manetti’s: anybody will tell you which is the house.”
22230: 
22231: Romola went along with winged feet, blessing that incident of the
22232: Carnival which had made her learn by heart the appearance of this
22233: necklace. Soon she was at the house she sought. The young woman and the
22234: children were in the inner room—were to have been fetched away a
22235: fortnight ago and more—had no money, only their clothes, to pay a poor
22236: widow with for their food and lodging. But since madonna knew them—
22237: Romola waited to hear no more, but opened the door.
22238: 
22239: Tessa was seated on the low bed: her crying had passed into tearless
22240: sobs, and she was looking with sad blank eyes at the two children, who
22241: were playing in an opposite corner—Lillo covering his head with his
22242: skirt and roaring at Ninna to frighten her, then peeping out again to
22243: see how she bore it. The door was a little behind Tessa, and she did
22244: not turn round when it opened, thinking it was only the old woman:
22245: expectation was no longer alive. Romola had thrown aside her veil and
22246: paused a moment, holding the necklace in sight. Then she said, in that
22247: pure voice that used to cheer her father—
22248: 
22249: “Tessa!”
22250: 
22251: Tessa started to her feet and looked round.
22252: 
22253: “See,” said Romola, clasping the beads on Tessa’s neck, “God has sent
22254: me to you again.”
22255: 
22256: The poor thing screamed and sobbed, and clung to the arms that fastened
22257: the necklace. She could not speak. The two children came from their
22258: corner, laid hold of their mother’s skirts, and looked up with wide
22259: eyes at Romola.
22260: 
22261: That day they all went home to Monna Brigida’s, in the Borgo degli
22262: Albizzi. Romola had made known to Tessa, by gentle degrees, that Naldo
22263: could never come to her again: not because he was cruel, but because he
22264: was dead.
22265: 
22266: “But be comforted, my Tessa,” said Romola. “I am come to take care of
22267: you always. And we have got Lillo and Ninna.”
22268: 
22269: Monna Brigida’s mouth twitched in the struggle between her awe of
22270: Romola and the desire to speak unseasonably.
22271: 
22272: “Let be, for the present,” she thought; “but it seems to me a thousand
22273: years till I tell this little contadina, who seems not to know how many
22274: fingers she’s got on her hand, who Romola is. And I _will_ tell her
22275: some day, else she’ll never know her place. It’s all very well for
22276: Romola;—nobody will call their souls their own when she’s by; but if
22277: I’m to have this puss-faced minx living in my house she must be humble
22278: to me.”
22279: 
22280: However, Monna Brigida wanted to give the children too many sweets for
22281: their supper, and confessed to Romola, the last thing before going to
22282: bed, that it would be a shame not to take care of such cherubs.
22283: 
22284: “But you must give up to me a little, Romola, about their eating, and
22285: those things. For you have never had a baby, and I had twins, only they
22286: died as soon as they were born.”
22287: 
22288: 
22289: 
22290: 
22291: CHAPTER LXXI.
22292: The Confession.
22293: 
22294: 
22295: When Romola brought home Tessa and the children, April was already near
22296: its close, and the other great anxiety on her mind had been wrought to
22297: its highest pitch by the publication in print of Fra Girolamo’s Trial,
22298: or rather of the confessions drawn from him by the sixteen Florentine
22299: citizens commissioned to interrogate him. The appearance of this
22300: document, issued by order of the Signoria, had called forth such strong
22301: expressions of public suspicion and discontent, that severe measures
22302: were immediately taken for recalling it. Of course there were copies
22303: accidentally mislaid, and a second edition, _not_ by order of the
22304: Signoria, was soon in the hands of eager readers.
22305: 
22306: Romola, who began to despair of ever speaking with Fra Girolamo, read
22307: this evidence again and again, desiring to judge it by some clearer
22308: light than the contradictory impressions that were taking the form of
22309: assertions in the mouths of both partisans and enemies.
22310: 
22311: In the more devout followers of Savonarola his want of constancy under
22312: torture, and his retraction of prophetic claims, had produced a
22313: consternation too profound to be at once displaced as it ultimately was
22314: by the suspicion, which soon grew into a positive datum, that any
22315: reported words of his which were in inexplicable contradiction to their
22316: faith in him, had not come from the lips of the prophet, but from the
22317: falsifying pen of Ser Ceccone, that notary of evil repute, who had made
22318: the digest of the examination. But there were obvious facts that at
22319: once threw discredit on the printed document. Was not the list of
22320: sixteen examiners half made up of the prophet’s bitterest enemies? Was
22321: not the notorious Dolfo Spini one of the new Eight prematurely elected,
22322: in order to load the dice against a man whose ruin had been determined
22323: on by the party in power? It was but a murder with slow formalities
22324: that was being transacted in the Old Palace. The Signoria had resolved
22325: to drive a good bargain with the Pope and the Duke of Milan, by
22326: extinguishing the man who was as great a molestation to vicious
22327: citizens and greedy foreign tyrants as to a corrupt clergy. The Frate
22328: had been doomed beforehand, and the only question that was pretended to
22329: exist now was, whether the Republic, in return for a permission to lay
22330: a tax on ecclesiastical property, should deliver him alive into the
22331: hands of the Pope, or whether the Pope should further concede to the
22332: Republic what its dignity demanded—the privilege of hanging and burning
22333: its own prophet on its own piazza.
22334: 
22335: Who, under such circumstances, would give full credit to this so-called
22336: confession? If the Frate had denied his prophetic gift, the denial had
22337: only been wrenched from him by the agony of torture—agony that, in his
22338: sensitive frame, must quickly produce raving. What if these wicked
22339: examiners declared that he had only had the torture of the rope and
22340: pulley thrice, and only on one day, and that his confessions had been
22341: made when he was under no bodily coercion—was that to be believed? He
22342: had been tortured much more; he had been tortured in proportion to the
22343: distress his confessions had created in the hearts of those who loved
22344: him.
22345: 
22346: Other friends of Savonarola, who were less ardent partisans, did not
22347: doubt the substantial genuineness of the confession, however it might
22348: have been coloured by the transpositions and additions of the notary;
22349: but they argued indignantly that there was nothing which could warrant
22350: a condemnation to death, or even to grave punishment. It must be clear
22351: to all impartial men that if this examination represented the only
22352: evidence against the Frate, he would die, not for any crime, but
22353: because he had made himself inconvenient to the Pope, to the rapacious
22354: Italian States that wanted to dismember their Tuscan neighbour, and to
22355: those unworthy citizens who sought to gratify their private ambition in
22356: opposition to the common weal.
22357: 
22358: Not a shadow of political crime had been proved against him. Not one
22359: stain had been detected on his private conduct: his fellow-monks,
22360: including one who had formerly been his secretary for several years,
22361: and who, with more than the average culture of his companions, had a
22362: disposition to criticise Fra Girolamo’s rule as Prior, bore testimony,
22363: even after the shock of his retraction, to an unimpeachable purity and
22364: consistency in his life, which had commanded their unsuspecting
22365: veneration. The Pope himself had not been able to raise a charge of
22366: heresy against the Frate, except on the ground of disobedience to a
22367: mandate, and disregard of the sentence of excommunication. It was
22368: difficult to justify that breach of discipline by argument, but there
22369: was a moral insurgence in the minds of grave men against the Court of
22370: Rome, which tended to confound the theoretic distinction between the
22371: Church and churchmen, and to lighten the scandal of disobedience.
22372: 
22373: Men of ordinary morality and public spirit felt that the triumph of the
22374: Frate’s enemies was really the triumph of gross licence. And keen
22375: Florentines like Soderini and Piero Guicciardini may well have had an
22376: angry smile on their lips at a severity which dispensed with all law in
22377: order to hang and burn a man in whom the seductions of a public career
22378: had warped the strictness of his veracity; may well have remarked that
22379: if the Frate had mixed a much deeper fraud with a zeal and ability less
22380: inconvenient to high personages, the fraud would have been regarded as
22381: an excellent oil for ecclesiastical and political wheels.
22382: 
22383: Nevertheless such shrewd men were forced to admit that, however poor a
22384: figure the Florentine government made in its clumsy pretence of a
22385: judicial warrant for what had in fact been predetermined as an act of
22386: policy, the measures of the Pope against Savonarola were necessary
22387: measures of self-defence. Not to try and rid himself of a man who
22388: wanted to stir up the Powers of Europe to summon a General Council and
22389: depose him, would have been adding ineptitude to iniquity. There was no
22390: denying that towards Alexander the Sixth Savonarola was a rebel, and,
22391: what was much more, a dangerous rebel. Florence had heard him say, and
22392: had well understood what he meant, that he would not _obey the devil_.
22393: It was inevitably a life and death struggle between the Frate and the
22394: Pope; but it was less inevitable that Florence should make itself the
22395: Pope’s executioner.
22396: 
22397: Romola’s ears were filled in this way with the suggestions of a faith
22398: still ardent under its wounds, and the suggestions of worldly
22399: discernment, judging things according to a very moderate standard of
22400: what is possible to human nature. She could be satisfied with neither.
22401: She brought to her long meditations over that printed document many
22402: painful observations, registered more or less consciously through the
22403: years of her discipleship, which whispered a presentiment that
22404: Savonarola’s retraction of his prophetic claims was not merely a
22405: spasmodic effort to escape from torture. But, on the other hand, her
22406: soul cried out for some explanation of his lapses which would make it
22407: still possible for her to believe that the main striving of his life
22408: had been pure and grand. The recent memory of the selfish discontent
22409: which had come over her like a blighting wind along with the loss of
22410: her trust in the man who had been for her an incarnation of the highest
22411: motives, had produced a reaction which is known to many as a sort of
22412: faith that has sprung up to them out of the very depths of their
22413: despair. It was impossible, she said now, that the negative
22414: disbelieving thoughts which had made her soul arid of all good, could
22415: be founded in the truth of things: impossible that it had not been a
22416: living spirit, and no hollow pretence, which had once breathed in the
22417: Frate’s words, and kindled a new life in her. Whatever falsehood there
22418: had been in him, had been a fall and not a purpose; a gradual
22419: entanglement in which he struggled, not a contrivance encouraged by
22420: success.
22421: 
22422: Looking at the printed confessions, she saw many sentences which bore
22423: the stamp of bungling fabrication: they had that emphasis and
22424: repetition in self-accusation which none but very low hypocrites use to
22425: their fellow-men. But the fact that these sentences were in striking
22426: opposition, not only to the character of Savonarola, but also to the
22427: general tone of the confessions, strengthened the impression that the
22428: rest of the text represented in the main what had really fallen from
22429: his lips. Hardly a word was dishonourable to him except what turned on
22430: his prophetic annunciations. He was unvarying in his statement of the
22431: ends he had pursued for Florence, the Church, and the world; and, apart
22432: from the mixture of falsity in that claim to special inspiration by
22433: which he sought to gain hold of men’s minds, there was no admission of
22434: having used unworthy means. Even in this confession, and without
22435: expurgation of the notary’s malign phrases, Fra Girolamo shone forth as
22436: a man who had sought his own glory indeed, but sought it by labouring
22437: for the very highest end—the moral welfare of men—not by vague
22438: exhortations, but by striving to turn beliefs into energies that would
22439: work in all the details of life.
22440: 
22441: “Everything that I have done,” said one memorable passage, which may
22442: perhaps have had its erasures and interpolations, “I have done with the
22443: design of being for ever famous in the present and in future ages; and
22444: that I might win credit in Florence; and that nothing of great import
22445: should be done without my sanction. And when I had thus established my
22446: position in Florence, I had it in my mind to do great things in Italy
22447: and beyond Italy, by means of those chief personages with whom I had
22448: contracted friendship and consulted on high matters, such as this of
22449: the General Council. And in proportion as my first efforts succeeded, I
22450: should have adopted further measures. Above all, when the General
22451: Council had once been brought about, I intended to rouse the princes of
22452: Christendom, and especially those beyond the borders of Italy, to
22453: subdue the infidels. It was not much in my thoughts to get myself made
22454: a Cardinal or Pope, for when I should have achieved the work I had in
22455: view, I should, without being Pope, have been the first man in the
22456: world in the authority I should have possessed, and the reverence that
22457: would have been paid me. If I had been made Pope, I would not have
22458: refused the office: but it seemed to me that to be the head of that
22459: work was a greater thing than to be Pope, because a man without virtue
22460: may be Pope; but _such a work as I contemplated demanded a man of
22461: excellent virtues_.”
22462: 
22463: That blending of ambition with belief in the supremacy of goodness made
22464: no new tone to Romola, who had been used to hear it in the voice that
22465: rang through the Duomo. It was the habit of Savonarola’s mind to
22466: conceive great things, and to feel that he was the man to do them.
22467: Iniquity should be brought low; the cause of justice, purity, and love
22468: should triumph; and it should triumph by his voice, by his work, by his
22469: blood. In moments of ecstatic contemplation, doubtless, the sense of
22470: self melted in the sense of the Unspeakable, and in that part of his
22471: experience lay the elements of genuine self-abasement; but in the
22472: presence of his fellow-men for whom he was to act, pre-eminence seemed
22473: a necessary condition of his life.
22474: 
22475: And perhaps this confession, even when it described a doubleness that
22476: was conscious and deliberate, really implied no more than that wavering
22477: of belief concerning his own impressions and motives which most human
22478: beings who have not a stupid inflexibility of self-confidence must be
22479: liable to under a marked change of external conditions. In a life where
22480: the experience was so tumultuously mixed as it must have been in the
22481: Frate’s, what a possibility was opened for a change of self-judgment,
22482: when, instead of eyes that venerated and knees that knelt, instead of a
22483: great work on its way to accomplishment, and in its prosperity stamping
22484: the agent as a chosen instrument, there came the hooting and the
22485: spitting and the curses of the crowd; and then the hard faces of
22486: enemies made judges; and then the horrible torture, and with the
22487: torture the irrepressible cry, “It is true, what you would have me say:
22488: let me go: do not torture me again: yes, yes, I am guilty. O God! Thy
22489: stroke has reached me!”
22490: 
22491: As Romola thought of the anguish that must have followed the
22492: confession—whether, in the subsequent solitude of the prison,
22493: conscience retracted or confirmed the self-taxing words—that anguish
22494: seemed to be pressing on her own heart and urging the slow bitter
22495: tears. Every vulgar self-ignorant person in Florence was glibly
22496: pronouncing on this man’s demerits, while _he_ was knowing a depth of
22497: sorrow which can only be known to the soul that has loved and sought
22498: the most perfect thing, and beholds itself fallen.
22499: 
22500: She had not then seen—what she saw afterwards—the evidence of the
22501: Frate’s mental state after he had had thus to lay his mouth in the
22502: dust. As the days went by, the reports of new unpublished examinations,
22503: eliciting no change of confessions, ceased; Savonarola was left alone
22504: in his prison and allowed pen and ink for a while, that, if he liked,
22505: he might use his poor bruised and strained right arm to write with. He
22506: wrote; but what he wrote was no vindication of his innocence, no
22507: protest against the proceedings used towards him: it was a continued
22508: colloquy with that divine purity with which he sought complete reunion;
22509: it was the outpouring of self-abasement; it was one long cry for inward
22510: renovation. No lingering echoes of the old vehement self-assertion,
22511: “Look at my work, for it is good, and those who set their faces against
22512: it are the children of the devil!” The voice of Sadness tells him, “God
22513: placed thee in the midst of the people even as if thou hadst been one
22514: of the excellent. In this way thou hast taught others, and hast failed
22515: to learn thyself. Thou hast cured others: and thou thyself hast been
22516: still diseased. Thy heart was lifted up at the beauty of thy own deeds,
22517: and through this thou hast lost thy wisdom and art become, and shalt be
22518: to all eternity, nothing... After so many benefits with which God has
22519: honoured thee, thou art fallen into the depths of the sea; and after so
22520: many gifts bestowed on thee, thou, by thy pride and vainglory, hast
22521: scandalised all the world.” And when Hope speaks and argues that the
22522: divine love has not forsaken him, it says nothing now of a great work
22523: to be done, but only says, “Thou art not forsaken, else why is thy
22524: heart bowed in penitence? That too is a gift.”
22525: 
22526: There is no jot of worthy evidence that from the time of his
22527: imprisonment to the supreme moment, Savonarola thought or spoke of
22528: himself as a martyr. The idea of martyrdom had been to him a passion
22529: dividing the dream of the future with the triumph of beholding his work
22530: achieved. And now, in place of both, had come a resignation which he
22531: called by no glorifying name.
22532: 
22533: _But therefore he may the more fitly be called a martyr by his
22534: fellow-men to all time_. For power rose against him not because of his
22535: sins, but because of his greatness—not because he sought to deceive the
22536: world, but because he sought to make it noble. And through that
22537: greatness of his he endured a double agony: not only the reviling, and
22538: the torture, and the death-throe, but the agony of sinking from the
22539: vision of glorious achievement into that deep shadow where he could
22540: only say, “I count as nothing: darkness encompasses me: yet the light I
22541: saw was the true light.”
22542: 
22543: 
22544: 
22545: 
22546: CHAPTER LXXII.
22547: The Last Silence.
22548: 
22549: 
22550: Romola had seemed to hear, as if they had been a cry, the words
22551: repeated to her by many lips—the words uttered by Savonarola when he
22552: took leave of those brethren of San Marco who had come to witness his
22553: signature of the confession: “Pray for me, for God has withdrawn from
22554: me the spirit of prophecy.”
22555: 
22556: Those words had shaken her with new doubts as to the mode in which he
22557: looked back at the past in moments of complete self-possession. And the
22558: doubts were strengthened by more piteous things still, which soon
22559: reached her ears.
22560: 
22561: The nineteenth of May had come, and by that day’s sunshine there had
22562: entered into Florence the two Papal Commissaries, charged with the
22563: completion of Savonarola’s trial. They entered amid the acclamations of
22564: the people, calling for the death of the Frate. For now the popular cry
22565: was, “It is the Frate’s deception that has brought on all our
22566: misfortunes; let him be burned, and all things right will be done, and
22567: our evils will cease.”
22568: 
22569: The next day it is well certified that there was fresh and fresh
22570: torture of the shattered sensitive frame; and now, at the first sight
22571: of the horrible implements, Savonarola, in convulsed agitation, fell on
22572: his knees, and in brief passionate words _retracted his confession_,
22573: declared that he had spoken falsely in denying his prophetic gift, and
22574: that if he suffered, he would suffer for the truth—“The things that I
22575: have spoken, I had them from God.”
22576: 
22577: But not the less the torture was laid upon him, and when he was under
22578: it he was asked why he had uttered those retracting words. Men were not
22579: demons in those days, and yet nothing but concessions of guilt were
22580: held a reason for release from torture. The answer came: “I said it
22581: that I might seem good; tear me no more, I will tell you the truth.”
22582: 
22583: There were Florentine assessors at this new trial, and those words of
22584: twofold retraction had soon spread. They filled Romola with dismayed
22585: uncertainty.
22586: 
22587: “But,”—it flashed across her—“there will come a moment when he may
22588: speak. When there is no dread hanging over him but the dread of
22589: falsehood, when they have brought him into the presence of death, when
22590: he is lifted above the people, and looks on them for the last time,
22591: they cannot hinder him from speaking a last decisive word. I will be
22592: there.”
22593: 
22594: Three days after, on the 23rd of May 1498, there was again a long
22595: narrow platform stretching across the great piazza, from the Palazzo
22596: Vecchio towards the Tetta de’ Pisani. But there was no grove of fuel as
22597: before: instead of that, there was one great heap of fuel placed on the
22598: circular area which made the termination of the long narrow platform.
22599: And above this heap of fuel rose a gibbet with three halters on it; a
22600: gibbet which, having two arms, still looked so much like a cross as to
22601: make some beholders uncomfortable, though one arm had been truncated to
22602: avoid the resemblance.
22603: 
22604: On the marble terrace of the Palazzo were three tribunals; one near the
22605: door for the Bishop, who was to perform the ceremony of degradation on
22606: Fra Girolamo and the two brethren who were to suffer as his followers
22607: and accomplices; another for the Papal Commissaries, who were to
22608: pronounce them heretics and schismatics, and deliver them over to the
22609: secular arm; and a third, close to Marzocco, at the corner of the
22610: terrace where the platform began, for the Gonfaloniere, and the Eight
22611: who were to pronounce the sentence of death.
22612: 
22613: Again the Piazza was thronged with expectant faces: again there was to
22614: be a great fire kindled. In the majority of the crowd that pressed
22615: around the gibbet the expectation was that of ferocious hatred, or of
22616: mere hard curiosity to behold a barbarous sight. But there were still
22617: many spectators on the wide pavement, on the roofs, and at the windows,
22618: who, in the midst of their bitter grief and their own endurance of
22619: insult as hypocritical Piagnoni, were not without a lingering hope,
22620: even at this eleventh hour, that God would interpose, by some sign, to
22621: manifest their beloved prophet as His servant. And there were yet more
22622: who looked forward with trembling eagerness, as Romola did, to that
22623: final moment when Savonarola might say, “O people, I was innocent of
22624: deceit.”
22625: 
22626: Romola was at a window on the north side of the Piazza, far away from
22627: the marble terrace where the tribunals stood; and near her, also
22628: looking on in painful doubt concerning the man who had won his early
22629: reverence, was a young Florentine of two-and-twenty, named Jacopo
22630: Nardi, afterwards to deserve honour as one of the very few who, feeling
22631: Fra Girolamo’s eminence, have written about him with the simple desire
22632: to be veracious. He had said to Romola, with respectful gentleness,
22633: when he saw the struggle in her between her shuddering horror of the
22634: scene and her yearning to witness what might happen in the last moment—
22635: 
22636: “Madonna, there is no need for you to look at these cruel things. I
22637: will tell you when he comes out of the Palazzo. Trust to me; I know
22638: what you would see.”
22639: 
22640: Romola covered her face, but the hootings that seemed to make the
22641: hideous scene still visible could not be shut out. At last her arm was
22642: touched, and she heard the words, “He comes.” She looked towards the
22643: Palace, and could see Savonarola led out in his Dominican garb; could
22644: see him standing before the Bishop, and being stripped of the black
22645: mantle, the white scapulary and long white tunic, till he stood in a
22646: close woollen under-tunic, that told of no sacred office, no rank. He
22647: had been degraded, and cut off from the Church Militant.
22648: 
22649: The baser part of the multitude delight in degradations, apart from any
22650: hatred; it is the satire they best understand. There was a fresh hoot
22651: of triumph as the three degraded brethren passed on to the tribunal of
22652: the Papal Commissaries, who were to pronounce them schismatics and
22653: heretics. Did not the prophet look like a schismatic and heretic now?
22654: It is easy to believe in the damnable state of a man who stands
22655: stripped and degraded.
22656: 
22657: Then the third tribunal was passed—that of the Florentine officials who
22658: were to pronounce sentence, and amongst whom, even at her distance,
22659: Romola could discern the odious figure of Dolfo Spini, indued in the
22660: grave black lucco, as one of the Eight.
22661: 
22662: Then the three figures, in their close white raiment, trod their way
22663: along the platform, amidst yells and grating tones of insult.
22664: 
22665: “Cover your eyes, Madonna,” said Jacopo Nardi; “Fra Girolamo will be
22666: the last.”
22667: 
22668: It was not long before she had to uncover them again. Savonarola was
22669: there. He was not far off her now. He had mounted the steps; she could
22670: see him look round on the multitude.
22671: 
22672: But in the same moment expectation died, and she only saw what he was
22673: seeing—torches waving to kindle the fuel beneath his dead body, faces
22674: glaring with a yet worse light; she only heard what _he_ was
22675: hearing—gross jests, taunts, and curses.
22676: 
22677: The moment was past. Her face was covered again, and she only knew that
22678: Savonarola’s voice had passed into eternal silence.
22679: 
22680: 
22681: 
22682: 
22683: Epilogue.
22684: 
22685: 
22686: On the evening of the 22nd of May 1509, five persons, of whose history
22687: we have known something, were seated in a handsome upper room opening
22688: on to a loggia which, at its right-hand corner, looked all along the
22689: Borgo Pinti, and over the city gate towards Fiesole and the solemn
22690: heights beyond it.
22691: 
22692: At one end of the room was an archway opening into a narrow inner room,
22693: hardly more than a recess, where the light fell from above on a small
22694: altar covered with fair white linen. Over the altar was a picture,
22695: discernible at the distance where the little party sat only as the
22696: small full-length portrait of a Dominican Brother. For it was shaded
22697: from the light above by overhanging branches and wreaths of flowers,
22698: and the fresh tapers below it were unlit. But it seemed that the
22699: decoration of the altar and its recess was not complete. For part of
22700: the floor was strewn with a confusion of flowers and green boughs, and
22701: among them sat a delicate blue-eyed girl of thirteen, tossing her long
22702: light-brown hair out of her eyes, as she made selections for the
22703: wreaths she was weaving, or looked up at her mother’s work in the same
22704: kind, and told her how to do it with a little air of instruction.
22705: 
22706: For that mother was not very clever at weaving flowers or at any other
22707: work. Tessa’s fingers had not become more adroit with the years—only
22708: very much fatter. She got on slowly and turned her head about a good
22709: deal, and asked Ninna’s opinion with much deference; for Tessa never
22710: ceased to be astonished at the wisdom of her children. She still wore
22711: her contadina gown: it was only broader than the old one; and there was
22712: the silver pin in her rough curly brown hair, and round her neck the
22713: memorable necklace, with a red cord under it, that ended mysteriously
22714: in her bosom. Her rounded face wore even a more perfect look of
22715: childish content than in her younger days: everybody was so good in the
22716: world, Tessa thought; even Monna Brigida never found fault with her
22717: now, and did little else than sleep, which was an amiable practice in
22718: everybody, and one that Tessa liked for herself.
22719: 
22720: Monna Brigida was asleep at this moment, in a straight-backed
22721: arm-chair, a couple of yards off. Her hair, parting backward under her
22722: black hood, had that soft whiteness which is not like snow or anything
22723: else, but is simply the lovely whiteness of aged hair. Her chin had
22724: sunk on her bosom, and her hands rested on the elbow of her chair. She
22725: had not been weaving flowers or doing anything else: she had only been
22726: looking on as usual, and as usual had fallen asleep.
22727: 
22728: The other two figures were seated farther off, at the wide doorway that
22729: opened on to the loggia. Lillo sat on the ground with his back against
22730: the angle of the door-post, and his long legs stretched out, while he
22731: held a large book open on his knee, and occasionally made a dash with
22732: his hand at an inquisitive fly, with an air of interest stronger than
22733: that excited by the finely-printed copy of Petrarch which he kept open
22734: at one place, as if he were learning something by heart.
22735: 
22736: Romola sat nearly opposite Lillo, but she was not observing him. Her
22737: hands were crossed on her lap and her eyes were fixed absently on the
22738: distant mountains: she was evidently unconscious of anything around
22739: her. An eager life had left its marks upon her: the finely-moulded
22740: cheek had sunk a little, the golden crown was less massive; but there
22741: was a placidity in Romola’s face which had never belonged to it in
22742: youth. It is but once that we can know our worst sorrows, and Romola
22743: had known them while life was new.
22744: 
22745: Absorbed in this way, she was not at first aware that Lillo had ceased
22746: to look at his book, and was watching her with a slightly impatient
22747: air, which meant that he wanted to talk to her, but was not quite sure
22748: whether she would like that entertainment just now. But persevering
22749: looks make themselves felt at last. Romola did presently turn away her
22750: eyes from the distance and met Lillo’s impatient dark gaze with a
22751: brighter and brighter smile. He shuffled along the floor, still keeping
22752: the book on his lap, till he got close to her and lodged his chin on
22753: her knee.
22754: 
22755: “What is it, Lillo?” said Romola, pulling his hair back from his brow.
22756: Lillo was a handsome lad, but his features were turning out to be more
22757: massive and less regular than his father’s. The blood of the Tuscan
22758: peasant was in his veins.
22759: 
22760: “Mamma. Romola, what am I to be?” he said, well contented that there
22761: was a prospect of talking till it would be too late to con “Spirto
22762: gentil” any longer.
22763: 
22764: “What should you like to be, Lillo? You might be a scholar. My father
22765: was a scholar, you know, and taught me a great deal. That is the reason
22766: why I can teach you.”
22767: 
22768: “Yes,” said Lillo, rather hesitatingly. “But he is old and blind in the
22769: picture. Did he get a great deal of glory?”
22770: 
22771: “Not much, Lillo. The world was not always very kind to him, and he saw
22772: meaner men than himself put into higher places, because they could
22773: flatter and say what was false. And then his dear son thought it right
22774: to leave him and become a monk; and after that, my father, being blind
22775: and lonely, felt unable to do the things that would have made his
22776: learning of greater use to men, so that he might still have lived in
22777: his works after he was in his grave.”
22778: 
22779: “I should not like that sort of life,” said Lillo. “I should like to be
22780: something that would make me a great man, and very happy
22781: besides—something that would not hinder me from having a good deal of
22782: pleasure.”
22783: 
22784: “That is not easy, my Lillo. It is only a poor sort of happiness that
22785: could ever come by caring very much about our own narrow pleasures. We
22786: can only have the highest happiness, such as goes along with being a
22787: great man, by having wide thoughts, and much feeling for the rest of
22788: the world as well as ourselves; and this sort of happiness often brings
22789: so much pain with it, that we can only tell it from pain by its being
22790: what we would choose before everything else, because our souls see it
22791: is good. There are so many things wrong and difficult in the world,
22792: that no man can be great—he can hardly keep himself from
22793: wickedness—unless he gives up thinking much about pleasure or rewards,
22794: and gets strength to endure what is hard and painful. My father had the
22795: greatness that belongs to integrity; he chose poverty and obscurity
22796: rather than falsehood. And there was Fra Girolamo—you know why I keep
22797: to-morrow sacred: _he_ had the greatness which belongs to a life spent
22798: in struggling against powerful wrong, and in trying to raise men to the
22799: highest deeds they are capable of. And so, my Lillo, if you mean to act
22800: nobly and seek to know the best things God has put within reach of men,
22801: you must learn to fix your mind on that end, and not on what will
22802: happen to you because of it. And remember, if you were to choose
22803: something lower, and make it the rule of your life to seek your own
22804: pleasure and escape from what is disagreeable, calamity might come just
22805: the same; and it would be calamity falling on a base mind, which, is
22806: the one form of sorrow that has no balm in it, and that may well make a
22807: man say, ‘It would have been better for me if I had never been born.’ I
22808: will tell you something, Lillo.”
22809: 
22810: Romola paused for a moment. She had taken Lillo’s cheeks between her
22811: hands, and his young eyes were meeting hers.
22812: 
22813: “There was a man to whom I was very near, so that I could see a great
22814: deal of his life, who made almost every one fond of him, for he was
22815: young, and clever, and beautiful, and his manners to all were gentle
22816: and kind. I believe, when I first knew him, he never thought of
22817: anything cruel or base. But because he tried to slip away from
22818: everything that was unpleasant, and cared for nothing else so much as
22819: his own safety, he came at last to commit some of the basest deeds—such
22820: as make men infamous. He denied his father, and left him to misery; he
22821: betrayed every trust that was reposed in him, that he might keep
22822: himself safe and get rich and prosperous. Yet calamity overtook him.”
22823: 
22824: Again Romola paused. Her voice was unsteady, and Lillo was looking up
22825: at her with awed wonder.
22826: 
22827: “Another time, my Lillo—I will tell you another time. See, there are
22828: our old Piero di Cosimo and Nello coming up the Borgo Pinti, bringing
22829: us their flowers. Let us go and wave our hands to them, that they may
22830: know we see them.”
22831: 
22832: “How queer old Piero is!” said Lillo as they stood at the corner of the
22833: loggia, watching the advancing figures. “He abuses you for dressing the
22834: altar, and thinking so much of Fra Girolamo, and yet he brings you the
22835: flowers.”
22836: 
22837: “Never mind,” said Romola. “There are many good people who did not love
22838: Fra Girolamo. Perhaps I should never have learned to love him if he had
22839: not helped me when I was in great need.”
